column3: the rappers on New York-based indie label Def Jux conducted odd science experiments on hip-hop
column4: making restless
column5: lyrically knotty records that pushed the art form towards new extremes of obliqueness. One of the label’s earliest and most beloved releases was The Cold Vein
column6: the debut LP from Cannibal Ox
column7: a duo made up of two Harlem rappers with names like Transformers characters (Vast Aire and Vordul Mega). The group’s sound was vaguely familiar
column8: with clear roots in Wu-Tang
column9: Gravediggaz and Kool Keith
column10: but it was distinguished by moments of sharp surrealism
column11: linguistic deconstructions
column12: and a deep underlying sadness. Def Jux co-founder and producer El-P’s beats enhanced the unfamiliarity of the landscape
column13: traversing a no-man’s-land between the dusty swing of boom-bap and glitchy electronica.

column1: In the decade and a half since the release of The Cold Vein
column2: Cannibal Ox have released only a few songs together. They fell out with El-P
column3: cut their ties at Def Jux
column4: and mostly receded from view. Following a string of one-off reunions on Vast’s solo albums
column5: the two rappers have been crying wolf about a new full-length for the last few years. It’s arrived
column6: by way of their own Iron Galaxy Records
column7: in the form of the sprawling 19-track collection Blade of the Ronin. In some ways
column8: the album resembles its predecessor. Both are distinctly overwhelming sets of songs—collections of dense verses strung between equally verbose refrains—backed by hazy samples
column9: damaged synth insulation and chunky breakbeats. But Ronin feels ponderous and self-conscious in a way that is at odds with the unfettered creative spirit of their first effort.

column1: Though this album
column2: too
column3: is full of offbeat and athletic bars—clearly
column4: the work of the same guys—the familiar soothsayer mysticism often feels like it’s been laid on too thick
column5: or just misplaced. After all
column6: Ox’s most far-flung moments on The Cold Vein got their mileage from meaningful framing
column7: with often-heartbreaking autobiographical imagery serving as the catapult into the rappers’ pan-religious parables and comic book fan fiction. Just as Bastian imagines The Neverending Story while reading alone and hiding from bullies
column8: the young versions of Vast and Mega dream up alternate realities after ""stealing Marvel comics and water uzis"" and decamping from the action on their block. But on Ronin
column9: we’re usually trapped in their diorama
column10: getting only a few glimpses of its inspiration.

column1: The handful of powerful connections to the outside world are made mostly by Vordul Mega
column2: the group’s more reticent half. On ""Harlem Knights""
column3: for instance
column4: Mega spends one of the album’s economically sketched verses describing concrete images of a misspent
column5: grief-punctuated childhood. He steals the Black Milk-produced ""Gotham (Ox City)"" with his opening couplet—""We stay in shape like Porsches on blocks/ Where women is gorgeous and kids stay strapped like Bugs Bunny Jordans""—before the song detours toward less inspiring talk of ""New York Gritty"" and Clayface.

column1: It seems strange that Can Ox’s new work would run dry on the white-knuckled realism which was once so important to them
column2: but the shortage becomes clear after dozens of verses padded out with half-cogent
column3: free-associative rambling and clunky insult humor. Vast Aire’s contributions are often fun and always inimitable—it would be hard to imagine almost any other rapper selling ""You will never see the vipers when they come out the sand/ You will never see the cobra head
column4: as it expands"" before ""I change my skin like Zartan"". However
column5: his lines of thinking quickly veer in cringeworthy (""These girls is like Frankenstein/ They got fake hair
column6: fake nails and monster behinds"")
column7: superfluous (""You gotta say my name backwards like Mxyzptlk/ Hold up
column8: did I mention/ I like to fight imps from the fifth dimension"") or lazy directions (""My kids are rough
column9: they eat iron candy/ My girl's tough
column10: she wears iron panties/ I was born in an iron galaxy"").

column1: The album is also impeded by its uniform
column2: relentlessly bleak production. Producer Bill Cosmiq paints his synth pads and samples on thick
column3: creating muffled washes of midrange sound. The snares thud rather than pop
column4: ringing out as if from a bunker to which everyone in New York has flocked to prepare for the end of days. There are moments of resourceful coloration and melody: see
column5: for instance
column6: the high
column7: mournful vocal sample on ""The Power Cosmiq"" or the tack piano melody and orchestral flourishes on ""Salvation"". But whereas El’s beats on The Cold Vein were aberrant in their very syntax—full of disconcerting rhythmic faultlines
column8: eerie melodic hooks and a sense of space—the curiosities  in Cosmiq’s work feel tacked on and vestigial.

column1: There’s no doubt that Blade of the Ronin is the work of two very particular and oversized personalities
column2: but the album does not feel like either a blast of fresh air or a return to form after wayward solo careers. Where The Cold Vein felt like an alien object dropped to Earth
column3: Ronin arrives in 2015 sounding a bit commonplace. That’s not totally Can Ox’s fault: By now
column4: indie rap of this sort has become a recognizable subgenre in the wake of so many DOOM alteregos
column5: Anticon releases and a continuing stream of Internet-celebrated underground rappers with absurd or psychedelic tendencies. But unfortunately Vast and Mega’s work here does not serve to remind us of the superiority of the genuine article
column6: or work to resensitize us. Like a new Paranormal Activity movie
column7: a greasy-spoon diner cheeseburger or the last Warhol screen print at the museum
column8: it will be worth its weight for hardcore fans who appreciate alterations to a template. But even those who decided years ago that this album was going to be great will be hard-pressed to find a great rap record here
column9:
only a sporadically enjoyable one.

The video for Young Guv’s ""Crushing Sensation"" plays like a failed Rocky montage. Inspired by the images of athletes posted around his apartment
column2: singer Ben Cook rolls out of bed
column3: throws on some sweats
column4: and hits the streets. His heart’s not in it
column5: though: He attempts some pull ups and listlessly swipes at a punching bag
column6: but mostly he putters around the city
column7: kicking snow
column8: smoking cigarettes
column9:
and staring at nothing in particular.
 
That same noncommittal attitude has carried through Cook’s many bands outside of his primary gig playing guitar for Fucked Up. He’s bounced from one flash collaboration or side project to another—among them Marvelous Darlings
column10: the Bitters
column11: Roommates
column12: and Yacht Club—leaving a trail of demo tapes and 7-inches but never devoting himself to any act for the long haul. Some of those bands flamed out before they could realize their potential
column13: others were probably never intended to have much of a shelf life
column14: but each inched Cook ever so slightly away from messy punk and toward the tuneful comforts of power-pop
column15: the jumping-off point for his full-length debut as Young Guv
column16: Ripe 4 Luv. Tying some of the loose ends from his previous projects
column17: though never too neatly
column18: it’s Cook’s cleanest
column19: most easygoing release yet
column20:
and far and away his catchiest.

Like every album released by Slumberland Records since its 2006 resurrection
column21: Ripe 4 Luv is versed in the shimmery indie-pop of the label’s heyday years. But Cook is too restless to limit himself to any single musical tradition
column22: so Ripe 4 Luv also detours into soft-rock slow jams
column24: and Prince’s hormonal R&B-pop. The title track is straight out of Dirty Mind
column25: all bubblegum guitar and funk strut
column26: while ""Aquarian"" sets its 10cc-style pillow talk against a mechanically cool
column27:
Sade-esque groove.

Cook has the songwriting chops to pull off all these styles. He’s ghostwritten for such unlikely big names as Taylor Swift
column30: so he’s never been as bound by punk orthodoxy as his years in the Canadian hardcore scene suggested. And unlike many indie acts that have moonlighted with soft rock and R&B over the last half decade—Blood Orange on Cupid Deluxe; Destroyer on Kaputt; Gayngs with Relayted—Cook isn’t too concerned with nailing the nuances of these genres. Instead
column32: mines it for a quick hook
column33: then moves on. He’s just not the type of musician who’s going to dedicate the effort required for a sustained
column35:
especially when the gist will suffice.

Ripe 4 Luv is relentlessly sunny throughout its 33-minute run
column36: though Cook can’t resist letting a little skeeziness in here and there. Behind its ringing guitars and Alex Chilton harmonies
column38: I’m Not a Creep"" disguises an unnerving portrait of an inter-apartment building stalker. The seven-minute closer ""Wrong Crowd""
column40: stretches Young Guv’s throwback soft rock to the point of sleazy parody. The joke grows stale even before some Showtime After Dark saxophone arrives to close out the song. It’s the album’s only bum track
column41: but thankfully it’s tucked at the end
column42: and it doesn’t sour what came before it. Throughout Ripe 4 Luv you can sense that it’s taking every ounce of discipline Cook has to play these pop songs as straight as he does
column43:
so he can be forgiven for indulging a little kitsch at the finish line.

As long as it took for Brendan Angelides to find a scene to work in
column2: it's taken nearly as long for him to sound comfortable in it. With a discography stretching back to the late '90s and a string of high-profile stopovers on some of the key destinations for abstract bass music—Planet Mu
column3: Ninja Tune
column4: Warp—Eskmo's career itself has been more enduring than any individual record he's put out. As someone who sounds more at ease testing his ideas than sticking with and building off a formula
column5: he hasn't had the chance to define himself with a signature style.

column1: Not that he hasn't had some highlights: 2003's Ascension and its glitched-up d'n'b
column2: the sun-drenched prog-dubstep of '09 single ""Hypercolor""
column3: and his oddly idyllic take on electro-house on 2012's Language made a career of constant digressions worth following. He may have tripped over his own ambitions a couple times
column4: but at least something like 2010's self-titled exercise in jumbled bass pile-ups couldn't be called complacent—or definitive
column5: for that matter. With his more recent work paring back the gloss and bloat of big-statement Eskmo
column6: a turn to more open-spaced
column7: modern-classical influenced compositions feels like a solid decision.

column1: Angelides' ear for nuanced ambience comes to the forefront on SOL
column2: an album inspired by the sun and his work with the Los Angeles composer collective Echo Society. Slow builds and minimal beats emerge into warm presences
column3: even if the droning compositions do more to insinuate moods than induce them. Spending enough time with the opening one-two of the Burial-interlude-style ""SpVce"" and the slow-motion monolith of ""Combustion"" will do a lot to distract from the actual dearth of kicks and snares on this record. The midpoint peak
column4: an eleven-minute stretch incorporating the tracks ""Sol"" and ""The Light of One Thousand Furnaces""
column5: lets the drones and bass thrums sink in until they sound like chamber strings
column6: building to the one big moment of intense
column7: cathartic percussion on the record.

column1: SOL has less gravity when it steers away from its majestic solar themes and tries to put its abstract sensations into words. Eskmo's vocals
column2: while delicate
column3: still feel intrusive. The mannered
column4: show-offy crooning about ""morning mist and firefly dust"" over ""Blue and Grey"" and the vague
column5: Mattel-Peter Gabriel cheapness of  ""Mind of War"" break the mood
column6:
putting the focus more on an (not especially engaging) individual voice than the feeling of bigger-than-all-of-us cosmic heat the record's best moments invoke. At least it's just one of dozens of voices he's worked with over the years—he'll find plenty more before it's all said and done.

On her first record as Yowler
column2: Maryn Jones stares down all the water she can find. It comes in the usual forms—oceans
column3: river
column4: rain—and the ones we don't consider as often
column5: like tears and spit and nicks of blood. Jones
column6: known for her work at the front of All Dogs and with Saintseneca
column7: uses The Offer to hunt down form inside a looming infinity. She hungers for the human shapes that break up the drones of time
column8: space
column9: and sea.

column1: Jones' dark guitar and gently creased voice form most of the album on their own
column2: but her songs don't feel restricted to a single person. They spill out of themselves
column3: flow into each other
column4: and cohere into a whole
column5: like circuits in a system. When synthesizers or drums or extra voices seep in
column6: they show up as naturally as weather. Jones might be alone
column7: but there are no seams between her and her atmosphere.

column1: There is a song called ""Yowler"" on The Offer
column2: a name that resists convention—you don't name your project after a song or vice versa unless you're trying to make a point. Here
column3: it fits; on the chorus
column4: Jones sings
column5: ""Your hands look just like mine."" She's looking across at another human body
column6: amazed at the mirror image she finds
column7: disturbed by the strange kinship. Hands are dense
column8: complex machines
column9: and yet you can hold your own up to someone else's
column10: and most of the time
column11: they'll match. On Soundcloud
column12: the track appears as ""Yowler :: Yowler"". The mirror is there before you hear the song.

column1: Jones reveals a love of language just in the way she bends it. She chooses and pronounces her words carefully. She'll invert cliches: ""You can lead me to the water but you cannot make me drink
column2: she sings on ""Yowler"". A chorus of low voices swarms her
column3: like a mob about to dunk her in the river
column4: or a hand guiding her away from the bank. ""You will not be avoided/ 'Cause your ghost is haunting me.""

column1: She sings about drowning on ""Holidays""
column2: only she calls it gestating. She imagines her body floating beneath a sheet of ice
column3: and she uses a word intended to describe new life. Is there hope in that image
column4: in the idea that dissolving into death is its own kind of birth? ""If I return my body to the running black dark... will it be me? Will I see me?"" Jones wonders. Does the person break apart when the body does
column5: or is there a different shape you can't see?

column1: ""I am nothing/ I am but a shape
column2: Jones sings on ""Water"". Those two lines seem to contradict each other
column3: and she spends The Offer negotiating the tension between them. The album is a deep
column4: sad comfort
column5: more complex than it first appears
column6:
like a pond frozen over and still writhing with life.

Even if a band includes specific instructions on how to listen to its music
column2: is there ever a ""correct"" way to hear anything? Of course
column3: there are better methods for listening to certain music. You’d hate to experience the majesty of Wagner’s Ring Cycle
column4: for instance
column5: by playing scuffed records on a Crosley Cruiser turntable
column6: and it would be a waste to dump a fortune into an ostentatious hi-fi system if all you really want to do is blast Mayhem’s De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas. But most music and music players fall somewhere in between
column7: so that the differences we experience are rather incremental. Maybe a good record sounds great with a certain setup
column8: but it should still have some payoff even through a pair of tiny white earbuds.

column1: Mysteries—the third album by the elusive
column2: prolific Portuguese one-man black metal band Black Cilice—highlights the question of how best to hear by suggesting that there are at least two distinct and acceptable answers. Given the subgenre
column3: you might think that it would be best to simply turn it up
column4: and let it roar. And
column5: yes
column6: at high volumes
column7: where the guitars can shriek and the agitated drums can pound
column8: Mysteries is a monster.

column1: But you can also turn Mysteries way down
column2: until those barreling drums recede into a heavy patter and the guitars blur into the record’s presiding distortion and feedback. It becomes a patterned sheet of sound then
column3: where bits and pieces protrude from a singular din. Because they were so poorly recorded
column4: early black metal records sometimes sounded like drone music: The instruments overwhelmed the devices meant to capture them. But Black Cilice take that aesthetic a step further
column5: deploying the technique selectively so that strident guitars
column6: bruised drums and yowled vocals move under and above that matrix
column7: as if they’re alternating between floating and drowning.

column1: Black Cilice don’t reinvent quarter-century-old black metal structures; they just lash at them
column2: playing hard
column3: fast
column4: loud and mean. ""Ceremonial Energy"" bursts forward
column5: a rising-and-falling blast beat and back-and-forth riff suggesting vintage Darkthrone. ""Into Morbid Trance"" bounds between primitive thrash and menacing black metal
column6: where every instrument seems to be attempting to force its counterparts out of the picture. The vocals suggest gale-force winds passing though a room of live microphones and amplifiers
column7: creating feedback only to harmonize with it.

column1: There’s finesse to this mess
column2: as though Black Cilice were trying to tease the border between heavy metal and experimental music. Turned up
column3: for instance
column4: ""The Truth"" is a pugnacious stomp-along; turned down
column5: it feels strangely warm and beautiful. It suggests Rhys Chatham’s music for massed guitars
column6: where so many instruments were played at once that it became impossible to tell where one ended and another began
column7: or a reprise of Alvin Lucier’s I Am Sitting in a Room
column8: where the first-person subject is actually a roughshod recording of a black metal band.

column1: This conceit may seem ridiculous
column2: both for the suggestion that you should lower the volume on a black metal record in order to enjoy it more and for the implication that Black Cilice is some avant-garde wizard with grander intentions than badly recorded bedlam. But to date
column3: each Black Cilice record has gotten more controlled and nuanced; the metal tantrums beneath the noise are more complicated and compelling
column4: and the hiss and squall above it all are more engrossing and interesting. There is an arc of progress to trace in Black Cilice’s output
column5: suggesting that the diametric results of putting Mysteries in the background or foreground are more than mere coincidence.

column1: The cover of each Black Cilice full-length has been all black
column2: save for a centered
column3: shrouded figure wearing corpsepaint and doing something wicked. On 2011’s <i>A Corpse
column4: A Temple
column5: <a href=""http://www.metal-archives.com/images/3/2/3/7/323785.jpg?1841"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">he reached skyward
column6: holding a volume bearing an inverted crucifix. On Mysteries
column7: he grimaces as he again looks upward and touches his stomach. For the last three months
column8: I’ve tried to figure out if he’s clutching a rosary to his chest or if he’s pressing against a gushing abdomen wound. The high-contrast image makes it impossible to tell
column9: at least to me and everyone I’ve asked. However willful or accidental
column10: such ambiguity epitomizes the aesthetic of Black Cilice
column11:
a strange transmission responsible for one of the most intriguing intersections of black metal and sound art I’ve ever heard.

Matthew E. White is a devoted Stevie Wonder disciple
column2: and also a devoted do-it-yourselfer. Accordingly
column3: the aesthetic for his Spacebomb record label and studio is “DIY” in the ‘70s auteur sense
column4: not in the punk-rock sense. In interviews
column5: the Richmond
column6: Virginia-based jazz studies alum often name-checks the likes of Marvin Gaye and Randy Newman. ""There's not some punk-rock version of Stevie Wonder
column7: White told Grantland. ""Stevie Wonder is deep music
column8: on a lot of levels.""

column1: White’s first album under his own name
column2: 2012's Big Inner
column3: contemplated Big Ideas — love
column4: death
column5: God — in an opulent setting of analog-era soul and down-home psychedelia
column6: brimming with horns and strings. Recent Spacebomb projects
column7: including the radiant 2015 self-titled debut of former Jenny Lewis backing singer Natalie Prass
column8: have followed suit. Fresh Blood
column9: White's sophomore album
column10: mostly stays true to the house style
column11: improving on Big Inner in some ways
column12: falling short in others
column13: but never less than fully engaged in the notion of music as a higher ground.

column1: A highlight on Big Inner was ""Will You Love Me""
column2: a Jimmy Cliff-quoting slow-burner that gracefully balanced intimacy and studio craft. Fresh Blood refines this mix of cozy and majestic
column3: with tracks spiraling out from just Fender Rhodes piano and hushed vocal to luxuriant codas replete with backup singers and ingeniously unfurling instrumental counterpoint. From the canopy of vibrant harmonies on ""Fruit Trees"" to the earthy guitar licks of ""Golden Robes""
column4: the music feels both familiar and resplendent. White's mellow
column5: M. Ward-like coo
column6: occasionally patchy on Big Inner
column7: is honeyed and smooth here.

column1: Lyrically
column2: he builds on the themes of his debut and 2013's Outer Face EP.  The stormy ""Holy Moly"" echoes a line from the EP's ""Eyes Like the Rest""
column3: about the perils of hope
column4: before building to its mantra: ""Fuck 'em all
column5: love is home
column6: home is love
column7: love is all."" (According to NPR
column8: the song is inspired by sexual abuse in the church
column9: though you wouldn't necessarily know it.) Opener ""Take Care My Baby” reiterates some words about the human touch from the EP's ""Hot Hot Hot"".

column1: White’s view of love and music remains decidedly spiritual: Big Inner’s finale
column2: ""Brazos""
column3: for instance
column4: climaxed in a stirring but ambivalent gospel chant of ""Jesus Christ is our Lord
column5: Jesus Christ
column6: He is your friend"". White relies on religious language much less here: When he calls upon Jesus on Fresh Blood's ""Circle 'Round the Sun""
column7: it's of a piece with the same song's use of the Dylan-evoking phrase ""shelter from the storm.""

column1: At times
column2: White’s knack for simplicity lapses into the slightly generic. On ""Take Care My Baby""
column3: he confides
column4: ""I never met another one like you before/ Talking all night long/ From the midnight on
column5: and I mostly want to know what they were up so late talking about. A similar case is ""Feeling Good Is Good Enough""
column6: which begins a compelling story about a couple who ""didn't make it"" rekindling their flame by going home together for the night
column7: but ends with fairly rote ""Hey Jude""-like repetitions.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: White overreaches slightly. The poetic
column3: dissonance-streaked hymn ""Tranquility"" was written as a tribute to Philip Seymour Hoffman
column4: but it's forbiddingly cryptic. And White's wry rock crit on first single ""Rock & Roll Is Cold"" creates an interesting tension with the song's spacey euphoria—think Spiritualized vamping the Velvet Underground's ""I'm Waiting for the Man""—but never quite coheres. Sure
column5: the power of music is mysterious
column6: but when you to try to sort out why his narrator specifically defines rock'n'roll as ""cold""
column7: R&B as ""free""
column8: and gospel as a ""gift""
column9: or ponder how those categories might overlap… well
column10: the power of music is mysterious.

column1: Those are small criticisms
column2: though
column3: and if you focus on the sumptuous sound of Fresh Blood they become easier to overlook. White addresses his musical ancestors directly on closer ""Love Is Deep""
column4: asking
column5: ""Ain't it so
column6: Marvin?/ Ain't it so
column7: Stevland?"" Gaye and Wonder (whom White pointedly addresses by his birth name) alike would probably affirm his argument —that ""love is deep shit
column8: ""sweet shit."" It's not the deepest point
column9:
but White's musical chops ensure it's generally convincing.

Oren Ambarchi is usually described as a guitarist but before 1998's Stacte
column2: his solo debut
column3: he was a drummer. And if early records like Suspension or Reconnaissance
column4: with Martin Ng
column5: tended to fixate on liquid oscillations and eyedropper drones

column7: from 2012's Audience of One

column9: and the recently released Live Knots

column1: At first

column4: and luminous tonal elements on the other. The music is aglow with streaks of feedback
column5: molten oscillators
column6: rubbed wineglass rims
column7: and even the occasional struck or held note. With music this abstracted
column8: this gradual
column9: small gestures count for a lot

column11: played several measures apart
column12: come to seem like a major theme. And while there are no melodies
column13: per se
column14: the way filament-like phrases flare up in the murk is nevertheless lyrical. Somewhere in the mix

column17: trembling movements
column18: even when the music is comparatively still. There are drones like the buzz of airplanes high overhead and a forest's canopy worth of synthetic birdcalls. Beneath the crystal-faceted edges of the sound

column1: What most separates Behold from Indeed is the new album's strong sense of groove
column2: with Ambarchi carving deep patterns with ride cymbals and hi-hats and ultra-low
column3: chest-caving kick drums. It feels like motorik distilled to its very essence

column5: the drums come and go. For most of ""Behold A""
column6: there's nothing more than a hint of cymbal tapped out in rolling
column7: quarter-note pulses; for long stretches
column8: there's not even that. Like an underground stream returning to the surface
column9: the rippling metal pulse returns midway through ""Behold B"" and gradually gathers strength
column10: rising in concert with squalls of guitar feedback and contrapuntal piano. After a long
column11: slow climb
column12: it's a quick climax; the beat dies
column13: and the remaining sounds go sailing out into the abyss
column14: like water over a cliff. But it's the rhythm that stays with you

column1: Behold is the kind of music where
column2: depending upon the angle from which you approach it

column6:
toggling between distracted reverie and close attention.

Swervedriver inhabit a funny spot within the pantheon of classic shoegazer bands. They were always slightly out of step with their 90’s Creation-era peers
column2: most of whom appeared content to disappear behind a veil of tastefully shimmering feedback and lyrical obtuseness. Swervedriver
column3: on the other hand
column4: were more interested in ripping. Their guitars may have fed back through the requisite number of effects pedals—classic Swervedriver tshirts actually featured a connected bank of effects pedals rather than the band members—but rather than shrink into the feedback
column5: Swervedriver married their guitar haze with nods to poppy psychedelia
column6: American film noir
column7: and songs about fast cars. They had more in common with bands like Dinosaur Jr. and Soundgarden (with whom they toured) than the more ethereal English bands (Ride
column8: Lush
column9: My Bloody Valentine) with whom they were forever lumped. Despite releasing four excellent records between 1991 and 1998
column10: Swervedriver—plagued by label woes
column11: lineup shifts
column12: and bad timing—somehow never quite got their due.

column1: Now
column2: some 17 years since their last effort
column3: (1998’s 99th Dream)
column4: Swervedriver return with a record that wisely plays up to the band’s most formidable strengths. Reunion albums can be a tricky and sometimes disastrous business (just ask the Pixies)
column5: but I Wasn’t Born To Lose You manages the rare trick of actually enhancing the band’s legacy rather than tarnishing it. Hewing most closely to their most beloved releases (1991’s Raise and 1993’s Mezcal Head)
column6: Born is a remarkably unfussy collection of songs that could easily pass—for better or worse—as a kind of lost album from the early 90’s.

column1: Swervedriver’s strength always stemmed from the melodic interplay of guitarists Adam Franklin and Jimmy Hartridge—a collaboration that
column2: at its best
column3: felt like watching a rocket take off at close range and having it subsequently blow up in your face. It’s hard not to use firework metaphors when describing the band’s music
column4: which seems to function best as a series of blinding explosions and brilliant fade-outs. Tracks like “Last Rites” and “Everso” are not-so-distant cousins to the band’s early “Sandblasted”-era singles—overdriven riffs reign supreme and songs build with mantra-like power before collapsing into long passages of looping
column5: blissed-out guitar lines. Lead single “Setting Sun” proves to be an accurate barometer of the record’s overall vibe—a sustained mid-tempo reverie pushed along by Franklin’s characteristically low-key vocals: “Pure solid gold
column6: you’re not alone
column7: hearing unseen sounds from the depths below…”

column1: If there’s a complaint to be had with I Wasn’t Born To Lose You it’s that the record too often errs on the side of restraint. The furious
column2: breakneck quality of classic Swervedriver tracks like ""Son of Mustang Ford” and “For Seeking Heat” is largely absent here
column3: eschewed in favor of tracks that aspire to a kind of majestic dreaminess. With the exception of the propulsive “Deep Wound” and scuzz-rocking “Red Queen Arms Race” the record plays like a kind of sustained trance
column4: everything buoyed by a sense of unwavering melody wrung out of guitars that—even when played gently—always seem to be turned up past eleven. “Behold this rhythmic creation
column5: it’s beautiful and true” Franklin sings on “I Wonder?”—a nearly six-minute bit of gorgeously rendered guitar squall that closes the album. It’s a fitting description for the record itself—a collection of songs that may not necessarily venture into any new sonic territory for the venerable band
column6:
but ultimately doesn’t really need to.

If you’re a newer band playing a classic form of metal
column2: you need to be concerned with songwriting. With such a strong history behind you
column3: putting together songs worth playing twice is more important than preserving vibes. Philadelphia doom quintet Crypt Sermon prove they’ve got plenty of songwriting mettle on their debut album

column5: they pay fervent tribute to early Candlemass and Dio-era Black Sabbath
column6: and already show more personality than many bands who’ve been trying to do this sound for a much longer time.

column1: Interestingly

column3: Candlemass’ first album from 1986. ""Temple Doors"" is Garden’s ""Solitude""
column4: a lumbering stomp with a slight thrash bent. ""Doors""'s opening interlude isn’t as iconic as ""please let me die in solituuuuuuuude
column5: but it sets the song’s tone. ""Heavy Riders"" boasts similarities to ""Demons Gate"" in that they’re both the meaner
column6: more confident second tracks. What sets ""Riders"" apart is its biker-like swagger
column7: American toughness to contrast their European influences’ more Gothic sensibilities. After a moodier opening track
column8: you need a ripper like ""Riders"" to get momentum going
column9: and it succeeds
column10: with guitarists Steve Jansson and James Lipczynski conjuring up Black Sabbath ""Neon Knights"" rhythms. ""Byzantium"" takes pages from Metallicus's ""Crystal Ball""
column11: especially in the high-tension
column12: high-drama opening leads. While they only last for the introduction
column13: they color the rest of the song
column14: with Jansson and Lipczynski’s trod carrying a more ominous weight. This shift is how subtlety best manifests itself in metal: not by deliberate understating
column15: but by smart songwriting that keeps the album’s vibe intact while giving each song its own character.

column1: The rest of the album doesn’t bear a whole lot of similarities to Metallicus
column2: but it’s a fun coincidence
column3: and the rest of the songs are well worth your attention. While ""Doors"" explored the contrast of their slow burns and galloping infernos
column4: it really comes into form in ""Into the Holy of Holies""
column5: with everyone delivering more charged performances. It’s the longest song on the record
column6: and not concidently
column7: their most ambitious. ""The Master’s Bouquet"" features gorgeous lead work that closes out the song: triumphant
column8: but alluding to a pyrrhic victory. Underlying synths further score the sadness that lays beneath
column9: but with knowledge that the leads are the star. Vocalist Brooks Wilson doesn’t have the dramatic flair of a Dio or a Messiah Marcolin
column10: and if there were a time we needed an ultra-charismatic metal frontman it’d be now
column11: but he’s got impressive pipes nonetheless. (Wilson handled bass in addition to vocals on the band’s demo but ceded the role to Hivelords’ Will Mellor to fully concentrate on singing
column12: which will hopefully become more of a positive development.)

column1: As far as contemporaries
column2: Crypt Sermon’s closest relative would be Solitude Aeturnus
column3: the Arlington
column4: Texas band usually considered to be the American answer to Candlemass. (Vocalist Robert Lowe even sang for Candlemass for a few years.) They’ve never gotten their due
column5: but also haven’t had a blazing trail to seize upon; one can only hope Crypt Sermon won’t face that curse. Garden is a debut most bands would light candles to Dio for
column6: and with time
column7:
this band could be a true contender in doom.

Following the explosive success of viral hits “U Guessed It” and “FuckEmx3”
column2: Atlanta’s OG Maco quickly emerged as a poster child for rabble rouser rap.  Much of the early coverage pegged Maco’s booming
column3: guttural chant music as hardcore rap
column4: but in truth “U Guessed It” felt more like an out-of-body experience
column5: or the product of a single drunken rage session
column6: than any calculated attempt at moshpit-starting.  In the months since his breakout
column7: fueled primarily by overdubbing his music on popular Vine clips
column8: the most visible signee to Quality Control Music has been trying to live his biggest success down
column9: releasing a slew of mixtapes and EPs more in line with the aspect of his sound that didn’t catch on
column10: which is more concerned with atmospherics and hooks delivered in a subdued
column11: Auto-Tuned croon.

column1: Maco’s latest EP
column3: comes just over a month after the release of a joint project with alt rap migrant Rome Fortune
column4: Yep. That
column5: in turn
column6: came on the heels of a three-track EP called Breathe. All told
column7: Maco’s released about seven projects in seven months
column8: the bulk of which is concerned with destroying the misconception of him as a one-trick pony while not alienating those who hopped on the bandwagon. 15 tries to kill two birds with one stone by grafting singsongy hooks onto synth-smashing raps. Maco anticipates you come for shout-raps but asks you stay for everything else
column9: and 15 is his latest bid to embrace his viral success without getting enveloped by it.

column1: Lost in attempts to find the right chemical balance for staying power is Maco’s own personality. He comes across as flat in 15’s one dimensional songwriting. The lyrics are often hollow regurgitations of frequently recycled ideas (See the half-baked sports motif of “Championships”: “Consistent Tom Brady
column2: rookie Russell Wilson/ I will go the distance
column3: win by feet
column4: not inches”). There is no depth of character. When he isn’t yelling
column5: it’s easier to tell he doesn’t have much to say. There isn’t a single mention of what makes him flawed or interesting. Instead it’s always about what he’s done
column6: what he’s doing
column7: and what he will do for the genre. OG Maco doesn’t seem to exist outside of his raps.

column1: Sometimes his energy makes up for it
column2: like on the strobing “Homies”
column3: but he’s just as prone to over-performing. He bulldozes through the productions of Metro Boomin and DJ Plugg and TM88 on “Legends” and “Mirror Mirror”
column4: respectively
column5: without giving them any breathing room. The former
column6: an eerie affair
column7: is particularly gorgeous
column8: but drowned out by Maco’s earnest howling chorus. Even as he learns to rein in the colossal bawls
column9: he is struggling to figure out just how to work around them.

column1: There are a handful of moments where OG Maco exposes his weirdness and becomes intriguing. He adds two contrasting full-length tunes in singsong
column2: the humming “Night Like This” and the warbling “Long Nights”
column3: and despite different affects both shroud him in dense waves of atmosphere. He proves himself a surprisingly capable technician on “The New Kid”. On the title track
column4: Maco worries that the clock may have started ticking on his career and it provides the only real glimpse into his thoughts. There’s some irony to a viral success worrying about his 15 minutes
column5:
but in pondering the time he has left Maco produces some of his most enlightening observations. It showcases what will keep him around when the shouts aren’t enough anymore: More introspective songwriting. There may be hope for him yet.

Though it can be hard recall amid the black tie arena shows
column2: papier-mâché puppetry
column3: and red carpet appearances that comprise their universe today
column4: Arcade Fire were once a highly volatile
column5: sometimes violent band. In their pre-Funeral genesis
column6: the group projected a startling intensity that often left their hands bloodied and bodies bruised; those motorcycle helmets you see in old concert photos weren’t so much costume props as necessary protective gear for a band prone to using their own heads as auxiliary drum kits. And in the middle of the melee you’d often find Will Butler
column7: younger brother of lead singer Win
column8: bearing the mischievous grin of a corrupted choir boy. As a utility-player multi-instrumentalist
column9: Will’s musical presence isn’t always easy to parse from Arcade Fire’s orchestro-rock onslaught. But onstage
column10: he’s the physical embodiment of the band’s music—deceptively mild-mannered
column11: yet capable of going off without warning. Not surprisingly

column1: Given that Arcade Fire’s last album
column2: 2013’s Reflektor
column3: boasted a rollout strategy more carefully plotted than most military operations
column4: Policy feels very much like an attempt to recapture some of the happy-accidental spontaneity that defined the band’s early years. Where most of Arcade Fire’s extracurricular pursuits—be it Richard Reed Parry’s Bell Orchestre

column7: Policy revels in the early rock'n'roll and punk influences that have become an increasingly obscured cornerstone of the band’s sound (think: ""(Antichrist Television Blues)""
column8: ""Month of May""
column9: or the sock-hop denouement of ""Wake Up""). Recorded at New York’s hallowed Electric Lady Studios
column10: this determinedly off-the-cuff album is nostalgic in sound
column11: but endearingly off-kilter in spirit.

column1: As a lead vocalist
column2: Will sounds exactly as you would expect—i.e.
column3: like Win Butler’s wiseacre little brother—and though he’s recently shown an interest in current events
column4: his lovelorn lyrical concerns here are several pounds less weighty than Arcade Fire’s conceptual statements about God and country. (When Jesus does enter the picture—via the folky
column5: Westerbergian power-pop of ""Son of God""—it’s merely to be gently blasphemed.) At its most inspired
column6: Policy resembles a screwball musical adaptation of John Lennon’s lost weekend. Rave-ups like ""Take My Side""
column7: ""What I Want""
column8: and ""Witness"" tumble out with infectiously inebriated energy
column9: their charging choruses teetering on the brink like runaway trains. The bacchanalia is compounded by sloppy piano stabs and knowingly cornball come-ons that would make Harry Nilsson flash a thumbs up while face down in puke. (To wit: ""If you come and take my hand/ I will buy you a pony/ We can cook it for supper/ I know a great recipe for pony macaroni."")

column1: As Butler recently explained to Pitchfork’s Evan Minsker
column2: Policy is intended to reflect his omnivorous musical taste
column3: but
column4: as the album rolls on
column5: the difference between cunning eclecticism and undercooked experimentalism grows stark. Policy's highlights maintain a precarious balance between classicism and cataclysm
column6: but the album often tips too far in either direction: the dirgey boombox disco of ""Something’s Coming"" and the cheap-sunglasses new wave of ""Anna"" suggest an alternate universe where Arcade Fire couldn’t afford James Murphy’s producer fee
column7: while ""Sing to Me"" and ""Finish What I Started"" are sullen piano ballads that Butler's restrained vocals can't invest with the necessary gravitas. ""Someone please
column8: finish what I started
column9: he sings on the latter song
column10: ""I tried my best
column11:
but my best was half-hearted."" It doubles as an uncomfortably on-the-nose diagnosis of the album itself.

Since their start as a live band in 2008
column4: Dick Diver have been golden calves of the Australian music press. Beginning with the 2009 debut EP Arks Up and the 2011 LP New Start Again
column5: they carved a national identity through songwriting in a way that'd been unfashionable enough to have virtually been forgotten. Attracting comparisons to Dunedin bands like the Clean—an alleged influence the band are quick to protest—their jangly
column6: working class rock inspired unlikely thinkpieces about new movements in Australian music towards reclaiming Australian-ness. Finally here was a band
column7: the thinking went
column8: that were proudly Australian without the conservative baggage
column9: and could articulate the lives of working class youth—even make it seem romantic—with elegant melodies and deft lyricism
column10: painting vibrant portraits of forlorn suburbs and tacit class warfare. This hefty burden culminated in 2013's <i>Calendar Days
column11: a record that
column12: in retrospect
column13: seems like their definitive collection.

column1: Consisting of primary songwriters Rupert Edwards and Al McKay on guitar
column2: and backed by Al Montfort (UV Race
column3: Total Control
column4: Straitjacket Nation) and Steph Hughes on bass and drums respectively
column5: Dick Diver face a burden in following such an auspicious release. But instead of trying for repeat glory
column6: on <i>Melbourne
column7: Florida
column8: they take a determined step forward.

column1: Dick Diver have always been skeptical
column2: if not cynical
column3: about their culture
column4: and there are signs they're becoming more scathing. True to life
column5: on <i>Melbourne
column6: Florida relationships are mediated by glass. Departed lovers are mourned in endlessly scrolling old emails and windows become the projection sheets of better-left-forgotten memories. On ""Beat Me Up (Talk to a Counsellor)""
column7: Al Montfort confronts the psychopathic condition of young males and on ""Competition""
column8: Rupert Edwards' targets seem mindless and obsessed with warped trappings of fame. This is tempered by the striking ""Boomer Class""
column9: which spits bile at the destruction of a family but is ultimately regretful that something so terrible should afflict people in the first place.

column1: In an interview last month
column2: Rupert Edwards said when Dick Diver start getting bad reviews
column3: he can finally buy an Xbox—that certainty in life after the band has given them the faith to look outwards. The buzzsaw synth on ""Competition"" might've seemed unimaginable on <i>Calendar Days
column4: and Al McKay's ""Waste the Alphabet"" is more bombastic and loud than the prettiness of previous songs would suggest. Steph Hughes' crystalline voice has only gotten stronger on the swelling ""Leftovers"" and piano ballad ""View from a Shakey Ladder"". The rich
column5: melody-stuffed jangle that scored them references to the Flying Nun catalogue has shipped off
column6: replaced by chugging verses and the tropes of FM radio rock
column7: the soundtrack to long drives down country roads.

column1: The novelty of domestic signifiers has also been shed. Sucked into the void go Zamel's ads and TV Weeks and tourist attractions in the shape of sacred desert rocks
column2: replaced by—as far as pop cult ephemera—Tonya Harding and Fleetwood Mac. But Melbourne
column3: Florida
column4: no matter the name
column5: is no pander to the great republic. There are still signposts of nationality
column6: only they're more subtle. ""Europe's fucked probably
column7: a blasé Edwards sings
column8: reflecting the cultural and geographical distance from the intercontinental headlines in a sick parody of those who see Europe as a theme park for backpacking. The fixation on everywhere but here
column9: if anything
column10: is even more Australian than the more obvious touchstones on previous records. On <i>Melbourne
column11: Florida
column12: the ghosts of civilisations haunt television screens that not that long ago were propaganda machines beaming the best of faraway cultures distilled into caricature through the lounge rooms of their corner of the Commonwealth.

column1: Dick Diver sound at peace on Melbourne
column2: Florida
column3: both certain of what they are now and certain that they could be almost anything in the future. Last year
column4: Edwards was afraid that Dick Diver risked a dangerous entrenchment with the connotations the band had accrued
column5: but this album breaks open new possibilities for them. Whether that's welcomed

column7: <i>Melbourne

column9:
and a solid entry point for new audiences.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21559/homepage_large.35c9db0d.jpg|Ultra-High Frequencies: The Chicago Party|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2015-03-06 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:00.106236|"

Although it eventually revolutionized club music when house bubbled up from the black gay underground in the mid-'80s
column2: Chicago couldn’t compete with Philadelphia
column3: New York
column4: or Miami when it came to disco. Aside from the city’s ballad-centric but occasionally fierce Chi-Lites and a few bandwagon-jumping old-timers like Gene Chandler
column5: Chicago’s major contribution to disco’s history was also a key event in its destruction: Shock jock Steve Dahl staged Comiskey Park’s Disco Demolition Night
column6: a baseball-promotion-turned-riot in the summer of 1979 often credited as the tipping point of the genre’s so-called death in the mainstream.

column1: But that doesn’t mean that Dahl convinced African Americans or any other minority to suddenly stop dancing. As lovingly and obsessively documented by Ultra High Frequencies
column2: the Windy City helped stoke some of disco’s funkiest
column3: most soulful flames. While DJ Frankie Knuckles mixed the ingredients for what would become house for a diverse crowd at the Warehouse
column4: an equally idiosyncratic scene went down at the straighter but still quirky CopHerBox II.

column1: Launched in 1979 by trombonist Willie Woods and aspiring singer James Christopher
column2: the publicity-hungry club hosted—along with assorted Miss CopHerBox pageants and Big Butt contests—its own TV program. Broadcast in 1982 on local UHF station WCIU
column3: the original host of ""Soul Train""
column4: ""The Chicago Party"" one-upped its famous competitor by not simply approximating a typical Saturday club evening: It documented exactly what went down on those nights at the CopHerBox for 23 episodes.

column1: Both the CD and double-vinyl editions of Ultra High Frequencies include a DVD featuring 23 musical performances
column2: a brief documentary on the scene
column3: and a 100-minute Chicago Party video mixtape. Between a swimsuit competition
column4: circus-type contortions by the Phantom
column5: James Brown-on-wheels splits via the Unknown Skater
column6: android dance moves from CopHerBox regulars modeling the wares of designer Caroline Peeples
column7: and the hosts’ own ""SNL""-inspired comedy hijinks
column8: the mixtape overflows with highly entertaining shots of uninhibited adult couples shaking what their mamas gave them.

column1: No doubt these dancers were boogying down to bigger names—acts like D-Train
column2: the Dazz Band
column3: Evelyn King
column4: Junior
column5: Skyy
column6: Shalamar
column7: and other disco-funk stars of 1982. But because this compilation comes from the Chi-Town obscurities-focused Numero Group
column8: their swiveling has been re-synced to vintage regional grooves
column9: most of them so indie that they likely wouldn’t have gotten spins even in their home city.

column1: One exception was Yvonne Gage
column2: whose smooth and sensual late '81 single ""Garden of Eve"" appeared on RFC Records
column3: a major label affiliate that generated numerous anthems for New York’s Paradise Garage. Another was Magnum Force
column4: a group that fused the sweaty bass-slapping stomps of Slave with the synth squiggles of the Time. They’re all over UHF: Their squishy slow jam ""Share My Love"" and brassy ""A Touch of Funk"" adorn the DVD
column5: while the most anxious and libidinous cut
column6: ""Girl You’re Too Cool""
column7: brightens the album. All three would’ve charmed R&B radio had their sole LP
column8: '82’s Share My Love
column9: received national promotion.

column1: Much of the rest lack their polish
column2: and the set’s most searing exceptions—male harmony quartet Closencounter’s violin-swept ""Without Your Love""
column3: a pair of gospel-soul wailers from the female foursome Chicago’s Finest—appear only on the DVD because they most likely never got past the demo stage. Despite what crate-diggers hungry for proto-house obscurities may claim
column4: disco was an emphatically hi-fi genre: A poorly recorded disc had to be otherwise good enough for most DJs to even temporarily compromise their equipment. ""The Chicago Party""’s low-budget local access charm enlivens the rawest tracks here
column5: like Universal Togetherness Band’s urgent but nearly tone-deaf ""Pull Up"". The set’s catchiest track is Donnell Pitman’s ""Love Explosion""—six-plus minutes of music originally squeezed onto a tinny private-press seven-inch single. It repurposes Ripple’s ""The Beat Goes On and On""
column6: a 1977 Salsoul Records disco classic
column7: via an overdubbed alternate male lead melody. Like the rest
column8: it’s hardly definitive
column9: but resourceful and resolutely spirited
column10: and the remastering here gives Pitman the sonic space he deserved.

column1: That familial energy lingers throughout. Hosts Woods and Christopher met while working for Model Cities
column2: a government program that aimed to fight poverty while fostering inner city renewal and minority leadership. Ultra High Frequencies affirms that it was this spirit of communities taking care of their own that the duo brought to both their club and TV show. Despite the polyester-funk-meets-futurist-punk details that date stamp some fashions
column3: most dancers are decked out in otherwise timeless
column4: church-friendly threads that suggest how the era’s club scene brought a sense of the sacred into the secular world. ""The Chicago Party"" may have been fun-loving
column5: even silly

but it serves as another fleeting example of disco’s ultimate spiritual purpose—elevation through togetherness.

The Black Ryder is a band out of time. It’s not just that their own music is heavily indebted to specific and identifiable sounds and eras from the past—that describes 95% of all bands working today. It’s more that their particular combination of influences has actually had several waves of revivalism
column2: so it’s hard to know which version they are drawing from. The band’s 2010 full-length debut
column3: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15110-buy-the-ticket-take-the-ride/""><i>Buy the Ticket
column4: Take the Ride
column5: was situated in a dreamy nu-Paisley Underground sphere that was
column6: at that moment
column7: quite fashionable. Mazzy Star had been gone for a long time
column8: and bands like Tamaryn
column9: Widowspeak
column10: and the Black Ryder were carrying their torch in different ways. The latter
column11: a band fronted by Australians Aimee Nash and Von Ryper (they’ve since relocated to Los Angeles)
column12: took the group’s languid ballads and reverbed mystery and scuffed it up with JAMC distortion
column13: and they showed a sure hand with the particulars even if the songs weren’t terribly memorable. For their ambitious follow-up
column14: The Door Behind the Door
column15: the Black Ryder burrow deeper
column16: directly engaging with the '60s and early-'70s sources that inspired it all.

column1: Inevitably
column2: that sort of engagement implies a certain grandiosity. You take a song like
column3: say
column4: the Rolling Stones’ ""Shine a Light""
column5: and you know it comes from an era when both the musicians and the audience were comfortable with the idea that rock stars should strive for something profound and sublime. For those playing rock music
column6: that sometimes meant tapping into the textures of black gospel
column7: specifically
column8: adding a chorus at just the right moment to take the rootsy earthiness of the musical form and send it to the heavens.

column1: Midway through The Door Behind the Door is a song called ""Throwing Stones""
column2: which begins with a strummed acoustic guitar playing a resigned refrain and then builds
column3: piece by piece
column4: to a climax where massed voices are singing ""Let your love shine on/ If you want to be free."" It’s almost shocking in its pompousness
column5: in part because the Black Ryder are
column6: after all
column7: a smaller independent band
column8: and you don’t expect them to be making gestures that presumably cost a certain amount of money to get right. But there is also something admirable about the initiatve
column9: that they are going for it to this degree.

column1: There are many details on The Door Behind the Door that the Black Ryder get right
column2: which
column3: with music like this
column4: is an accomplishment in itself. The moaning feedback drone in ""Seventh Moon"" has the gorgeousness of a Neil Halstead lead
column5: ""Let Me Be Your Light"" has a candy-kissed psychedelic swirl
column6: strings and all
column7: that serves as the perfect backdrop for Nash’s whispery vocals
column8: and ""Until the Calm of Dawn"" brings to mind the acid-fried Disneyfications of prime Mercury Rev
column9: with a twinkly music box set against a sweeping orchestral arrangement. The band loves the strings so much they close with ""(Le Dernier Sommeil) The Final Sleep""
column10: a cinematic 12-minute instrumental coda that brings to mind beautifully-shot imagery that makes you feel like you should probably be feeling something.

column1: Spiritualized is another band that has been down this particular road
column2: but something about the fact that Jason Pierce’s obsessions with drugs
column3: death
column4: and religion had years to marinate makes it easier for him to get away with Wagnerian bombast. Coming from a band like the Black Ryder
column5: where they know the sound and the history but don’t offer much in terms of personality
column6: it’s harder not to fixate entirely on the formal elements of the music
column7:
rather than the things that might make it personal. That leads to records where you listen to and admire them from a distance instead of getting immersed in them.

column3: a baseball game
column4: a barbecue—anywhere
column5: really—and you meet someone who earnestly describes himself as a ""hard luck boy."" He doesn’t appear to be a coal miner
column6: or a factory worker
column7: but a regular guy with a sharp haircut and a bespoke suit. Handsome
column8: too. How dare he? I’m comfortable in assuming most people would instinctively roll their eyes
column9: and wish this guy back to the Dust Bowl.

column1: Tom Brosseau pulls it off
column2: somehow

column4: but believable. Perfect Abandon
column5: his latest LP
column6: is an endearing collection of pastoral narratives and humble melodies that sounds unearthed from the Gaslight Cafe
column7: where minor folk singers plied their trade and presented their authenticity for analysis in the early '60s. It was recorded naturalistically
column8: with just a single microphone capturing Brosseau and his three-piece band. That accounts for the looseness—the way the arrangements fall together
column9: like when the kick drum rumbles into the mix on ""Roll Along With Me"" like a steam engine creaking into motion. Brosseau's handle on his acoustic guitar
column10: the album's predominant instrument
column11: will not blow you away. But he sounds like he's right in the room with you

column1: Brosseau sketches his origin story on ""Hard Luck Boy""
column2: where you understand he wasn’t being wry about his self-appointed moniker. The apparently autobiographical song is about how
column3: as a child
column4: Brosseau was abandoned by his mother in a department store. ""That's how it all happened
column5: all those years ago
column6: when I was just a boy
column7: Tom Brosseau drawls in a voice both quiet and sonorous
column8: ""and to this day I have never seen my mother.""

column1: How it all happened and all those years ago—it’s a singer approaching his life story as mythology
column2: oral history
column3: biblical text. Brosseau was raised religiously
column4: and Perfect Abandon is not only peppered with references to God

column6: he asks God if the darkness he sees in the world is only temporary; on ""Landlord Jackie""
column7: he balances his faith against his desires for the married Jackie
column8: and concludes
column9: ""trying to be faithful only increases the volume of the voice that says ‘It's all right
column10: what are you waiting for
column11: jump on in.’"" Brosseau sounds overwhelmed by the temptations of the world around him—his breathless paeans to ""your voice
column12: your breath
column13: your style of hair"" on ""Take Fountain""—and softly humbled about his place amongst all this majesty.

column1: I’m reminded of the novelist Marilynne Robinson
column2: whose work grapples with similar dilemmas in a similarly world weary voice. A 2007 Pitchfork review criticized Brosseau’s music for its smallness. But acknowledging one’s smallness can be its own virtue

column6: dear one

column10:
aware of his luck but determined to press on.

column3: Skrillex partnered with Cliff Martinez for the Spring Breakers soundtrack
column4: an ambient-skewing collection that displayed two brand-name artists collaborating on something subtle
column5: novel and tasteful. The music honored their specific styles and signatures while spinning a new and interesting whole. More than 2014’s tepid and somewhat soulless Recess

column1: Jack Ü

column3: is not like that at all. Instead
column4: it’s roughly the sum of its parts—Skrillex’s frenetic drop-heavy monoliths paired with Diplo’s frequent attempts at world-music-curation and general boner for eclectic collaboration. While some of Jack Ü soars above reasonable expectation—the Kiesza collaboration ""Take Ü There"" and its equally energizing remix featuring Missy Elliott
column5: for example—it mostly registers as a fun
column6: low-stakes affair with its finger often too close to the button. Given that the surprise release was celebrated with a livestreamed 24-hour-party

column2: AlunaGeorge
column3: 2 Chainz (""Yeah I am the shit/ So I should have Febreeze on it"")
column4: ragga soca artist Bunji Garlin—and makes the collaborations memorable. ""Where Are Ü Now""
column5: in particular
column6: builds  around an effervescent Justin Bieber vocal that surprises in all of the right ways—I wouldn't be surprised to see Bieber use the song as an effective bridge to the more mature sounds he coveted on 2013's Journals. In general

column9: clipped vocal samples
column10: and colossal Skrillex-starter-set WUB WUB WUB bass drops
column11: but Skrillex and Diplo carve out enough space for lower-key
column12: fun-loving moments. Over nine tracks
column13: there are definite misfires—the volatile throb of ""Holla Out"" scans as something that could live well on Clickhole while also reminding me of the fiendish ""Left Swipe Dat"" song—but Jack Ü ultimately gets its very specific job done.

column1: Above all
column2: this is maximalist party music that captures a specific moment in time. (Sample song title: ""Jungle Bae"".) Jack Ü is nothing but a fount of stomping
column3: outrageous EDM
column4: the kind that basically serves as a security deposit for $75k-a-night residencies in Vegas. While Jack Ü doesn't exactly roll the ball forward

The members of Radical Dads met while attending college in the Northeast in the '90s. Those facts alone do not a college rock record make
column2: but there’s no denying the subgenre’s omnipresence on Universal Coolers. Singer/guitarist Lindsay Baker’s guitar tangles with Chris Diken’s in an emulation of Sleater-Kinney’s anthemic brawniness
column3: and fuzzy Built to Spill chord progressions anchor tempestuous licks. Adding a bass guitar to the trio’s mix might provide a grounding force for potentially bigger payoffs
column4: but you get the feeling the Brooklyn band don’t want their angular jumps and careening hooks to be held down anyway.

column1: Radical Dads are best when they’re youthful and antagonistic
column2: and though this record isn’t a huge leap for the band
column3: it does signal a realization of where their strength lies. While Mega Rama and Rapid Reality found solace in a few minimal
column4: desert road melodies
column5: Universal Coolers refuses to quiet down. Lyrically
column6: Baker delivers lighthearted teenage colloquialisms with a knowing wink
column7: whether she’s encouraging pizza consumption (""Cassette Brain"")
column8: observing others ""making out"" (""DJ Pancake"")
column9: or resigning to watch TV because there’s ""nothing to do but chill"" (""Slammer"").

column1: Diken provides snotty vocals on outlier ""Flight to NZ""
column2: a stream-of-consciousness narrative that moves unexpectedly into a Daydream Nation-like freak­out of screeching guitars. Sometimes
column3: he stumbles over callow or clumsy phrasing
column4: and it’s difficult to take his stoic closing proclamation that ""there’s no city of light"" seriously. The ebullient opener ""Absurd Tests"" is much better
column5: the strain behind Baker’s disaffected shout-singing sounding as unapologetic as the bed of noise backing it. ""Got middle fingers on both hands/ Gonna break up all my bands
column6: she avows.

column1: Nearly every track is teeming with distortion pedals and pop melodies
column2: but ""Cassette Brain"" is the album’s most potent moment. The title alone taps into their aesthetic—it’s easy to imagine the band members trading the Clean tapes or Polvo 7-­inches before ending up in a basement jam session. Despite a mid­tempo pace—the record’s most leisurely cut—it never drags
column3: with limber arpeggios ricocheting off of a hiccuping drum fill. Baker’s lyrics offer slithering hints of Rad Dads’ industrial home base in Brooklyn’s Gowanus neighborhood (""We might get swept away/ Won’t you clear the toxic sludge from my head?/ We’ll build an armory/ Protect our collections with walls made of lead""). The breathing space in the arrangement and the subdued tone point a possible way forward for the threesome.

column1: Ultimately
column2: it’s difficult for Universal Coolers to be pinned down to one completely cohesive thought. Radical Dads are still investigating what indie rock has to offer
column3: how they can toy with their forebears’ foundations while digging jagged pathways outwards. But they probably wouldn’t be attempting this ambitious exploration together if they didn’t have fun along the way
column4:
and their energy is infectious.

Among many other projects
column2: Bay Area vocalist and multi-instrumentalist Ephemeral Domignostika puts out solo material as Mastery

column4: but none were adequate preparation for Mastery’s first full-length. Valis is an exercise in hyperactive neuron overload

column1: This is the first time Ephemeral Domignostika’s vision has been so clear; the memorable riffs are here
column2: but he pushes them all to their breaking point. He plays with the velocity of Orthrelm's Mick Barr and the inventiveness of Gridlink’s Takafumi Matsubara. To call this music ""dense"" would be an understatement
column3: as he piles on the skronky twists and synapse-melting tapping
column4: pausing only for a couple of ambient interludes (""A.S.H.V.E.S.S.E.L."" and ""I.L.K.S.E.E.K.E.R."") and moments where the electrified spasms give way to acoustic strumming (""V.A.L.I.S.V.E.S.S.E.L."") while frantic drums and scowls continue. Mastery is polarizing
column5: but unlike Ephemeral Domignostika’s one-man-band project <span>Pandiscordian Necrogenesis
column6: the music is much more than a cheap spectacle.

column1: Because for all of Valis' chaotic energy
column2: Ephemeral Domignostika remains a keen tactician
column3: with each improvised freakout compressed
column4: cut up into dizzying pieces
column5: and put in place. It sounds like it was created in one take
column6: with no edits
column7: which would be impossible. But the knowledge that he composed the album from jams
column8: integrating the best of improvisational spontaneity and metal’s tradition of rigid composition
column9: and in the process making sense of his own madness
column10: is just as staggering.

column1: There are sections where a righteous black thrash riff will come in
column2: something that demands only your most vigorous headbanging and your fists raised as high as you can raise them—the opening pummel of ""V.A.L.I.S.V.E.S.S.E.L.""
column3: which he also revisits in ""S.T.A.R.S.E.E.K.E.R.""—but just as soon as these come to fruition
column4: Ephemeral Domignostika will break it down and switch to another sequence equally as turbulent but even less comprehensible. While Mastery never abandons black metal
column5: his ability to nod to catchy riffs while also surgically dismembering them is what elevates him above would-be avant-metallists.

column1: Valis appears just as one-time Bay Area compatriot Leviathan is gaining attention—and in some eyes
column2: redeeming himself—for his latest
column3: and most accomplished
column4: record
column5: Scar Sighted. Both are triumphs of singular visions
column6: the ethos of one-man black metal fully realized. While Scar Sighted is an examination of a troubled self
column7: Valis is a warning to let you know just what Ephemeral Domignostika is capable of and how far he’s willing to scramble his mind for his music. It’s not an album for the stubborn traditionalists
column8:
nor is it for the newcomers who preach open-mindedness but are too timid to really engage with the art.

column9: Pitbull

column8: worse

Guardian Alien
column2: the ecstatic experimentalists that singer-songwriter Alexandra Drewchin has run with over the last few years
column3: have been described as ""psychedelic."" But despite that tag—and despite the fact that they had a Rastafarian extraterrestrial on one of their record sleeves—the rapturous emotional peaks and torturous noisemaking that Drewchin contributed to the group always rendered their explorations more ritualistic and earthy than that label suggests. Their interest in psychedelic experience is more ideological than aesthetic
column4: an idea that carries through on Drewchin's first full-length release as Eartheater
column5: Metalepsis.

column1: Drewchin displays an all-consuming interest in blurring boundaries that burrows all the way down to the record's textural details. Leadoff track ""Macro EV"" dances between delicate reverse-delayed electric guitar plinks and needly loops of her own vocals
column2: teetering on the brink between swooning and sickly. Drewchin plays with these opposing textures over the course of the record
column3: imbuing ""Homonyms""—the most tuneful and immediate of her folkier efforts—with lurching and chattering vocal exercises. She's upending the conventions of folk and ambient music—taking little excursions into harsher realms
column4: just for good measure—gracefully crossing stereotypical divides between genres without even really letting you notice that she's done so. It's a sort of sonic jamais vu: All of the ingredients feel familiar
column5: but the whole that they eventually make up remains alien and unattainable.

column1: There are also moments where Drewchin intentionally jars us
column2: delivering seemingly absurd elements (such as the minute-long Eastern European rap sample at the end of ""Youniverse""). But even those play seriously in context. In the tradition of most who consider themselves experimenters
column3: the origin of the sounds Drewchin uses become muddled. There are samples from John Frusciante solo experiments and stabbing string sections
column4: and all manners of instrumentation both recorded and synthesized. What's a product of the organic world and what's a product of her array of electronic equipment is suddenly unclear. Her treatment lightly suggests that all of these varying parts should be treated and approached the same way
column5: like a utopian psych-folk that embraces electronic instrumentation.

column1: Drewchin's lyrical concerns
column2: too
column3: center on interstitial spaces: between the natural world and the digital (""The Internet Is Handmade"")
column4: between the subjective truth and objective reality (""Infinity"")
column5: and between the self and the cosmos (""Youniverse""). Throughout she embraces thematic abstraction and philosophical ambiguities as guiding principles. In other words
column6: Drewchin may not have everything quite figured out
column7: and her insistence on posing questions rather than answers elevates Metalepsis into a compelling document of postmodern (and importantly
column8: post-Internet) confusion. Metalepsis is music that's built to overwhelm and envelop you
column9: and maybe even
column10: as Drewchin's moniker suggests
column11:
swallow worlds whole.

column1: Hearing Barnes sing about Grøttland—somehow a part of every Of Montreal album
column2: lyrically or otherwise
column3: since Satanic Panic in the Attic—anchors Aureate Gloom in reality. On Fauna
column4: Barnes strangled his heart inside of ""The Past Is a Grotesque Animal""
column5: an opus about his strained relationship with Grøttland. Now Barnes tempers his feelings with melancholy
column6: and instead of some catastrophic metaphor
column7: we get
column8: simply: ""You never did me wrong
column9: we just been together too long
column10: babe.""

column1: Which is to say
column2: while there's still plenty of Barnesian lyrical rhapsodies here
column3: there's also a refreshing ease
column4: helped in part by the backing group he's been using since 2013’s lousy with sylvianbriar. No longer a dusty
column5: paisley San Francisco band
column6: they’ve become '70s New York art punks. This is thoroughly an electric guitar album
column7: and references to Talking Heads and Television abound (the guitar riff on the verse of ""Last Rites at the Jane Motel"" is a direct homage to ""Marquee Moon""). Set against this wiry
column8: mid-gain pastiche
column9: Barnes' voice adopts a glittery
column10: damaged glam rock tone that falls right in with the musical palette.

column1: This consonance
column2: coupled with Barnes' starkly personal lyrics
column3: make this album one of the least inscrutable in their catalog. Aureate Gloom feels like it belongs in our universe
column4: not some spartan funk galaxy borne out of the recesses of Barnes' mind. ""I’m grieving for you
column5: my love"" he sings
column6: so innocently
column7: on ""Virgilian Lots"" before adding
column8: ""And I don't understand what's going on."" It is straight up shocking to hear Barnes at a loss for words. Of course
column9: just after his bemusement
column10: he falls back on psycho-Marc Bolan patter on ""Monolithic Egress"". In a series of admissions and realizations (including what sounds like a specific reference to the dissolution of pet names
column11: ""I’m not a different man ‘cause you now call me some fucked up name"") Barnes beats his chest around an ever-shifting garage rock template. It jumps from a fried take on Zeppelin’s ""Immigrant Song"" to a kaleidoscopic
column12: proggy psych dream
column13: and inside-out and back around again.

column1: This bounding
column2: perforated punk sound is enjoyable on its own terms
column3: though you wonder what could’ve been if this band didn’t work so modularly in fits and starts. A highlight
column4: ""Empyrean Abattoir""
column5: starts with Barnes' hushed singing
column6: slowly building with his signature three-part harmonies
column7: carrying the song fluidly until we get to the skittering 5/4 section and Barnes' emotions get the best of him. He sings
column8: now with more distortion on his mic
column9: ""Now it’s just a system of subtraction."" Which
column10: yes
column11: breaking up is just a system of subtraction
column12: but it’s not exactly a graceful turn of phrase. For every disarmingly honest moment
column13: in other words
column14: there is an equal and opposite moment where Barnes obfuscates
column15: to unclear ends. These sudden shifts make it fun to follow Kevin Barnes
column16: but difficult to get close to Kevin Barnes.

column1: Of Montreal's concept has migrated as erratically as the tempo shifts and time changes on Aureate Gloom
column2: so much that it’s hard to find their natural center now. So
column3: our attention spans drift away. By the time the chaos of the bitter closer ""Like Ashoka’s Inferno of Memory"" comes on like an overcooked Bowie tribute
column4: it’s hard to feel connected to the soul of this group. Even though Barnes is trying so desperately to figure out what’s happening in front of him
column5: it’s a barbed mess behind him. Ultimately the music becomes another mask
column6: another thing Barnes is trying to untangle
column7: in a great chapter in the lengthy
column8: wonderfully ornate Of Montreal compendium. That’s the paradox with Of Montreal: the more they create
column9:
the less you know them.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21468/homepage_large.ccfcaf4f.jpg|After|31052.0|Lady Lamb the Beekeeper|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mom & Pop']|2015-03-04 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:05.990279|"

Aly Spaltro isn't a teenager anymore
column2: but she was when she wrote much of her Lady Lamb the Beekeeper debut
column3: 2013's Ripely Pine. That album didn't sound like the emergence of a college-aged songwriter so much as it played like an experiment from someone who had already gotten good at putting music together. Full of nerves and breath and blood
column4: Ripely Pine whipped folk tropes into rock'n'roll rambunctiousness
column5: giving her plenty of space to sound precocious. On her second album
column6: After
column7: Spaltro hits one of the unexpected truths of your twenties: that embracing your repressed childlike instincts is one of the more adult things you can do.

column1: Ripely Pine struck out big
column2: with elegant metaphors rooted in the natural world. After's track list includes a song called ""Milk Duds""
column3: suggesting that Lady Lamb's tone has shifted from Ripely's seven-minute ballad ""You Are the Apple"". ""We fell asleep on a box of Milk Duds
column4: she sings on the new song. ""They melted into the clubhouse cushions/ I never loved another person/ More than I loved you when I woke that morning."" That sticky mess doesn't make the prettiest image in the traditional sense
column5: but Spaltro's probably the first songwriter to find a symbol of her love in a pile of chocolate and caramel and polyester. She's getting braver.

column1: After is heartsick to its core—the title seems to eulogize a love affair in a single word—but it's much rowdier than its lyrics alone would imply. On opener ""Vena Cava""
column2: Spaltro looks at her sleeping partner and sees the fiery death of their relationship as though it's already happening in slow motion all around her. ""I can feel how the seams of your ribs will separate from the seams of my ribs
column3: she sings. ""I know already how much TV will fail to comfort me in your absence."" She switches from two ribcages unraveling to a melancholic Netflix binge in one line. And the song's a jam to boot.

column1: Her lyrical muscle lets Lady Lamb oscillate between the visceral and the mundane without so much as a knowing lilt in her voice. Both modes come easily to her
column2: and the tension between them is fertile. There's a parallel tension in the music
column3: too: The strongest songs on After verge on acoustic despondency only to break into a big
column4: crunchy chorus. You can always weep out the pain
column5: but sometimes it's so much more fun to mosh it off.

column1: There are plenty of startling moments full of guts and gristle in Lady Lamb's dense lyrics
column2: and then there are the moments when she wanders. The fingerpicked ""Sunday Shoes"" stretches out between the shoegaze-inflected ""Heretic"" and ""Spat Out Spit""
column3: injecting a weird bubble of space into the album's flow. The rousing coda on ""Penny Licks"" almost feels like an Arcade Fire climax
column4: even though it only arrives in the seventh song. Like Ripely Pine
column5: After clocks in at a solid hour—and it's an hour you'll feel
column6: because while After boasts a stacked lineup of well-crafted songs
column7:
it's a choppy ride to make it through them all.
