Psychedelia has two speeds: Either it elevates you into an altered consciousness
column2: or it lulls you to sleep like so much television static. With Shadow of the Sun
column3: their third full-length effort
column4: Moon Duo often approach the former state
column5: and only occasionally slip into the latter. Singer-guitarist Ripley Johnson and singer-keyboardist Sanae Yamada are joined on record by drummer John Jeffrey
column6: and the consistent use of live drums—Jeffrey was only added to the band’s full-time roster after their 2013 European Tour—does a lot to imbue the winding
column7: floating sound with some physical power.

column1: Although Shadow of the Sun is rooted in psychedelia
column2: there are elements of proto-punk all over it
column3: darkening the songs and making them more human. ""Wilding""
column4: the album's standout opening track
column5: resembles one of Jonathan Richman’s more uptempo songs
column6: tinged with a tinny Haight-Ashbury tambourine and some wigged-out synths. Johnson’s solos
column7: which can occasionally wander
column8: are concise and focused here
column9: setting an energetic stage for what’s to come.

column1: Shadow of the Sun is psych for the city
column2: and even in its more ascendant moments
column3: a thin veil of industrial grit
column4: leaning towards krautrock
column5: keeps the record from ever really floating skyward. Their last LP
column6: 2012’s Ralph Waldo Emerson-inspired Circles
column7: hinted at a relationship to nature. But unlike fellow drugged-out craftsmen Brightblack Morning Light
column8: whose hazy
column9: shimmering songs are all palo santo and desert light
column10: Moon Duo’s creepy synths and razor-sharp guitars never venture into more magical realms.

column1: None of the songs on Shadow of the Sun sound new
column2: but the familiar sounds create an atmosphere of safety that allows the more unexpected elements of the record all the more noteworthy. Occasionally
column3: as on ""Night Beat"" and ""Zero""
column4: the synths reach horror-movie levels
column5: toeing the line between new wave and pure camp. The riff to ""Slow Down Low"" is more Bethany Cosentino than Jerry Garcia
column6: and the song’s precise
column7: languid gentleness accomplishes what psych does at its best; it transports the listener to that place just outside of reality
column8: where it’s ok to drop out and just float for awhile. It’s a shame that this effect isn’t more consistent throughout Shadow of the Sun
column9: but in the moments when the campy
column10: dirge-like darkness lifts
column11:
it shines bright.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21300/homepage_large.5ae12ba9.jpg|The Republic|3385.0|Sam Prekop|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2015-03-04 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:06.845781|"

Sam Prekop’s work is nothing if not subtle. His first band
column2: Shrimp Boat
column3: could be all over the place
column4: but after settling in with the Sea and Cake in 1994
column5: his distinguished careers in music
column6: painting
column7: and photography have been unified in theme and overall aesthetic. He’s never been worried about repeating himself. The Sea and Cake made a few outstanding albums and a few more good ones; as a singer and guitarist
column8: Prekop made two fine full-lengths that were different from his work in the Sea and Cake
column9: but not markedly so. And now he’s returned with his second album of solo electronic music in five years
column10: and it has many things in common with the last one.

column1: Once again
column2: the predominant theme is the emotional possibilities of the modular synthesis. Unlike
column3: say
column4: Oneohtrix Point Never
column5: Prekop’s electronic music never feels like commentary
column6: and unlike Arp the influences are more open-ended. Many of these tracks sound like they could have been made in 1975 or 1985. Simple
column7: clean tones bubble along
column8: tracing melodies that evoke a wide-eyed kind of retrofuturism
column9: redolent of an era when we hoped that technology could save humanity from itself. But even that marker seems slippery. The first nine all bear the title ""The Republic"" and were assembled as part of an art installation
column10: but titles (later ones include ""Ghost"" and ""Invisible"") are meaningless. This is music that proudly exists as sonic information
column11: music that invites you to meditate on how a simple tone with a halo of white noise
column12: pulsing along in medium tempo and working through different melodic combinations along a major scale
column13: makes you feel.

column1: Importantly
column2: as with Old Punch Card
column3: it asks such questions but doesn’t offer any particular answers. The Republic would make a lousy film soundtrack because the music is defined by its ambiguity. Some might hear mystery in this music
column4: some might hear something chill and late-night ambient
column5: some might hear a bright and sunny affirmation
column6: but Prekop’s relationship to sound can’t be summed up so neatly. As with his song lyrics
column7: his electronic music is built for in-between spaces that are experienced very differently depending on the listener’s perspective.

column1: Only in a few places does The Republic move outside its strict analog synth palette. ""The Republic 9"" incorporates what sound like samples of a harp
column2: and ""Weather Vane"" briefly features a thudding 4/4 kick
column3: but even that surprising turn is quickly subsumed back into the album’s more open-ended drift. Extremes of any kind have no place here. Even the tag ""music"" doesn’t always seem accurate. Passages from the installation make you wonder if you’re listening to an extremely quiet drone or just the sound of something being plugged in. The analog equipment hisses and crackles but these artifacts are no less important than the tunes. If the album has a broader idea to hang itself on
column4: that's it—after listening
column5:
you start to notice what your room sounds like.

Japanese singer-songwriter Rima Kato has kept busy over the last few years
column2: releasing a steady stream of EPs and touring with foreign artists such as Sharon Van Etten
column3: Mount Eerie
column4: and LAKE. It's a remarkable development for someone who spent nearly a decade hiding her music from anyone else. Kato originally played in the jaunty folk-pop duo Strrows while still a high school student
column5: spending the back half of the '90s making silly twee-pop before inching towards slower material near the turn of the century.

column1: Strrows called it quits in 2001
column2: however
column3: and Kato edged away from sharing her work. She says she spent most of the following nine years writing music by herself
column4: for herself. When she stepped out of the shadows to start performing live again in 2010
column5: the sunny tunes of Strrows were replaced by quieter acoustic numbers titled ""I Know Your Lies"" and ""I’m Still Alive"".

column1: Faintly Lit—technically her debut full-length as her 2012 collection Harmless is considered a ""mini-album
column2: but definitely her first release available outside Japan—clocks in at 25 minutes
column3: but its eight songs gestated for a long time
column4: and many were among the first Kato played live upon her re-emergence. Their construction is simple
column5: just Kato’s hushed singing and guitar dolloped with a few other instruments. Opener ""I Write Letter"" ends up being one of Faintly Lit’s busiest moments
column6: Kato double tracking her voice and adding a layer of electronic organ to create a dreamy atmosphere
column7: but it still comes across like someone singing a breath away from your ear.

column1: Kato constructs her songs like short stories and sings them in English that doesn’t waste time on anything complicated. This approach has its downsides
column2: including a groan-worthy campfire sing-along (""Have Fun"") and songs that meander (""Your River""
column3: the longest inclusion at four-and-a-half minutes). On much of the record
column4: though
column5: this lyrical directness coupled with the austere setting creates a convincing downtrodden mood
column6: a feeling not so much sad as resigned.

column1: Yet the best moments on Faintly Lit come when Kato’s words reveal small details that belie the simplicity of her music. ""Life Is Warm"" sounds like a blissful lazy-afternoon love song
column2: scored with xylophone plonks
column3: but then Kato mentions ""your girlfriend
column4: and later drops something about ""her boyfriend
column5: complicating the innocent scenario. Kato plays this little trick a lot: On the dreamy
column6: nostalgic loser ""Ferris Wheel""
column7: she sings ""Please don’t think of your girlfriend/ I’ll try to control my wicked emotion."" As simple as Kato can sound
column8: she sneaks emotional complexity into her creations.

column1: Even though Kato occasionally lets Faintly Lit get a little too straightforward or allows the songs to run a touch longer than they should
column2: her first proper album mostly features stark songs hiding a lot of craftsmanship
column3: shaped over many years. It helps a lot that it finishes up in under 30 minutes—Kato’s world is entrancing
column4:
but also a little too intimate for extended stays.

Levon Vincent's self-titled record
column2: which consists of 11 tracks spread across eight sides of vinyl
column3: is a half-lit maze
column4: an exploration of dance music at its most subterranean. But even as the record reinforces his reputation as one of techno's most determined purists
column5: it also suggests that his talents are more varied than perhaps anyone has given him credit for.

column1: Vincent
column2: a New Yorker now based in Berlin
column3: has been making records since the early 2000s
column4: but only in the past six or seven years has become a key figure in the underground. He's a bit like techno's own Fugazi: He has mentored up-and-coming artists
column5: supporting them out of his own pocket
column6: and he uploads vinyl rips of his own releases to SoulSeek. (In fact
column7: the day before this album was to hit shops
column8: he gave it away via WeTransfer.) His records
column9: mostly self-released on his own Novel Sound label
column10: may sell in modest numbers
column11: perhaps a few thousand copies apiece
column12: but sales are only a small part of the story. On YouTube
column13: some of his tracks and DJ sets have been played hundreds of thousands of times. Those numbers might be surprising
column14: even to his fans
column15: given the monochromatic rigor of his music
column16: its single-mindedness. His productions are radically austere and unusually somber—the color of an overcast sky
column17: or a bruise.

column1: That hasn't changed
column2: exactly. The music on his debut album is moody and
column3: sometimes
column4: a little counterintuitive. It's not necessarily trying to be difficult
column5: but it's intractable out of habit. Drums are scarce
column6: for one thing
column7: at least for a techno record: The four-to-the-floor kick is omnipresent
column8: but for long stretches
column9: the merest hint of washed-out hi-hat is the only percussive element audible. Swathed in murk
column10: these skeletal sounds give the impression of stone rubbings
column11: or a metal frame showing through where paint has been worn away. ""Phantom Power"" goes even further and does away with the low end entirely; for more than five minutes
column12: it is as though the bass EQ has been turned all the way down
column13: leaving tentative synthesizer figures tumbling weightlessly in midair. Which only accentuates the pile-driving wallops of the following track
column14: ""Junkies on Hermann Strasse""
column15: a classic Basic Channel-style clanger as physical and pliable as sheet metal. ""Junkies"" eventually dissolves into a cacophonous delay chain as contorted as Cabaret Voltaire's early tape works
column16: but not everything on the album is so relentless or so ugly. ""For Mona
column17: My Beloved Cat
column18: Rest in Peace"" is every bit as sentimental as the title promises; this time there is no kick drum
column19: just hi-hats mapping infinity across a glowing swirl of keyboards and mallet instruments
column20: part Philip Glass and part Rainbow Bridge.

column1: There's plenty of ""proper"" techno to be found here; ""Anti-Corporate Music"" comes closest to the dubby style of Vincent's singles
column2: with its brushed stainless steel textures and its deeper-than-deep sub-bass. (The title offers a glimpse of the politics implicit in Vincent's DIY project. ""This is music for the ugly ducklings of the world
column3: he wrote in a Facebook post announcing the LP. ""If you're a member of the rat race…you may of course listen
column4: but know—this is not music for you. This is action against you."") But nothing on Levon Vincent is merely functional
column5: and some of the best cuts jam a crowbar into club-music convention. For its first seven minutes
column6: the side-long ""Launch Ramp to tha Sky"" unrolls relatively smoothly
column7: just a lively
column8: vibraphone-like lead over swinging cymbals and chilly reverb. Without warning
column9: the beat falls away and is replaced by slack organ riffing
column10: and that
column11: in turn
column12: gives way to a chromatic freakout laced with angel choir. Piling nightly-news themes atop dial-tone fugue
column13: this coda to the coda is as unabashedly prog as a gatefold LP sticky with weed resin; give a medal to the DJ who manages to play the whole side to a dancefloor and get away with it.

column1: Thanks to its pared-down gear list and capricious flow
column2: Levon Vincent feels like the work of someone left alone in the studio
column3: sketching in real time with what's at hand and moving on. And that spontaneity gives it an even greater sense of intimacy. My favorite track

column5: is
column6: in many ways
column7: the most melodic
column8: with a stately bassline and contrapuntal melody that could lodge in your head for days. The tune is daubed on in broad strokes
column9: left to drift free of the beat—a sure sign that it was played by hand and not drawn across a grid in the browser window. Throughout it all
column10: Vincent keeps his hand on the knob that controls the cymbals' pitch
column11: and they rise and fall like swallows at dusk. It's freedom rendered four bars at a time—a snapshot of utopia that's made with dancefloors in mind
column12:
but not limited to them.

Revisionist feels grander than it is
column2: and bigger than the band that made it. The second album from the metallic Brooklyn instrumental trio Sannhet lasts only nine tracks
column3: or 38 minutes. But its overall density—of emotions and dynamics
column4: of textures and melodies
column5: of strengths and surprises—makes each moment so compelling that the record seems at least twice that length. The album’s brilliant centerpiece
column6: ""Empty Harbor""
column7: rises from a slow
column8: electrified fusion that suggests ECM in the '80s to a blast beat-backed surge powerful enough to match the best codas of Temporary Residence Ltd. Driven by masterful drummer Christopher Todd
column9: it sounds like a little symphony
column10: both in execution and effect; looking at the clock
column11: however
column12: it’s shocking to find that the song lasts for less than five minutes.

column1: Sannhet have always defied quick taxonomy. They are a byproduct of Brooklyn’s emergent metal scene; Saint Vitus
column2: one of the city’s heavy hubs
column3: issued their 2013 debut LP
column4: Known Flood
column5: which featured a tirade of screams from bar booker David Castillo. Although their new home
column6: The Flenser

column8: the core of its catalog remains metal
column9: however soft or mercurial. From the pummeling black-metal drums during the exhilarating climax of ""Lost Crown"" to the tense rhythmic lock of death metal near the middle of ""False Pass""
column10: traces of that pedigree populate Revisionist. But AJ Annunziata’s bass distortion during songs like ""Enemy Victorian"" implies the astral ascendance of space-rock. The same goes for John Refano
column11: a guitarist who likes to widen the band’s sound with layers of background noise perhaps more than he prefers to lead with coiled riffs. There are astutely applied electronics that suggest the abstraction of Touch Music masters like Philip Jeck
column12: and careful but brief drone passages that conjure Kranky. If metal made for the most convenient tag for Known Flood
column13: it is at best an awkward fit for Revisionist
column14: a record that revels and delights in a trove of outsider influences.

column1: American post-rock and post-metal have often offered the scores of wide-open spaces
column2: be they the football fields and Texas hills of Explosions in the Sky’s Friday Night Lights accompaniment or the rivers and valleys of their fellow Lone Star residents Balmorhea. Labradford
column3: Red Sparowes and ISIS suggested settings more vast and hospitable than the cities they called home. But Sannhet take many of those same sweeping
column4: cinematic impulses and apply them to cramped urban landscapes and lifestyles. They begin ""Mint Divine"" with a sample of voices
column5: which blur into the mind-numbing chatter endemic to busy city streets. The band works to overcome the pervasive din
column6: or to at least carve out a sheltered space within it. Refano and Annunziata deliver a delicate duet
column7: their gentle guitar notes and pulsing bass competing with the hubbub. The voices waft into the next track
column8: ""False Pass""
column9: but Todd battles them back with his heavy hands and deep
column10: floor-tom thuds. Together
column11: Sannhet finally overpower their environment
column12: finding solace in the solidarity of volume.

column1: This metropolitan sense of setting also explains Sannhet’s concision. Only ""Enemy Victorian""
column2: the album’s one listless point
column3: breaks the six-minute mark. Otherwise
column4: Sannhet push the parts together
column5: moving at a rate that suggests they’re worried the city will swallow them if they don’t press ahead. ""You Thy_"" collapses feelings of romance
column6: terror and longing into four breathless minutes
column7: maximizing emotional impact and efficiency all at once. By oscillating between lumbering
column8: loping patterns and sustained blast beats
column9: Todd turns the three-minute ""Lost Crown"" into a frantic
column10: crazed quest in an unsympathetic environment
column11: where no one else cares if you ever recover your holy grail. <span>Sannhet make music for subway stations and unlit street corners
column12: not winding hikes and idyllic vistas.

column1: If Explosions in the Sky and similar bands create accompaniment for Hollywood productions
column2: Sannhet offer a vivid
column3: real-life counterpoint. There’s no lighting
column4: no scripting
column5: no catering—just the exigencies and anxieties of existence
column6: delivered by a band battling pedestrian frustrations with uncommon focus. Revisionist
column7: turns out
column8:
is bigger than its 38 minutes or the trio that made it; these nine songs are as big as whatever life it is they soundtrack.

As much as classic-rock radio purports to be the last bastion of Real Music
column2: the format is
column3: of course
column4: just as formulaic
column5: repetitive
column6: and popularity-driven as any Top 40 station. Classic-rock radio doesn’t honor veteran bands’ legacies; it contracts and distorts them
column7: reducing diverse multi-decade careers to one or two focus tracks. And because of this
column8: a lot of people have been raised to believe that Thin Lizzy were a hard-rock band
column9: thanks to the only two songs of theirs you’ve been liable to hear on a North American terrestrial rock station over the past 30 years. But as the missing link between Van Morrison and Van Halen

column12: streetwise narratives in a molten
column13: harmonic twin-guitar attack that anticipated heavy metal without ever fully hardening into it. And while Lizzy’s sharp-angled logo fit in right next to the KISS and AC/DC patches on your older brother’s denim jacket
column14: Lynott was the rare arena-rocker who wasn’t shrieking to hit the cheap seats—he was singing about the sort of poor bastards stuck in them.

column1: That underdog mentality has made Thin Lizzy perhaps the only band of chest-baring
column2: leather-panted '70s rockers to be unironically embraced in the more humble environs of indie rock
column3: having been namedropped in song by Belle and Sebastian and the Hold Steady
column4: covered by the Mountain Goats
column5: and lovingly imitated by Ted Leo. And the band’s eclectic palette of formative influences
column6: not to mention their unique socio-political dynamic (with a half-black frontman
column7: and members from both sides of Ireland’s Catholic/Protestant divide) go a long way in explaining why their early Decca Records catalogue is currently being reissued on vinyl by the astute historical preservationists at Light In the Attic
column8: as opposed to some major-label bargain-bin CD run.

column1: Like Thin Lizzy's 1971 debut (reissued by LITA in 2012)
column2: Shades of a Blue Orphange (1972) and Vagabonds of the Western World (1973) have been ignored by classic-rock radio playlists
column3: and their existence is rarely acknowledged even by the band’s infinite stream of compilations and live albums. The Thin Lizzy represented here—the early trio formation of Lynott
column4: drummer Brian Downey
column5: and ex-Them guitarist Eric Bell—found themselves in the same position as many other blues-schooled rock bands at the dawn of the post-hippie '70s: aesthetically confused and willing to try anything in hope something would stick (all while surreptitiously recording entire albums of Deep Purple covers to pay the bills). And while neither of these albums is wholly rewarding enough to qualify as an overlooked classic
column6: they’re still illuminating documents of a hard-luck band finding its voice for the first time
column7: if only in fits and starts.

column1: As Shades of a Blue Orphanage makes abundantly clear from the get-go
column2: Thin Lizzy weren’t lacking ambition at this stage
column3: but rather direction: Album opener ""The Rise and Dear Demise of the Funky Nomadic Tribes"" is every bit as ridiculous and unwieldy as its title suggests
column4: cycling through tough funk grooves
column5: proto-metal riffage
column6: and progged-out breakdowns en route to a drum solo that fades out unceremoniously at the seven-minute mark. But the track is also something of a red herring
column7: an early
column8: clumsy stab at heaviosity from a band that
column9: at this point
column10: had a much better grasp of intimacy. Even though Thin Lizzy’s sound had yet to settle into place—variously taking the form of ersatz Elvis exercises (""I Don’t Want to Forget How to Drive"")
column11: pavement-splitting rockers (""Call the Police"")
column12: Astral Weeks-esque folk reveries (""Chatting Today"") and ethereal piano lullabies (""Sarah"")—Lynott’s lyrical voice was already providing a sturdy anchor to rally it around. On richly detailed character studies like ""Buffalo Gal"" and the hymn-like title track
column13: the then-23-year-old Lynott was already singing with the rueful wisdom of a man several decades his senior
column14: laying the foundation for the rugged-romantic archetype that would define his legend.

column1: While Shades of a Blue Orphanage did little to reverse the band’s flagging fortunes
column2: its follow-up single—a glammed-up cover of the traditional Irish standard ""Whiskey in the Jar""—gave Thin Lizzy its first UK hit single in 1972. But that success would not boost the commercial prospects of the band’s next full-length
column3: Vagabonds of the Western World. Fearing that ""Whiskey"" was a novelty hit that didn’t truly reflect the band’s sound
column4: Thin Lizzy refused to include the song on the record. Which is kind of funny in retrospect
column5: since the great breakthrough Thin Lizzy made on ""Whiskey""—in the form of Bell’s thick
column6: mercurial guitar hook—provided them with a new sonic blueprint.

column1: Thin Lizzy had yet to divest itself of all its hare-brained ideas—the spoken-word
column2: psych-funk workout ""The Hero and the Madmen"" may fancy itself a western-themed storybook epic
column3: but it sure as hell ain’t no ""Cowboy Song"". They were
column4: however
column5: starting to kick out the jams with greater confidence and consistency. When Lynott shouts ""I’m a rocker!""
column6: it’s no mere crotch-grabbing macho posturing; it’s the sound of a spiritually adrift musician ecstatically discovering his true calling. (Accordingly
column7: the song in question
column8: ""Rocker""
column9: was the one tune from this era to keep its place on the band’s set lists long enough to warrant inclusion on the band’s definitive 1978 concert document
column10: Live and Dangerous.) And though Bell would depart soon after the album’s release
column11: his sweet
column12: swirling leads on the swinging opener ""Mama Nature Said""
column13: the gorgeous soul serenade ""Little Girl in Bloom""
column14: and the storming title track laid down the gasoline trail that Lizzy’s future dream-team tandem of Brian Robertson and Scott Gorham would set ablaze. Respectively
column15: the best songs on Shades of a Blue Orphanage and Vagabonds of the Western World displayed the early
column16: indecisive Thin Lizzy's facility with wobbly barstool ballads and swaggering
column17:
hot-wired rockers. Their greatest victories would come once they started hitting both targets at the same time.

Estelle’s latest record True Romance offers something new in the singer's career: a cohesive album experience. The follow-up to 2012’s All of Me is a chronicle of love anchored by four themes—""passion
column3: courage
column4: bullshit
column5: and true romance""—though it sticks to this blueprint at the risk of losing some of the idiosyncrasy that gave her previous works character. All of Me and her debut album Shine incorporated many different elements—Estelle experimented with rapping
column6: boom-bap
column7: reggae. Her song with Kanye West
column8: ""American Boy""
column9: went double platinum before garnering a Grammy for ""Best Rap/Sung"" collaboration. Together
column10: the albums featured beats by will.i.am
column11: Mark Ronson
column12: Wyclef Jean
column13: and Swizz Beatz
column14: and guest appearances from Rick Ross
column15: Janelle Monáe
column16: and Trey Songz. The patchwork of styles made each album feel scattered and disjointed
column17: but enjoyable.

column1: True Romance instead finds Estelle hewing a narrative
column2: singing about passion and healing with the kind of focus and intimacy that all neo-soul ballads require. It’s a decidedly inward-looking album
column3: but as such seems too aspirational for its own good: Estelle narrates her experiences
column4: and hovers so closely to the outline that it feels like we're checking boxes rather than happening upon these themes organically. Spoken word intros break the album up into loose chapters: Estelle says the word ""passion"" and we hear a song about romantic ardor (""Something Good""); she mutters the word ""bullshit"" and we hear a song about a troubled love (""The Same"")—but neither of these songs have the playful immediacy of Shine’s ""American Boy"" or the inchoate longing of All of Me-standout ""Thank You"". There are many feel-good hooks and lilting choruses on True Romance
column5: but the album is so universal in its approach (""We all make mistakes/ You might fall on your face
column6: she sings on ""Conqueror"") that it can feel anesthetic. As a result
column7: there’s nothing about True Romance that rings with the feeling of ""passion
column8: courage
column9: bullshit
column10: or true romance."" It’s difficult to make inspirational pop music with personality
column11: and harder still to mold a voice as dynamic as Estelle’s to fit a template—so when the personal stakes don't seem high enough
column12: the message falls flat.

column1: Still
column2: True Romance is less busy than any of Estelle’s previous works
column3: and it shifts the emphasis away from crafty lyricism to vocals and nuanced production. Throughout True Romance Estelle’s voice moves in velvety cascades
column4: ribboning through melismas with muted precision. She adopts a honeyed rasp on ""Time Share"" and coos across a smoky dancehall on ""Not Sure""; she speak-sings through ""She Will Love"" and lowers her range amongst Turkish cymbals on ""Fight For It"". Album standout ""Something Good""
column5: meanwhile
column6: showcases an infectious candor in which Estelle sounds a good deal like Mary J. Blige
column7: belting upper-register refrains over a stammering house beat. The step-wise thrum of ""Something Good"" makes me think about the kind of sound Mary J. Blige was striving for in her work with Disclosure—and it complements Estelle’s voice enough to make you wish she pursued electronic music further on the rest of the album.

column1: Instead
column2: True Romance is preoccupied with the well-worn territory of soul-pop
column3: and its lyrics about overcoming obstacles and troubled relationships can often sound rote (see: ""Gotcha Love""). For a supposedly introspective record
column4: it feels strikingly sanitary—like a centrifuge of sounds and words that are often associated with romance and self-discovery
column5: without the depth of yearning that leads us to understand why these feelings matter. As an album
column6: it feels complete but transient: True Romance has the capacity to lift and inspire
column7:
but that feeling doesn’t linger.

While working at Cornell University in Ithaca
column2: N.Y. during the late '60s
column3: composer David Borden met Robert Moog
column4: who was then refining his first commercial voltage-controlled synthesizer
column5: what we would now refer to simply as a Moog. Freshly returned from a stint as a Fulbright student in West Berlin
column6: Borden had an open mind toward new ideas in music but knew very little about synthesizers
column7: which were then fairly bulky and esoteric. According to the composer
column8: this made him an ideal test subject for Moog
column9: who allowed Borden to experiment with his prototypes as a way to proof the designs for regular consumers.

column1: Not long after
column2: Borden would found Mother Mallard’s Portable Masterpiece Company
column3: a keyboard trio that performed works by then-emerging composers like Terry Riley
column4: Robert Ashley
column5: and Steve Reich. Very quickly
column6: the trio evolved into an all-synthesizer ensemble
column7: performing original work using a number instruments provided by Moog.

column1: Inspired by composers like Riley
column2: Borden wrote music that edged away from the abstract atonal sounds that dominated electronic music at the time
column3: instead relying on the gestures that would become central to minimalism—simple harmonies
column4: complex rhythmic figures
column5: and repetition. Mother Mallard released two LPs—self-titled and <i>Like a Duck to Water
column6: both on Borden’s Earthquack label—before the group dissolved entirely during the late '70s (though it has since been reactivated).

column1: Originally released in 1981 on Red Records
column2: Music For Amplified Keyboard Instruments collects four of Borden’s post-Mallard compositions. Stylistically speaking
column3: they are a direct continuation of that group's work. Indeed
column4: they even involve the same instruments—the MiniMoog
column5: Moog Modular
column6: and RMI electronic piano—which Borden retained after the band split up. Now remastered and reissued by Spectrum Spools
column7: the record still stands as an excellent work of minimalist composition and also an important piece of American electronic music. A number of early Moog oriented records involved shoehorning the instrument into existing repertoire (think ""Switched on Bach"" or ""Switched on Country"") or using it as a spacey aside within the context of prog or psychedelic rock. Music For Amplified Keyboard Instruments is different
column8: and arguably more interesting
column9: in that it involves new work composed specifically for that synthesizer.

column1: At first listen
column2: it’s easy to overlook the role of the Moog in Borden’s compositions. The gestures that often define synthesizer music—filter sweeps
column3: squelchy modulations—are mostly absent from Music For Amplified Keyboard Instruments. In comparison to the work of German synth gurus like Tangerine Dream
column4: the tweak-ability factor is fairly subtle. This was mostly due to Borden's frustrations with performing synthesizer music live. ""After dealing with the many difficulties and variables that occur in live performance situations
column5: especially with early model synthesizers
column6: I developed a style and language of polyphonic music that can be played with simple
column7: easy to set up wave forms
column8: wrote Borden in the liner notes to the record's original pressing.

column1: However
column2: many of the compositions are heavily shaped by the capabilities of the synthesizer. The Moog is a monophonic instrument
column3: meaning that only one key can sound at a time
column4: which makes it mechanically impossible to play chords. As a result
column5: much of Borden's work on Music For Amplified Keyboard Instruments relies on interlocking melodies that are performed by three keyboard players
column6: each using two keyboards simultaneously. Together these figures add up to simple but frequently shifting harmonies. And there are convenient workarounds
column7: too. On one piece
column8: for instance
column9: Borden tunes one instrument to a perfect fifth
column10: so that when a single key is pressed
column11: the keyboard produces two simultaneous pitches. The results
column12: particularly on the pieces drawn from Borden's larger work
column13: ""The Complete Story of Counterpoint""
column14: are gorgeous and meditative.

column1: While Borden has not become quite as well recognized as some of his minimalist contemporaries
column2: like Reich or Philip Glass
column3: you can hear his influence deeply embedded in the music of recent synthesizer-oriented electronic outfits
column4: like Emeralds (whose former member
column5: John Elliot
column6: runs Spectrum Spools) or Daniel Lopatin
column7: Laurel Halo
column8: and James Ferraro
column9: all of whom collaborated with the composer in the seventh installment of RVNG's collaborative series
column10: FRKWYS. Most of these are musicians who perform electronic works in concert.

column1: It's important to recognize that the pieces on Amplified Keyboard Instruments were recorded live. Arpeggiated melodies and chords are central to synthesizer music
column2: whether applied in a Krautrock-style zone-out or club-friendly dance tune. However
column3: those figures are often automated using a sequencer. Borden's compositions on this record and also in Mother Mallard were performed in real time by individuals
column4: and while that made the music challenging to represent accurately
column5: it also allowed for deeper and more intricate harmonic movement
column6: which would have been time-consuming to program into an old-school hardware sequencer. And more than that
column7: it allows for a bit of sloppiness—an un-gridded feel and inherent emotionality that's tough for a computer to crack
column8:
even now.

In early 2011
column2: Purity Ring showed us the perfect balance for ""future pop"": Be ahead of your time
column3: but not toofar ahead.""Belispeak"" and ""Ungirthed"" perfectly anticipated the reframing of indie pop as festival-ready ""Internet music""
column4: and when Shrines came out
column5: about a year later

column7: kindred spirits who helped shift the sonic paradigm further away from guitars. But if pop listeners come for the songs
column8: they tend to stay for the personalities
column9: and this is the issue facing Purity Ring on another eternity. On their debut
column10: Megan James and Corin Roddick were hard to read and analysis-averse
column11: and they remain so. Their sound remains singular
column12: but is it still interesting?

column1: Staying the course

column3: isn’t that risky a proposition for them: The pop world seems right about where Shrines left it. Accordingly
column4: James and Roddick try to close the gap separating their vision of pop from actual pop. The bolder and brighter presentation of another eternity singles ""push pull"" and ""begin again"" gets them awfully close to latter-day Taylor Swift or Katy Perry; ""repetition"" could’ve popped up on If You’re Reading This It's Too Late or serve as a backing track for the next Miley Cyrus single
column5: all acts whose 2013-2014 output drew liberally from Purity Ring.

column1: But if Purity Ring don't have the advantage of novelty anymore
column2: their aesthetic is strong enough that familiarity becomes a decent substitute. Within the first minute of another eternity
column3: the ease of recognizing Purity Ring amongst their still-growing brood of imitators is actually startling. If the lower-case stylization of another eternity and its song titles seems overly precious
column4: at least it’s congruent with James’ distinct vocal approach. She works something like an origami expert
column5: quickly folding and refolding melodies until they’re acutely angled
column6: pointed
column7: and elegant.

column1: James’ lyrics explore the same juxtaposition of delicacy and danger
column2: though less so than on Shrines. She promised a more personal
column3: present-tense perspective than her past work
column4: and so her macabre
column5: childlike fascination with bodily functions is applied to more adult situations
column6: like breakups and such. At best
column7: James’ impressionism leaves an imprint on your brain—on ""repetition""
column8: the curious boast ""Watching me is like watching the fire take your eyes from you"" is delivered with enough gusto to hit at a gut level.

column2: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">However
column3: by posting the lyrics sheet
column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> prior to the release of another eternity
column5: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">
column6: the duo revealed as many ""o’ers"" and leering
column7: stiff turns of phrase as a Decemberists
column8: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> album (""Baby why don’t you see my sea/ Get inside and build your castle into me""). At times
column9: the moony metaphors devolve into Wordsworth Tumblr-jumble
column10: and on ""stillness in woe""
column11: James achieves a sort of Purity Ring singularity with one line: ""Meet me in the back shed/ I’ll be hanging up the knives/ Humming melodies that rhyme/ Building castles out of shovels.""

column1: It's this twee undercurrent that manages to keep Purity Ring nominally ""indie""
column2: and also provides crucial contrast with Roddick’s productions. Roddick wants to remind listeners more of Mike WiLL Made It and Noah ""40"" Shebib than Burial and the Knife this time
column3: and he makes everything sound more cushy and cavernous
column4: evoking the sensation of sitting on the most comfortable couch in the club after everyone leaves. Throughout
column5: Purity Ring manages to sound big without sounding <i>expensive
column6: forgoing nuance and detail for scalability. Stream it on laptop speakers and you can still picture every dazzling MIDI trigger in a live setting.

column1: James and Roddick altered their process for another eternity
column2: working together in the same studio
column3: and as a result they seem to have gravitated towards the sort of tricks meant to provoke an immediate
column4: contagious enthusiasm from the person standing right next to you. Credit to Purity Ring for being honest with themselves and acknowledging that they’ve spent the past couple of years playing festivals and collaborating with the bigger names in oddball mainstream rap (Angel Haze
column5: Danny Brown
column6: Ab-Soul). The beats that pop up during the hooks of opening duo ""heartsigh"" and ""bodyache"" are meant for bleacher stomping
column7: while there are legitimate ""Levels""-level drops on ""begin again"". Any sort of indignation feels misplaced—you might as well shake your fist at a rock song for containing a riff. But most of Roddick's ""new"" tricks could’ve ended up on Shrines
column8: whether it's the apparitional
column9: pitched-down vocals
column10: flickering Auto-Tune
column11: warped bass and a fairly brazen nick of Frank Ocean’s ""Thinkin Bout You"" on ""stranger than earth"". As a result
column12: it's difficult to tell when another eternity builds on Shrines and when Shrines is being stripped for parts.

column1: By every objective standard
column2: even the one set by its near-suffocatingly cohesive predecessor
column3: this is a narrow work. Eight of its 1o tracks clock in between 3:15 and 3:40
column4: and its tone
column5: timbre
column6: topicality and flow are pathologically even-keeled; there’s nothing to upset the equilibrium like Shrines' jarring Young Magic guest spot ""Grandloves"". Verses and choruses are pretty much equidistant at all times. You can imagine another eternity as beat-tape like source material
column7: where just about every melody could be extracted for outside hook use.

column1: Perhaps we should’ve saw that coming considering the numerous allusions to repetition and new starts in both the album and song titles. But the most worrisome bit of referentiality comes not from Roddick's production or James' melodies
column2: but from a recycling of Shrines’ most powerful image. That one came on ""Fineshrine""
column3: where James experienced a love so overwhelming and frightening
column4:
she asked them to climb inside her rib cage. ""seacastle"" likewise views sexual congress as a supernatural escape plan and on ""repetition"" she echoes the favor from ""Fineshrine""—""Climb up in my rattling spine and I’ll contract."" This obsession with connecting and disappearing in rapid succession is fitting for a record that finds Purity Ring trying to stake their claim at pop's center but ultimately retreating within themselves.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21445/homepage_large.fb53b288.jpg|Chasing Yesterday|29794.0|Noel Gallagher's High Flying Birds|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sour Mash']|2015-03-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:11.792319|"

The first time I recall feeling true disappointment as a child was when I was given The Beatles’ Story as a birthday gift. Tearing off the plastic and firing up my Fisher-Price turntable
column2: I eagerly prepared myself for four sides of Fab Four classics
column3: only to hear... a lot of talking. The double-album set
column4: it turned out
column5: was nothing but a hastily compiled Capitol Records Beatlemania cash-in that edited together various press conferences. For famed Fab Fourologist Noel Gallagher
column6: I can easily imagine a reverse scenario—judging by his post-2000 track record
column7: an album of nothing but his interviews would undoubtedly be way more entertaining than one of proper songs.

column1: Reading a conversation with Noel Gallagher is one of life’s great pleasures. He’s quick-witted
column2: unguarded
column3: cheerily self-effacing—pretty much everything that the overly mannered music he’s making these days is not. His second foray with the High Flying Birds ventures further afield than his 2011 debut
column4: but still succumbs to the same issues—most notably
column5: a palpable joylessness
column6: and the extra strain that puts on Gallagher’s modest voice and piecemeal lyrics.

column1: Considering its creator’s penchant for playful plagiarism—not to mention the fact he’s staring down the 20th anniversary of his career best—you’ll find no richer album title this year than Chasing Yesterday. And in that regard
column2: the man doesn’t let us down: The opening ""Riverman"" alone cops its title from Nick Drake
column3: its acoustic groove from Gallagher’s biggest hit
column4: its first line from the Beatles’ ""Something""
column5: and its dreamy brass breakdown from Pink Floyd’s ""Shine On Your Crazy Diamond"". And the second-hand hits keep-a-comin’: ""The Girl With X-Ray Eyes"" puts Bowie’s raygun to her head; the album’s one true rave-up
column6: ""Lock All the Doors""
column7: finds Gallagher once again chained to the mirror and the razor blade
column8: albeit with a copy of David Essex’s Rock On on-hand as a back-up snorting surface. (And that’s not even the most Oasis-y song on here—that one’s called
column9: natch
column10: ""You Know We Can’t Go Back"".)

column1: Sure
column2: itemizing the song quotes in Noel Gallagher songs is a bit like counting all the f-bombs in a Tarantino flick
column3: a futile exercise in duh. But where Oasis once invested their obvious influences with an attitude and swagger undeniably their own
column4: here Gallagher's like the leader of a consummate cocktail-hour cover act
column5: momentarily piquing your interest with the sound of your favorite tune before tastefully receding into the background. Without brutish brother Liam around to personify his most primal emotions
column6: Noel and the Birds can’t do much but maintain a steady cruising altitude
column7: rarely working up the will to truly soar.

column1: Of course
column2: even in Oasis’ mid-'90s glory
column3: Gallagher was never an especially deep songwriter
column4: but his shopworn sentiments at least felt genuinely lived-in and relatable. (And
column5: ultimately
column6: those songs made you feel really good
column7: and you’re willing to forgive a lot when you feel good.) The moody
column8: mid-tempo torpor of Chasing Yesterday only emphasizes the fact that
column9: as Gallagher’s songs have turned more narrative and descriptive in his later years
column10: they’ve become more emotionally vague. Pretty much every tune here sees him pining for some mystical
column11: unattainable woman
column12: but with all the hazy cosmic jive about being ""shot from the sun like a bullet from a gun"" and ""dreaming about a revolution"" and a ""girl who electrifies the storm
column13: Gallagher isn’t so much burning his heart out as slipping inside the eye of his mind. And while the bloozy bar-band guitar/sax interplay would be enough to sink ""The Mexican"" on its own
column14: its restraining-order-worthy come-on—""You say you need love/ Just like a kid on crack""—makes it sound like Gallagher tests out his pick-up lines after watching reruns of Cops.

column1: But while the songwriting may be on autopilot
column2: Gallagher’s decision to self-produce Chasing Yesterday was a smart one
column3: resulting in an album that feels both intimate and expansive. Hands-down album highlight ""The Right Stuff"" reminds us that Noel does his best work with a foil—in this case
column4: guest vocalist Joy Rose
column5: whose simmering verses lend Gallagher's mid-song takeover a sense of occasion
column6: while goading saxophonist Jim Hunt into some destabilizing psychedelic squawking. In a recent interview for the album
column7: Gallagher ranked ""The Right Stuff"" and the similarly nomadic (if less captivating) ""Riverman"" as among the Top 12 songs he’s written. If this portends further excursions in uncharted terrain
column8:
let’s hope it’s the rare interview where Noel Gallagher’s not taking the piss.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21467/homepage_large.0e9e9aee.jpg|Lead Belly: The Smithsonian Folkways Collection|32724.0|Lead Belly|['Folk/Country']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Smithsonian Folkways']|2015-03-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:12.284487|"

Prestige box sets of pre-rock music that out-price the casual fan or curious newcomer tend to emphasize an artist’s importance and influence
column2: carefully delineating his or her legacy across subsequent generations of followers. You listen because it’s good for you
column3: is the implication
column4: which is certainly worthwhile as far as that goes. But rarely is this type of retrospective quite as much fun as Lead Belly: The Smithsonian Folkways Collection. It’s not only the first full career retrospective of one of the most significant musicians of the twentieth century. It’s also a blast.

column1: We have an image of Lead Belly as a somber bluesman
column2: a stoic song collector who wore a perpetually solemn expression like that on the cover of the new 5xCD set. That was
column3: of course
column4: only one side of the musician
column5: who memorized and personalized a vast array of American work songs
column6: play songs
column7: Tin Pan Alley hits
column8: spirituals
column9: blues
column10: ballads
column11: reels
column12: hollers
column13: jigs
column14: calls
column15: and more. He was as much a raconteur as he was a songster
column16: and when he has a chance to tell you all about a song—where it came from
column17: how he heard it
column18: why it sounds the way it does
column19: or how it fits into your everyday life—Lead Belly reveals the dynamism of a great storyteller. When he introduces ""Leaving Blues"" during a radio broadcast
column20: Lead Belly declaims the nature of the blues with a preacherly cadence
column21: which turns a sad situation into something almost comical. The story lasts longer than the actual song: For him talk is not just crucial to the music
column22: but a kind of music in and of itself.

column1: ""Fun"" is not the first word applied to Huddie ""Lead Belly"" Ledbetter because certain aspects of his life were inflated in the 1930s and '40s and have yet to deflate. He did serve prison sentences for manslaughter—at Imperial State Prison Farm in Texas and Angola in Louisiana
column2: both notoriously brutal institutions—and he managed to sing his way out of them. When he moved to New York City
column3: the press played up his past at the expense of his music; the New York Herald previewed an early performance with the sensationalist headline
column4: ""Sweet Singer of the Swamplands Here to Do a Few Tunes Between Homicides"". As archivist and curator Jeff Place points out in the liner notes here
column5: it was an all too common attitude at the time.

column1: Over the course of his relatively short 15-year recording career
column2: Lead Belly met many sympathetic label executives
column3: producers
column4: and fellow musicians who promoted him as a dynamic entertainer and an accomplished songster
column5: but he never truly escaped the condescending ""noble savage"" stigma attached to him by the liberal elite of the Northeast. Nor did he achieve much popular success during his lifetime. He sold primarily to a small community of folk fans in and around New York
column6: but never made a considerable impact beyond the city. In that regard
column7: he was a man slightly out of time. It was just a few years after his death in 1949 when folk became big business
column8: when the songs he had preserved became mainstays in coffeehouses and concert halls. Without Lead Belly
column9: the folk revival of Dylan
column10: Baez
column11: and Fred Neil would have been very different
column12: and it might not have happened at all.

column1: Lead Belly also left his mark on rock'n'roll. What’s remarkable about this collection is just how familiar many of these songs already are. ""Black Girl (Where Did You Sleep Last Night)"" is perhaps best known to many via Nirvana’s 1993 Unplugged performance
column2: but there’s also ""The Midnight Special"" (a hit for Creedence Clearwater Revival
column3: among others) and ""Black Betty"" (Ram Jam
column4: Tom Jones
column5: Jon Spencer Blues Explosion). ""Pick a Bale of Cotton"" and ""Rock Island Line"" formed the foundation of the UK skiffle movement in the 1950s
column6: and Led Zeppelin more or less stole ""The Gallis Pole"" riff
column7: lyrics
column8: and all. Lead Belly didn’t write all of these songs
column9: but he collected them from a variety of sources—other cotton pickers in Texas
column10: other inmates
column11: other musicians
column12: family members
column13: friends—and put his indelible stamp on them. Most subsequent artists discovered these songs through his versions.

column1: The first three discs of The Smithsonian Folkways Collection are as fine a retrospective as you can find for Lead Belly
column2: showcasing the diversity of his repertoire and the precision of his playing and singing. (For those who don’t have the $100 for this box set
column3: many of these tracks were compiled on Smithsonian Folkways’ Lead Belly Legacy series
column4: any of which makes a fine entry point into his vast catalog.) What distinguishes this collection is its scope: There have been hundreds of Lead Belly comps released over the last half-century
column5: but too few put his best-known material alongside his radio performances and final sessions
column6: which are included on the fourth and fifth discs. Recorded during the 1940s for a folk series on WNYC
column7: his radio broadcasts show him in a looser setting where the distinctions between his patter and his playing seem to disappear. Whether he’s singing solo or accompanied by the Oleander Quartet
column8: he’s an outsize personality on the airwaves
column9: especially during the two 15-minute programs that allow him to regale his imagined
column10: invisible audience with stories as well as songs.

column1: The final disc includes songs from what would be Lead Belly’s last sessions in 1948. His voice sounds noticeably weaker
column2: with an uneasy grain in his syllables that has less to do with age and more to do with the onset of ALS. He’d be dead in a year
column3: but as shaky as his voice may be
column4: it is no less certain in its phrasing
column5: whether he’s rhapsodizing with a Bessie Smith record on ""Nobody Knows You When You’re Down and Out"" or singing ""Stewball"" accompanied only by backing vocals and handclaps. It’s tempting to read anything called ""Last Sessions"" as poignant
column6: but Lead Belly brings a very familiar exuberance to ""It’s Tight Like That"" and ""House of the Rising Son"".

column1: It’s fitting that the final track on The Smithsonian Folkways Collection isn’t a song
column2: but a brief monologue called ""In the World""
column3: based on a half-remembered conversation from long ago. It makes for a fitting epilogue to this monumental box set
column4: primarily because it reveals Lead Belly’s role as an archivist of American music
column5: passing tunes and ideas along from one person to the next
column6: from one generation to the next. ""We all gotta get peace together because we’re in the world together
column7:
he muses. ""I never heard nothing like it. Now you got it now.""

It’s easy to make assumptions about Brooklyn trio EULA based on the company they keep: They’ve been a regular opening act for Mission of Burma and recorded their latest album with NYC underground vet Martin Bisi (who had a hand in the nastiest Sonic Youth and Swans records)
column2: while frontwoman Alyse Lamb recently extolled the virtues of Lydia Lunch on Michael Azerrad’s site The Talkhouse. And it’s a rather fortuitous coincidence that the band’s scabrous sophomore album
column3: Wool Sucking
column4: should drop at the same time that Kim Gordon’s Girl in a Band hit shelves to re-stoking interest in the early '80s East Coast avant-punk scene to which EULA pledge spiritual allegiance. But just as New York is a vastly different place than it was 30 years ago
column5: EULA put a friendly face on an aesthetic synonymous with self-loathing nihilism. They may be trudging through the same sewers as their forbears
column6: but they’re greatful for the sunlight poking through the grates.

column1: Wool Sucking is
column2: in essence
column3: an album of love songs
column4: though Lamb isn’t so much interested in communicating passion as transmitting what it does to you physiologically—the destabilizing sense of vulnerability
column5: the sweaty-palmed nervousness
column6: the heart-racing agitation. This is an album where every come-on doubles as a grave warning (""I collapse into you/ Be careful what you do… can you handle nasty weather?"")
column7: where caring too much leads to cardiac arrest (""My heart needs an orderly/ To keep it from exploding"")
column8: where innocence blurs into innuendo (""I could love you/ Like a mother""). Lamb was a ballet kid
column9: and you can sense that appreciation for theatricality in her acrobatic
column10: acquired-taste vocals
column11: which allow her to harmonize and play call-and-response with herself as if trying to give all the competing voices in her head an equal say. The music behind her is equally excitable and unsettled
column12: a roiling tempest of blues-battered scuzz (""Meadows"" revs up like the Allmans’ ""Whipping Post"" relocated to an S&M dungeon)
column13: doomsday basslines
column14: and fractious drum patterns that imagines where the Yeah Yeah Yeahs might be today if they never returned Interscope’s phone calls.

column1: At times
column2: EULA’s impulsive energy can manifest into ineffectual thrashing (see: ""Aplomb"")
column3: but
column4: in light of their more scattered 2011 debut
column5: Maurice Narcisse—which absorbed influences from disco to cow-punk—Wool Sucking wisely focuses on what the band do best: writhing rockers and disquieting
column6: oddly affecting ballads. In the latter mode
column7: not only do EULA project a surprising emotional depth
column8: but—through the deceptively calm pastorales of ""The Destroyer"" and “Monument”—also liberate themselves from the New York skronk-punk tradition to which they’re so often tied. And the quieter presentation only amplifies the symbiotic relationship between desire and destruction that forms the core of this album. When Lamb sings
column9: ""I will take your beat/ If you will take my heart"" on the chilling
column10: dying-embered torch song ""Your Beat""
column11:
you’re not sure if she's exchanging wedding vows or forging a suicide pact.

In certain parts of Boston
column2: Pile are beheld with the kind of reverence traditionally reserved for local sporting heroes and/or minor deities. Envied by their peers—Krill snuck a song about listening to Pile
column3: awestruck
column4: on a 2014 EP—and idolized by a growing army of diehards

column7: You're Better Than This—Maguire's already given up on King-dom: ""I'll never be Elvis
column8: I guess—one big
column9: moist bag of garbage."" So this is the Pile your cousin at MassArt's been raving about: the kind of band who'd take a startlingly gorgeous instrumental and give it a name like ""Fuck the Police
column10:
"" or reserve what just might be You're Better's tenderest moment for a half-remembered dream about ""customer servicing"" Maguire's second-grade teacher.

The knotty
column11: hermetic You're Better is
column12: above all else
column13: a profoundly skittish record
column14: prone to sudden outbursts and wild mood swings. The music on You're Better is gnarly and volatile: Even in its tenderest moments
column15: you can sense the encroaching dread. Pile's clotted
column16: cacophonous

column18: dander-up feel; even the songs you swear you know by heart seem to break off into wild tangents at a moment's notice. But Pile aren't simply thrashing for its own sake here; they're seeking to discombobulate. So
column19: while

column22: in fact
column24: laboriously plotted flare-ups meant to mirror the buzz and howl inside Maguire's head.

column1: So what's Maguire been losing sleep over these days? Well
column2: there's the little stuff
column3: like his utter helplessness with paperwork
column4: or his résumé
column5: which even he'll admit
column6: ""while less than impressive

column8: the specter of the past lingering over his every move. Maguire has a gift for rendering these emotional states in physical terms: On ""Yellow Room""
column9: for instance
column10: he recalls a moment in which his ""heart turned into a fist when my body can't move."" ""Hot Breath"" is written entirely on the body
column11: a laundry list of physical stress responses. Elsewhere

column13: or Maguire waiting ""as patiently as [he] can for [his] heart to ache again."" This cross-wiring of mental anguish with physical distress mirrors the fitful structure of You're Better. Maguire's not one to let these cognitive wrinkles go un-ironed; he really wants to get in there
column14: to dig in deep
column15:
and the music crackles and explodes alongside Maguire's over-firing neurons.

Spending 37 minutes with Maguire while he catalogs his—and
column16: by extension
column17: your—indiscretions might sound like a slog
column18: but Maguire makes for awfully good company. For one
column19: he's onto himself; on ""Appendicitis""
column20: which follows a good half-hour of bloodletting
column21: Maguire likens his troubles to an ""inflatable cross
column22: something he carries around to make himself seem more interesting. That
column23: and he's just weird as hell; on ""Tin Foil Hat""
column24: he likens himself to both a plumber and physicist. And
column27: is a curiously heartening record. Maguire's not big on pointing fingers or casting aspersions; his problems
column28: he'd be the first to admit

column30: obsessing over something we should've done or shouldn't have said. By delving deep into these loneliest of moments
column32: I do all this dumb shit
column34:
and there's a strange sort of comfort in that.

As buzzy new albums from indie rock up-and-comers go
column35: it's a particularly uneasy listen. While the cloistered

column37: it occasionally comes at the cost of clarity. Maguire's got no shortage of material

column44:
and Maguire's screams-of-consciousness. But that's precisely what inspires such devotion in Pile's growing cohort: They're not interested in being something to everyone when they can be everything to someone.

column11: zone out
column12: and coast on that perfect sound forever. And in terms of appealing to jam-band enthusiasts—well
column13: what demographic can better relate to a song like ""Stoned and Starving""?

column1: Alas
column2: that standout from Parquet Courts’ 2012 breakthrough Light Up Gold is nowhere to be found on the band’s new live album. But in lieu of such readymade 420 clarion calls
column3: Parquet Courts assert their jam-band bona fides the old fashioned way: by stretching four-minute songs into 10-minute songs. Cut last June at Third Man’s intimate Blue Room venue-cum-recording studio
column4: Live at Third Man Records is essentially Parquet Court’s 2014 Sunbathing Animal (of its 11 tracks
column5: this release features 10 songs from that record) if it were left to scorch in the desert a little longer.

column1: Listening to this album
column2: I’m reminded of an old legend about the Pixies playing select concerts backwards—i.e.
column3: opening the concert with the encore
column4: leaving the stage
column5: and then returning to play their proper set in reverse order. Because in this context
column6: the blitzkrieged banter of ""Duckin & Dodgin"" sounds less like an introduction than the sort of delirious high point a band hits two hours into a marathon set
column7: when they’re running on nothing but adrenaline. Following that
column8: it’s actually something of a miracle that singer/guitarist Andrew Savage has anything left for the rest of the show
column9: but his increasingly hoarse hectoring actually serves to streamline Sunbathing Animal’s grab-bag selections
column10: investing the proto-punk shimmy of ""Black & White"" and the Minutemen-esque oddity ""Vienna II"" with the same brutish urgency.

column1: So when the alternately comforting and needling riff to ""Instant Disassembly"" emerges at the halfway point
column2: it not only presents the band with a deserved opportunity to exhale
column3: but also nudges Savage and Austin Brown toward a twin-guitar fadeout that effectively transforms the song from Parquet Courts’ ""Here"" into its ""Free Bird"". But Parquet Courts take their greatest liberties with the roughshod rumble of ""Raw Milk""
column4: which gets distended to more than twice its original length through an extended feedback meltdown that proves to be an unexpectedly affecting setup for Sunbathing Animal’s closing ballad ""Into the Garden"". Parquet Courts may not be playing Bonnaroo this year
column5: though in many respects
column6: they're already there. However
column7:
the closing charge through Sunbathing Animal’s hardcore-hammered title track serves as a warning that you hacky-sack to these guys at your own risk.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21550/homepage_large.274a9d67.jpg|Dance 4 a Dollar EP|28468.0|MNDR|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""Fool's Gold""]"|2015-02-27 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:16.351560|"

Can something be ""stoner dance music""? The term sounds oxymoronic
column2: invoking a Bonnaroovian nightmare of twirling and wiggling
column3: but Dance 4 a Dollar—a collaborative EP between Wavves’ Nathan Williams and his brother Kynan’s production duo Sweet Valley and gear-head electro-pop savant Amanda Warner
column4: aka MNDR—is precisely that. Sweet Valley’s rap output has always been a counterpoint to Nathan’s slacked-out rock music
column5: but it's still decidedly too lo-fi to match the high gloss of MNDR tracks like ""Fade to Black"" and ""Feed Me Diamonds"". Yet
column6: somehow
column7: the three (along with producer Peter Wade) have crafted something hazy and gleaming that isn’t always fighting itself. The five-track collection sounds like it is coming apart at the seams throughout
column8: but some of its threads are luxurious.

column1: The EP opens with Warner cooing
column2: ""Hello
column3: status quo"" over bathwater synths and sleigh bells
column4: almost as if she’s nodding ironically at their unconventional grouping. The track
column5: ""Like Liars""
column6: boasts the most crystalline vocals of the project—which
column7: frankly
column8: should be the most highlighted element here—and you can hear Nathan and Kynan trying to squeeze in too many details
column9: many of which feel like weeded-out epiphanies that would have been removed in the sober light of day. There is evidence that Sweet Valley’s woozy production can work nicely alongside something more upbeat: Back in 2012
column10: Kynan flipped Joanie Sommers’ patriarchy-praising ""Johnny Get Angry"" for Lakutis’ lackadaisical ""Too Ill for the Law"". The sound was fuzzy
column11: but the vibe was hyperfocused. Dance 4 a Dollar could have used some of that precision.

column1: This is not to say that the fill-every-cranny-with-another-bleep-bloop-or-blorp approach to the EP is always ineffective. Among the five tracks
column2: some of the chaos works. ""Tongues Like Ghosts"" is what Rihanna would release if she ever has an LSD phase. The songwriting hews closer to MNDR’s work
column3: sounding enormous and immersive despite the EP’s anarchy. The project is overall a little bit lyrically impotent—the phrase ""Live fast
column4: die young"" should heed its own advice—but Warner turns heads occasionally with curious lines like ""Let’s make love like liars."" The powerful moments are like that
column5: confronting you with something that makes little sense but still sounds beautiful.

column1: Where the collection suffers is when it feels like Sweet Valley’s woozy production takes over. ""Do It Everyday"" is an erratic lullaby. It volleys between sparse melancholia with clip-clopping production that bolsters Warner’s voice and skittering synths which clog up the track. When Warner sings
column2: ""We don’t give a fuck/ And we know it
column3: it’s a little too on the nose. The glitchy ""HoldMeAlways MakeBelieve""
column4: meanwhile
column5: is bogged down by too many electronic bells and whistles
column6: which nearly mask Warner’s vocals. When yet another shooting-star synth grazes the track
column7: it’s like learning for the first time that when you mix all the paint colors you don’t get a rainbow
column8: you just get mud. But
column9: perhaps
column10:
mud is where stoner dance music belongs.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21514/homepage_large.27336424.jpg|O Shudder|30873.0|Dutch Uncles|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Memphis Industries']|2015-02-27 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:17.088102|"

In 2013
column2: after the release of their third LP Out of Touch in the Wild
column3: Dutch Uncles were plucked from the indie playground to join Paramore’s European stadium tour. Hard-earned though the break was
column4: the quintet seemed an arbitrary pick. Over the last half-decade
column5: northern England has reared a sharp and brainy brood of art-pop omnivores
column6: but Dutch Uncles err on the vegetarian side: They’re sleek
column7: but Wild Beasts are sleeker; they tweak Field Music’s oddball bombast without revamping it; and they tap into a weirdo-pop accessibility that’s neither as weird nor accessible as Everything Everything’s. Given the occasion
column8: their fourth record might have been a bells-and-whistles induction to pop’s champagne elite
column9: but in typically moderate fashion
column10: O Shudder is less concerned with the party booze than the kitchenware.

column1: That could be a criticism
column2: but inertia suits them. Dutch Uncles still sound spritely
column3: but as their thirties loom
column4: O Shudder finds them shaping up to settle down. Rather than an agonising compromise
column5: their songs confront domesticity as a playful challenge: Opener ""Babymaking"" fathoms parenthood like a rigged Rubik’s Cube
column6: while ""In N Out"" sketches a sexual entanglement in lyrical riddles as slippy and perplexing as interesting relationships invariably are. It’s an album wounded by suspicion and longing
column7: but the band stay bright and limber
column8: perhaps leaving disenchantment to those fool enough to have been enchanted to begin with.

column1: Holding it up is Duncan Wallis
column2: the kind of mildly eccentric pop singer who seems like he’d spend a long time ironing his shirts. Where marketable songwriters weaponize potent emotions
column3: or at least sound certain of their uncertainty
column4: Wallis precariously grasps for tangible feelings that rarely materialize. On ""I Should Have Read"" he navigates criss-cross piano lines with chronic trepidation
column5: his shy falsetto evoking a child in a mirror maze; on job-hunt saga ""Decided Knowledge"" he blurts jumpy exclamations
column6: flitting between inner and outer monologues
column7: as if he finds it awkward to have a voice at all.

column1: If Wallis’ exhortations find solace
column2: it’s in the backdrop’s orchestral splendour
column3: a complex lattice of woodwind
column4: strings
column5: percussion
column6: and marimba that winds up feeling improbably cosy and lived-in. The band’s secret weapon is Robin Richards
column7: their composer and bassist
column8: and his handiwork here glistens
column9: ranging from elegantly odd curiosities (""Babymaking""
column10: ""Drips"") to obscenely lovely mini-symphonies (""I Should Have Read""
column11: ""Given Thing""). On the livelier ""Upsilon"" and ""Don’t Sit Back (Frankie Said)""
column12: Dutch Uncles defibrillate third- or fourth-hand R&B with twinkly synths and piston bass pops
column13: signposting the sort of disjointed grooves by Japan and Talking Heads that might’ve soundtracked their parents’ own baby-making.

column1: Maybe it’s telling that their most obvious touchstones—Speaking in Tongues
column2: early Prefab Sprout—hail from Reagan and Thatcher’s '80s. Recession-ready and armed against austerity
column3: Dutch Uncles write physically involving tunes that rectify UK indie’s groove deficit while tentatively reviving the vast emotion of balladeers like Tears for Fears. The formula seems corny
column4: but when Dutch Uncles fall short
column5: it’s for the opposite reason: Though the busy
column6: Reichian loops help decorate the retro palette
column7: it's the sort of intricacy that can encase art-pop in bulletproof glass
column8: demanding admiration without meeting us halfway. At its best
column9: though
column10: O Shudder's timeworn skill is to combat looming adversity with verve and rhythm
column11:
emptying the mind through the body.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21526/homepage_large.712643b9.jpg|The Long Goodbye|32754.0|An Autumn for Crippled Children|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Wicker Man']|2015-02-27 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:17.738431|"

An Autumn for Crippled Children are exemplars of blackgaze
column2: the increasingly popular subgenre that takes inspiration from black metal and shoegaze. Naturally
column3: they're bound to get comparisons to Deafheaven and Alcest
column4: and while they are contemporaries of both
column5: they barely resemble one another. On the surface
column6: they keep black metal’s fuzzy hum that Alcest and others have consciously dropped. The Dutch trio also exert much more of a post-hardcore influence
column7: which is evident in their shorter songs. More significantly
column8: there’s a damaged aspect to their music
column9: with strings and synths breaking out haphazardly. The Long Goodbye is their fifth full-length release
column10: following Try Not to Destroy Everything You Love
column11: which honed their sound while keeping it endearingly messy. This album cleans up some more of the racket.

column1: Unlike most bands who focus more on the gaze than the black
column2: AAFCC still have a fairly abrasive guitar tone
column3: evident in the opening rings of the title track. You can detect a melody beneath
column4: but despite the dream pop influences
column5: the guitars are more blinding than soothing. Even so
column6: there’s variety to be found in Goodbye
column7: an advantage brought on by shorter overall song lengths. ""A New Form of Stillness"" is jangle pop under the spell of the second wave—grimness comes after bounciness. There are plenty of black metallers who will jam New Order on the low
column8: but the bassline from ""Stillness"" makes AAFCC's fandom public. ""Endless Skies"" (which has a vaguely trip-hop intro) and ""The Sleep of Rust"" are set within a depressive black metal framework
column9: but the conflicting nature of grime and glory presented throughout Goodbye adds a dimension most sadsacks can’t comprehend. ""She’s Drawing Mountains"" may be the highlight of the album
column10: as the melodies flex and compete with the onslaught of blackened drone.

column1: Goodbye’s synth work is what raises AAFCC above the blackgaze fray. Like most black metal keyboards
column2: they’re not technically complex and primarily function as ambient waves; where they differ with AAFCC is that they can be an antagonizing force in addition to the guitars. They don’t exactly intrude upon the music
column3: but they don’t make a graceful entrance either. In ""When Night Leaves Again"" they’re particularly unsettling
column4: as if encouraging the drums to lose their composure. ""Only Skin""’s intro comes at you like bright lights and a refreshing bucket of water dumped on your worst hangover. The torrent that surfaces afterwards is almost a relief. There was a period in time when black metal bands boasted about not using keyboards—thankfully
column5: AAFCC weren’t paying attention.

column1: Listening to Goodbye
column2: it’s evident that AAFCC are also students of Lifelover
column3: a Swedish band who were pioneers in mixing post-punk and black metal. Before guitarist and leader B’s passing in 2011
column4: they found a way to make Burzum’s buzz blend with the Cure’s basslines
column5: and few have been able to match them since. Lifelover also had a knack for somber piano melodies that would drive the song more than the guitars on the forefront; AAFCC channel this at the end of ""Converging Towards the Light""
column6: where the piano nearly overtakes the guitar during the final hurrah. AAFCC aren’t clones—they mutate Lifelover’s ethos into a gnarlier
column7: and at the same time beautiful
column8:
sound.
