0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21547/homepage_large.f4df0208.jpg|Future Brown|31889.0|Future Brown|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2015-02-26 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:18.325560|"

All right
column2: enough with ""forward-thinking"" already. By now
column3: it’s up there with ""ethereal"" as one of the most mercilessly abused descriptors in the music critic’s arsenal
column4: and I’m still not exactly sure what it means. Sometimes it feels like nothing but buzz terminology for tastemaker companies like record label Fade to Mind
column5: ""post-Internet lifestyle magazine"" DIS Magazine
column6: or youth-centric streetwear label Hood by Air. It’s easy to see why we’re so drawn to the concept
column7: though. In Internet media especially
column8: our appetite for newness has grown almost unsustainable—fuck right now
column9: what’s happening next? All this ""forward thinking"" has dropped us at a disorienting crossroads: We’ve got unprecedented access to previously unreachable parts of the world
column10: a constantly refreshing news feed
column11: we’ve got 27 tabs open
column12: and oh god
column13: we’re still so terribly bored.

column1: In concept
column2: Future Brown’s promise is both realistic and utopian: A multi-media reflection of club and street music from across the globe
column3: lovingly curated
column4: and an idealistic glimpse of what the Internet at its best can facilitate—a democracy where genre is revealed as a construct so the real fun can begin. The project is a natural extension of the work of its four members: producer and composer Fatima Al Qadiri
column5: Lit City Trax founder J-Cush
column6: and Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda of production/DJ duo Nguzunguzu. These guys are known for their omnivorous
column7: boundary-refuting DJ sets and club nights as much as their official releases; Nguzunguzu’s Perfect Lullaby set a new standard for post-regional
column8: no-rules DJ mixes in 2011. With their self-titled debut album
column9: released via Warp
column10: the ethos is the same but the budget is bigger: The quartet provides the beats for a rotating cast of featured guests who traffic in styles as seemingly disparate as bop
column11: grime
column12: dancehall
column13: and drill. Theoretically
column14: everyone is pushed out of their respective comfort zones
column15: geography-defying parallels are drawn
column16: underappreciated street artists get some well-deserved shine
column17: and we all turn up in the process. Everyone wins!

column1: Theoretically
column2: that is. But if we are to invest so heavily in theory here
column3: we should probably get our theories straight. As Future Brown’s members would describe it
column4: this is very much a free-form
column5: vibes-based passion project
column6: steered by the unrestricted contributions of the featured collaborators as much as the producers’ whims. ""It’s all on accident. The thing that unites Future Brown is that there’s very little agenda
column7: said Al Qadiri in a T Magazine feature earlier this month.

column1: But for a freewheeling happy accident
column2: there’s a fair bit of vague art school conceptualism floating around the project. The video for ""Vernáculo""
column3: featuring Maluca
column4: premiered at Art Basel last year as ""an exercise in capitalist surrealism"" (a descriptor that could easily apply to Art Basel itself). There’s the glossy and hi-def basketball imagery
column5: the sort of winking
column6: hyper-mundane meta-commercial iconography we’ve come to expect from DIS Magazine
column7: who designed the album art. These slapped-on layers of meaning only distract from what this project could be at its best: surprising
column8: accessible
column9: genuinely utopian.

column1: If the project’s sense of purpose seems a bit scattershot on paper—it’s about everything and nothing
column2: partying and post-postmodernism
column3: global street music and the New York art world
column4: commodity fetishism and basketball—that ambiguity is even more apparent in sound. As thrilling as this tracklist appears at a glance—UK grime originators butting up against Chicago drill newcomers! Generations of feminist rap underbosses aligning!—the resulting tracks are weirdly unremarkable. The album has its moments: on ""Big Homie""
column5: icy steel drums draw Sicko Mobb’s Lil Trav and Lil Ceno out of their usual Rainbow Road soundscapes into somewhere colder and more cavernous.

column1: But for a project lauded as progressive
column2: I’m not so sure what’s being pushed forward here. We’ve heard sounds like these
column3: and better
column4: on Future Brown’s solo members’ side projects. We’ve seen these visual aesthetics (frankly
column5: they peaked in 2012 on Jam City’s Classical Curves album art). And most regrettably
column6: the featured artists’ guest spots rarely do justice to what makes them special in their own right. Even Tink
column7: the irrepressible
column8: multi-talented Chicagoan who Timbaland’s called the next Aaliyah
column9: sounds just okay on her two showcases here. ""Room 302"" and ""Wanna Party"" are decent songs
column10: but instead of a mutually stimulating partnership
column11: they kinda sound like Tink verses plopped over grime beats.

column1: Club music doesn’t need to come with a thesis to be worthy of further investigation—if anything
column2: a thesis is an impediment. But if you’re going to start a conversation
column3: you should be prepared to finish it
column4: and Future Brown feels overwhelmingly like a bunch of intriguing ideas left to drift off inconclusively. It’s an album of aesthetics and not many ideas
column5: and that’s just fine. But it’s okay to let a basketball be a basketball
column6: and not an orb imbued with the power of community
column7: or something. It would seem that Future Brown has been so focused on forward motion that they’ve gotten ahead of themselves. The thrill of discovery from unexpected juxtapositions
column8: the kind that makes you feel like the world is a more intimate
column9: interconnected place
column10: that happens organically in the Future Brown members’ DJ sets
column11: doesn’t feel as thrilling as promised.

column1: Earlier this month
column2: Maroof quietly released a DJ mix
column3: under solo moniker MA Nguzu
column4: for club label Tobago Tracks: 20 minutes
column5: no tracklist
column6: pretty straightforward. It presents itself as nothing other than what it is
column7: and it is wonderful. Chris Brown’s ""Loyal"" collides with bhangra; dancehall artist Kranium’s mellow ""Nobody Has To Know"" sits atop Kid Ink’s glossy ""Show Me""
column8: which in itself borrows from Robin S.’s ""Show Me Love"". Hell
column9: even an Iggy Azalea collaboration sounds cool in context. It’s effortless
column10: uncomplicated
column11:
and genuinely surprising; it’s endlessly more compelling than Future Brown.

The first skit on Dena Tape 2
column2: Hodgy Beats's first full-length since 2010
column3: will induce déjà vu in hardcore Odd Future fans. A hopeless stan approaches Hodgy for a photo at what sounds like the annual Odd Future carnival
column4: in much the same manner as the fans who accosted <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29179-tyler-the-creator/"">Tyler
column5: the Creator at Six Flags on the OF mastermind's ""Colossus"". Tyler’s song went on to explore the dicey relationship between artists and fans who take their every word as gospel
column6: but Hodgy doesn't seem to have given the issue quite as much thought. Rather than dig into the skit
column7: or go anywhere with it
column8: he regards the fan with total contempt and excuses himself
column9: promising to return. A couple of tracks later
column10: in the skit’s sequel
column11: he’s schooling us on his favorite hash
column12: the pesky admirer abandoned and long-forgotten.

column1: Gerard Damien Long has never displayed the commitment of others in his camp
column2: preferring instead to leap from idea to idea as fast as his jagged
column3: lightning bolt flow will take him. On his new tape
column4: despite his clear effort to inject some substance into his work
column5: what we see is largely more of the same. As always
column6: Hodgy excels at blasé funtime rap
column7: replete with guns and drugs and sex and little in the way of effective personal exploration or storytelling.

column1: Hodgy’s efforts to grow have been the selling point of the tape
column2: and it’s quite obvious when he’s trying to show that he’s matured: on ""Cudda Been""
column3: ""Moneyball"" and ""HakuemeniB"" he drops his usual demonic grin and raps solemnly over beats originally used by Lupe Fiasco
column4: Kendrick Lamar and OutKast. But Hodgy has trouble channeling the spirits of these more thoughtful rappers
column5: and his stabs at frank discussion come across as discombobulated and unfocused. At one point on ""Moneyball"" he dedicates a couple of bars to an unclear thought about the relationship between greed and President Obama. Either he doesn’t care to work out what he’s trying to say
column6: or he isn’t really trying to say anything at all. In any case
column7: the next line begins a short discussion of his relationship with a stripper.

column1: Hodgy explains his own personality on the best of these tracks
column2: ""HakuemeniB""
column3: giving us some insight into his weaknesses on wax. He admits to being compulsive and heated
column4: and generally comes across as a hedonist with a heart of gold. It follows
column5: then
column6: that he remains best over punchy
column7: percussive beats. On Dena Tape 2
column8: he slays tracks like ""Da Man"" and ""Wild Boy"" through a light-fingered flow reminiscent of Azealia Banks at her most agile. Like Banks
column9: Hodgy is purposively provocative
column10: but there isn’t any particular ideological force driving his edgier rhymes
column11: which are often racial jabs like ""Asian eyes like a nigga rap for rice."" (It's worth mentioning that he's part Filipino.) He simply thrives on mayhem
column12: and when fenced in by highly structured
column13: rhythmic production
column14: he shines.

column1: The original Dena Tape was the first solo project ever released under the crew’s umbrella
column2: according to the Odd Future subreddit. Since that time
column3: Hodgy’s had a son
column4: grown from the age of 19 to 24
column5: and released or been featured on over a dozen tapes. And yet it seems like he can’t help but to keep things light. To celebrate himself rather than think about his failings
column6: to toss off an easy punch line instead of working to craft a complex thought
column7: and to mock his loser fans rather than genuinely try to understand
column8: explore or even warrant their admiration. After more than five years
column9: he still comes across as one of the lost boys
column10:
happily treading water in Neverland and still not all the way willing to grow up.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21501/homepage_large.a170d537.jpg|What Happens Next|1677.0|Gang of Four|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Metropolis'
column2:
'Membran']|2015-02-26 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:19.613408|"

The original 1977-81 version of Gang of Four was such a fearsomely airtight
column3: telepathic unit that its individual constituents are rarely regarded among the finest in their respective fields. Though frontman Jon King uniquely channeled both the lithe physicality of Iggy Pop and the suave dignity of Bryan Ferry
column4: he’s rarely spoken about in the same breath as either. Andy Gill is the quintessential musician’s musician
column5: worshipped and imitated by countless celebrity acolytes (The Edge and Tom Morello among them)
column6: but not enough of a household name to land on Rolling Stone’s 100 Greatest Guitarists list. And the rhythm section of Hugo Burnham and Dave Allen was nothing less than the post-punk Bonham and Jones
column7: but didn’t stick together long enough to be widely hailed as such. What each member brought to the table is ultimately best gauged through the process of attrition that has played out over the band’s spasmodic career.

column1: But even if none of the albums King and Gill made without Allen and Burnham recaptured the funky ferocity of their earliest output together
column2: the unmistakable interplay between the singer and guitarist at least marked them as Gang of Four records
column3: in spite of whatever period-specific production signatures defined (and dated) those releases. However
column4: after getting the old band back together in 2004
column5: updating their back catalog
column6: and even sticking it out for a respectable showing after Allen and Burnham bailed once again
column7: it appears the only thing left for Gang of Four to do is to not be Gang of Four. Now that King is out of the picture following his 2011 resignation (to focus on his career in advertising)
column8: with What Happens Next
column9: Gang of Four have effectively entered the reality-TV vocal-competition phase of their career
column10: with lone holdout Gill filling the gaping hole at the mic stand with a revolving cast of guest vocalists.

column1: Which is
column2: of course
column3: a perfectly Gang of Four thing to do. After all
column4: inciting the ire of Go4 purists—through sudden changes in direction and personnel—is perhaps the only constant factor in the band’s disjointed trajectory. As the band’s founding member and perennial musical director
column5: it’s well within Gill’s rights to keep the Gang of Four name alive even without the guy who’s sung pretty much all of their songs. But while the guitarist’s signature scabrous funk lashes and ear-piercing feedback frequencies remain ever-present
column6: here they’re in service to a boilerplate post-industrial aesthetic—mid-tempo metronomic beats
column7: distorted-megaphone backing vocals
column8: fuzz-filtered basslines
column9: ominous electronic oscillations—that makes What Happens Next sound more like a mid-'90s alt-rock product than the album Gang of Four actually released in the mid-'90s. Factor in the singer ringers
column10: and What Happens Next doesn’t so much resemble a new look for a veteran post-punk band as the soundtrack to some dystopian thriller from 20 years ago. (In light of this
column11: you could be forgiven for thinking the closing Gill original ""Dead Souls"" is less a callback to the Joy Division classic of the same name than to Nine Inch Nails’ remake for The Crow.)

column1: That said
column2: it helps Gang of Four’s cause that the technophobic prophecies found in 20-year-old dystopian thrillers are increasingly coming true today. Thematically speaking
column3: What Happens Next updates Gang of Four’s buyer’s-remorse blues (in short: when you consume
column4: you make cons of you and me) for the Internet-addiction age
column5: complete with de rigueur dismissive Facebook references. Playing the role of Gang of Four’s J.D. Fortune

Over their decade-plus long existence
column2: Pelican have rarely
column3: if ever
column4: found themselves in a rush. The band's formation in Chicago in 2001 was a natural consequence of the slow-burning fires stoked by pioneering acts like Isis and Neurosis: more specifically
column5: their cumulative
column6: logic proof-like paths to the sublime. From the post-rock salvos of their debut Australasia to their recent effort Forever Becoming and its anthemic strivings
column7: Pelican’s artful approach to metal has always been informed by the notion that all the leaden pieces (torrential riffs
column8: sparse drum bursts
column9: mournful synths) will eventually fall into their proper place when granted proper gravity and time. By gutting the easily relatable bits of metal—verse-chorus-verse templates
column10: mach-speed solos
column11: and most importantly
column12: vocals—and placing a stronger emphasis on meditative forms
column13: the band has successfully married post-rock with metal
column14: broadening listeners’ understanding of both. Now all’s left is the singing.

column1: Enter The Cliff EP—three reworked versions of the song of the same name from Forever Becoming
column2: plus a previously unheard (and unassuming) cut titled ""The Wait"". The 25-minute affair seems pretty damn skimpy on paper
column3: a treat for diehard fans at best. Fifteen seconds after pressing play
column4: skepticism gives way to surprise as the band brandishes its hidden blade: a human voice
column5: crying out from the striated spaces as if it were howling this whole time. This updated version of ""The Cliff"" marks the first time in six years—and only the second time in their entire career—that the band has recorded a song with vocals
column6: after the title track off 2009’s What We All Come to Need. The gravelly
column7: cigarette-shorn tone is a dead ringer for Mark Lanegan
column8: but the bleary-eyed moans are actually all the Life and Times’ Allen Epley
column9: a post-hardcore veteran cast here as a deranged Lothario incapable of envisioning the concept of ""no"". ""Baby
column10: you’re fighting destiny
column11: he deadpans atop ornery riffs and crash of cymbals
column12: ""I’m getting close
column13: you know/ I’m not leaving ‘till you say my name."" As his demands of ""Who do you love?"" eventually coalesce into a somber semi-chant
column14: we realize that Pelican didn’t break their lyrical silence to spout esoteric essays or wax transcendentalist
column15: but rather to profile that familiar beast stalking dives and preying on good intentions—you know
column16: that guy. Coupled with the straightforwardly sludgy music
column17: ""The Cliff""'s subject grounds Pelican’s atmospheric endeavors in a gritty realism; while some might consider this to be regressive
column18: I find it the opposite—a much-needed shift in perspective from a group that’s always had its head in the clouds.

column1: There are two other renditions of ""The Cliff""
column2: both weird and worthwhile. Godflesh’s Justin Broadrick takes the instrumental way down
column3: glitching out the synths and soldering an additional layer of industrial steel to everything to render the entire composition factorylike. The swampy bass rusts into a dull throb
column4: the guitars whirr and rotate and sharpen themselves
column5: and the mechanized drums hiss and clang in time. The vocal remix comes from Palms
column6: the duo of Isis’ Aaron Harris and Bryant Clifford Meyer
column7: who offer the song a shot of adrenaline. Their version marches along at a slightly quickened pace
column8: spruced up with beefier
column9: more involved drumming and the addition of some woozy samples recorded in reverse.

column1: Both remixes of ""The Cliff""
column2: like the instrumental and vocal versions of the song itself
column3: posit ways in which a more melodically inclined Pelican could operate
column4: vocals or no. I doubt anyone would be seriously dismayed if the group chalked up this EP to a sonic experiment and went back to making turbid masterpieces. At the same time
column5: this little stopgap EP makes the prospect of a catchier
column6: more melodic Pelican all the more appealing. If ""The Cliff"" is any indication
column7: they’ve still got that lyrical touch
column8: meaning there’s an entire narrative mode ready to be shaped by their able hands. For a band that thrives so much in liminal spaces
column9:
it would be a mistake to pass up that kind of opportunity.

""Citizen Zombie""
column2: the first single in nearly thirty-five years by the Bristol post-punk band the Pop Group
column3: opens with a blast of abrasive industrial static
column4: which grows louder and wirier as it surges into the martial stomp of the song’s chorus. Bruce Smith’s guitar traces sharp
column5: barbed pendulum arcs as synths blaze like welding torches
column6: and Dan Catsis’s bass scours the low end
column7: as though attempting to dig its way out. Over the assembly-line clangor
column8: the familiar atonal caterwaul of Pop Group mainstay Mark Stewart rings out. The whole thing sounds like a factory that churns out other factories.

column1: I wish I meant that to be a compliment; these are sounds they’ve been toying with ever since the quartet blazed out of Bristol in '77
column2: after all. But ""Citizen Zombie""
column3: like much of the album that follows
column4: is overcrowded
column5: overserious
column6: oversold. Less dissent than just din and distraction
column7: it’s closer to mid-2000s dance-punk or to early-1990s post-NIN industrial than late-1970s post-punk. Perhaps because they were more a singles band than an album band—although what a single ""She Is Beyond Good and Evil"" is!—the band never enjoyed the sizable cult following of the Fall
column8: Wire
column9: or Gang of Four. Yet they remain influential for their ingenious combination of various genres: As Simon Reynolds wrote in Rip It Up and Start Again
column10: ""The genius of the Pop Group lay in the way they were pulled every which way by their passion for black music. They couldn’t settle on just reggae
column11: or just funk
column12: or just jazz
column13: so they went full throttle for all three simultaneously.""

column1: A band that relies on friction to define itself cannot survive long
column2: and by the time they released their third album
column3: We Are Time
column5: the Pop Group had exploded in a mushroom cloud of internal conflicts and legal wrangling
column6: to be replaced by splinter groups like Maximum Joy
column7: Pigbag
column8: and Rip Rig + Panic. In 2010
column9: the band rose from the dead
column10: with the original members performing a string of reunion shows that lead
column11: sadly but inevitably
column12: right up to Citizen Zombie.

column1: Both musically and lyrically
column2: the album is a mess. They were never the most politically nuanced band of their era
column3: but the bluntness of the message often worked in sharp contrast to the antagonism of their music. So many years later
column4: both the music and the message have lost their impact
column5: and the Pop Group have become the ultimate zombie band: They’re back from the dead with no real purpose or direction
column6: and they’re just stumbling around dumbly.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Stewart has taken to repetitive sloganeering
column3: shouting ""citizen zombie"" or ""deny everything"" like he’s clobbering us over the head. He sounds reasonably believable rattling off an anti-consumerist monologue on ""Nations""
column4: but elsewhere he seems to have regressed. The title track grates
column5: not only because the undead have long been deployed as metaphors for everything from the Moral Majority to the military industrial complex
column6: but because Stewart doesn't even stay on message. Soon he’s telling us ""you’ve got the brainwashed look of an alien abductee"" and comparing the hordes to ""a bad
column7: bad robot spinning out of control."" Just pick a sci-fi trope and stick with it. On ""The Immaculate Deception"" he bellows about the ""age of anxiety"" and ""wolves in the throne room
column8: but he sounds less like a post-punk eminence than a shouting guy you’d avoid on the subway. Whether he’s railing against game shows on ""Box 9"" or religion on ""St. Outrageous""
column9: the message sounds stale and the targets too easy.

column1: But the most glaring shortcomings of this disinterred Pop Group have to do with space and spontaneity. As teenagers in Bristol
column2: the band members were heavily informed by dub and free jazz
column3: citing King Tubby and Ornette Coleman as influences. The former relies on the space between the notes as much as on the notes themselves
column4: using reverb and delay to convey the shape of a room; the latter is more concerned with shedding the constraints of music
column5: its scales and its structures
column6: in order to arrive at something jarring and new. During their original run
column7: the Pop Group put these ideas to good use: They built a room with deep corners
column8: sharp angles
column9: sloping floors
column10: and no doors or windows
column11: then they razed it.

column1: By contrast
column2: there is almost no space anywhere on <i>Citizen Zombie
column3: beyond the pauses between tracks. Every moment is crammed with stray sound and errant fury: blooms of guitar distortion or thuds of industrial beats or some of the most incongruent backing vocals imaginable. Even closer ""Echelon""
column4: which is the closest this album gets to a quiet moment
column5: eventually piles on the synths and guitars and even a pipe organ. Featuring production by the eclectic Paul Epworth (Adele
column6: U2
column7: Cee-Lo Green
column8: and Crystal Castles
column9: among many others)
column10: the album sounds scripted and overdetermined
column11: its noise and commotion sculpted to assault your ears. Superficially
column12: it’s successful
column13: in that it’s not easy to listen to these songs. Yet
column14: it feels like a cheap tactic
column15: as if the band don’t trust themselves to get their point across and
column16: worse
column17:
don’t trust their listeners to comprehend anything but the most blatant lyric and the most thudding attack. The result of so much suspicion is an album that’s somehow both loud and timid—all clamor and no soul.

column5: ""ass-state

column5: and fantastic
column6: second verse. On these songs

column8: no Marlins

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the album only sustains that energy for about half its run time. After ""Paradise""—which is preceded by the admirably boogying R&B palate cleanser ""Play No Games""—Dark Sky Paradise becomes dreary and ponderous much like his second album

column4: loosening and losing shape

column1: In fact

column1: Even as it builds on those previous collaborations

it mimics the trajectory of getting lost. Rarely does losing your way sound so purposeful and inviting.

Tica Douglas is the kind of musician who indulges the comfort of sadness. The Brooklyn-based songwriter's sophomore album
column2: Joey
column3: is crafted from the winsome murmurs and gentle guitar strums of someone left alone to think in their bedroom
column4: and the result is a tender meditation on youthful malaise
column5: intensified by Douglas’s status as a gender outlier. ""Joey"" was apparently the name Douglas’s parents were considering if Douglas ""were born a boy""
column6: and the ambiguous state of identity (Douglas is non-binary
column7: and as such doesn’t identify with any one gender category) is a source of the album’s confusion
column8: yearning and wonder about who ""Tica"" is and where that person fits in the world.

column1: Throughout Joey
column2: Douglas’ forlorn ruminations take on philosophical implications. ""I Didn’t"" addresses the dull ache of past regrets with simple
column3: subtly powerful language (""There was a party last night where you used to live/ And I wanted to go… but I didn’t""). Douglas's voice curls off in mournful tendrils on ""Ease""—""I call you over and make up something to make you stay""—and the negative space conveys the weight of the song's loneliness. It’s only through Joey’s casual statements that Douglas gets at the crux of the real burden
column4: which the difficulty of being inside one's own head. ""I hope I don’t exhaust you like I exhaust myself
column5: Douglas admits on the album’s opening song

column1: Because Douglas grew up grappling with the liminal space of gender roles

column3: goes a line addressing a lover’s parents
column4: ""though I know I’m not quite what they had in mind for you."" References to Douglas' family—""I grew up on the ocean with a family that I loved""—are delivered with a deliberateness that suggests the reflections are too comfortable to be the whole truth. ""And my brother called to talk/ About my parents’ split
column5: Douglas later qualifies
column6: ""I thought it never got to me/ But now I think it did."" There’s an underlying sense that Joey is narrated in hindsight
column7: its vignettes strewn together by someone who is still learning from the past.

column1: And yet
column2: the suffering of Joey is balanced with glimmers of optimism. ""You don’t have to be broken/ To make heartbreaking art
column3: Douglas sings on ""All Meanness Be Gone"". Here and throughout the album
column4: the nostalgia feels distinctly hopeful
column5: a mix of melancholy and the kind of catharsis that comes with exploring hurt in order to heal it. On ""Too Long""
column6: Douglas reflects on a past relationship (""I learned the pain of too much tenderness"")
column7: but drags out the words as if to savor the sting. The harmonies on the record are straightforward—it's just voice and guitar—and the sparseness adds to the record’s intimacy. ""Black & White"" contains a declaration of love and loyalty to a significant other despite years of torment
column8: and in these moments Douglas' voice is so melodious and enveloping that it immerses you like a fog—an atmosphere that’s bleak and enlivening at the same time. ""I never have and never will understand why simple is so difficult
column9: Douglas coos as if in summation on ""My My My"". It’s a profoundly relatable sentiment
column10:
and the simplicity is part of the charm: The beauty of Joey’s sadness lies in how it dignifies the mundane.

"|20149.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20149-joey/|7.0|Molly Beauchemin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21549/homepage_large.4e4e4594.jpg|Terraplane|32776.0|Steve Earle & The Dukes|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New West']|2015-02-25 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:24.648558|"

Steve Earle has learned to compartmentalize. In the twenty-first century he has released an album of Townes Van Zandt covers
column2: a few collections of agit-Americana
column3: and another inspired by the immigrant sounds of New York City—each one so laser-focused musically and thematically that they sound like concept albums. On one hand
column4: the approach gives each record its own distinctive identity within his catalog. When his overarching subject was the idiocy of the Bush Administration he hit paydirt: Jerusalem and The Revolution Starts… Now had a hardscrabble righteousness only intensified by the fact that few other singer-songwriters were tackling that particular subject matter at that particular time. Both have aged more gracefully than their topicality would have suggested.

column1: On the other hand
column2: that urge to cordon off genres and ideas seems particularly odd for an artist who changed the course of country music in the 1980s by insisting that everything could be commingled freely. His 1986 debut Guitar Town and 1988's Copperhead Road melded rock guitars and country songwriting
column3: honkytonk rowdiness and folky gentleness
column4: as if to rebuke the timid conservatism of the Nashville mainstream. Even in the 1990s
column5: he emerged from a four-year stint in the clink with a string of adventurous records that made forays into doo-wop
column6: Beatlesque pop
column7: Civil War storytelling
column8: and twangy psychedelica. That eclecticism was—and still is—rousing
column9: yet nowadays each of those creative impulses would get its own neat album.

column1: Earle's latest is also his most specific: Terraplane is his Texas blues album
column2: an homage to the likes of Lightnin' Hopkins and Mance Lipscomb
column3: Robert Johnson and Stevie Ray Vaughn
column4: Freddy King and ZZ Top. There are no cheeseball Blueshammer theatrics
column5: which often accompany blues records made by non-blues artists. Earle's more interested in craft than ostentation
column6: and his touring band the Dukes keep things raw and wiry
column7: as though everything was caught in one take during Shiner runs. Only on ""Baby's Just as Mean as Me""
column8: a he said/she said duet with Eleanor Whitmore
column9: do Earle's blues sound less than casually persuasive.

column1: To his credit
column2: Earle understands that Texas is a big place and therefore Texas blues is a broad term that encompasses various sounds and song forms. Terraplane volleys from acoustic to electric
column3: from solo delivery to full-band performances
column4: from pop melodies to spoken-word verses. He conjures some fire and brimstone on a talking blues called ""The Tennessee Kid""
column5: which would be one of the best songs here if it didn't so readily buy into some of the persistent myths orbiting the blues: reaching the crossroads
column6: meeting the devil
column7: selling your soul. These seem like tired tropes
column8: equivalent to naming your album after a Robert Johnson song
column9: yet Earle brings so much grit and wiliness to the song that you almost don't roll your eyes when he name-drops ""Bob Johnson.""

column1: The blues is often mischaracterized as uniformly worried and woeful
column2: as though a hellhound were on every strummer's trail
column3: yet that is only one facet of the form. It can also be funny
column4: or randy
column5: and it's this last trait that Earle taps into most eagerly
column6: as Terraplane is his lustiest album in a long while. Sex is the major theme
column7: and Earle beholds his hard-on with a self-effacing chuckle. The first song is called ""Baby Baby Baby (Baby)""
column8: and that parenthetical aside is not only his best punchline but a winking nod to the ridiculousness of it all. Casting him as the leering oldie
column9: ""Go-Go Boots Are Back"" may be his most frivolous song yet
column10: but its lack of gravity is freeing
column11: even funny. Nevertheless
column12: the concept framing Terraplane also reduces its scope and limits its impact. It's good for what it is—better than it needs to be
column13: in fact—yet what it is is only a fraction of what it could be
column14:
if only Earle would stop trying to tidy up his inspirations.

With Led Zeppelin
column2: there was no break-in period
column3: no ""early phase"" where they figured out what kind of band they wanted to be. They were fully formed from the first repetition of the ""Good Times Bad Times"" riff
column4: and they powered along through their first half-dozen albums crushing everything in their path. Zep never had their Sgt. Pepper's
column5: their Exile
column6: their Who's Next
column7: because every album was more or less that good—for a while
column8: anyway. This was a band that knew the music it wanted to make and executed it with ruthless precision. The second trio of Led Zeppelin reissues (the fourth album and Houses of the Holy came out last fall
column9: Physical Graffiti this week) found the band inhabiting what Neil Tennant once described (and Tom Ewing fleshed out) as their ""imperial phase."" Riding on their massive initial success
column10: and pushed even further by the game-changing success of ""Stairway to Heaven""
column11: everything they tried during these years somehow worked.

column1: If you grew up on classic rock radio
column2: you sometimes felt like you were listening to Led Zeppelin's fourth album on shuffle. It has eight songs
column3: all of them are huge
column4: and one
column5: ""Stairway to Heaven""
column6: frequently lingers near the top of lists of the Greatest Rock Songs of All Time. Given its place in culture
column7: IV can seem like an album of moments more than songs. Individual parts have been selected
column8: cropped
column9: amplified
column10: and dropped into both songs by other artists and into our collective unconscious. Every song has two or three sections that are instantly identifiable and always seem to be playing somewhere nearby. The circular guitar figure in ""Black Dog""; the chiming mandolin in ""Going to California""; Bonham's cymbal bashing on ""Rock and Roll"". It's hard to hear ""When the Levee Breaks""
column11: by now
column12: and not think of hip-hop. If Led Zeppelin's music formed the DNA of anything that could remotely be called ""hard rock
column13: IV is a petri dish overflowing with stem cells. The debut was darker and moodier
column14: II was heavier
column15: and III was prettier
column16: but the fourth album is a triumph of form meeting function.

column1: ""Stairway to Heaven"" is so ubiquitous that it cycles through phases of deep reverence and self-parody
column2: and the movement between these two poles is so rapid it all becomes a blur. This happens both for individual listeners (I'm going to guess the very young still discover this song and have their idea of what a rock song can be expanded considerably) and on the level of mass culture. It's both a marker of religion and an instant punchline
column3: a singularity that sucks in a world of experience and observation and jeering laughter and sincere tears and compacts it all into an infinitely dense point. Like many who both love it and hate it
column4: I pretty much never need to hear it again. But ""Stairway"" aside
column5: IV is their least weird album. It's basically their stab at perfection
column6: and they get there
column7: but this band was always at its most interesting at the margins
column8: when they had the possibility of failure.

column2: Zeppelin's only competition for Biggest Band in the World was the Stones
column3: who were losing their hunger. Later that year
column4: the Stones would put out Goat's Head Soup
column5: beginning a period of drift they wouldn't return from until 1978's Some Girls. The field was clear
column6: with the '60s starting to recede in the rearview
column7: but punk was still a couple of years away
column8: Zeppelin didn't waste the opportunity. Houses of the Holy
column9: their fifth album in four years
column10: takes the most powerful moments of the fourth album and amplifies them
column11: and also adds some oddball experiments that flesh out the Led Zeppelin story.

column1: They are most in the zone on ""Over the Hills and Far Away""
column2: which is on a very short list of best songs Zep ever wrote
column3: which is to say that it's among the best rock songs ever written. Everything they ever did well—pastoral beauty
column4: crunchy riffs
column5: stop/start changes
column6: monster drum grooves—could be found on this single track. ""The Ocean"" features what could be Jimmy Page's single greatest riff. ""The Rain Song"" is a masterful study in the power of guitar tone
column7: both for its full acoustic strumming and the electric guitar work that has always evoked the weather of its title. John Paul Jones' gorgeous Mellotron passage is one of the definitive uses of that strange instrument. And ""No Quarter"" is a disorienting bad-vibes epic
column8: archetypal of the '70s
column9: capturing the bleak interiority of a certain kind of drug experience.

column1: Houses of the Holy is a perfectly reasonable choice for best Zeppelin LP
column2: even if it had signs that the band couldn't last forever. ""The Song Remains the Same"" is the first sign of Robert Plant using a more pinched sound for his upper register
column3: adapting to that gradually disappearing top octave by contorting his vocals into a strange squeal. By the last two Zeppelin records this would be his default approach when singing in this range. ""The Crunge"" is a sour version of funk
column4: a weirdly fascinating half-song complete with a groaner of a James Brown joke. John Bonham supposedly disliked ""D'yer Mak'er"" so much he refused to write an interesting drum part
column5: sticking instead with the first shuffle beat that came to mind. It was Zeppelin's stab at reggae
column6: and though they never try to breathe any space or light into the mix
column7: it's impossible to dismiss the song's easy catchiness
column8: its affection for doo-wop melody
column9: the motion of Page's spindly guitar.

column1: Houses of the Holy might be Zeppelin's most impressive album on a purely sonic level
column2: and this particular remaster reinforces that notion. The best remastering jobs always offer a subtle improvement—a touch of EQing here
column3: a bit more volume there without overdoing it. Taken together
column4: they hopefully offer more detail
column5: and these versions make the grade. The bonus discs
column6: however
column7: continue to be disappointing. From one angle
column8: there's actually something admirable about how little Led Zeppelin left in the vaults. It was a testament to their brutal efficiency as a rock machine. But aside from the live set released with the debut
column9: the bonus discs so far have been the definition of ""fans only.""

column1: They are mostly filled with ""alternate mixes
column2: which is a strange concept. Mixes freeze in time a single moment that is the end result of many individual decisions; they document fader settings. Alternate mixes showing what could have happened are literally infinite; all these mixes are said to have been created while the album was being mixed
column3: and there is no reason to doubt that
column4: but the truth is Page could just as easily make an ""alternate mix"" of any one of these songs this morning and no one would know the difference. The fact that a mandolin was briefly considered to be slightly louder for a given sound is basically a stray fact and nothing more. All it provides is a chance to hear familiar performances in familiar songs in a way that sounds slightly unfamiliar.

column1: Among the first six records
column2: aside from III
column3: Physical Graffiti suffers least from overfamiliarity. It's Led Zeppelin's White Album
column4: the one they made when they were at their creative peak and had a million ideas
column5: but were also under a tremendous amount of strain and saw the end starting to come into focus. It's also
column6: to my ears
column7: their best album
column8: even if it's not as unified or complete as some of what had come before. Why their best? First of all
column9: there's more of it. The previous two albums were awesome
column10: but each had just eight songs; Physical Graffiti has 15. It's math—when you are talking about songs from this period of the band
column11: that makes it roughly twice as good.

column1: But Physical Graffiti is Zeppelin's best album ultimately because it felt like a culmination. In some senses it was literally so
column2: since its tracks had been recorded over the course of the previous few years and
column3: in some cases
column4: were leftovers from the previous few records. (The best of the new material was still too much for a single record
column5: so they went back to unreleased songs and decided to flesh out a full 2xLP. The songs are all over the place
column6: but the band makes it all work together.)

column1: Iconic riffs abound—""Custard Pie""
column2: ""The Wanton Song""
column3: and ""Houses of the Holy"" alone have more hooks than most rock bands manage in a career—but here they are just the beginning of the story. ""In My Time of Dying"" is Zeppelin's ultimate blues deconstruction
column4: mixing the open-chord slide of acoustic Delta blues with electric heaviness and extending the whole thing past 11 minutes. Pastoral instrumentals had been in the mix for Zeppelin since the first album's ""Black Mountainside""
column5: but Page never managed another one as beautiful as ""Bron-Yr-Aur""
column6: a crushingly brief two minutes of guitar bliss that every rock kid who picked up an acoustic guitar in the next 10 years dreamed of playing. And their non-Western dabbling crested with ""Kashmir"". But Physical Graffiti's greatest strength is its looseness and general sense of playfulness. Here and there
column7: Zeppelin showed comfort with pop. The bounce of ""Trampled Under Foot"" owes everything to Stevie Wonder; ""Down By the Seaside"" has an easeful lilt; and ""Night Flight"" twinkles with a bright optimism.

column1: The song I returned to most here is also the simplest—""Boogie With Stu""
column2: an interpolation of Ritchie Valens' ""Ooh My Head"" (his mother gets a songwriting credit). It makes me think of what blues and early rock'n'roll meant to a certain generation of young men growing up in England during the 1950s and '60s. You hear one story after another about lives being changed by a rock'n'roll record. In a famous quote
column3: John Lennon summed up his musical taste to Jann Wenner in a 1971 Rolling Stone interview: ""Sounds like 'Wop Bop a Loo Bop'. I like rock and roll
column4: man
column5: I don't like much else.""

column1: When the members of Led Zeppelin get together with famed session pianist/long-time pal Ian Stewart on ""Boogie With Stu""
column2: you can hear five people who speak the same language. It's drunk on the joy of the discovery. Whatever else they have going on in their lives
column3: they can sit down and play a chugging 12-bar song and have a fucking ball
column4: because they remember when they first heard a song like this as kids and realized that song was a portal to another world. On Physical Graffiti
column5: the end point of Led Zeppelin's incomparable initial run
column6: they are living deep inside that new world
column7: still finding new things to discover
column8:
taking it all in.

The circular guitar figure in ""Black Dog""; the chiming mandolin in ""Going to California""; Bonham's cymbal bashing on ""Rock and Roll"". It's hard to hear ""When the Levee Breaks""
column11: by now
column12: and not think of hip-hop. If Led Zeppelin's music formed the DNA of anything that could remotely be called ""hard rock
column13: IV is a petri dish overflowing with stem cells. The debut was darker and moodier
column14: II was heavier
column15: and III was prettier
column16: but the fourth album is a triumph of form meeting function.

column1: ""Stairway to Heaven"" is so ubiquitous that it cycles through phases of deep reverence and self-parody
column2: and the movement between these two poles is so rapid it all becomes a blur. This happens both for individual listeners (I'm going to guess the very young still discover this song and have their idea of what a rock song can be expanded considerably) and on the level of mass culture. It's both a marker of religion and an instant punchline
column3: a singularity that sucks in a world of experience and observation and jeering laughter and sincere tears and compacts it all into an infinitely dense point. Like many who both love it and hate it
column4: I pretty much never need to hear it again. But ""Stairway"" aside
column5: IV is their least weird album. It's basically their stab at perfection
column6: and they get there
column7: but this band was always at its most interesting at the margins
column8: when they had the possibility of failure.

column2: Zeppelin's only competition for Biggest Band in the World was the Stones
column3: who were losing their hunger. Later that year
column4: the Stones would put out Goat's Head Soup
column5: beginning a period of drift they wouldn't return from until 1978's Some Girls. The field was clear
column6: with the '60s starting to recede in the rearview
column7: but punk was still a couple of years away
column8: Zeppelin didn't waste the opportunity. Houses of the Holy
column9: their fifth album in four years
column10: takes the most powerful moments of the fourth album and amplifies them
column11: and also adds some oddball experiments that flesh out the Led Zeppelin story.

column1: They are most in the zone on ""Over the Hills and Far Away""
column2: which is on a very short list of best songs Zep ever wrote
column3: which is to say that it's among the best rock songs ever written. Everything they ever did well—pastoral beauty
column4: crunchy riffs
column5: stop/start changes
column6: monster drum grooves—could be found on this single track. ""The Ocean"" features what could be Jimmy Page's single greatest riff. ""The Rain Song"" is a masterful study in the power of guitar tone
column7: both for its full acoustic strumming and the electric guitar work that has always evoked the weather of its title. John Paul Jones' gorgeous Mellotron passage is one of the definitive uses of that strange instrument. And ""No Quarter"" is a disorienting bad-vibes epic
column8: archetypal of the '70s
column9: capturing the bleak interiority of a certain kind of drug experience.

column1: Houses of the Holy is a perfectly reasonable choice for best Zeppelin LP
column2: even if it had signs that the band couldn't last forever. ""The Song Remains the Same"" is the first sign of Robert Plant using a more pinched sound for his upper register
column3: adapting to that gradually disappearing top octave by contorting his vocals into a strange squeal. By the last two Zeppelin records this would be his default approach when singing in this range. ""The Crunge"" is a sour version of funk
column4: a weirdly fascinating half-song complete with a groaner of a James Brown joke. John Bonham supposedly disliked ""D'yer Mak'er"" so much he refused to write an interesting drum part
column5: sticking instead with the first shuffle beat that came to mind. It was Zeppelin's stab at reggae
column6: and though they never try to breathe any space or light into the mix
column7: it's impossible to dismiss the song's easy catchiness
column8: its affection for doo-wop melody
column9: the motion of Page's spindly guitar.

column1: Houses of the Holy might be Zeppelin's most impressive album on a purely sonic level
column2: and this particular remaster reinforces that notion. The best remastering jobs always offer a subtle improvement—a touch of EQing here
column3: a bit more volume there without overdoing it. Taken together
column4: they hopefully offer more detail
column5: and these versions make the grade. The bonus discs
column6: however
column7: continue to be disappointing. From one angle
column8: there's actually something admirable about how little Led Zeppelin left in the vaults. It was a testament to their brutal efficiency as a rock machine. But aside from the live set released with the debut
column9: the bonus discs so far have been the definition of ""fans only.""

column1: They are mostly filled with ""alternate mixes
column2: which is a strange concept. Mixes freeze in time a single moment that is the end result of many individual decisions; they document fader settings. Alternate mixes showing what could have happened are literally infinite; all these mixes are said to have been created while the album was being mixed
column3: and there is no reason to doubt that
column4: but the truth is Page could just as easily make an ""alternate mix"" of any one of these songs this morning and no one would know the difference. The fact that a mandolin was briefly considered to be slightly louder for a given sound is basically a stray fact and nothing more. All it provides is a chance to hear familiar performances in familiar songs in a way that sounds slightly unfamiliar.

column1: Among the first six records
column2: aside from III
column3: Physical Graffiti suffers least from overfamiliarity. It's Led Zeppelin's White Album
column4: the one they made when they were at their creative peak and had a million ideas
column5: but were also under a tremendous amount of strain and saw the end starting to come into focus. It's also
column6: to my ears
column7: their best album
column8: even if it's not as unified or complete as some of what had come before. Why their best? First of all
column9: there's more of it. The previous two albums were awesome
column10: but each had just eight songs; Physical Graffiti has 15. It's math—when you are talking about songs from this period of the band
column11: that makes it roughly twice as good.

column1: But Physical Graffiti is Zeppelin's best album ultimately because it felt like a culmination. In some senses it was literally so
column2: since its tracks had been recorded over the course of the previous few years and
column3: in some cases
column4: were leftovers from the previous few records. (The best of the new material was still too much for a single record
column5: so they went back to unreleased songs and decided to flesh out a full 2xLP. The songs are all over the place
column6: but the band makes it all work together.)

column1: Iconic riffs abound—""Custard Pie""
column2: ""The Wanton Song""
column3: and ""Houses of the Holy"" alone have more hooks than most rock bands manage in a career—but here they are just the beginning of the story. ""In My Time of Dying"" is Zeppelin's ultimate blues deconstruction
column4: mixing the open-chord slide of acoustic Delta blues with electric heaviness and extending the whole thing past 11 minutes. Pastoral instrumentals had been in the mix for Zeppelin since the first album's ""Black Mountainside""
column5: but Page never managed another one as beautiful as ""Bron-Yr-Aur""
column6: a crushingly brief two minutes of guitar bliss that every rock kid who picked up an acoustic guitar in the next 10 years dreamed of playing. And their non-Western dabbling crested with ""Kashmir"". But Physical Graffiti's greatest strength is its looseness and general sense of playfulness. Here and there
column7: Zeppelin showed comfort with pop. The bounce of ""Trampled Under Foot"" owes everything to Stevie Wonder; ""Down By the Seaside"" has an easeful lilt; and ""Night Flight"" twinkles with a bright optimism.

column1: The song I returned to most here is also the simplest—""Boogie With Stu""
column2: an interpolation of Ritchie Valens' ""Ooh My Head"" (his mother gets a songwriting credit). It makes me think of what blues and early rock'n'roll meant to a certain generation of young men growing up in England during the 1950s and '60s. You hear one story after another about lives being changed by a rock'n'roll record. In a famous quote
column3: John Lennon summed up his musical taste to Jann Wenner in a 1971 Rolling Stone interview: ""Sounds like 'Wop Bop a Loo Bop'. I like rock and roll
column4: man
column5: I don't like much else.""

column1: When the members of Led Zeppelin get together with famed session pianist/long-time pal Ian Stewart on ""Boogie With Stu""
column2: you can hear five people who speak the same language. It's drunk on the joy of the discovery. Whatever else they have going on in their lives
column3: they can sit down and play a chugging 12-bar song and have a fucking ball
column4: because they remember when they first heard a song like this as kids and realized that song was a portal to another world. On Physical Graffiti
column5: the end point of Led Zeppelin's incomparable initial run
column6: they are living deep inside that new world
column7: still finding new things to discover
column8:
taking it all in.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21466/homepage_large.9e261a6e.jpg|Archive Series Volume No. 1|26448.0|Iron & Wine|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Black Cricket']|2015-02-24 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:25.498810|"

In retrospect
column2: there was no way that Sam Beam—or anyone else
column3: for that matter—could keep singing such quiet
column4: devastating songs. Recorded in his living room while he worked a day job teaching cinema in Florida
column5: his early Iron & Wine material examined harsh truths about the precarious nature of marriage and family: Every child grows up and leaves home
column6: every friendship is eventually defined by distance and difference
column7: every marriage ends in death and loneliness. ""One of us will die inside these arms
column8: he sang on ""Naked As We Came""
column9: off 2004’s Our Endless Numbered Days. ""One will spread our ashes ‘round the yard."" It wasn’t always easy to hear that kind of clear-eyed sentiment
column10: so it couldn’t have been easy to deliver it night after night after night.

column1: Beam’s first forays away from that kind of minimalist folk and its treacherous intimacy were promising
column2: with the Woman King EP and his mini-album with Calexico leading right up to The Shepherd’s Dog in 2007
column3: still a career high. If subsequent albums have sounded less inventive and immediate
column4: the reason wasn’t so much the widescreen arrangements
column5: the experiments with psychedelic jazz and free rock
column6: or even the full band Beam took into the studio and out on the road. Instead
column7: it was a new tack in songwriting
column8: which found him experimenting with fleeting impressionism over concrete details. Each new record put more and more space between Beam and the listener; his songs began to sound affected and oddly distant
column9: as though he were filming a movie whose action took place entirely in the middle distance.

column1: Coming at the end of that ho-hum run of albums
column2: this new rarities catch-all Archive Series Volume No. 1 arrives like a breath of fresh air. Beam is currently between labels
column3: with a few rumored collaborative projects (a duets record with Jesca Hoop
column4: a covers album with Ben Bridwell) overshadowing any talk of his next studio album. While it certainly doesn’t constitute a do-over
column5: it does gently recall a time when he was just beginning to form a strong connection with his listeners and when he could take that indie folk sound in any direction imaginable. Tucked under the bed or squirreled away in the guest bedroom closet
column6: these songs become a point from which to measure his decade-long career
column7: to see how far he has come since he made those first home recordings.

column1: It’s bracing to hear him in this familiar setting once again
column2: to hear the roomy ambience of opener ""Slow Black River""
column3: a song strong enough to hold its own against anything on The Creek Drank the Cradle. But it’s also a good reminder of just how intricate his minimalist folk arrangements could be. Most of these songs feature just voice and guitar
column4: yet there is a lot going on. There’s a physicality to Beam’s guitar playing
column5: which makes even the slower tunes sound both urgent and casual. The lo-fi production erases any sense of depth in the production
column6: which might be a problem for many artists but here it means that every instrument and every sound is on the same plane—a small wall of sound.

column1: Beam’s strums can be percussive and quietly emphatic
column2: highlighting the breeziness of the melody on ""The Wind Is Low"" and evoking a sinister force driving ""Minor Piano Keys"". When he adds instruments—a bass on ""Judgement"" [sic] or the slide guitar on ""Loretta"" or what sounds like a mandolin on ""Wade Across the Water""—it’s restrained and specific
column3: like a soundtrack composer insinuating emotions onscreen. On the lo-fi ""Quarters in a Pocket"" a rambunctious banjo conjures a contentment tinged with sadness: ""Time spent with you feels like charcoal sketches for a painting that you won’t let me see
column4: he sings over the spiky picking and plucking. ""But I’ve come to find that comfort comes like quarters in a pocket
column5: discovered accidentally.""

column1: Much like 2009’s Around the Well
column2: the 2xCD retrospective that acted as an epilogue to his Sub Pop tenure and provides a template for Volume No. 1
column3: the songs on here are surprisingly strong
column4: such that any of them could have appeared on a proper album at any point in Beam’s decade-plus career. But the collection never sounds like the sum of its parts. That may be due to the absence of the kind of overarching idea that animates his studio albums
column5: or with the fact that at 16 tracks Volume No. 1 is simply too generous. That’s the nature of any kind of vault-clearing compilation: Instead of a simple snapshot of a period in his career
column6: Beam has created something more like a charcoal sketch. Hopefully
column7:
more volumes will soon follow.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21504/homepage_large.8fed32c0.jpg|Wild Strawberries|28298.0|Eternal Tapestry|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2015-02-24 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:26.139608|"

For their latest album Wild Strawberries
column2: Portland
column3: Oregon-based psych rockers Eternal Tapestry headed out to a remote cabin in Oregon to isolate themselves while recording
column4: where they produced a set of tracks all named after plants native to the area. Essential ingredients of their sound remain—expanses of sound
column5: culled from improvisations stretched out into infinity—but here they mainline nature more directly than ever before. Throw in the darkness that often cloaks their music
column6: and the fact that some of it was recorded over a bunch of Phish cassette bootlegs
column7: and it becomes something akin to a full-gamut hippie experience
column8: lost somewhere between quiet introspection and howling bad dreams. Eternal Tapestry slice right down the middle of that juxtaposition
column9: giving in to both good and evil as they progress.

column1: Committing to Wild Strawberries is a daunting undertaking; unlike its namesake
column2: the rather more concise Ingmar Bergman film of the same name
column3: this is a place where sprawl begets sprawl
column4: coming in just shy of 90 minutes in length. It's cosmic music with an earthy tone
column5: slowly ricocheting between the stars and the ground
column6: recalling similarly minded souls such as Acid Mothers Temple
column7: Spacemen 3
column8: Popol Vuh
column9: and Guru Guru. Wild Strawberries has distinct parts
column10: becoming looser and more rock-focused at the beginning
column11: with deeper experimentation in its back half. The transition from the jammy title track
column12: built on a twinkly organ drone pricked with guitar solos
column13: to the closing ""White Adder's Tongue""—all bare husks of sound
column14: slowly uncoiling drones
column15: and a purposefully dysfunctional loop that envelopes half of its 15-minute duration—highlights the band's breadth.

column1: Loose ends fray at the seams of these songs
column2: sometimes to their detriment
column3: when the players don't appear to have a good sense of where they're heading. ""Enchanter's Nightshade"" treads a circular path similar to the one taken on ""Wild Strawberries""
column4: but can't reach the same level of transcendence
column5: rarely getting away from the sense of a bunch of guys jamming on a half-formed idea. When they fall back on familiar psych-rock trappings
column6: Eternal Tapestry fall short
column7: mostly because they're so obviously trying to surpass them elsewhere. Echoed vocals
column8: such a staple of the genre
column9: feel like a splotch across the glassy surface of the minimalist ""Maidenhair Spleenwort"".

column1: If the ideas on Wild Strawberries don't always appear to coalesce
column2: it's a problem with which Eternal Tapestry are well aware. Talking in a recent interview of their time in the cabin
column3: they explain how it ""let us completely let down our guards and do whatever we want all the time
column4: producing an atmosphere where they ""didn't have a lot of focus."" The material they extracted from that period is endemic to such a process
column5: but it's still intermittently impressive how they manage to zone in on a sharp piece of mystical riffing or lay out on an elegant ambient plane. The quieter work here may suggest a way forward
column6: but Wild Strawberries has a transitional feel. It leads Eternal Tapestry to an outlet where they can shed the tags with which they're so often saddled
column7:
but not to a place where they're reaching far beyond that into the ether.

"|20236.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20236-wild-strawberries/|6.2|Nick Neyland

Diet Cig burst out of the Hudson Valley college town and musical hotbed New Paltz
column2: N.Y.
column3: this January with a memorable name and an origin story like something from a microbudget romantic comedy. Singer Alex Luciano and drummer Noah Bowman met at a house show when she interrupted a set to ask him for a lighter; a few months later
column4: they were playing shows and getting ready to record their first songs at a studio in New Paltz. Over Easy
column5: their debut EP
column6: is the product of that labor
column7: a collection of brisk
column8: personal pop-punk that recalls '90s bands like Beat Happening or Tiger Trap in its simplicity and Eternal Summers in its tone.

column1: It's not hard to get to the core of the songs on Over Easy. Built mostly out of Bowman's frenzied drumming and Luciano's distorted guitar and vocals
column2: they're simple
column3: propulsive
column4: and monochromatic; they're dense
column5: but not rich with detail. They mostly serve as vehicles for Luciano's reflections on the life changes
column6: relationships
column7: and social anxiety that characterize extended adolescence. It's a time that's served as fodder for more than its share of music
column8: but Luciano comes at it with a keen observational eye and a fresh perspective. She turns opener ""Breathless""
column9: an anthem for people living independently for the first time
column10: into something with character through her use of location and detail (like the fact that she's still missing a shower curtain). In other moments
column11: she has a knack for memorable and catchy phrasing that reminds me of Dashboard Confessional
column12: specifically the way every song threatened to break into a cathartic group singalong in a live setting. When she hammers out the line
column13: ""and I am sweating and I'm/ betting you are
column14: too!"" in the chorus of ""Pool Boyz""
column15: it's easy to imagine a roomful of people yelling it with her and revelling in the song's heat and pent-up lust.

column1: There are moments on Over Easy where Diet Cig crosses the line from relatable young adult angst into petulant
column2: immature whining. There are pieces of ""Scene Sick"" that are appealing on their own—the way its slow shuffle explodes into a speedy romp
column3: the nicely varied percussive elements—but when tossed together with Luciano's powdered sugar vocal
column4: it's painfully saccharine. It's also based around a complaint that's remarkably insular
column5: namely the oppressiveness of the titular scene; it's a sentiment that likely resonates with people who have spent a lot of time embedded in the music industry
column6: but without that context it hews a little closer to straightforward whining. Closer ""Harvard""
column7: fuller and funnier and more dynamic
column8: does a better job of conveying that kind of annoyance by focusing on a snobby
column9: jerky ex.

column1: There's obvious talent and light in these songs
column2: though it's also obvious that Diet Cig are still in their infancy. (In spending time with the EP
column3: I kept coming back to Eternal Summers' ""Lightswitch"" as a best case scenario for songs of this length and complexity: more colour
column4: more depth
column5: more space
column6: more intensity.) There's promise here
column7: but Over Easy barely scrapes the 10 minute mark
column8:
and the duo's next release will be the one that really proves their worth.

"|20237.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20237-over-easy-ep/|6.1|Jamieson Cox

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21503/homepage_large.d742862e.jpg|I Want to Grow Up|29116.0|Colleen Green|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hardly Art']|2015-02-24 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:27.408041|"

While Colleen Green's first LP for Hardly Art
column2: Sock It to Me
column3: was a slice of breezy
column4: self-aware stoner bubblegum that insisted on a shallow read—perhaps to force us to turn away from deeper truths—its follow-up
column5: <i>I Want to Grow Up
column6: is weed paralysis and paranoia in a sugary glaze. (In keeping with her first record
column7: Milo Goes to Compton
column8: Green named I Want To Grow Up after another Descendents album.) On this record
column9: Green has managed to capture in very real and human terms the existential terror that everything is futile and that our lives will never amount to much: no small feat. She is keenly aware of her own limitations and has turned her reflection on those limitations into strengths.

column1: Green’s got a knack for songwriting. While the Ramones taught us all that we only need a few chords to make an endless number of perfect pop songs
column2: most bands that have followed that model to the letter don’t have the ear for hooks
column3: structure
column4: or wordplay that their heroes did. Green does. She is also extremely effective at manipulating the studio to get the hidden depths of her seemingly simple songs—the sharks
column5: jellyfish and other prehistoric monsters beneath the sunny surface of the beach waves—to become evident.

column1: ""Deeper Than Love""
column2: for instance
column3: is an existential meditation on the human capacity for connection and disconnection. Driven by heavily processed bass
column4: a metronomic drum machine
column5: and a twinkling
column6: haunting guitar melody
column7: Green’s soft voice
column8: doubled
column9: asks persistently: ""Will I find a love that lasts as long as my life or will I die before ever becoming a wife? And I’m wondering if I’m even the marrying kind. How can I give you my life when I know you’re just gonna die?"" It is intensely claustrophobic
column10: the kind of stream of mundane self-reflective horror that we all run away from by tapping at our phones or flipping channels. Then it turns in on itself
column11: Green’s voice nearly a whisper as she recounts the reasons she holds potential partners at arm’s length: ""'Cause I’m shitty and I’m lame and I’m dumb and I’m a bore/ And once you get to know me you won’t like me anymore."" The coda
column12: repeated
column13: a shiver in the spine
column14: guitar and synth spiraling around it: ""Further than fantasy
column15: deeper than love ever could be."" The fear of intimacy triumphs over the fear of death.

column1: Green isn’t complacent to just identify her problems and stare them calmly in the face
column2: though. On the title track and the twin stars that are ""Things That Are Bad For Me (Part 1)"" and ""Things That Are Bad For Me (Part 2)""
column3: she rhetorically kicks herself in the butt to take responsibility for her actions
column4: whether that be getting on a proper schedule or getting away from a boyfriend who brings out the worst in her
column5: despite her acknowledgment that her anxiety drives her bad behavior. She doesn’t just want to grow up—she is growing up
column6: and she’s doing it in elegantly wry
column7: acerbic
column8: hooky pop style. Her blasé delivery might seem impenetrable at first
column9:
but there is warmth and wit to her work that rewards those who are patient enough to hear its message.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21546/homepage_large.2156c710.jpg|Gliss Riffer|5258.0|Dan Deacon|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2015-02-23 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:27.936548|"

It's been almost a decade since Baltimore singer/songwriter and electroacoustic composer Dan Deacon made his breakthrough with Spiderman of the Rings
column2: but it feels like longer. The album recalls a time when flamboyance and uncouth goofiness was close to the rule in indie rock
column3: and the possibility that Sade would be a frequent comparison point for new
column4: buzzworthy artists felt remote. On subsequent releases
column5: Deacon has put lustrous new coats of paint on the noisy and ambitious electro-pop sound he prototyped on Spiderman (and to a lesser extent
column6: his earlier
column7: more overtly experimental Carpark releases)
column8: shifting inspiration points and performing forces
column9: but not his fundamental aesthetic.

column1: That aesthetic unites elements of process music and primitively catchy pop
column2: blending the two until you're not sure which is the main article. On 2009's hyper-complex
column3: percussion-ensemble-driven Bromst and 2012's lush
column4: electro-orchestral America
column5: ""songs"" are less of a focal point: Deacon's heavily treated vocal melodies are simply kinetic layers in larger pieces. His recent return to a man-and-electronics approach—with a concise electro-disco lead single to match (""Feel the Lightning"")—has suggested that his first LP in three years
column6: Gliss Riffer
column7: might bring hooks and lighthearted mania back to the fore.

column1: However
column2: this tidy narrative doesn't really fit. First of all
column3: Gliss Riffer boasts few show-stopping choruses. Reverb and chorus effects dampen and blend his synth and 808 patterns
column4: creating the illusion of organic space and gradation where
column5: once
column6: all was coarse
column7: brittle and vacuum-sealed. More than a return-to-form album
column8: Gliss Riffer simply feels like an exploration of a more pared-back
column9: intuitive way of working.

column1: One of the things which has always made Deacon's music divisive is the difficulty of knowing what
column2: exactly
column3: he's ""going for."" Crude summaries vary—is this rave music for the DIY-house-show set? Avant-garde electronica? Performance art? Minimalism? Maximalism? The confusion is a testament to how over-stimulating his music can be. It's hard to decide where to focus when listening. At his finest
column4: most expansive moments
column5: Deacon renders this dilemma beside the point
column6: but on Gliss Riffer
column7: it's hard to avoid it; the battle between song and arrangement is staged in too small of an arena. Sometimes both seem to be vying for the spotlight without either one seeming totally worthy
column8: as in the robotic new-wave of ""Mind on Fire"" or the facile electro-punk of ""Sheathed Wings"".

column1: As on any of Deacon's albums
column2: it's the moments where he seems to be on the cusp of discovering something new that prove the most exciting. ""Take It to the Max"" sounds like Deacon coming out on the other side of Oneohtrix Point Never and PC Music. Opening like Steve Reich's Drumming: Windows 95 edition
column3: the amazingly detailed and constantly mutating piece builds powerfully
column4: its second half bolstered by synth-horn chorales
column5: high
column6: expressive woodwinds and glottal vocal noises. The Tangerine Dream synths interwoven through the decidedly funky ""Meme Generator"" create an unusually mellow atmosphere for Deacon
column7: and ""Steely Blues"" is bookended by sections of glacial
column8: arrhythmic synth ambience. He's not reinventing any wheel
column9: but these road tests of new textures are enjoyable and occasionally exceptional.

column1: By Deacon's own account
column2: the phrase ""gliss riffer"" refers to his penchant for manipulating loops of layered glissando (rapid ascending and/or descending streams of sequential notes). The title functions as a self-effacing joke
column3: but also evokes the album's straightforwardness of purpose: ""This is what I do
column4: I know what I do
column5: and I have fun doing it."" A more cynical interpretation would be ""Look
column6: more of the same."" The latter characterization would be unfair
column7: but by not making a point of challenging his instincts
column8:
Deacon nonetheless fails to climb to new heights.

column1:

Torche leave very little room for misinterpretation as Restarter
column2: their fourth album
column3: begins. On vicious opener ""Annihilation Affair""
column4: the quartet wallops a short
column5: simple theme
column6: in unison
column7: at mid-tempo and very high volume. Frontman Steve Brooks barks his words
column8: delivering them like marching orders as an enemy approaches: ""Know it
column9: build it
column10: grow it
column11: blow it
column12: he shouts
column13: the band surging behind him. The action eventually grinds to a dissonant halt
column14: the guitars feeding back and screaming against the beat like a long train trying to brake before slipping into hell. After seeming so eager to capitalize on their pop underpinnings in recent years
column15: Torche arrive on <i>Restarter
column16: their Relapse debut
column17: as harsh
column18: heavy and mean as they have been in nearly a decade.

column1: Since the release of the head-turning 2008 shout-along Meanderthal
column2: and the subsequent dismissal of guitarist Juan Montoya
column3: Torche have not been shy about their melodic enthusiasm. Recorded as a trio
column4: the eight-track Songs for Singles aimed to cram captivating hooks into rock tunes that ran anywhere from 52 seconds to more than six minutes. After adding guitarist Andrew Elstner
column5: they cut Harmonicraft
column6: a record whose cover of furry beasts holding chocolate-chip cookies and puking rainbows portended their most brisk and ebullient batch of songs yet. Torche were still plenty demanding
column7: but the harmonies were brighter and the guitars both quicker and slicker. The metal at their core had started to melt; the big refrains and the bigger sound began to collapse into one another
column8: producing diminishing tension. Harmonicraft felt transitional
column9: putting Torche perhaps one album away from a package tour with retro-rock hawkers like Free Energy or Wolfmother.

column1: But Restarter push Torche back toward the more punishing pole of its sound. The brief ""Undone""
column2: for instance
column3: counts as one of the heaviest pieces in Torche's catalog. Brooks leads multiple marching sections
column4: but when he pauses
column5: they slip into the sort of down-tuned
column6: instrumental slogs that consumed multi-minute chunks of their early records. This allows Torche to be brutal while still moving
column7: a trick they've rarely mastered. This doesn't mean they've suddenly slid into doom or sludge metal. These 10 songs are actually no less memorable than those on Harmonicraft; ""Minions""
column8: ""Blasted""
column9: and ""Undone"" rank as new shoo-ins for any hypothetical best-of-Torche collection.

column1: This time
column2: though
column3: Torche achieve magnetism as a band that lumbers and roars in unison
column4: instead of manic
column5: flashy guitars or songs that seem in a hurry to reach an end. Bassist Jonathan Nuñez and drummer Rick Smith are essential like never before. They trace Brooks and Elstner closely
column6: fortifying every melody and movement with powerful
column7: unselfish playing. Brooks' seesaw singing during ""Annihilation Affair""
column8: for instance
column9: sticks because of how the bass and drums reinforce every note. Like the best songs from Meanderthal
column10: ""Loose Men"" is agile but strong
column11: lovable but aggressive. Its rhythm section is a juggernaut
column12: but it moves gracefully around a guitar solo
column13: like an elephant tap-dancing in a small room. During ""Minions""
column14: incisive guitar lines and Brooks' monotone singing crisscross like a game of cat's cradle; Nuñez and Smith pulse behind the action
column15: offering the equivalent of a house beat
column16: pushing you along with the song. ""Blasted"" is one of Restarter's quickest songs
column17: its racing tempo and vocals recalling Harmonicraft. But the rhythm section remains the bulwark beneath it
column18: not making room for the band's pop-rock maneuvers so much as forcing them to fight for space and attention. Brooks sings of lascivious men and scenes that seem stolen from The Fast and the Furious. The band pushes you along for the ride.

column1: Restarter is Torche's first album since Brooks reunited Floor
column2: the band's predecessor in terms of style and personnel. It seems as if
column3: in rebooting that old act
column4: he remembered the root of the formula for both: Write catchy songs and play them at undeniable volumes
column5: no gimmicks or flourishes necessary. On Restarter
column6: that precept again takes the lead
column7:
and Torche have made their most compelling record since Meanderthal.
