0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21464/homepage_large.823e5348.jpg|Rose Mountain|27878.0|Screaming Females|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Don Giovanni']|2015-02-23 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:29.183368|"

Screaming Females' 2012 album
column2: Ugly
column3: was a brazen arrangement of squeals
column4: wails
column5: and howls. Their new Rose Mountain
column6: like the title suggests
column7: pretties up the guitar rock trio's grotesque side. Since Ugly
column8: Screaming Females have reworked their songwriting process
column9: poring over the nuts and bolts of each composition. Marissa Paternoster
column10: the band's vocalist and guitarist
column11: also spent months fighting off a nasty bout of mono
column12: and chronicled the sterile boredom of doctor's offices in a slew of new songs. Rose Mountain might be Screaming Females' most deliberate music yet
column13: but it lacks much of their former wildness.

column1: What it's missing in ragged edges
column2: the band's sixth studio album makes up for in force. Matt Bayles produced the record
column3: and part of the change in mood comes from the strange way he slots Paternoster's guitar. He's more of a metal guy
column4: having worked with Mastodon
column5: Isis
column6: and Russian Circles; in his hands
column7: Screaming Females' frayed chords clump up into solid blocks. Rather than a backbone
column8: King Mike's basslines feel more like walls enclosing the whole sound into a smaller space. At times
column9:
the songs sound choked by the professionalism of their own treatment.

Though her voice falls lower in the mix this time
column10: Paternoster still pounds home powerhouses like ""Empty Head""
column11: whose chorus packs a blunt and heavy punch. But she's dropped the sneer on the edge of her words. On Ugly's ""Rotten Apple""
column12: she sings the line ""I'm a rotten apple"" six times at every chorus
column13: and each one feels bound up in a new irony. Her singing remains skilled and idiosyncratic
column14: but on Rose Mountain
column15: she plays things straight. Even her lyrics lose some of their sense of play; on ""Wishing Well""
column16: Paternoster imagines the titular change receptacle as a portal straight to hell
column17: a clunky image compared to
column18: say
column19: Kim Deal's lean
column20:
evocative turn of phrase (""spitting in a wishing well"") on ""Cannonball"".

Even when Rose Mountain addresses sickness directly
column21: its tone keeps closer to the ennui of a waiting room thick with the smell of hand sanitizer than the stifled pain of a blood draw in the exam room. On ""Ripe""
column22: Paternoster sings
column23: ""Peel the skin raw/ Pinch till the feeling's gone
column24: while the instrumentation around her—the stifled distortion
column25:
the clipped drums—sounds more numbing than painful.

They're still young
column26: but Screaming Females have carved out their own corner in this century's take on guitar rock. It's hard to fault them for going clean
column27: but it's easy to miss the happy accidents they stumbled upon when they weren't so worried about keeping within the lines. For an album about how bodies can betray us with their chaos

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21537/homepage_large.bf3cfca8.jpg|Ibeyi|32764.0|Ibeyi|['Global']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['XL']|2015-02-23 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:29.677829|"

""Ibeyi"" is the Yoruba term for the divine spirit that exists between twins. It is also the name of 20-year-old French-Cuban duo Naomi and Lisa-Kaindé Díaz. Currently based in Paris
column2: Lisa-Kaindé and Naomi grew up on both sides of the Atlantic. Their father was Cuban conguero and master percussionist Miguel ""Angá"" Díaz of Irakere and Buena Vista Social Club. Díaz passed away when Lisa-Kaindé and Naomi were only 11
column3: and their older sister Yanira followed him seven years later. But the sisters have taken up their legacies via their own music and their family's shared beliefs in Regla de Ocha. Regla de Ocha
column4: also known as Santería
column5: is a widely practiced Afro-Cuban religion based on the worship of orishas
column6: which have roots in West African Yoruba culture. Musically
column7: Ibeyi ground themselves firmly within these traditions
column8: but they weave them together with jazz
column9: soul
column10: hip-hop
column11: and downtempo/electronica. The result is their deeply evocative self-titled debut.

column1: In many ways
column2: Ibeyi is an extended ritual—a consecration of life and love
column3: both past and present. Fittingly
column4: the album opens with a Yoruba prayer to Eleggua
column5: the gatekeeper of crossroads and pathways
column6: whose blessing alone allows ceremonies to proceed. The presence of Eleggua and other orishas saturates the album
column7: thematically and musically. In ""River""
column8: for example
column9: Lisa-Kaindé and Naomi pray to Oshun
column10: the orisha of rivers and fertility. As the song begins
column11: a bass-heavy drum beat churns through a slow-moving current of looped ""ah""s
column12: and Lisa-Kaindé intones
column13: ""Carry away my dead leaves/ Let me baptize my soul with the help of your waters/ Sink my pains and complaints/ Let the river take them—"" she chokes up
column14: ""—river
column15: drown them!"" The track feels monumental; this is
column16: after all
column17: a call for rebirth. Yet
column18: upon stripping away the vocals and reverb
column19: it becomes apparent that the only other instruments involved are a MIDI controller (or two) and the occasional smattering of piano. And that's exactly what makes Ibeyi so remarkable. Instrumentally
column20: their music is sparse. But it always feels full
column21: with emotion and the kind of spirituality that is as deep as the people and circumstances that created it.

column1: And so it makes sense that Ibeyi is teeming with ghosts. Most prominent among them
column2: of course
column3: is their father's. On ""Think of You""
column4: the sisters sample Angá's drumming
column5: which fades in and out
column6: specter-like
column7: during the refrains when his daughters list the things that remind them of him (laughter
column8: walking on rhythm
column9: etc.). On ""Mama Says""
column10: he resurfaces in the frustrations Lisa-Kaindé expresses as she sees her mother struggle to find meaning in life after his death. And during the chant break
column11: she and Naomi pray to Eleggua
column12: who was their father's orisha.

column1: Vocally
column2: Lisa at times channels Nina Simone
column3: and in her higher register
column4: she can even recall Kate Bush circa ""Wuthering Heights"". Her ability to imbue deep emotion and otherworldliness into simple lyrics
column5: meanwhile
column6: is Björk-like. Naomi
column7: in turn
column8: explores the ways that Yoruba tradition and contemporary rhythms can meet. It's not quite what her father did on his last project
column9: in which he fused Afro-Cuban music with jazz and hip-hop
column10: but they both move from the same impulse. Naomi will sometimes play hip-hop beats on cajón
column11: or add electronic booms and claps that thunder through a track like ""Oya""
column12: in reference to the song's namesake—Oyá
column13: the orisha of storms and cemeteries.

column1: The texts and subtexts in Ibeyi keep unfolding
column2: but it feels immediate and direct regardless of how much of that text the listener is familiar with. Part of that is the nature of the language: Ibeyi do not just sing about their father
column3: or Yanira
column4: or once-lovers
column5: or the orishas; they sing to them. By and large
column6: they sing in terms of ""me
column7: ""you
column8: and ""we
column9: and at times
column10: the lines between those entities are blurred. Which means that we are automatically implicated
column11: living with them
column12: or at least standing very nearby.

column1: If there is a critique to make
column2: it's that the production can at times feel too smoothed over. Some of the rougher edges and raw(er) emotion that got the twins noticed in the first place get ironed out a bit. And one side effect is that a few of the album's final tracks sound somewhat similar in tonality
column3: tempo
column4: and their vibe. But Ibeyi still find subtle ways to create shape
column5: as in the single piano key that pulses like a heart monitor in ""Yanira""
column6: their song to their late sister
column7: or the chilling dissonance in the twins' harmonies throughout.

column1: By the end of the album
column2: Naomi and Lisa-Kaindé come full circle to face themselves
column3: ending as they began: with a prayer. This time
column4: it is to their namesake
column5: Ibeyi. It is a joyful moment. And it is also
column6: as every debut album attempts to but doesn't always succeed in being
column7:
a declaration of self.

"|20270.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20270-ibeyi/|7.4|Minna Zhou

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21397/homepage_large.172d409b.jpg|Nadastrom|32690.0|Nadastrom|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Friends of Friends']|2015-02-23 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:30.302161|"

Back in 2009
column2: when another D.C. area native brought mainstream attention to the region’s rap music
column3: DJ Dave Nada created his own sound on a whim. The style—called Moombahton— quickly resonated beyond the nation’s capital. The style's signature is a decelerated blend of Latin-infused techno that Nada conceived at a house party in Maryland. As the story goes
column4: the kids there were playing reggaeton and bachata when he arrived
column5: not at all aligned with the fast-paced EDM Nada planned to spin. So he slowed the Afrojack remix of Silvio Ecomo & Chuckie’s ""Moombah"" to 108 beats-per-minute ""and that’s when shit popped the fuck off
column6: Nada said a year later. ""I was losin’ it and told myself
column7: I need to make some edits of this shit!""

column1: So he did
column2: and everyone from Diplo to Skrillex made their own Moombahton remixes
column3: even though its origin—reggaeton—had lost its luster. As one-half of Nadastrom with production partner Matt Nordstrom
column4: Nada and Nordstrom’s first EP—2008’s Pussy—was an easy electro-house offering that didn’t fully tap into the duo’s creative well. The bounce kept the party going
column5: but it ultimately felt too thin for long-term enjoyment.

column1: For Nadastrom
column2: Nada and Nordstrom’s full-length debut
column3: the two move to a richer sound better suited for headphone listening than the dance floor. Sure
column4: Moombahton sounds good when you’re sipping drinks in D.C.’s U Street Music Hall
column5: but there’s only so many ways to contort the same two-step rhythms before they feel redundant. Perhaps influenced by their 2010 move to Los Angeles
column6: there’s a prevalent West Coast vibe throughout Nadastrom
column7: which resembles more of a woozy Brainfeeder aesthetic than a Pitbull retread. Vestiges of Moombahton emerge on Nadastrom track ""Headed Home""
column8: but it gives way quickly to a psychedelic pulse.

column1: To that end
column2: Nadastrom’s music doesn’t really force you to dance; instead
column3: it gradually pulls you in with warm synthesizers that billow above thick bass drums. Nadastrom is mostly instrumental
column4: yet when the producers use vocals
column5: they hide them behind dense
column6: amorphous melodies to keep their soundtrack at the forefront. ""Somebody"" is a standard EDM tune until halfway in
column7: when muffled chants calmly emerge to accentuate a foggy rhythm. The same goes for ""Fallen Down""
column8: except the words are indecipherable
column9: crystallizing the track’s surrealism.

column1: With ""Phantom Eyes""
column2: the album’s otherworldly centerpiece
column3: the song pivots between singer RYAT’s ghostly howls and the producers’ shape-shifting composition
column4: none of which comes together as a straightforward arrangement. It’s an intriguing tug-of-war that stands alone
column5: though it works best within the scope of the full LP. In a good way
column6: there aren’t many standouts on Nadastrom
column7: which
column8: like the producers’ mythical DJ sets
column9: falls into a nocturnal haze before it gently fades away. It’s a recording you have to play front to back to fully appreciate.

column1: Of course
column2: it isn’t entirely perfect: ""Hide the Advisement""
column3: a thin loop near the album’s center
column4: sort of comes and goes as a Radiohead clone. ""Medium Redeye"" starts off in an interesting way
column5: but its distorted mantra (""I’m gonna make this work/ I’m gonna figure this out"") and patchwork instrumental quickly grows stale
column6: especially since its situated between highlights ""In the Air"" (Pt 1 and 2)
column7: featuring singer Jesse Boykins III
column8: near the album’s end. Still
column9: it’s not enough to dampen Nadastrom’s vibe. As with their geographical shift
column10:
Nada and Nordstrom tread new sonic ground and seem comfortable in fresh surroundings. 

"|20128.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20128-nadastrom/|7.4|Marcus J. Moore

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21500/homepage_large.bc3808d5.jpg|Bad News Boys|8662.0|The King Khan & BBQ Show|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2015-02-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:31.836549|"

Arish ""King"" Khan and Mark ""BBQ"" Sultan have been partners in punk going on 20 years now
column2: enjoying an open marriage that’s allowed them to indulge passion projects outside their relationship
column3: secure in the knowledge they can always go home again (even as that home has changed from their native Montreal to Berlin). Alas
column4: in the six years that have elapsed since their previous outing as the King Khan & BBQ Show
column5: we’ve seen that even the most lax
column6: non-committal unions can turn tense
column7: with the duo cutting ties after a series of onstage blowups in 2010. And perhaps
column8: not coincidentally
column9: post-breakup
column10: each has ventured further afield from their garage-rock base: Sultan with his eclectic double-album set Whatever I Want/Whenever I Want
column11: Khan with Idle No More
column12: his regal 2013 outing with long-time backing band the Shrines. Their inevitable reunion effort
column13: Bad News Boys
column14: thus functions as a form of couples therapy: a reminder of shared values to get them back on the same page again. And
column15: naturally
column16: that page is still covered in blood
column17: spit
column18: sweat
column19: and other bodily fluids best left to a forensics team to verify.

column1: While all King Khan & BBQ Show albums to date have been built from the same rudiments—Khan’s rasp
column2: Sultan’s croon
column3: two frayed-string guitars
column4: and a ceaseless sleigh-belled stomp so steady
column5: you’d swear it’s a click track—2009’s Invisible Girl saw them tightening up their songcraft and
column6: if not totally scrub up their sound
column7: at least attempt to squeegee the surface-layer soot. With Bad News Boys
column8: however
column9: the duo jump back into the deep fryer where they cooked up 2006’s extra-greasy What’s for Dinner?
column10: the album that saw these two vets join younger comrades like Jay Reatard and the Black Lips on the frontlines of the umpteenth garage-rock revival. Recorded in Sultan’s Berlin home with just two microphones
column11: Bad News Boys delivers exactly what you’d expect: more crudely rendered songs about zombies and food (or
column12: more specifically
column13: what happens when the latter doesn’t agree with you)
column14: doled out according to pre-established rations: There’s the paisley-pop flashbacks (""Illuminations""
column15: ""Kiss My Sister’s Fist"")
column16: the church-pew R&B (""Ocean of Love"")
column17: the goofy novelty single (""Snackin’ After Midnight"")
column18: the puerile hardcore throwback (""D.F.O.""—as in ""diarrhea
column19: fuck off"")
column20: and another pair of winsome belt-’em-out ballads (""Buy Bye Bhai""
column21: ""Never Felt Like This"") to join the likes of ""Why Don’t You Lie"" and ""Third Ave."" on your prom slow-dance card.

column1: But the question of whether you need another record like this is ultimately answered by the fact that Khan and Sultan play like they need it
column2: barreling through these 12 songs with audible smiles on their faces and a reinvigorated sense of camaraderie. And while the composition of Bad News Boys adheres to a tried ‘n’ true formula
column3: the songs here consistently yield charming little details
column4: like the bouncing baritone harmony that serves as a secondary percussion track on Khan’s ""Illuminations""
column5: or the honey-sweet middle eight that emerges from the psychotic-reactive crunch of ""When Will I Be Tamed?"" or the quote from Hendrix’s meditative ""Third Stone From the Sun"" that turns up amid the cartoonish
column6: cannibalistic anarchy of ""Snackin’ After Midnight"". Khan and Sultan may be devout rock'n'roll traditionalists at heart
column7: but their deft balance of sweetness and insolence remains distinctly their own. When the heart-rending jangle-pop of ""Never Felt Like This"" gets rudely upended by the cantankerous closer ""Zen Machines""—a sort-of juke-joint update of the Suicidal Tendencies’ ""Institutionalized""
column8:
with the Pepsi product placement swapped for puzzling Conan O’Brien shout-outs—it feels less like a willful act of self-destruction than a rightful restoring of order in the King Khan & BBQ universe.

"|20232.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20232-bad-news-boys/|7.0|Stuart Berman

My Love|32714.0|The Juliana Hatfield Three|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['American Laundromat']|2015-02-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:32.473360|"

Blake Babies
column3: the Boston trio of vocalist/bassist Juliana Hatfield
column4: guitarist/vocalist John Strohm
column5: and drummer Freda Love
column6: were one of those late '80s/early '90s bands who felt huge to what turned out be basically just a few people. But their first three albums
column7: especially 1989's Earwig and 1990's Sunburn (and 1991's Rosy Jack World EP)
column8: were on constant rotation for a certain frustrated New Jersey teen: Hatfield's angsty lyrics and crystalline voice
column9: the ramshackle instrumentation and perfect hooks; the reference to William Blake (via Allen Ginsberg
column10: no less); the Dinosaur Jr. and Stooges covers
column11: that they shaved their hair and cut their fingers in their videos and wrote a song about the life-saving effect of early Nirvana. They felt like your peers
column12: and part of your underground
column13: but were also clearly further along than you were.

column1: Hatfield was the one doing most of the singing
column2: and stood front and center in the press photos
column3: so when she went solo in 1992 with Hey Babe
column4: it made sense. Despite her blue-black hair on the cover
column5: that record felt like a continuation of Blake Babies—it included a revved-up electric version of ""Nirvana"" and a song co-written with Strohm. The same goes for 1993's Become What You Are
column6: which found Hatfield on guitar with bassist Dean Fisher and drummer Todd Philips as the Juliana Hatfield Three. The personnel was different
column7: but it felt like part of a whole.

column1: Now
column2: after 13 solo albums (the last being 2013's Wild Animals)
column3: work with Some Girls
column4: Minor Alps
column5: and a briefly reunited Blake Babies
column6: Hatfield has rejoined Fisher and Philips for <i>Whatever
column7: My Love
column8: a record billed as ""the first Juliana Hatfield Three album in over 21 years."" Which
column9: yeah
column10: technically
column11: it is. Fans at the time
column12: though
column13: saw Philips playing drums with Hatfield on the Hey Babe tour
column14: and the distinction of ""solo"" versus full band didn't register. After all
column15: that first solo album featured contributions from Philips (on most of the songs) along with contributions from Blake Babies regular Evan Dando
column16: John Wesley Harding
column17: Mike Watt
column18: and others. What Become What You Are had
column19: though
column20: were Hatfield's biggest hits. It featured ""Spin the Bottle"" (also on the Reality Bites soundtrack) and ""My Sister""
column21: and that's what the ""getting the band back together"" storyline is supposed to remind you of here. Because
column22: outside of a lauded Elliott Smith cover last year
column23: there haven't been any real hits since then.

column1: It's worth mentioning
column2: too
column3: because Hatfield recorded that last solo album Wild Animals by herself: she played every instrument and produced it. She took the same solitary approach on 2010's coffee house collection
column4: Peace & Love. Throughout her career
column5: Hatfield's strongest work's emerged when she's clicked with her collaborators. She made magic with the Blake Babies. And she made magic with Fisher and Philips. So
column6: for longtime fans
column7: <i>Whatever
column8: My Love gives reason for optimism. And
column9: of the album
column10: Hatfield's said: ""We haven’t totally reinvented the wheel or anything."" Which is what you want to hear. She goes back to her earlier timeless sound
column11: one that emerged from punk
column12: and skips the saccharine singer-songwriter stuff.

column1: Wrapped in very '90s cover art
column2: Whatever opens with the breezy ""Invisible""
column3: a track that starts almost in medias res and sounds like it could've easily been written during the older
column4: prime period. And
column5: you know
column6: it was. I listened to Whatever a number of times before learning that my favorites—""Invisible""
column7: the excellent first single ""If I Could""
column8: and ""Now That I Have Found You""—were all songs she wrote in the mid-to-late-'90s. They were demos previously
column9: and only given the full studio treatment now. They have the classic guitar tone
column10: and a kind of effortlessness to the hooks. Another standout is ""I'm Shy""
column11: a lite rocker that reminds me of the Blake Babies cover of ""Loose""
column12: featuring straightforward
column13: sharp lyrics about
column14: well
column15: being shy. These could've showed up on any of those older records and been standouts.

column1: That effortlessness is harder to locate on the stiffer
column2: less distinctive material. These are leaden
column3: relatively tuneless songs like ""Push Pin"" (which
column4: oddly
column5: feels like a soft post-punk They Might Be Giants outtake)
column6: ""Blame the Stylist""
column7: ""Dog on a Chain""
column8: ""I Don't Know What to Do With My Hands"" (which does have a good synth-accompanied bridge)
column9: ""Wood"" (which sounds like wood)
column10: and ""If Only We Were Dogs""
column11: a silly song that was somehow chosen to be a single (complete with unfortunate video). These tend to go nowhere and feel longer than they actually are. (The way the album's sequenced
column12: you get you a bunch of the duds in a row
column13: making me think an EP of the six stronger tracks would've made more sense. Especially because the catchy mid-tempo closer
column14: ""Parking Lots""
column15: has plenty of charm and smart wordplay.)

column1: On a whole
column2: Whatever is milder and gentler than the darker Become What You Are; that comes with age
column3: I guess. But
column4: all said

column3: the clean
column4: starlit twinkles of synthesizer on ""He’s Not Real and He Ain’t Coming Back"". Should the Light Go Out is alluringly coated in reverb

Put too much reverb on an album and it tastes like reverb. Too many of Should the Light’s 10 songs just taste like reverb.

column2: exciting rock songs into a pleasant air-conditioner hum. On ""Word to the Wise""

column4: guttural register
column5: which are difficult to hear

column7: flange’d guitar solo that drives the song to its peak sounds as faraway as a car crash on a muted TV news broadcast. The pogoing ""Anything Goes"" feels similarly sapped. Live clips of Twin River reveal a much more dynamic band
column8: with a hint of Nashville twang and soul-rock heat that can’t really be discerned here. The closest we get is the slow 6/8 shuffle ""It Won’t Be Long""
column9: which offers a chance for Bromley to belt
column10: and lean into the whooping ""drinkin’ alone"" chorus.

Chris Ward
column2: aka singer/producer Tropics
column3: never quite found his sound on Parodia Flare
column4: his atmospheric 2011 debut. Its aesthetic—part-chillwave
column5: part-shoegaze—felt like a wistful backdrop for Wham!-era George Michael or Jamiroquai frontman Jay Kay without the standout vocals. Ward seemed content hiding his words behind thick layers of coffee-shop acid jazz and old-school R&B. Though he updated these sounds
column6: the result was tentative; debut albums should make bold statements
column7: and Ward’s direction was unclear.

column1: For Parodia follow-up Rapture
column2: Ward has cut back the haze
column3: showing a more vocally assured presence as he ponders broken romance. His newfound confidence is ironic
column4: given the record’s lovelorn premise: When your heart aches
column5: you generally don’t want to discuss what happened or how you contributed to the mess. You want to sit somewhere alone
column6: just you and your thoughts and a few Roberta Flack records. Throughout Rapture
column7: Ward asks sensitive questions that will feel familiar to anyone who has loved hard enough.

column1: He openly explores his hurt on Rapture
column2: and it’s obvious he’s still searching for a resolution. ""Could I have changed the things that stopped it?"" he ponders on ""Hunger"". ""How did I get to feel so helpless?"" ""How can you let go?/Give it time""
column3: he decides on album closer ""Not Enough"". His words are more prominent than anything on Parodia
column4: reflecting the scattered musings of a man clinging to the past while trying to figure out how to move on. ""I’m through telling all these lies
column5: he croons midway through the title track. ""Love is a hard thing to capture
column6: when you keep it all inside.""

column1: At its core
column2: Rapture details Ward’s quest for understanding and his eventual resignation. There’s an overwhelming sense of isolation that you feel in its hollow production and barely-there ballads
column3: the spacious electro-soul supporting Ward's despondent whimpers of regret. Rapture conjures an atmosphere of confessional intimacy: You can imagine Ward sitting by himself at a piano
column4: notepad in hand
column5: culling torment from a house that once held affection.

column1: In the album's second half
column2: the music breaks down and becomes more abstruse as Ward gains personal clarity. Transitional tracks like ""Perfume Kinship""
column3: ""Gloria"" and ""Torrents of Spring"" recall the abstract approach of Parodia
column4: but with a decidedly sexier feel. Overall
column5: Rapture is a decent step forward for Ward
column6: one that shows his progression as a composer
column7: but without enough variation
column8: the album grows sappy over repeated plays. Heartbreak records
column9: like Beck's downtrodden 2002 opus Sea Change or Bon Iver's For Emma
column10: Forever Ago
column11: need some central magnetism to keep pulling you back. Rapture’s nocturnal R&B plays well enough at moderate volume
column12:
but the grief-stricken mood becomes a bit stale without noteworthy tunes to revisit. Rapture is ultimately an honest effort devoid of staying power.

The Wave Pictures have a gift for making art of life’s cutting room floor. Fronted by David Tattersall
column3: a sharp songwriter with crafty rhymes and a bullied-schoolboy vibrato
column4: the trio has subsisted on the periphery of British indie for over a decade. While they hew to a one-take
column5: soundbites-and-solos setup
column6: their frequent output has been diverse enough to keep you checking in: Last year they released two quietly charming records
column7: a collaboration with Herman Dune’s Stanley Binks and a full-LP cover of Daniel Johnston’s Artistic Vice. Great Big Flamingo Burning Moon is roughly their 16th album
column8: their gnarliest yet
column9: and it’s another collaboration
column10: this one produced and co-written by beret-wearing punk artiste Billy Childish.

column1: Their mutual attraction figures: Both are prolific pseudo-amateurs and hail from cities outside London where punk never took off but hasn’t really died
column2: either. Solos aside
column3: the Wave Pictures have always cut a more modest path than forebears Hefner and Orange Juice
column4: but Great Big Flamingo’s garage-rock primitivism marks the first time they’ve really glamourized their limitations. The slight redirection is likely thanks to Childish
column5: who was expelled from art school for having ""an attitude of total rejection"" and has since devoted his life to demystifying the pompous institutions of modern art and music. The single ""Pea Green Coat"" (punning on <a href=""http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Nonsense_Songs
column6: _Stories
column7: _Botany
column8: _and_Alphabets/The_Owl_and_the_Pussycat"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">a line by nonsense poet Edward Lear) is not unlike a Childish painting
column9: nailing a couple of neat memories—the bustling station
column10: the garish coat in a sea of suits—to capture an alluring fragment.

column1: That’s a highlight
column2: and there are a few. Listening to songs like ""Fake Fox Fur Pillowcase"" and ""All the Birds Lined Up Dot Dot Dot"" is like reading an interesting person’s notebook with every second page ripped out. On the brilliantly hare-brained ""Frogs Sing Loudly in the Ditches""
column3: any pretence towards plot vanishes
column4: as if the notebook had been torn up in a huff and then hopelessly reassembled: ""It’s raining champagne but I’m struggling to breathe/ You can hold them in your hand
column5: that’s why they call them palm trees."" Elsewhere
column6: the bluesy riffs and relentlessly sparing observations wear thin. ""The Fire Alarm""
column7: for one
column8: darts poetically between ""polka dot shorts"" and a ""peppermint tongue"" without tying the loose visuals together. ""Sinister Purpose"" and ""Green River""
column9: back-to-back Creedence Clearwater Revival covers included at Childish’s behest
column10: might have benefited from an attitude of total rejection.

column1: Much of the record’s activity occurs at a distance
column2: drifting from the street and up through the window
column3: and Tattersall casts the same curious eye on buzzing insects and street sounds as his own vague exploits. It would be misleading to separate plot from scene-setting
column4: because often it's unclear which is which. Sometimes the domestic and external worlds merge sweetly–take the Larkin-like breeze that ""whistles like a kettle"" in ""At Dusk You Took Down the Blinds"". But later in the song
column5: over plaintive Sunday-morning strums
column6: Tattersall simply sends characters drifting between candlelit rooms. ""We curl up like hedgehogs/ And whisper to one another
column7: he teases in the chorus
column8: but the content of those whispers is left hanging
column9: and not in an appealing or enigmatic way. His style seems to be: What happened happened
column10: and that’s that.

column1: The best track here
column2: ""We Fell Asleep in the Blue Tent"" tells a fleeting
column3: straightforward love story over meandering bass and punk-club guitar stabs. Tattersall describes ""moths all dancing underneath the streetlight
column4: kids drinking cider in the shadows
column5: before walking up with his companion for ""paracetamol
column6: pineapple juice and that first cigarette."" It’s funny
column7: pinpoint-sharp
column8: and smartly evocative enough that Childish would probably consider it an irredeemable sell-out. But truthfully
column9: Great Big Flamingo Burning Moon could use more songs like it. As it is
column10:
the album feels slightly cluttered by a surfeit of dry minutiae that calls for a cutting room floor of its own.

Of all rock 'n' roll’s tropes and traditions
column2: is the official live album the most meaningless? There's a certain we-made-it hubris to it
column3: an assumption that people not only care enough to see you perform but that they wish to relive the experience in the privacy of their own homes
column4: too. It’s not enough to simply press ""Record"" and play: If you’re going to issue an onstage set
column5: you’d better make sure that the band behind you is rehearsed
column6: that your catalog is fit to be culled
column7: and that every factor in the room
column8: from the amplifiers to the engineer capturing it all
column9: is ready to be immortalized.

column1: What’s more
column2: the band had better be prepared to be more than a mere traveling karaoke machine. If they can’t add some new element or interpretation to the tunes
column3: why bother with a two-dimensional reproduction of something that happened in front of a three-dimensional audience? This troublesome sub-category has produced some incredible and urgent records

column7: then

column2: an exhaustive hour-and-a-half
column3: three-LP
column4: career-crossing set from Phosphorescent
column5: falls somewhere in between these extremes. Recorded during a four-night stand at the Music Hall of Williamsburg in Brooklyn nine months after the release of 2013’s Muchacho
column6: the album attempts to meet the extra pressures of the official live format. Surrounded by a six-piece that features drums and auxiliary percussion
column7: stopping for an intimate solo acoustic section
column8: and adding a string quartet on ""Song for Zula""
column9: Matthew Houck works to turn Live at the Music Hall into more than a mere document of another gig. The band recharges ""Dead Heart""
column10: an old organ-and-acoustic dirge
column11: with the neon-light electricity of Crazy Horse. They turn up the volume for a closing 10-minute version of ""Los Angeles""
column12: where Houck screams and the drummer rolls and the pianist pounds until the air of desolation becomes an exorcism. And they amplify the space-cowboy glee of ""Ride On/Right On""
column13: with Houck smiling audibly through the playful wah-wah pedal and calypso organ.

column1: But the six-piece around Houck is more competent than combustible
column2: a quality that’s long made Phosphorescent a good band to see for a 90-minute show but not one that makes you need to take them home. Phosphorescent was
column3: for years

column5: where players would fall into and out of a fold that clearly belonged to the frontman. And no matter how many people ended up playing on them
column6: his records were at their best when they read like personal transmissions
column7: confessions delivered during the dead of night or from the bottom of a bottle. In recent years
column8: though
column9: Phosphorescent has somewhat codified its lineup
column10: with anchors like Ricky Ray Jackson on guitar
column11: Christopher Marine on drums and Scott Stapleton supporting with piano and harmonies. They’re all here. Still
column12: these 19 songs make it clear that Phosphorescent remains Houck’s act. The players are there to support the songs
column13: not to rearrange them. As a result
column14: the musicians sometimes feel hemmed in
column15: leashed. ""A New Anhedonia"" is heavier and more indulgent than the Muchacho take
column16: but it mostly scans like the studio version sans its subtle flourishes. ""Terror in the Canyons (The Wounded Master)""
column17: which follows
column18: suffers the same problem. As if aware of the stasis
column19: Houck screams the final chorus
column20: his voice cracking in an uncontrolled eruption. For a singer who can make even the most tortured feelings sound like small talk
column21: it’s a rare error of overexertion.

column1: Indeed
column2: the star here remains the same that it’s been for much if not all of Phosphorescent’s discography—Houck’s voice
column3: a beautifully idiosyncratic instrument full of cracks and bumps and bruises that have always made his words feel lived-in and real. During the set’s three-song solo stretch
column4: he’s in stunning form
column5: whether condensing and distending the syllables in lithe little runs during ""A Picture of Our Torn Up Praise"" or harmonizing with himself and a loop pedal for the sublime close of ""Wolves"". During an organ-abetted rendition of ""Muchacho’s Tune""
column6: he brilliantly renders the helplessness and hope of the song’s protagonist. <span>He murmurs about being fucked up and being a fool

column9: he sounds the signal of his own redemption: “I’ll fix myself up to come and be with you.” The transition gives the familiar song a fresh layer of vulnerability. He's just as poignant leading the band through a full version of ""Wolves""
column10: too
column11: adding just enough soul-singer gusto to suggest abandon without losing control.

column7: linking his work to a strange but specific arc of predecessors that includes Will Oldham and Willie Nelson
column8: Brian Eno and Sandy Denny
column9: Neil Young and Leonard Cohen. The live album
column10: then
column11: seems inevitable for Phosphorescent

column13: the requisite features that bind the best ones. At points

that voice and a little air to breathe.

""East Coast
column2: West Coast
column3: you can jump in the sea/ I don't need no ocean

column10: Rubber City Rebels had zero trace of art in their DNA. Their theme song says it all: Firestone's big ""fuck you"" to both coasts celebrated Ohio's flyover status and admittedly crumbling industrial infrastructure

column1: Soul Jazz has released two new anthologies of Ohio proto-punk

column3: and post-punk from the late '70s and early '80s: <i>Burn Rubber City
column4: Burn! (centered on Akron) and Extermination Nights in the Sixth City (centered on Cleveland). Of the two

column1: Any Akron comp without Devo
column2: however

column4: and <i>Burn
column5: Rubber City
column6: Burn! includes the 1974 demos of ""Mechanical Man"" and ""Auto Modown"". Robotic
column7: withdrawn
column8: synth-twiddling
column9: and playfully bleak
column10: these two songs set the tone for later comp highlights such as Chi-Pig's ""Apu Api"" and ""Ring Around the Collar"". Neither would have been out of place on a contemporaneous Rough Trade comp
column11: and members of the Slits-esque Chi-Pig would go on to co-write Devo's ""Gates of Steel"". (Mark Mothersbaugh
column12: meanwhile

column2: jazz-fusion meander that seems to have been listed for historical purposes only

column5: of Gerald Casale of Devo as well as Chrissie Hynde

column7: also
column8: that this completist spirit didn't spill over to the Cramps
column9: who recorded a definitive batch of punkabilly demos in Akron in 1979 and whose frontman Lux Interior was a native.

column1: Akron has been honored with two documentaries about its punk heyday—2003's It's Everything
column2: and Then It's Gone and 2005's If You're Not Dead
column3: Play. Cleveland
column4: meanwhile
column5: has had none (with the exception of 2007's Cleveland Screaming

column7: Pere Ubu
column8: were every bit as trailblazing as their Akron counterparts Devo. The fresh context of Extermination Nights in the Sixth City gives the anthology's two Pere Ubu selections—""Heart of Darkness"" and ""Final Solution""
column9: plucked from their first two singles circa 1975 and '76—even more stark power. Leader David Thomas was still going by the ominous moniker Crocus Behemoth
column10: and his mystique pervades these remarkable documents

column12: Rocket from the Tombs

column15: but that's all they need; the anti-anthem remains as haywire and nihilistically disjointed as the day it crawled out of Thomas' feverish brain.

column1: Cleveland contained plenty of protean talent besides Pere Ubu and kin. The Dead Boys
column2: featuring former members of Rocket from the Tombs
column3: may have broken out of Cleveland and headed for New York's CBGB scene
column4: but plenty other punk-rock provocateurs stayed behind and flourished like blacktop weeds. Among them were the Pagans

column4: lackluster
column5: blues-rock oddity ""The Comb""—which appears on both The Akron Compilation and Burn Rubber City

column1: Still
column2: there's an underdog pride and a furious invention to this music that unites these anthologies. The ache of doomed ambition

column4: and often well beyond
column5: is palpable. Industrialized civilization may have been crumbling in the Rust Belt in the late '70s and early '80s
column6: but <i>Burn Rubber City
column7: Burn! and Extermination Nights in the Sixth City prove just how much decay

column9:
and the specter of encroaching dystopia can fuel the fiercest of sounds.

column10: Devo. But ""Rubber City Rebels"" represents Akron circa the late '70s far more passionately. Where Devo started out with a noise that was simultaneously punky and abstract
column11: Rubber City Rebels had zero trace of art in their DNA. Their theme song says it all: Firestone's big ""fuck you"" to both coasts celebrated Ohio's flyover status and admittedly crumbling industrial infrastructure
column12: boosting the Akron scene in much the same way the Stooges and the MC5 did for Detroit a decade before in the process.

column1: Soul Jazz has released two new anthologies of Ohio proto-punk
column2: punk
column3: and post-punk from the late '70s and early '80s: <i>Burn Rubber City
column4: Burn! (centered on Akron) and Extermination Nights in the Sixth City (centered on Cleveland). Of the two
column5: <i>Burn Rubber City
column6: Burn! has a clear blueprint in Stiff's The Akron Compilation. Four songs from the Stiff disc have found their way onto Burn Rubber City
column7: Burn!
column8: but that slight overlap isn't enough to make the album redundant. Instead
column9: the record fleshes out the portrait of Akron past. Bizarros and Rubber City Rebels blurred the line between bluesy
column10: hard-rocking
column11: keyboard-spiked proto-punk; in particular
column12: Bizzaro's own slithery theme song
column13: ""I Bizarro""
column14: dramatizes the shift between Detroit stoner-snarl and punk's frantic animosity. And although ""Rubber City Rebel"" doesn't appear on <i>Burn Rubber City
column15: Burn!
column16: the group is well represented by ""Kidnapped"" and ""Such a Fool""
column17: two tracks taken from their '77 split with the Bizarros that demonstrate the no-holds-barred ethic of the time
column18: before punk became petrified by its own image; the former is a raw
column19: blistering spasm that predicts the coming hardcore storm
column20: while the latter sounds as if it could be a raucous Alice Cooper demo.

column1: Any Akron comp without Devo
column2: however
column3: would be disastrously incomplete
column4: and <i>Burn
column5: Rubber City
column6: Burn! includes the 1974 demos of ""Mechanical Man"" and ""Auto Modown"". Robotic
column7: withdrawn
column8: synth-twiddling
column9: and playfully bleak
column10: these two songs set the tone for later comp highlights such as Chi-Pig's ""Apu Api"" and ""Ring Around the Collar"". Neither would have been out of place on a contemporaneous Rough Trade comp
column11: and members of the Slits-esque Chi-Pig would go on to co-write Devo's ""Gates of Steel"". (Mark Mothersbaugh
column12: meanwhile
column13: penned the lyrics for the group's ""Ring Around the Collar"".) Their presence helps pinpoint the big bang of Akron's more experimental contingent.

column1: But for every gem like Jane Aire & the Belvederes' ""When I Was Young""—in which Aire belts out gutsy and righteous tirades over jerky math-punk—there are oddities like ""Narrow Road"" by 15 60 75 Numbers Band—a listless
column2: jazz-fusion meander that seems to have been listed for historical purposes only
column3: seeing as how the group's lineup consisted
column4: at one point or another
column5: of Gerald Casale of Devo as well as Chrissie Hynde
column6: an Akronite who moved to England and launched the Pretenders just before the Akron scene took off. It's unfortunate
column7: also
column8: that this completist spirit didn't spill over to the Cramps
column9: who recorded a definitive batch of punkabilly demos in Akron in 1979 and whose frontman Lux Interior was a native.

column1: Akron has been honored with two documentaries about its punk heyday—2003's It's Everything
column2: and Then It's Gone and 2005's If You're Not Dead
column3: Play. Cleveland
column4: meanwhile
column5: has had none (with the exception of 2007's Cleveland Screaming
column6: covering the city's '80s hardcore scene). Yet Cleveland's leading band of the era
column7: Pere Ubu
column8: were every bit as trailblazing as their Akron counterparts Devo. The fresh context of Extermination Nights in the Sixth City gives the anthology's two Pere Ubu selections—""Heart of Darkness"" and ""Final Solution""
column9: plucked from their first two singles circa 1975 and '76—even more stark power. Leader David Thomas was still going by the ominous moniker Crocus Behemoth
column10: and his mystique pervades these remarkable documents
column11: which foreshadow the poetic tension and asperity of post-punk before punk itself had even solidified. Pere Ubu's predecessor
column12: Rocket from the Tombs
column13: gets a single song
column14: ""Life Stinks""
column15: but that's all they need; the anti-anthem remains as haywire and nihilistically disjointed as the day it crawled out of Thomas' feverish brain.

column1: Cleveland contained plenty of protean talent besides Pere Ubu and kin. The Dead Boys
column2: featuring former members of Rocket from the Tombs
column3: may have broken out of Cleveland and headed for New York's CBGB scene
column4: but plenty other punk-rock provocateurs stayed behind and flourished like blacktop weeds. Among them were the Pagans
column5: Cleveland's answer to Rubber City Rebels. Their pulsing
column6: Iggy-like conniptions are represented on Extermination Nights by three raging tracks
column7: most notably the garage-rock-on-glue-fumes desperation of ""Dead End America""—a beer-swilling
column8: blue-collar rallying cry in the midst of socioeconomic collapse.

column1: The artist side of the Cleveland scene finds expression on Extermination Nights
column2: too. The Electric Eels
column3: trafficking in punk savagery on ""Splittery Splat"" and avant-rock deconstruction on ""Bunnies"". The Mirrors' jangling
column4: atmospheric ""Hands in my Pockets"" parallels Television's dreamy vistas as well as England's Swell Maps; Poli Styrene Jass Band's twisted ""Drano in Your Veins"" is a fit of Syd Barrett-meets-Frank Zappa whimsy. These quirks help make for a more solid
column5: consistent listen than <i>Burn Rubber City
column6: Burn!—a higher batting average aided by the fact that Pere Ubu's tracks here reflect some of the best and most important music the group ever created
column7: while Devo's contributions to <i>Burn Rubber City
column8: Burn! amount to mere marginalia.

column1: Ironically
column2: one of the most popular bands to emerge from the collective ooze of <i>Burn Rubber City
column3: Burn! and Extermination Nights in the Sixth City were the Waitresses. The quirky
column4: lackluster
column5: blues-rock oddity ""The Comb""—which appears on both The Akron Compilation and Burn Rubber City
column6: Burn!—in no way prepares us for the new-wavers who eventually charted with ""I Know What Boys Like""
column7: performed the theme song to ""Square Pegs""
column8: and were covered by the Spice Girls and on ""Glee"". Their success underlines the lack of cohesion to the Akron and Cleveland scenes. They were a free-for-all mix of inspired amateurs
column9: ambitious opportunists
column10: and serious
column11: self-styled artists. In that way
column12: Ohio wasn't all that different from any other place
column13: then or now.

column1: Still
column2: there's an underdog pride and a furious invention to this music that unites these anthologies. The ache of doomed ambition
column3: of a creative spirit pushed to the limit of endurance
column4: and often well beyond
column5: is palpable. Industrialized civilization may have been crumbling in the Rust Belt in the late '70s and early '80s
column6: but <i>Burn Rubber City
column7: Burn! and Extermination Nights in the Sixth City prove just how much decay
column8: disenfranchisement
column9:
and the specter of encroaching dystopia can fuel the fiercest of sounds.

As part of the B-52s
column3: Kate Pierson has left a significant fingerprint on the last four decades of popular music. From their early
column4: kitschy new wave blasts to later PG-13 party hits like ""Love Shack""
column5: the group’s music has always been defined by an irreverent queerness: a patchwork quilt of influences
column6: a willingness to embrace femininity
column7: and a surprising resilience
column8: all fused together in the shape of a band that occupies a unique space in pop history. Pierson is one of the talented utility players that helps the band run—a multi-instrumentalist
column9: a songwriter
column10: and a distinctive vocalist—but hasn’t had a chance to shine on a solo basis until now: She’s releasing her first solo record
column11: Guitars and Microphones
column12: at the age of 66. (She came close a decade ago
column13: with a whole batch of songs ready for release
column14: but the project was scrapped as the B-52s began to work on comeback record Funplex.) It’s a project that’s been hatched with some surprising collaborators—reigning radio-pop weirdo Sia co-wrote and executive produced the album
column15: and the Strokes’ guitarist Nick Valensi plays on much of it—and perhaps the most remarkable thing about it is how conventional it sounds.

column1: If you spend your time with Guitars and Microphones hunting for some sonic signature on Sia’s part
column2: you won’t find it; she’s more of a complementary piece than a heavy-handed force when writing for others
column3: and that holds true for her work with Pierson. She excels at amplifying an artist’s best traits
column4: whether that means highlighting their areas of musical skill or connecting with them to help craft a particularly resonant piece of lyric. That’s what she does with Pierson throughout the record: The two of them understand that her greatest strength is her voice
column5: and they push it to the forefront of every song. Pierson hasn’t lost any of the force or heat that’s characterized her vocal work for 40 years; if anything
column6: she’s acquired the ability to enrich otherwise pedestrian line readings with a resonance that feels born of a life well lived. When she guns for high
column7: loud notes in climactic moments
column8: like on the dreamy ""Crush Me With Your Love""
column9: you can feel it burning in the pit of your stomach. That passion only intensifies when Pierson is singing about something that’s obviously important to her
column10: be it her relationship with partner Monica Coleman (""Crush Me With Your Love""
column11: ""Wolves"") or questions of independence and feminism (opener ""Throw Down the Roses""). The intensity is welcome
column12: because it brightens up arrangements that split the difference between two very familiar brands of recent rock music: the Shins’ luminous
column13: buoyant pop-rock
column14: and the Strokes’ sharper
column15: more tonally distinct work. The familiarity of the sounds is comforting
column16: but fleeting. The only thing you remember after finishing a song is Pierson’s voice.

column1: There’s only one real misstep on Guitars and Microphones
column2: but it’s a big one
column3: revolving around the concept and reception of lead single ""Mister Sister"". To hear Pierson tell it
column4: it’s a chugging would-be anthem for anyone who’s ever felt that what’s inside of them isn’t being adequately reflected by what they see in the mirror
column5: something that’s not specific to ideas about gender identity or sexuality or anything especially technical. But in giving a quote to the Huffington Post
column6: she used the phrase
column7: ""I hope it becomes a trans anthem
column8: ” a well-meaning but bold statement that seemed especially tone deaf given the song’s campier and more stereotypical elements. (If you’re interested in a more detailed analysis of why a potential Pierson attempt at a ""trans anthem"" would be inappropriate
column9: this Bustle article is worthwhile.)

column1: It was an unfortunate situation stemming from a miscommunication
column2: and a great example of the misunderstandings and hurt that can flare up between even members of two different wings of the broader LGBT community. Pierson was quick to apologize
column3: and has appeared eager to learn in interviews conducted since. But unintentional offence aside
column4: ""Mister Sister"" still feels like a relic from a different time; it aims for that aforementioned compassionate
column5: quirky B-52s queerness
column6: but falls short and ends up cheap and cloying. <span>On a purely musical level
column7: it lacks the melodic firepower and passion that colors the best of Guitars and Microphones
column8: with blocky riffs and a Pierson performance that skews a little campy but fails to engage the listener. Most importantly
column9: it’s an outlier on a record that manages to feel impressive
column10:
contemporary and vital with most of its other songs.

In 2012
column2: I came across a copy of DJ Sotofett’s ""Pulehouse""
column3: one of the more aslant electronic 12”s in recent memory. It's an EP designed to mimic the font of an old A&M Records promo while transmitting from some strange outpost in Norway. One uncanny track was ""Åsså Med Den Derre Fløyta (Video Bootleg Med Den Elektriske Fløyta)"" composed of white noise run through a ring modulator
column4: a Korg synthesizer and a plonking mbira that provided the telltale kick of a house beat. But then came a wheezing
column5: not-quite-tuned flute line
column6: unmooring it and nudging house music as close as it has ever come to the woozy
column7: ecstatic sound of Don Cherry’s Organic Music Society.

column1: But almost any DJ Sotofett release I encounter (they can be rather maddening to track down) produces that same sense of exhilaration and bewilderment
column2: the more incongruent the better. Take ""Lagrimas Negras""
column3: where he twines Fran Benitez’s Spanish plaint around an ominous deep house throb
column4: a mood not unlike that whisper of ""silencio"" from Mulholland Drive stretched out over nearly 12 minutes. Across numerous vinyl releases
column5: he scans as a mischievous scamp
column6: prone to have his tracks wander across acid
column7: freestyle
column8: nu-disco
column9: stiff digital reggae
column10: sweaty house
column11: cheeky New Age
column12: as un-peggable as untraceable. Drippin’ for a Tripp
column13: his double 12” for UK’s Honest Jon’s label
column14: is about as far as he’s ever gone above ground
column15: with each side of the record showcasing a different style.

column1: For having such a peculiar sensibility
column2: Sotofett collaborates often with a broad range of musicians. There’s that flautist
column3: sure
column4: but he’s also engaged with fellow countryman Prins Thomas
column5: NYC disco producer Tim ""Love"" Lee
column6: and noisy techno producer Madteo
column7: to name just a few. And Drippin’ showcases a new set of colleagues. There’s tracks made with influential Parisian producer/label head Gilb'R
column8: Finnish musician Jaakko Eino Kalevi and German producer Phillip Lauer (both heard most recently via singles on the Beats in Space imprint). Kalevi contributes a slowly unspooling guitar line to the opening spiral of ""Ibiza Dub (with Thomas ""Paleo's Buddy"" Mende)"" and then the ""Main Bar Mix"" seems to be engineered specifically for José Padilla to play in Ibiza come sunset
column9: a warm
column10: shiny
column11: undeniably Balearic track that if you listen closely to
column12: you can hear crickets chirping underneath all that bass. Lauer joins the proceedings on the second side. In light of Edgar Froese’s recent passing
column13: ""Space Dub"" feels like an homage of sorts
column14: a gentle
column15: twinkling slice of kosmische
column16: while the nine-minute ""Nimbus-Mix"" adds shortwave squiggles
column17: charming high frequencies
column18: and bathtub-warm bass that brings to mind early Fila Brazillia.

column1: On the second disc
column2: there’s another take on the original ""Pulehouse""
column3: those dreamy swells of Korg still intact
column4: but with the starchy Nordic digital reggae drum programming of the original replaced by a battery of hand drums
column5: nudging it over into tribal house territory. The highlight of the set is Sotofett’s collaboration with Karolin Tampere and Maimouna Haugen on ""Nondo"". The sputtering keys at times make me think of A-Musik productions
column6: but the vocals bring to mind African house music. But then the beat also bears a stutter and skip that could make you think you heard it at a Que Bajo party or else on some cosmic soca compilation. The exotic melody snaking underneath it all at some stretches makes me think of Arabic music
column7: at other times like something off of Synthesizing: Ten Ragas to a Disco Beat. Like the best Sotofett productions though
column8:
it draws a bit from everywhere yet sounds like it’s from nowhere at all.

During her eight years as the drummer in Osaka rock band Afrirampo
column2: the artist known as Pikachu hardly ever sat still. Along with sister and guitarist Oni
column3: the duo created frantic numbers packed with feedback and screaming
column4: guided by a playful curiosity in what sounds their instruments and bodies could cough up. Pikachu hammered away at her kit while hollering into a microphone
column5: and even their most slow-burning moments rarely allowed her space to rest. By the time Afrirampo disbanded in 2010
column6: they had carved out a space next to fellow Japanese noise rockers (and friends) Boredoms and Acid Mothers Temple
column7: while attracting attention from the likes of Sonic Youth and Lightning Bolt among others.

column1: It might be surprising for those who didn’t follow Pikachu’s career after Afrirampo to hear Ryu No Sumika
column2: her latest solo album recorded under the moniker Pika. She’s always been part of various side projects even while Afrirampo barreled forward
column3: most notably as Moon Mama
column4: which sometimes featured cello player Hiromichi Sakamoto taking an electric drill to his instrument. Like many Japanese musicians
column5: however
column6: she changed her focus after the 2011 Great East Japan Earthquake and subsequent Fukushima Daiichi nuclear incident. She helped start Taiyo 33 Osaka
column7: a project focusing on exploring future of energy sources and just making people feel happy after the disaster. And she started playing the songs that would end up forming Sumika
column8: songs that moved away from chaos in favor of reflective numbers that are happy to take their time getting anywhere.

column1: The title track opens the album
column2: and it offers a fake out aimed at anyone expecting a reversion to Afrirampo form. After nearly four minutes of build
column3: Pikachu lets the song burst open in a rush of chirps
column4: drum smacks and guitar squall. But this brief stretch ends up being the only real throwback to her dissonant heyday
column5: as the bulk of Ryu No Sumika finds Pikachu operating against sparser backdrops. ""Reazon"" strolls forward via acoustic guitar and piano
column6: while ""Kara Wo Mitara"" is pure campfire sing-a-long
column7: accented by clarinet courtesy of David Duval-Smith.

column1: Afrirampo
column2: however
column3: wasn’t just great because they could make clattering shriekfests better than most. They were an extremely fun band
column4: unafraid to go off in whatever goofy direction appealed to them
column5: including pretending to be various Australian mammals in concert. The sonic backdrop might be different
column6: but Pikachu is still unafraid to follow whatever muse beckons her forward. Highlight ""Mermaid"" might be the closest Japan’s noise community comes to making a Broadway number
column7: as Pikachu verbally skips among steel drums
column8: at one point ditching words entirely in favor of tongue trills (adding to the theater vibe
column9: several guests are credited as ""performers
column10: their roles listed as ""Merman"" or ""Merman’s friend""). Elsewhere
column11: she spends seven minutes listing off different types of people
column12: sometimes with vague political implications (""American"" and ""Iraqi"" falling next to each other for example) and somehow making this potentially eye-rolling sentiment work thanks to her enthusiasm for the idea...along with drama-raising violin from Katsui Yuji.

column1: Yuji is a good example of what else makes Ryu No Sumika work. Pikachu’s selection in contributors comprises an all-star cast of artists hailing from Japan’s improvised and experimental music communities
column2: and many of their contributions add welcome tension. Sakamoto appears across Sumika
column3: and though he never grinds power tools against his cello
column4: he does add prickles of unease to otherwise direct songs such as ""Onnanoko Yurayura"". Acid Mothers Temple mastermind Kawabata Makoto joins Pikachu
column5: wonky singer-songwriter Tavito Nanao and sine-wave aficionado Sachiko M on ""Sen""
column6: Sumika’s bleakest cut. Saeki Mayumi—better known as Afrirampo’s Oni—even stops by to read poetry on an interlude track.

column1: That moment feels important
column2: a signal that the freewheeling spirit behind Afrirampo also inhabits Ryu No Sumika
column3: just in a different shape. Sometimes Pikachu’s more patient approach falters
column4: with several songs meandering and going on too long
column5: but it also results in some deeply sweet and earnest moments. ""Okaasan"" opens with the line ""Mother/ Yesterday mother died
column6: and from there Pikachu turns in her most passionate vocals on the album as the music swells around her
column7:
reaching the point where her singing approaches breakdown. It’s the peak emotional moment on an album where Pikachu matures musically without losing the youthful playfulness that led her to this point.

You’d never describe José González’s music as ""confrontational
column2: but Vestiges & Claws
column3: his first solo album since 2007
column4: offers an odd kind of ultimatum. After eight years of extreme cultural
column5: political and artistic upheaval
column6: it's likely that you're in a much different place than you were when In Our Nature was released. Meanwhile
column7: the music of José González has not changed at all. Are you in or are you out?

column1: Whether it’s his greatest asset or biggest sticking point
column2: González endures while the context around him changes. Veneer had the benefit of timing
column3: as Garden State and ""The O.C."" were redefining ""alt-rock"" as ""indie."" González evoked the spare beauty of Nick Drake’s Pink Moon but not the crippling emotional baggage
column4: and he had a good ear for crowd-pleasing covers
column5: easing fans into Kylie Minogue
column6: Joy Division
column7: and the Knife (prior to their Silent Shout about-face) when walls between genres seemed more solid. By 2007's In Our Nature
column8: his name was mentioned alongside whispery and haunted projects like Bon Iver
column9: Iron & Wine
column10: and Sun Kil Moon; González is the only one that can still be described as whispery and haunted in 2015.

column1: González self-produces on Vestiges & Claws and there’s an unvarnished
column2: prickly edge to the recording. Even when others are in the room
column3: the album feels solitary—the cello and flute on ""The Forest"" might as well be weaving in and out of González’s head. His best songs don’t unfold
column4: exactly; instead
column5: the cyclical guitar and vocal patterns sound like they’re adding invisible but perceptible layers. Though his vocals are as soft and supple as a down comforter
column6: there’s an eerie quality to González’s restraint and levity. He reaches for high notes and hooks
column7: but he never raises his voice—he’s post-anger
column8: post-verse-and-chorus. His fingerpicking lends a percussive
column9: rhythmic drive that can obscure the actual drums. The percussion on ""Leaf Off / The Cave"" is almost imperceptible under off-kilter
column10: low-register riffs that sound like Trail of Dead arranged for a campfire singalong.

column1: Though González’s music is pastoral in timbre and placid in pace
column2: his songs ask big questions. How do you situate yourself in the world? What makes a person take dominion over another? How much time should a laborer set aside for leisure? How can you make your voice heard without crowding out those who feel less inclined to speak? His approach to songwriting has appeal in light of the stridency and self-righteousness of modern discourse. But González’s metaphors can also feel unnecessarily feathery or too general: ""Every Age"" buckles under the assumed weight of its introductory lyric (""Every age has its turn/ Every branch of the tree has to learn/ Learn to grow
column3: find its way"")
column4: and while ""Leaf Off / The Cave"" boasts the record’s loveliest arrangement
column5: the connection between the Garden of Eden and Plato’s Cave is specious and tenuous in a charming
column6: AP English sort of way.

column1: Even when Vestiges & Claws exudes strain
column2: González never gives the impression of truly challenging himself. When he draws on the canons of both ancient philosophy and post-punk
column3: he sounds like José González. Whether covering Massive Attack
column4: Bruce Springsteen
column5: or Low
column6: he sounds like José González. Even when fronting a legitimate
column7: kraut-influenced rock band in Junip
column8: it just sounds like José González with the rhythmic tracework of his solo albums filled in. But as a record that so frequently meditates on unchanging human nature
column9:
that could just mean Vestiges & Claws achieved exactly what it set out to do.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21430/homepage_large.1603d83b.jpg|A Distant Fist Unclenching|31405.0|Krill|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Exploding in Sound'
column2:

There was a time when you might have confused Krill with a band who cared more about actual shit than giving one. ""Turd""
column3: from a 2014 EP released by the grunge-pop Boston slackers
column4: found frontman Jonah Furman imagining himself as the titular piece of fecal matter. ""If I could just be ate/ At least someone might say I was worthy
column5: he sings
column6: resigned to a life as an undigested peanut.

column1: So yeah
column2: Krill are a little juvenile and a lot insecure—the title of that EP
column3: Steve Hears Pile in Malden and Bursts into Tears
column4: refers to Krill’s admiration for (and low-key jealousy of) fellow Bostonians and Exploding in Sound label-mates Pile. On Lucky Leaves
column5: Krill’s borderline-paranoid 2013 album
column6: Furman defended the right to feel like a failure. But in the year that followed the release of Steve
column7: something changed. ""I was thinking about how Lucky Leaves had all of this sad shit
column8: and I believed in it and totally agree with it
column9: but I wanted to see where you could go after that
column10: Furman told Rolling Stone last month. The result is the band’s best album to date
column11: the bigger
column12: brighter and bolder A Distant Fist Unclenching
column13: which locates a weird confidence in the universality of our individual anxieties.

column1: Pile-worship aside
column2: Fist finds more evident kinship with another band just a few hundred miles north: Montreal's Ought
column3: whose More Than Any Other Day was one of last year’s finest indie rock releases. Both Furman and Ought’s Tim Beeler deal in open-ended questions and nervous tics
column4: suggesting worried young men striving for uncommon lives. Though Fist has more passion than anything Krill have done
column5: Furman is still a dyspeptic figure
column6: asking God to grant him strength to deal with his ""brain problem.""

column1: But for all of Furman’s neuroses
column2: there’s a purgative quality to Fist that feels almost joyful. It helps that the band has become powerful enough to lift Furman out of his own head for a little while
column3: boosted also by cleaner production and more distinctive guitar work. Their secret weapon remains drummer Ian Becker
column4: whose dynamics and off-kilter rhythms keep everyone on their toes. Once content with mere tantrums
column5: Krill are now flirting with an almost anthemic sound
column6: with songs like ""Squirrels"" and ""Brain Problem"" climaxing in ways big enough to inspire listeners to keep their fists not only clenched
column7: but aloft.

column1: Fist will present a few sticking points for some listeners
column2: the most notable being Furman’s voice. Like an unfortunate cross between Eef Barzelay and Jeremy Freedman (plus a little Bobcat Goldthwait for when he gets really riled up)
column3: it scans anywhere from vaguely comical in its jittery frogginess to weirdly precious. And while he's deft with odds turn of phrase
column4: Furman is often too reliant on metaphors either too simple (""It Ends"") or too open-ended to connect. But when they get it right
column5: like on the stuttering S&M allegory ""Torturer""
column6: everything clicks into place.

column1: Above all else
column2: A Distant Fist Unclenching is an album about embracing clarity in the face of constant
column3: nagging doubt <span>(""To be given one shot
column4: and to know I could blow it
column5: Furman wails on ""Squirrels""). On seven-minute centerpiece ""Tiger""
column6: the titular unclenched fist appears ""in the distance
column7: but ""in the nearness
column8: Furman sings
column9: ""there is a bad day ending."" Though Krill aren’t quite ready to let go of the anxieties that inspired them to write their eccentricities in excrement in the first place
column10:
Fist suggests that there is light at the end of the sewer drain.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21497/homepage_large.4606aa71.jpg|Tragedy of the Commons EP|32736.0|Felix K|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blackest Ever Black']|2015-02-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:40.322602|"

Berlin-based producer and DJ Felix Krone comes across as well-adjusted enough in interviews
column2: but if you're looking at only the smattering of records he has released since debuting under the name Felix K in the late '90s
column3: he seems to nurse a dark streak. In some senses
column4: that was par for the course of the bare
column5: monochromatic drum and bass exercises that have populated many of his releases. Over the past couple of years
column6: the man has morphed into a kitchen-sink sort of tinkerer
column7: with one hand still dedicated to the rapid-fire clicks and thumps of the now-aging sphere he came up in. But he's casually embraced a whole host of genres with similarly downcast dispositions: brittle blasts of noise
column8: desolate stretches of ambient composition
column9: the thunderous foreboding bass work of dub. On Tragedy of the Commons
column10: Krone engages single-mindedly with those gloomy impulses and crafts a uniquely bleak release fitting of its home on the London-based purveyors of all things Cimmerian Blackest Ever Black.

column1: Much of this EP's runtime is taken up by the title track
column2: an expansive ambient piece that manages to be his most striking meditation on melancholia yet. Devoid of the jittery percussion that's marked most of his work
column3: he's free to indulge in more abstract composition. Bleary smears of off-kilter arpeggios and thunderous bass blasts that give a sense of immediacy to the track's delirious plod and found sound samples of ghostly chatters and creaks lend a bodily terror to the piece. Beyond the purely cinematic horror of many darker ambient works
column4: Krone adds details that give ""Tragedy of the Commons"" a sense of a real physical space
column5: a grimy sort of environment that becomes more unsettling the more you explore it.

column1: At its 17-and-a-half-minute length
column2: the murk and mire of ""Tragedy of the Commons"" could have easily collapsed in on itself
column3: but as static-y samples and slurred synth lines continually edge their way into the mix
column4: it manages to earn its monumental length. Despite the fact that Krone is used to using drums to give shape and form to his tracks
column5: he's still able here to give an amorphous piece some narrative weight. He demonstrates a knack for casually adding more and more moving parts to the mix
column6: spinning details off one another to reshape the structure into fresh
column7: unfamiliar forms across the track's whole runtime. It's an approach he picks back up on the B-side too. And though the drums return for the shorter piece ""Silent Money""
column8: he's still scrambling tenebrous synthesizer parts and spoken-word samples as the track proceeds
column9: making even the more familiar structures of that work hard to fully apprehend.

column1: Marginally less essential is the collection's closer
column2: a thunderous rave-up called ""Fundamentals"" that's credited as a remix by the unknown quantity Onar Anxiety. Billowing noise is pinned down instead here by a pummeling drum loop that doesn't relent for more than a few moments of the track's six minutes
column3: and it settles into a more static sort of horror that underscores Tragedy of the Commons' dynamic high points. Felix K is still working with the same black-and-white palette that's colored his whole career. But in stretching out and working in a more explicitly formless mode
column4:
he's granted more freedom to play with a more fully developed vision of instrumental darkness than ever before.

"|20229.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20229-tragedy-of-the-commons-ep/|7.4|Colin Joyce

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21499/homepage_large.6c52717f.jpg|Carter Tutti Plays Chris & Cosey|32738.0|Carter Tutti|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Conspiracy International']|2015-02-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:40.893051|"

The past is so present in today's musical landscape that you can easily connect the dots when an artist looks backwards. A greatest-hits tour on its third go-around or a lengthy set of dates performing a single album from start to finish—both reek of good ideas gone stale
column2: or some form of stasis winning out over creative urges. The difference between a cash grab and a victory lap feels ever more slight. Of course
column3: it’s not always that way. There’s even something to be said for artists approaching their back catalog with a sort of humorous disdain. In the late 1980s
column4: art-punks Wire reformed
column5: only to announce they wouldn’t play any of their older material
column6: instead hiring a cover band
column7: the Ex-Lion Tamers
column8: to perform that function in the opening slot of their shows.

column1: The approach Wire took for those concerts—essentially not giving fans what they want
column2: even actively antagonizing them—is a feeling with which Chris Carter and Cosey Fanni Tutti
column3: founding members of industrial behemoths Throbbing Gristle
column4: are acutely familiar. These are people
column5: after all
column6: who were once deemed the ""wreckers of civilisation."" Carter Tutti have been addressing their past
column7: in various tours and reissue programs
column8: for more than 10 years at this point. Their path through it is often inspired
column9: with the dissolution of the reunited Throbbing Gristle leading to the excellent X-TG album. In tandem
column10: their brittle electronic music as Chris & Cosey began to cast a long influence over body music-inspired artists such as Factory Floor
column11: culminating in a fully energized collaboration with that band’s Nik Colk Void.

column1: Since 2011
column2: the pair have been sporadically playing dates where they take a fresh approach to the Chris & Cosey material
column3: stripping it of the production trappings of the various eras they draw on
column4: instead replacing it with something tougher and far more impactful. This is the recorded document to accompany those shows
column5: put together in Carter Tutti’s studio in the English countryside. It’s a sound that meshes elements of their past lives—the fussy electronics speak of Carter’s career as a synth boffin and TV sound engineer
column6: while the pulsing backing and breathy vocals hark to Tutti’s work as a stripper. Tutti even recalled as much in a recent Wire interview. ""I was bringing back things like Donna Summer and Giorgio Moroder from my stripping
column7: she said
column8: of Throbbing Gristle’s attempted turn to that sound.

column1: Carter Tutti Plays Chris & Cosey illustrates the extent to which Carter Tutti are still enamored with dousing raw electronics in a seedy
column2: heavily sexualized tone. Much of the album moves at a trance-like pace
column3: strung somewhere between something you can either dance to or zone out on. The opening ""Lost Bliss"" (from Megatropolis) and ""Driving Blind"" (from Songs of Love & Lust) are highlights
column4: bringing in a pop edge and much fuller production than the originals—a signature strung throughout most of these reworkings. It’s possible to hear legions of electronic acts from the past decade or so in here
column5: including Zola Jesus
column6: Ladytron
column7: even Fischerspooner
column8: making it easy to conclude that Tutti’s vocal style—masterfully disengaged no matter what the subject matter—might be one of the great unheralded influences of the 2000s.

column1: It’s not hard to see why the Carter Tutti/Factory Floor relationship flourished so fruitfully when working through this material. Both work from a starting point that’s largely unmoveable—rippling Moroder electronics
column2: a pinch of dance culture that’s more observatory than participatory—and drive their point into the ground over the course of an album. The shift from ""Beatbeatbeat"" (from Exotica) to ""Workout"" (a 1987 single) highlights how they build with remarkably similar tools then subtly corrupt the formula from within. ""Workout"" is wonderfully obliterated by Tutti’s railroad guitar lines
column3: which butt up against chunky synth patterns that divert close to the whiteout assault of 808 State’s ""In Yer Face"" (a track actually released a few years after ""Workout"").

column1: Overhauling prior work may not be the most unique tool in the backward facing bandwagon of old lags giving the circuit one last run-around. But the difference with Plays Chris & Cosey is of a duo pushing beyond what came before instead of resting too heavily on things that already exist
column2: in much the same way as it was in the general atmosphere of the X-TG album. They make revisiting the past sound like a creative place to be
column3: where latent potential is given some room to breathe in the noxious
column4: leather-fueled atmosphere of these songs. An important aspect
column5: perhaps
column6: is that Carter Tutti have myriad contemporary projects they’re working on at the same time as addressing material like this. As such
column7:
this record reads like an object lesson in how former glories are sometime best served by becoming a malleable part of the present.
