column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21530/homepage_large.b86973f6.jpg|Comb the Feelings Through Your Hair|28509.0|Grooms|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Western Vinyl']|2015-02-18 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:41.618829|"

Brooklyn indie-rockers Grooms announced the release of their previous album
column2: 2013’s Infinity Caller
column3: by admitting they nearly broke up twice while making it. Things did not get any easier for them in the interim. After skipping out on Infinity Caller’s tours due to day-job commitments
column4: bassist Emily Ambruso—whose history with band co-founder Travis Johnson dates back to their pre-Grooms outfit
column5: the Muggabears—decided she could no longer afford to be in the band. That said
column6: no amount of financial security could’ve inured Grooms to the subsequent blow of losing their longtime studio space
column7: Death by Audio
column8: last fall to the office complex that ate Williamsburg. All this would seemingly make Grooms the ideal sad-sack subjects for some ""60 Minutes"" segment on the depressing economic reality of the aspiring modern American indie-rock band. But don’t feel too sorry for Grooms—on their fourth and most illuminating album to date
column9: the band don’t sound defeated so much as defiantly liberated.

column1: The trajectory of Travis Johnson’s creative evolution mirrors that of indie rock itself. Where the Muggabears conjured a distinctly early-'90s discord
column2: and the first few Grooms albums hewed toward the more refined melodicism of post-Pavement college rock
column3: with Comb the Feelings Through Your Hair
column4: Johnson and company have reached the same career crossroads that forbears like the Flaming Lips and Radiohead hit at the turn of the millennium. And while they haven’t gone so far as to embrace the orchestral pomp of the former or the abstract electronic experimentation of the latter
column5: Comb the Feelings Through Your Hair—the last album to be recorded at Death by Audio prior to its closure last November—bears the telltale signs of an indie rock band who’ve become bored with being just another indie rock band: Guitars take a back seat to synth-powered rhythmic propulsion; traditional song forms get broken down into open-ended arrangements; Can records get dusted off for spiritual guidance.

column1: But while Johnson’s standing as the last remaining original Grooms member would presumably make him the band’s de facto musical leader
column2: Comb the Feelings fully harnesses the collaborative potential of the lineup he assembled for Infinity Caller’s tours. Throughout the record
column3: bassist Jay Heiselmann and drummer-cum-""Better Call Saul"" star Steve Levine (this album’s MVP) establish a restless rhythmic undertow that stews beneath the songs’ deceptively placid surfaces. At its most potent—like on the title track
column4: or the Lonerism-scaled ""Will the Boys""—the tension between Johnson’s clear-headed
column5: plainspoken delivery and the band’s equilibrium-upsetting textural overload conjures that sensation of trying to keep your cool in mixed company while feeling like a heart-palpating
column6: panic-attacked mess on the inside.

column1: In terms of sound and vision
column2: Comb the Feelings constitutes a massive upgrade from Grooms’ hazy
column3: hermetically sealed previous releases
column4: trading in underdog scrappiness for boldness and bravado. It’s the sort of album where every song ends up in a much different place than where it started and
column5: in the case of the roiling opener ""Bed Version""
column6: sometimes the big instrumental hook isn’t revealed until the outro. But Grooms are still getting a feel for the new sonic environments they’ve opened for themselves
column7: and still figuring out how their linear melodies fit into more amorphous surroundings
column8: resulting in some abrupt structural shifts that leave the seams showing. Perhaps sensing that the krautrockin’ rave-up ""Doctor M"" is precisely the sort of predictable move indie rock bands resort to when they’re trying to be unpredictable
column9: Grooms derail its motorik momentum into an extended ambient symphony that
column10: for added enigmatic effect
column11: dissolves into indecipherable party chatter. The following ""Half Cloud""
column12: meanwhile
column13: begins as a Red House Painters-style reverie before a martial drumbeat clears the way for a feedback-sculpted passage that cuts out just as the song seems to be venturing into uncharted territory
column14: like a hastily scrapped rough sketch for some unrealized master plan. But that sort of impulsiveness is the natural byproduct of an album from a long-suffering band audibly brimming with a renewed sense of purpose. If not all its experiments yield consistently entrancing results
column15: Comb the Feelings is the sound of Grooms basking in the first radiant glimpse of a future that
column16: not too long ago
column17:
it didn’t think it’d live long enough to see.

"|20263.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20263-comb-the-feelings-through-your-hair/|7.3|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21538/homepage_large.a8c69ffb.jpg|If You're Reading This It's Too Late|27950.0|Drake|['Rap']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Cash Money']|2015-02-17 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:42.289512|"

Death is the only certainty for rap dynasties. One year it’s ""All About the Benjamins"" and the next it’s Lincolns and Washingtons. Cash Money Records has escaped the fate of the Roc-A-Fellas and Bad Boys thanks to the enduring genius of Bryan ""Baby"" Williams
column2: AKA Birdman. Birdman’s business acumen and A&R smarts carried Cash Money through three distinct eras
column3: from the late '90s Hot Boys heyday through Lil Wayne’s mid- to late-2000s bid for ""Best Rapper Alive"" to the current YMCMB incarnation featuring Drake and Nicki Minaj. (With Young Thug and Rich Homie Quan he seems to be training still another army.) The wheels appeared to come off of the Cash Money machine for good
column4: however
column5: on a random December afternoon when Wayne gave a curt Twitter update on his long-gestating Tha Carter V album
column6: blaming Birdman and Cash Money for the holdup and demanding an exit from the label he’s called home most of his life. He’s since initiated an audacious $51 million lawsuit requesting not only his own exit but that of Drake and Nicki Minaj as well.

column1: Drake and Nicki have been smartly mum on the split (well
column2: word around town is Birdman was barred from Minaj’s Grammy party earlier this month)
column3: but years of whispers about Drake being owed substantial back royalties were publicly validated with the surprise release of If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late
column4: a retail mixtape arriving on the six year anniversary of Drake’s star-making So Far Gone. If You’re Reading This is littered with pith for Drake’s label situation (""No Tellin’"": ""Envelopes coming in the mail
column5: let her open ‘em/ Hoping for a check again
column6: ain’t no telling
column7: ""Star67"": ""Brand new Beretta
column8: can’t wait to let it go/ Walk up in my label like ‘Where the check
column9: though?’"")
column10: and all of this surfacing weeks after Wayne’s lawsuit bombshell raises a few questions. Is this release a ruse to close out Drake’s Cash Money deal? Is the absence of Birdman from the mixtape’s lengthy thank you's an oversight or an intentional slight? Is the title a dig?

column1: If You’re Reading This arouses many unanswered questions on a business front
column2: but where it truly delivers is giving Drake room to breathe outside of the lumbering commercialism of his retail albums. There’s little in the way of obvious singles here
column3: (though the Ibiza bop ""Preach"" might find a chart by accident). Instead we get a spectral late-night longing not unlike that of So Far Gone touchstones ""Lust for Life"" and ""Successful"". The pre-fame queasiness of early Drake is now the loneliness of a distrustful despot. On ""10 Bands"" he’s holed up in a home studio for weeks pushing himself to create (""Drapes closed
column4: I don’t know what time it is/ I’m still awake
column5: I gotta shine this year""). ""Know Yourself"" celebrates the thrill of mobbing through a city that’s his for the taking
column6: but even in joy there’s a note of tension and the ever-present possibility of actual danger. (""I ain’t rock my jewelry
column7: and that’s on purpose/ Niggas want my spot and don’t deserve it."") Success creates as many problems as it solves.

column1: Music is the real joy for Drake
column2: and If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late is best enjoyed as an exercise in the casual excellence of the artist as rhymer and purveyor of hooks. The vocals are often just vampy flow experiments
column3: but at their best these verses exhibit the weightless exhilaration of a technician at work. Drake’s never more formidable than when he’s shadowboxing
column4: and at its flashiest
column5: If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late feels like his Rocky run. Inspired by gauntlet tosses from adversaries high and low
column6: Drake uses the mixtape to toast and taunt a rogue’s gallery of industry frenemies. For Diddy
column7: who reportedly punched him over ownership of the beat for ""0 to 100/The Catch Up"": ""Real quick
column8: man
column9: you couldn’t’ve hated that/ Let’s be real
column10: nigga
column11: you couldn’t’ve made it that."" For disgruntled labelmate Tyga
column12: who insulted Drake in a Vibe magazine feature: ""You need to act your age and not your girl’s age."" For friend-turned-rival Kendrick Lamar: ""They gon’ say your name on them airwaves/ They gon hit you after like it’s only rap.""

column1: On If You’re Reading This
column2: all of this chest beating is delivered over the most darkly hypnotic beats Drake’s graced since So Far Gone. Much of the mixtape foregoes the supervision of his producer-in-residence Noah ""40"" Shebib
column3: but 40’s codeine-soul aesthetic is the ghost in the machine. The PARTYNEXTDOOR showcase ""Wednesday Night Interlude"" matches the OVO signee’s pleading vocal to a chunk of Canadian producer Ekali’s ethereal ""Unfaith""
column4: itself an interpolation of Ciara and Future’s ""Body Party"". Ginuwine and Timbaland’s 2000 classic ""So Anxious"" is sampled twice
column5: soundtracking the slow-cooking opener ""Legend"" and the 40 contribution ""Madonna"". Where R&B sounds aren’t incorporated directly
column6: their thick sensuality is frequently hinted at. The pace of the mixtape rarely elevates past a crawl
column7: reveling in the moody
column8: winding instrumentals and hooky sentimentality of Boi-1da
column9: PARTYNEXTDOOR and newcomers Wondagurl
column10: SykSense
column11: and Sevn Thomas without worrying about posting upbeat knockers to Top 40 radio.

column1: In the days to come you’ll read that Drake ""pulled a Beyoncé"" with the stealth drop of If You’re Reading This
column2: and yes
column3: both are surprise releases from A-list artists topping the charts without a rollout or much in the way of an advance warning. But Radiohead’s In Rainbows is the better comparison: Both records found the artists revisiting the mood of a highly regarded early work as they transition into new methods of delivering music to fans. Whether the Drake tape is a clever track dump disguised as an album with the intent of worming out of his Cash Money deal
column4: a deliberately planned gesture to tide fans over until the upcoming Views from the 6
column5: or just an exercise in shirking the protracted waits and missed dates of the retail rap game
column6: If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late winningly employs the occasion of the So Far Gone anniversary to revisit the twilight consternation of Drake’s breakout release
column7:
perhaps to close out a chapter of his career on the same note on which it began.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21543/homepage_large.92241114.jpg|Freedom Highway Complete|8441.0|The Staple Singers|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Legacy']|2015-02-17 00:00:00|1965|2016-06-11 16:14:42.977989|"

It’s impossible to discuss the Staple Singers’ 1965 live album Freedom Highway without considering what was going down in America that year. On March 7
column2: more than 600 marchers set out to make the 50-mile walk from Selma to Montgomery
column3: Alabama
column4: and were attacked by Alabama state troopers and armed posses. Two days later
column5: they tried again
column6: but turned back when Governor George Wallace denied them state protection. Two long weeks later
column7: they tried a third time
column8: with federal protection from the US Army and the National Guard. It took them three days
column9: but they finally reached the state capitol.

column1: Just a few weeks later and several hundred miles north
column2: one of the hottest groups on the gospel circuit debuted a new song during a service at the New Nazareth Church on Chicago’s South Side. Pops Staples
column3: patriarch and bandleader of the formidable Staple Singers
column4: explained the inspiration in his introduction. ""From that march
column5: word was revealed and a song was composed
column6: he explains
column7: sounding less like a preacher addressing his congregation and more like a close friend shaking your hand. ""And we wrote a song about the freedom marchers and we call it the ‘Freedom Highway’
column8: and we dedicate this number to all the freedom marchers."" As he is addressing the congregation
column9: Pops strikes a clutch of chords on his guitar
column10: and those chords coalesce into a spry blues riff that he sends rolling down the aisles of New Nazareth.

column1: Then Al Duncan enters on drums
column2: his rhythm a little funkier and more physical than you might expect in such a godly setting; Phil Upchurch lays down an elastic bass line
column3: and the syncopated clatter of handclaps completes the rhythm section. Just as the song is taking off
column4: the Staple Singers—Pops and his kids Pervis
column5: Yvonne
column6: and Mavis—shout the chorus: ""Marching… up freedom highway
column7: marching… each and every day."" Mavis sings lead on the verses
column8: her voice lunging at the low notes and filling every space in the sanctuary. Despite the worry in the lyrics (""The whole wide world is wonderin’ what’s wrong with the United States"")
column9: the family does not sound concerned or beaten down or fatigued in any way. Rather
column10: ""Freedom Highway"" is pure jubilation
column11: as though the Staples are celebrating that third march to Montgomery
column12: confident in the righteousness of their cause. With God on their side
column13: how could they fail?

column1: Recording the performance that day was producer Billy Sherrill
column2: who edited the songs for radio play
column3: then rearranged them for the Staples’ first live album
column4: Freedom Highway. Instead of coming halfway through the performance
column5: the title track opened the first side
column6: announcing Pops’ intentions of connecting gospel music with the struggle for civil rights. It was the family’s biggest hit to date
column7: a pivotal record that inched them toward the pop mainstream without sacrificing their gospel message for a secular audience. In that regard
column8: the New Nazareth concert proves a pivotal event not just for the family
column9: but for pop music in general—just as crucial as anything that happened at Woodstock or Monterey
column10: albeit not as storied or as celebrated. Somehow
column11: the record slipped out of print and has been unavailable for decades. (An excellent 1991 compilation bears the same title but includes only two tracks from the album among contemporaneous studio and live recordings.)

column1: To mark the 50th anniversary of the freedom marches as well as the Staples’ performance
column2: the New Nazareth concert has been remastered and restored to its original setlist and runtime
column3: complete with a short sermon by Rev. Dr. John E. Hopkins
column4: a benediction
column5: and even a guilt-motivated offertory (""We got less than 75 dollars here. You know this is not right."") As a historical artifact
column6: it is invaluable for what it reveals about gospel performances of the era
column7: even if the proceedings fall into a lull whenever the singing gives way to talking. That’s true of so many church services
column8: though
column9: especially those you don’t actually get to attend.

column1: This remaster
column2: however
column3: emphasizes the bustle of the congregation
column4: lending the proceedings a you-are-there intimacy. You can hear every cough and mutter
column5: every rifle of a Bible page
column6: and every amen. In this vivid setting
column7: the songs take on new power. Pervis’s recitation of Hank Williams’ ""The Funeral"" sounds more intensely melancholy
column8: as though he is not quite convinced of God’s mysterious motivations but is surrendering to Him nonetheless. You can hear Pops joking with his son-in-law just before he launches into ""Samson and Delilah""
column9: and his good spirits inject the song with a vivid snap.

column1: And this version restores the original sequencing
column2: so that ""Freedom Highway"" is immediately preceded by ""We Shall Overcome""
column3: which was a familiar standard that had taken on new relevance for African Americans during the 1960s. It’s a sly bit of programming by Pops
column4: as it primes the audience to respond enthusiastically to a tune they do not know. Yet
column5: ""Freedom Highway"" is a very different song
column6: one that is less concerned with someday and more interested in today. It was Pops’ way of marking a victory
column7: of saying they were already in the process of overcoming.

column1: Even if he was often overshadowed by his daughter Mavis
column2: whose voice often sounded like the hand of God parting the clouds
column3: Pops was definitely the leader of the group and the head of the family. Even as they won mainstream success
column4: trading choir robes for Afros and churches for concert halls
column5: he kept them rooted in gospel and focused on a spiritual message. He also became an influence on several generations of guitarists—including Robbie Robertson of the Band and John Fogerty of Creedence Clearwater Revival—who mimicked Pops’s nimble melodic lines and distinctive tremolo. Shortly before he died in 2000
column6: he recorded a handful of new and old songs
column7: just him and his guitar
column8: and he must have been pleased with the results
column9: because he entrusted the tapes with his daughters with the request
column10: ""Don’t lose this.""

column1: Mavis held on to them for 15 years
column2: before asking Jeff Tweedy to complete them. To his credit the Wilco frontman brings to these songs the same restraint he showed on You Are Not Alone and One True Vine. He never crowds the performances with extraneous elements or modern touches; in fact
column3: he is largely invisible on Don’t Lose This
column4: occasionally playing bass and generally trusting Pops and his guitar to speak as clearly now as they did in 1998 or in 1965. Spencer Tweedy plays drums on a few songs and proves himself to be as sensitive a sideman here as he did on last year’s Sukierae. His beats on ""No News Is Good News"" and ""Somebody Was Watching"" have a textural quality that accentuates the songs’ genial funk
column5: and he knows exactly where to put the downbeat so that it complements Pops’ vocals. Spencer may be one of the best and most interesting drummers around
column6: but he also knows this is someone else’s show.

column1: As a result
column2: Don’t Lose This sounds like an excellent entry point for newcomers and casual fans
column3: a gateway to exploring the Staples’ vast catalog. Without sounding like a career retrospective
column4: the album revisits the straightforward gospel of the '50s and '60s as well as the sunshine funk of the '70s
column5: all the while playing up the humane optimism in Pops’ vocals. Songs like ""Sweet Home"" and ""Love on My Side"" may depict men at their lowest points—steeped in self-pity

column7: distant from God—but they are cautionary tales: Any of us could end up in a similar situation
column8: lonely and despairing but never undeserving of redemption.

column1: Still
column2: this is a Pops album in name only. At its core
column3: it may be the final Staple Singers record. His children—including Cleotha
column4: who died in 2013—feature prominently on many of these songs

column6: especially on a song like ""Sweet Home""
column7: which plays up their individual styles. Pops’ vocals are steady and measured

column9: her performance might sound ostentatious or overbearing
column10: but for Mavis
column11: it sounds natural and fluid
column12: a perfect complement to her father’s performance.

column1: Perhaps the standout on Don’t Lose This is ""Will the Circle Be Unbroken""
column2: an old Baptist hymn popularized in the 1930s by another pop music patriarch
column3: A.P. Carter. The Staples covered the song in the '60s
column4: but 40 years will change anyone’s perspective on life and death. Chronicling the funeral of a beloved parent
column5: the song poses the important question
column6: Will the bonds of family persist beyond this world? On the new version Pops manages to gently interpret the song
column7: singing not from the point of view of a child losing a parent

column10:
one last bit of wisdom from a man who showed us the spiritual potential in pop music of all kinds.

It’s impossible to discuss the Staple Singers’ 1965 live album Freedom Highway without considering what was going down in America that year. On March 7
column2: more than 600 marchers set out to make the 50-mile walk from Selma to Montgomery
column3: Alabama
column4: and were attacked by Alabama state troopers and armed posses. Two days later
column5: they tried again
column6: but turned back when Governor George Wallace denied them state protection. Two long weeks later
column7: they tried a third time
column8: with federal protection from the US Army and the National Guard. It took them three days
column9: but they finally reached the state capitol.

column1: Just a few weeks later and several hundred miles north
column2: one of the hottest groups on the gospel circuit debuted a new song during a service at the New Nazareth Church on Chicago’s South Side. Pops Staples
column3: patriarch and bandleader of the formidable Staple Singers
column4: explained the inspiration in his introduction. ""From that march
column5: word was revealed and a song was composed
column6: he explains
column7: sounding less like a preacher addressing his congregation and more like a close friend shaking your hand. ""And we wrote a song about the freedom marchers and we call it the ‘Freedom Highway’
column8: and we dedicate this number to all the freedom marchers."" As he is addressing the congregation
column9: Pops strikes a clutch of chords on his guitar
column10: and those chords coalesce into a spry blues riff that he sends rolling down the aisles of New Nazareth.

column1: Then Al Duncan enters on drums
column2: his rhythm a little funkier and more physical than you might expect in such a godly setting; Phil Upchurch lays down an elastic bass line
column3: and the syncopated clatter of handclaps completes the rhythm section. Just as the song is taking off
column4: the Staple Singers—Pops and his kids Pervis
column5: Yvonne
column6: and Mavis—shout the chorus: ""Marching… up freedom highway
column7: marching… each and every day."" Mavis sings lead on the verses
column8: her voice lunging at the low notes and filling every space in the sanctuary. Despite the worry in the lyrics (""The whole wide world is wonderin’ what’s wrong with the United States"")
column9: the family does not sound concerned or beaten down or fatigued in any way. Rather
column10: ""Freedom Highway"" is pure jubilation
column11: as though the Staples are celebrating that third march to Montgomery
column12: confident in the righteousness of their cause. With God on their side
column13: how could they fail?

column1: Recording the performance that day was producer Billy Sherrill
column2: who edited the songs for radio play
column3: then rearranged them for the Staples’ first live album
column4: Freedom Highway. Instead of coming halfway through the performance
column5: the title track opened the first side
column6: announcing Pops’ intentions of connecting gospel music with the struggle for civil rights. It was the family’s biggest hit to date
column7: a pivotal record that inched them toward the pop mainstream without sacrificing their gospel message for a secular audience. In that regard
column8: the New Nazareth concert proves a pivotal event not just for the family
column9: but for pop music in general—just as crucial as anything that happened at Woodstock or Monterey
column10: albeit not as storied or as celebrated. Somehow
column11: the record slipped out of print and has been unavailable for decades. (An excellent 1991 compilation bears the same title but includes only two tracks from the album among contemporaneous studio and live recordings.)

column1: To mark the 50th anniversary of the freedom marches as well as the Staples’ performance
column2: the New Nazareth concert has been remastered and restored to its original setlist and runtime
column3: complete with a short sermon by Rev. Dr. John E. Hopkins
column4: a benediction
column5: and even a guilt-motivated offertory (""We got less than 75 dollars here. You know this is not right."") As a historical artifact
column6: it is invaluable for what it reveals about gospel performances of the era
column7: even if the proceedings fall into a lull whenever the singing gives way to talking. That’s true of so many church services
column8: though
column9: especially those you don’t actually get to attend.

column1: This remaster
column2: however
column3: emphasizes the bustle of the congregation
column4: lending the proceedings a you-are-there intimacy. You can hear every cough and mutter
column5: every rifle of a Bible page

column7: the songs take on new power. Pervis’s recitation of Hank Williams’ ""The Funeral"" sounds more intensely melancholy

Northerners visiting Los Angeles might be surprised to discover how many of the city's subcultures are drawn to monochromatic black and white clothing. Despite living in the land of PacSun and surfboards
column2: something about being front-and-center as the masses descend on California beaches makes a portion of the city's youth culture push hard in the opposite direction
column3: to leather jackets and combat boots. Perhaps the reverse dynamic is at work in Northern Europe
column4: where over the last decade DJs and producers have gravitated towards heliocentric sounds
column5: the soundtrack to an idealized beachfront lifestyle courtesy of kids raised in the land of the ice and snow.

column1: A perfect example is Studio's 2006 LP West Coast. Since the Swedish duo of Rasmus Hägg and Daniel Lissvik first hit the world like a modest cult comet
column2: the Balearic beach bum aesthetic they popularized reverberated across hip dancefloors and afterparties worldwide and inspired countless imitators. But West Coast is more than its position at the crest of a breaking trend-wave: like DJ Harvey's Sarcastic Study Masters Vol. 2 and Lindstrøm and Prins Thomas' epic BBC Essential Mix
column3: it epitomized a moment
column4: yet sustains as great escapist entertainment years later.

column1: Since its release
column2: Lissvik has retained an active résumé
column3: remixing
column4: producing for other artists (Taken by Trees
column5: Young Galaxy)
column6: and recording under various pseudonyms
column7: as he did for last year's Meditation under the moniker Atelje. But he hasn't unleashed a full solo project since 2008's 7 Trx + Intermission. Shuvit! is the first release in the lead-up to his second official full-length
column8: and much as Atelje promised a return to the spiritual center of West Coast
column9: Shuvit! tackles that sound in all its unpredictable
column10: dubby disco glory. Well
column11: maybe not glory: if Studio's biggest album both epitomized its time and transcended it
column12: Shuvit! does neither—although it does neither in a very pleasant way.

column1: The aims and accomplishments of this EP are modest. After a superfluous intro track
column2: the rubbery funk of ""Airwalk"" is an archetypal Lissvik record. Sound design is of foremost concern: much like his fellow European house and techno producers
column3: each drum snaps with purposeful distinctiveness. But unlike the average German techno auteur
column4: Lissvik seeks more organic instrumentation; bass and guitar strings reverberate and the beat has a crunchy texture. Each song is more likely to recall a drum circle than a nightclub. The most ""artificial"" instrument are vocal patches; its aim is less dancefloor futurism than a party after the power goes out.

column1: While ""Airwalk"" relies on a straightforward groove and low-key payoff
column2: ""Shuvit!"" is the EP's stronger track. Underneath quarter-note doo-doo-doo-doo vocals
column3: a fidgety groove reminiscent of People's Choice's 1975 disco record ""Do It Any Way You Wanna"" unfolds into a flute breakdown before a new melodic theme begins. In construction
column4: it recalls the kind of purposeful meandering compositions of West Coast. It may not be as revelatory as that record's ""Life's a Beach!""
column5: but the song creates a warm and comfortable world in which to let time slip away.

column1: In the middle of the decade
column2: this new Balearic music felt counterintuitive. A new school of producers embraced unfashionable sounds
column3: calling upon Mediterranean dance history as a new source of cool. As the years slip by and these innovations enter the slipstream
column4: the trade in new Balearic music approximates the '90s infatuation with trip-hop. An intersection of soundtrack music
column5: kraut
column6: disco
column7: dub
column8: '70s album rock
column9: and electronic dance music
column10: the style is worldly and referential
column11: finding coherence in the spaces where old genres intersect. The end result—most of the time—is a kind of upscale lifestyle music for cosmopolitan
column12: historically-minded listeners
column13: where artists toy with ambiance in an effort to tap into the mystique of the past
column14: the foreign
column15: and the exotic.

column1: Which is a long way of saying that sometimes the line between ""comfortable"" and ""boring"" is thin. On the one hand
column2: it's hard to fault Lissvik for running on a track he knows: The ground may be worn down
column3: but it's the kind of idea that bears repeating. Anyone unfamiliar with Studio's history will no doubt find Shuvit! pleasant. But even by those standards
column4: nothing here is as transcendent as
column5: say
column6: Todd Terje's ""Inspector Norse""—a late entrant into the Balearic banger sweepstakes. If you liked West Coast and want a couple of b-sides
column7: check out Shuvit!. If you haven't heard West Coast
column8:
buy it.

If there's one thing you need to know about Chicago's Brett Sova
column3: it's that he shreds. He records under the name Axis: Sova
column4: which stands as a solo project in the studio but morphs into a full band on the road
column5: and in either formation the most interesting element is easily his guitar. When there is percussion on Early Surf (his second LP
column6: and his first for Ty Segall's God? Records imprint)
column7: it's minimal
column8: synthetic
column9: and purely functional. He's only two full-lengths in
column10: but he's already established a reputation for buzzing
column11: unsteady
column12:
occasionally muffled psych music spiked with a few giant guitar solos for good measure. He's established a formula—""avant garde yet burly""—that he delivers once again with Early Surf.

The trouble with this sort of psychedelia is that it sometimes veers toward abstraction and facelessness. That's definitely a concern here
column13: as Sova's somewhat of an elusive figure in his music. He's the guitar-wielding figure on the album's cover
column14: his features blotted out by blinding light
column15: singing poems that address uncertainty and unclear identities. His distorted and effects-laden vocals cut off words
column16: and he occasionally comes across as dour and reserved
column17: but his oblique storytelling (with references
column18: for example
column19: to the overpowering nature of artificial light and television) and amorphous guitar leads hint at a larger aesthetic unity. On ""Ask Me About My Smell""
column20: in which a woman named Heather does
column21: indeed
column22: ask him about his smell
column23:
he steps away from his heavier persona and lets a sense of humor shine through.

Early Surf's best moments brim with potential. ""Fractal Ancestry"" shows a guitarist and songwriter unafraid to explore different approaches: Over seven minutes
column24: Sova's guitar melody operates within a loose structure
column25: but things always seem to be in a state of flux. His solos guide the song down alternate routes as he continually shifts the balance from the right speaker to the left
column26: peppered throughout with sci-fi sound effects. Again
column27: his approach mirrors his lyrics: ""Open the door
column28: let it close behind you. What do you see now? It's just another door."" At his best
column29:
Sova seems like the type of guy who could endlessly swing open new doors to unexpected places.

Unfortunately
column30: a few of the songs just don't have legs. The two-minute track ""Secret Hand"" seems to be building to something enormous before it just sort of fizzles out. It happens again on the album's title track: Sova named his band after a classic Jimi Hendrix LP
column31: and for a brief moment at the start of the song
column32: it seems like he's going to do his namesake proud by springboarding off his earworm and heading into the stratosphere. Instead
column33: he just stays the repetitive course
column34: only changing his approach in the song's final seconds. Sova's undeniably the sort of guy you want to hear go long—the lengthier jams are undeniably the best. When he's not going on an epic journey
column36:
he winds up spinning in place.

Naomi Yang and Damon Krukowski have been performing together for the better part of 30 years
column2: yet in that time music has never been the sole focus of their creative energies. Damon is a poet and writer (and an occasional Pitchfork contributor) while Naomi is a photographer and graphic designer whose visual design skills have always been an integral part of the duo’s work
column3: dating back to her album designs for their beloved group Galaxie 500. In addition to operating the 20/20/20 record label and Exact Change small press
column4: in recent years Naomi has branched out into directing stylish and evocative music videos for such artists as Marissa Nadler
column5: Julia Holter
column6: and Elisa Ambrogio.

column1: So it seems like a very organic progression that Naomi has now directed Fortune
column2: her first short film. Though the film itself is silent
column3: it arrives paired with a full-length soundtrack of new songs by Damon & Naomi
column4: which can give it the essential feel of a 30-minute music video. The film and its music
column5: naturally enough
column6: work best in combination and enjoying them together (currently available for free) is an experience well worth the half-hour devotion of your time and attention. As is often the case the film itself feels incomplete without its musical accompaniment
column7: whereas the soundtrack does function as a short but coherent and satisfying stand-alone collection of songs.

column1: The Fortune soundtrack is Damon & Naomi’s first album of new music since 2011’s False Beats and True Hearts and
column2: if you want to get technical about it
column3: their first as an actual duo since their Sub Pop work in the early 1990s. After a long and fruitful series of collaborations with guitarist Michio Kurihara of Ghost
column4: here the two play all the instruments themselves. The music is characteristically quiet and introspective but
column5: as with much of their work with Kurihara
column6: more lush and enveloping than the spacious Galaxie 500 sound. Using little more than acoustic guitar
column7: keyboards and Krukowski’s jazz-tinged drumming
column8: they have crafted arrangements for these 11 pieces that sound remarkably full-bodied. And it would appear that the natural constraints of the soundtrack form have worked to their advantage. The songs are concise and focused
column9: hitting their melodic or lyrical marks and then quickly moving to the next scene without getting weighted down by repetition or digression.

column1: The film
column2: which stars Norman von Holtzendorff
column3: centers on a man coping with the death of his father
column4: a successful portrait painter
column5: and the conflicted artistic and personal legacy he has left behind. This is deeply intimate material for Yang
column6: who had recently lost her own artist father and was left to sort through a storage space of his artwork and what she refers to in her director’s statement as ""the aftermath of his very flawed parenting."" This unavoidably gives both film and soundtrack an elegiac tone
column7: with many of the album’s lyrics reflecting on the various burdens of mourning and memory.

column1: As has long been their practice
column2: the duo swap lead vocal duties back and forth and join together in casual harmonies
column3: but given the project’s backdrop perhaps it is unsurprising that those songs sung primarily by Yang—""It’s Over""
column4: ""The North Light""—are the most immediately striking. The critical quibbles that have followed Damon & Naomi throughout their career can still be applied: Their hushed voices remain pretty
column5: but not dazzling
column6: and their cozy music never strays much beyond the comfort zone that they firmly established a couple of decades ago. Especially when taken in conjunction with Yang’s film
column7: however
column8:
Fortune packs a subtle yet undeniable emotive force whose impact can linger long after the projector has gone dark.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21463/homepage_large.cdeb5d7f.jpg|Sour Soul|1824.0|Ghostface Killah|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lex']|2015-02-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:45.717753|"

Once upon a time
column2: the prospect of hearing Ghostface over moody live-band psychedelic soul held promise. Twelve Reasons to Die dropped less than two years ago
column3: and Adrian Younge’s outsized 8mm splatter-flick gloom funk was fresh enough to make the record sound something like a comeback. Ghost’s storytelling had certainly been stronger in the past
column4: but at least he was spinning his conceptual tales over murky
column5: time-faded R&B-noir. After further collaborations with groups carrying Real Instruments
column6: like the déjà vu of last year’s 36 Seasons
column7: where Ghost teamed up with Brooklyn funk band the Revelations for another detail-scarce Tony Starks yarn
column8: the novelty has worn off
column9: and it’s easy to start asking whether Ghost still has it.

column1: Toronto jazz-funk dons BADBADNOTGOOD are a good fit
column2: ably replicating the kind of gritty ’70s pulp-paperback breaks Ghostface has long favored. But Sour Soul could have every musician who ever played with the J.B.’s backing him up and it still wouldn’t obscure the fact that he’s slacking on the mic. His voice is still his
column3: and it’s difficult if not impossible for Ghostface to actually sound bored. But if you gravitated to DOOM team-up ""Ray Gun"" just because ""Angels"" was hot and still hold out hope that Swift & Changeable will see light of day
column4: the disappointment will hit hard: ""Back in black
column5: it’s your local superhero from the hood/ Ironman Starks got the good/ Not that good good like Snoop/ I bulletproofed the coupe/ Polished up the suit and gathered the troops."" He goes on to make a Matrix reference in the year 2015 and states ""Ain’t a bird or a plane
column6: it’s a ghost on the mic."" A ghost of himself
column7: maybe.

column1: Ghostface gets outshone every time there’s a guest verse—a concentrated dose of DOOM wiseassedness on ""Ray Gun""; Elzhi punchlining all over ""Gunshowers""; Tree rasping with a thousand-yard stare on ""Street Knowledge""; the continued lights-out rampage streak of Danny Brown on ""Six Degrees""—but the feeling that he can barely carry this record on the mic goes beyond that. His flair for narrative and knack for offbeat observational details are nearly gone; pop-culture punchlines land with a thud and play more like spot-the-reference jokes than evocative analogies—""my clan is Bravehearts
column2: you move like Paul Blart"" on the title cut is probably the most egregious example.

column1: Ghostface still knows how to balance his most well-known facets: the bombastic comic-book hero
column2: the ruthless criminal mastermind
column3: and the independent philosophical thinker. Ghost working through these notions in such close quarters doesn’t really feel like a personality crisis; he’s always been equally convincing as a man dispensing advice on keeping your drug distribution efforts low-key and your spiritual mind on the right path a verse or two apart. Even if the language isn’t anywhere near as transporting as when Fishscale jumped from dope tales to love songs to underwater revelations
column4: there are at least hidden dimensions under the all-too-matter-of-fact statements.

column1: The lackluster lines are even more of a letdown given the strength of the music. BADBADNOTGOOD’s arrangements are the most immersive yet in this three-album run of live-band Ghostface. The core trio leans towards RZA’s old Morricone-via-Stax waypoints here and there
column2: then warps them into something more enigmatic and heated—basslines and drums creep and skulk instead of just booming
column3: string arrangements recall the late '60s heyday of David Axelrod turning the Wall of Sound into cresting liquid waves. The instrumental version of this album is going to make a lot of SoundCloud-bound demo-tapers lose their minds trying to get their turns in.

column1: Make no mistake: The presence of BADBADNOTGOOD and some show-stealing guest verses are reason enough to face the prospect of Ghostface in second gear. There isn’t even that much to weather
column2: what with the whole record being all of 33 minutes
column3: with only nine tracks actually featuring a Ghostface verse. Both the scant material and under-inspired lyricism are symptoms of the same problem: a dearth of unexpected ideas from an MC once seemingly capable of endless ones. Ghost’s done worse
column4:
but he used to be so excitingly unpredictable. Now you pretty much know what you’re going to get.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21364/homepage_large.090347b6.jpg|Picture You|28372.0|The Amazing|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Partisan']|2015-02-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:46.958816|"

The Amazing’s Christoffer Gunrup would probably make fast friends with Mark Kozelek. At least to the extent you can predict anyone would. Not only is Picture You one of the surprisingly rare rock records of recent vintage drawing legitimate
column2: discernible inspiration from Led Zeppelin
column3: Gunrup just so happens to be influenced by the same exact songs Kozelek namechecked on his spellbinding autobiography ""I Watched the Film ‘The Song Remains the Same’"". There’s the Fender Rhodes hum of ""No Quarter""
column4: as well as the capability to touch on jazz and prog-rock without being ""jazzy"" or ""proggy"". The Amazing spend vast stretches of time strolling the verdant expanses of ""Rain Song""
column5: as well as basking in the glimmering acoustic sunrises of ""Bron-Yr-Aur"". And Gunrup’s vocals are that of a very melancholy kid mesmerized by everything
column6: one who did see Zep as gods
column7: but benevolent and nurturing ones—more Pan and Demeter than Dionysus.

column1: The end result is a record that reverently draws from a dazzling array of past masters only to short-circuit critical capacity. Discussion of Picture You can only end up with slack-jawed remarks about how goddamn pretty it is. Stranger still is how the adverbs you’d feel tempted to latch onto that superlative somehow makes that seem like a bad thing: ""obscenely pretty
column2: ""ridiculously beautiful
column3: etc.  But the Amazing specialize in a beauty that isn’t airbrushed or slick or antiseptic
column4: the kind captured by lad mags or Trevor Horn
column5: everything exaggerated to emphasize its status as eye or ear candy. Nor is it smudged or vaporous like shoegaze. It doesn’t even make a full attempt at an au naturel realism of folk or the otherworldliness of psych-rock
column6: though it does touch on those aspects. Picture You is elemental rock—earthy
column7: molten
column8: aquatic
column9: but using each of their qualities to soothe rather than destroy or intimidate.

column1: Opener ""Broken"" is the Amazing at their most grand
column2: but not grandiose—the guitars dip in the same deep water as the Cure's Disintegration
column3: while Moussa Fadera plays his drums with the activity of Keith Moon or John Bonham. Yet
column4: the guitars merely come off as being coated with morning dew
column5: every cymbal splash sounds like it’s releasing a light ocean spray. Even when ""Safe Island"" ends with nearly three minutes of blistering harmonic feedback
column6: it’s never meant to overwhelm
column7: it’s more the encroaching low heat of a sweat lodge. This part is notably absent from the ""single"" version.

column1: The Amazing’s previous album was called Gentle Stream and very much earned that title; this one is more like a lazy river—you know
column2: the weekend summer outing where an inner tube with a cooler of beer drags behind
column3: long stretches of a calming buzz that evolves into some serious disorientation only after you figure out where you’ve been the past six minutes. This is pretty much the whole point of ""To Keep It Going""
column4: where Gunrup repeats the title and only the title for its five-minute duration. Picture You doesn’t jam or meander
column5: it drifts knowing its final destination is preordained—“Fryshusfunk” and the title track take a few minutes to commit to basic song structures before getting into vast stretches of lead guitar interplay that never quite becomes soloing. The Amazing can be concise
column6: though prototypical psych-folk fusions like ""Tell Them You Can’t Leave"" turn out to be the parts where Picture You feels like it loses focus.

column1: There is focus here
column2: though it's hard to elucidate: While the Amazing could certainly find themselves winning over the same festival crowds swooning to Tame Impala’s Lonerism and the War on Drugs’ Lost in the Dream
column3: what Picture You lacks compared to those albums is
column4: well
column5: a frame. Or at least the knowledge of who ""you"" is. Gunrup doesn’t commit his lyrics to the credits
column6: and he even admits this on the band's website: ""I have no idea how to describe the songs. If you theorize about the songs
column7: it ruins the tension and passion. Just shut the fuck up and play
column8: but play good.""

column1: In other words
column2: he might have no better idea than I do about what these songs are actually about. And I certainly have no idea. ""The Headless Boy"" is the drumless acoustic ballad where the lyrics are most audible and it’s as slippery as the song called ""Fryshusfunk"". But during the Meddle-esque ""Circles""
column3: Dunrup mentions watching Beverly Hills Cop II
column4: whose soundtrack contains songs such as ""I Want Your Sex"" and Bob Seger’s ""Shakedown""
column5:
which exist in a completely different solar system than the one occupied by ""Circles"". But the impression given by Gunrup is that the same headspace that would lead someone to watching Beverly Hills Cop II in its entirety is similar to the one that’s amenable to Picture You—a fugue state where you somehow manage to be happily committed to your own incapacitation.

"|20095.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20095-picture-you/|7.5|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21462/homepage_large.204a588d.jpg|The Mainframe|22494.0|Joker|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kapsize']|2015-02-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:47.584197|"

It all seemed straightforward enough. Back in 2011
column2: Joker's The Vision was a pop-move faceplant that squandered the momentum he'd built off his early singles. Faithful still copped the instrumentals
column3: but a cred renewal project seemed like the best next move
column4: and a couple fairly strong EPs on Kapsize seemed to stave off the worst fears. 2013's The Face Off and 2014's Head Top were back to the wheelhouse—heaving bass wobbles that stayed sinuous even when they sounded like groaning crushed metal
column5: melodies that reinjected some of grime's heightened delirium into the UK bass continuum
column6: and drums that flipped from leadfoot stomping to counter-rhythmic intricacy without stopping up the motions. If it was a comfort zone
column7: well
column8: more artists should be comfortable bringing stuff the caliber of ""Newham Generals"" or ""Deserted Island"".

column1: But sometimes that artistic urge to push outside those boundaries comes back
column2: maybe in a different enough form that it feels like those previous pitfalls can be avoided. Sure
column3: a few new ones could spring up
column4: but that's the way it goes
column5: right? Part of the hype around The Mainframe is that it's intended as an album-qua-album
column6: a non-stop listen that only reveals its full meaning and breadth once you've run through its entire length without stopping. You're welcome to try
column7: but you're also welcome to pick your own spot to give up and jump to the next track. It could be one of the moments where Joker's knack for joyously martial melody gets run through a wringer of action-blockbuster pianos-and-strings that reveals just how many of his compositional strengths actually rely on nuance and negative space—and what happens when those tendencies are crowded out. It could also very likely be the moment on ""Lucy"" where Sam Frank's squeaky falsetto belts out the line ""let me be your little honky boy.""

column1: It's a skeptic's worst case scenario
column2: all that orchestral grandeur and the threats of Vision-ary pop-vocal overload. But it's not like Joker's forgotten how to smartly exploit the push-pull/stop-start dynamic of a two-step beat
column3: or balance out uppercut chords with slick melodic counterpoints. Even at its most prog-bombastic
column4: it flows well and doesn't lose sight of the need to bump: The seamless opening one-two of ""Intro"" and ""Boss Mode"" promises symphonic piano noodling and arena-filling synth arpeggios but delivers something more compactly driven to head-nods than arm sweeps. Basslines stay future-mindedly filthy in modular ways—there are these shrugging hiccups on the frantic tension of ""Boss Mode"" that resurface on the melancholy uplift of ""Mixed Emotions""; hydraulic-press background hums bolster the high ends on moodier cuts like ""Mahogany""; acidic hip-hop synth squelches that immolate lesser trap-peddlers on sight push a jumpy interplay with precision snares on ""Midnight"".

column1: Think of The Mainframe as his own effort to do widescreen R&B and it makes a lot more sense
column2: even if the moments that can stand toe-to-toe with the best of that milieu are scarce. The voices that hold the most impact tend to be the ones chopped into wordless choral exclamations in the instrumentals—the oh-oh-ohs of ""Midnight"" rendering human ecstasy and synaptic synth jolts as the same impulse
column3: or the recurring hum in ""Mahogany"" that sinks into and emerges from a parallel guitar strum. The one actual guest singer who really seems to fit is Rochelle Perts
column4: the onetime Dutch ""X Factor"" winner whose lush intensity and sweet-sounding frustration on the anti-platonic ""Love"" stands strong in the face of dizzying seesaw bass waves. On the other hand
column5: the pianos-and-handclaps backbone of ""Wise Enough"" needs more than Zak Abel overexerting his bland-in-any-octave voice and some chords from the ""Psychedelic Runway"" parts bin to say what the surrounding instrumentals do without vocals. And I should probably mention that aside from Sam Frank's ""little honky boy"" thing ""Lucy"" also contains the line ""I'm the bear in your cave
column6: girl
column7: so there's that.

column1: With the gloss and brass-section pomp
column2: The Mainframe feels like a more logical big-move progression for someone who turned heads with a flip of the Bond-pastiche theme to ""Metal Gear Solid 3"" on ""Snake Eater"" back in 2008. It might still mortify some of his more purist fans
column3: but there's little on this record that a few instrumental-version substitutions wouldn't fix. And as another step towards finding a place in a crossover space where he could easily put his imprint on hip-hop
column4: R&B
column5: pop
column6: or UK bass
column7:
it makes for a far better audition reel than The Vision. No need to regroup after this one—there's more evolutionary promise cresting ahead.

"|20195.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20195-the-mainframe/|6.8|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21427/homepage_large.75d5fb63.jpg|Supermoon EP|28938.0|S. Carey|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2015-02-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:48.275829|"

As exciting as the term sounds
column2: a supermoon is a fairly common occurrence
column3: an illusion caused when a full or new moon happens to coincide with the moon’s closest approach to Earth. Basically
column4: it means the moon looks a bit bigger than usual. While that might not seem significant to most people
column5: it’s the type of phenomenon Sean Carey pays close attention to. Even more so than his brother in flannel Justin Vernon
column6: whom he backs in Bon Iver
column7: Carey syncs his music to the rhythms of nature. His writing process frequently involves hiking or fishing
column8: and in his spare time he photographs mountainous terrains and forests
column9: likening the images to his songs. Yet for all his wilderness worship
column10: there’s often been a disconnect between Carey’s naturalistic mindset and his production-heavy recordings. Both of his albums were pieced together from meticulous overdubs
column11: while his 2012 Hoyas EP pulsed with electronic texture. His songs sought to capture nature’s warmth
column12:
but they wore the stamp of cold technology.

With his Supermoon EP
column13: recorded during a supermoon last August
column14: Carey aims to bring his music closer to the natural world that inspired it
column15: scaling back his precise arrangements to let the songs speak for themselves. That’s a noble goal
column16: if not necessarily a wise one. Last year’s Range of Light proved Carey a stronger composer than lyricist
column17: and although he’s got a capable enough falsetto
column18: his voice never demands the spotlight the way Vernon’s does. So his decision to dedicate four of Supermoon’s six songs to downsized remakes of album tracks is a head scratcher: He’s removing much of what made these songs interesting in the first place. ""We Fell""
column19: a highlight from Carey’s 2010 debut All We Grow
column20: is reprised here without its radiant choral swells
column21:
while Range of Light’s luxuriously jazzy ""Fire-scene"" is reworked as a lonely piano dirge. They’re still the same songs; there’s just less of them now.

EPs made up mostly of alternate versions are usually a tough sell
column22: but if done right they can free an artist to play against type in amusing ways. The most successful are the ones that drastically reinvent their material
column27: or busy twee-punk as slightly less busy acoustic twee-punk. But Supermoon never takes those kinds of leaps. If it’s been a while since you’ve heard the original versions of these songs you might not notice any differences. Even ""Bullet Proof… I Wish I Was""
column28: the Radiohead cover that closes the EP
column29: clings stubbornly close to its source material. Rather than pick a Radiohead song he could deconstruct
column30:
Carey started with one that was already broken down.

Just one of Supermoon’s revised takes improves on the original: ""In the Stream""
column31: a lovely number that lost the plot on All We Grow during a busy climax. Freed from the clutter
column32: the song’s rueful sentiment comes through much more clearly. One marginally improved song isn’t enough to justify an EP
column36: a solo piano offering with no secrets to reveal. Like the rest of the EP
column37: the song radiates tranquility and comfort without doing much else. Carey has rarely sounded more in his element. Unfortunately
column38:
he’s also never sounded less distinguished.

"|20158.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20158-supermoon-ep/|4.8|Evan Rytlewski

In his feature on the late J Dilla and his still-resonant productions
column2: Nate Patrin wrote: ""Dilla's productions got so busy and dense and unpredictably stitched-together that some artists who had to incorporate them into their own songs must have taken them as some kind of challenge."" He then singles out British-born singer Steve (neé White) Spacek’s ""Dolar"" on his lone solo album and his selection of one of Dilla’s trickiest beats
column3: which reduces Philly soul singer Billy Paul’s ""Let the Dollar Circulate"" to a looped syllable and a shoe-in-drier stumble of toms. But Spacek sounded surefooted on such slippery terrain. And whether working alongside the trio Spacek
column4: as half of Africa Hitech
column5: or else on his own as Black Pocket
column6: each one of Spacek's projects danced around R&B
column7: soul
column8: hip-hop
column9: broken beat
column10: drum'n'bass
column11: and grime
column12: without ever planting solidly down in one. No matter the setting
column13: Spacek’s falsetto was unfussy and at ease

column1: But it’s been six years since we last heard from Spacek under his own name or as Black Pocket. On Modern Streets
column2: his low-key
column3: nonchalant return—this time as Beat Spacek—he sounds unhurried and casual—it's an album made in those brief moments after being roused from an afternoon nap. Spacek purportedly crafted the entire album on iPad and iPhone apps rather than in a full-fledged recording studio
column4: giving a sweatpants-and-Adidas slippers vibe to Modern Streets. Perhaps the closest parallel might be to those Vines that Erykah Badu has been uploading of late

column7: little blips of songs abutting longer selections
column8: most of them favoring blurriness over distinction.

column1: Spacek’s ability to breeze over hectic beats is evident from opener ""I Wanna Know""
column2: a snare drum skitter right out of an old jungle track sliding beneath him
column3: while on ""Tonight""
column4: he whispers sweet nothings about being VIP over a flipped Afrobeat sample. At moments like this
column5: Spacek’s penchant for twisting beats feels like child’s play
column6: most evidently on the halting claps and bleeps of ""Gotta Get Some Music""
column7: where he and his kids titter about that very phrase. And amid the shortwave squeals of ""Back to School"" are strange background vocals that might make you wonder if Spacek has been listening to early Prince or else early Ariel Pink.

column1: Most tracks on the first half clock in under four-minutes
column2: but as the songs stretch out longer on the album’s back half
column3: there’s not enough structure to support them. And midway through
column4: as Spacek’s slender falsetto stretches to the breaking point
column5: the slightness of some lyrics also become evident. Funky as the leaky faucet and thrummed kora that loop through the single ""Alone in Da Sun"" are
column6: it does little in its six minutes. Some songs wiggle in place
column7: as on ""There Is a Love""
column8: and no matter the theme of ""Stand Firm""
column9: the backing squishes like Nerf underfoot. As we celebrate J Dilla’s birth and death this week and lament what might have come from the man in the future
column10:
it feels like Spacek—despite some bright moments here—might have also benefited from another challenge.

Hundred Waters’ excellent 2014 album The Moon Rang Like a Bell felt detached from this present moment in terms of both its sound and its themes; the pace was slow
column2: the production was thick and precise
column3: the lyrics were a mix of surreal observations and vague yearning. It wasn’t so much that its sound scanned as ""'90s""
column4: though vocalist Nicole Miglis’ debt to Björk in both tone and phrasing sometimes made it feel that way. It was more that the album as an album hearkened back to a slower time
column5: suggesting patience and trust that enough people would want to sit down and let the music wash over them.

column1: Speaking of the '90s
column2: one music trend from the era remembered less than fondly is the remix album. In the second half the decade
column3: when CD sales were on the rise
column4: file sharing was not yet an issue
column5: and electronic music was gaining currency; remixes were
column6: I guess
column7: a way for bands to gain traction with people who were growing accustomed to music samples and sequences. Depending on which label you found yourself on
column8: it became almost expected to follow up a successful album with a collection of remixes. A parallel for Hundred Waters would have been an artist like the Pastels
column9: whose 1998 album Illumination was re-worked a year later as the remix collection Illuminati. The commissioned producers found on that record
column10: including Kid Loco
column11: Cornelius
column12: Stereolab
column13: and John McEntire
column14: were more or less a Who’s Who of the late '90s remix record scene. There are no equivalents to these names in 2015 because in the mp3 era indie rock remixes pretty much lost whatever credibility they once had
column15: as they were (and are) clearly and obviously put together to keep a band’s name active in the online press. A remix included on a real album and pressed to vinyl at least pretends to matter; one blasted with a press release with new tour dates is forgotten almost immediately.

column1: Hundred Waters released Moon on Skrillex’s OWSLA imprint. But despite presumably easy access to EDM bass-drop royalty
column2: no one here tries to turn their songs into teeth-grinding summer festival anthems. And Plaid aside
column3: the remixers lean obscure. Brandt Brauer Frick turns ""Murmurs"" into a dark
column4: throbbing bit of noir with a two-step break
column5: Shigeto strips ""Cavity"" back to just voice and thumb piano to beguiling effect
column6: and Alex Zhang Hungtai of Dirty Beaches does his thing to ""Broken Blue""
column7: basically sounding like he put a boombox in the window of his apartment
column8: hit Play
column9: and recorded the sound from across the room. Those are all highlights. Illangelo’s ""Confessional Remix"" of ""Innocent""
column10: on the other hand
column11: with its pitch-shifted ""ghostly R&B"" vocals
column12: sounded dated before he’d saved the .wav file on his computer. There are also three re-works by the band themselves. The opening ""Show Me Love"" is one of the set’s best moments
column13: featuring just Miglis and piano
column14: while ""No Sound"" gets an awkward arrangement from the band’s Paul Giese and Zach Tetreault including a surge of brass at its close. Trayer Tryon’s ""Seven White Horses"" is the record’s one stab at dance music proper
column15: amplifying the original’s stuttering rhythm and adding a 4/4 kick
column16: and it’s mostly a mess.

column1: Even with its weak points
column2: The Moon Rang Like a Bell (Remixed) is charming in part because of the sincerity with which it's presented. The remixes are sequenced in the same order as the album proper
column3: for one
column4: suggesting that it is meant to be absorbed as a whole. There are no repetitions of individual tracks
column5: and for the most part
column6: the remixes are low-key and tasteful
column7: hewing closely to the group’s preferred mode
column8: suggesting an ""alternate version"" of the record more than a mishmash collection of promo detritus. All of which combines to make The Moon Rang Like a Bell (Remixed) an unlikely album that is much better than it could have been
column9: even if
column10: ultimately
column11:
its utility as an album is less clear. Will I ever reach for this over the original? Never. But it’s not impossible to imagine someone out there doing so once in a while. Which for a remix album is about as good as it gets.

To call Body Pill Anthony Naples' debut album should probably come with a big fat caveat: its eight tracks only amount to 29 minutes' total running time
column3: and two of its cuts are just a sketch-like two minutes long. But who cares when the record holds together this well? It feels like an album
column4: which
column5: in the post-format day and age
column6: is the only guideline that matters. And it certainly doesn't feel like a debut—at least
column7: not in the sense of baby steps or half-measures. The New York electronic musician's vision is fully formed here
column8: and it's original enough for him to stand out from the scads of producers trying similar hybrids of house
column9: techno
column10: and beat-up home-listening fare.

column1: That confidence is all the more striking given that Naples is a relative newcomer. He put out his first record in 2012
column2: on Mister Saturday Night
column3: the label arm of a popular New York party series. Strikingly
column4: ""Mad Disrespect"" was the first song he had ever completed—not bad at all
column5: given how effortlessly it flitted between the cut-up soul of artists like Andrés and the slightly off-kilter vibe of artists like Four Tet and Caribou in dancefloor mode. Since then
column6: he's recorded a handful of singles and EPs that have built upon the foundation established by his debut. They've all tended towards snapping house rhythms marked by flayed hi-hats and nervous
column7: syncopated kick drums; he's fond of chopped-up keys and copious overdrive. Equal parts sweet and gruff
column8: his club tracks are typically as juicy as a bruised blood orange.

column1: But Body Pill
column2: despite the title
column3: swerves away from the club. Its opening track
column4: ""Ris""
column5: opens with two minutes of beatless drones
column6: and the drums-and-synth figure that rises up out of the fog sounds less like dance music than a Casiotone reconstruction of the opening bars of Sonic Youth's ""Teen Age Riot"". ""Abrazo""
column7: which follows
column8: is a proper club track (even if that 3:25 running time may send DJs scrambling to come up with a follow-up before it fades out); its keening string loops and keyboard counterpoints are clearly in the vein of Pépé Bradock or Andrés
column9: and it employs some of the toughest
column10: most declarative drums on the whole record. Still
column11: it doesn't take long to see that Naples' idea of dance music is a little bit different from the norm. The drums are sort of lumpy and disheveled; the hi-hat is turned up a hair too loud
column12: and the snare sticks out like a broken front tooth. All that roughness is a way of balancing out the melancholy strings
column13: but it also highlights the way even the strings are a little bit raw
column14: their fidelity rough and their waveform crudely truncated; if this were a visual collage
column15: there'd be Scotch tape visible over the corners of the picture.

column1: The closing track
column2: ""Miles""
column3: seems like it'll be another of the record's go-to dancefloor cuts
column4: given its overlapping layers of drum machine and sampled percussion and its eyes-closed deep house vibes; it rings like a lawn sprinkler aimed at a gamelan ensemble. But then a curious thing happens: shortly before the three-minute marker
column5: it fades out
column6: the tempo shifts from 120 to 110 beats per minute
column7: and we're ushered out with tapped hi-hats and a tentative
column8: burbling melody
column9: as though someone had stepped on the hose. The rest of the album proceeds along similar lines
column10: in which club-music convention is tweaked ever so slightly
column11: its tropes repurposed for squirrelier aims. ""Changes"" balances absent-minded keys—a tinkly little up-and-down melody
column12: an unbroken chord—with a cutting machine beat that spins idly in place
column13: throwing off sparks. It's tough and drowsy all at once
column14: and so is ""Refugio""
column15: its tarnished counterpoints sounding like a conversation between two lonely robots. Most producers tend to visualize packed dancefloors when they're writing music
column16: but I suspect this one was made with an empty room in mind
column17: given the way its melody scoots like an idle gobo pattern across buffed hardwood. The only club-oriented track here that doesn't work so well is ""Used to Be""
column18: which swathes swaggering
column19: dubstep-inspired bass and drums in rosy Twin Peaks chords. It's not bad
column20: but it feels aimless—even though
column21: ironically
column22: it's one of the record's most clearly defined tracks.

column1: Perhaps he's simply better at abstraction. The drum-free
column2: two-minute ""Pale"" sounds even more like a '70s public-television soundtrack cue than Boards of Canada's music does; ""Way Stone""
column3: with its tight ripples of delay
column4: might be sourced from rocks skipped across a still lake. Its wooden lead sounds like a kalimba wrapped in layers of sticky masking tape; at the short track's end
column5: there's a rush of white noise like a seashell being held up to the ear. It's not terribly hard to make music that signifies varying shades of melancholy or unease; ""moody"" seems to be the default setting in dance music these days
column6: from the underground to the main stage. But Body Pill is different: it's moody
column7: but in a way that feels like he's not entirely clear about what the underlying mood really is. And there's an honesty to that. It sounds less like a young producer enjoying the fruits of quick success than a restless experimenter figuring out what to do next. Lucky for us
column8:
the woodshed is destination enough.

column7: and on their fourth LP Transfixiation
column8: the mere titles of ""Now It’s Over""
column9: ""Filling the Void"" and ""I Will Die"" let you know it caters to the indoor sunglasses crowd as expertly as ""Too Drunk to Karaoke"" and ""Oldest Surfer on the Beach"" did to the Croakies set.

column1: As with all of APTBS’ previous work
column2: Transfixiation is full of noise
column3: though it’s not necessarily noisy. The blistered
column4: red-hot distortion and shrieking feedback are purposeful noise
column5: the kind that’s typically a cloaking device within indie rock—either for a pure pop predilection
column6: hurt feelings
column7: or at worst
column8: a disinclination for songcraft. In this case
column9: the noise is a feint for an underlying ambition; even as Oliver Ackermann finds new ways to subject his guitars to circuitry S&M
column10: APTBS have increasingly given the impression that they want to be seen as more than ""the guy who makes guitar pedals.""

column1: And so Transfixiation emphasizes its rhythm section
column2: which in turn emphasizes that APTBS are a band. It’s not surprising that when given more a showcase
column3: bassist Dion Lunadon relies on the steady menace of early Peter Hook or the high-fretted melodicism of later Peter Hook. That doesn’t mean it’s ineffective—
column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">""
column5: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Straight"" is the most instantly memorable track if only because it recalls a jacked-up version of Radiohead
column6: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">’s ""Myxomatosis"" while ""Supermaster"" and ""We’ve Come So Far"" rely on pure velocity. APTBS don’t actually deal much in hooks
column7: so the semblance of danceable rhythm is a proper substitute.

column1: It’s not a huge shift from 2012’s relatively streamlined Worship
column2: which itself wasn’t a huge shift from its predecessor Exploding Head. APTBS’ progress has been incremental over the years
column3: so Transfixiation derives much of its success from being compared to their 2007 breakthrough— those who have been following since A Place to Bury Strangers can recognize the band’s evolution and justify their own investment. Those who are coming into Transfixiation blind might just hear a notable band boasting a currently rare commitment to an '80s kind of noise-rock rather than the '90s iterations of shoegaze
column4: goth
column5: or industrial that’s more prominent in 2015.

column1: Then again
column2: APTBS’ progress as a band only serves to expose the underlying one-dimensionality of their actual songwriting. This is a style of music rarely lauded for its lyrics in general
column3: let alone its topical range—it’s probably too much to ask for a political A Place to Bury Strangers song or a tripartite prog epic
column4: or a gooey love note just to shake things up. But for a band whose songs so frequently draw on the depths of despair
column5: incapacitating depression
column6: and occasional kink for inspiration
column7: the grousing of Transfixiation feels perfunctory. However admirable ""Filling the Void""
column8: ""I’m So Clean"" and ""Love High"" are for their sonic formalism
column9: the songs themselves are like fortune cookies filled with quotes from latter day Trent Reznor or the @sosadtoday Twitter feed.

column1: Case in point
column2: ""Deeper""—a generous reading would frame it as a devastating parody. An accurate reading would frame it as the six-minute nadir of APTBS’ fourth album. The chorus goes
column3: ""Deeper
column4: deeper
column5: deeper still/ Deeper than the deepest well
column6: which isn’t the funniest part only because Ackermann adopts a Christian Bale-as-Batman baritone to taunt
column7: ""if you fuck with me
column8: you’re gonna burn"" right before it. Occasionally
column9: <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column10: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">APTBS traffic in a speedfreak roadhouse blues that recall a mondo distorted version of Suicide; conversely
column11: ""Deeper"" is the first song ever to be conceivably inspired by Rollins Band’s legendary high comic cover of ""Ghost Rider"". If The Crow: 2037 ends up getting a release
column12: ""Deeper"" would do well to soundtrack the rain-soaked resurrection of whoever that year's version of Edward Furlong happens to be.

column1: But zone out from ""Deeper"" and
column2: combined with its instrumental successor ""Lower Zone""
column3: Transfixiation is capable sludge-goth ambience. Regardless of its issues
column4: it never distracts from intimating the same old points: Ackermann makes expensive guitar pedals and the band plays with a ferocity that will make theirs the only show you’ll want to see for the next month—and due to its ear-splitting volume
column5: maybe the only show you’ll physically be able to hear for a month. So whenever the temptation to lend a closer ear to Transfixiation arises
column6:
you should know better by now.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21392/homepage_large.85472034.jpg|Tangier Sessions|577.0|Sir Richard Bishop|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2015-02-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:14:52.264375|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".3jh02445c0.1.6:0.1.0.$20123/=1$20123.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div class=""ii gt m14b76169793dcc24 adP adO"">
