In the 1920s
column2: a reactionary trend began to take hold in classical music. Composers began to imitate and quote styles from centuries past: particularly
column3: the music of Baroque and Classical masters like Bach and Mozart. Simplicity and symmetry became the order of the day
column4: instead of density and sharp dissonance (hallmarks of the prevailing avant-garde). ""Neoclassical"" is a fitting descriptor to use when comparing the bulk of Sir Richard Bishop’s solo recordings to the far-flung experiments of the Sun City Girls
column5: his disbanded
column6: performance art-inclined avant-rock trio. As the Girls did
column7: Bishop mixes and matches pan-continental musical styles (from East Asian traditional music to gypsy jazz)
column8: but he does so less abrasively: with simple tools (a guitar or two) and little theatricality. As in the most compelling neoclassical compositions
column9: Bishop’s music is driven by clever stylistic juxtapositions and attractive melodicism.

column1: Tangier Sessions
column2: Bishop’s latest album of solo guitar music
column3: was recorded in just a week during a short visit to the Moroccan city. Like much of his output both alone and with the Girls
column4: it’s largely improvised. Bishop circles around and tries out instantiations of a melodic phrase before committing to one
column5: seemingly debating where to move in real time. A particularly clear example of this phenomenon is the speed-ramping ""International Zone""
column6: which grows in rhythmic complexity and tempo as the guitarist hones in on a central
column7: raga-like melodic pattern.

column1: Stylistically
column2: the album evokes Morocco as a hub of cultural exchange. Bishop often explores the Andalusian flamenco guitar style
column3: infusing it with gestures from across the country’s other borders. In the seductive
column4: cyclical crocheting of ""Mirage""
column5: there’s traces of the Mali-centered ""desert blues
column6: a style sometimes considered to have inspired the American blues
column7: but which now
column8: in contemporary practice
column9: re-emulates it. Elsewhere
column10: Bishop’s haunting melodies recall the sound of the oud
column11: a popular lute-like instrument in North Africa
column12: as well as in the Middle East and Greece.

column1: This image of Moroccan culture as manifold and mysterious is a prevalent one in literature and film
column2: usually contributing to an atmosphere of intrigue or seediness (see Casablanca
column3: Naked Lunch or Jim Jarmusch’s recent Only Lovers Left Alive). Bishop playfully evokes some of the Hollywood Morocco on Tangier Sessions. There is the flamenco chugging of the appropriately titled ""Safe House""
column4: which comes across like Bishop scoring a farcical chase scene in a spy film. The energetic piece not only breaks up the otherwise meditative album nicely
column5: but seems to acknowledge the music’s inherent cultural tourism
column6: or the way this part of the world has historically captured the Western imagination.

column1: The Sun City Girls’ tendency toward exoticism is hard to avoid; indeed
column2: when doing something like shrieking in faux-Far Eastern gibberish
column3: they push it in their listeners’ faces. Does Bishop’s more polite collage-artistry
column4: too
column5: condescend to and totemize its source material? To some extent (so
column6: often
column7: does the music of John Fahey
column8: Claude Debussy and The Nutcracker)
column9: but Bishop’s irreverence doesn’t overshadow the beauty and gentle
column10: sometimes breathtaking intricacy of this music. He’s spent decades getting musical vocabularies from all over the world under his fingers
column11: and even when his improvisations begin to meander
column12: what he creates from his well of options is remarkable and wholly his own.

""When I saw that photo of the sun setting into the ocean
column2: it seemed to express everything we were trying to say
column3: said Supreme Jubilees keyboardist Leonard Sanders in the liner notes to Numero Group’s excellent rare gospel comp from 2013
column4: Good God!: Apocryphal Hymns. It’s one of the rare comps–gospel or otherwise—that I find myself returning to time and time again
column5: regardless of that long-passed deadline. That said
column6: I’d be hard-pressed to instantly name any of the nineteen acts that comprise the set
column7: be they Robert Vanderbilt & the Foundation of Souls or the Fantastic Goldenaires of Rocky Mount
column8: N.C. But when Light in the Attic last month announced the reissue of California sextet the Supreme Jubilees’ 1981 album
column9: It’ll All Be Over
column10: their unforgettable contribution to that set immediately sprung to mind.

column1: Formed in Fresno
column2: Calif. by two sets of siblings
column3: the Supreme Jubilees consisted of four Sanders brothers and two Kingsby brothers
column4: all cousins who attended the same church. Whether you’re a fan of the Everlys or the Isleys
column5: the Blue Sky Boys in the early 20th century or Haim in the 21st
column6: the preternatural close harmonies of kin is one of the more sublime sounds on Earth
column7: regardless of whether it's recording secular or profane music. And the Jubilees' ability to make their voices converge as one is sweet indeed.

column1: The liner notes suggest it was a struggle getting the gospel group’s sound down in the studio. One half of the record was engineered by someone well-versed in country and western
column2: but not inclined to give the group the kind of low-end their live shows dealt in. So half of the nine-track album has a lightness about it that apparently didn’t do the band justice—the group was forced to relocate elsewhere to finish the album. When they moved to another studio
column3: tracks like ""Do You Believe"" and ""You Don’t Know"" have a heftier groove
column4: the bass and hi-hats crisp.

column1: There’s some talk in the notes that ""If God had a disco
column2: the DJ would be playing the Supreme Jubilees
column3: but we all know he'd just have Larry Levan spinning the Joubert Singers' ""Stand on the Word"". Decent as the uptempo tunes are
column4: in retrospect it’s the slower
column5: more effervescent numbers that have a tactile magic about them. ""We’ll Understand"" is taken at a stately pace
column6: the organ plaintive
column7: the flanged guitar like the last tendrils of honey in a jar. ""Maybe you can find some consolation in this song
column8: they sing right before the chorus. When the organ wheezes and aligns with those voices
column9: there’s a tingling sense of elevation.

column1: But back to the title track
column2: which also appeared on Good God!. It’s as the glorious as the golden sunset that comprises the cover art
column3: even if it is a stock photo that numerous bands deployed for their own privately-pressed albums. ""It’ll All Be Over"" arches over the setting sun
column4: suggesting that the afterlife is as beauteous as the Pacific Ocean come sunset
column5: yet as warm as a baptismal dip in the Caribbean. The song itself is manna
column6: the keys suggesting soul as well as Sunday service
column7: with a woodblock beat clocklike even as it signifies that moment forever outside of time. When the Jubilees’s vocals meld together on the chorus: ""It’ll all be over/ And we won’t have to cry no more."" it devastates
column8: not from that admission of death
column9: of burden being released
column10:
but because it signifies that sheer beauty of the beyond. It’s about as close to a convincing argument I’ve encountered that the afterlife just might be better than life itself.

The cover of the debut album from Barcelona-based foursome Mourn bears an uncanny compositional resemblance to that of another debut album by another young
column2: petulant quartet with an M
column3: O
column4: R
column5: and N in their name. The band logo emblazoned in white all-caps
column6: the grimly grayscale urban backdrop
column7: the dark-haired subjects clad in leather jackets—Mourn’s reverence for the Ramones couldn’t be more obvious if they wore their t-shirts in their press photos. (Oh wait.) But despite a shared affinity for 90-second tunes
column8: Mourn are drawn to the Ramones more as a model of aesthetic purity than a sonic template to emulate; though all four members are still in their teens
column9: their scabrous sound feels less like a hyperactive buzzsaw assault than a series of steely knife nicks on the arm. And while
column10: like the bruddahs
column11: Mourn’s songs can be simplistic to the point of absurdity
column12: for them
column13: rawness is as much an emotional quality as a musical one.

column1: Mourn was reportedly recorded live off the floor in two days
column2: a tactic that emphasizes both the band’s feral energy and the isolated
column3: claustrophobic uneasiness that ties these 11 songs together. More so than the surface Ramones similarities
column4: what’s ultimately most striking about that cover shot is the fact that vocalists Carla Pérez Fas and Jazz Rodríguez Bueno are seen in a protective embrace
column5: suggesting that this band is less an innocent adolescent pastime than a necessary sanctuary from a cruel world. That said
column6: Mourn aren’t so eager to fit in with the normals at school
column7: pledging allegiance to artists who died before they were born or who are old enough to be their mom
column8: if not their grandmother; in the few interviews they’ve done so far
column9: they’ve talked about having their music mocked by classmates
column10: and the dispiriting experience of encountering a potential new soulmate in a Nirvana shirt
column11: only to find out the person wearing it thought Nirvana was just the name of a clothing brand.

column1: As such
column2: Mourn is the sound of outcasts congregating in a basement on a Friday night and making a savage racket to forget about the fact they weren’t invited to the big house party that all the popular kids from school are attending. It’s loud
column3: cathartic
column4: and boiling over with disdain for those who’ve done them wrong; when they start naming names on ""Jack"" and ""Marshall""
column5: you can practically picture Fas and Bueno hunched around a computer
column6: subjecting those guys’ pictures to unflattering Photoshop makeovers. Their music is anti-social media: Mourn don’t so much write songs as status updates—""you think you’re awesome/ I say you’re boring/ you called me a baby/ I just say ‘fuck you!’""—that most people would be rushing to delete the morning after
column7: but Mourn turn candor into sport
column8: dropping truth bombs and reveling in the emotional fallout. (And as if the album proper didn’t serve up enough unfiltered honesty
column9: this stateside issue of Mourn tacks on a bonus single… called ""Boys Are Cunts"".)

column1: But for all their impulsive lyricism
column2: Mourn are an impressively patient band
column3: with a keen sense of dramatic dynamics and gritty groove (courtesy of Bueno’s 15-year-old sister Leia and drummer Antonio Postius Echeverría) that belies their primordial teenage garage-band beginnings. (In particular
column4: the opening ""Your Brain Is Made of Candy"" is a masterstroke of sustained tension that builds from a stark
column5: solitary strum into a raging
column6: stomping beast that abruptly cuts out the second it hits its feverish peak
column7: transforming that titular sentiment from coy come-on to brutal kiss-off.) And for a record that whips by in just 24 minutes
column8: Mourn exhibits a refreshing breadth that makes it feel like a complete album rather than an overstuffed
column9: undercooked EP—while punkish toss-off tracks like ""Misery Factory"" and ""You Don’t Know Me"" feel like remnants of a formative phase Mourn have already outgrown
column10: the ""Jane Says""-like sway of ""Marshall"" and the goth-psych eruption ""Silver Gold"" respectively assert the band’s accessible and experimental potential. More than a simple clash of teen-angst noise and old-soul poise
column11:
Mourn’s debut album is a reminder that a big impetus for the former is the frustration of wishing you were old enough to savor the latter.

There’s a moment on Talent Night at the Ashram when singer Sonny Smith is conversing melodramatically with a dog. ""Why did you go?"" he asks it sadly
column2: receiving whining barks in response. ""Well
column3: I’m going to swallow you
column4: he replies before seemingly directing his voice back to whoever is listening in on their conversation. ""And then it pans and it goes into this other scene that felt much more artificial
column5: he finishes before the song teeters back into a psychedelic jam session of electric guitar and reverb.

column1: The dog mini-drama is just a little taste of what Talent Night at the Ashram could have been had it come to fruition in its original format. Sonny and the Sunsets' fifth album was supposed to be a short film but after shooting pieces with actors
column2: Sonny Smith realized the project was clearly becoming an album and ditched the plan altogether to construct a record.

column1: <div dir=""ltr"">
Towards the end of the 2000s
column2: a time-portal to 1960’s garage rock must have opened
column3: because out came Thee Oh Sees
column4: White Fence
column5: and Sonny Smith. And while his early early contemporaries only got louder
column6: Smith’s psych music has cooled to a still vintage-sounding
column7: folk-tinged mellow
column8: like a crunchier Mac DeMarco. Smith has always been less concerned with crafting the most fuzzed out rock jams and more with telling the best stories. Every song on the band’s latest
column9: Antenna to the Afterworld
column10: was some sort of hyper-detailed space-age mythology
column11: full of sword-swallowing girls and green blood-splattered martian murders. His sun-kissed record Longtime Companion had him at his best Bob Dylan impression
column12: crooning about his babe the divorcee and reminding everyone of their mortality
column13: as if he were dispelling wisdom around an invisible campfire.

column1: So it’s surprising that Sonny and the Sunsets' latest isn’t totally batshit weird. Perhaps its cinematic intentions left Smith toning down his fantastic visions because Talent Night at the Ashram is grounded in a very palatable reality
column2: one that harkens back to the band’s first two albums. But that isn’t to say this record isn’t without its surrealist moments. In ""Cheap Extensions""
column3: Smith follows a girl he spotted in a grocery store by trailing her strange
column4: long hair. In ""The Secluded Estate""
column5: he speaks of a bizarre house filled with all the women he’s ever known and how scary a house it really is. Smith seems to consistently approach the female sex with the curiosity of a wide-eyed 10-year-old
column6: but in a way that is ultimately charming rather than grating.

column1: The stories Smith chooses to tell on Talent Night at the Ashram are mini-character studies seeking to answer what it means to be a put-together human. Whether he’s dwelling on a very private girl’s life on ""Alice Leaves for the Mountains"" or the stressed eccentric Icelene on the folksy
column2: Kurt Weisman-esque ""Icelene’s Loss""
column3: Smith tries to figure out his own characters like puzzles. The seven minute-long ""Happy Carrot Health Food Store"" plays like a kooky Richard Scarry book
column4: a laundry list in pointing out hippie passersby that could set Smith on the fast track to pulling a Jonathan Richman in the children’s music industry. ""Shannon who outworks everyone but always messes shit up
column5: he sings
column6: ""Why is she so terrible with all the customers?""

column1: There’s indirectness to Smith’s delivery on this record
column2: his voice sleepy and layered on each song. He’s usually a voyeur in these songs
column3: not the main character
column4: grasping for signifiers of other people’s normality (long hair
column5: loud voices
column6: happy homes) as he tries to figure out his own. Whereas on Smith’s last record he was battling the aliens
column7: on Talent Night at the Ashram it sounds like he’s just become one
column8: slinking through grocery stores and peeking into houses trying to pin down what everyone’s deal is. ""I filled out the application to be a human being
column9:
Smith sings on the album’s opening song to a girl who might as well be the whole world. ""I hope my papers go through.""

Before Guided by Voices
column3: before Boston Spaceships
column4: before the Circus Devils
column5: Go Back Snowball
column6: Acid Ranch
column7: Psycho & the Birds and all the rest
column8: there was Ricked Wicky. Well
column9: sort of; when a then-teenaged Robert Pollard dreamt up his very first band from his Dayton bedroom
column10: the name Ricked Wicky shone down from the imaginary marquee. Through dozens of bands and hundreds of records
column11: Pollard—whose inhuman output rarely leaves him holding much in his back pocket for very long—held onto Ricked Wicky. Why he'd resurrect it now—with Guided by Voices' second act retreating into the rearview—isn't hard to figure: though they managed six LPs in four years' time
column12: you increasingly got the sense Pollard's famously overactive mind was starting to wander. So
column13: after a few shaky years and far too many diminishing returns
column14: Pollard's looking to cast off expectations
column15: refocus his efforts
column16:
and get back to what got him here in the first place.

Ricked Wicky finds Pollard joined by a few familiars—right-hand man Todd Tobias and Earthquake Glue-era GBV drummer Kevin March—and one complete newcomer to the Pollard fold: Nick Mitchell
column17: a Dayton guitarist who Pollard stresses is ""no relation"" to ex-GBV axeman Mitch. Nearly all of I Sell the Circus
column18: Ricked Wicky's restorative 15-song debut
column19: was laid down on analog tape at Dayton's Cyberteknics; the sound is clean
column20: crisp
column21: and most of all
column22: consistent
column23: a comparatively hi-fi spin through the beery arena rock
column24: prog-addled balladry and post-R.E.M. jangle that Pollard's spent the last 15 years alchemizing into something all its own. I Sell the Circus isn't a particularly surprising record
column26: it's among the most satisfying: 15 would-be anthems and stumbling serenades
column28:
little fuss.

I Sell the Circus bounds out of the gate with a five-song stretch to rival that on any Pollard record of the last half-decade: the sunny ""Well Suited""
column31: the champagne-on-an-empty-stomach stumble of ""Cow Headed Moon""
column33: swaggering ""Piss Face"". Delicately accented—a dab of pump organ here
column34: a sliver of slide guitar there—and blithely catchy
column35: this five-song run is post-millenial Pollard at his finest: nimble
column37:
just mercurial enough.

While it starts off strong
column38: Circus does get a little paunchy around the midsection.""Uranus Flies"" isn't much more than shits and giggles
column39: while ""Even Today and Tomorrow"" only differentiates itself from the dime-a-dozen proggy Pollard ballads that pepper Pollard's every release only through Nick Mitchell's stately steel-string runs. Pollard passes the mic to Mitchell (who
column41: sounds for all the world like Bob Pollard just before) for the egghead-baiting ""The Intellectual Types""; sure it's dumb
column42:
but it's just the right kind of dumb.

Pollard being Pollard
column43: certain quirks are inevitable: throwaway lyrics
column46: flagging energies. But the overall impression one gets from Circus is that of engagement: Pollard clearly wants this thing to work
column47: wants to find a few guys to play with who he doesn't feel held back by
column48: and despite the occasional foible here and there
column49: his dedication to Ricked Wicky's cause rings out throughout nearly all of I Sell the Circus. One regal instrumental (""Tomorrow"")
column52: and Circus goes out on a high—""A Real Stab""
column53:
a stirring slab of straightahead power-pop that seems to gather strength as it charges towards the finish line.

Pollard could've kept GBV going: if nothing else
column54: the money's probably better. Or he could've peeled off a few picture-perfect pop songs for any number of washed-up rockers without an idea between them
column55: collected a few fat royalty checks
column56: and spent the rest of his days holding court at home in Dayton. And he could've just as easily retreated into weirdness
column57: content in the knowledge that the loyal servants of the Fading Captain would continue to lap up just about anything he had to offer. Instead
column58: we get Ricked Wicky: recognizably him
column59: but with what—after a few rocky years—feels like a renewed sense of purpose. If Circus isn't a front-to-back triumph
column60: it's got enough juice in it to forgive the occasional misfire. Whether Ricked Wicky proves an ongoing Boston Spaceships-style reboot or just another nifty diversion remains to be seen; we'll know more in June
column61: when their second album's due. For now

column1: Whereas You Blew It! have dutifully and enthusiastically embraced opportunity to become the revitalized Jade Tree’s most notable signing to date

column8: Tanner Jones got drunk on the Harry Potter ride at Universal Studios. You get the idea. But all this means is that You Blew It! know their strengths—they’re committed to making accessible

column1: It’s also their warmest work yet

column4: but more of an arrival

column6: Dude. Five minutes in

column8: softie mixtape tentpoles like ""Strong Island""
column9: ""House Address"" and ""Better to Best""
column10: which showcased Jones’ pliable lower register and the most luxurious and luminous guitars in modern emo. This is the only kind of You Blew It! that shows up on Pioneer of Nothing.

column4: gooey pop center. But there’s a bitter edge to the lyrics that carries over from Keep Doing What You’re Doing as Jones expresses another disappointment in a friend who hasn’t moved on—""Don’t be cold/ I couldn’t think of anything less cool/ Than your Saturdays talking trash."" ""Lanai"" is a love song to the music that moves him
column5: but also Jones writing a love song to a more positive version of himself.

column2: a show-closing
column3: slow-climb ballad that’s been concentrated into a three-minute anthem. ""Your Side"" follows as Pioneer's most revelatory moment

column6: it’s Brand New’s ""Me vs. Maradona vs. Elvis"" that can’t quite go there
column7: and deliver the necessary vocal
column8: lyrical or musical catharsis.

column1: In a way
column2: the near-miss of ""Your Side"" works in the favor of Pioneer of Nothing; otherwise
column3: it might be too promising in a literal sense

Which would raise the question of why they wouldn’t just save ""Lanai"" and ""Bedside Manor"" for a record that has excellent odds of being the properly worthy Nothing Feels Good follow-up the Promise Ring never delivered to Jade Tree in light of Very Emergency’s cloying pop-rock and leaping to Anti- for their lush

a lack of hang-ups about the e-word—it stands to reason that they'll let us know their next step when the time comes and that it'll come soon.

In the five years since disbanding the seminal post-metal act Isis
column2: Aaron Turner has broadened the scope of his work
column3: offering a variety of sounds in numerous projects that range from the sludge punk weirdness of Old Man Gloom to the more pensive ambience of Mamiffer. Amid this kind of experimentation
column4: his tendency to manipulate the spaces his music inhabits has remained a given
column5: and for all that the multi-instrumentalist has produced in the world of heavy music
column6: his most profound contribution has been an innate sense of the balance between elegance and ugliness. While The Deal isn’t a reinvention of that formula
column7: the debut from his latest project
column8: Sumac
column9: offers a new perspective
column10: one that finds Turner at his most sonically aggressive in years.

column1: The Deal capitalizes on an energy of unease
column2: building from moments of fractured disquiet into a tumult of guitar tones and the disjointed rhythmic patterns of drummer Nick Yacyshyn (of Baptists). It’s not unfamiliar territory for Turner: much of what provided Isis with its distinctive sound came from the same move from dissonant ambience into volatile culminations. But The Deal isn’t an exercise in self-involved nostalgia; where his other projects largely homed in on carefully constructed frameworks
column3: Sumac takes its strengths from a powerful fragmentation.

column1: Though listed as an ""auxiliary"" member
column2: bassist Brian Cook provides a point of reference for the music’s hollowed-out qualities. Cook’s playing with Russian Circles
column3: in addition to his past work with These Arms Are Snakes and Botch
column4: has seen him at his most commanding when manipulating the lower end of the sound’s spectrum. That bone-rattling distinction for Cook works so well with the other two members here that it’s almost surprising Sumac is a new band and hasn’t been around for years.

column1: The music here employs both hardcore and post-metal with careful
column2: but unhinged abandon. The outstanding ""Hollow King""
column3: for instance
column4: is a 12-minute rendering of Turner’s former ornate proclivities turned into something unpredictable and ruptured. That bellicosity is The Deal’s underpinning
column5: giving the album a common thread to ground its otherwise improvisational focus.

column1: Venturing into free form is a bold move
column2: especially given that with few exceptions
column3: the other projects for the band's members are built around directed compositional frameworks. There are certainly moments where the music struggles under the weight of its own improvised technique. But by and large
column4: the risk pays off
column5: the approach offering a sound familiar enough to speak to the individual members’ strengths
column6:
and vulnerable enough to see those singular characteristics take on something darker and more ferocious.

The minority who find Tame Impala's self-seriousness a slog have always needed the clowns in Pond. They're more obvious performers

column3: more obvious comedians—everything they do is more <i>obvious
column4: and while snobs have reamed them as nothing more than dumb fun
column5: dumb fun is emphatically the point. ""It's all a joke

column1: That's by design. Pond are chaotic

column1: Members of the band have winkingly referred to their records forming a conceptual rock star career trajectory: Frond was the auspicious breakthrough

column2: but here they lack momentum

Closer ""Somerset (I Can’t Get Over)"" is the closest we get to a glimpse at the pre-nomadic Moss with her bookishness wit taking center stage as she pleas for an ex to ""please don’t get over me"" between listing famous authors. It’s devoid of the symbolism that became distracting on Virtue

Ben Chasny has always been an unsettled artist. In his work as Six Organs of Admittance
column2: he refuses to stay in one place for long
column3: darting between folk
column4: rock
column5: psych
column6: and noise from album to album and song to song. But Hexadic is his first record that actually sounds unsettling. His guitar playing is desperate and cutting—a fiery
column7: jagged rip that recalls Japanese air-piercers like Keiji Haino and KK Null. On the more hectic tracks
column8: Chasny and his band approach the aggressive howl of drowned-in-the-red acts like Sightings and Harry Pussy. But even when they swing slower and sparser
column9: the music remains harrowing
column10: more bent on disturbing than soothing.

column1: The constantly-disruptive feel of Hexadic makes it perhaps the most consistent Six Organs albums to date. There’s a real sense of aesthetic purpose here; though none of Chasny’s work has ever sounded non-commital
column2: his dedication to one guitar approach creates thorough cohesion
column3: gluing all nine tracks together under one communal vibe. That effect was likely enhanced by Chasny’s self-devised songwriting system
column4: one that even inspired him to create his own set of Six Organs playing cards. But this method seems more about creating a frame of mind than hewing to specific rules
column5: as the resulting music sounds ready and willing to go anywhere.

column1: That openness allows Chasny and his colleagues—including his Comets on Fire bandmate Noel Von Harmonson on drums—to play patiently and thoughtfully. Even when they’re smashing into a crescendo
column2: it feels like a natural
column3: well-worn state rather than a rushed attempt to force frenzy. In a way they come off like an athlete who’s so calm under pressure her heartbeat hardly varies whether she’s winning easily or taken down to the wire. So even though Hexadic bears an ominous
column4: sometimes even disorienting tone
column5: there’s a placidity to the proceedings that keeps the music more welcoming than confrontational. It reminds me of how Neil Young’s noisiest songs sway rather than crash
column6: more reflective than assaultive
column7: despite all the sonic debris.

column1: In Hexadic’s best songs
column2: the reflective and the assaultive are two sides of a coin. The heavy march of ""Hollow River"" is both turgid in Chasny’s dense distortion and spacious in its elongated beat. ""Guild"" creates a similar atmosphere before retreating subtly into dry
column3: open spaces
column4: while ""Future Verbs"" is almost all open spaces
column5: like a spaghetti Western theme stretched into suspense-movie tension. Other tunes are more blunt
column6: terrorizing attacks—take the pummeling grind of ""Sphere Path Code C"" or the aptly-titled ""Maximum Hexadic""—yet still somehow feel measured
column7: perhaps just by association.

column1: Whether those destructive sides of Hexadic will appeal to anyone not already initiated into the Six Organs circle is hard to guess. You could even imagine some fans of Chasny’s folkier side balking at the relentlessness of his dark-lensed vision here. But such concerns seem beside the point; if Chasny was worried about maintaining or growing an audience
column2: he wouldn’t have made so many unpredictable choices and opposing moves while crafting one of the most unique discographies of the past 15 years. And besides
column3: you might not have guessed Hexadic would sound like this
column4:
but you won’t be surprised that it sounds this good.

Though he came of age during the heyday of the bad-boy R&B singer
column3: Ne-Yo’s allegiances have always belonged to an earlier

column13:

Of course
column14: being the cautious sort
column15: he gives himself some cover. In interviews
column16: Ne-Yo has said for inspiration that he reached out to fans on social media to share their experiences

and Juicy J to impart some hardened masculinity for him.

For all his character acting
column27: Ne-Yo couldn’t be playing anybody but himself. ""She Said I’m Hood Tho"" finds the star drawn to a brassy nail salon worker who isn’t shy about telling him he’s fallen off. Despite the mutual attraction
column28: the chasm between their social castes leaves both of them feeling insecure. Anxieties about his career standing also creep into ""Everybody Loves/The Def of You""
column29: where he can’t shake a girl who’s less interested in him than his celebrity connections. ""Only time I hear from her is right around the BET awards
column33:
‘If you going can I come with ya? And can you ask Trey if I can get a picture?’""

Though Non-Fiction only occasionally rises to the high songwriting standards of Ne-Yo’s seamless 2008 album Year of the Gentleman

There are 19 songs on Quarterbacks’ proper debut and every single one of them is about a girl. More broadly
column2: they’re about ""girls""—specific ones that occupy young Dean Engle’s thoughts
column3: couch and bedroom
column4: but they're also present as a theoretical construct in his daydreams. ""Knicks"" and ""Sportscenter""? They’re kinda about girls. ""The Dogs"" is 28 seconds long
column5: Engle’s recollection of a guy with two puppies on his lap driving off a back road. It still manages to be about a girl
column6: because he wishes the proverbial ""you"" were there to see it. Engle spends Quarterbacks in a heightened state of romantic curiosity
column7: waking up with the express intent of either falling in love or falling out of love; a day without either is considered a miserable failure and staying in love is compared to being unconscious. To paraphrase a legendary overseer of quarterbacks
column8: love isn’t everything to Engle. It’s the only thing.

column1: Engle has found the perfect vehicle for this kind of subject matter
column2: which is twee-punk in its purest form. Based on some of their songwriting values
column3: Quarterbacks could be a hardcore band—they have the requisite velocity
column4: the brevity
column5: the structural minimalism. His most complicated songwriting tricks are doubling a guitar riff with his vocals and bringing a song to a dead halt midway through just to catch his breath. There isn’t enough time for a verse and a chorus
column6: so Engle just stuffs as many words into a melody as it can hold
column7: zips it backwards and lets it fly.

column1: But as with nearly all bands in the indie world using a sports reference in their name
column2: Quarterbacks call attention to their music’s total lack of aggro masculinity therein. The guitars are played without distortion
column3: which is necessary for Engle’s classic
column4: nasal lilt to be heard. The entirety of Quarterbacks is slightly less than 22 minutes
column5: meaning the average song lasts about 69 seconds. Even in the context of twee defined by their K Records forebearers
column6: Engle’s couplings are adolescent
column7: relationships entirely based on watching TV
column8: holding hands and kissing. Engel begs
column9: ""I wanna be the last boy to love you
column10: the choice of the word ""boy"" being very important
column11: as the settings of swimming pools
column12: awkward dances and car rides liken college as more or less an adult summer camp.

column1: Fortunately
column2: there’s a cynical streak that prevents Quarterbacks from being a literal charm offensive. Engle acknowledges his own social failings without dwelling on them
column3: but Quarterbacks also grapples with its right to even exist. ""Simple Songs"" is the most obvious meta moment
column4: as Engle sings
column5: ""I believe in pop music the way I wish I believe in God/ Completely
column6: without question
column7: his preferred E minor-C-G chord progression serving as a surrogate Hail Mary. Except he doesn’t really believe they’re a proper substitute
column8: implicating that choosing pop over God isn’t just a poor choice for one’s spiritual health
column9: but a terrible cliché.

column1: And so then
column2: love. On ""Center""
column3: Engle muses
column4: ""As I get older/ I recognize that love is mostly situational."" True
column5: and Engle seems to find it in every situation. Some form of ""love"" is mentioned in nearly half of Quarterbacks’ songs; within the first minute
column6: Engle shrugs
column7: ""I’m in love as usual"" and seconds later
column8: ""I’m not in luv with anyone/ What’s wrong with me?"" He seems to realize he’s talking about some pop version of love
column9: one that either belongs in scare quotes or misspelled as ""luv"" to drive home its falsehood.

column1: In spite of the formalism
column2: individual tracks on Quarterbacks are a sharp jolt. Together
column3: they blur to make the album more of a mood piece; you can picture a house show where Engle starts to play the chords to ""Usual"" and the rhythm section thinks it’s ""Stay in Luv"" or vice versa. And while Engle ensures even the slightest song is a completed thought
column4: compared to his more ambitious and extroverted peers
column5: you wonder if the charm of the form exceeds that of the content—in similarly cramped spaces
column6: Frankie Cosmos brings more clarity and whimsy
column7: Modern Baseball more detail
column8: Joyce Manor more intricate pop craftsmanship. Then again
column9: Quarterbacks may just be the sound of modest ambition being met. In an interview with Fader
column10: Engle admits
column11: ""20 years ago
column12: this band would have released a 7-inch and then disappeared
column13:
his point being that he'd be perfectly fine if that was the ceiling. Which is to say that Quarterbacks truly is a labor of love.

""There’s more warmth and space in dub
column3: more than in any other music

column7: reggae

column9: Afrobeat
column10: electro
column11: and hip-hop began to entangle and crossbreed
column12: Sherwood was often in the producer’s chair to help dub out the results. His credits range from punks like the Fall and New Age Steppers to Lee ""Scratch"" Perry and industrial hip-hop band Tackhead. And his remixes—be it for Sinéad O’Connor or Skinny Puppy—accentuated both the sharp and corroded edges of the beats as well as the space in-between. The work he rendered in Brit-Jamaican mash-ups as Creation Rebel
column13: Dub Syndicate
column14: and African Head Charge on his On-U Sound label in the early 1980s remain the headiest amalgams of dub some three decades later.

column1: Collaboration lies at the heart of Sherwood’s work

column3: so it makes sense that in the 21st century

column6: aka Pinch. Dub oozes from Ellis’ production portfolio and he
column7: too
column8: favors collaboration
column9: be it with old drum and bass producer Photek or the likes of Shackleton. Ellis and Sherwood’s collaboration stems from a 2011 DJ night at London superclub Fabric and singles followed.

column1: On their first full-length collaboration

column1: Part of the trickiness in pinning down Castex's newest LP stems from the seemingly disjointed stable of guests he enlisted to help in its construction. There's assists from the narcotized Montreal ambient act Sea Oleena
column2: Francois Marry of the staid multinational indie pop crew Francois and the Atlas Mountain

column1: Creatures nevertheless remains engaging for how these largely collaborative constructions highlight the stunning omnivorousness that Castex has been able to imbue in his solo recordings. column4:

Terry Riley’s minimalist landmark In C turned 50 years old in 2014. In that time
column3: it’s become one of the most well-known and oft-performed minimalist compositions
column4: and the reasons for this seem clear enough: The piece’s heterophonic structure is harmonically unusual
column5: but uniformly consonant
column6: and the piece’s insistent rhythm and devotion to melody
column7: however fragmentary
column8: give it a sense of unstoppable motion. It is friendly music
column9: and a lot of music that challenges compositional traditions is not.

column1: The basic structure of In C is simple: Someone plays a simple
column2: droning pulse on the note C
column3: usually on a piano or marimba
column4: and the other performers
column5: whose number and instrumentation Riley did not specify
column6: have 53 melodic phrases from which to choose. The musicians select the phrases they want to play and decide how long to play them. The effect is that the phrases overlap in unpredictable ways
column7: creating shifts in harmony
column8: evolving polyrhythms
column9: tonal and timbral changes and the sense that nothing is constant
column10: even though the same note repeats insistently under the whole performance at the exact same tempo.

column1: There are dozens of recordings
column2: starting with Riley’s own from 1968. Some are kinetic and exciting
column3: others never seem to come together
column4: but the piece is so dramatically different from performance to performance that it never grows old. Damon Albarn’s Africa Express project
column5: which over the years has fostered collaborations between a huge number of Western and West African musicians puts a decidedly unique spin on In C. With an ensemble of 17 musicians—including Albarn on melodica
column6: Brian Eno
column7: Bijou and Olugbenga on vocals
column8: Jeff Wootton and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs’ Nick Zinner on guitar
column9: Cheick Diallo on flute
column10: Badou Mbaye
column11: Alou Coulibaly and Mouse on Mars’ Andi Toma on percussion
column12: Modibo Diawara and Defily Sako on kora
column13: Guindo Sala on imzad
column14: Kalifa Koné and Mémé Koné on balafon
column15: Adama Koita on kamel n’goni
column16: and André de Ridder on several instruments and conducting—they have an earthy collective sound
column17: and their dynamic interplay is quite distinct from any other version of In C I’ve heard.

column1: For one thing
column2: the non-tonal percussion included in the ensemble layers a dance vibe under the piece’s usual trance vibe. Diallo’s flute in particular is so dissimilar from every other sound on the recording that he stands out and shifts the emphasis briefly to melody
column3: while the three voices lend it an ethereal quality. The mellow tone of the koras
column4: kalimbas
column5: and balafons
column6: meanwhile
column7: have a strange effect during the period cooldowns over the course of the piece; they lend it an odd
column8: cool darkness that I usually don’t hear in In C. These passages lend it a suite-like feel where the piece most often is structured as a giant crescendo followed by a long diminuendo. The most bold decision here comes just past the halfway mark
column9: though
column10: when the ensemble goes nearly silent
column11: including the pulse
column12: leaving just guitars and koras playing the slowest melodic phrases in a strange kind of canon
column13: and then we’re treated to a brief spoken word passage (not in English) before the larger ensemble dives back in with even more rhythmic insistence than before.

column1: This willingness to play with the form and shape of an iconic piece of music is one of the things that most fully sets this recording of In C apart from most others. It’s unexpected and enlivens the music just as much as the djembe that lends the evolving beat its weight. The overall form of the piece may be more premeditated than Riley originally intended
column2: rather than the independently reached and unforeshadowed consensus of a large group of musicians
column3: but this mostly serves to make it an engaging performance and worthy interpretation of a piece of music that’s so eternal it could literally be played eternally if someone was able to get musicians to keep showing up to play it. Africa Express keeps it to a bite-sized 41 minutes
column4:
and every one of them includes something to savor.

column6: and raping his then-girlfriend and leaving her overnight outside of the tattoo shop where he’d been working. As reported

column8: but even more so because it actualized a decade-plus of Whitehead’s lyrical and musical malevolence.

column1: Since the late ’90s
column2: working under the name Wrest in one-man
column3: aggression-and-obsession outlets Lurker of Challice and Leviathan
column4: Whitehead had emerged as a pillar of black metal in the United States. He coupled severe misanthropy with idiosyncratic execution to create mesmerizing
column5: barbed records that sounded like little else. Epitomized by song titles like ""The History of Rape"" and lines like ""I will ruin your life... I will fuck you in the sun
column6: Whitehead made his name documenting evil ideas. But with 34 charges leveled against him
column7: it seemed that he had moved beyond simply detailing darkness and into enacting it. And that’s the guy that Decibel decided to put on its March 2015 cover
column8: his seven-month-old daughter Grail cradled in his arms and his new album
column9: Scar Sighted
column10: in promotional tow.

column1: The cover prompted
column2: of course
column3: a rush to judgment: Decibel was accused of rape apologetics
column4: trolling
column5: and using the prurient allure of a convicted felon to sell magazines and Orange Goblin flexi discs. Another
column6: more ridiculous subset accused Decibel of going soft by putting a kid on the cover
column7: since innocence isn’t metal or whatever. But defenders of Whitehead and the magazine—even Decibel managing editor Andrew Bonazelli—clamored to point out that 30 charges against Whitehead had been dismissed and that he’d been cleared of all but one of the remaining accusations. In what essentially served as an embarrassing advertorial for the issue
column8: Bonazelli told Metal Sucks that ""both [Whitehead] and Profound Lore label head Chris Bruni hotly dispute [that conviction]."" So what? Are convicted felons generally in the business of ""hotly endorsing"" their verdicts?

column1: But the real resonance of Whitehead and Grail as Madonna and Child is
column2: in fact
column3: a parable that does link up with heavy metal’s ethos. It’s the tale of the vanquished villain returning as the triumphant hero. Whether or not you ""hotly dispute"" Whitehead’s conviction or call his accuser a liar
column4: as many of his peers have
column5: the scenario turned his music into a morass. From its derisible name to its scattered mess of songs
column6: <i>True Traitor
column7: True Whore—released eight months after Whitehead’s arrest and nine months before his conviction—represented a new nadir in his vast catalogue. ""Things were very tenuous
column8: he confessed to Steel for Brains in an interview late last year
column9: ""and I wasted a lot of time being as drunk as possible during that period.""

column1: Since his conviction
column2: though
column3: he’s moved to Portland
column4: launched a new label and tattoo business with musician and new girlfriend Stevie Floyd
column5: and had Grail. The family has its own Instagram account and a new band. Once infamously churlish with the media
column6: Whitehead has been candid and even optimistic in recent interviews. ""Inspiration and energy-wise
column7: he again told Steel for Brains
column8: ""I feel like I’ve returned to a personal space where I can attempt to form what I hear in my head."" At least for now
column9: Whitehead seems to have salvaged his life—a heavy metal antagonist-turned-protagonist
column10: beating back the bedlam of his existence to push toward something like redemption.

column1: For the most part
column2: Scar Sighted holds up its end of that deal. As strange and surprising as anything Whitehead has ever made
column3: these 10 songs bristle with an exploratory energy that has long been his best (if rather inconsistent) asset. Though Whitehead has built his reputation as a nominal black metal player
column4: his music is more compelling when that serves as its aesthetic core and not its outward bound. Scar Sighted presses hard against that past. Using uproarious blitzes of black metal only as dynamic peaks or plateaus
column5: Whitehead commandeers the rest of the 64-minute record to create a stylistic phantasmagoria. Death and doom
column6: musique concrète and noise rock
column7: harsh noise and industrial sounds collide
column8: bending into each other to create lurid new shapes.

column1: Every few minutes
column2: Scar Sighted takes another turn
column3: but the moves rarely feel like detours here. In a 10-second window
column4: for instance
column5: ""Dawn Vibration"" pivots from a pneumatic black metal roar to a death metal stepdown to a bridge that sounds like a dying man screaming over a Nirvana demo tape. There’s momentum to the motion. Similarly
column6: the beautiful title track marches toward low-tempo oblivion
column7: ghoulish voices and creeping riffs haunting a funereal lurch. When Whitehead leaps suddenly into one of its most straightforward black metal spans
column8: the move feels only like another part of Leviathan’s current whole
column9: not the inchoate tangents emblematic of Whitehead’s recent letdowns.

column1: Perhaps the most important element of Scar Sighted is the sense that Whitehead is again controlling chaos
column2: rather than letting it control him. He is and has been something of a studio improviser
column3: using the space of a room and a recording to create unique documents. Paired with real-life instability
column4: that process has caused alternately brilliant and disastrous results. That carries over to an extent with Scar Sighted
column5: as parts of these tunes can sometimes feel formless or flatulent. But many of these tracks are thoughtfully layered
column6: so that you’re always peering through the melee to pick out the sound on the other side. ""A Veil Is Lifted"" is a stomping
column7: stentorian monster
column8: where a cavalcade of drums battles an army of guitars. But the rhythm fights against rumbles of alien bass and noise. In the background
column9: a fluorescent second guitar riff runs counter to the lead. As ""The Smoke of Their Torment"" rumbles ahead
column10: Whitehead slashes back and forth with counter-riffs that arrive at extreme angles
column11: not unlike Gorguts’ most dense successes. The song exits through an instrumental comedown
column12: where lumbering bass and discursive drums dance with Whitehead’s atonal guitar. Suddenly
column13: you remember that the guy briefly shared a band with Thurston Moore.

column1: Whitehead foregoes shock-value misogyny and tawdry invective here
column2: but he hasn’t softened. Instead
column3: Scar Sighted depends upon an apocalyptic worldview
column4: where extra effort is futile and ruins are all that’s promised. At the start of ""Within Thrall""
column5: a multi-tracked chorus of one sings about ""the death of the gloaming""; at the close of ""The Smoke of Their Torment""
column6: an extended reading from Revelation boasts of the wrath of god at the end of time. ""All our righteous arts are like filthy rags
column7: Whitehead bellows during the bridge of ""Gardens of Coprolite"". The song
column8: mind you
column9: is named for fossilized feces.

column1: It’s easiest to think about Whitehead and the last five-to-15 years of his life in reductive terms: For some
column2: he is a felon convicted of domestic abuse
column3: and he may never be anything more. For others
column4: he is a dark dude who was caught in a darker situation
column5: and he’s worked to build a new life and to renew his band. But the truth
column6: at least as suggested by Scar Sighted
column7: is something much more complex. It’s not a record of penance
column8: as it’s about as furious as Whitehead has ever been. But it’s not a record of provocation
column9: either
column10: where he’s calling names and making threats. It seems mostly like an imperfect but intriguing attempt to reorganize his life and reassert his craft
column11: to not right his wrongs but to not repeat them
column12:
either.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21453/homepage_large.07da51f9.jpg|Fight for Yourself|32719.0|Zex|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Magic Bullet']|2015-02-06 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:11.041205|"

Punk
column2: like many areas of popular and underground culture
column3: is in a '90s revival. Ottawa's Zex must feel real alien in this regard
column4: owing their vibe from punk's initial explosion in the late '70s and early '80s. <i>Fight for Yourself
column5: the band's full-length debut
column6: was self-released last fall
column7: but Magic Bullet picked it up for release this year. It's a collection of classic punk where the youth and energy of the band members—guitarist and primary songwriter Jo Capitalicide
column8: vocalist Gretchen Steel
column9: bassist Gab Sex
column10: and drummer Tasha G—belies unexpectedly experienced songwriting.

column1: Fight highlights a very important aspect of any punk's existence
column2: or any angsty music fan's existence
column3: really: You'll do almost anything to get away from your shitty hometown
column4: but where you came from will always be a part of you. This is propelled by the album's two strongest songs
column5: ""Wanderlust"" and ""Savage City""
column6: both of which appeared as singles prior to the album's release. ""Wanderlust"" sounds convincing with its streetwise playing
column7: but it's not just the band's performance that sets it apart. Capitalicide has expressed difficulty bringing punk and hardcore bands to Ottawa
column8: primarily because many groups see it as a blip between Toronto and Montreal. Getting out isn't just a desire
column9: it's a necessity. Zex tour frequently
column10: and are set to tour Southeast Asia
column11: Australia
column12: and New Zealand soon—their ""Wanderlust"" is certified. ""Savage"" closes out the album
column13: and it's a loving beating of their hometown. Steel
column14: in her most spirited performance on Fight
column15: sings about being stuck in a city that's hostile towards them
column16: comparing her and her bandmates to ""lab rats"" stuck in some cruel experiment. With backup vocals from Capitalicide and Sex in the chorus
column17: in an Oi style
column18: Zex treat hell like a celebration at a neighborhood pub.

column1: While heavily indebted to the forefathers of punk
column2: Zex also remember that the Ramones may have played loud
column3: fast
column4: and loose
column5: there was still some bubblegum in them. Capitalicide is known in metal circles for his work with Iron Dogs
column6: and while that group's NWOBHM style is somewhat present in Zex
column7: especially in the charging opening title track
column8: he lets out his poppy side on Fight. It's somewhat of a return to his street punk roots in Germ Attak
column9: though he's become a more capable songwriter here. ""Screaming at the Wall"" makes being voiceless sound like an exciting proposition
column10: the dread in Steel's voice serving as a foil for Capitalicide's bouncy guitar work. ""XXX"" is a catchy jam that conjures wandering through the red-light districts of Times Squares' distant past
column11: curiosity running rampant. Steel's confidence shines through
column12: but not without a menacing playfullness. The only moment Zex's pop flair backfires is on ""On Our Own""
column13: a sluggish song whose main crime is that it packs the least wallop out of the whole album. Capitalicide tries a little too hard to sound bubbly and comes out jagged. That it's just before a banger like ""Savage"" is all the more infuriating.

column1: Zex wear their influences on the sleeves of their studded jackets
column2: but show an upside to young people bowing down to retroism: Sometimes it's more exciting watching a band exert it all on stage and still have energy left for an all-night kegger than it is sitting through the peformance of a tired
column3: flabby group whose fire was extinguished not long after whenever ""back in the day"" was. Fight isn't perfect
column4: but Zex have a stronger grappling of presentation than their peers
column5:
or the many that came before them.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21411/homepage_large.fac82530.jpg|A Flourish and a Spoil|32695.0|The Districts|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Possum']|2015-02-06 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:11.552633|"

The Districts’ appeal lies in how you can call them a ""rock band"" and have a typically vague term mean something specific. Or
column2: maybe
column3: they’re a throwback to the last time ""rock band"" meant something. All four members are under 21 years old and they play bar-friendly rawk with the irreverence and impatience of kids who still have to get drunk in the parking lot
column4: replacing the classic rock and blues with mannish-boy punk vigor. They’re from Lititz
column5: Penn.
column6: a town whose closest metro area is Lancaster
column7: but they evoke New York in 2002
column8: which itself evoked New York during a non-specific time in the late-'70s; think ""Welcome to New York"" with Taylor Swift swapped out for Julian Casablancas and Hamilton Leithauser and Paul Banks
column9: a fantastical guided tour of art-damaged
column10: post-punk
column11: Koch-era NYC minus the clear and present danger. They’re a ""the + plural noun"" band. For those who felt the ""New Rock Revolution"" was exactly what its name promised rather than a revival of old aesthetics
column12: the Districts' A Flourish and a Spoil signifies a restoration of order. For everyone else who simply likes rock bands
column13: it's actually kinda quaint.

column1: They're hardly the only ones who fit this description
column2: but the Districts have significant advantages over their contemporaries. For one thing
column3: they leave something to the imagination. It’s rare for the Districts to hit a specific reference point; the chalkdust guitars and laggard tempo of ""Chlorine"" recall the magisterial mope of early Walkmen
column4: but otherwise
column5: A Flourish and a Spoil is the first half of the past decade in ""rock bands
column6: wadded up and spitballed. Rollicking opener ""4th & Roebling"" in particular establishes itself as the meeting point in a drunken Transatlantic exchange between the loose-lipped pub crawling of the Libertines and Arctic Monkeys and their more tight-jeaned American counterparts. And unlike
column7: say
column8: Drowners or Catfish and the Bottlemen
column9: Rob Grote doesn’t revert to flippant
column10: soft misogyny as the most effective way of conveying ""attitude.""

column1: Rather
column2: he’s someone just removed from high school and parental supervision
column3: grappling with how to live with one’s self and with another person. Grote’s subject matter is mostly what one might expect from a band of teens in a small town
column4: which is to say
column5: drinking
column6: girls and getting the fuck out of that town. Classicist imagery abounds: in ""4th & Roebling""
column7: he waits by a train station
column8: wine is drank
column9: used as metaphor and personified; ""Suburban Smell"" looks towards the high school gridiron as a spiritual void.

column1: In these songs
column2: the Districts’ youthful energy and belief manifests in effort—while the band trudges dutifully behind him
column3: Grote furrows his brow and intently scratches out his thoughts with the intent of giving everyday occurrences some true gravitas. Unfortunately
column4: his logorrhea muddles his perspective
column5: as the transition from feelings to lyrics lessens the impact of his words rather than deepening their resonance. Clichés are jumbled and reconstituted
column6: and in turn sound both banal and strained—""We’d crack mothers’ backs just by walking the street
column7: ""There are sixteen homes on every street/ They all of course lie in the neatest rows."" It’s a shame that Grote doesn’t trust the impact of observation; ""Bold"" is one of the few times he lets the situation speak for itself
column8: noting
column9: ""My brother’s not home/ He’s learning war in fatigues"" as a reflection on the triviality of his worries about the dishes and whether or not he’s capable of loving.

column1: Or
column2: the main issue with the Districts is that they just haven't found a way to channel their energy and ambition into memorable hooks. John Congleton produces and similar to his work on Cloud Nothings’ Here and Nowhere Else
column3: he stays out of the way
column4: capturing a raucous
column5: live-room sound. But whereas Dylan Baldi uses velocity and distortion to counterbalance his facility with songcraft
column6: plodding tempo
column7: wavering melody
column8: and gritted ambience is all the Districts have. The few bits of trickery show a band still unsure of itself in the studio—a wobbly flange effect on Grote’s vocals in ""Hounds"" and the puttering drum machines on ""Bold"" emphasize A Flourish and a Spoil's time-stamped experience by touching on Dave Fridmann’s obtrusive production work with the Flaming Lips and Phantom Planet.

column1: All of which makes ""Suburban Smell"" a purposeful outlier in a number of ways. It’s a brief acoustic number where Grote shows his age; he’s not the road dog or barfly in prior songs
column2: but rather the kid getting stoned in his basement while the rest of his class goes to parties and football games
column3: the sum of which he calls
column4: ""the retard dance."" It’s easy to call out Grote for lack of sensitivity. But while ""Suburban Smell"" may stink of piss and vinegar platitude
column5: it’s the rare time when you truly know where Grote’s coming from
column6:
where the Districts are a ""millennial"" band in age and disposition rather than ""millennial"" in simply sounding like they could’ve scored some MTV2 play at the turn of Y2K.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21360/homepage_large.4e4f04f5.jpg|Lost Themes|32608.0|John Carpenter|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2015-02-05 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:12.015345|"

Since his career began in the mid-1970s
column2: John Carpenter has been responsible for an admirable run of well-loved science fiction and horror films. Many of his features had low budgets but a lot of style. They were dark
column3: dystopian
column4: and violent (though seldom gory)
column5: with plots that glued together genre conventions drawn from westerns
column6: '50s monster flicks
column7: and exploitation cinema. His best movies—Halloween
column8: Escape From New York
column9: and Assault on Precinct 13
column10: to name a few—have transcended cult-classic status. For the type of people who read Fangoria magazine
column11: these are all-time hall-of-famers and required midnight movie viewing for virtually anybody else.

column1: In addition to writing and directing
column2: Carpenter also composed the scores for a number of his films. Working primarily with synthesizers
column3: he crafted minimalist music that perfectly matched the eerie vibe of his pictures. These scores have proven at least as influential as the films they accompanied. Over the years
column4: they have been studied by countless electronic musicians
column5: dance producers
column6: and general weirdos
column7: who continue to find inspiration in the director’s ability to marry mechanical orchestration and highly emotive melodies.

column1: Released by Sacred Bones
column2: Lost Themes is Carpenter’s first standalone record. It is not a collection of cues
column3: but a set of independent compositions that echo the sinister tones of the director’s film work. Each track is a sort of mini-score unto itself
column4: shuffling a theme through a variety of moods and variations. To call Lost Themes a John Carpenter solo album is a bit misleading
column5: though. The record is a collaborative effort that was casually jammed into existence by the director
column6: his son Cody (of the band Ludrium)
column7: and godson Daniel Davies. As a result
column8: if you’re coming to Lost Themes looking for the vintage Carpenter sound
column9: you will have to adjust your expectations a little.

column1: Horror and sci-fi films are where the techniques and sounds of 20th century avant-garde music—electronic composition
column2: tape music
column3: atonal harmonies—found practical use in the mainstream world. Dissonant sounds slot well into these kinds of stories because they effectively convey shock and alienation. And it doesn't hurt that they're easy to generate with minimal resources. All you really needed to start with was one long
column4: sustained
column5: eerie and suspense-generating minor chord.

column1: Carpenter's scores blended experimental ideas with simple but solid melodies. Having limited skills as a musician
column2: the director made innovative use of technology—mainly synthesizers and drum machines—to generate epic sounds on a thin budget. Most importantly
column3: he allowed synthesizers to sound like synthesizers
column4: rather than trying to pass them off as a budget orchestra. These warbly alien squiggles and pulsing bass tones imbued his melodies with a distinctively robotic touch.

column1: Because these machines were time consuming to set up and program
column2: the director had to adopt a spare style
column3: which he often put to brilliant use. Some scores
column4: like Carpenter's collaboration with composer Alan Howarth on Halloween III
column5: were composed on synthesizers as the film was being played back live
column6: which gave them a drifty and improvisatory feel. These instruments played a large role in Carpenter's aesthetic
column7: but he never seemed wedded to vintage gear. As the times changed
column8: so did his instrumentation
column9: and by the '90s
column10: Carpenter's scores had lost a bit of their grit and otherworldliness.

column1: Lost Themes was composed using the computer-based sequencing software Logic Pro
column2: and it sounds quite different from his analog synth-driven works. The keyboards are brighter and more video-gamey. On some songs
column3: this doesn’t matter so much. From its first piano tones
column4: ""Vortex"" is immediately recognizable as Carpenter’s work. If the director has a defining go-to gesture
column5: it’s the pulsing synthesized bass tone
column6: the beating of a single repeating note that provides a foundation for plaintive chords and hazy keyboard leads. It provides the bedrock for the Assault on Precinct 13 theme and also the soundtrack to Escape From New York. Fittingly
column7: it is the central ingredient on ""Vortex""
column8: which opens Lost Themes.

column1: Other times
column2: though
column3: the details seem more haphazard. In Lost Themes’ lesser moments—""Obsidian"" and ""Domain""—it sounds as if the pair are trying to evoke dread and awe using keyboard presets borrowed from Kraftwerk-goes-Christmas holiday electro ensemble
column4: Mannheim Steamroller.

column1: The main thing that’s missing
column2: though
column3: is a movie. Carpenter’s classic scores were filled with silence and space out of necessity. Film cues needed to stay simple and retain a consistent mood so as not to overpower the on-screen imagery
column4: which relieved a lot of the director’s music from the need for formal structure. Unshackled from that restraint
column5: Carpenter and his collaborators have created a set of recordings that are very ornate and dense. They shift moods frequently
column6: segueing between eerie drones and heavy rock. At times
column7: the album is a bit reminiscent of the Italian prog rock band
column8: Goblin
column9: who also composed horror film scores. This doesn’t make it bad
column10: but it does make it a very different kind of listen. And ultimately
column11: it's a less distinctive one. The eerie and empty vibe-outs that made up Carpenter scores like Halloween III and Prince of Darkness left a lot of room for imagination. They imparted scant information—just heavy atmosphere and mood that oozed out of the speakers like
column12: well
column13:
the fog from The Fog and ultimately seeded creativity and invention that had little to do with the films they were made to accompany. Lost Themes is plenty dark and heavy but shorter on inspiration.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21287/homepage_large.23cb8c88.jpg|COIN COIN Chapter Three: river run thee|31823.0|Matana Roberts|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Constellation']|2015-02-05 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:12.555795|"

By the time the 46 minutes of COIN COIN Chapter Three: river run thee end in a wash of synthesizer
column2: one verdict resounds long beyond the haze: It is no longer adequate to call the New York saxophonist Matana Roberts a mere musician. Roberts’ initial reputation indeed stemmed from her reed-based backstory; an improviser in Chicago who co-founded the bracing trio Sticks and Stones
column3: she eventually broadened her work through scrappy solo records and session musician work with the likes of TV on the Radio and Burnt Sugar.

column1: Her proper step toward the spotlight
column2: though
column3: arrived with the release of her last two albums
column4: or the first parts of a planned 12-record series dubbed COIN COIN. Intended as her personal and political exploration of African-American history
column5: the work would pivot between the country’s barbaric slave-trade roots
column6: the sustained suffering of Reconstruction
column7: the upheaval of the Civil Rights era
column8: and the country’s current climate of racial turmoil. She’d broach all of these topics
column9: sometimes within the same song. The idea seemed an audacious undertaking
column10: an epic that would either put Roberts in rarified visionary company or find her struggling near anonymity as she worked toward COIN COIN’s conclusion sometime around the start of this century’s second-third—or maybe both.

column1: The work began brilliantly
column2: with Roberts leading jazz ensembles large and small through tempestuous
column3: non-linear tales of hard truths. Slaves were bought and abused
column4: sold and insulted; mothers rescued children; a great diaspora scattered kin across corners of a new country. Roberts served as both anchor and motor. Using a technique she calls ""panoramic sound quilting
column5: she pushed both bands through intriguing hymns and choruses
column6: tangents and outbursts
column7: reading and screaming and singing as the music moved around her. But could she continue plundering the past with a sound that kowtowed to it for a full dozen records? Could the ""jazz musician"" take it that far?

column1: It seems now that she never intended to. river run thee
column2: the third installment
column3: is a seamless solo improvisation for a panoply of electronics
column4: a multitude of multi-tracked voices
column5: and a small coterie of saxophones. Something of a one-woman opera
column6: these 12 tracks plow through harsh noise passages and spring into sudden refrains
column7: drift through halcyon field recordings and float through harrowing spoken-word passages.

column1: As a whole
column2: the album examines the ways in which seemingly innocent objects—the oceans and the boats that traveled them centuries ago—fostered so much suffering that continues even now. (It is worth noting that
column3: for the past several months
column4: Roberts has lived on a houseboat in Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn
column5: writing about her experiences as if to reclaim that vestige of American infamy.) ""Oh
column6: why do we try so hard? All is written in the cards. The price rolls by the seaside
column7: Roberts sings in the intoxicating and traumatizing opener
column8: her cracking alto seeking redemption in spite of itself. The music reflects that maritime perspective: Oscillating tones and static swells are severe enough to induce seasickness. Roberts’ kinetic saxophone—and
column9: sometimes
column10: her voice
column11: too—must wade through an electronic din
column12: as though the sounds were a secret signal sent underwater.

column1: The process here is paramount. Working in the same Montreal studio she utilized for mixing the first two COIN COIN albums
column2: Roberts kept adding layers to the same batch of tapes
column3: responding in real-time to what she’d already recorded rather than using a computer to put tiny parts into a meticulous whole. She inserted fragments of American standards—the famous and infamous ""Star Spangled Banner""
column4: the soporific lullaby ""All the Pretty Horses""—and field recordings captured on a trek early last year through several benighted and/or proud burgs of the South. That semi-live approach elevates river run thee past the point of collage; there’s a momentum here that recalls
column5: for me
column6: the gusto of a great Aaron Dilloway set and a situational attentiveness that mirrors the close care of Pauline Oliveros. A solo noise-and-vocal record about history and built with folkloric and found texts might seem like an invitation to the obscure. But in part because of how it was made
column7: these 46 minutes are magnetic
column8: inescapable. I find myself wanting to see like Roberts sees
column9: to hear like she hears.

column1: To that end
column2: river run thee suggests that Roberts is her generation’s rejoinder to Laurie Anderson
column3: another wide-screen thinker who combined her instrument
column4: voice and tale with the sounds and stories of others to ask questions so large that easy answers might not be found. But where Anderson could feel cool and clinical
column5: Roberts takes care to be urgent and intimate. Though this set is a solo construction
column6: where only she speaks and sings and vamps with her saxophone and synthesizers
column7: it is absolutely not an interior map or a diary given sudden voice. Roberts instead pulls across generations and geographies
column8: so that the confessions of a slave-trader neighbor the convictions of Malcolm X and the sound of a lonely saxophone telling the news of the blues tangles with the screech of a subway car and a newborn baby crying. It’s hard not to think of Roberts driving through the South
column9: collecting and observing the experiences of others. In crossing theirs with her own
column10: her work becomes an overwhelming chorus instead of an isolated monologue. This suffering is not meant to exist in a vacuum.

column1: Late into river run thee
column2: during one of the album’s more placid moments
column3: Roberts declares
column4: ""I like to tell stories."" The admission might suggest an easy key to the world that Roberts is building with COIN COIN. But it seems too reductive
column5: really
column6: not unlike calling her a mere musician. She collects stories
column7: analyzes them
column8: and then transmogrifies them
column9: aggregating bits of material until anecdotes become open-ended
column10: elliptical histories. Roberts knows that any story
column11: just like jazz

The material that Noveller's Sarah Lipstate has recorded over the last half decade focuses on the power of small gestures. Consisting mostly of drones sourced from solo guitar
column2: her albums rely on deceptively dynamic elements that shift almost imperceptibly
column3: forcing you to engage with each guitar lead
column4: each swooning bass drone. On Fantastic Planet
column5: Lipstate's latest LP
column6: this detail-oriented approach is foregrounded for the first time
column7: allowing the pieces to breathe with a vibrancy that they hadn't been able to attain before. Even from the opening strains of the album's lead track
column8: ""Into the Dunes""
column9: all of the moving parts spring forth in total clarity. It's a striking moment
column10: given how often over her last couple of records she's been reliant on a sort of swooping sonic muck as her main songwriting tool. Her pitch-warped melodies bubble and coalesce into a creeping latticework of booming bass
column11: twitchy drones
column12: and slurred guitar leads. Each part is given distinct and clear weight within the mix
column13: making the moments when Lipstate unleashes something a little bigger that much more powerful.

column1: Lipstate moves from pointillist detail to hazy heaviness throughout Fantastic Planet
column2: but that contrast is most striking when the sounds she wrings from her Fender Jaguar don't obviously scan as guitar lines. Even since her days playing with the Brooklyn noise-rock experimenters Parts & Labor
column3: she's demonstrated an interest in conjuring atypical sounds from her instrument—early Noveller shows were even played with her guitar laid flat on a keyboard stand—but Fantastic Planet finds her pushing those boundaries more than ever.

column1: On tracks like ""Rubicon"" and ""The Ascent""
column2: among others
column3: Lipstate contorts her guitar parts into shimmering bands of sound that recall Oneohtrix Point Never's early synthesizer explorations as often as they do fellow spaced-out six-stringers like Delicate Steve. Since every layer is easy to isolate
column4: this becomes a particularly disorienting tactic; such instrumental confusion forces constant attention and searching through what are otherwise familiar-feeling ambient pieces. The more momentous passages
column5: as on the middle section of ""Pulse Point""
column6: start to feel a lot stranger when you can't quite pin the source of the sounds down.

column1: This has its drawbacks. As Lipstate so thoroughly focuses her pieces on details and deception
column2: she occasionally loses the forest for the trees. With such focus paid to each individual part
column3: ""Sisters"" and ""Growing"" display a tendency to let her fascination with the moving gears trump the narrative movement that marks her best material. But fortunately
column4: such moments are few and far between. Most of these compositions represent a newfound directness for Lipstate
column5: a willingness to present her strange experiments without feeling the need to obfuscate with the labyrinthine compositional exercises or guitar effects she used in the past. Hiding behind all of that was Fantastic Planet
column6:
a world just as alien and unsettling as the one depicted in the 1973 film the title alludes to.

column14: gangsta rap

column17: explicit
column18: often escapist
column19: and made do with the resources available
column20: and as such

column1: Last year’s Hardcore Traxx: Dance Mania Records 1986-1997

column4: and it arrived on the heels of Parris Mitchell and owner Ray Barney’s 2013 announcement of Dance Mania’s re-launch. (It shuttered gracefully in 2001; the label’s commitment to musical risk-taking had always relied on the financial success of its primary role as a record distribution hub
column5: a foundation that crumbled in the late '90s as the independent retailers it serviced began to disappear.) That compilation focused on the label’s most essential tracks
column6: documenting straightforward but formative early work like Hercules’ 1986 ""7 Ways""
column7: the label’s second-ever pressing
column8: as it grew leaner
column9: rawer
column10: and lewder by way of flirtation with acid
column11: hip-hop
column12: and techno. These are records that never crossed over into the mainstream in any significant sense (beyond the errant Daft Punk shout-out) but often sell for thousands of dollars on Discogs today
column13: thanks to a recent surge in popularity among primarily European collectors. It’s a familiar paradox for Rust Belt dance music innovators looking to keep their legacy alive: if financial viability is at all a priority

column4: homes in on subtler
column5: deeper-digging gems in the label’s sprawling catalog. Where Hardcore Traxx gave special attention to ghetto house’s formative years

column7: by which point the label had found its niche and dug deep
column8: its dogged prolificacy speeding up to match the steadily increasing BPMs. The tracks are brittle

column1: From a strictly commercial standpoint

column4: house’s most visible torchbearers in 2015 are
column5: for the most part
column6: precocious

column8: some have wondered if house still matters in its hometown of Chicago. But doubting the movement’s persistent relevance in its hometown ignores a fundamental truth: House never left Chicago
column9: it simply changed forms. Steadily evolving over its three decades of existence

column11: motivational hip-house
column12: warp-speed juke
column13: and abstracted footwork. The legacy of Dance Mania’s insouciant
column14:
trail-blazing ghetto house is preserved in the city’s flourishing juke and footwork communities as much as it lives on through the label’s second life; Ghetto Madness is just a reminder.
