In recent years
column2: Oakland-based singer/songwriter and one-man indie rock chamber orchestra William Ryan Fritch has been recording more music than your favorite mixtape rapper. Last spring
column3: he began releasing a collection of 110+ songs in a fashion that is as decadent as the contained music itself: through an ongoing subscription service. Revisionist is intended as the culmination of the series
column4: and high rollers receive it on 140-gram vinyl inside a book of paintings. The ballads that make up the album are equal parts melancholic
column5: Americana-flavored pop and percolating

column7: Fritch’s album could have reasonably been made during this period.

column1: Fritch’s chief musical preoccupation is dissonance—not in regards to notes and harmonies
column2: but to quality of sound. Much as synth devotees painstakingly shape sine waves

column4: rolling piano chords

column6: Fritch seems to visualize structure horizontally rather than vertically

column8: rather than focus on carefully building individual moments in succession.

column2: by integrating them into non-descript song structures. The songs on the album spend a lot of time seesawing between two or three chords
column3: which are squeezed for all attendant drama as they would be in a post-rock coda. The songwriting feels underdone; a side note instead of a focal point. A few striking ideas emerge
column4: such as the catchy vocal motif in the hazy
column5: timpani-punctuated pastorale ""Unholy Frames"". Fritch’s periodic field-holler chorale harmonies (see the shoegaze-inflected
column6: Benoît Pioulard-produced ""Winds"" and funereal waltz ""Imposters"") are attractive
column7: but they are not always forceful enough to disguise the basic formlessness of the melodies they embellish.

column1: Revisionist doesn't feel like a grand summary of Fritch’s project; in fact
column2: it’s less alluring than some of the earlier
column3: more cacophonous offerings in the series (see last April’s Emptied Animal). On those tracks
column4: his vocals function more as an equal part of the overall sheen
column5: or aren’t there at all. ""Revising""
column6: in the new album’s libretto
column7: refers to trying to reimagine
column8: or even lie to one’s self about the past. ""Remain[ing] weightless and refus[ing] to be ashamed

column10:
without leaving time to reflect or regret.

column9: for Elverum

column1: Like Clear Moon and Ocean Roar

column10: and the light from the coals."" The song rolls on for 10 minutes
column11: a luxurious stretch of drone rock as thick and murky as the lyrics are clear: ""My life is a small fire I carry around

His lyrics are riddled with everyday actions: ""I walked to the bookstore in the rain that silently filled the air/ All the lights were off or dim/ And there was nothing to do but walk to town and back

column1: As always

As the de facto leader of the collective Phantom Posse
column2: New York-based multi-instrumentalist Eric Littmann (whose solo project Phantom Power gives the group its name) has overseen several low-key collections of hazy electro-pop. But in the year and change since the group's last set
column3: one of the musicians in the orbit of the amorphous crew has seen his profile raised substantially. On the strength of a Drake remix and a well-received EP of similarly blunted ballads
column4: iLoveMakonnen was one of rap radio's strangest successes in 2014. But while he was working with the likes of Mike WiLL Made It and Sonny Digital

column1: While the Makonnen connection is the most likely entry point to the record
column2: his contributions are only a small part of what's going here. Each contributor brings something uniquely warped to the LP's seasick atmosphere

column7: winks
column8: and smirks. Throughout the record

column6: urban disaffection (""Come to Chicago"")

column1: The emotional range of Phantom Posse is evident in the solo work of the constituent members (Littmann pens self-serious love songs under the jokey moniker Steve Sobs and Makonnen has been known to pair even his most heartfelt ballads with Andy Milonakis videos)

and Home succeeds in crafting a delightfully dizzying headspace out of that divide. It can be tricky to handle serious subjects with a smile and Littmann's crew keeps getting better. It's only a surreal bonus that an internationally famous rapper had a hand in its construction.

With a career that’s almost passed the two-decade mark

column3: Tejada made the jump to Kompakt in 2011. The collaboration spoke to his influence as a dependable underground producer and it led to the excellent Parabolas

column5: textural techno

column10: left without its repetitive chord structure

column3: Thomas Fehlmann

Signs Under Test is a strong entry that proves Tejada's quietly building up a legacy of excellence.

column19: which revamps the frivolously folky Neil Young standard into a phantasmagoric tropical fantasia that feels like riding through It’s a Small World at Disney World after downing a bowl of ayahuasca.

column1: Flyaway Garden makes an airtight case for Breakfast in Fur’s atmospheric allure and mastery of mood
column2: though
column3: with the album clocking in at a tidy 36 minutes
column4: it’s more a collection of beautifully sculpted building blocks than a holistic grand design. A handful of the tracks—like the whirring rave-up ""Aurora Falls""
column5: the Pure Phase-d ""Whisper""
column6: and the dewy-eyed ""Sun Catcher""—feel less like standalone songs than carefully plotted ascents to as-yet unconquered peaks; by contrast
column7: the yearning melancholy of ""Episode"" shows what an affecting singer Van Pelt can be when she’s entrusted with a song that allows her to do more than just coo pretty chorales
column8: while Wolfe’s wiry standout ""Setting Stone"" presents a snapshot of what this band is capable of when it matches its lofty sonic ambitions with nervy intensity. The name Breakfast in Fur can denote both the obscene luxury of 1 percenters who can afford to get a little hollandaise on their mink stole
column9: or the primitive
column10:
survivalist instincts of off-the-grid cave dwellers; the wonderful thing about Flyaway Garden’s agrarian psychedelia is that it makes both parties feel at home.

If you’ve ever stayed up to an ungodly hour searching YouTube for the weirdest available Internet—like this masked man drinking a can of malt liquor during a hurricane—you’re likely to understand the music of Sean Schuster-Craig
column2: alias Jib Kidder

column4: and you see that Schuster-Craig approaches music as cosmophage
column5: chewing up his influences—Atlanta rap
column6: Animal Collective
column7: AM radio—into raw material for a blank canvas dripping with the excess of these ideas. His new album
column8: Teaspoon to the Ocean
column9: is his debut for Domino imprint Weird World
column10: and represents a formal attempt to surface from the deep web into a small corner of the music world.

column1: Teaspoon is an album in perpetual slide
column2: an egg cracked on the pan and swished around. What I remembered most was the pulsing bass line on ""World of Machines""
column3: which is bathed in pops and clicks like a field recording from the unconscious. On songs with some percussive momentum
column4: like ""Remove a Tooth"" and ""Dozens""
column5: there’s a wobbly element to his guitar tone that emulates the precarious feeling of riding a boat on shaky waters without trying to tip over. He sings like one of those text-to-speech processors
column6: his cadence all cracked and warbled. The songs and ideas within lap over one another like the waves Schuster-Craig sings about on ""The Waves""
column7: which is interrupted midway through by a saxophone solo that leaps out like the Kool-Aid Man bursting through a wall.

column1: ""I love all adhesives: the tidy boogers of rubber cement
column2: the matte haze of Elmer's
column3: the puffy fungus of Gorilla Glue
column4: he told Dazed when asked about the importance of collage to his music. His songs are preoccupied with hazy
column5: uncertain sentiments represented by phrases that sound like they’ve been assembled through one of those magnetic poetry kits you slap on your refrigerator. Aside from a handful of vocal spots from Julia Holter and contributions on electric piano from Zach Phillips
column6: Teaspoon to the Ocean is a self-produced album—Schuster-Craig does it all on every track. The brightest moments sell him as an auteur with something to say; the worst make it sound like he's just dicking around.

column1: The result is a little absent-minded
column2: with the difference split between gleeful assertion and wanton noodling
column3: the type of album that might sound best when you’re thinking about something else. This is partly by design
column4: it seems; ""I prefer art to assume the form of dreams
column5: Schuster-Craig writes in his bio. ""Dreams have their own rules
column6: and I use these as rules of form."" So is it criticism or compliment to say that
column7: like most dreams
column8: Teaspoon to the Ocean fades to a blurry impression? Elsewhere in that Dazed interview
column9: he said he likes to work with ideas he doesn’t fully understand. ""It's a kind of hunting
column10: to try and force a world together and then find the most alive thing in it and capture it
column11:
he said. Consider this a sign post on the path toward some more fertile destination in the world he's created.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21457/homepage_large.bf1abcf1.jpg|Shadows in the Night|1177.0|Bob Dylan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2015-02-03 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:19.347073|"

Is Bob Dylan trolling us? His 36th studio album
column2: Shadows in the Night
column3: is a collection of old jazz crooner standards most closely associated with Frank Sinatra. It’s an idea seemingly as weird as his phlegmy Christmas album or his leering Victoria’s Secret ad. In the '60s
column4: Sinatra was arguably for squares; entrenched in Vegas and disdainful of rock'n'roll (which he had called ""the most brutal
column5: ugly
column6: desperate
column7: vicious form of expression it has been my misfortune to hear"")
column8: he represented the establishment against which the counterculture was kicking
column9: and that made him a kind of anti-Dylan. And then there’s the fact that crooning is all about the voice—making it smooth yet expressive
column10: agile yet graceful. Just as Dylan’s songwriting exploded the notion of the tightly structured pop tune
column11: his voice has roundly rejected the notion that pop singers must sound pretty.

column1: While it may prompt some exasperated debates
column2: Dylan has in fact been teasing this project for years
column3: if not decades. A few of the songs on Shadows in the Night have appeared sporadically in his setlists since the 1990s
column4: and in his 2004 memoir
column5: <i>Chronicles
column6: Volume One
column7: Dylan even professed his fandom for the Chairman of the Board
column8: even if he subtly admitted that the crooner wasn’t exactly a popular figure among the folkies in the Village: ""When Frank sang [""Ebb Tide""]
column9: I could hear everything in his voice—death
column10: God and the universe
column11: everything. I had other things to do
column12: though
column13: and I couldn’t be listening to that stuff much.""

column1: In other words
column2: Shadows in the Night represents a lifelong appreciation for Sinatra
column3: but more than that
column4: Dylan is toasting a very specific era in pop songwriting. He’s not interested in aping the man’s vocal style (which would be laughable) or retreading his signature tunes (which would be redundant). There’s no ""Strangers in the Night"" or ""My Way"" on here
column5: nor is there a single dooby-dooby-doo. Instead
column6: Dylan digs deep
column7: picking personal favorites rather than obvious hits. ""Some Enchanted Evening"" and ""That Lucky Old Sun"" may be familiar to many listeners
column8: but others
column9: like ""Stay With Me"" and ""Where Are You?"" are more obscure
column10: which allows Dylan to put his stamp on them without sounding like he’s falling back on that late-career cliché: the standards album.

column1: Rather than mimic the robust orchestral arrangements that define Sinatra’s catalog
column2: Dylan strips these songs down considerably. According to a statement on his website
column3: he’s not covering them
column4: but ""uncovering"" them: ""Lifting them out of the grave and bringing them into the light of day."" There are some gentle horn charts on ""The Night We Called It a Day""
column5: but they’re generally unobtrusive
column6: included less for dramatic effect and more for simple ambience. His small band accompanies him sensitively and sympathetically
column7: often playing so quietly that it sounds like Dylan is singing a cappella. The lead instrument here is Donny Herron’s pedal steel
column8: which is so crucial to the album’s moonlit ambience that it might as well hang the stars from the night sky.

column1: And what do you know
column2: Dylan can actually sing. Without sounding overly reverent
column3: he croons persuasively
column4: especially on ""Why Try to Change Me Now"". That song
column5: recorded by Sinatra in 1959 for his album No One Cares
column6: resonates powerfully on Shadows in the Night
column7: with a performance so assured you might think Dylan wrote it himself. And perhaps that’s why Dylan gravitates to these tunes. Never the most confessional songwriter—he dodges more than he professes—he has remained guarded about his inner life
column8: making him both the most studied songwriter of the rock era and also the least known. But ""Why Try to Change Me Now"" may be one of the most revealing tunes he has sung in the twentieth century
column9: allowing him to settle into the role of the lovable curmudgeon
column10: a man who understands he’s a mess but is too old to change. It’s the best reason he’s given for recording this album.

column1: Because these songs seemingly reveal some new facets of Dylan’s character and celebrity
column2: they comprise a fascinating and conceptually rich object whose meaning will be debated and dissected for years to come. In particular Shadows in the Night asks us to hear these crooner anthems as folk tunes
column3: as though Sinatra was Seeger with a tux and a stint at the Sands. While ignoring social or political dilemmas
column4: they speak to certain emotional conundrums common to everyone: how to live with love and heartbreak
column5: how to survive on whimsy and regret. Trying to explain the nature of attraction on ""Some Enchanted Evening""
column6: Dylan offers a sly wink as he sings
column7: ""Fools offer reasons
column8: wise men never try."" Especially in such a popular tune
column9: the line takes on fresh gravity in the context of Dylan’s career
column10: as though he could be quoting one of his own songs.

column1: And yet.
Shadows in the Night may pose some compelling questions for the Bobophiles who scrutinize every line and every word of every Dylan song
column2: but for the more casual
column3: less obsessive listener
column4: it can be a bit of a snooze. The songs are well chosen and certainly revealing
column5: but Dylan and his band play them all pretty much the same
column6: sacrificing any sense of rhythm for stately ambience. Once they strike a mood on opener ""I’m a Fool to Want You""
column7: they never stray from it. That gives Shadows a distinctive identity in Dylan’s catalog
column8: but it also has a leveling effect. Each song hits the same tempo and strikes the same tone
column9: so that swoon quickly turns somnambulant. As the album progresses
column10: the songs sound more and more emotionally muted
column11: as though this style of American pop songwriting was good only for providing ruminative ambience rather than sophisticated humor
column12: feisty insight
column13: or infectious rhythm. Say what you want about Sinatra
column14:
but at least the man could swing.

One of the longest shadows in hip-hop is cast by a 14-month stretch from September '93 through November '94. Arguably the last and finest run of hip-hop's golden age
column3: this period is bookended by the releases of De La Soul's alt-rap classic Buhloone Mindstate and Redman's surreal
column4: grimy Dare Iz a Darkside—and encompasses so many distinctly earth-shaking individual statements it's almost beyond belief. Midnight Marauders
column5: Enter the Wu-Tang
column6: Illmatic
column7: Ready to Die
column8: Doggystyle
column9: The Diary
column10: Hard to Earn
column11: Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik
column12: Resurrection—even the stuff that hasn't crossed over to the same extent
column13: like Black Moon's Enta da Stage or O.C.'s Word…Life or Del the Funky Homosapien's No Need for Alarm
column14: reign as certified classics
column15: each with their own stories to tell and unique elements that made them stand out in rap's busiest creative flourish of the coming-of-age '90s.

column1: As profiles and reviews have regularly pointed out
column2: Joey Bada$$ wasn't alive for any of these albums' release dates. That's not really the issue here
column3: though it's easy to draw conclusions from that fact; when the weight of influence an artist carries has the additional weight of history piled on
column4: that can't be good for the backbone. But as his career has developed
column5: from the claim-staking mixtape 1999 to the moody regrouping effort Summer Knights to a litany of guest verses (A$AP Rocky's ""1 Train""; the remix of Madgibbs' ""Knicks"")
column6: he still hasn't strayed far from that two-decades-past area of influence
column7: a narrow purview that's resulted in some fine mood music but little that's been transcendent or reinventive. Official debut B4.DA.$$ keeps that frustrating formula going.

column1: And make no mistake
column2: B4.DA.$$ is a case of squandered resources rather than some expected mediocrity inoffensively met. It sets a compelling mood well—a restless-youth disbelief in actually making it
column3: even when all the evidence is laid out in front of him
column4: until finally the cloud cover breaks and it all starts registering. (One of his most unguarded moments of cynicism-shaking excitement comes at the end of ""Piece of Mind"": A jailed friend admits that he caught Joey's new single on the radio and Joey's reaction—""oh
column5: you heard that shit!""—is pure
column6: hard-earned pride.) And even at their most obvious
column7: the beats nail that East Coast melancholy winter sensation
column8: whether coming from vets of the era Joey nods back to (DJ Premier on ""Paper Trail$""; a Roots/Dilla reconstruction on ""Like Me"") or Pro Era hands like Kirk Knight (""Big Dusty""; ""Hazeus View"") and Chuck Strangers (""Escape 120""; ""Black Beetles""). Some of the homages are blatant to the point of distracting; if you can hear Statik Selektah's beat for ""No. 99"" and not scoff at the idea of putting a Canal Street ""Scenario"" knockoff in the middle of an otherwise moody album
column9: I envy your reserve. But the heavy traditional soul-jazz/boom-bap backing is at least well-executed
column10: and the occasional shakeup via drum'n'bass-adjacent uptempo breaks (""Escape 120""; bonus track ""Teach Me"") is welcome. You could do far worse than to pick this record up for meditative late nights or bad-weather commutes
column11: where it's best to just zone out and let the vibe sneak up on you.

column1: But the catch for an MC aiming his sights at the pantheon of stylistic greatness circa '93-'94 is that the people who appreciate that music the most—especially the people who came of age with it as their soundtrack when that shit was new—are also the least forgiving when it comes to lyrical complacency. And with a voice and a flow barely distinct enough to be instantly recognizable just yet
column2: there's no margin of error for Joey here. There aren't enough intricate lines to make up for the ones so flatly familiar they feel like placeholders: check one-verser ""Christ Conscious"" and its opening-line ""Motherfuckin' microphone checker/ Keep that grip tight
column3: like my Smith & Wesson"" couplet
column4: then realize that there's still Namedrop 101 references to Ike Turner
column5: ""Dragon Ball""
column6: and Thriller-era Michael on the way. There aren't enough unexpected detours to compensate for the constant quasi-iconoclastic invocations of other artists' well-known hooks
column7: with ""Paper Trail$"" and its nuance-draining ""Cash ruined everything around me"" maybe the most egregious. And most disappointing of all
column8: there's not enough spark to the rhymes to excuse the goofy metaphors (""Hazeus View"": ""I'm a titan
column9: like Zeus I enlighten 'em/ Kick flows till it's kung fu fightin' 'em""). He's still relatively young
column10: but Joey's experienced enough worth sharing that it feels like his words are inadequate to even cover its scope.

column1: And that's what separates albums like this from records you just kind of shrug at and move on from. Joey's less than a month into his twenties and he's already lost a close friend in Capital STEEZ
column2: is trying to figure out his place in the rap world (and the rest of the world) under a social media microscope
column3: and has to live up to being the type of new-hope torch-carrier who can get friggin' Primo to do a beat for him. Through all of this
column4: he still has to develop and evolve
column5: in public
column6: after already setting a precedent for himself as an ambassador for the aesthetic of a previous
column7: endlessly revered and long-lamented era. That he can hint at who he really is beneath the simplistic words and still-developing voice is a good sign
column8: and with the opportunity to vent on this record—dealing with money woes (""Paper Trail$"")
column9: strengthening familial ties (""Curry Chicken"")
column10: reflecting on a childhood he's growing out of yet still strongly shaped by (""O.C.B.""
column11: short for ""only child blues"")—he's gradually but noticeably building up a real identity on record. But if that next level's within reach
column12:
there has to be one obstacle to overcome: Firsthand truths take longer to sink in when they're delivered with secondhand styles.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21376/homepage_large.0e9e1c01.jpg|Depersonalisation|32681.0|Nite Fields|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Felte']|2015-02-03 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:20.675358|"

At some point in the mid-'90s—right about the same time that Marilyn Manson became the style icon of choice for teens looking for new ways to horrify their parents—the concept of ""goth"" started to get a bad rap. For those of us who grew up discretely smoking clove cigarettes while listening to Cocteau Twins and Dead Can Dance records in the '80s
column2: seeing goth culture hijacked by the likes of Hot Topic and Korn was something more tragic than Rozz Williams’ suicide. It was the death of an aesthetic. Goth became
column3: for all intents and purposes
column4: a pejorative.

column1: So it’s with no small sense of gratitude that
column2: in recent years
column3: aging goths such as myself have seen a slew of young bands (Trust
column4: the Horrors
column5: Zola Jesus) exploring the genre’s spidery
column6: tear-stained roots. Such is the case with Australia’s Nite Fields
column7: a four-piece band whose full-length debut
column8: the somber Depersonalisation
column9: could almost pass for a long-lost Lonely Is an Eyesore-era 4AD compilation from the late '80s. That the record so thoroughly mimics its forbears—imagine a nearly seamless union of vintage New Order (when they still leaned more heavily on guitars than synths)
column10: Clan of Xymox
column11: and early Cure—is both a blessing and a curse. Depersonalisation plays with a kind of intense familiarity that goes down so easily that the record seems to end before it even gets started—like a fog that rolls through the room and evaporates before you realize it was there. Clocking in at 35 minutes
column12: the nine songs (two of which are instrumental) are both beautiful and slight
column13: which in this case turns out to be the perfect combination.

column1: Aligning dark atmospherics with a basic rock setup
column2: Depersonalisation is a thing of mostly spectral simplicity. Front man Danny Venzin’s voice hovers somewhere in the range of ghostly baritone
column3: which lends standout tracks like ""Fill the Void"" and ""Hell Happy"" a perfect
column4: deathly glamour. ""You want to whip the heart from my inside/ take away the beat
column5: he intones on ""Prescription""—a track that boasts guitar lines that would have made both Peter Hook and Robert Smith cry envious tears of blood at some point in 1983. It’s also a song that strongly puts forth the record’s most pervasive themes—disassociation
column6: dissipation
column7: disappointment
column8: evaporation—all of which are echoed in the record’s consistently moribund lyrics: ""I go out in the night/ Nothing happens but nothing’s something.""

column1: Given the perfectly considered aesthetic of Depersonalisation
column2: it’s not surprising that the band’s front man also runs a record label (Brisbane’s Lost Race
column3: specializing in ""Unpopular Music from Australia"") or that the band cites ""Michael Hutchence on a rope"" as an influence on their Facebook page. They may be unrepentantly moody
column4: but they are not entirely humorless. The way in which Nite Fields melds nihilist post-punk with Cocteau-friendly shoegaze vibes indicates a coterie of musicians who have likely spent a lifetime absorbing old Dif Juz and This Mortal Coil records. Nowhere is this fascination more evident than album closer ""Winter’s Gone""—a seven-minute moodscape that unspools some serious The Moon and the Melodies-style Harold Budd/Robin Guthrie guitar ripples (complete with underwater saxophone squalls) that one wishes could go on for approximately forever. For those who grew up worshipping at the altar of such ephemeral sounds
column5: a record like Depersonalisation is a welcome bit of gloom
column6:
even if it ultimately feels like a record you probably already own.

If you had to force a standard narrative on Obnox
column2: the solo project of Cleveland’s Lamont ""Bim"" Thomas
column3: it might go something like this: prolific
column4: lo-fi one-man band steps into a proper studio to make his most accessible and acclaimed album—last year’s wide-ranging
column5: hard-hitting Louder Space—and must grapple with how to follow that peak. The problem with that story is that Thomas isn’t much of a grappler when it comes to making records. Boogalou Reed
column6: released less than a year after Louder Space
column7: finds him still cockily speeding along
column8: cranking out high-octane
column9: hip-hop-influenced garage rock like it’s a spiritual calling.

column1: Even if Thomas is a song-making factory
column2: Boogalou Reed sounds nothing like an assembly line. In contrast to Louder Space—his first full-on exploration of his rap leanings—this is more of a straight-up garage-punk album
column3: filled with hyper-fuzz guitars
column4: stomping beats
column5: and snarling vocals. That’s reflected in some of Thomas’s rock-history-sniffing song titles: ""Cynthia Piper at the Gates of Dawn""
column6: ""Too Punk Shakur""
column7: the title track. Judged solely on the scale of how hard it rocks
column8: Boogalou Reed is a head-rinsing success.

column1: But Thomas has been at his craft too long to settle for anything that simple. He knows the value of head-down rock action
column2: but he also knows how to layer that with something more complex. Most of these 15 tracks are miles-deep sonically
column3: with guitars piled high
column4: beats thickened into gunshots
column5: and vocals that morph hip-hop fire with punk frenzy. The result is just as varied—albeit in a sneakier way—as Louder Space. Blink and you might miss the twists and turns
column6: as Thomas dives into sultry noise-R&B (""Situation"")
column7: stoner grunge (""Protopipe"")
column8: rap-metal (""Watching You"")
column9: organ-driven '60s rock (""Empire"")
column10: and even a demolishing cover of ""Ohio"" that beats Neil Young at his own guitar-growl game.

column1: What glues all these sides of Obnox together is the way Thomas infects every moment with electricity. The lightning-bolt energy that courses through Boogalou Reed’s 15 tracks is a kind of genre of its own
column2: a sonic signature that Thomas can fit many styles into without losing the mark of his bold handwriting. As he put it recently
column3: ""White cats can get into it. Hip-hop niggas can get into it. Punks can get into it. Indie rock dude
column4: he’s already in. Noiseheads. It’s all in there."" Yet none of those categories takes over; you never get the sense that Thomas is trying on costumes or speaking a second language. His supreme confidence steamrolls any worries of dilettantism.

column1: Steamrolling is basically Thomas’ job now. Since launching Obnox after years spent in some of Ohio’s best garage bands
column2: he’s slammed forward with all the force of a smoke-blowing engine. (He’s already got another record on the way soon
column3: a ""punk rock concept album"" called Know America about taking over a radio station.) But that steamroller metaphor doesn’t catch how Thomas’ music is as subtle as it is pummeling. His business is all about charging forward
column4:
but his art is about more than just the moment.

"|20168.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20168-boogalou-reed/|7.8|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21461/homepage_large.0ce505c5.jpg|Big Dark Love|4820.0|Murder by Death|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bloodshot']|2015-02-03 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:22.233785|"

Like most of the songs on Murder by Death’s seventh studio album
column2: ""The Last Thing"" follows a character as he tiptoes along the line between life and death. Details are always tantalizingly scant in Adam Turla's lyrics
column3: but the narrator seems to have decided that he would rather embrace darkness and death than burden his loved ones any longer. ""I just don’t want to be another chore
column4: some wounded bird to care for
column5: he sings over a manically strummed guitar
column6: a rambling banjo
column7: and a live-wire bass. The song is more about epiphany than action
column8: yet the music is a flurry of commotion: not downbeat but quick-paced
column9: not resigned but unburdened and celebratory. Turla sings excitedly
column10: as though professing love rather than suicide
column11: and Sarah Balliet delivers a cello solo that’s scratchy and energetic
column12: yet also inscrutable. Her playing is almost scolding
column13: perhaps even taunting
column14: as though there is more to the situation than the narrator is telling us.

column1: For fifteen years these two elements—Turla’s husky voice and Balliet’s tectonic cello—have formed the foundation of Murder by Death’s dark country gothic sound
column2: coloring their tales of thwarted lust and grim violence as they fashion a new mythology form the southern Indiana soil. Those two founding members have provided the band’s most distinctive sounds
column3: and their musical conflict—they play against each other as often as they play with each other—has fortified even their weaker material and distinguished them from the hordes of other country-leaning groups that have come and gone in the twenty-first century.

column1: Their early albums
column2: especially <i>Like the Exorcist
column3: but More Breakdancing
column4: possessed a dark humor and raw energy
column5: as though the band had crossed the police tape to record at the actual scene of the crime. As Murder by Death has progressed—as they have shed and gained new members
column6: as they have relocated from Bloomington to Louisville—they have grown bigger in their sound and brasher in their arrangements
column7: incorporating more and more instruments with each album. Big Dark Love bustles with soundtrack keyboards
column8: sequencers that could be held together with rusty barbed wire
column9: and a mandolin that sounds like a jackhammer. Opener ""I Shot an Arrow"" thrums on a dated drum loop
column10: while ""Solitary One"" features a horn line that may be playing at gunpoint.

column1: In other words
column2: this is Murder by Death’s most ambitious album to date
column3: yet it is also their least weird
column4: their most crowded
column5: and arguably their most inconsequential. Recorded with co-producer Kevin Ratterman (Flaming Lips
column6: fellow Louisvillains Houndmouth) and mixed by John Congleton (St. Vincent
column7: Angel Olsen)
column8: Big Dark Love buffs away the band’s rougher edges
column9: including relegating Balliet’s cello from lead to supporting role. Instead
column10: they resort routinely to dramatic choruses and rousing crescendos
column11: as though trying to persuade us of the bigness and the darkness of these characters’ conflicts. Too often
column12: however
column13: its sound has just the opposite effect: The arrangements distract from the stories rather than bolster them

column1: This is a drier

When Hiss Golden Messenger made their network television debut back in November
column2: David Letterman introduced the band as a duo
column3: but what appeared onstage looked more like a collective: a double-digit lineup that included bass
column4: guitar
column5: back-up singers
column6: a bass sax
column7: brass
column8: and a particularly excitable drummer. The group’s membership has always been in flux: It began life as a duo (M.C. Taylor and Scott Hirsch)
column9: then shrank to a solo project
column10: then ballooned into a full band. With Paul Shaffer playing along
column11: the new line-up turned ""Southern Grammar"" into something similarly unrecognizable. On last year’s Lateness of Dancers it was a languid number
column12: with a laidback tempo and a wistful ambience that hid darker depths. On Letterman’s stage
column13: however
column14: the song got up out of its rocker and danced in the yard. The band goosed that mathematical guitar riff to make it sound spiky and insistent
column15: transforming the song from an interior monologue into an extroverted Southern rocker. It’s a testament to the mutability of Taylor’s songwriting that ""Southern Grammar"" can sound so remarkably different with just a few tweaks
column16: but the song supports both interpretations: the nodding reverie and the waking celebration.

column1: The live version that anchors Hiss Golden Messenger’s new EP is not the Letterman performance
column2: but a similar recording from WXPN in Philadelphia that features yet another lineup. The band’s touring roster includes Hirsch
column3: Phil Cook of Megafaun
column4: Matt McCaughan of Bon Iver
column5: Alexandra Sauser-Monnig of Mountain Man
column6: and saxophonist Matt Douglas of the Small Ponds. Playing loosely
column7: they quickly establish a stuttering groove that’s ultimately more Allmans than Appalachian. The sax is crucial: When the song opens
column8: Douglas plays that riff just behind the beat
column9: ghosting Taylor’s guitar and making the song crackle precariously
column10: opening it up in a way that belies its cry for simplicity. This take on ""Southern Grammar"" may not be quite as startlingly exclamatory as the television version
column11: but the band sounds grittier
column12: more animated
column13: more volatile than you might expect.

column1: Southern Grammar
column2: however
column3: is not a rousing live EP
column4: as its title track might suggest; instead
column5: the remaining two songs are studio-bound and downtempo—the band at its most contemplative. ""He Wrote the Book"" may be the most Bible-bound song Taylor has written
column6: which is saying a lot. Especially after ""Grammar""
column7: the pace plods
column8: but the arrangement is gently lush
column9: founded on a churchly piano
column10: a rattling snare
column11: and a gathering of reeds that transforms this sunny Sunday morning hymn into a slow-burn soul number. It conveys the contentment that comes at the end of a long journey
column12: yet the next song
column13: ""Brother
column14: Do You Know the Road?"" fades in like we’re catching up to Hiss Golden Messenger in the middle of an especially arduous trek. The rhythm section lopes along
column15: trudging yet determined to make the next ridge
column16: and Taylor coaxes a tremulous solo out of his guitar—short but powerful. This sojourner’s dirge is a call-and-response between the songwriter and his band
column17: who answer only
column18: ""Yes
column19: my brother
column20: I know the road
column21: to convey a palpable world-weariness that is less physical than spiritual.

column1: To their credit
column2: Hiss Golden Messenger never sound weary. In whatever form the band might take
column3: they convey too much joy and direction in creating the music and making the journey. Despite its subdued momentum
column4: Southern Grammar still sounds like an exclamation point at the end of Lateness of Dancers
column5: echoing that album’s celebratory cry while also warning of all the miles that lay ahead of this band. ""What are you worried about?"" Letterman asked the band
column6: only somewhat rhetorically. ""We’re not worried about anything
column7:
was Taylor’s apt answer.

It might sound silly to call any shambling rock band a ""machine
column2: especially one that practically invented shambling. But seriously: in the late 1980s
column3: Half Japanese were a song machine. Their three LPs released in the last three years of that decade—Music to Strip By
column4: Charmed Life
column5: and The Band That Would Be King—boasted 70 songs
column6: with nearly 40 more appended to CD and cassette versions. Unlike much of their 1980 triple-LP debut ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts
column7: little on these albums
column8: now issued together by Fire as Volume 2: 1987-1989
column9: is noisy or abstract. Most of the songs have verses
column10: choruses
column11: even bridges. And many could stick in your head for years.

column1: Half Japanese’s stunning knack for cranking out two-minute gems during this period is even more impressive given how tumultuous that time was. The core of the band to that point was brothers David and Jad Fair
column2: who conceived and launched Half Japanese from a bedroom in their parents’ house. So it had to be a blow when
column3: before the recording of <i>Music to Strip By
column4: David exited the group. He had written as many Half Japanese songs as Jad and was their in-house philosopher
column5: espousing the virtues of ignoring musical rules.

column1: But Half Japanese’s arc by this point had a magical inevitability
column2: a progress immune even to fundamental change. Their music had grown more accessible with every record after ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts
column3: and Jad had become increasingly adept at funnelling his obsessions into songs that were charming
column4: frank
column5: comical
column6: and weird. His vision was so strong
column7: in fact
column8: that the many contributors here—including Shimmy Disc head/Galaxie 500 producer Kramer
column9: ex-Velvet Monkey Don Fleming
column10: and avant-garde stalwarts John Zorn and Fred Frith—all unite under Jad
column11: complementing his unique voice rather than diluting it. David is actually on Charmed Life (recorded before Music to Strip By but released after)
column12: and his influence is felt on all three records
column13: but Jad is clearly the star of this triple feature.

column1: From that star shines a deceptively naïve sensibility. Jad sings about love with words that could be lifted from a high schooler’s notebook
column2: in a geeky voice that seems allergic to conventional pitch. But a close listen reveals slyly clever wordplay and suprisingly versatile singing. All three albums are filled with sharp couplets that turn cliches over (""I read the writing on the wall/ In fact I’m the guy that wrote it"")
column3: dole out absurd jokes (""I could stuff my pockets full of 10 dollar bills/ But then where would I put all these 20s?"") and state things so plainly (""I used to have fun but now I don’t/ The things I did now I won’t"") that they cut straight to the gut. Jad varies his phrasing to match these surging sentiments
column4: creating a counterpoint to the spot-on music. When the band grinds out a groove behind his half-rhythmic/half-blank cadences
column5: the woozy disconnect—the way they alternately meet and diverge—is oddly compelling
column6: like the nerdy cousin to the rants of Mark E. Smith atop the repetitions of the Fall.

column1: Jad’s versatility is also reflected in the thematic distinctions between these three albums. True to its name
column2: Music to Strip By is the most prurient
column3: perhaps even the sleaziest of the three. Many of its songs are crooked blues
column4: with the subject of sex dealt with in guilelessly-blunt terms (""Sex at Your Parents’ House"" opens with ""Tonight we’ll have sex/ Sex at your parents’ house""). The tunes are often skeletal
column5: relying on Jad’s voice to carry the show
column6: and he steps up to that duty impressively.

column1: Compared to Music to Strip By
column2: Charmed Life is fuller
column3: more realized
column4: and simply greater. There’s a bright hook
column5: a snappy turn of phrase
column6: or a funny story in every song. Tunes pour into each other to build a narrative
column7: detailing an earnest journey toward some kind of love. And the band is synced almost telepathically
column8: their flowing parts connecting like puzzle pieces. Particularly valuable is Fleming
column9: whose voice serves as an airy ghost of Jad’s
column10: echoing his sentiments like a best-friend chorus. The result is a thoroughly happy record that still sounds wise and wistful.

column1: Charmed Life’s buoyancy morphs into something harsher on The Band That Would Be King. The songs are still sharp
column2: but the execution is rawer and rougher
column3: and the band’s churn feels frustrated
column4: sometimes even angry. Even though David’s cover art depicts Jad outboxing Elvis Presley
column5: there’s a bitterness in the title’s ""would
column6: implying that Half Japanese should be king
column7: but aren’t. Jad’s sentiments are still honest and forthright
column8: but the music makes them feel more pained—Take ""Some Things Last a Long Time""
column9: an ode to a dead relationship's remains treated as a heavy dirge
column10: replete with crying saxophones. But The Band That Would Be King is only tortured by Half Japanese standards. There’s still lots of sweetness here
column11: and Jad again smartly navigates between the poles of heartbreak and joy.

column1: That dichotomy is part of what makes these records vital nearly three decades later. They set a blueprint for subsequent indie rock
column2: the kind that valued DIY yet didn’t shy away from melody
column3: and addressed matters of the heart without arch distance. Yet this period of Half Japanese could never be imitated because it was so dependent on Jad’s peculiar
column4: wholly-original character. The strongest echo of his personality came in the rawly honest work of Daniel Johnston—listen to his duo record with Jad
column5: released right after The Band That Would Be King
column6: and see if you can tell who's who. But where Johnston leaned more toward a loner vibe
column7: Jad had the singular ability to make his personal obsessions relatable
column8: inclusive
column9:
and ultimately universal.

About 90 seconds into ""Confetti""
column2: the stunning second song on James Blackshaw’s Summoning Suns
column3: the guitarist hesitates as he begins to negotiate a particularly tricky—and
column4: for him
column5: rather unprecedented—passage. The first two verses have ended
column6: a small string section has pushed the tune onto a carousel that might have suited Van Dyke Parks in his prime
column7: and an ascendant third verse has thrust Blackshaw into a place he’s never been: a vocal hook that he has to sing himself. ""The needless noise you air
column8: he offers gently
column9: the instrumentalist’s voice so soft and uncertain at the start of each word that he almost drops ""the."" ""Echoes everywhere
column10: he ends
column11: pushing the last syllable with such force it seems he’s using his last bit of breath. It’s guileless
column12: charming
column13: and the anchor of a masterful few minutes of acoustic pop so good they make you ask an unlikely question: Why hasn’t James Blackshaw been singing all along?

column1: A decade ago
column2: Blackshaw emerged as a leading young stylist for instrumental acoustic guitar music. He’d started as many of his peers have
column3: offering knotty revisions of songs with ""blues"" or ""rag"" appended to the title. (See last year’s reissue of his pleasing if predictable 2003 debut
column4: Apologia
column5: by example.) But he soon assimilated new influences into his six- and 12-string songs
column6: from a classical grandeur borrowed from romantic composers to immersive atmospheres that seemed to reflect an interest in mysticism. Between 2006 and 2010
column7: he issued a string of impossibly beautiful records in that vein
column8: epitomized by his cascading Tompkins Square debut
column9: The Cloud of Unknowing. Droning chords provided ballast beneath fluid fingerpicking
column10: gilded sometimes by coruscating piano and strings. Blackshaw had transcended those formative blues to reposition existential sadness and spiritual wonder as self-made sanctuaries of sound.

column1: But for the last half-decade
column2: and perhaps even while he was issuing those pivotal albums
column3: Blackshaw struggled with what might come next. He didn’t abandon his resplendent aims so much as try to find new ways to deploy them—intricate collaborations with lutist Jozef Van Wissem
column4: improvisational exaltations with pianist Lubomyr Melnyk
column5: accompaniment for the recent Current 93 records of fellow English seeker David Tibet. He tried contemplative classical guitar and clanging piano for 2012’s <i>Love Is the Plan
column6: the Plan Is Death. He built jazz-influenced
column7: full-band noir for a live score to the 100-year-old silent film Le faux magistrat. All of it was fine
column8: but none of it sparkled with the same sense of discovery his records once held. For the last several years
column9: then
column10: Blackshaw’s albums possessed an air of steady discontent and the demand that comes in trying to fix it.

column1: For someone whose recent output has been so seeking and fitful
column2: especially someone who has never before sung on record
column3: Summoning Suns is remarkably decisive and self-assured. Blackshaw’s first recorded attempt at writing lyrics and singing them opens and ends with brief but significant instrumentals. ""Averoigne"" collapses the dramatic thrust of his work on the Magistrat score into two perfect minutes
column4: glockenspiel and piano playing games of melodic ping pong over a roaring organ; ""Winter Flies"" is a modest reprise of Blackshaw’s career-making guitar majesty
column5: his round sound and rippling strings suggesting a symphony tucked inside a soft gig bag. The core
column6: though
column7: comes in the shape of five bright
column8: smart
column9: and sad acoustic pop numbers. It’s as if
column10: after years of letting the guitar speak for his thoughts and feelings
column11: Blackshaw decided he might make his melancholy resonate anew by giving it a more direct voice—that is
column12: his own.

column1: The allure is instant: ""Confetti""
column2: that second song
column3: is as memorable and muted as the best of Jim O’Rourke’s pop cuts
column4: and it reinforces O’Rourke’s love of extreme lyrical and musical dissonance. The drums gallop
column5: the strings glide and Blackshaw’s guitar dances. But he and Annie Nilsson

column11: Blackshaw—somehow too beguiling to actually sound bitter—alludes to his public reputation as a white-hot guitarist who was never quite satisfied with that status. As the strings rise around the guitar

column5: its writer

It takes more than guts to dredge below rock bottom. Certainly some degree of bravery is involved

column1: There's very little virtue in We Are Undone

column3: singer/guitarist Adam Stephens and drummer Tyson Vogel sounding wrung out by their own integrity. Maybe it's a creative adaptation for a band born and raised in San Francisco: The city today

column1: The most satisfying callback to Two Gallants' halcyon
column2: mid-'00s prime comes in the album's second half. ""My Man Go"" demonstrates the patience and melodic intelligence that incites 2Gs live shows into sing-and-sway mosh pits. ""In the ruins of my night I can still pretend
column3: Stephens sings over acoustic guitar
column4: ""close my eyes
column5: see my life as it could have been."" ""Katy Kruelly"" references 200-some years of American folk-music tradition
column6: from the Revolutionary War to the Civil War to early 20th-century race records to '60s folk revivalism. As presented here
column7: the song glows with Stephens' voice and acoustic guitar
column8: as much a history lesson as a beautiful ballad of loss. It segues directly into ""Heartbreakdown""
column9: another slow
column10: somber number
column11: literary in its lyricism and oozing regret.

column1: ""There's So Much I Don't Know"" closes the album with an anti-gentrification anthem that's equal parts preservationist and xenophobic. City living in 2015 is a thorny subject; urban evolution is a process both inevitable and stomach-churning. In the case of San Francisco
column2: wealthy people are displaced by even wealthier people—plains-bred newcomers ""trying to make it rain."" Two Gallants rightly addresses the issue in folk-song form
column3: but Stephens' response is to begrudge
column4: flee
column5: and burn the city to the ground on his way out. Die-yuppie-scum middle fingering is an appropriate first response of the self-possessed dispossessed
column6: but it can't be the last. ""All things blow eventually/ There's so much I don't know
column7: goes the chorus. I wish there were more to say than that.

column1: Which is the overall sense the album leaves: The band wields the same righteous fury as always
column2: regardless of a world evolving around them
column3: without them. The only obvious shift within Undone is in Stephens' guitar tone
column4: which occasionally takes on prog-ish
column5: Malmsteenian melodrama—not necessarily for the best. That guitar roars into a satisfyingly ferocious riff on the album-opening title track
column6: but thematically the song echoes ""Waves of Grain"" from their 2006 album What the Toll Tells
column7: pitting a young idealist versus an aging cynic in a sort of epistolary folk-metal showdown. This time around the singer remains agnostic. Cynicism is realism. And that resignation hurts.

column1: This band has articulated youthful frustration so well for so long but what comes next? What's below rock bottom? At least the jaunty ""Fools Like Us"" injects a dose of what-me-worry? haplessness into the album a few songs later. But otherwise
column2:
we're left hurt and hopeless. Nobody should have to live like that.

All We Are’s debut album is
column2: above all else

column1: If you were to call All We Are ""edgeless

column7: nonchalantly grabbing the first matching pair out of a drawer of regulars: ""There’s something about you
column8: ""I need you

""Reality TV put eyes on me—but it makes it difficult when it comes to Grammy nominations."" Sullivan has built a strong fanbase without a show and despite this catch-22. Of course its hard to imagine a performer of her talent wouldn't be more widely celebrated in any other era. But though R&B's commercial fortunes dropped precipitously over the past decade

column3: but they are performances of unblinking honesty and an acceptance of consequence that makes our judgement beyond the point. This often means a certain fatalism: ""#HoodLove"" is cinematic in its portrayal of a relationship's loyalty down to the .45 its protagonist packs in her purse
column4: but the couple are poised at the precipice. ""I'ma rock this bitch till the wheels fall off
column5: she sings with the conviction that they'll both be around to see exactly that happen

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21327/homepage_large.1d048987.jpg|Further/Deeper|757.0|The Church|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Unorthodox']|2015-01-30 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:27.683398|"

The Church inhabit a peculiar place in the minds of most American music lovers. The Australian band have been together for a whopping 35 years and their latest album—the sprawling Further/Deeper—is their 21st proper full-length release. While back home in Australia they are rightly respected as titans
column2: here in the States their legacy is tied forever to ""120 Minutes""-era college rock (specifically 1988’s eternal mix tape staple ""Under the Milky Way"") and for the uninitiated they presented a back catalog so long and dense as to feel a little impenetrable.

column1: While it seems unlikely that Further/Deeper will do much to change the band’s Stateside legacy
column2: it certainly doesn’t do anything to diminish it. The 12 tracks here deliver the same kind of languid psychedelia and pillowy atmospherics that have been a hallmark of Church albums for most of the latter half of their career. ""Love Philtre"" and ""Volkano"" are the band’s stock in trade—prolonged bits of mysticism narrated by frontman Steve Kilbey’s wry vocals. ""If you touch us we disappear/ If you are waiting we are never here"" he sings on ""Let Us Go""—a track that
column3: quite literally
column4: could have appeared on any number of Church albums released in the last decade.

column1: This isn’t necessarily a slight to the band
column2: who have consistently delivered this kind of shimmery alt-pop for decades now
column3: but this kind of psychedelic sameness grows tiresome after a while. Longtime fans will note the departure of longtime guitarist Marty Willson-Piper (replaced here by Powderfinger’s Ian Haug) as denoting a shift in the band’s sound
column4: but anyone but a hardcore devotee would likely be hard pressed to discern any radical difference. Occasionally the guitars rip and roar (""Lightning White""
column5: ""Toy Head"")
column6: but mostly they jangle and drift through these songs like smoke...another defining characteristic of the band’s back catalog.

column1: It seems unfair to expect radical reinvention from a band like the Church—a shape-shifting outfit that has spent the better part of three decades more or less circling the same singular vibe. A discography 21 albums deep evidences the kind of career that few bands ever get to experience
column2: but that kind of back catalog can also be stifling. More than five years since their last album
column3: 2009's Untitled #23
column4: Further finds the band trying (in baby steps) to play around with the tropes that have been the hallmarks of their career.

column1: Historically
column2: some of the band’s best songs (""Metropolis""
column3: ""Ripple"") have married druggy atmospherics with an airtight pop sensibility. If Further/Deeper fails on any front it’s that the single-appropriate pop moments feel too blandly adult contemporary (no one ever needs to write another song called ""Laurel Canyon"") and the record’s most grandly ambitious song—the epic eight-and-a-half-minute album closer—is
column4: somewhat inexplicably
column5: an ode to Miami. That being said
column6:
Further/Deeper is hardly a misstep—it’s a perfectly lovely addition to the band’s canon—but it’s not the kind of record that's going to usher in a new era or mesmerize people who haven’t already been blissed out on this band for decades.

Jack Name has a flair for the dramatic. Here's the establishing shot that opens Weird Moons: ""Activated midnight
column2: actuate the beast/ Cast your spell on the bastard child blasting Judas Priest."" The stage is set for a concept album featuring werewolves

column6: he was diagnosed with cancer. ""I had had it for five years without even knowing

column8: my body is changing
column9: and I feel like I’m all alone

column11: I feel like I’m already dying.""

column1: Steeped in darkness

column6: occasionally mimicking a wolf's howl. He's soulfully ethereal like Station to Station or Low-era Bowie (""Something About Glenn Goins"")
column7: and he's crunchy and industrial (""Watcher Talk""). If his voice isn't muffled beneath other instrumentals

column1: In order to enjoy Light Show
column2: it felt necessary to be invested in the album's story. A lot of the songs were essentially character-establishing scenes in a film
column3: and even though the music was interesting
column4: some songs felt like vehicles for the plot. While there's obviously an arc here
column5: all eight of these songs work when removed from the album's context. His ambition as a songwriter has earned him a spot in the Hall of Pop Eccentrics alongside Ariel Pink (Pom Pom featured Name) and Connan Mockasin
column6: but when you step back from the monsters and implicit darkness
column7:
you realize that Jack Name is also very good at writing earworms.

column5: which ignores the beat's fault lines and a clear sense of symmetry. On his new The Cost of Victory
column6: however
column7: Spencer's sense of control
column8: rather than his unpredictability
column9: takes center stage. He successfully recasts familiar styles—sample-heavy gangsta and underground rap idioms from the late '90s—without indulging in anodyne nostalgia
column10: a difficult feat for most contemporary rappers. More than on his previous releases
column11: it feels like Spencer is paying tribute to the music he grew up listening to; on horn-driven opener ""Deadstock""
column12: he remembers ""walk[ing] up and down Lamron/ Rappin’ out loud the lyrics to ‘Confessions’ by Cam’ron
column13: and mutters ""They don’t make this kind of shit no more"" throughout the tellingly titled ""Sony Walkman"". But this music is clearly an individualistic response to this source material
column14: not rite-of-passage rehashing.

column1: Above everything else
column2: Spencer is able to carry the project off because these songs are so skillfully and painstakingly written. As always
column3: his verses characterize his bigger-than-life
column4: reliably disagreeable personality
column5: and are propelled by the healthy competitive spirit of a battle rapper or a dozens player (""I play the background but my rhymes live and direct/ I don’t care if that’s your chick
column6: boy
column7: I’m eying the chest""). On every song
column8: the rapper quickly comes out swinging against buzzworthy rap phenoms
column9: ""Internet thugs
column10: ""fashion bozos"" or the misspent adolescents of Chicago (""murk[ing] something"" when they can’t even ""spell the name of [his] fucking block""). Spencer’s ability to pivot between incongruous talking points recalls the periodically humorous mood swings of DJ Quik
column11: one of his espoused favorites. However
column12: unlike the sleek Comptonite
column13: Spencer's brash delivery is all live-wire assault tactics. The approach is enough to keep the listener’s attention even in the near-complete absence of hooks
column14: and to carry over the album’s busy
column15: heavily sliced-and-diced production.

column1: Building up hip-hop acts gradually—across and despite trends—through pushing cohesive
column2: full-length projects instead of viral singles is largely a foregone conclusion for today’s labels
column3: but Spencer is following this old model on his own. Though he remains a few steps from making a major breakthrough (""Vic spits shit like a toilet that’s fucked up/ Five years on the scene and I’m still next up"")
column4: Spencer continues to invest in his future without trying too hard to picture it
column5:
and by refusing to compromise.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21431/homepage_large.4caea212.jpg|Beast Mode|30068.0|Future|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-01-29 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:29.714887|"

After a debut album littered with yearning club jams like ""Turn on the Lights"" and ""Neva End""
column2: warm hits penned for pop stars
column3: and a whirlwind romance with singer Ciara that produced a few pretty duets and an adorably well-dressed baby
column4: Future has come to be understood
column5: perhaps prematurely
column6: as one of his generation’s premier romantics. His story was always more complex than that
column7: though
column8: as we came to understand over six months in 2014
column9: when our rap Romeo went from ""Girl when I’m with you
column10: feel like a champion"" to ""Girl you know you like a pistol
column11: you a throw away."" Things soured for Future and Cici somewhere between the April release of Honest and Halloween’s Metro Boomin produced Monster
column12: and the callous nature of his writing post-breakup has given the lie to the Nicholas Sparks perception that’s clouded his major label career.

column1: On Beast Mode
column2: produced in full by Atlanta trap maestro Zaytoven
column3: Future retreats further into the flashy player lifestyle presented on pre-album mixtape highlights Dirty Sprite and True Story. He’s colder than he’s been since 2012’s Astronaut Status’ ""My Ho 2"" on cuts like ""Lay Up"" and ""Peacoat""
column4: bragging on the former about passing a hook-up off ""like a lay up"" and glibly remarking that he ""spent a check on that pussy"" on the latter. At first it seems like a continuation of the aggy sexual and emotional revenge tactics of Monster (see: ""My Savages""’ ""You think I’m sitting up depressed?/ I’m somewhere counting up me a check
column5: ""Throw Away""’s ""I was fucking on a slut and I was thinking about you"") but the deeper you delve into Beast Mode
column6: the more it comes off as the vice grip headache and hangover to Monster’s seedy rager.

column1: At the outset Beast Mode is somewhat mechanical
column2: Future locking into whirring synth arrangements and churning out three-minute nuggets of dopeboy grit. Opener ""Ooooh""
column3: Juvenile tribute ""Aintchu""
column4: and closer ""Forever Eva"" coolly channel the inherent catchiness of mixtape Future
column5: the half cast off
column6: half accomplished greatness he exuded before he began to write more keenly for mass consumption. But when Zay tosses out something darker he gets it back in kind. You can hear Zaytoven catch Future in the chest at the top of ""No Basic"" as the track billows in and he ad libs
column7: ""You gotta feel the pain of a kid in the ghetto
column8: the heart of the ghetto"" before laying out a list of hard hits he took in getting to the money (""Took all the pain and I ran with it.../ I took a few losses and ran with it""). On ""Just Like Bruddas""
column9: he’s suspended in a daze of Percocet
column10: Xanax
column11: and promethazine self-medication amid a bad press cycle of his own design as his producer dances around a gutting
column12: intricate piano line underfoot.

column1: Future and Zaytoven have collaborated quite a bit in the past but it’s apparent that Zay is bringing something different to the table this time and that it’s bringing something else of Future. Zay’s best works (Gucci Mane’s ""Bricks"" and Usher’s ""Papers""
column2: to name just two) are wonky collisions of trap drums and church organs armed with a fleet musicality that the bullish simplicity of the Lex Lugers and the druggy atmospherics of the Mike WiLLs have often lacked. Recent Zaytoven productions have eased off a measure of the emotionalism of his playing
column3: though
column4: resulting in still great
column5: still quirky winners like Migos’ ""Versace"" and Shy Glizzy’s ""Catch a Body"" with hooks that grip but don’t much pull. Beast Mode feels heavier
column6: particularly in the stretch from ""No Basic"" to ""Where I Came From""
column7: a succession of dour compositions rendered quietly devastating by Zay’s soulful riffing around the central themes and by Future’s matching reflective malaise. Their deepening chemistry is Beast Mode’s boon.

column1: Jutting outside his hitmaking responsibilities has allowed Future to make music that speaks to a very specific personal turmoil without worrying about whether it’ll be relatable or even likable. The feed-the-charts-feed-the-streets formula of Honest worked as well as it possibly could’ve last year
column2: but lately
column3: Future’s feeding himself
column4: taking inventory of his journey
column5: and learning how to navigate a very public rough patch. The casual sex doesn’t seem fun
column6: the recreational pharmaceutical use feels ominous
column7: and there’s a distinctly mournful air to the proceedings. Though he’ll only tacitly admit as much
column8: our player entrepreneur is hurt
column9:
and Beast Mode’s heavy-hearted sounds assist him in sorting through it just as Monster’s menace helped him turn spite to fuel.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21429/homepage_large.8ecb8cb5.jpg|Matador|32710.0|Gaz Coombes|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hot Fruit']|2015-01-29 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:30.320838|"

Any list of Britpop’s distinguished elder statesmen is unlikely to have Gaz Coombes—the mutton-chopped frontman for English oddballs Supergrass—in its top five. But over the course of six solid-to-great full-lengths
column2: Supergrass were a welcome alternative to the witty austerity
column3: sexual malaise
column4: and idol worship that came to define the movement. Around the time of the 2004 singles collection Supergrass Is 10
column5: it became clear that Supergrass were born to play Cult Favorite. From the whirligigging Ritalin rush of their U.S. breakthrough ""Alright"" to the rip-snorting grunge-pop of ""Richard III"" and on through the retro-futurism of ""Rush Hour Soul""
column6: Supergrass reminded people how much fucking fun being in a rock band could be. Still
column7: Coombes’ post-Supergrass output has been prone to the usual trappings. There was the HotRats’ Turn Ons
column8: a one-off covers collection that found Coombes and Supergrass bandmate Danny Goffey tackling such on-the-nose favorites as ""Love Is the Drug"" and ""Queen Bitch"" (and
column9: uh
column10: ""Fight for Your Right (to Party)""); an obligatory car commercial; his 2012 debut solo affair Here Come the Bombs. Now with Matador
column11: Coombes takes the road more traveled
column12: offering 11 new tunes that retain familiar glimmers of mischief but try to appeal to a more mature sensibility.

column1: Coombes still sounds eager
column2: and Supergrass' sense of restlessness continues here: Matador suggests a guy constantly on the move
column3: exorcising as much as from his brain as he can before scurrying on over to the next thing. But where Coombes was once a conscientious self-editor
column4: keeping things as lean and catchy as possible
column5: here he tends to overwork ideas. Take ""Detroit""
column6: which is fairly representative of the album on the whole: What starts out as a wonderfully introspective
column7: acoustic track built for daydreaming gives way to overblown bursts of string-augmented gospel. Matador is constantly being pulled in different directions. Had he resigned himself to taking a looser
column8: more natural approach (which did Bombs a favor or two)
column9: or gone all-the-way with the Albarn-esque pageantry
column10: we might be talking about a more interesting record.

column1: Fans will no doubt try to engage with Matador as a Supergrass album
column2: which is unfair. But when it seems content to play as merely a Supergrass footnote
column3: it’s hard not to make easy comparisons. A few tracks make some effort to remedy that kind of thinking
column4: all while appeasing longtime loyalists. ""The English Ruse"" is one of the better songs here
column5: its looping
column6: Schroeder-indebted keyboards primed to score another wacky sped-up music video (fun fact: Steven Spielberg once approached Supergrass to do a Monkees-inspired TV show)
column7: but this time with a strong undercurrent of paranoia. ""Needle's Eye""
column8: which ultimately suffers from overcrowding
column9: has a louche touch reminiscent of the B-movie glam of Life on Other Planets. The cautious creep of single ""20/20""
column10: which nicely exemplifies Matador’s crisp production values
column11: helps balance its lucid moments of euphoria by blending in uneasier elements along the way. Coombes comes at these songs with a less-is-more attitude
column12: but even the simplest fare fails to connect. The Manic Pixel Dream Girl fantasy ""The Girl Who Fell to Earth""
column13: which finds Coombes ""blinded by computer love
column14: is a snoozer that predicts a good portion of Matador’s back end. ""Oscillate"" is stoner music that plays like a parody of stoner music
column15: while the reflective ""Seven Walls"" and the understated title track are just there. Instead of following his darker impulses or fantastically out-there indulgences
column16:
Coombes plays it safe.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21436/homepage_large.9598952e.jpg|Back From the Grave Vol. 9|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Crypt']|2015-01-29 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:30.997517|"

Throughout the 1980s and '90s
column2: Crypt Records dug up lost 45s from rock'n'roll's fringes and assembled and released them on a series of Back From the Grave compilations. Adorned with album art depicting cartoon zombies wreaking havoc on the living
column3: these sets promised <a href=""http://www.discogs.com/Various-Back-From-The-Grave-Volume-5/release/404997"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">crazed
column4: frantic
column5: bone-crunchin'  and raw blastin' garage punk screamers from the mid-'60s. They were the ""unpsychedelic"" alternative to Nuggets and Pebbles—shaggy-haired flower child types who had too much to dream last night need not apply. Back From the Grave was reserved for the bands that screamed a little harder
column6: played with fuzzboxes (either store-bought or makeshift)
column7: and sought refuge in early Animals and Kinks records. The Gories cited the series as an influence
column8: which makes a lot of sense (especially when you hear their cover of the Sloths' Vol. 4 highlight ""Makin' Love""). By 1996
column9: series curator Tim Warren was eight-for-eight in putting together albums full of forgotten but thrilling rock'n'roll.

column1: After Vol. 8 came silence; needless to say
column2: it's surprising to see a new Back From the Grave compilation nearly 20 years later. Even better
column3: Crypt have shared two new installments at once (released separately on LP and packaged together as a single CD)
column4: more music for the self-anointed rebel and the kid who likes a dirty joke. On this 30-song totem of lost almost-hits
column5: you'll find an organ-heavy melody obscured by a Missouri teenager shouting ""You're gonna die!"" (the Warlocks' ""Beware"")
column6: while ""When I Feel Better"" is a potent reminder that a song with lots of tambourine is still capable of being a complete jam. On ""69""
column7: the frontman of the Four shrieks a few times inside Sam Phillips' Memphis studio before singing about his favorite sexual position and giggling with his bandmates as the song ends. These sets are time capsules
column8: with liner notes filled with old photos and newspaper clippings
column9: but even in 2015
column10: Back From the Grave has something to teach us.

column1: Those notes also share the frequently bizarre stories
column2: expertly told by garage rock historian Chris Bishop
column3: of the bands behind the music. The Orphans' story deserves its own biopic: The Iowa teens got kicked out of high school for having long hair
column4: ripped up a record contract (again
column5: because they were told by an authority figure to cut their hair)
column6: and were robbed by their terrible manager. Nobody's Children
column7: a band of Las Vegas teens
column8: wrote ""Mother's Tin Moustache"" after smoking weed for the first time
column9: and the lyrics are pure '60s stoner humor. In a fantastically frantic old-coot voice
column10: they shout ""Keep that turtle out of my cabbage patch"" and ""That sure is a funny picture of your mother and me"".

column1: Naturally
column2: these bands weren't reinventing the wheel. The ""rock'n'roll wild man"" archetype was perfected by Little Richard and Jerry Lee Lewis a full decade earlier
column3: and while it's cool that some of these artists can scream as hard as the Sonics
column4: Vol. 9 and 10 are about more than a ""who's the loudest"" contest. In voice
column5: tone
column6: and narrative
column7: there's a lot going on across the comps' 30 songs. ""I'm Hurtin'"" by the Classics
column8: for example
column9: is influenced by a very similar Animals song
column10: but singer Richard Titlow's voice is mousy and muffled—more Daniel Johnston than Eric Burdon. Elsewhere
column11: you've got bands that cackle about witches and your imminent demise (GMC and the Arcells) and invoke Dickensian grave robbers (the Emeralds).

column1: The gatefold of Vol. 10 shows rock
column2: pop
column3: and electronic music stars lining up to face their undead executioner. Illustrating this music with murderous zombies is appropriate—these records are artifacts
column4: and yet here they are
column5: walking among us
column6: while screaming about mortality and lust. After 32 years of putting together Back From the Grave records
column7:
Warren has exhumed another big batch of wild-eyed gems from the unwitting fathers of punk and contemporary garage rock.

"|20171.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20171-back-from-the-grave-vol-9-and-10/|7.6|Evan Minsker
