column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21395/homepage_large.5e13d00a.jpg|Tierra Y Libertad|30511.0|Xibalba|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Southern Lord']|2015-01-29 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:31.629494|"

Hasta La Muerte
column2: the last album from Southern California death metal/hardcore hybrids Xibalba
column3: showed a group challenging their peers to step up the heaviness while never losing sight of their humble beginnings. It sounded as though a hardcore band got locked in their rehearsal space with only their gear
column4: Obituary's Cause of Death
column5: and Crowbar's Broken Glass to pass the time. Muerte was less cerebral than death metal
column6: meaner than sludge
column7: and unsubtly knuckle-dragging and proud of it. Beneath Xibalba's ultra-tough exterior was a desire to advance their sound
column8: even by adding armor to their older vessels. ""Cold""
column9: which started out on a split with World of Pain and Ruckus as a chugging mosh song
column10: became a hulking riff mass with Greg Anderson's guidance and additional guitars. The band emerges as an even more confident war machine with Tierra Y Libertad
column11: streamlining their sound
column12: cranking the tempos
column13: and tipping the balance towards death metal. If Muerte was the beginning of the workout process
column14: Libertad is where they come out swole as hell.

column1: Where does this newfound vigor come from? Xibalba have clearly been studying the British death metal band Bolt Thrower's move from grind to death
column2: and unlike crusties who lean towards metal
column3: not just their rawer 1988 debut In Battle There Is No Law! Many of the album's faster moments sound not unlike 1991's grind-ditching War Master
column4: and Xibalba's development mimics Bolt Thrower's on that as a whole. ""Enemigo"" establishes the album's direction promptly and with no mercy; that chug is undeniable. Most of the record is carried out with similar intent; the confidence in their playing cannot be overlooked. It's not just that they add more solos
column5: it's that they've found a way to advance beyond listing their influences. Xibalba's penchant for groove is still evident even though their dances have become quicker and deadlier
column6: which is primarily why these songs carry. ""Invierno"" has bounce for days
column7: the closest death metal can get to being funky. The ending riff of ""Si Dios Quiere"" is just disjointed enough to sound a bit hazy
column8: but still packs that hardcore punch
column9: making for a beatdown whose impact you'll remember better than the conflict that set it off. It's hard to believe that Xibalba were the same band that made Madre Mia Gracias Por Los Dias
column10: their 2010 debut whose production sounds downright anemic compared to Nails drummer Taylor Young's work on Libertad.

column1: Muerte was primarily conceived for rough-housing
column2: and few modern hardcore records serve that purpose better
column3: but Xibalba also gave into a bit of experimentation. Some ideas worked better than others—the female vocals on ""Mala Mujer"" gave a new dimension to Muerte's agony
column4: but instrumental piece ""The Flood"" was plodding along in search of a breakdown. Libertad's instrumental piece
column5: ""Pausa""
column6: is much shorter and serves primarily as a lead-in for ""En Paz Descanse"". Xibalba's restraint in this aspect pays off
column7: as the focus stays on the death metal muscle. They only really extend themselves on Libertad's closer
column8: ""El Vacio"". A lot of the sludge influence comes back on this song; most of it sounds like Pallbearer going back to basics
column9: with dreary cleans and especially deep
column10: longing vocals that could be on the next Skepticism record.

column1: ""Vacio"" is Xibalba at their most alienated
column2: and while they've never been more sure of themselves musically
column3: there's hints throughout that they really want to shake up and challenge their audience. Most of the record looks inward
column4: but ""Guerilla"" speaks of violent revolution with no uncertain terms. Vocalist Nate Rebolledo's call for unity against oppressors isn't a whisper: ""I'm not a spick
column5: a nigger
column6: a cracker/...I am the pissed off human race/ We are here to scream 'fuck you!'"" His vocals are the most obvious remnant of Xibalba's hardcore days
column7: and they're needed for a direct proclamation such as this. And it's just the thing fans of hardcore
column8: death metal
column9: and
column10: really
column11: any form of heavy music need to hear more of.

column1: Hardcore waxes on and on about brotherhood and sticking together
column2: and isn't opposed to using violent metaphors to express such sentiments
column3: but Rebolledo is speaking on a grander scale than bros looking out for bros. That may be harder to take than an accidental punch in the face at one of their shows. Some punk kid may cry ""ACAB"" because he got written up for open containers
column4: but there are many who don't get off that lightly. Dan Seagrave's artwork for Libertad is another one of his classic dystopian war scenes
column5: but Xibalba's war is not literal: it's about what your expectations of them might be
column6: it's about pushing the limits of hardcore
column7:
it's about combating apathy. Helps when you've got sick riffs on your side.

"|20126.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20126-tierra-y-libertad/|7.6|Andy O'Connor

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21359/homepage_large.0ef63e0c.jpg|Xe|5596.0|Zs|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Northern Spy']|2015-01-29 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:33.134073|"

Whether at its most chaotic or calm
column2: dense or delicate
column3: Xe is the sort of album that causes its listeners to picture its creators
column4: the long-evolving and ever-confounding New York ensemble Zs. During these five tracks
column5: electric guitars splash swatches of neon sound between a rhythm section built from athletic handclaps. Multi-tracked saxophones spiral in perfect antiphony with static-and-hiss electronics. Drums move back and forth between a sustained roll and a snapping march with inhuman stamina. You imagine the musicians not only playing these parts but—brows furrowed behind a mixing board
column6: eyes glazed in front of a computer’s glow—putting the pieces in their proper places
column7: creating a meticulous whole from many unwieldy segments. How else could three people so perfectly toe the lines between free-jazz bedlam and near-classical precision
column8: between sound-art abstraction and math-rock execution
column9: all while making the intertwining instrumentals somehow bright and accessible
column10: too? This stuff seems too complicated to be only played.

column1: It is
column2: however
column3: just one miracle of <i>Xe
column4: the first proper album by Zs’ new trio configuration
column5: that these five tracks stem from real-time
column6: single takes. There was little-to-no editing or post-production
column7: or no overdubs to shore up the squawk of Sam Hillmer’s saxophone or the ricochet of Patrick Higgins’ guitar. Years and lineups ago
column8: Zs worked from complete scores
column9: toting sheet music into rock-club contexts. On 2013’s two-sided Grain
column10: the new trio split into dual factions
column11: each remixing recordings from earlier Zs incarnations into 21-minute epics. The rendering by new drummer Greg Fox
column12: best known for his work in Liturgy and Guardian Alien
column13: was a surrealistic reimagining of the old band’s strict order. You can picture Xe being built by either process
column14: really—read from a chart by a well-rehearsed troupe or built on screen by people with as much patience as programming acumen. But no
column15: Xe was created live in a room
column16: using only loose sketches and structures as signposts.

column1: Thanks to that setup
column2: Zs demonstrate an energy and urgency here that they’ve never before had
column3: as these pieces leap off the page in exhilarating fashion. The tantric title track bursts into heavy paroxysms
column4: like a metal band launching into a snippet of Albert Ayler’s ""Holy Ghost"". Opener ""The Future of Royalty"" is
column5: at first
column6: pneumatically precise
column7: with several sets of rhythms stacked against taut guitar and reed lines. But it’s most electrifying when they leave the plan and rip into a cacophonous crescendo
column8: the band locked in a three-way battle for air.

column1: Still
column2: Zs take no breaks or breaths during these 42 minutes
column3: with each number seguing into the next. That decision ferries momentum between the tracks. What’s more important
column4: though
column5: to the record’s compulsory flow is how Zs turn arrays of influences and ideas into uninterrupted
column6: seamless streams. Fox
column7: Higgins
column8: and Hillmer share the ability to take disparate
column9: treasured sources
column10: disassemble them into essential components
column11: and spontaneously build something singular and distinct from them all. That rush of touchstones—and the surprising
column12: uncanny ways Zs find to fit them together—give Xe much of its magnetism. The plucky guitar line that anchors ""Corps""
column13: for instance
column14: echoes the sounds of various West African traditions
column15: while Hillmer’s slinking-and-crying saxophone work nods to Pharoah Sanders’ languid lines and the pointillist landmarks of Steve Reich. Fox moves between a steady thump that proclaims he’s keeping time for a band of German legends and tense drum rolls that indicate he wants to do little more than disrupt the meter. ""Wolf Government""
column16: meanwhile
column17: interposes aleatoric electronics that suggest the recorded murmurs of short circuits with a mutated hair metal guitar solo
column18: as if played by Sammy Hagar on speed and acid. At best
column19: this configuration of Zs finds ways to soften the edges of discrete and disconnected ideas
column20: pushing them into a space where the listener can fit
column21: too.

column1: Despite rightful talk of increasingly permissive genre borders and the sometimes-narrowing gaps between what is perceived as the aboveground and the underground
column2: the distances between experimental
column3: academic and more popularly accepted realms can still be vast. But Xe delights in such rifts. This trio leavens the abstruse with the excitable
column4: pairs the improvised and wild with the calculated and controlled. Despite its slide into full-on roar
column5: ""The Future of Royalty"" is irrepressible
column6: with a combination of riff and rhythm that recalls the success of Ratatat. And in the hands of the right mixer
column7: the steady percolation
column8: sudden eruptions and seesaw theme of the self-titled grand finale could offer endless dancefloor steam. It’s music to freak out to
column9: yes
column10: but that promise isn’t necessarily limited to the freaks of free-jazz or art-rock enclaves. From the all-in-one-room way it was made to the forceful assimilation of so many sounds that Zs’ members just seem to like

column12:
you’ll soon hear it just the same.

column3: blue geraniums—and accordingly On Your Own Love Again plays like acoustic dream-pop. Its warm
column4: home-recorded atmosphere is more dramatic and distinctive than Jessica Pratt: finger-picked psychedelia

column11: the grave depth of Nico—but she ultimately sounds like Vashti Bunyan or Nick Drake as found in the sleepy subconscious of Ariel Pink. ""Sometimes I pray for the rain

column3: or wordless. Sometimes her crystalline guitar strum sounds like a harp

column8: the end of a longterm relationship

column10: it sounds like Pratt is plaintively
column11: playfully singing stoned ""da-da-da"" tunes just to drown out the sorrow or numb the chaos. On ""Game That I Play""
column12: for one
column13: she imbues
column14: ""I often try to leave my thoughts of you behind
column15: but her wish is left hanging; there is no resolve. And on ""Jacquelyn in the Background""
column16: Pratt similarly drifts
column17: struggling for the right words: ""Deep inside my lonely room/ I cry the tears of never knowing you

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Pratt's austere meditations conjure confusion
column3: wrongness
column4: illusive realities. She sings of lonely outsiders and starry-eyed boys she wants to love but audibly cannot. Pratt understands her own flaws and so seems to better understand those of others; it's humanizing. She might call out a guy's disloyal tricks and lies

column7: ""But I see that you're leaving
column8: so what can I say."" She doesn't airbrush her faults. The title track

column11: and it's the album's most confessional song—""I try to believe in you somehow/ But every time I do I get down and out""—as if
column12: after working through her clouded thoughts

column14: pointing outward

column1: But there is a vessel to that clear-headed solitude: ""Back
column2: Baby"" is the record's penultimate track

column5: Baby"" to come at the end of a film as the credits roll—closure at the end of an ill-fated romance. There is an understated power to it
column6: not just because Pratt is cutting off a person who no longer serves her

column8: Jessica Pratt offers an even more emphatic ""can't go back

Twerps make things easy on us—they're an Australian band that works exclusively in chime and charm
column2: with guitars jangling in brisk rhythms beneath warm and fuzzy melodies. From the outset
column3: they’ve named the Clean’s ""Anything Could Happen"" as their gold standard and the Go-Betweens as a formative influence
column4: saving everyone the time it would otherwise take to come up with the proper comparisons. In the past
column5: they’ve dabbled in exploratory instrumentals
column6: ballads
column7: and spoken-word
column8: and all came off as temporary distractions from the things they do best. Which is perhaps why they stick with what got them here on their Merge debut and decided to call the album Range Anxiety. But as opposed to a concession
column9: their focus is a sign of artistic progress.

column1: And so the most genuinely surprising moment on Range Anxiety might be its only surprising moment: it arrives when Martin Frawley describes his object of affection on ""Love at First Sight"": she’s a Peruvian DJ wearing Louis Vuitton heels
column2: and she has a boyfriend. It’s a one-way attraction of opposites
column3: because she’s everything Frawley isn’t within the context of Twerps: a multi-tasker
column4: a socialite
column5: fashion-conscious and ostensibly in a happy relationship.

column1: That neither Frawley nor co-vocalist Julia Macfarlane have their shit together is hardly to their detriment. So there’s a distinct comic element during ""Back to You"" when Frawley expresses envy at someone out there sipping iced tea and living free. At no point does Frawley seem bothered by any pressing obligation
column2: but his foil does not share the constant incapacitation as a result of the girl who keeps walking out of his life. ""It all keeps coming back to you
column3: Frawley sings on a chorus that could pass for the main sentiment on over half of Range Anxiety and one that finds a comfort in the predictability of despair—it’s a toast of the one beer that becomes the ""one too many.""

column1: Still
column2: Range Anxiety goes by in an instant
column3: makes minimal demands
column4: and is remarkably enjoyable for its simple pleasures. It may not have the heft to move you
column5: but it’s gentle and never unwelcome. Classic jangle-rock hooks lodge in your head without taking up much space. The lyrics are simple expressions of feelings and there is a song called ""Simple Feelings"". The bulk of the record consists of post-breakup laments delivered with an insouciance that can be confused with cheer; they could just as easily find themselves on a mix prepared for a future crush.

column1: It all comes so naturally to Twerps that Range Anxiety could be considered effortless as a pejorative
column2: which is why “I Don’t Mind” is not only their best song to date
column3: but also their most important. As the first proper track on Range Anxiety and one of two tracks over five minutes
column4: it towers over the proceedings. It's a committed and extroverted song about not caring about the outside world
column5: one that evokes big bands like the Velvet Underground and U2
column6: a song that simmers rather than pops and fizzes
column7: that plays Frawley and Macfarlane’s voices for contrast when they otherwise conspire to share the same shrugging views on social demands.

column1: Range Anxiety could use more of the emotional ballast provided by ""I Don't Mind""
column2: even if it doesn’t necessarily need it. Some will hear the album as perfectly breezy
column3: others might consider it featherweight. But this isn’t entirely the fault of Twerps—they just don’t have much of a desire to present their music as autobiography. Hook-for-hook and chime-for-chime
column4: it matches up with the most recent work of Real Estate and Mac DeMarco
column5: 2014’s kings of college quad indie. But while Atlas and Salad Days made a point to stress their reckoning with parenthood
column6: aging
column7: the demands of art and other adult topics
column8: Twerps all but admit Range Anxiety was inspired by a rock'n'roll
column9: on-the-dole lifestyle that leaves vast gaps for drinking and alone time. Which is what a lot of people grappling with family and work pine for anyway
column10:
and the predictability and reliability of Range Anxiety just means it's always there when you need it.

House music has been occupying much of Matthew Herbert’s time recently. In 2014
column2: the British producer dipped back into the genre by reactivating an EP series he started in the mid-'90s
column3: of which Part 8 is supposedly the final entry. (Like most things Herbert
column4: his words probably shouldn’t be trusted
column5: marking this as neither an end or a beginning). It’s art
column6: put out into the world

column10: the waxy synth lines
column11: the tastefully worked samples
column12: the exquisite way he has for working with vocalists.

column1: Herbert’s name might not be as prominent as it once was
column2: perhaps due to the deluge of wildly differing music he releases into the world. But he often crops up
column3: sometimes in unexpected places: Björk talked of his value as a collaborator recently
column4: the London Sinfonietta extended an invitation for him to work with them in 2010
column5: and his work as Creative Director of the BBC Radiophonic Workshop has led him into unexplored pastures. It makes sense that Herbert can connect to so many disparate sources—his ability to diversify within his own musical range is largely unparalleled. Part 7 of this series touched on a contemporary feeling
column6: via the PC Music referencing ""Bumps""

column1: If there is a single element that binds Herbert’s recordings
column2: it’s in his ability to metaphorically tie his feet together to prevent himself ending up in the space where he seems to be heading. So ""The Wrong Place"" lands somewhere far heavier than its lighter beginnings
column3: with a pile of digital interference swamping the track in a blocky
column4: malfunctioning tone. ""Ticket"" falls just the right side of irritating
column5: using the mind-numbing repetition of its title in a manner close to the novelty gabber hit ""Poing"" by Rotterdam Termination Source
column6: but with Herbert upping the mania by driving it to a point that’s simultaneously fascinating and mind-bending. He’s having fun here
column7: clearly
column8: although it often feels like he’s lost in conversation with himself
column9: not digging deep enough into one of house/techno’s most powerful properties—the ability to connect with an audience—especially in the overly earnest ""Her Face"".

column1: The highlights of recent installments in Herbert’s Parts series have mostly come through his work with vocalists
column2: and Part 8 is no exception. ""Remember Ken"" draws a soulful vocal out of Ade Omotayo (who has worked with both Kindness and Amy Winehouse) and matches it to strings and handclaps that sound so plastic it’s like hearing a demo of the cheapest Casio keyboard ever unleashed on the market. It hits on something Herbert always does so well

column4: creating space for the most artificial of pop gestures and a sort of rootsy authenticity. Taking beautifully climbing vocal passages and matching them to instrumentation that
column5: while skillfully played
column6:
sounds like it cost about 50 cents from a local junk store—these are things that make a charming kind of sense in his world.

Napalm Death are one of the most virulent bands in metal: the legendary UK grindcore crew's violent
column2: stream-of-consciousness operates like a punk pandemic. Fed by the cesspools of unrest and corruption in the world
column3: their inspiration flares up and runs wild
column4: feeding off whatever styles are at the ready. Sometimes their visceral sound skews hardcore punk

column1: Despite some early instability in their ranks—particularly between when they got their start in 1981 and 1992’s landmark album Utopia Banished—and the continued procession of new bands on the block
column2: Napalm Death haven’t relented one bit. If anything
column3: their path of destruction has grown ever wider
column4: fueled
column5: as always
column6: by the grotesque workings of the musical and political communities that surround them

column1: Three decades in

column3: bassist (and longest tenured member) Shane Embury
column4: drummer Danny Herrera
column5: and that maniacal frontman Mark ""Barney"" Greenway. Embury and Herrera are the whiplash-inducing back end
column6: hammering out tempos atop which Harris proudly stands and slashes
column7: bolstering his dissonant chords with high-register yelps and screeches. <span style=""line-height: 24px;"">And
column8: even at 45
column9: Greenway's role as vocal juggernaut remains secure as he continues to gleefully shove aside whatever structures his bandmates assemble in his path. On Apex Predator
column10: <span>Russ Russell’s mixing allows you to catch every strain
column11: every gasp
column12: every last drop of spit. From the way Greenway huffs and puffs on ""How the Years Condemn""
column13: you’d think the guy was the Big Bad Wolf’s cousin from a nuclear dystopia. A closer look at Embury's lyrics reveals instead an ordinary man
column14: haunted by the friends he's lost and desperate to better his life so as not to sully their memory. Napalm Death's splatterhouse hijinks are rooted in a more profound sense of psychological pain this time around
column15: and that their ability to convey that pain hinges largely on its voice.

column1: What’s more
column2: he remains capable of embodying a dizzying number of roles
column3: adopting the cadence of a murderous carnival barker one moment (on ""Smash a Single Digit"" and ""Metaphorically Screw You"") and an unholy clergy member the next (the title track
column4: an almost meditational nod to Swans). Don’t come into this thing expecting a solo spree; aside from John ""Bilbo"" Cook’s delicious guest riff on ""Hierarchies"" (touted humorously in the liner notes as the ""token guitar solo"")
column5: the axework on Apex Predator - Easy Meat skews workmanlike

column7: chaotic
column8: hyper-speed grindcore
column9: and just a hint of groove metal to make the acrid medicine go down smoother.

column1: Way back in the mothball-scented archives of YouTube there’s this old TV interview with Jim Carrey in which he half-seriously declares his allegiance to thrash metal
column2: launching into an impassioned parody of Napalm Death. ""Some day
column3: this guy’s gonna wanna slow down and do some duets
column4: he grins
column5: launching into a simulation of what that might sound like. What's crazy is that Carrey's mockery ended up being half fulfilled. On Apex Predator
column6: Napalm Death have scaled back the mach-speed sections of yore
column7: specifically with regards to the drums
column8: and the album does feature a screamed duet of sorts with the shattered dialogue of ""Beyond the Pale"". What’s more
column9: as on 2012's Utilitarian and in other scattered corners of their discography
column10: there are periods of clean singing that would've seemed unthinkable back in the days of Harmony Corruption. Here
column11: it's more interestingly interwoven than in the past. And it’s still a Napalm Death record through and through—which means shredded eardrums and tinnitus for days. After all this time
column12:
we’d expect nothing less.

Jan St. Werner's Miscontinuum Album is one of those rare records—rare in experimental music
column2: anyway—that needs no context in order to be appreciated
column3: enjoyed
column4: and absorbed. It's all there
column5: right in front of you; to take it in requires only attention and an open mind. That might sound counterintuitive
column6: given the record's actual backstory: It stems from an electronic opera written and performed by St. Werner
column7: with a libretto by Markus Popp
column8: better known as the glitch pioneer Oval. St. Werner
column9: Popp
column10: and their collaborators—including
column11: here
column12: Dylan Carlson
column13: of Earth; Kathy Alberici
column14: aka Bocca al Lupo
column15: and a member of the psychedelic doom group Drum Eyes; and Taigen Kawabe
column16: of psychedelic punks Bo Ningen—have also fashioned a radio play out of the same material. Could anything sound more like it required homework?

column1: But knowing much of anything about St. Werner's work in Mouse on Mars is neither help nor hindrance here; Miscontinuum Album is so far from that duo's already enormously varied terrain that the main bullet point on his résumé scarcely bears mentioning. Nor do you need to be familiar with Lithops
column2: the alias for a number of St. Werner's solo electronic releases between 1996 and 2010. Sonically
column3: the shimmering
column4: electroacoustic drones here share more in common with St. Werner's Blaze Colour Burn
column5: from 2013
column6: the first release in his Fiepblatter Series. (This is the third in that series.) Ultimately
column7: though
column8: Miscontinuum Album feels less like a project
column9: or even an album
column10: than a garden or a warren of streets or an abandoned building—something you stumble upon
column11: enter
column12: and explore at your own pace.

column1: Time—or
column2: more accurately
column3: the experience of time—is its primary subject. The musical portions of the album thrum with buzzing synthesizers and naked oscillations—extended passages of unsteady repetitions
column4: rippling loops
column5: and long
column6: held tones that twist like moebius strips. The sound shimmers; heavy on organ-like sounds and trilling electronic frequencies
column7: it scans as a cross between Emeralds and Gastr Del Sol. Several tracks are quite long
column8: running to 12
column10: and even 25 minutes. The music moves like snowmelt in the process of becoming a river
column11: trickling and rushing without obvious shape or direction. The background is awash in voices: pellucid soprano
column12: insectoid chatter
column13: time-stretched shrieks
column14: and the ragged cries of black metal
column15: all blown out into a chalky blur of breath and spittle.

column1: But the album's real center of gravity is to be found in the libretto's five text passages
column2: each between two and three minutes long
column3: read by Earth's Dylan Carlson. The text is plainspoken and prosaic
column4: until it's not; it has the habit of ducking and feinting
column5: hiding behind its own shadow
column6: cloaked in ambiguity. ""We hear footsteps above us
column7: says Carlson in the introductory track. ""But we're already on the roof. Each now lasts only for a moment. It's all just memory. Holding firm
column8: forget
column9: search for home. Something somewhere
column10: in us
column11: lives on
column12: as—spirit?"" These words don't do much on the page
column13: but the way he speaks them makes them come alive—as riddle
column14: or incantation
column15: or blindfolded expressway to yr skull.

column1: Carlson's voice is strangely hypnotic. ""How am I not myself?"" he asks
column2: early in the piece
column3: describing a continuous tone as a buzz rises in the background behind him and then falls silent. ""It cuts to the heart
column4: he continues
column5: his voice at once monotone and strangely tender. ""This loneliness after silence. This siren is older than hunger. The loneliness is now electronic. The sound has always been there. It is the undead in me."" There is a tiny rustle of noise in the background
column6: and you lean towards the speakers
column7: acutely aware of the act of listening.

column1: Miscontinuum Album is not meant to be background music. It was also not made to be experienced on YouTube or the free version of Spotify
column2: where an ill-timed advertisement would break the music's spell. It doesn't require your full attention
column3: but it tends to capture it. I like to imagine what it would feel like to stumble across the piece on the radio
column4: late at night
column5: perhaps in your car
column6: having no idea what you were hearing
column7: or why—being drawn into its web
column8: confused and intoxicated. After Carlson has finished his monologue
column9: there is a long
column10: enveloping finale
column11: ""Amazonas""—25 minutes of shimmer and thrum
column12: hiccup and sigh. It is a sort of psychedelic aftershock to the sober meditations that have come before
column13: and it feels like an answer to a question that Carlson asks in ""Scene 2"": ""Why always the need to explain everything
column14: and from every angle? Everything so endlessly questioned
column15: understood
column16: disassembled
column17: until one wants to do more—but no longer can."" To do more
column18: in the context of Miscontinuum Album
column19:
is simply to listen. It is more than enough; it is the be-all and end-all.

column1: Texturally
column2: the music bears some similarity to bits found on Drukqs
column3: specifically the prepared piano tracks that contrasted with that album's more frenetic breakbeat excursions. ""Jynweythek Ylow""
column4: ""Strotha Tynhe""
column5: and ""Penty Harmomium"" are clear antecedents to the music found here
column6: but Acoustic Instruments takes those ideas further. Piano
column7: prepared and otherwise
column8: features heavily
column9: but so do various drums and wood and metal percussion instruments. And where James used to offer his electro-acoustic pieces as a showcase for lyrical melodies
column10: about half the music here consists of crisply arranged beats
column11: with loping drum lines that occasionally veer toward funk.

column1: The most striking thing about Computer Controlled Acoustic Instruments pt2 (the title is a typical James puzzle—no word of where Pt 1 may be) is how directly his musical concerns can be mapped on to another context. The grooves
column2: the de-tuned melodies
column3: the bridges
column4: the way rhythms can lag a split second behind the beat—all are signatures of his electronic work and all are found here intact. A good point of comparison demonstrating how difficult this must be is Acoustica: Alarm Will Sound Performs Aphex Twin
column5: an album from a decade ago that found the new music ensemble tackling some of James’ better-known compositions. The skeleton of tunes like ""4"" and ""Meltphace 6"" was there
column6: but the sense of movement was way off. Here
column7: we can hear the person and the sensibility behind the sounds.

column1: On some tracks
column2: you can almost hear their electronic counterparts. ""diskhat1"" features clipped drums with a steady hi-hat and a prepared piano riff that sounds dissonant to the point of seeming alien. ""hat5c 0001 rec–4"" is constructed with similar tools but uses a piano motif from the bass clef to give it the anxious feel of a tightly-sequenced synth. ""piano un10 it happened"" can be filed with James’ most delicate and beautiful pieces
column3: one of those effortless melodies that vanishes into the air right around the time you start thinking about the Windham Hill catalog. Indeed
column4: brevity is key: Acoustic Instruments is the perfect length—28 minutes long
column5: 13 tracks
column6: with about half fully fleshed out and the others serving as sketches—for this sort of treatment. James has a handful of ideas
column7: he comes in and executes them perfectly
column8: and then he gets out.

column1: If Syro was a re-introduction for James
column2: a way to put his music in front of people who didn’t know or follow along with his earlier work
column3: Computer Controlled Acoustic Instruments pt2 is a release for established fans
column4: people who want to know what his pieces would sound like in an altogether different setting. So while the EP feels like it can be connected to other music (it’s easy to draw lines to gamelan music and kinetic film scores)
column5: the greatest pleasure comes in knowing where it came from and how it came to be. It’s an Aphex Twin EP more than just an EP
column6:
and as those go it’s very good.

To put on a Doomtree record is to commit to a certain amount of intense collective energy. Anything much more than that—left-field lyricism
column2: hooks that sink their claws into you
column3: a collection of beats that cohere into some loose future-is-now synthesis of electronic hip-hop—is a bonus

column5: where calls to get on their level meant promises of camaraderie more than challenges for competition. And yet they pull weight when they make those calls to arms omnidirectional
column6: ricocheting off each member and filling the room with all these different levels of signal-obscuring noise that make even the matter-of-fact stuff feel enigmatic.

column1: In other words

column3: no matter how big that circle's designed to get. A big-in-Minnesota cult act that's taken both local roots and global possibilities to heart
column4: Doomtree's hard-earned success has built-in safeguards against complacency and predictability. For one thing

And their new album All Hands bears out some of that urge to hit a reset button that doubles as a fast-forward.

column1: Written in a cabin with dicey-at-best cellular reception
column2: All Hands feels cut off from most of the world outside their own universe. It's a blessing and a curse keeping a collaborative relationship between seven different artists—with five of them being MCs
column3: and two of those MCs contributing beats alongside their two regular producers
column4: it's both kind of amazing and really understandable how they've all been able to both maintain and move ahead without imploding after more than a decade. The complementary pieces are all keystones here
column5: and stylistic variety—the focused punk-vibe grit-and-grind of P.O.S.
column6: Dessa's smooth venom

column8: Sims and Mike Mictlan rounding out the rewind-demanding punchline barrage—is what keeps the album alive even when the words start to blur.

column1: Which they do
column2: often. You can pick out the mood-setting references if you want: ""Final Boss"" has Sims paraphrasing The Karate Kid and finding stressed empathy with decline-era Kobe; P.O.S steers the vigilante study "".38 Airweight"" with the art-imitates-life-imitates-art invocation of Bernhard Goetz and Charles Bronson (the latter not for the first time); Dessa rattles through a breathless itinerary on ""The Bends"" that sounds like instructions to an undercover fugitive. But each line feels more like a disconnected thought strung together in a more allusive whole

column4: which in itself stands for their own ready-to-bolt restlessness

column6: dragging the chain/ Anchor's off
column7: man
column8: lost it again"") to Sims' dichotomy-driven jokes (""I'm really real
column9: half Built to Spill half Kill at Will"").

column1: So as you draw in messages that are more atmospheric than direct

column6:
there's nothin' but bones left.""

The Body and Thou must get bored easily. During the last decade
column3: both of these delirious doom metal squads have issued records at startling clips

column1: The six-song set is available as a limited-edition record through Thrill Jockey

column3: however

The results are included here not as a prequel but as a necessary companion to the recent arrivals. Those Southern sessions made it clear that this is a painful and powerful fit for complementary brutes. Perhaps because of their economical configuration
column6: the Body often affixes parts that aren’t noise
column7: drums
column8: guitars
column9: or screams to the ends and beginnings of songs. The more versatile Thou
column10: however
column11: allow for more engrained subtlety. During opener ""The Wheel Weaves as the Wheel Wills""
column12: Thou’s Bryan Funck delivers imprecations in his deep
column13: full scream. Behind him
column14: the Body’s Chip King squeals like a wounded animal
column15: his high pitch offering a sliver of contrast to the mid-range
column16: mid-tempo melee. A later cover of Vic Chesnutt’s ""Coward"" seems as terrifying for the singers as it does for the listener. In his raspy falsetto
column17: King yells the opening lines like a death cry. The band builds behind Funck as he bellows the chorus—""I
column18: I
column19: I
column20: I
column21: I
column22: I am a coward""—until they collapse in exhaustion around the sound of that last word. A counter-riff adds drama to the stentorian march of ""In Meetings Hearts Beat Closer""
column23: while mutated bridges afford misdirection to the aptly named ""Manifest Alchemy"". Thou and the Body could be wider and wilder together than separately.

column2: the second batch hits hardest when these two bands land as one. There’s perhaps no better example than their reverent but explosive take on Nine Inch Nails’ ""Terrible Lie"". The crews reanimate the industrial architecture of the original
column3: with guitars and bass turning the melody into a mess of forceful chords and corrosive feedback. And the beat gets massive
column4: punched down as if both drummers were born wielding sledgehammers. The sound is as colossal as the Body’s but as sharp and severe as Thou’s—a combination that makes the 1989 template feel
column5: by comparison
column6: like little more than a stripped skeleton. Though ""The Devils of Trust Steal the Souls of the Free"" begins like the Body with more guitars or Thou with more drums
column7: it captivates when King and Funck again split vocals. The song’s commandments
column8: like ""Reach out and find nothing
column9: only get shocking when it seems as though the whole world were yelling them at once. The pair slips when the results are expected
column10: as if you’re listening to two bands play the same song at once rather than finesse the parts as one unit. ""Her Strongholds Unvanquishable"" and ""Lurking Free"" both stumble toward that mire

column1: But those are aberrations for this collusion. Taken as a full-length by two groups that treat the format with some suspicion

column3: Whom I Have Always Hated is a remarkably cohesive and singular album. Though it shows signs of both responsible parties

column5: as they’re both willing to bend toward one another to create something richer than they might have rendered themselves. It’s important that <i>You
column6: Whom I Have Always Hated marks the shortest effective span between successive LPs from either the Body or Thou. Perhaps together
column7:
they can continue to avoid boredom.

To hear Ethan Miller tell it
column2: Howlin Rain hit rock bottom after leaving American Recordings

column11: less Dead than Joplin at her booziest

column13: he’s bellowing ostentatiously

column1: Mansion Songs ends with the seven-minute ""Ceiling Fan""

""There are records I have found in my life that I was almost wishing existed before hearing them."" So writes Four Tet’s Kieran Hebden in the liner notes to this reissue of a rare piece from Italian percussionist/minimalist composer Lino Capra Vaccina. Hebden goes on to cite totemic albums like Alice Coltrane’s spiritual jazz masterpiece Journey to Satchidananda and Don Cherry’s world music forbearer Organic Music Society as these sorts of ""idealized"" concepts
column3: adding Vaccina’s 1978 album Antico Adagio to that short list.

column1: Out of print for decades
column2: the punctilious Italian label Die Schachtel now reissues Vaccina’s debut album along with another half-hour of previously unheard compositions making for nearly 70 minutes of glorious
column3: shimmering minimalism. It would not be remiss to think of Antico Adagio as the slightly more European cousin to Steve Reich’s flawless Music for 18 Musicians
column4: taken with the infinite patterns that can be rendered from percussion and metallophones. In the past few years
column5: there’s been a deluge of bell-like sounds—either acoustic or computer-generated—with producers like Four Tet
column6: Caribou
column7: Gold Panda
column8: Jon Hopkins
column9: and Pantha du Prince deploying them. It’s the kind of pure tone that serves as connection between a particular strain of American minimalism of the 1970s and modern electronic music
column10: making extant the lineage between the two disciplines. So while this album will find fans of the former
column11: those who favor the latter will also have such struck metal resonate.

column1: Rather than the crack ensemble who performed Reich’s music
column2: most of Antico Adagio is rendered by Vaccina alone
column3: who is credited with vibraphone
column4: marimba
column5: tablas
column6: darbuke
column7: gong
column8: cymbals
column9: bells
column10: metal sheets
column11: tom
column12: and snare. Smatterings of other sounds like oboe
column13: violin and female voices also mix in and it never quite feels like the work of one lone drummer banging on metal. Carefully layering these voices
column14: there are moments that bring to mind Gregorian chants and Tuvan throat singing
column15: or when '60s psychedelic acts cast their voices in massive amounts of echo to suggest the blackness of deep space.

column1: In the CD notes
column2: Vaccina calls his approach to music-making ""sound ecology
column3: talking about how free improvised concerts in public spaces in the late 1960s and the examples of American minimalists Glass and Reich—the latter’s Drumming a touchstone—led him to the making of this album. Openers ""Elegia"" and ""Voice in XY"" most closely resemble Reich’s layers of percussion
column4: which move from snowflake-contemplative to dizzying in a few minutes
column5: the pulsing rhythms evoking visions of crystal lattices and the kinds of sprockets and clockworks one might have glimpsed in Hugo.

column1: But the album does more than merely reflect the example of Reich
column2: venturing from such resplendent
column3: beautiful moments into darker
column4: more gnarled terrain. On experimental pieces like ""Chants of the Spheres"" and ""Fragments of Sleep""
column5: percussion mixes in with voice and the music more closely resembles the likes of This Heat and Pink Floyd’s ""A Saucerful of Secrets"". The careful pacing of the ten-minute title track moves with gentle grace. At some moments it reminds me of Pharoah Sanders’s Tauhid and jazz vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson; at others of a Javanese gamelan performance in a royal court. But many times
column6:
Vaccina’s music sounds like something beyond your imagination.

Natalie Prass is not history ripped from a black-and-white photo
column2: but a real
column3: living person. She crafts slow-burning soul music indebted to singers like Dolly Parton
column4: Dusty Springfield
column5: and Jenny Lewis (with whom she toured as a backing vocalist)
column6: and she makes her home in Nashville
column7: where she settled after stints in Cleveland
column8: Virginia Beach
column9: and Boston’s Berklee College of Music. (She dropped out after only a year because she thought the city was too big.) In Richmond
column10: Va.
column11: she found her people at Spacebomb Records
column12: the label run by retro revivalist and high school friend Matthew E. White. He and producer Trey Pollard hooked her up with the Spacebomb house band
column13: and helped craft her debut album
column14: Natalie Prass
column15: around luxuriant string-and-horn-heavy instrumentation to give her smoldering perspective on passionate romance some pomp and circumstance.

column1: When the album opens
column2: Prass is telling us she doesn’t feel much
column3: which would sound more like a joke if her voice didn't sound so somber. Natalie Prass is an album of relationships troubled by misunderstandings
column4: of earnest lovers caught in the claws of the unmerciful. She sounds lighter than air as she sings lyrics devastating in their economy
column5: addressing someone who ""plucked me from the vine"" on ""Bird of Prey"" and later telling someone else (or the same person?) ""I just want to know you violently"" on ""Violently"". The latter reminds me of Sharon Van Etten’s ""Your Love Is Killing Me""—the songs even share a similar lyric about having their legs broken so they won’t walk to someone all wrong for them. (Yikes!)

column1: But Prass sounds positively uplifted as the band swells over her lovesick harmonies
column2: forgoing any tortured abnegation. There’s idealism in her voice that’s tempered by heartbreak without falling prey to cynicism—like the bitterness has been skimmed off the top
column3: leaving an evergreen sweetness. In an interview with Grantland
column4: Prass said the record was completed in early 2012. ""Violently"" dates as far back as 2009
column5: when she was still in college. What’s remarkable is how the songwriting coheres into one vision
column6: even as Prass herself must’ve changed over the years. Recently
column7: Run the Jewels participated in Rookie’s ""Ask a Grown Man"" video series
column8: where they doled out advice on life and love to teenage girls. During one question
column9: Killer Mike said that love should feel good—that it shouldn’t hurt. Fine advice for hormonal romantics just starting out
column10: but anyone with an ounce of life experience knows it doesn’t work that way.

column1: Natalie Prass is officially the work of nearly three-dozen musicians
column2: most of whom played horns or strings for Spacebomb’s house band. (Prass has called the record ""a community."") The arrangements were handled by White and Pollard
column3: and they’re crucial. Without those horns and strings
column4: the repeated refrain of ""our love is a long goodbye"" toward the end of ""My Baby Don’t Understand Me"" wouldn’t percolate to a rolling boil before exploding in that final
column5: devastating delivery. Still
column6: it would be unwise to think that any old singer-songwriter would work with this band behind them. What makes Natalie Prass is her confident delivery amidst so many unconfident feelings—the way she nimbly skips over the verses on ""Bird of Prey""
column7: or walks along the groove on ""Why Don’t You Believe in Me"". She sounds comfortable and in charge
column8: wielding her massive band like a wizard’s scepter.

column1: Prass is most impressive working within the biggest instrumentation
column2: where her emotional precision acts as a counterweight for all the textural grandiosity. The songs where the drums don’t do the driving
column3: like ""Christy"" or ""It Is You""
column4: raise the question of what the album would sound like were she a more bombastic singer
column5: capable of blowing out speakers. Prass herself seems aware of her limitations. ""I don’t think I’m the most talented musician or the best singer
column6: but I work really
column7: really hard
column8: she told Pitchfork. ""And sometimes these random things happen
column9: and it makes you keep going."" As mantras go
column10: ""I’m not the best but I work really hard"" isn’t the type to get turned into a Tumblr macro
column11: but the result makes Natalie Prass a warm
column12:
intimate debut album that leaves space for darker contemplation—those stray thoughts that light you up at the end of the night.

"|20088.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20088-natalie-prass/|8.3|Jeremy Gordon

column1: The scattershot nature of No One Is $afe is initially appealing but grows tiresome. He makes a case for psychedelics as the party drug of choice on ""$hroom Party"" over the muted horns of the young producer Brandon Thomas. He moves between the opposite ends of 2014 Atlanta in the gleefully downtrodden ""H.O.M.E."" with iLoveMakonnen and the frantic darkness of OG Maco on ""ALLAU$"". There is even a track
column2: ""T Jame$ Expre$$""
column3: which sounds like blog house
column4: but novelty can't sustain it. For all those odd turns
column5: the heavily trap ""Only N Atlanta"" with Offset of Migos and Peewee Longway is the tape’s highlight
column6: as the trio brags about spending racks at Lennox Square Mall and Phipps Plaza
column7: two of Atlanta’s landmarks of capitalism. As Trinidad moves through typical rap tropes (sex talk
column8: putting down other rappers) and repeatedly falls flat
column9: he ultimately sounds overextended. He may care about fashion and the people around him
column10:
but on No One Is $afe he struggles to find where the music fits into his life these days.

Even by his prolific standards
column2: it has been a busy couple of years for Scottish singer-songwriter Alasdair Roberts. There was A Wonder Working Stone
column3: the 2013 album billed to his group Alasdair Roberts & Friends
column4: and Hirta Songs
column5: his full-length collaboration with poet Robin Robertson. Then last year saw At Our Next Meeting
column6: the excellent debut album of traditional folk ballads by his new group the Furrow Collective. So it seems noteworthy that
column7: after all of these various collaborations
column8: his latest Drag City album comes self-billed and self-titled. Often when such a veteran artist releases an eponymous album it is for purposes of redefinition
column9: but Alasdair Roberts feels more like a simple re-centering
column10: and a paring back of his music to the purest essentials.

column1: As most of his recent work should make abundantly clear
column2: Roberts creates folk music without much need for any additional prefixes or modifiers. It has long been his practice to balance his original songs with a deep appreciation for the traditional folk of the British Isles and
column3: as the Furrow Collective have put it
column4: ""balladry at its darkest and quirkiest."" On Alasdair Roberts he sticks exclusively with original material
column5: although a simple scan of the song titles (""The Mossy Shrine""
column6: ""The Final Diviner"") might camouflage that fact. Compared to such previous solo works as 2009’s Spoils
column7: and certainly to the more raucous group work on A Wonder Working Stone
column8: Roberts’ songs here are quieter and simpler
column9: and his language less ornate. And while all of Roberts’ music
column10: even at its most traditional
column11: has sounded unique and intimate it has seldom sounded this personal.

column1: Although these songs are more concise
column2: Roberts retains an abiding love for dense lyricism
column3: internal rhyme schemes
column4: and melodies that wind their way along like wild vines gradually unspooling over stony ruins. And his keening Scottish brogue remains as rich as fresh cream
column5: so any attempt to fully interpret his lyrics with American ears is a pathway to misadventure. But from where I sit
column6: songs such as ""Artless One"" and ""This Uneven Thing"" might stand as the barest
column7: most undisguised love songs in Roberts’ catalog. The latter is an especially affecting lament of long distance or unrequited romance
column8: and it’d take a steely soul to not be moved when Roberts sings ""If I had known before we courted that love would be this uneven thing/ I’d have packed my heart in box of iron and chained it down with a leaden ring.""

column1: It should be noted that although Roberts gets solo billing here he is far from alone. On nearly every song his voice and nimble guitar lines are joined by Alex South’s clarinet and Donald Lindsay’s tin whistle
column2: as well as backing vocals from singing quartet the Crying Lion. The presence of so much tin whistle
column3: in fact
column4: might be a stumbling block for listeners who associate the instrument with too many bad St. Patrick’s Day memories or the Titanic soundtrack. This is no fault of Lindsay
column5: however
column6: and here the wind instruments add undeniable atmosphere and do much of the heavy melodic lifting on more rambling tunes like the ruminative ""Hurricane Brown"".

column1: Elsewhere on the album Roberts seems to take a step back to address the state of folk music itself and the role of the artist in a troubled world. Throughout the record he sides with the underdogs and the outsiders who choose to take
column2: as one title puts
column3: ""The Way Unfavoured"".  On the closing ""Roomful of Relics"" he describes the loneliness of the folklorist’s life. ""Men have withdrawn and left me alone in a roomful of relics
column4: he sings in what seems a combination of pride and chagrin
column5: ""but I carry the song that all men inherit."" And as this album shows once again
column6: that inherited tradition is very safe in Alasdair Roberts’ expert hands
column7:
and it is treated here with an uncommon tenderness and simplicity of vision.

""When the train is coming through
column2: you better get on board."" So says José Pascual
column3: of Antwerp's USA Import shop
column4: in The Sound of Belgium
column5: a fascinating 2012 documentary about the country's remarkable club scene—or scenes
column6: really
column7: going all the way back to the ""mirror balls"" of the post-war years
column8: with their punchcard-controlled organs. He's talking specifically about the boom mentality that accompanied New Beat
column9: an electronic-music craze that gripped the nation in the years between 1986 and 1989.

column1: The sound of New Beat is relatively easy to describe. A homegrown strain that borrowed from new wave
column2: EBM
column3: and Chicago acid
column4: it was dark
column5: menacing
column6: sensually severe
column7: and distinguished largely by its torpid chug of a pulse. New Beat stemmed
column8: in part
column9: from Belgian DJs' propensity to play records at the wrong speed. The genre's foundational track is said to be A Split-Second's 1986 single ""Flesh""
column10: played at 33 RPM instead of 45. (Incredibly
column11: this turns out not to have been an entirely new concept: Belgian DJs pioneered the technique in the so-called ""Popcorn"" scene of the 1970s
column12: playing obscure American soul 45s from the 1950s and '60s at 33 RPM
column13: pitched up to +8. The result was to make the songs sound deeper
column14: fuller
column15: and just a little bit off
column16: but not exaggeratedly so—disorienting
column17: but not distorted.)

column1: Adherents of the movement describe New Beat's effects in rapturous terms. It was slow enough that you could dance to it all night without tiring
column2: and without drugs (although drugs
column3: we can assume
column4: were definitely a part of the mix). The bass did weird things at slower tempos
column5: its frequencies greasy and swollen; spine-tingling electronic timbres and undulating acid lines added to the music's hypnotic properties. In the film
column6: Renaat Vandepapeliere
column7: founder of the R&S label
column8: describes the Boccaccio
column9: a Belgian nightclub that served as the high temple of New Beat
column10: as ""a dark inferno… a slowed-down movie."" The veteran Dutch DJ Eddy De Clercq says of the club
column11: ""It was cramped and eerie. But that's what the DJ was looking for—this uncomfortable
column12: grisly atmosphere.""

column1: New Beat was an underground phenomenon in the sense that commercial radio wouldn't touch it
column2: but it was wildly successful. Money flooded the scene; anything with ""New Beat"" stamped on the cover would sell
column3: and sell in astonishing numbers. Even ho-hum singles could shift 30
column4: 000 copies—no small feat for a country of 10 million. (In adjusted terms
column5: in the United States—which then had a population of 244 million—that would equate to selling 782
column6: 000 copies.) Popular singles were moving as many as 60
column7: 000 units
column8: equivalent to platinum certification in the United States
column9: all without any commercial airplay. ""Bands"" like Erotic Dissidents
column10: whose performance consisted entirely of lip-synching
column11: earned the equivalent of 1000 euros for 20 minutes on stage. With those kinds of numbers in play
column12: producers with no connection to the underground club scene began to churn out New Beat. It was easy to make
column13: after all; all you needed was a synthesizer and a drum machine. (Having even a modicum of musical theory gave you a vast advantage over most of your competition.) As the frenzy built up steam
column14: it came to resemble the Dutch tulip mania 350 years prior. As one producer tells the filmmakers
column15: ""We had to act fast
column16: because we knew it wouldn't last. It was much too unreal.""

column1: Rembert De Smet doesn't appear in The Sound of Belgium
column2: but he was one of New Beat's fellow travelers. Even the press release for a new anthology of his work paints the former new waver (and eventual flamenco guitarist) as something of a bandwagon-jumper: ""Producing without a pause and getting the music out the week after was the plan
column3: as one knew that this lucrative era wouldn't last forever."" In the early and mid '80s
column4: De Smet was a member of the duo 2 Belgen (""2 Belgians"")
column5: a synth-pop act that found reasonable success at home but never broke internationally. As the new style took off
column6: however
column7: he adopted the name Ro Maron and began releasing New Beat tracks under a dizzying array of further aliases
column8: both solo and in collaboration with producers like Ferre Baelen and Jean-Lou Nowé. Collected #1 gathers the work of 20 of those assorted aliases—acts like Zsa Zsa LaBoum
column9: Air of Gloom
column10: Kaos 007
column11: 2 Body's (sic)
column12: Trance Trax
column13: Beat Beat Beat—the bulk of which was recorded between 1988 and 1990.

column1: If you're familiar with EBM and early acid house
column2: the tropes here won't be entirely unfamiliar. Track after track is built out of brittle drum-machine programming and squelchy
column3: rubbery acid sequences. Handclaps claw through clammy reverb like fingers scrabbling against moss-slicked dungeon walls
column4: and the programmed drum beats lurch with zombie-like stiffness (a sensation heightened by drill-sergeant chants of ""Left
column5: right
column6: left
column7: right
column8: left
column9: right
column10: left!"" that kick off the very second song). The music is for the most part instrumental: there are no lyrics
column11: just sampled mantras repeated ad nauseam (""Welcome to my acid house
column12: ""Gimme some acid
column13: ""A la recherché du temps perdue
column14: etc.)
column15: and chemical mischief bubbles to the surface in songs like ""Brainkiller""
column16: which cribs its bassline from ""White Lines"" and mutters about ""pleasure area[s] in the brain.""

column1: At 35 tracks and three hours long
column2: it's an enormous amount of material to wrap one's head around
column3: but a lot of it turns out to be pretty great. The gnarled acid and wet-cardboard kick drum of 2 Body's ""Body Drill"" wouldn't be out of place on the L.I.E.S. label today. SM's ""SM""
column4: with its sampled yelps and fidgety
column5: chromatic arpeggios
column6: balances industrial grit with the more playful funk of contemporary groups like Colourbox. Sleepwalker's ""All Jazz"" features a killer squarewave bass line that anticipates Biosphere's ""Novelty Waves"".  Those kinds of reference points are all over the collection
column7: a reminder that while he may have been an outsider and an opportunist
column8: De Smet's work was deeply enmeshed in a dance-music tradition that stretches backwards and forwards across generations. I don't think it would be a stretch to call him a pioneer: he may not have invented the acid techniques and rhythmic tropes that pepper his music
column9: but his work overflows with vision and unique character.

column1: Even on the most pro-forma genre studies
column2: like Sleepwalker's proto-deep-house ""Sleepwalker""
column3: there's something about the odd proportions—the synthesized sax line that's just a little bit too loud; the vocal line that sounds better suited for a Factory release—that distinguishes it from its peers. ""Cute Acid"" is another one that grabs your attention for the way it conjures a kind of temporal Uncanny Valley: if you heard it in a nightclub
column4: you'd be hard-pressed to say whether it was a vintage cut or a brand-new production. It vaguely reminds me of Bradley's Robot
column5: a record Aphex Twin released under the Bradley Strider alias in 1993
column6: but its nimble percussion
column7: bright colors
column8: and birdsong timbres—the title ""Cute Acid"" was certainly well chosen—sound unlike anything I've heard before.

column1: The Sound of Belgium's filmmakers make a good case that New Beat deserves more attention than it has received until now. The genre's main components may have been invented in Chicago and Detroit
column2: but New Beat came so close on their heels that the genre should be seen less as a mere imitation of African-American electronic music
column3: and more a crucial node in a conversation that bounced back and forth across oceans and borders. (Many riffs from New Beat and early Belgian rave music would become staples of the U.K.'s breakbeat hardcore.) From a contemporary perspective
column4: it's clear that De Smet's work
column5: as commercially motivated as it may have been
column6: helped expand the possibilities for this eerie
column7: not-quite-underground music on the cusp of conquering the world. The history of dance music is full of missing pieces
column8: and Collected #1 offers up 35 of them. It's a mixed bag
column9:
but sorting through the remnants is a blast.

column1: However

But the cassette issue amounts to more than just a contrarian act of antiquated-format fetishism—it’s actually the most appropriate medium through which to experience the two
column5: half-hour suites that comprise Seltzer.

column1: In essence
column2: Seltzer is an ultra-exclusive document of an ultra-exclusive performance. Its first half is pulled from an April 2013 event that saw Peals debut a new improvised work—amid projections by artist Zoe Friedman—in the extremely cramped clock room of Baltimore’s historic Bromo Seltzer Arts Tower
column3: a former antacid dispensary that’s been converted into studio spaces. But even in the absence of Friedman’s visuals and the room’s <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KwLT0SmXEU4"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">imposing
column4: industrialized innards
column5: the piece—boasting the prophetically McConaughey-esque title of ""Time Is a Milk Bowl""—exudes a vivid sense of place. More hazy and vaporous than the melancholic reveries of Walking Field
column6: this sweetly serene symphony of glimmering glockenspiels
column7: tranquil tremolos
column8: and aquatic Eno-esque ambience is tuned to the pervasive hum of the clock motors (in the key of G
column9: Peals note) while using the intrusive clatter of the building’s old elevator mechanism to signal sectional shifts. Fenced in by the room’s four giant clock-faced walls
column10: Peals are surrounded by oppressive reminders of time’s passage
column11: yet patiently play as if totally oblivious to it. But after 25 minutes of slowly layered swells
column12: Willen and Cashion build up a tick-tock rhythm and intertwining guitar melodies into a cheery
column13: chiming melodic passage that reorients this amorphous movement toward a linear and satisfyingly ascendant finale.

column1: If ""Time Is a Milk Bowl"" feels like the sort of high-quality cassette bootleg that would’ve been a prized tradable commodity in the pre-Internet era
column2: Seltzer’s second piece
column3: ""Before and After""
column4: indulges in another of the format’s popular uses: the mixtape collage. The track stitches together a career-spanning cache of unearthed demos

column9: nor strike the same emotional chords as Walking Field
column10: ""Before and After"" is an intermittently engaging

And its scattered presentation more explicitly reinforces a quality that Willen and Cashion’s more subtly evolutionary work only hints at: that
column13: for a stridently mellow band with no rhythm section
column14:
Peals are a restless beast.

While it’d be wrong to say it’s for the best that Vulnicura was leaked then rush-released—no one in Björk’s position would welcome that—the leak does her an inadvertent service: it makes Vulnicura the first Björk album in years to come into the world untethered by museum exhibitions

For legal reasons
column2: Ejecta
column3: a mystical alien everywoman embodied by Leanne Macomber and given a soundtrack by producer Joel Ford
column4: now goes by Young Ejecta. At the risk of sounding a little like the pair have wandered into the rap game
column5: the new name works; ""ejecta"" is the word for the dust that falls after a volcano erupts or a meteorite strikes the earth. Fresh dust implies a recent impact
column6: and so does the duo's new record
column7: The Planet
column8: which sees Macomber reeling from heartbreak and trauma.

column1: The EP's near-title track ""Your Planet"" is an ode to Macomber's close friend who died at 20. To mourn him
column2: she imagined him in his own
column3: new world
column4: looking fondly down at Earth like a lost Little Prince laughing among the stars. ""You were the only one who ever loved me
column5: she intones on the track
column6: while Ford transitions from celestial organ to an outer space dance party bass line. In mourning there's also celebration
column7: and ""Your Planet"" gently wraps its tendrils around both.

column1: Ford
column2: who's known for collaborating with Oneohtrix Point Never as half of Ford & Lopatin
column3: enjoys testing the edges of tastefulness with cheap-sounding synth patches. Like the PC Music tricksters
column4: he's interested in that porous boundary between cool and corny
column5: and he oscillates all over it here. It works and it doesn't; ""Your Planet"" feels appropriately sci-fi and sad
column6: and the blushing pop opener ""Into Your Heart"" pounds with all the adrenaline of a brand new crush. But the chirpy bass on ""All Day"" tends to meander without an endgame
column7: cartoony and brash next to Macomber's delicate singing.

column1: When Young Ejecta nail in a song
column2: they nail it clean. ""Into Your Heart"" blooms with the best of them as Macomber's long melodic phrases spiral out of the atmosphere
column3: while Ford's club bass and drum beat rattle like a star fighter out of hell. ""Is there any way I can dive into your heart?"" wonders Macomber
column4: her voice dry and double-tracked
column5: unsheathed from the reverb that clouded Ejecta's debut Dominae. Ford's quaking backbeat compounds the question's anxiety. The stakes are high
column6: and Young Ejecta swoops to meet them with grace.

column1: Macomber emotes better without those effects
column2: but her newly clean singing can feel at odds with Ford's harshly synthetic compositions. She's a subtle vocalist
column3: giving a light touch to lyrics about lazy days spent masturbating on ""Welcome to Love"". When Ford's fake
column4: fake strings enter the chorus
column5: it muddies the effect. Macomber wraps self-deprecation
column6: frustration
column7: and pure yearning into the way she sings just a few words
column8: and Ford struggles to match that complexity. The two musicians match well in terms of overall ethos
column9: but at some points it feels like they just stopped listening to each other
column10:
and what should be otherworldly comes clunking to the ground.

""I'm an old punk
column2: Lena Willikens told Germany's Groove magazine last year. ""For me
column3: everything needs to have edges
column4: corners and rough surfaces."" To that list
column5: I'd add frayed wires
column6: tarnished metal
column7: and greasy ball bearings: whatever the Cologne DJ pulls out of her bag
column8: from contemporary dance music to krautrock B-sides
column9: tends to sound like it's been salvaged from a scrap heap. Maybe that battered
column10: lived-in quality is related to the fact that everything she plays also needs to have a story—or at least
column11: it tends to have one by the time she's done with it.

column1: For her monthly Radio Cómeme show ""Sentimental Flashback""
column2: Willikens puts together astonishingly diverse selections around themes both idiosyncratic and hyper-specific. One early show spotlit ""the dark side of my record collection
column3: focusing on the time period between '77 and '84""; she has gone on to make tributes to female electronic music pioneers like Delia Derbyshire and Daphne Oram; West African music from the '70s; minimal wave and post-punk; and cosmic disco
column4: redefined. (""Do you remember? Some years ago there was a cosmic disco revival
column5: she asked at the outset of the program. ""That time I asked myself what is cosmic? After listening to Baldelli's mixtapes
column6: I think I've got the idea: play emotional
column7: and fuck genre borders. I like that idea."") And while her club sets may not be as rigorously thematic
column8: they are said to be every bit as daring; her residency at Düsseldorf's Salon des Amateurs has contributed to its reputation as one of dance music's most progressive venues.

column1: Phantom Delia is Willikens' debut EP. Co-produced by Matias Aguayo
column2: it's in line with the aesthetic of his label
column3: Cómeme—dark but playful
column4: modestly mid-fi but full of attitude—but this is clearly Willikens' show. She may have released little of her own music before now
column5: but her aesthetic arrives fully formed. There are multiple inspirations audible here
column6: but they all revolve around primitive electronics: there are the rudimentary thuds and drones of the early synth-pop known retrospectively as ""minimal wave
column7: and there's the sultry machine sex of groups like Detroit's A Number of Names
column8: of the foundational proto-techno single ""Sharevari"". Towering above both styles is the figure of Delia Derbyshire
column9: the record's presumable namesake
column10: whose pioneering work for the BBC Radiophonic Workshop was enormously important in popularizing early electronic music. (Renowned for both her technological and artistic acumen
column11: Derbyshire
column12: who died in 2001
column13: is also remembered as a feminist icon: upon graduating college
column14: she applied to work at Decca Records
column15: only to be told that they didn't hire women. That her music would go on to become so universally known
column16: even if her name was not—who hasn't heard her theme for ""Dr. Who""?—feels like vindication
column17: to say the least.)

column1: ""Howlin Lupus"" opens the record on an ominous note
column2: as foghorn bleats tangle with wolf howls over typewriter clatter and minor-key throb. It's got it all
column3: really: a danceable beat
column4: a widescreen sense of drama
column5: and rich
column6: resonant sonics evocative of copper wires and glowing tubes. On ""Nilpferd""—that's German for ""hippopotamus""—detuned oscillators buzz and squeal while monotone muttering dissolves into deadpan laughter; it sounds like a bad trip in a concrete bunker
column7: a real Cold War hangover. Her sound design comes to the fore on ""Asphalt Kobold""
column8: in which plucked tones thumb-wrestle with synthetic mouth harp. At the center of it all
column9: a glassy bauble of a rimshot sound stands out as if presented upon a velvet pillow; it suggests coldwave aesthetics as a pinnacle of electrical engineering
column10: a feat of design comparable with Braun's legendarily sober
column11: streamlined gizmos.

column1: ""Mari Ori"" is all hopped up on Halloween vibes; wind whistles through the cracks of its drum programming
column2: and the tremolo lead shivers as though terrified. (It comes as no surprise to learn that Willikens also plays Theremin.) Even on her clubbiest tracks
column3: her touch is distinct from virtually everyone else working in dance music; it has to do with the way she uses drums as accents rather than pulse-keeping devices. That's especially true on ""Noya Noya"" and ""Howlin Lupus""
column4: with their stumbling kick drums and stabbing white noise. She's also got a real way with counterpoints
column5: which she braids like pliable icicles
column6: each strand chillier than the next—well
column7: unless thawing's your chosen metaphor
column8: in which case look to the slow dissolution of the beatless closing track
column9: ""Phantom Delia""
column10: a steady stream of sawtoothed frequencies seeping deep into the firmament. It is
column11: after all
column12: a kind of roots music—simply of a revisionist strain
column13:
bearing a mutant fruit that's been decades in the making.

The most celebrated figures of early 1990s alternative rock were enigmas and iconoclasts
column2: tortured souls or wayward poets raging against machines that weren’t always clearly defined. Not every member of the Alternative Nation bled for their art
column3: however. Behind the genre’s complicated stars were bands less interested in challenging the establishment than in just making cool noises with their guitars
column4: acts like Superchunk
column5: Elastica
column6: and the Breeders. What these bands lacked in mystique
column7: they made up for through sheer sonic abundance
column8: amusing themselves with unfettered hooks
column9: giddy tempos
column10: and stylized riffing. With their fuzz-kicking guitars and modest attention spans
column11: those bands serve as the guiding inspiration for the young Leeds group Menace Beach
column12: whose full-length debut Ratworld bottles and concentrates the exuberance of that era's alterna-pop.

column1: Menace Beach are in good company mining these sounds. Over the last few years the same intersection of early '90s alternative and indie-rock has inspired vital releases from Speedy Ortiz
column2: Swearin’
column3: and Joanna Gruesome
column4: but Menace Beach are even more committed to their specific set of influences than those groups. Their closest peers
column5: in that sense
column6: are Yuck
column7: another band that's so fully internalized their record collection that their music becomes a form of roleplay. When singer/guitarist Ryan Needham merrily sings ""Fuck everything you ever wanted to be"" on Ratworld opener ""Come On Give Up""—flanked on backing vocals
column8: as he almost always is
column9: by his eager co-lead Liza Violet—he’s channeling every unassuming alt-rock singer who ever softened a barbed lyric with a chipper
column10: slightly dweeby delivery. Casual self-loathing was just as much a part of the fabric of '90s alternative as whimsical tonal juxtapositions
column11: and Menace Beach don’t shy from either.

column1: Like many of Leeds’ buzziest rock bands
column2: Menace Beach have ties to Hookworms leader Matthew ""MJ"" Johnson
column3: who produced their album at his increasingly busy Suburban Home Studios. Johnson also serves as a sometimes member of the band
column4: but little of Hookworms’ psychedelic menace carries through Ratworld. The only hints come from the warped organs piped into ""Dig It Up"" and ""Fortune Teller""
column5: and even those songs are so bombastically poppy that they go down easier than anything in Hookworms’ playbook. Johnson is smart to stay in the background
column6: rather than risk interrupting the simple
column7: sugary chemistry between Needham and Violet. They co-wrote the album together
column8: and Ratworld reaches puppyish levels of excitement every time one of its choruses unites them. Theirs is the rare lead vocalist/backing vocalist dynamic that feels like an equal partnership
column9: with Violet’s injections propelling these songs nearly as much as their rubbery bass lines or pogoing guitars.

column1: Violet takes just one solo lead on Ratworld
column2: and it’s the album’s biggest departure
column3: a song so personal she confided to Rookie its working title was ""This Is My Song""
column4: because she didn’t want anybody else to hear it. It's the record’s one moment of true vulnerability
column5: but like every song Menace Beach write
column6: it’s also an homage
column7: in this case to the smoldering
column8: reverb-saddened ballads of Galaxie 500. Here the familiarity that usually works in the band's favor cuts against them. When the song’s dreamy haze breaks into a shower of corroded guitars
column9: there’s no surprise; that’s how these kinds of Galaxie 500 appropriations always play out. On an album that otherwise so joyfully captures the exhilaration of alternative's recent past
column10:
it's one of the rare moments where Menace Beach's borrowed sounds don't deliver the same charge they did the first time around.
