column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21355/homepage_large.c79cf2e9.jpg|Viet Cong|32165.0|Viet Cong|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar'
column2:
'Flemish Eye']|2015-01-22 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:47.554286|"

Starting a band is easy; an actual career in indie rock is a much tougher proposition these days. Financial success seems harder and harder to come by and saying something new within the context of guitar based music might be even more difficult. Maybe you get to express yourself
column3: but what if you think music should aspire to something other than being a vehicle for your feelings? You’ll probably just get compared to bands who ceased to exist two decades ago. Viet Cong have clearly thought about this a lot in their brief period of existence
column4: most of which has been spent relentlessly touring in support of last year’s introductory EP ""Cassette"". But don’t let the deadpan song titles like ""Pointless Experience"" and ""March of Progress"" throw you: the Calgary band’s self-titled debut projects unbridled passion
column5: creativity
column6: and possibilities while speaking in a presumably dead language of post-punk.

column1: Their mission is not altogether different from that of Women
column2: the short-lived and sorely missed indie deconstructionists in which half of Viet Cong previously served. Women existed as a band that knew its impending expiration date
column3: operating in secrecy and driven by entropy. Their albums felt like black boxes
column4: reports of turbulence and panic captured on grimy tape in Chad VanGaalen’s basement. They were statues during live performances
column5: with the exception of their final show
column6: which ended in a violent fist fight. If not necessarily a pop band on ""Cassette""
column7: Viet Cong initially distinguished themselves with more extroverted
column8: less intriguing impulses—there were snappy radio rock songs and Bauhaus covers amongst the typically stonefaced gestures
column9: things that would lead you to believe that the death of guitarist Chris Reimer at 26 might have dissuaded them from trying to carry the same heft of Women.

column1: A year later
column2: Viet Cong are a cohesive and confident unit that goes even further into inaccessibility than Women
column3: confrontational in a way that reaches out to an audience rather than turning inward. The sound that begins Viet Cong most closely resembles someone trying to punch their way out of a coffin. The record ends with an 11-minute song called ""Death"". It is also a self-titled debut from a band named Viet Cong. So whether you’re familiar with their past or you’re just here because you’ve been hearing things about this band
column4: everyone is getting the same first impression: That of a very serious rock record that won’t offer too many cuddly points of self-disclosure. So
column5: in the moments where Viet Cong do reveal themselves
column6: you might want to pay attention.

column1: Two important instances occur during ""March of Progress""
column2: Viet Cong’s astonishing six-minute centerpiece. Matt Flegel could be mocking the speculative nature of music criticism and predictable
column3: tiresome process of ""proving"" one’s self in dazed
column4: layered harmony: ""Your reputation is preceding you/ We’re all sufficiently impressed/ And this incessant march of progress/ Can guarantee our sure success."" It proves Viet Cong are self-aware
column5: have a subzero sense of humor to match their environs
column6: and recognize those two qualities might combine to give the impression that this isn’t music that is meant to be enjoyed. That’s when the double-time beat kicks in
column7: and Viet Cong make a sprightly
column8: major-key sprint towards a dead halt. There’s mastery of form
column9: instrumental prowess
column10: and on a record that thrives on unpredictability
column11: ""March of Progress"" elicits the most unexpected response—that was fun.

column1: Viet Cong is full of knowing moments and reference points—the fact that it could pass for Guided by Voices (""Continental Shelf"")
column2: Wolf Parade (""Silhouettes"")
column3: and This Heat (take your pick) is enough of an accomplishment. It is not exactly a meta work
column4: however. Viet Cong are just a band that’s unusually obsessed with the mechanics and process of their given trade. While their ashen sonics and rigid demeanor is liable to have them labeled as post-punk
column5: they’re also industrial in a literal sense. Flegel’s vocals are those of a foreman
column6: authoritative
column7: commanding and prodding. Guitars often sound dissolved in caustic chemicals; instruments contort themselves and interlock to achieve forward momentum. It’s music that works very
column8: very hard to express a perverse hometown pride you often see used to sell spring water or thermal outerwear —you might not want to brave Calgary’s bleak winters
column9: but the way Viet Cong captures its forbidding chill and placid
column10: sprawling beauty sure make it seem like a good place to be a post-punk band.

column1: Most of all
column2: this is a record of exertion
column3: where the physical investment in live performance is meant to stimulate creativity
column4: those demoralizing tours inspiring smarter use of the studio. Viet Cong’s favorite tactic of disorientation is inversion—laying high-register
column5: melodic bass patterns over rhythmic
column6: disassociated six string rubble
column7: EQ’ing percussion so it sounds like a drum machine being run through a guitar amp. And Flegel’s most passionate vocal performances deliver his most disillusioned lyrics. Viet Cong has only seven tracks and more than half don’t pass the five minute mark. Yet all are heavy
column8: ingenious contraptions.

column1: This is also a record of conflict and contrast
column2: in particular
column3: a winter war. The sensations of Viet Cong are specific to being bundled up in the arctic
column4: where one’s body feels suffocating warmth and blistering cold all at once. During ""Newspaper Spoons""
column5: shrieking guitars morph into woozy synths
column6: the effect is like watching a bloodied hand sink into a bucket of ice. There are many times when Viet Cong reveal psych-pop as their true north—clean guitars chime
column7: harmonies are stacked in odd
column8: almost madrigal-like forms
column9: and Flegel’s lyrics favor surreal imagery of liquid gold
column10: radiated primates and telepathically ""bending newspaper spoons."" But it’s psychedelia rendered in black and white; after three minutes of vertiginous percussion
column11: a section of stereo-panned
column12: autoharp-like riffs and stoned folk harmonies recall a grayscale Animal Collective ca. Feels. Meanwhile
column13: ""Continental Shelf"" flips Echo and the Bunnymen’s ""big music""
column14: attempting to have the sky crash down to earth rather than reaching for it.

column1: These are the kind of pleasures of which Viet Cong is composed; its emotions are otherwise proprietary to Flegel. Viet Cong do not write love songs
column2: their politics are a mystery. They have no commentary on what it means to be alive in 2015. But to hear this kind of commitment to craft
column3: particularly rock music that maintains the vibrancy and tension of four musicians playing instruments in the same room while testing its boundaries
column4: Viet Cong questions what it means to care about the creation of art
column5: if not necessarily its effect on its audience. Most of Viet Cong was written during a brutal tour across what the band described as ""shit earth"" that tested their resolve and was liable to make the same old question the center of discussion—why do this
column6: again?

column1: Viet Cong is filled with moments that tap into the primal impulses of true post-punk—think of the first time someone puts together a couple of effects pedals and tries to make a guitar sound like something other than a guitar
column2: of falling out with the sonic strictures of punk rock by embracing the philosophical freedom. Towards the end of ""March of Progress""
column3: Flegel yelps
column4: ""What is the difference between love and hate?""
column5: and it can be taken as an allusion to the metaphysical conflict at its center; Viet Cong pits the romanticism of a newly enrolled philosophy major against the cynicism of the dropout who still hangs around the library to tell the fresh-faced youngsters it’s all bullshit. The album doesn't settle the argument
column6:
it's still as volatile and spirited as it was 30 years ago. The important thing is that people are still willing to have the conversation.

Lupe Fiasco seems exhausted by his own career. ""I think I had my peak and now I am coming down in relevancy
column3: he told Billboard recently. ""It's not a sad thing for me...I can't compete with a Wiz Khalifa for the attention of a 12-year old."" This doesn't make for inspiring promo copy
column4: but there's no arguing that his run has been a wearying one: From 2006's Food & Liquor
column5: which suffered from leaks and a Billboard mishap misreporting his first-week sales
column6: to 2011's reviled Lasers
column7: which his fans had to storm Atlantic’s gates to get released
column8: Lupe is forever swimming upstream
column9: his hands tied behind his back.

column1: Of course
column2: many of Lupe's problems stem directly from Lupe—he was pointing out flaws in F&L even before it was released
column3: and he’s perennially signing off Twitter
column4: announcing his retirement
column5: scheduling and canceling albums. And yet something feels different this time around: If Tetsuo & Youth is any indication
column6: something has shaken loose in Lupe
column7: because it's the most focused
column8: thoughtful
column9: and satisfying project he's offered since The Cool.

column1: What’s shifted? Well
column2: for one
column3: the album serves as the end of his tortured contractual obligation to Atlantic. Even then
column4: he wasn't let off the hook without a fight: Depending on whom you believe
column5: the world might owe Tetsuo's existence to the hacker group Anonymous
column6: which publicly threatened Atlantic if the album was not given a release date. The label's official announcement came swiftly afterwards
column7: and Lupe tweeted a simple ""V"" as a wordless gesture of thanks.

column1: Whatever set the stage for him
column2: he dives back into rapping for its own sake like it's a big dusty novel he's been waiting to pick back up for years. He opens after an intro track with ""Mural""
column3: which lets him rap
column4: endlessly
column5: for nine minutes
column6: with no hook. He remembers browsing his brother’s porn stash and contemplating the back pages
column7: where you could find ""ad space for rubber girls."" He poses enigmatic rhetorical questions like ""Now what’s a coffin with a scratched ceiling?"" The question has no specific meaning
column8: but the image
column9: and its ghoulish riddle formulation
column10: makes you ponder a lurid scenario for a half-beat longer so that it sinks in.

column1: Fiasco has talked about his love of painting (he painted the album’s cover)
column2: and his way with language has always felt painterly rather than writerly
column3: more concerned with how one word shades the next than with literal coherence. The words sound and feel gorgeous
column4: and Tetsuo & Youth bursts with ripe
column5: beautiful lines
column6: like ""Sanskrit dance on the page of the dead book
column7: from ""Body of Work""
column8: or ""High as the angel on Dikembe’s shoulder"" from ""They.Resurrect.Over.New"". Following his darting thoughts has always been a thrill
column9: and Tetsuo is a gratifyingly clear transmission.

column1: His longer
column2: more ambitious gambits connect
column3: too
column4: mostly because they preach to no one. He has earned a reputation for sermonizing
column5: but his best songs
column6: like ""Hip-Hop Saved My Life""
column7: eschew sermons for empathy: Even the KKK member he namechecked on on F&L's ""American Terrorist""
column8: who ""can't burn his cross because he can't afford the gasoline
column9: was worthy of pathos. On Tetsuo's ""Prisoner 1 & 2""
column10: Lupe examines the prison-industrial complex
column11: wriggling his way into multiple characters' heads
column12: including the prison guard who has to work at the prison ""or it's no lights"" and feels a pang of jealousy every time a prisoner walks out. On ""Deliver""
column13: a pizza delivery car serves as a metaphorical vehicle to explore neglected neighborhoods and the semi-mythical status of ""the hood."" Neither song hits a single strident
column14: or forced
column15: note.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the same weakness that always hobbles Lupe albums—namely
column3: the music—continues to dog him here. His in-house production team consistently surrounds him with a flavorless
column4: vaguely rock-derived backing
column5: while hook singers like ""Australian Idol"" winner Guy Sebastian and St. Paul singer/songwriter Nikki Jean croon the anonymous choruses. The placid
column6: flat-footed rhythm is a poor match for Lupe's lively
column7: elastic flow. Ironically
column8: one of his recent ""label concession"" singles
column9: the spry Ty Dolla $ign-featuring ""Next to It""
column10: would have livened up the album's sound considerably. It's not on here
column11: leaving Lupe in his own universe. It’s a pleasant place
column12: but often a little flat.

column1: Lupe has always been most exciting when he's somewhere outside his comfort zone
column2: engaging directly with the commercial-rap epicenter he criticizes so shrewdly. He has a naturally subversive mind
column3: but a subversive working outside the mainstream has very little to examine or tweak
column4: and he's thrilling when he’s wriggling on the hook of a big
column5: fat
column6: contradiction—pushing against his audience’s idea of him with Bun B's ""Swang on 'Em""
column7: for instance
column8: or grappling with magnetism of rap cliches on ""Daydreamin'"". ""Chopper""
column9: produced by DJ Dahi
column10: pairs Lupe with Trae tha Truth
column11: Billy Blue
column12: Buk of Psychodrama
column13: Trouble
column14: Fam-Lay
column15: and Glasses Malone
column16: a never-to-be-repeated line-up and a ferocious standout.

column1: Of course
column2: sometimes when Lupe engages with the mainstream
column3: you get strident messes like Lasers' ""Words I Never Said"". You just never know. He's mercurial
column4: as likely to strike gold on an obviously corporate-mandated single or an inward-burrowing indulgence. It’s tough to imagine his best-case scenario for creating: He always seems to be interrupting himself mid-sentence. In a recent New Yorker profile of Chris Rock
column5: hip-hop critic and author Nelson George affectionately dubbed Rock the ""Duke of Doubt
column6: pinpointing the skepticism that makes Chris Rock’s comedy hardy and evergreen. If Lupe has a similar wellspring
column7: it is ambivalence. It's a tricky muse
column8: but every Lupe project has found a way to harness at least 15 or 20 minutes of his fluid
column9:
fleeting mind. Tetsuo & Youth is the most generous gulp he's managed in years.

1978-1984|1737.0|The Go-Betweens|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2015-01-22 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:48.957489|"

The Go-Betweens were their own favorite band
column3: and there's a lot to be said for that. Robert Forster and Grant McLennan met as teenaged boys at the University of Queensland in Brisbane
column4: Australia
column5: as Forster explains in the book that's the centerpiece of this anthology of their first seven years together. (His 70-page history of that period is written in the third person; count on the Go-Betweens for a touch of the impersonal where it's least expected.) They had their own ideas of what pop might be
column6: and especially of what Australian pop might be. The very end of the book names their influences: Abba
column7: Bowie
column8: Creedence
column9: Dolenz
column10: Easybeats
column11: Fellini
column12: and then themselves.

column1: The two of them bonded over their enthusiasm for film and literature at least as much as they did over music. Young men of that era didn't become filmmakers or novelists together
column2: because that couldn't yield Jules et Jim
column3: so Forster taught McLennan how to play guitar
column4: and they started the group. (Forster described their partnership as ""platonic homosexuality."") Between 1978 and 1989
column5: they made a small mountain of records but never made much of a ripple commercially; their 2000-2006 reunion was cut short by McLennan's death. Forster's essay
column6: though
column7: disputes the received wisdom that they ""were 'unsuccessful' and had little luck. It is a view Forster and McLennan never shared
column8: having taken a two-piece Brisbane bedroom band out to the world.""

column1: The Go-Betweens have tried to organize and reassess their chaotic early period a few times now: There have been a few greatest-hits sets
column2: 1985's semi-bootlegged Very Quick on the Eye
column3: 1999's '78 Til '79: The Lost Album
column4: the expanded 2002 reissues of their early albums. G Stands for Go-Betweens includes new vinyl remasters of Send Me a Lullaby (1982)
column5: Before Hollywood (1983) and Spring Hill Fair (1984)
column6: and an LP called The First Five Singles
column7: which is just that. There are also four CDs: three discs' worth of demos
column8: compilation tracks
column9: B-sides and oddities
column10: and a live set from April
column12: which features a few songs that mutated or disappeared before they could be recorded. This is
column13: in other words
column14: aimed at Go-Betweens superfans
column15: but most of their fans were always superfans anyway.

column1: They were a singles band more than they tended to let on—a lot of their songs are best experienced one or two at a time. The First Five Singles
column2: released one a year from 1978 to 1982
column3: is the most immediately delightful of these eight discs
column4: although the very early Go-Betweens were callow
column5: awkward
column6: and a little uncomfortable with women
column7: in the way that bookish young men can be. Both sides of their first single are paeans to unattainable women
column8: one of them Lee Remick and the other a librarian who ""helps me find Genet
column9: helps me find Brecht
column10: helps me find Chandler... she's my god
column11: she's my G-O-D."" ""People Say""
column12: from 1979
column13: is a homemade homage to the garage singles of a dozen years earlier; the next year's skittish ""I Need Two Heads"" made them the only non-Scottish band to release music on Postcard Records
column14: thanks to a trip to the UK whose charming details Forster explains in the book.

column1: Forster has noted that people shouldn't buy the Go-Betweens' first album ""without at least owning three others
column2: and he's probably right. (The 1999 Go-Betweens retrospective Bellavista Terrace didn't include anything from it.) Send Me a Lullaby—the LP included here is the 12-song British version that came out in early 1982
column3: rather than the eight-song 1981 Australian version—is the kind of arch
column4: dry post-punk that sat itchily next to
column5: say
column6: Essential Logic or James Chance records (the occasional blurts of James Freud's saxophone are a reminder that that was the flavor of the underground at that particular moment).

column1: Forster and McLennan weren't yet comfortable with their voices; ""Midnight to Neon"" sounds like Forster wasn't even sure how its melody was supposed to go. Lullaby's main contribution to the band's history is introducing drummer/occasional vocalist Lindy Morrison
column2: who was also dating Forster at the time
column3: and who would be the backbone of the band until the end of its first incarnation in 1989. Morrison was never a showy musician
column4: but she gracefully navigated the eccentric rhythms and time signatures that were starting to appear in both songwriters' work.

column1: Before Hollywood from 1983 was the first time the Go-Betweens really sounded like they would for the rest of their initial run: a little bit off to the side of the pop mainstream's commercial-alternative tributary
column2: looking skeptically at it as it rushed alongside them. The distinction between Forster's writing (acidic
column3: bristling) and McLennan's (tender
column4: playful) was starting to become clearer; McLennan's first real jewel of a song
column5: ""Cattle and Cane""
column6: is a self-consciously poetic reminiscence of his youth
column7: set to a gorgeous mesh of acoustic and electric guitar tones in 11/8 time; Forster's songs are the album's tougher rockers
column8: especially ""By Chance""
column9: which sounds more than a bit like the early Smiths (both bands were releasing records on Rough Trade at the time).

column1: By the time they made 1984's Spring Hill Fair
column2: on which McLennan switched to guitar and Robert Vickers
column3: who'd met them at their first show
column4: took over on bass
column5: the Go-Betweens had apparently made peace with prettiness. Its single ""Bachelor Kisses"" was McLennan's sweetest-sounding song yet—although
column6: naturally
column7: its lyrics bit harder than his delivery suggested. The band's reach still exceeded its grasp sometimes
column8: and their stabs at funk and spoken-word vers libre are stumbles (although not disasters); a remake of the ""Man O' Sand to Girl O' Sea"" single doesn't match the frantic nervousness of the original. But you can also hear them successfully assimilating what they'd picked up through their engagement with other people's music. ""The Old Way Out"" is effectively the Fall translated into the Go-Betweens' own idiom
column9: and Forster's ""Part Company"" is Bob Dylan's Blood on the Tracks refracted through Australian rehearsal room windows.

column1: Dylan's idea of a ""thin wild mercury sound"" was an obvious ancestor of what McLennan and Forster had called ""that striped sunlight sound
column2: a phrase from the sleeve of their first single that reappeared as the title of their 2005 live album. You don't come up with something like that unless you're very interested in figuring out how to mythologize yourself. But why shouldn't they have? The Go-Betweens' endless enthusiasm for their own work is what propelled them out of that Brisbane bedroom in the first place
column3: and the richness of context that this box provides makes it a deeper pleasure than its component albums are on their own.

column1: The first 600 copies of G Stands for Go-Betweens: Volume 1 also features a bonus book: a volume from McLennan's own book collection. (Domino has hinted that there are another 1200 books in reserve for follow-up collections.) That's entirely appropriate for them in a way that it wouldn't have been for nearly anyone else. There may have never been a more bookish great band than the Go-Betweens
column2:
and their career had a lot less to do with the kind of massive pop-cultural success that usually engenders comprehensive boxed-set histories than it did with precious artifacts passed from one fan to another.

Unless you completely checked out of indie rock between 1996 and 2006
column2: Steve Ciolek’s voice will sound very
column3: very familiar. It’s a high
column4: boyish wail first attributed to Doug Martsch and later mainstreamed by James Mercer and Ben Bridwell. And Ciolek isn’t trying to sidestep those warranted comparisons on the Sidekicks’ new record Runners in the Nerved World. In fact
column5: the Cleveland
column6: Ohio
column7: band are welcoming them in the most obvious way by working with Phil Ek
column8: a guy who has not coincidentally produced Built to Spill
column9: the Shins
column10: and Band of Horses. There’s a nature vs. nurture question going on with this style
column11: as all four of these guys make music that perfectly aligns with their natural tone—it’s suburban operatic
column12: a small voice for big spaces
column13: giving the outer appearance of rumpled
column14: hands-in-pockets meekness but having arena-ready expanse and resonance. None of them are from major media centers and that informs the distinct kind of restlessness implied twice over in the title of Runners in the Nerved World: It’s by and for adults looking at open fields
column15: vast stretches of highway
column16: or commercial sprawl and still feeling trapped in their own heads.

column1: This is almost an exact repeat of what labelmates Joyce Manor experienced on last July’s Never Hungover Again. After a couple of albums established them as a clear cut above their local scene
column2: both made the jump to Epitaph and got a big-name producer involved. By 2012’s Awkward Breeds
column3: the Sidekicks were punk rock in ethics only
column4: but their angsty beginnings still subjected them to the same ol’ tired comments about alienating their fans from the basement days. And the risk is in how Sidekicks are also transitioning into a keening
column5: melodic
column6: and heartfelt style that hasn’t produced a major new act in a very
column7: very long time—""centrist"" indie rock when guitars aren’t necessarily at the center of discussion.

column1: While Runners lacks Never Hungover Again’s consistency and melodic generosity
column2: it likewise functions under the assumption that its new audience might be an anachronism
column3: but it’s one worth chasing: people who value the album not so much as a cohesive
column4: continuous 40-minute piece of music but one where every song justifies the act and trust of spending $10 for the whole. With the exception of the brief
column5: fluttering closer ""All Things Run""
column6: everything could be the ""single""—the Sidekicks are beholden to huge choruses with carefully constructed lead-ins
column7: warm harmonies
column8: and quotable lyrics about relatable topics. Remove the crusty production from their past work and nothing here should be a major surprise; it’s just more polished in every way
column9: the melodies are less jittery
column10: the dynamics are more pronounced
column11: the presentation is immaculate.

column1: Still
column2: it’s easy to be bowled over by the broad strokes of the first two songs the Sidekicks let go from Runners. ""Jesus Christ Supermalls""
column3: from its title on down
column4: is grandiose festival music
column5: weeping guitar lines descending with the speed of an exhausted exhale while Ciolek’s voice beams like a klieg light
column6: hitting the highest possible notes during a desperate chorus. Meanwhile
column7: ""Deer"" is more sedate and somehow even more startling for its hearty offering of strummy Midwestern roots-rock with Ciolek’s voice constantly in close harmony with itself. In other words
column8: it sounds exactly like Band of Horses
column9: but the kind we haven’t heard since Cease to Begin
column10: not the corndoggin’ county fair stuff of recent vintage; it's a void well worth filling.

column1: ""Jesus Christ Supermalls"" and ""Deer"" aren’t exactly outliers
column2: so Sidekicks’ ability to maintain both the velocity and direct lyricism of their past keeps Runners in the Nerved World from being an unintentional 10-year anniversary celebration of indie rock’s ""O.C."" era. Whereas most of the Sidekicks’ comparisons are often framed as an accessory to being a thoughtful
column3: sensitive adult trying to find one’s place in the world
column4: Runners in the Nerved World actually speaks on living that situation—the contrast between Ciolek’s embittered
column5: specific lyrics and a sound that isn’t accustomed to those sort of things doesn’t make Sidekicks a particularly innovative band
column6: but one with a distinct voice nonetheless.

column1: Fittingly
column2: a record meant as a musical transition out of the regional punk scene is stocked with lyrics that are often about just that—Ciolek writes as someone who’s ascended to a level where his peers might want to take shots at him
column3: but still low enough where they can reach him. Runners finds heavy symbolism in the mundane—during ""Century Schoolbook Grown-Ups""
column4: the font on merch buttons lets Ciolek know his friends have turned on him
column5: while ""Everything in Twos"" bristles with the anxiety of watching everyone around you pair off while your own relationship falls apart. ""Maybe if this bed could talk/ I think it’d say to get the fuck off
column6: Ciolek sneers on ""Summer Brings You Closer to Satan""
column7: a car-radio anthem for shut-ins. The process of writing ""Summer"" gets name-checked earlier on ""The Kid Who Broke His Wrist""
column8: a masterfully structured song about exactly what the title promises. During its intro
column9: Ciolek sings in a crystalline falsetto about the indignity of having to recuperate from physical writer's block at his parents’ house
column10: before the band goes headlong into Britpop jangle wherein he’s resigned to an inability to
column11: ""Cover up his marks/ His fated heart or really much of anything.""

column1: Fittingly
column2: the true throwback to Sidekicks’ formative years is a memory mashup of trying to recapture young lust. On ""Blissfield
column3: MI""
column4: Ciolek yelps
column5: ""I feel like how the Bulls felt in '93/ I feel like how my head felt the last time you kissed me""
column6: a line so dense with possible meanings that there has to be some serendipity in him picking that exact year and phrasing it that exact way. In June of 1993
column7: Chicago won the NBA Championship. In October
column8: Michael Jordan retired and left the Bulls a shell of themselves until he returned in 1995. So then
column9: what does he mean by last time
column10: a ""most recent"" or ""final"" kiss? Is this a positive recollection or something far more painful? Is he Michael Jordan
column11: is he the ultimate sidekick Scottie Pippen
column12: or does he think of both as people whose drive for greatness made them seem like sociopaths in civilian life? Or you might not ask any of that. ""Blissfield
column13: MI""
column14: like most of Runners in the Nerved World
column15:
is such an effortlessly enjoyable listen that you can miss the tension and ambition emanating from a band that’s chasing greatness as an escape from being Midwestern also-rans.

Something is amiss in Based World. Lil B’s apartment building caught fire last week. His teenage neighbor pounded on his door as the flames spread
column2: and he escaped. He seems okay
column3: but it’s hard to ignore the impulse to view the incident as a harbinger of some greater metaphysical ill
column4: a hint of cosmic misalignment that can only be communicated through the Based God. And though Young L
column5: the mastermind of B’s old group the Pack
column6: has been known for his video game bloops and indulgent bass throughout his nearly 10-year production discography
column7: his music has turned inward
column8: his larger-than-life productions hunching in on themselves
column9: reflecting a preoccupied mind rather than a packed function. His latest mixtape
column10: Final Fantasy
column11: continues the melancholy path he’s been forging since 2013
column12: one on which he’s never stopped to rest for too long.

column1: It’s easy to forget
column2: these days
column3: that Lil B was never really the most essential member of the Pack. That honor went to Young L
column4: the quartet’s in-house producer as well as a rapper
column5: in whose home studio they recorded their first two mixtapes
column6: the stuff that got them signed by Too $hort. It’s clear he’s always been the idea guy
column7: and his production choices shaped the Pack’s aesthetic: rubbery
column8: hyphy-indebted knock
column9: but looser
column10: rougher
column11: with enough empty space for sounds to vibrate off one another
column12: in many ways an early glimpse at the turn-up efficiency of the minimal club sounds that have dominated not just West Coast rap but radio in general in recent years. Post-Pack
column13: as Lil B has grown into his role as swag-rap shaman
column14: Young L has quietly pursued his own solo career
column15: and while he may not wield his influence as visibly as Lil B
column16: he’s usually a couple steps ahead of the game.

column1: Young L’s early 2010s solo projects were informed by video game sounds
column2: Bay Area house party tunes
column3: flat
column4: bright
column5: anime slickness
column6: and an alien truther’s stoned commitment to cosmic unpredictability. Underwritten tapes like 2011’s DOMO-KUN or 2012’s split with Soulja Boy
column7: Mario & Domo Vs. the World
column8: were early success stories within the intersection of rap and EDM sounds. Raucous bangers like ""Loud Pockets"" and ""All Gold Everything""
column9: with their destructive bass and glitchy video game bloops
column10: beat EDM-trap at its own game
column11: slightly ahead of guys like TNGHT and Baauer
column12: and often with more finesse. But something snapped for Young L in 2013: he had his 808s & Heartbreak moment
column13: or probably more accurately
column14: he got older
column15: hitting the point at which ""swag"" is no longer an appropriate response to the gamut of life experiences. His YFGOD mixtape explored neon-lit
column16: night-driving cinematics
column17: somewhere between Kanye’s ""Robocop""
column18: Justice’s †
column19: and the Drive soundtrack. Months later
column20: on his Convulsion EP
column21: he abandoned rap altogether and sunk into the murky melodrama of Clams Casino-style instrumental beat-making
column22: the most depressive stuff of his career.

column1: Final Fantasy isn’t as sharp of a departure as Convulsion—at the very least
column2: it’s recognizably a rap tape—but it shares a similar headspace: anxious
column3: bittersweet
column4: nostalgic for something vague and possibly nonexistent. Over a concise seven tracks
column5: Young L probes light-headed cloud-rap balladry
column6: blown-out trap scuzz
column7: and somber
column8: liturgical R&B. Its introductory suite traffics in the wistful Imogen Heap-core of many of Lil B’s most gut-wrenching Clams Casino collaborations
column9: that unlikely sweet spot between swag rap and ""The O.C."" soundtrack. Things get more interesting from there: a pair of staggering
column10: bottomless trap songs
column11: ""Doors Open"" and ""U Know What I Mean""
column12: provide counterpoints to long-standing allegations that Young L’s tepid rapping is dead weight to his innovative production. Tape highlight ""$ugar Ray"" wallows in last night’s pastel afterglow: over two-and-a-half minutes
column13: L channels Frank Ocean’s ""Pyramids"" pimp waking up in a puddle of drool
column14: DJ Khaled surveying his kingdom
column15: unmoved and with Four Loko in hand
column16: in the ""I’m on One"" video
column17: and DJ Screw’s Late Night Fuckin’ Yo Bitch tape. There’s the detached menace of ""Slam Dunk""
column18: the tape-closing Lil B collaboration featuring the hardest based freestyle in recent memory
column19: shouting out fellow Pack brother Stunnaman.

column1: None of this represents any sort of bigger-than-itself artistic statement
column2: and it probably won’t stand the test of time
column3: but all that’s besides the point. There’s been a planned obsolescence to Young L’s work from the very beginning
column4: a byproduct of a music career inextricably tied to the Internet (""Vans"" would be nothing without Myspace). It’s a survival tactic for continued relevance as an independent artist whose music exists primarily in a digital space
column5: and it’s perfectly suited for restless idea guys like Young L. These songs don’t need to exist for years down the road so much as they need to exist right now
column6: in this specific moment
column7: as snapshots of time
column8: place
column9: and mood
column10: and then they need to move on. There’s no need to linger for too long—everything happens too fast for that. It’s no coincidence that Young L drifted away from explicitly West Coast sounds around the same time that stuff had begun to blow up nationally
column11: thanks to DJ Mustard
column12: YG
column13: and HBK Gang. For a guy like L
column14: who doesn’t rely on music financially (he’s got a successful clothing line
column15: Pink Dolphin)
column16: there’s no need to stress over the pursuit of hits or pump out 20-track mixtapes in hope that something sticks. He’s free to follow his impulses
column17: no matter how ephemeral
column18: and though it may not have rendered him the most visible of his Pack brethren
column19: it’s resulting in the most reliably intriguing solo catalog. Young L’s sound may have evolved
column20: but his strategy hasn’t: Set the trends
column21: keep it moving
column22:
and watch the wave crest behind him.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21405/homepage_large.c8046b3f.jpg|Girls in Peacetime Want to Dance|324.0|Belle and Sebastian|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2015-01-21 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:51.514069|"

Seven years is how long Belle and Sebastian lead singer Stuart Murdoch was afflicted with chronic fatigue syndrome
column2: a debilitating illness with no easy cure. You’re tired all the time
column3: but sleep doesn’t help; you can’t hold a job down
column4: since you don’t have the energy to be anywhere. Murdoch developed the disease as a university student
column5: when he was old enough to fully comprehend what he’d be forgoing should his symptoms endure. Family? The hope of fame
column6: or fortune? Forget about it.

column1: If you imagine for a second how Murdoch must’ve despaired
column2: then you’ll understand why he calls ""Nobody’s Empire""—the opener on Girls in Peacetime Want to Dance
column3: in which he sings about the solitude brought on from his sickness—the most personal song he’s ever written. That’s not a small statement
column4: considering Belle and Sebastian’s reputation. Their ethos was crystallized in the title of the first song on their first album—""The State I’m In""—and they’ve spent nearly two decades staking their claim as the most sensitive band in indie rock
column5: patron saints for daydreaming boys and girls. Their early records sounded feather-soft
column6: but over the years
column7: they slowly put on weight and become a real band
column8: translating their bedroom aesthetics for the festival set.

column1: On Girls in Peacetime Want to Dance
column2: they’ve added a new wrinkle by writing an album that attempts to be pop qua pop
column3: filled with synthesizers and dance grooves to coax their once notoriously-staid live crowds to cut a rug. Even the artwork is different: This is their first cover that doesn’t use a monochromatic photographic still that directly references the Smiths
column4: their emotional forerunner. The band hired outside producer Ben H. Allen III (Animal Collective
column5: Washed Out) to punch up their sound
column6: and he encouraged them to take more chances. The band is confident enough to step into pro forma P-funk on ""The Party Line"" and polka singalong on ""The Everlasting Muse"" without losing their penchant for bookishness: ""The Power of Three"" name drops Sherlock Holmes and Moriarty
column7: while the jaunty ""Play for Today"" mixes in chants of ""author! author!"" as Murdoch and Dee Dee Penny of Dum Dum Girls trade harmonies.

column1: ""Enter Sylvia Plath"" combines both worlds
column2: with a brittle rhythmic backbone giving the band their first song that you might—might—hear in a club. ""The Cat With the Cream"" and ""Ever Had a Little Faith?"" are both classic Sebastian
column3: softly spoken songs where Murdoch reminisces for rainy days and childhood wonder. The piano line that kicks in during the latter’s outro is a pleasant little melody that accentuates Murdoch’s ear for nostalgic detail. So does ""Nobody’s Empire""
column4: which Murdoch wasn’t lying about. It’s a nakedly autobiographical song that’s verbose even by their standards
column5: with Murdoch spitting rapid-fire verses over a sleepy melody before letting loose with what passes for a scream in the Sebastian-verse
column6: which is a place filled with indoor voices.

column1: In an interview with the Daily Beast
column2: Murdoch said he would’ve loved to be ""a young Carole King
column3: working in the Brill Building where so many of pop’s yesteryear hits were written. ""I see no reason why that music can’t be possible again
column4: but I look around and don’t see it
column5: he said. ""Sophisticated
column6: nuanced
column7: melodious pop music
column8: that sweeps you away."" That Murdoch’s shining ideal of pop harkens back to a half-century ago goes hand-in-hand with a lot of the band’s dandier affectations
column9: as does his casual dismissiveness of today’s comparatively hedonistic Top 40. It's also strange because
column10: to many long time listeners
column11: the band already took their shot at writing a pop album with 2003's Dear Catastrophe Waitress and 2006's The Life Pursuit
column12: where they churned out romantic hook-loaded singalongs like ""I'm a Cuckoo"" and ""The Blues Are Still Blue""
column13: both of which are catchier and more memorable than anything on Girls in Peacetime Want to Dance.

column1: Besides
column2: Murdoch is surely trifling if he doesn't think sweeping
column3: sophisticated pop has a place on the charts: Adele and Sam Smith are two singers who've carved their niche by singing right to your parents. A flippant comment to Pitchfork about how listeners would rather lose themselves in Nina Simone than Beyoncé shows not just a flagrant misunderstanding of how people listen to Beyoncé
column4: but to the artists they love. He means well
column5: but it faintly stinks of snobbery that's gotten other indie acts in trouble when they've tried to explain their theory of pop with
column6: well
column7: a lot of theory. Tom Krell of How to Dress Well raised hackles when he told Pitchfork he wanted to be ""pop
column8: but not populist."" But what's wrong with trying to appeal to as many people as possible?

column1: Girls in Peacetime Want to Dance reminds me of another recent attempt from a high-profile indie band to change directions. Arcade Fire surprised fans with the Caribbean-influenced Reflektor
column2: their attempt at writing a looser
column3: more playful album. They sort of looked like a bunch of dorks
column4: but it didn't matter. Eventually
column5: everyone learns what children and merengue instructors know to be true: Dancing is fun
column6: regardless of how well you move your hips.

column1: Look at the video of the band cutting through ""I’m a Cuckoo"" from the 2013 Pitchfork Music Festival. Murdoch hams it up
column2: casting flirtatious looks from side-to-side
column3: dropping to his knees like Elvis. At one point
column4: he loses the guitar
column5: because you can’t dance while holding a guitar. He’s having fun. And if fun is what he wants to have after 19 years and nine albums anointing them as kings of coyness and crossed arms—it’s hard to begrudge that.

column1: And
column2: who knows: Maybe this is the album to teach someone about fun. If not
column3: it’s still a perfectly respectable hour of Northern soul-influenced pop
column4: even if it’s difficult not to hear the intention behind every song. (Or to shake the feeling that a band like Cut Copy is much better at this shambling soul revue style of music.) One of Murdoch’s imaginary women instructs him to ""be popular
column5: play pop
column6: and you will win my love"" on ""The Everlasting Muse""
column7: which sounds like noble inspiration but ends up falling short. You don’t win anyone by simply playing a pop song
column8: or by deciding to be pop. It takes something else
column9: something that can’t be explained by a mission statement. For a band so well-loved for writing from their heart
column10:
it sounds like they got stuck in their head.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21390/homepage_large.7045d945.jpg|Uptown Special|5304.0|Mark Ronson|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sony']|2015-01-21 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:15:52.089321|"

Crowning the Song of the Summer has become an annual tradition akin to the Super Bowl for music pundits
column2: spawning its own Billboard chart
column3: a seasonal stream of speculative think pieces
column4: and official betting odds. But no such fanfare exists for determining the Song of the Winter
column5: an arguably more impressive achievement
column6: given that it must seize our attention from the hectic pre-Christmas crunch through to the post-New Year’s onset of Seasonal Affective Disorder (and all the grueling family gatherings in between). Where Songs of the Summer are readymade soundtracks for the happiest moments of your life
column7: Songs of the Winter must be scientifically engineered with enough exuberance to fire up your serotonin during the most miserable time of year. Lest we forget
column8: some of the most universally embraced
column9: monoculture-fortifying singles of this millennium—from ""Hey Ya!"" to ""Crazy"" to ""Happy""—all surfaced during the chilly season
column10: making their outsized energy not just welcome
column11: but psychologically necessary. And if 2014 was indeed the hottest year on record
column12: we can thank ""Uptown Funk"" for raising the mercury during its dying days.

column1: A year ago next month
column2: Bruno Mars appeared at the Super Bowl half-time show in a rare
column3: shared bill with Red Hot Chili Peppers—the implication being that
column4: even with two multi-platinum albums under his belt
column5: the singer was somehow still too young or unproven to carry the show on his own without the help of some rock veterans. But on the heels of ""Uptown Funk""—his inescapable
column6: undeniable chart-topping collaboration with producer Mark Ronson—Mars could not only claim the show for himself this year
column7: but make everyone in the stadium forget there was a football game going on. If ""Uptown Funk"" represents something of a supernova moment for Mars’ ascendant star—unleashing a braggadocio that’s several degrees sassier than what we’ve heard on his more congenially soulful solo hits—it’s a hard-fought moment of Stateside redemption for Ronson. Though his name can be found in the fine print on some of the biggest British pop records of the past decade
column8: Ronson’s own collaboration-heavy albums failed to establish the London-born producer as a star in his own right in his second home of America (where his sister Samantha is arguably more famous for being Lindsay Lohan’s long-time party pal). His productions for others have cracked the Billboard Top 10
column9: but this time he has a monster hit to call his own—that is
column10: if you discount the veritable syllabus worth of '80s-funk sources ""Uptown Funk"" so unapologetically references. Between the Morris Day-schooled mojo and Michelle Pfeiffer name-drops
column11: all the song is missing for maximum period detail is an Eddie Murphy cop flick to soundtrack.

column1: There’s more where that came from on Uptown Special—though not as much as you might think. Where last fall's ""SNL""-showcased double shot of ""Uptown Funk"" and its gloriously profane
column2: Mystikal-manned counterpart ""Feel Right"" suggested Uptown Special would be Ronson’s star-studded reenactment of a Revolution-vs.-Time First Avenue showdown
column3: the album is actually more like a five-CD-changer shuffle through styles that dominated pop radio while Ronson was still a grade-schooler. Pieced together in several cities spanning Toronto to Memphis to L.A.
column4: the album represents something of a Sonic Highways-style journey for Ronson
column5: and like Dave Grohl
column6: the producer boasts both the chart-pop and alt-rock bona fides to attract luminaries from the mainstream and indie-verse alike. The guest list here includes everyone from a hall-of-fame legend like Stevie Wonder to an unknown choir singer
column7: Keyone Starr
column8: recruited from Mississippi State; from electro-pop pin-up Andrew Wyatt of Miike Snow to reigning psych-rock king Kevin Parker of Tame Impala; from the guy who wrote The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay to the guy who wrote ""Shake Ya Ass"".

column1: If Ronson’s previous albums were united by formalizing principles (retro-soul makeovers of alt-rock standards on 2007’s Version
column2: odd-couple duets on 2010’s Record Collection)
column3: his strategies on Uptown Special are more conceptual. For several songs
column4: he enlisted novelist Michael Chabon to pen pulp-novel-like lyrical vignettes of crime and passion on the outskirts of Las Vegas and hipster identity crises in L.A.
column5: providing the album with
column6: if not a linear narrative
column7: then a recurring motif of dislocation. And in the spirit of Todd Terje’s producer-cum-artist-album gold standard
column8: It’s Album Time
column9: the tracklist follows a loose dusk-till-dawn trajectory
column10: welcoming us in with Stevie’s signature harmonica squeals on the sunset-summoning intro ""Uptown’s First Finale"" before slipping into the cocktail-hour psychedelia of ""Summer Breaking"" (the first of Parker’s three leads). But before the album’s 15-minute mark
column11: Mystikal has already gotten up and offa that thing
column12: Mars has completed his one-and-done deal
column13: and newcomer Starr has held her own with the jazzy
column14: jittery R&B of ""I Can’t Lose""
column15: rendering Uptown Special as an album of all-too-brief
column16: berserker highs followed by a protracted
column17: increasingly ponderous comedown period. The problem isn’t that Uptown Special’s incongruous collaborators clash with one another
column18: it’s that Ronson sounds like he’s mashing two entirely different albums—one libidinous
column19: one languorous—together.

column1: In sharp contrast to the scene-stealing performances that dominate the album’s first half
column2: Uptown Special’s second act essentially sees Parker and Wyatt trading smooth soft-rock volleys overtop chill grooves
column3: with refereeing from Jeff Bhasker (who plays the same role on ""In Case of Fire"" as Todd Edwards did on Random Access Memories’ ""Fragments of Time""—i.e.
column4: a big-name producer making a rare vocal turn on a thinly veiled Steely Dan tribute.) Parker’s contributions—be it the Toro Y Moi-style cosmic funk of ""Daffodils"" or Ween-like bounce of ""Leaving Loz Feliz""—provide a prophecy of what a tamer Tame Impala might sound like another five years down the road should they ever trade in heavy-duty guitar jams for streamlined pop; Wyatt’s ""Heavy and Rolling"" cops its strut from ""Billie Jean"" but none of its dramatic tension
column5: denying Uptown Special the late-game climax it’s begging for. Before you know it
column6: Stevie Wonder’s returned for the sunrise swirl of ""Crack in the Pearl
column7: Pt. II"" to send us off with another unmistakably Stevie-esque harmonica line (while making you wonder why the hell Stevie Wonder isn’t doing anything more on this album other than playing harmonica). Too top-heavy to sustain its momentum
column8: yet too fleeting for its thematic framework to cohere
column9:
Uptown Special is that rare beast: a concept album that actually could use more fat.

Erase Errata looked like they could have been a brightly colored flash in the pan in the early 2000s. Between 2001 and 2003
column2: the Bay Area band toured consistently and released a slew of well-regarded singles and splits as well as two full albums
column3: Other Animals and At Crystal Palace. Since the twitchy dancefloor ""post-riot-grrrl"" sound they specialized in was on the ascent at the time
column4: there was a lot of hype
column5: which brings with it naysayers and trendwatchers. With founding guitarist Sara Jaffe’s departure in 2004
column6: the band took a couple of years to regroup
column7: finally solidifying into trio form for 2006’s relatively under-the-radar LP Nightlife. On Lost Weekend
column8: their first LP in nearly a decade and their first offering since 2010’s ""Damaged"" single
column9: they take a measured
column10: deliberate approach
column11: an acknowledgment of space and patience.

column1: Lost Weekend is a short record
column2: but it doesn’t feel rushed and it never feels labored. Erase Errata haven’t lost their ability as songwriters
column3: the smart tack they developed over their discography of winding unexpected texture around sparse
column4: jagged rhythmic structure. I hear bits of sonic reference to some underrated and unexpected post-punk predecessors here—Bush Tetras
column5: Disco Inferno
column6: Moonshake—but Erase Errata have eked out their own space here
column7: grown into their own legacy.

column1: ""In Death I Suffer""
column2: one of the album's standouts
column3: roils and rumbles its catchy rhythm over a chilly expanse of synth noise
column4: out of which blooms a surprisingly hooky chorus. Guitarist Jenny Hoyston’s voice has become more understated over the years
column5: and when she intones ""They came from all sides—all sides
column6: it is one of those prickly-neck moments I didn’t need to fully understand intellectually in order to respond to.

column1: Lest anyone think Lost Weekend is all clouds and ice and gloom
column2: the opening track
column3: ""History of Handclaps""
column4: is a sly
column5: self-deprecating look back at the indie dancefloor culture in which Erase Errata found their voice and early fame
column6: a scene where syncopated (and sometimes synthesized) handclaps became ubiquitous. The disco claps here are buried in the mix
column7: only surfacing during the breakout chorus; the song is mainly propelled by Bianca Sparta’s nearly unbearably precise drumming and Ellie Erickson’s curdling bass. This is a band that has never forgotten the main tenet of post-punk: the genre is nothing if it doesn’t place most of its strength in its rhythm section. ""History of Handclaps"" isn’t snide
column8: though—in its tracing of the sonic trend both lyrically and musically
column9: it acknowledges both the overuse and humanity of the handclap through rock'n'roll
column10: soul
column11: disco
column12: and punk.

column1: ""Watch Your Language"" kicks and shudders
column2: built around a blues riff; it’s a claustrophobic and intimate look at information-age communication (it also features a particularly judicious use of the flat
column3: splattery sound of analog synths.) ""Galveston
column4: Dark Tides"" might be the closest thing to a straightforward pop song Erase Errata have ever done. They’ve learned when to hustle and when to lay back
column5: and Lost Weekend is a good marker that if Erase Errata wants
column6: they could have a career as long and as consistent as a band like the Ex (who have had said kind things about Erase Errata)
column7: post-punk stalwarts who are over 30 years old at this point and over 20 albums deep. This band is leaning into their stride
column8: picking up the wind
column9:
challenging all those flash-in-the-pan expectations from over a decade ago with solid work.

Elephant Micah is Joseph O’Connell
column2: a 33-year-old singer-songwriter whose songs betray his day job as an Indiana folklorist. Take ""Slow Time Vultures""
column3: the 7-1/2-minute centerpiece of his Western Vinyl debut Where in Our Woods
column4: which describes the time O’Connell’s childhood home in Pekin
column5: Indiana
column6: attracted a giant flock of vultures. The song anthropomorphizes the birds
column7: who use the barn roof as a soapbox to lament Indiana’s conforming to Daylight Savings Time. (Prior to 2006
column8: most of the state disregarded DST
column9: and locals often referred to its singular zone as ""slow time."")

column1: The vultures question and criticize fast-paced progress (""We can’t afford to go forward any more"")
column2: and O’Connell sanctifies their words in a sparse
column3: patient arrangement. It takes about 20 seconds for him to sing the first six words—""Vultures on our old barn roof""—and he spends much of the song hypnotically plucking the low E of a nylon-stringed guitar that permeates the album
column4: becoming its signature instrument. The effect is stark and haunting and entirely vulture friendly.

column1: O’Connell has been experimenting with Midwestern Americana for 14 years now
column2: but most of the 11 Elephant Micah releases prior to Where in Our Woods were primitively recorded and distributed on tiny labels or self-released on CD-Rs. Elephant Micah isn’t exactly a secret (you can find most of the releases for pay-what-you-want prices on Bandcamp)
column3: but O’Connell has remained on the margins more than friends like M.C. Taylor of Hiss Golden Messenger (the two covered each other’s songs for a 7'' release a few years ago). All that
column4: plus the folklorist thing
column5: has contributed to Elephant Micah’s outsider/not-of-this-time rep. You get the feeling O’Connell doesn’t get worked up about iTunes updates or the appropriate context for leggings.

column1: If 2012’s Louder Than Thou refined the Elephant Micah sound
column2: Where in Our Woods continues the distillation until
column3: after stripping away all but guitar
column4: voice
column5: a pump organ
column6: and some rumbling drums (courtesy of O’Connell’s brother Matthew)
column7: the minimalism becomes the album’s calling card (think Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy’s unadorned but crisply rendered Master and Everyone). The album isn’t so decorous that it doesn’t take chances
column8: though. It’s a risk
column9: in fact
column10: to present O’Connell’s voice so nakedly
column11: since it’s neither a showstopper nor terribly eccentric. He doesn’t whisper
column12: doesn’t yell. It’s smooth
column13: almost to a fault
column14: but the clarity of his tenor fits the pace and spareness of these eight songs. And just when you start yearning for something more
column15: the bonnie prince himself
column16: Will Oldham—an obvious inspiration here—shows up to add some harmonies.

column1: Often
column2: folk singers are either storytellers or read-into-it-what-you-want poets
column3: but some of this generation’s best (Oldham
column4: Jason Molina) fall somewhere in the middle. Elephant Micah stands firmly in that middle ground
column5: not shying away from small details nor lofty
column6: ambiguous ideas. Without some background explanation
column7: it would be impossible to know that ""Demise of the Bible Birds"" refers to an Indiana man who trained birds to perform Christian-themed tricks. Or that O’Connell ripped the three stories in the gorgeous ""Albino Animals""—hunters killing an albino deer
column8: athletes capsizing on a boat
column9: and meth cooks avoiding prosecution for a trailer fire—from the headlines of his hometown newspaper. O’Connell
column10: though
column11: gives us all the details we need to ponder ignorance and the unknowability of life while falling under the spell of a bewitching
column12: repeating guitar line that somehow communicates both the tragedy and mercy in the stories.

column1: The songs on Where in Our Woods were all written in 2006 and 2007
column2: and while the Elephant Micah albums of that period have an experimental
column3: homespun charm to them
column4: O’Connell was wise to set these songs aside until he found the right setting for them
column5: even if that didn’t become clear for several years. As the slow time vultures sing
column6:
""Ours are the spoils and the things that we can find on our own time."" Maybe those birds are onto something.

The most frequently quoted fact from Cloakroom’s bio is that they’re a trio of factory workers from Indiana. It is a backstory that makes sense in hindsight upon hearing their minimally arranged
column2: moderately morose
column3: and maximally loud debut LP Further Out. Cloakroom know from heavy machinery; the operative terms for Further Out are ""bulldoze
column4: ""steamroll."" Here’s a picture of the band—Brian Busch is on the left and the drums on Further Out sure sound like they’re being hit by a guy who has 100-litre barrels for arms. Meanwhile
column5: Doyle Martin valiantly keeps up with all the might his lanky
column6: mortal frame can bear
column7: as Further Out comes off like the only indie rock album released in 2015 actively gunning for its own tablature book. Opener ""Paperweight"" sums up Martin’s sedentary
column8: sarcastic point of view (""You exist in material states/ One part paper
column9: one part weight/ You could not decide what force is holding you down today"") and empties his arsenal of bullying power chords
column10: fluid
column11: clean arpeggios
column12: melodic fills and narcotized acoustic strums.

column1: All of the aforementioned provide for a wealth of hooks throughout Further Out
column2: even if it’s an album for the gearheads who’d rather spend time and money assessing amplifier nuance than effects pedals. Proudly analog from the recording to the vinyl pressing
column3: Further Out utilizes a mere handful of tones because Martin took like two years to get these settings just right: his favorite is a super-saturated buzz that somehow sounds both impenetrable and like it could dissolve on contact. It’s a shame someone else beat Cloakroom to Let’s Cry and Do Pushups at the Same Time as an album title
column4: as Further Out is equal parts thick muscle and lactic acid.

column1: The result is a record heavy enough to justify a 2xLP pressing even with a relatively brief 45 minute runtime. It’s probably best for the vinyl considering the contents: ""Paperweight"" inherits the Secret Machines’ ambitions to recreate Texas-sized arena boogie that’s part Slacker
column2: part Dazed and Confused
column3: ""Lossed Over"" and ""Moon Funeral"" are the basis for the pop record to which Jesu refused to commit
column4: while ""Outta Spite"" and ""Starchild Skull"" hulk boxes upon boxes of CDs from the time when indie rock went alt and cast a lot of truly great bands as one-hit wonders stashed in the Buzz Bin. Most specifically
column5: Hum—Further Out was recorded in Matt Talbott’s studio and his former band would be a reference point even if had no direct involvement. Hum have become a kind of shorthand for contemporaries like Cloakroom who draw from but are not limited to shoegaze
column6: slowcore
column7: alt-rock
column8: emo
column9: basically all forms of music that favor distorted guitars and never really have their ""moment"" in indie rock post-1995.

column1: But for that reason
column2: they also never really go out of style. Further Out does successfully sound genreless despite being referential of a half dozen genres at once and is presented as a continuous listening experience. Though Cloakroom might be selling themselves short in the interest of cohesion—""Mesmer"" and ""Sylph"" are meant as instrumental interludes
column3: but their skittering rhythms and timbral beauty are such intriguing divergences from the consistent piledriving that they feel like unkept promises; one wishes they could’ve been extended into vocal tracks. But in light of the effort and exertion required of Further Out’s eight other songs
column4: perhaps that was too much of an undertaking for the time being.

column1: All of the deliberate aggression in Cloakroom's music is a none-too-subtle defense mechanism for the implacable depression at its core. Martin’s yawning moan is a dead ringer for that of Pedro the Lion’s David Bazan
column2: somehow managing to emerge clean and clear from the murk despite him never raising his voice. But unlike Bazan
column3: Martin’s pen is caked with bong resin rather than poison. Cashed bowls and empty cans litter Further Out
column4: having served as coping mechanisms rather than means of escape. All of these low-level narcotics have a way of muddling situations as Martin attempts to explain his disappointment in people who continue to fail him. At any given point
column5: it’s unclear whether he’s addressing a girlfriend
column6: a friend
column7: a coworker
column8: a parent
column9: the mailman
column10: whoever.

column1: Most likely
column2: it’s himself
column3: but his lethargic delivery becomes a part of the hook: on ""Asymmetrical""
column4: Martin describes suburban
column5: drunken intransigence as a night out where he
column6: ""Took a long drive/ Got a few dents/ Told a couple jokes at your expense""; the major-key melody appears to be mocking the target
column7: as Martin’s words drip with both dejection and derision
column8: a perfect match of content and delivery.

column1: Cloakroom once described themselves as ""stoner emo"" as a joke and they’ll probably spend the rest of their career getting shit for it. It’s clearly meant as a joke
column2: the punchline being the obvious incompatibility of its two parts. The latter is defined by anxious rhythms
column3: a tenuous connection to straight edge
column4: brazen
column5: high-register melodies and a desperate desire for human connection amidst a litany of misunderstanding and communication failures. Meanwhile
column6: a band named Sleep made one of stoner rock’s formative documents

column8: somewhat timid debut EP Infinity couldn’t achieve
column9: Further Out presents those genres existing as a continuum rather than in conflict: Cloakroom are driven by a distinct Midwestern despair and disillusion
column10: they just don’t make music that reflects it. Instead
column11: they hit a very specific catharsis wrung from exhaustion; at a certain point

column13: the office
column14: or just enduring a line at the grocery store
column15: and you figure you may as well just spark up and crank up the amps.

Now is the time: breaking the decade of relative silence that followed Sleater-Kinney's prodigious supposed finale
column2: 2005's The Woods
column3: the girls are back in town. We have arrived at the critical reappraisal and celebrated comeback of music's most revered feminist saviors of American rock'n'roll. It is 2015 and we are staring down Sleater-Kinney's wise eighth album—exactly 50 years removed from the birth of ""R-e-s-p-e-c-t""
column4: exactly 40 years removed from the birth of Horses
column5: exactly 30 years removed from when Kim Gordon first yells ""brave men run away from me"" in the Mojave desert
column6: exactly 20 years removed from Sleater-Kinney
column7: a primal
column8: insurrectionist warning shot from the margins. Ever since
column9: we have had Corin Tucker
column10: Carrie Brownstein
column11: and Janet Weiss to soundtrack our societal chaos and progressing zeitgeist: tangled agitation
column12: pummeled norms
column13: principled wit
column14: sublimity
column15: sadness
column16: friction
column17: kicks.

column1: Nowadays
column2: there is a prevailing notion that we ought not want such epochal bands as Sleater-Kinney to reunite
column3: because why tarnish the legend of ""Best Band in the World"" acclaim and a perfectly ascendant seven-album streak? But if any band in the past two decades has proved they've got the intellect
column4: skepticism
column5: and emotional capacity to deserve this—to keep living—it's Sleater-Kinney. No Cities to Love is a disarming
column6: liberationist force befitting the Sleater-Kinney canon. Fervent political leftism has been implicit to this Olympia-born trio since they first inverted Boston's ""More Than a Feeling"" on a 1994 comp and that goes on here as well; we desperately need it. It is astonishing that a radical DIY punk band could grow up and keep going with this much dignity and this many impossibly chiseled choruses. No Pistol
column7: Ramone
column8: or unfortunate mutation of Black Flag could have done this.

column1: The necessity of change—the creative virtue of ripping it up and starting again—remains a crucial strand of Sleater-Kinney's DNA. This is still them: low-tuned classic rock tropes resuscitated with punk urgency
column2: raw and jagged like Wire compressing crystalline Marquee Moon coils. Weiss' massive swoop is still the band's throbbing heart

It is no less emphatic and corporeal than punk classics Call the Doctor and Dig Me Out. But unlike their last two albums of monstrous combat rock
column4: No Cities to Love keeps only the most addictive elements—if Sleater-Kinney are still taking Joey Ramone as a spiritual guide
column5: this is their mature
column6: honed
column7: and clean-sounding Rocket to Russia. Catchy as all-clashing hell

column9: amping their omnipresent love of new wave pop with aerodynamic choruses that reel and reel
column10: enormously shouted and gasped and sung with a dead-cool drawl. The album has the particular aliveness of music being created and torn from a group at this very moment—tempered
column11: but with the wild-paced abandon that comes with being caged and then free.

column1: As ever

New York producer Max McFerren hears the human voice differently than you do. You hear a sigh

column3: crucially

Progress can be a hard thing to quantify. For bands
column2: it’s often either measured by record sales

The twosome of Meric Long and Logan Kroeber have been making music together for the better part of a decade and by now they have honed their own distinct language. The records they make together as the Dodos are generally characterized by a kind of symbiotic back and forth—a balance composed of virtuoso playing
column5: alternately-tuned guitar sounds
column6: and insanely intricate drum patterns. That they have managed to create a sound that is instantly and distinctly recognizable as their own (and amass a devoted following) is no small feat
column7: but figuring out how to push their sound forward without repeating themselves or abandoning their aesthetic has proven to be much trickier business.

column1: After tinkering with their sound in a variety of ways over the past few years—employing additional musicians

column1: Recorded hot on the heels of the sessions for 2013’s Carrier—an album seemingly haunted by the death of occasional contributing guitarist Christopher Reimer—Individ plays like a companion piece to the band's breakthrough Visiter. ""Until now there was a reason/ Let go of it

What seems like a simple bit of repetition and melody grows increasingly more forceful before exploding into a stadium-size loop of riffs and pounding drums. ""Let go of it/ And get out of here/ Let’s get out of here/ For good"" sings Long in what seems less like a concession of defeat and more a statement of liberation. As album openers go
column3: it’s a doozy—six minutes of triumphantly shaking off a lot of old baggage. ""We’ll keep playing/ Till there is nothing
column4: he promises elsewhere on ""The Tide""
column5: further establishing what could be Individ’s most prevalent and endearing theme—a sense of acceptance paired with dogged resilience.

column1: The Dodos began their career as avowed primitivists before eventually experimenting with ways to broaden their sound. Longtime fans of the band will appreciate Individ’s back-to-basics quality
column2: which generally forgoes electric guitars in favor of Long’s maniacal strumming and dexterous
column3: breakneck time changes. ""Competition""
column4: the record’s first single
column5: showcases the band at their most deceptively simple: dueling guitar lines playing against a staccato rhythm
column6: all being tugged along by Long’s effortless vocal. In this case
column7: the band’s reaction against perfection is what makes most of Individ so sublime. Both Long and Kroeber are virtuoso musicians
column8: and while Long’s vocals rarely ever strain to be anything more than pleasantly plaintive
column9: hearing he and Kroeber push themselves to the point of raggedness as musicians is what continues to make the Dodos’ music such a surprising and singular listen.

column1: Clocking in at almost 40 minutes
column2: the nine tracks on Individ make for an exhilarating
column3: albeit fairly melancholy
column4: listening experience. While the duo has not lost their youthful exuberance as players (listening to Long and Kroeber rip through ""Retriever"" is a potent reminder of what a thrillingly visceral band the Dodos actually are)
column5: Individ seems mostly wrapped up with very adult concerns. And while the band might never better the pop jubilance of Visiter’s ""Fools""
column6: tracks like ""The Tide"" and the perfectly wistful ""Bubble"" come mighty close. On Individ’s closing track
column7: the sprawling
column8: seven-minute ""Pattern Shadow""
column9: Long intones that ""I cannot predict/ All your patterns/ You blew us away/ And I could not escape."" It's unclear exactly to whom he is singing
column10: but the shadow at the core of the song—mysterious
column11: ever-present
column12: ocean-sized—could be a fitting stand in for the band itself and the epic
column13: mercurial nature of their songs. In the record’s press materials
column14: Long explains
column15: ""This record is about accepting what is natural for you or even a part of you."" Ten years deep into their career
column16: the Dodos have never actually steered too far from their roots
column17: but the loose
column18: unselfconscious feel of Individ proves that there is something to be said for recognizing and playing to your strengths
column19: trusting your chops
column20:
and simply feeling things as intensely as you possibly can.

Damon McMahon has spent much of his life both physically and spiritually adrift
column2: vacillating between urban enticements and rural retreats. Born in Philly
column3: but raised in the sticks of Connecticut
column4: he would settle in New York in the early 2000s just in time for his former band
column5: Inouk
column6: to enjoy its 15 pixels of fame during the post-Clap Your Hands Say Yeah blog rush. A subsequent failed attempt to establish himself as an Astralwerks-backed singer-songwriter would prompt McMahon to hole himself up in a Catskills cabin to record his wilfully primitive debut as Amen Dunes
column7: before embarking upon an extended self-exile to China. But since returning stateside around the start of this decade
column8: McMahon has increasingly channeled his sense of wanderlust into his music
column9: breaking down his traditional folk-rock roots to open up more celestial spaces
column10: and amassing an ever-expanding circle of collaborators like a backpacker making new friends at a hostel lounge.

column1: For his 2014 triumph
column2: Love
column3: he decamped to Montreal and ensconced himself in the Godspeed You! Black Emperor inner circle to produce his most fully realized
column4: emotionally resonant work to date. In interviews
column5: McMahon often cited Astral Weeks and Pharoah Sanders’ turn-of-the-'70s odysseys as inspirations for the album’s spiritually infused sprawl
column6: but Love’s seemingly loose aesthetic did not come without much tinkering and second-guessing. (The album reportedly took five studios and over a year to complete.) The new Cowboy Worship EP sheds light on McMahon’s meticulous methodology: Four of its six tracks are reprises of Love songs
column7: and though the differences between these versions and the official ones are sometimes barely perceptible
column8: they serve as testaments to McMahon’s determination to get the vibe just right.

column1: In fact
column2: the rendition of ""I Know Myself"" that opens the EP is identical to the one that appears on Love
column3: its gradual transformation from solitary strummer to communal hymn serving as a microcosm of Amen Dunes’ own creative evolution. However
column4: this time McMahon lets the tape roll past the final chord
column5: and after he confidently declares ""that’s the one
column6: I think
column7: we hear a chintzy electronic-doorbell chime
column8: the sort of modern dollar-store distraction that Amen Dunes’ music seems designed to transport us away from. ""Woah
column9: perfect timing
column10: McMahon chuckles as drummer Parker Kindred enters the studio
column11: but in that seemingly frivolous exchange
column12: a certain maxim of recording is reinforced. A perfect take ultimately requires the serendipitous absence of external distractions beyond one’s control; the artist’s actual performance is just one of many stars that have to align.

column1: That said
column2: the first drafts McMahon scrapped along the way to Love’s completion could’ve easily held their own amid the album proper; in lieu of any major structural variations
column3: the early versions heard on Cowboy Worship are more like alternate mixes that accentuate or deemphasize McMahon’s measured use of noise. Love’s raucous
column4: in-the-red climax ""I Can’t Dig It"" is presented in a more controlled
column5: piano-rolled take (recorded as he first wrote it in China)
column6: but the quieter performance ultimately serves to amplify the textural strangeness wafting behind McMahon’s anthemic exclamations. And while a primordial ""Green Eyes"" lacks the haunting Elias Rønnenfelt guest vocal that imbues the Love version
column7: it’s given a thick coating of molten psychedelic ooze courtesy of Harvey Milk’s Stephen Tanner. (The EP also features a revision of ""Lezzy Head"" from 2011’s Through Donkey Jaw that dials down the original’s oddball wobble for a more patient
column8: meditative treatment closer in spirit to Love.)

column1: Given the similarities to its source material
column2: Cowboy Worship probably would’ve made more sense as a bonus-disc appendage to Love than a stand-alone release. The EP even closes just as Love
column3: serif;""><span> does
column4: with the latter’s eight-minute title track (the apotheosis of McMahon’s effort to unite singer-songwriter tradition with avant-jazz exploration)
column5: and while the Cowboy Worship
column6: serif;""> mix gradually brings Colin Stetson and Jen Reimer’s subliminal horn hum to the fore
column7: such subtleties simply reinforce the original’s transportive
column8: out-of-body effect. As such
column9: Cowboy Worship’s most notable feature is also its outlier: a Ben Greenberg-assisted
column10: dueling-acoustic rip through Tim Buckley’s ""Song to the Siren"". It’s a tune that’s hardly lacking for covers
column11: of course
column12: and McMahon acknowledges this history by imagining Buckley covering This Mortal Coil’s immortal version of his own song. But Buckley’s conflation of human and earthly nature fits right into Love’s thematic wheelhouse—and
column13: by striking the same balance of ethereal and elemental that defines the music of Amen Dunes
column14:
McMahon makes ""Siren"" his own.
