Disappears left plenty of space in the cracks on their last album
column2: 2013's Era
column3: and at points it was a surprisingly inviting kind of emptiness. That album's title track even gripped something like a hook: ""Is rapture your only fear/ Or do you think about it at all?"" asks singer Brian Case at the chorus. Sure
column4: he's musing on the end of days
column5: but at least he's singing right to us. No such luck with the Chicago band's fifth album
column6: Irreal. Disappears have traded in their last pop streak for a world of stark and brutal rhythm.

column1: Instead of questions
column2: answers
column3: and hypotheses
column4: the lyrics on Irreal assume the shape of isolated fragments. Instead of melodies
column5: the instruments trace shrapnel in the wind. ""I want to remember/ Make me
column6: Case demands on ""Interpretation"" as a roiling drum pattern whips past him. He repeats the words in a steely monotone
column7: only breaking his flat timbre when he throws the occasional ""oi!"" away from the mike. Somewhere behind him
column8: guitars that don't sound like guitars play chords that don't sound like chords. ""Anything could happen
column9: he smirks
column10: and it's more of a threat than a promise.

column1: Irreal is a deliberately exhausting listen. The band dares you to see how far you can stomp behind them without a melodic phrase or a lyrical narrative to grab hold of. But unlike Swans
column2: who paved much of this terrain
column3: Disappears sound more resigned than spiteful. They're eager to pummel themselves
column4: but not because it offers any catharsis.

column1: ""Another thought/ Another memory
column2: Case drones later in the record. ""Living in a loop of different lives."" His accompaniment is pitchy
column3: nervous
column4: and streaked with noise. The drums racket from the right channel to the left. This is cabin fever at its most intricate
column5: a cage of beautiful repeating patterns that holds no chance of escape.

column1: On the album's title track
column2: the guitars seem to bicker with each other
column3: cutting squalls of feedback with sharp
column4: demented arpeggios. Even the name sounds like a trap
column5: a portmanteau of ""unreal"" and ""irregular
column6: maybe
column7: a word that's just familiar enough to hint at meaning while still coming up void. When Case pronounces it
column8: it sounds like ""I will."" I wonder if there's supposed to be a pun on ""IRL""
column9: too.

column1: The song ""Halcyon Days"" probably hides a joke about aging behind its title. It's certainly no calm before the storm. That may be Irreal's whole punchline: You count your years in suffocating routines and repeated patterns. You build memories somewhere between the filler. What do you get from it
column2: except a library of respites to look back on in the tedium? What good are the best days of your life if you can only access them in retrospect?

column1: The album's last song coughs up the first melodic bass line in the whole piece
column2: a mournful
column3: descending figure. ""Am I alone now?"" Case wonders as the record spirals to a close. The band named that song ""Navigating the Void"". If Irreal is a map
column4: don't expect to stop walking in tight
column5:
lonely circles.

"|20065.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20065-irreal/|7.0|Sasha Geffen

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21353/homepage_large.2e9070e1.jpg|Euclid|32669.0|Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Western Vinyl']|2015-01-19 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:01.207829|"

There’s a gentle kind of alchemy at work on Euclid
column2: making it feel like the work of someone with an unshakable belief in magic. Bay Area composer Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith has produced works before
column3: ranging from the glacial wistfulness of Useful Trees to electronic compositions with a distinctly agrarian hue (Cows will eat the weeds). This album
column4: her first for Western Vinyl
column5: is Smith’s most complete album yet
column6: with a range that encompasses something approaching song structure and a form of ambient drift that nimbly floats up into the stratosphere. The overall feeling of enchantment is only heightened by learning that Euclid was recorded primarily on a Buchla Music Easel
column7: a synth as colorful as the sounds it creates
column8: and vocal passages that only occasionally resemble words. She puts some separation between its two sides
column9: flooding Euclid’s first half with song-y material then plunging into a reflective pool in its backend
column10: making it feel like Smith took out a pair of scissors and carefully cut the record in two.

column1: The most noticeable trait of Euclid is how light it feels—there’s very little bass
column2: nothing much to hold it down. It appears to just float there in front of you
column3: opening up its kaleidoscopic layers. Smith grew up in isolation
column4: on an island in Washington state
column5: and there’s a certain singularity to her work that surely grew out of those roots. She often appears adrift in her music
column6: endlessly laying strips of sound over one another until everything’s just right. For ""Careen""
column7: Smith works in a space similar to the one inhabited by High Places in the latter part of the last decade
column8: where hippy idylls
column9: rustic charm
column10: and gusty pop combine as one. If there is a darker component to her work it’s in the processed vocals
column11: which resemble the type of squelchy effects Karin Dreijer Andersson tried on for the Knife’s Silent Shout on ""Wide Awake"". Still
column12: those are only loose comparisons—a big part of the charm of Euclid is in hearing someone mapping out their own space and time
column13: figuring out their own destination to land in.

column1: Of the first half-dozen songs here it’s in ""Sundry"" that everything coalesces
column2: with Smith drawing on a tone that’s just the right side of whimsical. It’s here that her instrumental passages squeak and cry
column3: feeling like she’s conducting a dialogue with them through the wordless vocal inflections skirting across the top. There’s joy
column4: although not the kind that gives over to abandon—her music is slightly too studied for that. Smith indulges the considered side of her personality further on the set of ""Labyrinth""-themed tracks that make up the second half of Euclid
column5: where rain-like trickles of synth vie with cloudier electronics and deep pulses purposefully obscured in the mix. It’s in a similar sphere to Laurie Spiegel’s The Expanding Universe
column6: where rhythms come together then break apart
column7: where a single one- or two-note riff becomes a macrocosm unto itself. Sometimes it’s a little too blurry
column8: but it’s superseded by the way Smith works her way around sounds to open up new dimensions in them.

column1: There’s a video clip of Smith playing her Music Easel
column2: which enforces this album’s air of beauty mixed in with color and conjury. Smith plugs brightly colored cables into its modular interface and her hands drift over its silvery keys
column3: creating an expanse of sound that’s more elastic than you might expect from just a few operations. There’s an element of gear fetishization to it for sure
column4: but also a healthy dose of wonder
column5: causing it to feel like you’re watching someone just as enamored of the process of discovery as they are with delivering a final product. That’s a useful way to describe Euclid
column6: with Smith figuring out a place to operate in somewhere between structure and freedom
column7: often indulging one and not the other. This feels like a beginning rather than a natural way forward
column8:
but it’s driven by an important idea—where the process of separation can be a more powerful and intuitive way of working than forcing harmony upon contrasting ideas.

"|20084.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20084-euclid/|7.3|Nick Neyland

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21382/homepage_large.452c117c.jpg|SremmLife|32655.0|Rae Sremmurd|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Interscope'
column3: buoyed by effervescent hits like the anti-stunt anthem ""No Flex Zone"" and the jarring synth pound ""No Type""—a song revered by composers and bloggers alike—Rae Sremmurd became a household name despite the fact that people have had a hard time figuring out how to say ""Rae Sremmurd"". SremmLife
column4: their debut LP
column5: floats with a singular energy
column6: a culmination of the group’s 2014 coming-of-age.

column1: While trying to build an album of stuff that’s approximately as good as ""No Flex Zone"" or ""No Type"" is a tall task
column2: SremmLife hurdles the hype machine with infectious rap music. It never sags
column3: packing hooks into every pocket and half-beat. Swae Lee giddily slides over syllables (""trill-ass ind-div-vid-du-al"" on ""No Flex Zone"") while Slim Jimmy’s gruffer delivery sets up an interesting vocal dynamic where sometimes it’s difficult to discern who’s rapping
column4: but at other times it’s clear as day. A six-second snippet of each song would be enough for its own free-standing Vine
column5: but often the full product—energetic pounds like ""Up Like Trump"" and ""YNO""—earns its longer form.

column1: Though a few songs stretch out an interesting idea too far—for instance
column2: the post-Nae-Nae scrum ""My X""—SremmLife is a showcase of an electric new talent paired with all the trappings of a bigtime major label debut. Guests like Big Sean
column3: Young Thug
column4: and Nicki Minaj (who sings the earworm hook on strip-club anthem ""Throw Sum Mo"") meet the energy of the Brown brothers
column5: who are paired with exceptional production from Mike WiLL
column6: Sonny Digital
column7: and others. The music here is at once huge but also inward looking—burly soundscapes like ""No Type"" and the closer ""Safe Sex Pay Checks"" create an atmosphere that suggest something shadowy lurking outside the frame. Given that SremmLife is a flagship of Mike WiLL’s new Ear Drummer  imprint
column8: it may not be surprising that SremmLife is a logical companion to his other recent pop-minded success—Miley Cyrus’ Bangerz
column9: the album equivalent of being caught up in the thrill of an epic party but knowing that it’ll soon come crashing down. It’s life-affirming music in ways that make you feel both better and worse.

column1: SremmLife fulfills the promise of ""No Flex Zone"" and ""No Type""
column2: though a prominent piece of the record hints at something more. ""This Could Be Us""
column3: SremmLife’s fifth song
column4: stands apart from the whole. A lovely track about a failed relationship
column5: the brothers Brown—Jimmy rapping
column6:
Swae singing—deliver a promise that’s easy to project a successful career upon. Above all else Rae Sremmurd pull you in with their synergy and symmetry: SremmLife is a less of an album and more of a way of life.

"|20113.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20113-sremmlife/|7.8|Corban Goble

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21374/homepage_large.70e74a8f.jpg|Blackheart|30349.0|Dawn Richard|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Our Dawn Entertainment']|2015-01-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:02.496177|"

Dawn Richard has spent her solo career blowing up emotions to near-mythical levels. Her last solo album
column2: 2013's self-released Goldenheart
column3: portrayed a love affair in the language of battle and war
column4: while 2012's Armor On channeled it through religious devotion. It's potentially hammy territory
column5: but it works because Richard sells it so well—she's a tremendously evocative singer who can turn a song as fluffy as Katy Perry's ""Dark Horse"" into something truly exotic and alluring. And with help from her close partner Druski
column6: she dressed it all up in sleek
column7: futuristic production. All of that made last year's reunion of Danity Kane
column8: the ""Making the Band"" group with which she got her start
column9: almost shocking
column10: at least on Richard's part. Jettisoning her independent freedom in favor of cookie-cutter girl-group pop she already managed to escape once
column11: it turned out the group couldn't contain her anyway. The reunion only lasted a few months
column12: resulting in a nearly-unlistenable album and an alleged physical altercation involving Richard. Now
column13: just a few months after DK3 landed with a flop
column14: we get Blackheart
column15: a fierce and sometimes harrowing album that feels all the more potent given the shaky year that preceded it.

column1: Blackheart is the second installment in Richard's planned Heart trilogy
column2: and it also launches a new phase in her career which she calls ""The Black Era."" Appropriately
column3: the music is darker
column4: more paranoid
column5: and more personal. Where Goldenheart's themes of romance were intentionally universal
column6: Blackheart deals with Richard's own experiences in the music industry
column7: her frustrations and her frayed nerves. She also plays a much larger role in the production
column8: co-producing most of the tracks herself with Noisecastle III. Don't be fooled by the bump and grind R&B of first single ""Blow""; Blackheart offers a sprawling and sometimes knotty take on songwriting
column9: sometimes doing away with verse and chorus structure altogether and settling on a stream-of-consciousness barrage instead.

column1: The album's opening run seems purposefully designed to scare away less adventurous listeners with rushing synth runs
column2: jungle breaks
column3: and sharply-cut vocal samples. Dawn doesn't even come in for three minutes on ""Calypso""
column4: and once she does
column5: she's nearly taken in by the tide anyways. The idea might be a cliché at this point
column6: but on Blackheart Richard truly uses the studio as an instrument. Organic sounds are few and far between
column7: and just when you think you've got a hold on a song
column8: it could all melt away and morph into something else entirely. ""Billie Jean"" turns from side-eye rant into an orchestral ballad
column9: and the cautionary tale ""Adderall/Sold"" swells into a passionate vocoder hymnal where Richard bellows ""She was living/ Like she's dying soon"" with such conviction that it's hard to believe she's not talking about herself. The vocoder aappears over and over on Blackheart
column10: embellishing her cries with a gravity that meshes with the already otherworldly texture of her natural voice.

column1: There are a few more traditional moments on Blackheart
column2: beginning with the power ballad ""Warriors""
column3: which sounds like a holdover from Goldenheart. ""Projection"" is a stunning rumination on memory that sounds illusory
column4: transient
column5: and in danger of simply flickering out at any moment
column6: while ""Castles"" focuses on themes of fragility and solidarity amidst a torrent of vocal ad-libs both sampled and Richard's own. This section of the album forms a redemptive arc that peaks with ""Phoenix""
column7: a feel-good duet with ex-Danity Kane partner Aundrea Fimbres that would be overbearing if it didn't feel so triumphant. Look at it one way and it's a typical radio song about coming back from heartbreak
column8: but put it in the context of Richard's career outside her solo work—a series of false starts unbefitting of such a uniquely talented artist—and it feels transcendent. Even its relatively simple structure and Top 40 sonics register as a renewed sense of clarity rather than a compromise.

column1: The excess of ""Phoenix"" is tempered by ""Choices""
column2: a short interlude where Richard croons ""I love you/ But I love me more"" over gilded threads of synthesizer. It's one of the many little moments on Blackheart that feels like an emotional punch in the stomach
column3: especially once she starts cooing ""I choose me"" in gorgeous falsetto melisma that sounds as effortless as her talk-singing on ""Billie Jean"". ""Choices"" and penultimate track ""Deep""—a bare
column4: conciliatory climax—are a reminder that beneath all the production flourishes and high-art concepts
column5: Richard is also a deft and powerful vocalist.

column1: ""Deep"" is a heartbreaking conclusion where Richard acknowledges her mistakes. ""Trying to save the little soul I have left/ I lost it in a poker game to the highest bet/ And if you ask me I'm not the kind to play and quit/ And even though I lost the best of me/ It was worth it
column2: goes the opening verse
column3: a confession from someone who was
column4: at one point in her career
column5: part of a major pop group. As she stands now
column6: Richard is a lone wolf
column7: and Blackheart reaffirms it. The album pulls her back onto the path she she started with Armor On and into unknown territory.

column1: ""I took it to the deep
column2: she sings on the song's chorus
column3: ""because my heart doesn't swim in shallow creeks."" She's not exaggerating: if there's anything that defines Richard's music
column4: it's her grand
column5: sweeping feelings that she lays bare for all to see and hear. Blackheart takes it down a peg from the mythology of Goldenheart into a more introspective
column6: earthy realm—that it's wrapped up in inventive production that feels about five years ahead of mainstream radio is just icing on the cake. She begins the album howling ""I thought I lost it all"" into the void
column7: but by the end
column8: it feels like she found herself
column9: and her voice
column10: again—Blackheart is the singular
column11:
visionary work that she's been hinting at since she struck out on her own post-Diddy in 2011.

"|20104.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20104-blackheart/|8.0|Andrew Ryce

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21394/homepage_large.51a0cdb6.jpg|Ransom|31333.0|Mike WiLL Made-It|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ear Drummer']|2015-01-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:03.070892|"

You may have heard: Atlanta's become an undeniable commercial force for rap over the past 10 years
column2: producing huge stars and molding hip-hop's core sound. A relentless microscope now fixates upon the city
column3: waiting expectantly for the next 2 Chainz
column4: Gucci
column5: or Jeezy. Creative peaks and valleys are glossed over
column6: a craggy history remembered as one long ascent
column7: success a continually foregone conclusion. And so we end up with a ""flourishing"" young scene as rampant with speculation and opportunism as genuine creative talent. Although veterans (Nicki
column8: Gucci) pop up on Mike WiLL Made It's Ransom mixtape
column9: it's mainly a showcase for rookies (iLoveMakonnen
column10: Young Thug) and aspiring stars (the various members of Two-9
column11: Bankroll Fresh)
column12: eager to stake their claim on the city's storied history.

column1: Much as DJ Mustard's 10 Summers sat in the shadow of his work on YG's much more successful My Krazy Life
column2: Ransom feels like a supplement to Rae Sremmurd's SremmLife. But where Mustard's sound remained consistent across his two major projects
column3: Mike WiLL's Ear Drummers stable diverged sharply for this release. SremmLife is a jubilant pop record
column4: packed with hooks and teeming with effervescent juvenile energy. But Ransom fits its stark black-and-leather cover art to a T. The production throughout
column5: replete with minor-key piano loops and metallic textures
column6: conjures up a sinister atmosphere
column7: even when the rappers themselves pull away from this brooding mien.

column1: Mike WiLL made a name for himself thanks to a counterintuitive taste for subtlety. In a time when clobbering
column2: maximal Luger beats dominated the Down South mixtape circuit
column3: Mike WiLL was drawn to subtle effects
column4: like the way his use of EQ filtering and panning submerged listeners in the emotional space of a booming strip club record. On Ransom
column5: the Ear Drummers production team is at its best when working towards a similarly crafted style
column6: where use of space and attention to the details of timbre and atmosphere takes precedence. No other producers so precisely approximate tactile sensations. At their best
column7: these beats evoke steam rising from steel.

column1: The 21-track street tape can feel like something of an endurance test; the superstar-laden ""Buy the World"" displays the shortcomings of Mike WiLL's approach
column2: an example of how easy it is to lose track of the forest while focusing so intently on the trees. In fact
column3: it's the star vehicles which suffer the most; ""I Lied""
column4: which also appeared on The Pinkprint
column5: aims for sincerity but feels like a detached approximation; Juicy J feature ""Don't Trust"" has the grim obligation of a winter commute. And unfortunately
column6: a fizzy carbonation of the ""Choppin' Blades"" beat can't redeem RiFF RAFF's loveless false advertising: ""Jody Highroller
column7: anything can happen."" Nothing does.

column1: Opener ""Paradise (Intro)""
column2: an acrobatic feature for established star Big Sean
column3: is a major exception. And Rich Homie Quan's ""Hasta Lauego"" conveys the kind of heartfelt candor that would have made an ideal closer. Future's three appearances are all exceptional standouts from an artist not always remembered for his lyrics. But despite a spotty hit rate
column4: it's novice performers who dominate the highlight reel
column5: glimmering in the tape's portentous tunnel vision.

column1: Newcomer Bankroll Fresh has been on the receiving end of a fair amount of hype
column2: with Atlanta on the lookout for a new street rap auteur. Thus far
column3: Bankroll's dry
column4: unadorned style has been easy to appreciate but hard to love. Thanks to dynamic production from Mike WiLL and Pluss
column5: ""Screen Door"" transforms a familiar dope boy story into an unpredictable noir—a standout in the rapper's diminutive catalog. On Yung Joey and Dej Loaf's ""Possible""
column6: Mike WiLL and JBo weave an enigmatic canvas through layered chimes
column7: letting the stars move with confidence in an air of wavering uncertainty. And while ""ethereal"" might be one of music criticism's most abused words
column8: no term better captures the queasy anxiety of Swae Lee and Future's ""Drinks On Us""
column9: the album's best song.

column1: At its best
column2: Ransom feels like an album-length exploration of the sound Mike WiLL established with 2014's ""Move That Dope"". But with doubt and ambiguity as its primary tonal colors
column3: Ransom is a tough recommendation front to back. Few will last the numbing trek through its extended running time
column4: and some of its stronger moments are liable to fall through the cracks. Nonetheless
column5:
it's encouraging to see a producer willing to go out on a limb for the new and developing generation at a time when a click-driven press is so attentive to established legacy artists.

"|20125.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20125-ransom/|6.7|David Drake

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21386/homepage_large.c6219414.jpg|Cosmic Vibrations|28805.0|Secret Circuit|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Emotional Response']|2015-01-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:03.556363|"

Despite an uptick in activity in the past year
column2: one suspects that Eddie Ruscha Jr. isn’t looking to surrender the laidback and low-key aspect of Secret Circuit's music anytime soon. There have been opening dates for idiosyncratic indie artists such as Panda Bear and Ariel Pink and remixes ranging from a dreamy take on DFA’s Museum of Love to a ludicrously dubbed-out version of Peter Tosh’s ""Legalize It"". But rather than go for bigger beats or more epic statements
column3: he seems content to just make crafty yet understated tracks
column4: touching on boogie
column5: Balearic
column6: cosmic disco
column7: ambient
column8: and leftfield dance music without ever alighting on one place too long. There’s an underlying attitude to the music that makes you think that Ruscha’s side project Blasé might just be truth in advertising.

column1: Cosmic Vibrations—despite the spaciness of its title—is at its most delightful the closer it stays to terra firma. The second compilation of tracks culled from a run of cassettes self-released between 1996 and 2012
column2: Vibrations isn’t too different in feel to 2012’s Tropical Psychedelics
column3: though the beats all feel a bit looser the second time around
column4: less concerned with getting your feet to move than your head to nod. Opener ""Out West"" features the kind of slow
column5: sputtering drum machine that could be bought from Sly Stone’s yard sale
column6: Ruscha then adding analog keys and a reverberating guitar lifted from a desert noir
column7: ample echo applied to all components until at one point they blur into a haze.

column1: As opposed to Tactile Galactics and Tropical Psychedelics
column2: the tracks aren’t wholly dependent on old analog synthesizers for their melodies as instead Ruscha adds licks of guitar to the mix. Much like his sometimes collaborator Torn Hawk
column3: he processes and compresses the strings until they take on strange new quicksilver shapes. Around the tribal thump of ""Cartusian Log Book"" are picked guitar lines—run through effects until their notes resemble bubbles from an upturned water cooler jug—which turn to ripples on the surface of the track. Another twanging set of exotic strings sync with the machine clicks of ""Minimal Vibrations"".

column1: On most of his tracks
column2: there’s a feel not unlike a pied bunch of genres of all different colors all wadded up into a big Play-Doh ball
column3: which at times makes tracks gum up into something not quite as distinct as its components. ""Straightline"" uses a shuffling digital reggae beat and shoots it through with backwards guitars and Ruscha’s own murmured vocals
column4: the effect not unlike an Alan Parsons Project outtake. ""Nova Laser"" is a pleasant enough groove of an instrumental
column5: but in light of other L.A.-based producers of a similar ilk (think Benedek
column6: Suzanne Kraft or Stones Throw folks) the track feels unfinished. A guitar sears across the tropical hot dog marimbas of ""Somnambulation"" yet the track just wanders away after engaging you.

column1: Had Inherent Vice been set a bit deeper in the 1970s
column2: Ruscha could have provided the perfect soundtrack to sync with those washed-out SoCal vibes
column3: stoned yet groovy. Yet on standouts like the hummed-harmony chug of ""She Got Love"" (which sounds like a '70s Beach Boys outtake tweaked by Todd Terje) and ""Shockers""
column4: Ruscha weds outer space phasers to an irresistible cosmic disco thump
column5:
concocting a psychedelic level of synergy that would make any Californian glow.

"|20117.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20117-cosmic-vibrations/|7.4|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21396/homepage_large.f86edce9.jpg|The Dead of the World|32688.0|Ascension|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Season of Mist']|2015-01-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:04.172819|"

When I saw the German black metal band Ascension at Maryland Deathfest in 2013
column2: they were among the most memorable acts
column3: largely because it was hard to know what to make of them. After being battered with a weekend of booze and an especially pulverizing set from the war metal group Revenge
column4: their performance took on semi-psychedelic qualities. Their identities remain unknown
column5: which is not all that unusual for a black metal group
column6: but their singer was unmistakable
column7: resembling a zombified '70s John McLaughlin with longer hair and a creepier disposition. Ascension played as if they were not only trying to lift the crowd out of Sunday sloth
column8: but also trying to redeem them in a blackened fashion. That they played under a white tent only added to the black metal revival vibe. Even if they weren't consciously trying to be weird
column9: it was one of the strangest performances of the fest that year.

column1: Ascension's actual work isn't quite that trippy. Their 2010 debut full-length Consolamentum was an interesting hybrid of black metal
column2: noise
column3: and spindly guitar work; for a young group
column4: they showed plenty of ambition. With The Dead of the World
column5: Ascension have cut back on some of the more far-flung aspects of their debut in favor of a more streamlined sound
column6: building on an early 2000s Swedish black metal approach pioneered by Watain and Ofermod. This focus favors them in some ways
column7: but they're still holding themselves back from making a real impact.

column1: ""Deathless Light"" was released as a single in October
column2: and it is easily the strongest song on the record. That opening salvo is where they embrace their black metal roots the most
column3: trance-like and utterly destructive all at once. Drums lull and pulsate; guitars twist in spiky knots without becoming needlessly complex. All of this is Ascension taking their name seriously: this is music for a one-way cannon shot to a higher plane. Some of the lead work from Consolamentum also returns on ""Light""
column4: and while saying that the rest of the record is undeveloped would be false
column5: this song feels the most thought-out and rightfully executed of them all.

column1: Right before ""Light"" is ""Unlocking Tiamat""
column2: whose overt doominess and mid-paced
column3: chunky intro chords could have been something off a Triptykon record. Interestingly enough
column4: Triptykon guitarist V. Santura assisted in recording and mastering Dead
column5: and with a fuller production
column6: the doomier sections
column7: which have a much greater presence on this album
column8: work. Even with a more unified sound
column9: they don't sap energy from the album as a whole. ""Death's Golden Temple"" also carries a blackened Triptykon vibe
column10: though the vocalist doesn't attempt to replicate the uncanny vocals of Tom G. Warrior. The slower passages also feel more mournful
column11: as a way of crying for the loss of LSK
column12: a veteran of the French black metal scene who contributed vocals to Consolamentum and took her own life in October 2013.

column1: Dead is a frustrating record
column2: one that finds the band on the cusp of making something truly great. While consistency and better production do work in Ascension's favor
column3: some of the spontaneity of the first record would have been rendered even more powerfully here. A singular focus won't help if that focus is not at its most intense; Ascension don't half-ass it
column4:
they're just at the edge.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21349/homepage_large.3be1da81.jpg|Mr. Face EP|27962.0|Ty Segall|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Famous Class']|2015-01-15 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:04.827584|"

Pity the poor live album. In the era of streaming video
column2: smartphones
column3: and extensive fan-driven digital archiving
column4: their utility has diminished. Amid so much constantly accumulating data
column5: it’s difficult for a single concert—particularly one that you did not personally attend—to feel at all remarkable. And let’s be real: the old problems remain unresolved. With the exception of the Grateful Dead
column6: no band’s live record is its best record.

column1: Castle Face Records’ Live in San Francisco series is an outlier
column2: though. It’s not so much about a single artist as a whole scene. Over the last couple of years
column3: the label has released a number of concert recordings capturing the bests acts in—or intimately involved with—the Bay Area’s garage and psych-rock community
column4: including sets from OBN IIIs
column5: White Fence
column6: and Icky Boyfriends. The performances are usually recorded to a Tascam 388 tape machine
column7: which imbues the recordings with a grit-heavy feel that’s not too distant from the band’s ""studio"" albums.

column1: Ty Segall Band’s Live in San Francisco is the fifth installment in the series. This isn’t his first live record (that was 2011’s Live in Aisle Five) and it’s not even his first appearance in the series (his prog-loving side project
column2: Fuzz
column3: was also included)
column4: but it's an important addition. Along with Castle Face co-founder John Dwyer and his band Thee Oh Sees
column5: Segall was a defining voice in the city's late '00s garage rock bubble and he and Dwyer are also
column6: arguably
column7: its most popular exports. And while it’s clear that Segall is prolific—he’s put out a double LP and a singles collection just within the last six months—this record isn’t filler.

column1: Like a garage-rock version of Prince
column2: Segall performs almost all of the music on his LPs alone
column3: yet his live band—which includes drummer Emily Rose Epstein
column4: guitarist Charles Mootheart
column5: and bassist Mikal Cronin—is no joke. Having toured extensively for the last four years
column6: they’ve tightened up into a be-all
column7: end-all rock'n'roll group with the volatility and spirit to match choice '70s sweathogs like the Coloured Balls or Groundhogs.

column1: The set list draws heavily from 2011’s full-band album
column2: Slaughterhouse
column3: along with a few of the heavier cuts from the last handful of Segall’s solo records. These live takes are
column4: for the most part
column5: harsher
column6: nastier
column7: and faster than their studio versions. The song ""Feel"" appeared on last year’s double LP Manipulator with a considerably more polished presentation. The version on Live in San Francisco is unhinged—abandoning nuance for five minutes of gale force choogle.

column1: Some of the other entries in Castle Face’s live series have encouraged spontaneity via covers or drawn-out jams. Regrettably
column2: there’s not much of that to be found on Live in San Francisco. Here Segall and his band perform the songs pretty much as written
column3: only louder. It isn't Segall's best record
column4: but it's worthwhile if only in that it documents the whole crew playing together at the peak of their ability.

column1: And because
column2: you know
column3: why stop there: this month also sees the release of Segall’s Mr. Face EP. On Manipulator
column4: Segall attempted to dial in an ambitious high-gloss classic rock masterpiece
column5: complete with string section. Mr. Face is more or less back to business as usual—four songs that find Segall returning to the hazy mid-fi sound of his 2010 LP
column6: Melted.

column1: Available digitally and also as a pair of 7'' singles—which double as 3D glasses—the four songs are pleasant enough
column2: but in comparison to the unruly sounds on Live in San Francisco
column3: it feels like a bit of an afterthought. At this point
column4: Segall can write this kind of lightly dazed
column5: psychedelic pop with about as much effort as most people expend while checking their e-mail. If anything
column6: Mr. Face is enough to tide you over until the next Segall record which
column7: as always
column8:
can’t be all that far off.

"|20080.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20080-mr-face-eplive-in-san-francisco/|6.8|Aaron Leitko

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21383/homepage_large.83a5071c.jpg|Sunset Mountain|29364.0|Geotic|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-01-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:05.456298|"

Though Baths is his best known musical project
column2: the Los Angeles native Will Wiesenfeld once said he was more likely to make music under the name Geotic ""when it’s beautiful and cold outside and the weather is just more mellow."" Given its ambient sound and comparatively basic hip-hop loops
column3: the side project felt less ambitious than Baths
column4: but also less theatrical
column5: less constructed
column6: and overall
column7: like a more comfortable listening experience. Last July
column8: after a three year hiatus
column9: Wiesenfeld once again started releasing music as Geotic
column10: this time in service of a trilogy of albums referred to collectively as Eon Isle.

column1: But while the first album in the series
column2: Morning Shore
column3: may have seemed like a throwback to that comfortable sound
column4: Wiesenfeld had transformed Geotic; no longer a release from the creative strain that clearly went into Baths
column5: it was now a challenge unto itself. Each Eon Isle album is constructed from the sounds of a single instrument. Morning Shore was all guitar. The second album in the trilogy
column6: Sunset Mountain
column7: which came out last month
column8: consists entirely of vocals and nothing more. (The final album
column9: <i>Evening Sky
column10: due next spring
column11: will be made from piano.)

column1: While the trilogy has a clear sense of exploration in common with its Geotic predecessors
column2: it also finds Wiesenfeld on more of a mission. Albums like Mend found him happily meandering
column3: but the restrictions he’s imposed on himself both on Morning Shore and on Sunset Mountain can make it seem as if he’s throwing down a kind of creative gauntlet
column4: a test to be overcome. That’s particularly true on Sunset Mountain. Though the human voice is at least as flexible an instrument as the guitar
column5: for whatever reason
column6: Wiesenfeld restrains himself here more so than he did on the last record.

column1: The result is an even more technically impressive set of compositions
column2: which find Wiesenfeld constructing vocal cathedrals—tracks whose complexity is such that it becomes entirely possible to forget that the entire thing is voice and voice alone. ""Hidden Springs
column3: Floating Leaves"" sounds as if it was written for a choir—the variety of voices layered around each other in different registers is staggering in its breadth
column4: even when you forget that it's all Wiesenfeld. ""Reach the Broad Expanse"" shows equal range
column5: as Wiesenfeld roughs up one version of his voice
column6: letting his lowest tone provide a floor for the track while other iterations of his voice float toward the sky.

column1: A characteristic shared by Baths and Geotic are the two projects’ intense sensuality. In much of his music
column2: Wiesenfeld comes off as almost carnal
column3: a man obsessed with the way things feel and taste. For that reason
column4: the music on his new record
column5: even when angelic in melody
column6: can come across as decidedly more deviant. It is gothic in a way that is less sober Bavarian hymnal and more ""The Turn of the Screw"".

column1: Indeed
column2: while monks do appear in one of the album’s best tracks
column3: they are described as being ""off somewhere
column4: and there is a lilting sweetness to the singing here that is less mournful and more satisfied-sounding. ""Hidden Springs
column5: Floating Leaves"" makes use of that same wicked vocal style that fans will recognize from Obsidian
column6: and even ""Piggybacking""
column7: with its heavenly spiral stair patterns
column8: comes off as somewhat sexual. (Though it may just be that the song’s title is reminiscent of the ""sweet swine"" from ""Ironworks""
column9: the one engaged in ""tempestuous foreplay."")

column1: Without any instrument available to keep time (thankfully
column2: Wiesenfeld does not beatbox here) the album suffers from significant problems with pacing. Some of the tracks here retain a remarkable sense of momentum
column3: the kind usually created by the presence of a beat. ""We Can Conquer Small Fears"" is an early example; the track is patterned to the point where it’s easy to detect its natural rhythm. But several falter. True to its name
column4: ""Slow Fading Heat"" is a slow
column5: fading bore
column6: one of more than a few songs here that lull you into forgetting about the creative talent behind them even when your attention is fully focused on them.

column1: And that’s ultimately the key issue with Sunset Mountain. This sort of formal experiment fades a little when you ignore the process and consider the end-result. It’s impressive that Wiesenfeld is able to magic this music out of such a limited tool-set but at the same time
column2: imposing those kinds of gimmicky limitations may be keeping Wiesenfeld from dealing with knottier artistic puzzles.  Since his best album to date
column3: Obsidian
column4: was released in 2013
column5: he’s made a single EP as Baths. While Geotic is pretty
column6: diverting
column7: and shows a prodigious formal skill
column8: the end product
column9: in spite of its process
column10: lacks the drive and ambition of the artist’s best work. It ends up feeling like something of a practice session
column11: albeit one of a very talented athlete
column12:
a grueling workout for the even more challenging event still to come.

"|20114.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20114-sunset-mountain/|6.4|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21384/homepage_large.1ee50e9d.jpg|Unmoored by the Wind|30820.0|Itasca|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New Images']|2015-01-15 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:06.809820|"

""Aloneness is a state of being
column2: Townes Van Zandt once observed
column3: ""Whereas loneliness is a state of feeling."" On Unmoored by the Wind
column4: Kayla Cohen
column5: a.k.a. Itasca
column6: spends much of her time navigating between those two states. Her folk-derived style is one that seems necessarily borne from many hours spent in solitude and quiet contemplation. And though this solitude has clearly given Cohen the space to perfect her instrumental craft and to revel in the rhythms of the natural world
column7: there is also a subtle tug of melancholy coursing through many of these songs that speaks to a sense of displacement and a yearning for community or connection.

column1: Unmoored by the Wind is Cohen’s second album proper under the Itasca name
column2: following a string of CD-R and cassette releases
column3: including several mystic drone and experimental works that she recorded under the name Sultan. On this album her work can be classified as a much more straightforward form of homespun folk. Cohen’s delicate and expert fingerpicking places her work somewhere in the area of American Primitive
column4: a genre that can always stand to benefit from additional female performers. But on Unmoored by the Wind
column5: her vocals are an even bigger draw. She has a voice that is at once striking and vaguely familiar
column6: the type of voice that will send folk-nerds to rack their memories to decide which other obscure or semi-obscure singer she most resembles. (I’m going with Bridget St. John and/or Sibylle Baier for now.)

column1: Recorded at her home in Los Angeles
column2: the album features the occasional flutter of flute or overdubbed vocal
column3: but is otherwise built almost exclusively on Cohen’s voice and acoustic guitar. She does a fine job of balancing the album’s lyric and instrumental passages
column4: and constructs her songs with enough textural variety and narrative energy that the album’s momentum never flags despite the simplicity of its production. Aside from such baroque interludes as ""Colt in Hiding""
column5: which features multi-tracked layers of angelic vocals
column6: the album’s overall tone is one of conversational intimacy
column7: and it is not difficult for listeners to feel as if we’ve been invited to pull up a chair right there in the room with her
column8: with the shades partially drawn.

column1: This never feels more literally true than on the prayer-like ""After Dawn""
column2: which finds the singer sitting quietly by her window watching as the sunlight changes and people flow past. It’s as though she is viewing the world and its human activities from a distant remove
column3: a meditative sort of self-imposed seclusion that is further echoed on such tracks as the pastoral ""The Hermit’s View"" or the dreamy instrumental idyll of ""Walking in Hahamongna"".

column1: Elsewhere
column2: however
column3: this sense of isolation from the world grows a bit more pronounced. On the narcotic ""Dream of the Water Bearer""
column4: the song’s narrator
column5: beset by mysterious dream figures
column6: helplessly waves her hands in the air ""just to see if I could change the picture."" Similar dream figures appear in ""Nature’s Gift""
column7: images that ""seem as if I’ve called them here"" although she is unable to determine how ""these angels can help me out.""

column1: When the dreamy cobwebs clear away
column2: as on the wake-up call ""Alleyway"" (""I walk out my door to find the world same as it was before"") and especially on the radiant ""Congregation""
column3: Cohen writes personal pep-talks with the lucidity and clarity of a self-help manual
column4: variously singing ""I’ve got to change my ways"" or ""I’ve got to find my hopeful place to rest"" like she is writing lines in a private journal. This feeling that we
column5: as listeners
column6: have been granted access into Itasca’s private inner sanctum is what helps give Unmoored by the Wind its quiet gravity
column7:
and her ample instrumental skills and deft songcraft make this invitation well worth your while. 

"|20115.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20115-unmoored-by-the-wind/|7.4|Matthew Murphy

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21379/homepage_large.e4c6ccfd.jpg|Money Train|2243.0|Mike Jones|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-01-15 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:07.387576|"

Houston rapper Mike Jones’ moment in the pop cultural sun was brief but intense: He scored a multiplatinum hit with 2005’s ""Still Tippin'""
column2: broke his city nationwide
column3: promptly fell out with his labelmates
column4: and became a symbol for ""too rich
column5: too fast
column6: all basically by 2007. The line separating ""icon"" and ""souvenir"" is always perilously thin
column7: but Jones made the leap more quickly than most rappers. By 2009
column8: he only appeared in news feeds for getting punched by colleagues or robbed by friends.

column1: Like T-Pain
column2: with whom he appeared on ""I’m 'n Luv (Wit a Stripper)""
column3: Jones has been quietly climbing back up his reputation cliff with a series of lower-profile
column4: solid releases. ""Where’s Mike Jones? I heard he back to runnin’ shit!"" he proclaimed on 2011's ""Leanin On Dat Butter""
column5: and while that certainly wasn’t true
column6: the song was another notch in a long comeback campaign.

column1: The Money Train
column2: a mixtape dropped at the start of the New Year
column3: is probably his most visible solo project since 2009
column4: but it’s not much different from his other work. He very loosely approximates Quavo’s jumpy
column5: bunched-up delivery on ""On My Momma"" and ""Hallelujah"". ""Call Me When You Need Me"" and ""What We On"" feature digitally processed singsong that faintly echoes Chicago bop
column6: but otherwise Jones doesn’t have much to offer to rap-listening kids who are probably too young to remember ""Still Tippin'"".

column1: The people Jones seems to be aiming for with Money Train are his old fans
column2: people now in their 30s
column3: who wonder what the hell happened to him. His next album
column4: after all
column5: is called Where’s Mike Jones?
column6: but ""What Happened to"" would have made just a suitable name. He drops a few verses on ""I Remember"" that hint at his struggle and his come-up
column7: but unlike T-Pain
column8: who returned with a searing take on his post-fame exile
column9: Jones has nearly nothing to say about where Mike Jones is
column10: or what happened to him. He could have spoken on losing hundreds of pounds
column11: weathering AIDS rumors
column12: falling out with Paul Wall and others
column13: and starting from square one
column14: but Jones has never been interested in autobiography apart from ""back then
column15: hoes didn’t want me.""

column1: Money Train is a well-made project: The viscous
column2: fluttering ""Foreign Whips""
column3: produced by DJ Plugg
column4: is moody and rich. Along with ""Let Me Show You"" and ""Champaigne Music""
column5: you can hear Jones mixing some of Drake’s melancholy into the tarry
column6: slow-moving Houston mix that he has borrowed so much from. But the tape has a generic
column7: stamped feel that makes it hard to care about. People moved by mild curiosity to download it will probably nod approvingly
column8: but Mike Jones never did much as an artist besides exist
column9:
which is maybe why he also disappeared so easily in the first place.

Chicago’s Red Red Meat
column2: led by Tim Rutili and including members he would carry on into his next band
column3: Califone
column4: were active in the fringes of alternative rock throughout the 1990s. They were one of the few groups that did something different with the basic tools of what was then called grunge. Red Red Meat were on Sub Pop and they toured with hometown friends Smashing Pumpkins
column5: but they were one of those indie bands that never really had a chance at the big time. They were too insular
column6: too weird
column7: they didn’t look very interesting on camera. But they made four fine records and the last of these
column8: 1997’s There’s a Star Above the Manger Tonight
column9: has been lovingly reissued.

column1: This wasn’t Red Red Meat’s best record—that honor goes to its predecessor
column2: 1995’s Bunny Gets Paid
column3: which gets over purely on the strength of its songwriting. Almost every cut on Bunny still sounds like a bent rock classic. Star Above the Manger
column4: on the other hand
column5: is an album about sound
column6: the place where Red Red Meat fully discovered the studio-as-instrument. One of the reasons the music press loved so much of '90s alternative rock is because it was heard as moving ""back to the basics"": loud guitars
column7: heavy drums
column8: and a singer howling in torment. From one angle
column9: it was a conservative movement. Red Red Meat provided an interesting twist on this template with an intent focus on technology. Based in Chicago in the '90s
column10: Red Red Meat were well aware of what bands in what would eventually come to be called post-rock were doing. The ideas of manipulating a gnarly guitar riff with a computer and snapping beats to a grid were not out of the question. All of those ideas came into full flower on Star Above the Manger. For as much crunchy
column11: blues-based riffing as is going on here
column12: Star feels like it’s happening inside of a computer. The band themselves were drawing inspiration from Teo Macero’s work with Miles Davis
column13: seeing how fragments of live jamming could be altered and re-edited into something new. The result is an album that
column14: even now
column15: 18 years later
column16: still sounds remarkably fresh and like little else.

column1: The ultra-stiff drums on ""Chinese Balls"" are one example among many of what makes this record unusual: on one level
column2: it sounds like a Stones-y rock song
column3: with trebly chords and slide guitar
column4: but the rhythmic undercurrent is pure Man-Machine
column5: even though the individual drum hits sound ""live."" The title track smashes old against new in a different but still intriguing way
column6: with a violin and banjo that are all pinched midrange
column7: bringing to mind the thin response of a 78 that might wind up on The Anthology of American Folk Music. But the layered voices and particulars of the mix sound thoroughly contemporary
column8: with small details that would have never occurred to someone hearing music before the advent of multi-track. On ""Second Hand Sea""
column9: one of the most beautiful ballads Tim Rutili has written
column10: the banjo is midrange-heavy and in an unusual tuning
column11: sounding more like a Chinese qinqin
column12: and it traces the delicate melody as bassy throbs of percussion crash like waves on a shore
column13: while the instrumental ""Paul Pachal"" moves from tense surges of guitar and malleted drums to something approaching pure noise music. You can never quite tell where you are inside this album—depression-era blues
column14: early-'70s arena rock
column15: downtown post-punk
column16: early laptop era—and all the sounds and techniques swirl together
column17: resulting in something beautifully disorienting.

column1: For the reissue
column2: boutique label Jealous Butcher have commissioned a new cover by John Herndon of Tortoise
column3: pressed the records on bright orange vinyl
column4: and have also included a variation on the song-specific artwork (also by Herndon) included with the original release. The latter is an especially nice touch
column5: as the projects of Red Red Meat and their various offshoots always had the aura of the found object
column6: that feeling when you confront something interesting without all the necessary context and figure out the story by working backwards. The bonus tracks
column7: the usual assortment of outtakes
column8: flesh out the story
column9: and demonstrate that this was indeed a fertile period of exploration for the band. The highlight among them is the version of ""Welcome Christmas""
column10: the B-side on the title track’s 7''. It’s a version of the song sung in Whoville during the climactic scene of How The Grinch Stole Christmas. Between this cover and the one of ""There’s Always Tomorrow""
column11: from ""Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer""
column12: off Bunny
column13: Red Red Meat out themselves as a band with a sentimental streak about the holiday season
column14: not unlike that of fellow travelers the Flaming Lips
column15: another group that did something strange and compelling within the confines of '90s alt rock. Red Red Meat never had a chance to be anywhere near that huge and probably would have blown it if they had
column16:
but their records hold up as well as any of the bands they were lumped with.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21373/homepage_large.26e6e0de.jpg|Remixes Made With Tennis Data|5462.0|James Murphy|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['IBM']|2015-01-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:08.647727|"

In 1961
column2: John Cage laid a musical stave over a map of the galaxies and traced clusters of notes over the stars. The result was Atlas Eclipticalis
column3: an unusual attempt at capturing the music of the spheres. He repeated the technique in 1974 for Etudes Australes
column4: a set of short
column5: blindingly difficult piano pieces he composed—or transcribed
column6: anyway
column7: with the help of the I Ching—for the pianist Grete Sultan. In a 1975 review in the New York Times
column8: John Rockwell drew a comparison to Arnold Schoenberg's 12-tone method
column9: noting that ""the music sounded almost serial
column10: in a lazily erratic sort of way. The process of its creation reflects Mr. Cage's all-embracing mysticism
column11: but one result is to insure a harmonic randomness that Schoenberg sought by far different means.""

column1: In the intervening years
column2: as the world has been plotted across every type of map and grid imaginable
column3: such translations of data points to musical values have become commonplace. Tobias Frere-Jones' ""F-Hz (#190736
column4: 1996)"" gathered a year's worth of high and low temperature readings from the Blue Hill Meteorological Observatory in Milton
column5: Massachusetts
column6: and converted them from Fahrenheit to hertz. On the 2000 album Traceroute
column7: the noise collective UBSB (Zbigniew Karkowski
column8: Atau Tanaka
column9: Edwin Van Der Heide
column10: and Ulf Bilting) created a Unix software agent that eavesdropped on Internet communications before translating that mass of data into abrasive noise. And in 2011
column11: a multimedia project called the Radioactive Orchestra paired the electronic musician Axel Boman with a group of nuclear physicists to generate musical patterns from the behavior of radioactive isotopes.

column1: The latest addition to this canon of data-oriented music making comes from James Murphy—well
column2: strictly speaking
column3: from James Murphy
column4: IBM
column5: the advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather
column6: the ""visual storytelling"" brand agency Tool
column7: and all of the players in the 2014 U.S. Open. Last summer
column8: as a demonstration of IBM's cloud-computing might
column9: data scientists from Tool worked with Murphy to create generative music
column10: in real time
column11: out of all 187 matches in the tennis tournament. Excerpts of the results are available on IBM's SoundCloud page
column12: and while it's difficult to discern much about their methodology from the music itself
column13: we know from interviews with the project's masterminds that basic variables like pitch
column14: timbre
column15: and tempo were determined by players' names and seeds
column16: temperature
column17: court names
column18: etc.
column19: and that game data—game score
column20: set score
column21: time between points
column22: and ""significant events"" like aces and point breaks—determined the shape of the music as the games played out.

column1: If you've listened to a few of the excerpts
column2: you may have noticed that a little bit of this goes a long way
column3: at least as a listening experience. (Apparently the audio was initially live-streamed as the matches played out
column4: along with complementary visuals that parsed additional data points from the tournament.) It sounds a little like a Casiotone with the hiccups
column5: or a small animal walking over the controls of a sequencer. A few of them are mildly unpleasant to listen to; on ""Match 6
column6: Round 1""
column7: some variable or another has given the sound a harsh
column8: distorted edge
column9: suggesting an etude written on crumpled tinfoil. Others are more absorbing: ""Match 104
column10: Round 2"" is animated by lively swing and odd little call-and-response motifs; ""Match 184
column11: Men's Semifinals"" is both placid and quietly stylish
column12: as though a computer virus had hybridized the back catalogs of Windham Hill and Smallville. But only a crazy person would listen to them all. For the most part
column13: they recede into the background
column14: like wind chimes—or at least windchimes rigged
column15: via strings and pulleys
column16: to a metronome.

column1: For the final step in this long
column2: lazy volley between humans and machines
column3: James Murphy has remixed various segments from the tournament into a dozen discrete tracks. A few of them
column4: like ""Match 186 Set 1""
column5: don't sound much less aimless than their raw material
column6: but that's also not a criticism; especially at these more manageable lengths
column7: that meandering quality is part of their appeal. In general
column8: though
column9: Murphy's guiding hand has become visible as he selects key motifs and reworks them into arrangements resembling techno or ambient music. ""Match 4""
column10: displaying Murphy's fondness for Carl Craig
column11: features steady Roland drum programming
column12: a grinding bass arpeggio
column13: and a dramatic breakdown
column14: complete with congas. The breakbeat under ""Match 104"" brings vintage Aphex Twin to mind. In ""Match 184""
column15: harpsichord-like plucks are fleshed out with a doleful 303 line and a slow
column16: four-to-the-floor kick drum
column17: and the results sound uncannily like Tin Man's mournful
column18: drifting acid. The electro-disco ditty ""Match 185"" might almost be an early sketch from the Sound of Silver sessions
column19: while the closing ""Match 187""—with plucked arpeggios beating against buoyant choral pads—takes the whole collection out on a high
column20: hopeful note.

column1: This isn't a major work for Murphy
column2: which I think is implicit in the fact that it's been given away for free. But
column3: particularly when compared with the truly random raw data that was his source material
column4: it has plenty of charm. Whether or not the original feed tells us anything about tennis
column5: as he coaxes data points into patterns
column6: and massages happenstance into meaningful events
column7:
we learn at least one thing about Murphy: this guy can make music out of virtually anything.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21377/homepage_large.d211175b.jpg|Meditation|32682.0|Atelje|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vinyl Export']|2015-01-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:09.437275|"

Revivals aren't unusual
column2: in music or in other areas of culture. Rarer is the revival that goes beyond nostalgia and sets itself up to be eventually revived in its own right. I keep seeing the phrase ""Balearic"" used in different ways
column3: so let's be clear: For our purposes
column4: the term refers to a late-1980s style linked to Ibiza
column5: where clattering acid house had given way among some DJs to a mellower
column6: more eclectic mindset that made room for extended Cure remixes and Italo-house krautrock appropriations—and Chris Rea's soft-rock guitar workout ""Josephine"". But the scene was never limited to Spain
column7: and by the mid- to late '00s a Balearic revival had taken hold
column8: much of it centered in Scandinavian groups
column9: not least of them a Gothenburg-based duo known as Studio.

column1: Dan Lissvik
column2: aka Atelje
column3: was one half of Studio. What he accomplished with collaborator Rasmus Hägg around that time
column4: especially on 2006's West Coast (and 2007's somewhat-overlapping Yearbook 1 compilation)
column5: looms larger now that we've had some years to see how singular it was. You can spot traces of their aesthetic
column6: musically and visually
column7: in minimalist electronic producer Nicolas Jaar's work with guitarist Dave Harrington as Darkside
column8: and you can find other cosmic guitar instrumentalists not unlike Lissvik
column9: most notably former Emeralds member Mark McGuire. But Studio had a particular way of blending largely Balearic elements and exploring them
column10: sometimes at great length
column11: while also maintaining enough sly conceptual unity
column12: enough tunefulness
column13: for easy first-impression appeal. Last year
column14: in a measure of Studio's enduring influence
column15: Jamie xx sampled West Coast/Yearbook 1's ""Out There"" for his ""Girl"" single.

column1: Lissvik has stayed busy
column2: but Studio called it quits and shut down their label
column3: Information
column4: at the beginning of 2012. That farewell was part of a broader moment of closure for the scene: Air France
column5: who took a more Saint Etienne- and Avalanches-leaning approach toward the Balearic idea
column6: broke up not long after
column7: and Service
column8: the Gothenburg label that nurtured Studio and others in the early '00s
column9: gave up the ghost in January 2013. Since 2008's Yearbook 2
column10: a comp containing Studio reworkings of other artists' songs
column11: Hägg has done production for gut-wrenching Swedish singer-songwriter El Perro Del Mar
column12: and in 2013 he told an interviewer he'd lost four to five solo albums in a burglary. Lissvik has been the more publicly prolific
column13: showcasing his Vini Reilly-goes-to-warmer-climes instrumentals on a late-2008 solo album as D. Lissvik
column14: 7 Trx + Intermission
column15: and teaming up with Fredrik Lindson of fellow Service alums the Embassy for a charmingly low-key 2009 LP as the Crêpes—that is
column16: when not producing for the likes of CEO and Taken by Trees
column17: or remixing everyone from Fever Ray to Haim.

column1: Meditation is the most Studio-like full-length we've heard from Lissvik since his former band. That not-quite-reggae lope is back
column2: along with hypnotic yet lyrical guitar repetitions
column3: dubwise bass
column4: and Nordic space-disco synths. As ever with Balearic
column5: part of the formula is that there is no formula
column6: as seen in the twinkling piano on the album's bookends ""Ode to Studio"" and ""Awake"" (the latter with strummy acoustic guitar). And those Studio-era yearning vocals are long gone. Still
column7: when the LP gets into a cosmic groove
column8: especially on side B's percolating ""Everslick"" or its gentle
column9: piano-sprinkled comedown ""Transition""
column10: the effect recalls the Balearic revival at its peak. Considering
column11: again
column12: that the title of the opening track is ""Ode to Studio""
column13: that might not be an accident.

column1: Back-to-roots moves can be a bit hackneyed in rock
column2: or at the very least seen as a bit of a retreat
column3: but I don't get that sense here. It might help to remember that the original Balearic beat was as much about context as content: Rea's ""Josephine"" or
column4: to take a Studio-remixed example
column5: Kylie Minogue's ""2 Hearts"" belongs not because it was necessarily supposed to but simply because it can. Meditation plays as a thoroughly absorbing meditation on—or ode to—Studio
column6: and it works because it does; there's still nothing else quite like this. With only 300 copies pressed
column7: most of us probably won't be able to own the LP on vinyl
column8: and at slightly more than half an hour
column9: Lissvik doesn't quite get a chance to stretch out the way Studio could. But there's reason to hope for at least at least a personal musical revival: Diehard watchers of Studio will know Lissvik has shared 50 tracks
column10: as Archive
column11: on his SoundCloud
column12: and a tantalizing new solo single
column13: ""Airwalk"" b/w ""Shuvit""
column14: is on the way in February via Smalltown Supersound. As Lissvik wrote when Studio ended
column15:
""See you in another shape and form.""

One of last year's most warmly received archival discoveries was Talk to the Sea
column2: a collection of unreleased recordings by the Italian musician Gigi Masin. His debut album
column3: Wind
column4: self-released in 1986
column5: is an understated gem that falls somewhere between Balearic ambient music and secular new age
column6: with echoes of Harold Budd
column7: Jon Hassell
column8: and Arthur Russell's World of Echo. It's not terribly well known
column9: but those who have heard it tend to be passionate about it. A former radio DJ
column10: Masin has done other things over the years
column11: including a 1989 split LP with This Heat's Charles Hayward
column12: on Sub Rosa
column13: and
column14: in the '00s
column15: a handful of recordings for small Italian labels. But he's remained largely under the radar. I had never heard of Masin until I encountered Talk to the Sea
column16: released by the fledgling Amsterdam label Music From Memory
column17: but its impact was immediate—if ""impact"" is quite the right word for a sound so warmly
column18: woozily amniotic
column19: a sound entirely without hard surfaces or sharp edges.

column1: Masin returns here as one-third of Gaussian Curve
column2: a multi-generational ensemble that also includes the Scottish musician Jonny Nash
column3: a founder of the ESP Institute label and member of the synth-besotted softronica act Land of Light
column4: and Amsterdam's Marco Sterk
column5: better known for his woozy house productions under the Young Marco alias. Nash and Sterk first met Masin in the fall of 2013
column6: and they wound up briefly jamming together in the house of a friend. The three musicians reconvened in Amsterdam in early 2014
column7: and they ended up completing eight tracks in a single weekend. Clouds is the result of those sessions
column8: and it's every bit as dreamlike as the musicians make the weekend sound. ""It was almost like we weren't involved
column9: Nash told Juno Plus. ""It just slipped out.""

column1: The eight songs here
column2: all instrumentals
column3: feel less like standalone pieces than variations on a common theme. They share similar instrumentation
column4: and they're all uniformly limpid and languid. Masin sets the tone
column5: and the pace
column6: with slow-moving chords on acoustic piano or Rhodes keyboard
column7: while Nash and Sterk flesh out the songs with gently meandering electric guitar
column8: wispy synthesizer pads
column9: and
column10: occasionally
column11: trumpet and melodica. Given the trumpet
column12: the music often brings to mind Jon Hassell's Last Night the Moon Came Dropping Its Clothes in the Street. A few songs feature rudimentary drum-machine programming
column13: mostly just tuned toms and woodblocks
column14: that might be mistaken for dripping faucets. To call it ""atmospheric"" would be an extreme understatement. (On the closing ""Red Light""
column15: they hold a microphone out the studio window and record the voices and footfalls of the alley outside.) It probably bears as much in common with watercolor as it does most electronic music.

column1: While the music unfolds with about as much drama as a smoke ring wafting towards the ceiling—about as much consequence
column2: too—these are masterfully crafted mood pieces. In the opening ""Talk to the Church""
column3: Masin mimics the chimes of a bell tower that loomed over the trio's studio
column4: his chords gently bouncing and swaying
column5: enlivened by millisecond-long syncopations and subtle shifts in volume. And despite the limited palette and the uniform tempos
column6: they wisely change keys for virtually every song. So while the view remains the same
column7: the light shifts
column8: ever so subtly. True to the title
column9: the experience of this short album
column10: just 38 minutes long
column11: feels a little like a time-lapse film of clouds crossing the sky—of day turning to night
column12: and back again. With the closing ""Red Light""
column13: the music returns to its original key
column14: and it feels like things have come full circle. The logical response—my response
column15: anyway—is to resume the cycle
column16:
and launch into the daybreak bells of ""Talk to the Church"" all over again.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21393/homepage_large.f0b48b2a.jpg|Preacher's Son|32686.0|Tut|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-01-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:10.766718|"

Sundays in the South are quiet—streets sit empty
column2: as shops still close before sundown
column3: and FM Stations that were playing the most explicit rap at night roll into early hours of gospel. On Preacher’s Son
column4: Chattanooga rapper Tut inhabits this scene: the tape opens with a brief news item about police seeking the help of a church to capture a man accused of murder. Tut positions church as a place where a community comes together even in the most trying times. On ""Corner Stories""
column5: he raps: ""Remember sitting in my uncle’s kitchen
column6: I was 8
column7: though/ Whipping up a little something for the pesos"" and then contrasts the scene to himself in the same house innocently playing with Legos. He spins a tale of a small-time drug dealer and a simple robbery that turns into something more complicated and touches on other community ills
column8: and even when he restrains the narrative detail
column9: he humanizes acts both right and wrong.

column1: Preacher’s Son is produced primarily by Ktoven and avoids common Southern rap styles (Snap or Swag) and trendy producers (Metro Boomin or Zaytoven). Ktoven creates lively and warm beats that recall when blues and funk were still embedded in Southern music's DNA
column2: bringing to mind a time when hearing a horn section (""Hangin'"") or a guitar (""Holy Water"") was the norm
column3: not an exception. The uniformity gives the tape a cumulative force
column4: but some tracks towards the middle blend together as the style gets too comfortable within its own groove.

column1: Tut struggles throughout trying to understand the issues that ail his community and figuring out what he should do
column2: even as he's trying to avoiding repeating his own mistakes. The tape returns back to church with an excerpt of sermon on trying to decide whether one is just of this earthly world or joined the heavenly ranks of Christ and the Lord. Tut then closes with ""Sunday Service""
column3: highlighting a great irony of church mornings in that so many in the pews just spent the night sinning (""Damn
column4: we gotta hurry/ Late to the Sunday service/ Last night I hit the town/ Late
column5: I was on the screw juice swervin'""). The track is also laced with light ad-libs from fellow Chattanooga rapper Isaiah Rashad
column6: whose presence loomed heavily over the tape even if he was never officially mentioned. But where Rashad’s Cilvia Demo from last year appeared lost with its place in the world
column7:
Preacher’s Son knows where it stands within the church aisles. Tut just needs to pull his head up and decide which path to travel.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21381/homepage_large.d805a721.jpg|Dreams and Images|32683.0|Arthur|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Light in the Attic']|2015-01-14 00:00:00|1968|2016-06-11 16:16:11.384225|"

If you had met Arthur Lee Harper in 1967
column2: around the time he was writing his debut album
column3: it probably wouldn’t have been too long before he introduced himself as a poet. That might seem strange
column4: considering he did not actually publish poems. Instead
column5: he played guitar and wrote songs—not verse set to music
column6: but rhyming lyrics with verses and choruses
column7: delicate melodies and Romantic imagery. He was then what we might call today a singer-songwriter
column8: but the '60s being the '60s
column9: Harper and his friends Stephen John Kalinich and Mark Lindsey Buckingham had grander ambitions than simply strumming pop tunes or providing entertainment. Poetry was an aspiration
column10: a true calling
column11: a means of peeling away the veneer of society and exposing some hard human truths both beautiful and revolting.

column1: At that time anyone could claim the mantle of poet
column2: even if it no longer brought with it the perks enjoyed by Dylan or Ginsberg. In fact
column3: before Harper signed with Lee Hazlewood’s LHI Records
column4: he was living at the YMCA and sharing bags of potatoes with his friends. <i>Dreams and Images
column5: released under his first name to almost no fanfare
column6: did not do much to change those conditions
column7: and this reissue does not present it as a lost or unheralded classic
column8: along the lines of Karen Dalton’s In My Own Time or Patrick Haggerty’s Lavender Country. Instead
column9: it’s another piece of the LHI puzzle that Light in the Attic has been putting together for a few years now.

column1: In that regard it’s a revealing artifact of that scene as well as a gentle statement of purpose by a struggling poet. According to the liner notes
column2: Hazlewood assigned an arranger named Don Randi to beef up Harper’s songs
column3: and to everyone’s credit
column4: the additions are both odd and nonintrusive
column5: lush and minimal: a bed of strings on opener ""Blue Museum""
column6: an oboe riff on ""Children Once Were You""
column7: what sounds like a clavier on ""Open Up the Door"". Such flourishes bolster the dreamlike quality of Harper’s songs
column8: as though Randi intended them to be slightly surreal illustrations in an imagined chapbook.

column1: Dreams and Images reveals a poet very exacting in his craft
column2: even if he seems to be still finding his voice. Harper’s lyrics are occasionally ponderous or oblique
column3: but just as often he can be unnervingly direct (""I don’t know why/ There're tears in my eyes"") or darkly whimsical (""You look like a human chair""). On the other hand
column4: some of these songs can’t survive outside the context in which they were written. ""Walking down the street is a sunshine soldier
column5: he sings on ""Sunshine Soldier"". ""A child walks by and hands him a flower/ And that’s how love is begun."" Still
column6: there is something radical about Harper’s naivety. His words never howl. Instead
column7: they whisper.

column1: Reinforcing that impression are Harper’s high
column2: expressive voice and his precise guitar playing. The former lends a thoughtfulness to his delicate melodies and the latter frames every line as a soul-searching query. He was self-taught in both regards
column3: favoring idiosyncratic phrasings and odd tunings that other musicians might find nonsensical. But the music lends some heft to the words and portrays a gentle personality behind the songs. Even when he’s singing about love and beauty and sunshine soldiers and maidens fair
column4: he never sounds like just another folkie. It’s enough to make you wonder what he might have accomplished if he had pursued his muse further
column5: but after Dreams and Images and one follow-up
column6: he quit the music business
column7: started a family
column8: and took a 9-to-5 designing rocket engines. It’s an odd fate for any poet
column9:
especially one who made a virtue of having his head in the clouds.
