Remember when Death Grips were as much a band as they were a bunch of agent provocateurs? No slight to the hype cycle-upending stunts they've pulled post-The Money Store—skipping highly anticipated shows (including Lollapalooza)
column3: holing up in the Chateau Marmont
column4: sending every fan of theirs a cover-art dickpic
column5: telling Epic to go screw
column6: releasing an album that was supposedly a legitimate Björk collab but presumably merely sampled her voice
column7: breaking up
column8: ditching an opening gig for Nine Inch Nails
column9: maybe not breaking up
column10: and so forth. But even as the sound that made all this relevant in the first place got a fraction of the press as the crazy shit orbiting around it like noisy satellites
column11: the music itself is more notable than the social media gimmickry. Anyone can be an aloof dildo on the Internet; not everyone could bring the trans-genre aggro bravado that those antics were meant to justify at a couple hundred kilobytes per second.

column1: That said
column2: it wouldn't be a Death Grips album without some weird mystery behind it
column3: and Fashion Week has its share. For instance: someone of unknown origin and affiliation downloaded this entire album from some arcane private corner of Death Grips' website a few months back
column4: posted it to the band's fan subreddit
column5: and was widely dismissed as someone trying to pass off a fraudulent leak. Then Death Grips
column6: or a representative thereof
column7: actually posted the album on Soundcloud to prove its legitimacy
column8: gave it a track listing that spelled out ""JENNYDEATHWHEN"" as a taunting acknowledgement of their supposed last album's all-question-marks release date
column9: and then went off to do who the hell knows what else.

column1: Leaving hungry listeners with some scraps to pick over means that what might be a stopgap release in the context of any other band is going to be pored over fiendishly by one of the more dedicated cult fanbases in music today. So Fashion Week is going to be put through the wringer
column2: and there will be speculation about future direction. Maybe this is a bunch of scraps from the archives that hints at ideas they eventually strengthened and routes they could've taken instead
column3: or maybe it's a few things Zach Hill scraped together to keep Death Grips in the public eye as jenny death struggles to life
column4: or maybe it's an actual Fashion Week soundtrack some designer commissioned
column5: or maybe it's even the instrumentals for jenny death itself
column6: or maybe it's just some record.

column1: Whatever it is
column2: it's pretty bracing—not hellaciously noisy or completely impenetrable
column3: but at least raucous enough to feel legit. That it was so readily dismissed as a hoax when it first leaked months ago gives you some idea of its quality
column4: but what makes this record likable is still pretty elusive. You get careening invocations of trademark ideas all butting up next to each other
column5: riding on sparking
column6: hissing
column7: glitching synthesizers and Zach Hill's drums rattling like a lost-time accident at the corrugated steel warehouse. And it really knocks in a surprising way when some distinct elements jump out through the familiar framework: feverishly lighthearted circus organ on the first ""Runway N""
column8: occasionally abrasive but otherwise straightforward classic Detroit techno on ""Runway D""
column9: a nasty
column10: mud-trudging lope driven by oozing nightmare Moogs on the first ""Runway H"" that plays like a power struggle between Tobacco and Trent Reznor. Hell
column11: ""punk"" usually seems like a ""for lack of a better subculture"" term that gets thrown at Death Grips as a Gen-X dadrock assessment
column12: but the second ""Runway H"" proves that if they wanted to
column13: they could be this decade's Devo.

column1: What Fashion Week's really missing
column2: though
column3: is some kind of central idea—if anybody ever thought this music could melt steel without MC Ride acting as threat-slinging
column4: dinosaur-lunged instrument of corrosion
column5: they'll probably be let down. The album needs the percussive abrasion of his voice
column6: and digging into some of the more typical slabs of Death Grips' instrumental tendencies doesn't unearth much more than a pretty solid workout soundtrack. It makes for a good exercise in how grimy and knuckles-out they can get even when going straight-up electro
column7: but don't try and call ""Runway A"" or ""Runway W"" transgressive hardcore art when they barely transcend the possibility of sounding like decent Run the Jewels outtakes. The titles aren't the only parts of the songs that spell out a question about what Death Grips' future is supposed to sound like
column8:
and don't expect answers to come easy.

The Baton Rouge rapper Kevin Gates is good at many things—switching quickly between rapping and singing
column3: writing powerful choruses

column6: he told Mass Appeal recently

column5: in fact

column1: Local-stardom details
column2: like the discomfort he observes at his presence at the local barbershop
column3: dot his lyrics
column4: and give a feel for Gates as a big fish in a small pond
column5: warily charting his home territory. His infant son
column6: who often appears in his arms on his Instagram account
column7: is a looming presence: ""Full time father
column8: full time artist
column9: ask God
column10: he said 'Grind harder
column11: '"" he announces proudly on ""I Don’t Get Tired"". His belchy

column16: Bobby Johnson-produced ""Sit Down""

""Would I be wrong to wanna fuck you with one of my niggas/ If afterward I promised I wouldn’t look at you different?"" he inquires respectfully on ""Wild Ride"". These are the moments when his particularly messy brand of honesty shines

but his greatest achievement is more intangible: He feels like a person living inside his own records.

Over the past couple of years
column2: Erol Alkan has built up a diverse but cohesive roster for his Phantasy label. Most of his artists have one foot on the dancefloor and one foot elsewhere—the indie scene
column3: the modular synth builders' club
column4: the clouds—which is a pretty good approximation of the style of DJing that Alkan has practiced since the days of Trash
column5: his fondly remembered club night from back in the days of electroclash.

column1: At one end of the spectrum there's Tom Rowlands
column2: of the Chemical Brothers
column3: who offered up a pair of noise-besotted throwback acid-house tracks for the label; at the other end
column4: Brazil's <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/28048-babe-terror/"">Babe
column5: Terror
column6: whose fuzzy layers of looped vocals sound like doo-wop from a world spun off its axis. Daniel Avery's sawtoothed throb swings the pendulum towards techno again
column7: and Connan Mockasin's idiosyncratic psychedelic pop draws it back into the singer-songwriter's realm. Ghost Culture
column8: Phantasy's latest addition
column9: falls squarely in the middle of that array. The alias belongs to the 24-year-old London studio engineer James Greenwood
column10: and his debut album carefully fuses canny song-craft with clattering machine constructions; it offers an unusual balance between muscular grooves and whispered intimacy
column11: as though erecting a bedsheet fort smack dab in the middle of a throbbing basement party.

column1: The most immediate point of comparison might be Swim-era Caribou and the clubbier music of his alter ego Daphni. Greenwood is similarly fond of loping drum grooves and burbling synthesizers
column2: and his breathy voice is faintly reminiscent of Dan Snaith's
column3: except that Snaith tends to soar
column4: while Greenwood's delivery is more downcast—literally
column5: as though he were singing into his jacket lapels. (Perhaps that has something to do with the fact that he apparently recorded his vocals with a microphone salvaged from a tank.) But that muted tone is just what the mood of his songs calls for. In any case
column6: he's got a way with sing-songy melodies that stick in your head; the bulk of these songs would probably work unplugged
column7: though that's no reason to wish they were any different than they are
column8: if only because their sound—Factory Floor does bubblegum pop
column9: basically—is so unusual and delightful.

column1: The opening ""Mouth"" is full of simple pleasures—the satisfying oomph of a well-rounded bass synth; the delicious crispness of a well-tempered machine clap—and supple nuance. The nervous spring reverb that accompanies his keyboard trills is a small detail
column2: but it amps up the music's quiet
column3: visceral thrill; it adds depth to the song's ample negative spaces. The principal synth riff rolls like a fistful of agates
column4: and everything sounds as polished as a bauble in a raccoon's paws.

column1: The bulk of the album offers variations on the same set of elements: the lonely warble of the Korg Mono/Poly synthesizer
column2: snaky drum grooves
column3: and his mopey
column4: husky voice. In ""Arms""
column5: detuned synth pads drizzle down like cold rain over snapping electro syncopations as he mutters cryptically about ""Moving arms
column6: flashing teeth/ Half-closed
column7: half-open."" ""How"" is all percolating arpeggios and lullaby repetitions; it sounds a little like the xx if they made their music on broken-down Russian synthesizers and steam-powered gizmos. Many of his melodies carry a whiff of déjà vu: on ""Lying""
column8: it's the Christmas carol ""Silent Night""
column9: while on ""Glass""
column10: it's New Order's ""Your Silent Face"". There's a lot of New Order here
column11: in fact
column12: from his voice's faint resemblance
column13: in places
column14: to Bernhard Sumner's
column15: to the chilly string pads reminiscent of the group's early albums.

column1: And there are a few wildcards
column2: too: ""Glaciers""
column3: with its waltz tempo and wheezing organs
column4: sounds like Phil Spector via Stereolab (on Quaaludes)
column5: and the clammy echoes of ""Answer"" lend a hint of an Elvis-at-Sun-Studios vibe. But the album's largely uniform palette is both a strength and a weakness. By seven or eight tracks in
column6: the sameness of the production begins to feel faintly claustrophobic. One possible way out of that cul-de-sac might have been a few more straight-up club cuts. We know that he's got them in him
column7: because he already delivered one in the form of the Border Community homage ""Red Smoke""
column8: the B-side to his debut single. And he hasn't exactly turned a blind eye to the dancefloor here
column9: either. While his voice is foregrounded throughout
column10: most of the album's tracks tend to break down
column11: halfway through
column12: into skeletal
column13: dubbed-out fantasias. It's clear that he's arranged them with an ear for future extended mixes in which the pop songs fall away
column14: leaving only the shuddering metallic chassis underneath. Maybe
column15: in retrospect
column16: it's his judicious sense of balance that holds him back: a few more extremes
column17:
and his next work might really sing.

Jon Brooks’ compositions as the Advisory Circle immaculately turn around one another
column2: irrespective of the varying moods that beset him during recording. He moves from the outdoorsy pine of his 2011 record As the Crow Flies to the more inward facing From Out Here
column3: carefully trailing links to make it sound recognizably him. It’s there in the perfectly interlaced synth lines
column4: the air of Cold War nostalgia
column5: the overriding sense that utopian thought has become a past construct. Brooks works quietly
column6: releasing music under varying guises
column7: never looking for attention. It fits with his fondness for barely heralded musicians—synth pioneers who never got their dues
column8: whose work now fuels a small part of the reissues industry. This is music that’s longing to be lost just as much as it is to be found
column9: made with a knowledge of how the process of falling out of view can end up coloring works with a unique texture.

column1: Brooks finds a broad sound palette to explore on From Out Here
column2: even more so than on his other works under this name. The best tracks often have a non-musical component
column3: such as the ticking clock that keeps rhythm on the upwardly twirling synth patterns of ""Winter Hours""
column4: or the crackly spoken word transmission of the title track
column5: which bears the cadence of a lost World War II-era recording. There’s even a concept driving it all
column6: based around the arcadian English countryside being an artificial conceit generated by a computer program
column7: making it sound like the bastard offspring of technology-run-amok thrillers like the 1977 feature Demon Seed. It’s often hard to square that idea with the reality of From Out Here
column8: which is all tightly controlled passages of sound
column9: ranging from short minimal synth apparitions (""Verberatim"") to expansive tracts of folky wanderings (""Upon Oakston"").

column1: Brooks’ inspirations are often musicians who could be classed as people hiding in plain sight—artists such as Suzanne Ciani and Brian Bennett
column2: who both feature on this mixtape to accompany From Out Here
column3: or the library music he and the Ghost Box label hold so dear. None are household names
column4: but all have worked in the commercial sphere
column5: either through advertising or by penning TV or film themes. The sense of build in Advisory Circle tracks such as ""Escape Lane"" and ""The Walk Home"" would fit perfectly in that sphere
column6: scrolling over B-movie end credits or zipping across a sepia tinted vacuum cleaner commercial. Somehow
column7: this music
column8: and arguably the entire Ghost Box aesthetic
column9: makes those worlds seem closer than many people may have realized. It’s also what prevents these darker Advisory Circle tracks from encroaching too close to the gloom—there’s always a key sense of play at work.

column1: The most satisfying part of From Out Here is how much wider Brooks casts his net than before. Sure
column2: there are hints of small releases
column3: such as that mysterious Jürgen Müller record from a few years back on the beautiful ""Jessica Finds the Beach"". But it’s not hard to see the spectre of Kraftwerk’s power station fear surface on ""The Blue Energy Programme""
column4: and it’s easy to trace a path from the sparse passages of ""Experiment!"" to the melancholy side of Spacemen 3’s Playing With Fire. At those moments the Advisory Circle vibrates with possibility
column5: drawing in endless strands of music’s past
column6: with Brooks steadying the tiller to make sure everything maintains the correct trajectory. For a notionally darker work this album ends up being more enjoyable than some of his prior records
column7: mainly because the sense of exploration is heightened with each turn taken. Brooks and Ghost Box are often talked about in narrow planes of sound
column8:
but here the future feels persuasively wide open.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21380/homepage_large.6d5cf6ea.jpg|Celebrating the Music of |0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nonesuch']|2015-01-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:15.968737|"

Neither the film Inside Llewyn Davis nor its soundtrack had hit theaters or stores in September 2013 when a phalanx of roots musicians gathered at New York City’s Town Hall to sing some old folk songs together. Frequent Coen Brothers collaborator T Bone Burnett organized the concert as a loose celebration of the music featured in the film
column2: a bleak comedy of haplessness that follows a frustrated folk singer in 1960 as he plies his trade around Manhattan. Featuring older legends alongside some of the younger musicians they inspired
column3: the event was filmed and released first as a documentary and now as a soundtrack
column4: both titled Another Day Another Time: Celebrating the Music of ""Inside Llewyn Davis"".

column1: In some ways it’s not too far removed from the folk and blues showcases curated by archivists and producers like John Hammond and Alan Lomax in the 1940s
column2: who brought then-obscure folk acts like Leadbelly and Dock Boggs to venues like Carnegie Hall. But the real precursor for Another Day Another Time is obviously Down from the Mountain
column3: which in 2000 extended the success of O Brother Where Art Thou? from screen to stage. That movie played its rural milieu for cheap laughs
column4: but the soundtrack played it straight and sold millions
column5: won the Grammy for Album of the Year in 2002
column6: and inspired today’s highly dubious folk boomlet. Of course it would be nearly impossible for Inside Llewyn Davis to match the fluke success of O Brother
column7: especially the fluke part
column8: so the concert is premature at best and self-congratulatory at worst. There’s something suspicious in this cart-before-the-horse endeavor
column9: which plays less like a celebratory concert and more like an elaborate promotional push.

column1: A year and a half later
column2: we know all the beats of the movie
column3: but how would concertgoers have responded to Elvis Costello
column4: Adam Driver
column5: and Oscar Isaac so faithfully re-creating ""Please Mr. Kennedy"" with no knowledge of its use in the film? Did they even know who Isaac was when he took the stage to perform ""Hang Me
column6: O Hang Me""? His performance was crucial to the movie
column7: projecting more melancholy than the Coen Brothers could muster themselves
column8: but the gravity he brings to the stage can be unwieldy: Singing ""Green Rocky Road""
column9: he makes the line
column10: ""Hooka tooka soda cracker
column11: does your mama smoke tobacco?"" sound like a suicide note.

column1: While Burnett has spent the 13 years between Down from the Mountain and Another Day Another Time becoming the most ubiquitous man in Americana as well as the most boring
column2: he at least assembles a diverse line-up for the show. There are some of his expected cohorts
column3: including Costello
column4: Marcus Mumford
column5: and Rhiannon Giddens
column6: all of whom appear on Burnett’s New Basement Tapes project in 2014. Giddens bulldozes her two songs
column7: showing little of the interpretive nuance that distinguished the Carolina Chocolate Drops
column8: and Mumford pretty much just shows up. But there’s also the Milk Carton Kids evoking the collegiate folk of Simon & Garfunkel
column9: Colin Meloy lowering the stakes of Jackson C. Frank’s ""Blues Run the Game""
column10: and the Punch Brothers harmonizing on ""Tumbling Tumbleweeds"" (wait
column11: isn’t that Big Lebowski?). Lake Street Dive conjure some much-needed lasciviousness on the R&B-stoked ""You Go Down Smooth""
column12: showing how folk can meld so naturally with other genres
column13: and Jack White
column14: huffing helium while gargling gravel
column15: offers a respite from the event’s staid pace with rambunctious renditions of ""Did You Hear John Hurt?"" and the Stripes’ own ""We’re Going to Be Friends"".

column1: Still
column2: Another Day Another Time doesn’t have much more to say about the genre and its lasting influence than ""Yay
column3: folk!"" The lack of any sort of critical thesis or undergirding may seem merely academic
column4: but it translates into performances that are wanly reverent and unanimated
column5: celebrating the music mainly for its age but not its actual history. Perhaps the most disappointing aspect of the concert is how apolitical it is. Throughout most of the 20th century
column6: folk was a highly radicalized form
column7: largely because it heralded a populist political stance. Simply playing this music and teaching it to others was enough for the House Un-American Activities Committee to brand Pete Seeger a commie. ""This Land Is Your Land"" may be our unofficial national anthem
column8: but Woody Guthrie intended it as a protest song. It’s actually refreshing to hear Gillian Welch and Dave Rawlings sing the unpopular verse lamenting the very idea of private property
column9: but how much were those concert tickets again?

column1: Folk songs aren’t private property. Especially in 2015
column2: when racial violence is depressingly common and the disparity between the haves and have-nots unfathomably wide
column3: this music ought to be more relevant than ever. But there’s no sense of danger or dissent in any performance on Another Day Another Time
column4:
and therefore there is no sense of courage or outrage to illuminate the songs. The fatal flaw in this concert is that these artists are only celebrating folk music when they should be practicing it.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21348/homepage_large.c5d9fc4f.jpg|Panda Bear Meets the Grim Reaper|3241.0|Panda Bear|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2015-01-12 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:16:16.481259|"

The great irony about bringing a new life into this world is you start worrying a lot more about death. Not just that of the family members you must provide for and protect
column2: but your own
column3: as well. Plain and simple
column4: the first rule of parenting is: don’t die. When entrusted with the immense obligation of caring for a child
column5: even the youngest of new parents become exceedingly conscious of their own mortality and survival instincts. Behaviors once taken for granted—like
column6: say
column7: air travel or cycling alongside cars on city streets—start to feel more like roulette games wagered with your life; once-considered activities like bungee jumping and skydiving get transferred from your bucket list to a ""fuck that"" list.

column1: You could hear that sort of uneasiness gradually seep into the seemingly serene work of Noah Lennox—a.k.a. Panda Bear—over the past decade
column2: both without and within Animal Collective. As the first A.C. member to become a parent
column3: Lennox has become increasingly fond of rooting his boundless sonic exploration in meditations on home life
column4: whether cheekily celebrating the drudgery of domesticity (""Chores"")
column5: eulogizing the family dog (""Derek"")
column6: making heartfelt affirmations of paternal duty (""My Girls"")
column7: or openly fretting over his shortcomings as a breadwinner (“Alsatian Darn”). And though he’s avoided explicitly ecclesiastical language in his solo work since writing 2004’s psych-folk hymnal Young Prayer for his late father
column8: each Panda Bear record released since has retained the form and feel of a communal church service: They welcome us in with reassuring proverbs (<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MT3NVv7IZ8Q"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""try to remember always
column9: always to have a good time"") couched in heaven-sent harmonies
column10: provide a sense comfort in the face of encroaching chaos
column11: and strive to connect our physical world to a more celestial plane. And be it the psychedelic pop sprawl of 2007’s Person Pitch or the dub-like lurch of 2011’s Tomboy
column12: a Panda Bear record ultimately requires a test of faith
column13: a belief that Lennox’s beaming voice will guide us safely through the dense
column14: phantasmagoric fog that threatens to consume it. In Lennox’s cathedral of sound
column15: you can always see the stormy skies creeping in view through the radiant stained-glass windows.

column1: On his latest venture
column2: the tension between inner peace and external pressure reaches boss-battle proportions. Lifting its main-event billing from old King Tubby records
column3: Panda Bear Meets the Grim Reaper serves a similar function for its creator as Slasher Flicks did for Avey Tare—it’s a playful
column4: fantastical response to some serious life changes. In Portner’s case
column5: it was divorce and strep throat; for Lennox
column6: it’s the entry into middle age and the substantial familial responsibilities that go with it. In a recent Rolling Stone interview
column7: Lennox pondered the possibility of retiring the Panda Bear moniker
column8: which makes sense—part of getting older is doing away with your old college nicknames. But if that is indeed the case
column9: Panda Bear is not going down without a fight.

column1: More streamlined than Person Pitch and more rhythmically robust than Tomboy
column2: Grim Reaper is Panda Bear’s toughest
column3: grimiest
column4: and funkiest album to date. But all that extra grit and groove doesn’t come at the expense Lennox’s unmistakable melodic graces

column7: many of the songs on Grim Reaper lock into a looped beat and rarely waver course. However
column8: they’re often prefaced by or dissolve into ominous
column9: buzzing oscillations (some of which
column10: like the half-minute ""Davy Jones' Locker""
column11: are portioned off into stand-alone tracks) that suggest the onset of a panic attack or some shadowy predator. As such
column12: the midnight-marauding march of lead single ""Mr Noah"" and electro-fuzzed yodeling of ""Boys Latin"" are transformed into weapons of retaliation—a strobe-lit assault on the encroaching bleakness. ""Dark cloud has descended again
column13: Lennox sings on the chorus of the latter song

column1: Lennox told Pitchfork last fall that
column2: despite all the personal rumination that inspired Grim Reaper
column3: he wanted to keep his lyrics purposefully non-specific and relatable. But for all its booming breaks and future-shocked freneticism
column4: Grim Reaper—like all Panda Bear records—remains a highly insular experience
column5: one where it often sounds as if Lennox is speaking into a mirror. ""So good
column6: you’ve got it so good
column7: he sings overtop the blissed-out shuffle of ""Crosswords""—a simple statement of fact from a happily married father of two who lives in a cosmopolitan coastal European city in between sold-out tours. But his wistful delivery betrays the fear of losing it all. And Lennox spends much of the seven-minute ""Come to Your Senses"" repeating a question (""Are you mad?"") for which there is only one logical answer (""Yeah
column8: I’m mad"")
column9: as the song’s shantytown acid-house throb mediates between serenity and insanity. A sobering aftershock arrives in the form of late-album wake-up call ""Selfish Gene""—a sort-of post-rave ""That's Not Me""—where the incessant synth-jabs provide Lennox with needling reminders of his family-man mission (""When it comes to fill those spaces/ Only you can fill those spaces"").

column1: Taken as a whole
column2: Grim Reaper feels like a gradual process of Lennox trying to tune out the extraneous noise of modern life and focus on what’s truly important to him. And it’s an evolution mirrored by the album’s sequence
column3: which bookends the most boisterous

The former is a cosmic doo-wop serenade that stands as the most affecting and beautiful vocal performance of Lennox’s career; the latter projects a gorgeous
column5: aqueous tranquility unheard from the Animal Collective camp since side two of Feels
column6: its light piano drizzle summoning thundercloud rumbles of foreboding reverberations.

column1: But even when it trades in day-glo stompers for weightless ballads
column2: Grim Reaper still crushes. In the unsentimental
column3: funereal refrain of ""Tropic of Cancer""—""you can’t get back
column4: you won’t come back
column5: you can’t come back to it""—Lennox invokes his father’s 2002 death and
column6: in doing so
column7: reemphasizes his own current reality as a patriarch
column8: and that pervasive
column9: deep-seated fear of prematurely leaving one’s family behind. If Panda Bear Meets the Grim Reaper posits adult life as some imaginary horror movie
column10:
it’s one where the phone call warning of impending doom is coming from inside the house.

Thomas Pynchon's 2009 novel Inherent Vice gave filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson an outlet for his more antic
column2: erratic impulses. Paul Thomas Anderson's 2014 film Inherent Vice
column3: meanwhile

column1: The soundtrack

column1: The second selection
column2: after Greenwood's plush opening
column3: is Can's ""Vitamin C""
column4: a gonzo piece of insect-throated avant-rock that hits you in the face like a scalding cup of gas station coffee. It shares time with Neil Young's idyllic ""Journey Through the Past"" and the medicated lounge lizard cheer of Kyu Sakamoto's ""Sukiyaki""
column5: all of which finds itself jostled up against bits of Greenwood's score

The vaguely Morricone-esque ""The Golden Fang"" features mallet percussion and guitar arpeggios that shimmer like exhaust off a motel parking lot.

column1: If this soundtrack were a room full of furniture

column3: you would shield your eyes from the clash. But it might actually make for a sleeker and more condensed vehicle for the film's stoned
column4: clammy energy than the film itself

column6: and ""Adrian Prussia"" is incredible

column8: the soundtrack is a pungent
column9: incoherent
column10: occasionally haunting trifle. The feeling is of a bunch of intelligent and talented people trying on a bunch of funny-colored clothing and giggling at each other. If you're not wearing the costumes
column11:
there's a limit to just how entertained by all of it you can be.

Yips
column5: skrrrrts

column1: Finally Rich
column2: as an album title

If you’re going to be misunderstood anyway

column12: like much of Nobody

column11: I’ll give it up... Life ain’t that much
column12: I’ll live it up."" He’s at once proud of his ability to support his people and wary of being used: ""Everybody eat
column13: I’ll bill it up/ Baby I’ll keep my mouth closed
column14: I’ll seal it up."" Even its title references the unflinching ubermasculinity that characterizes drill and its proponents
column15: and beyond that

Brian Chippendale and Greg Saunier are spectacular drummers in the most literal sense: when they play
column3: they create a spectacle. Sitting next to his Deerhoof bandmates instead of behind them
column4: Saunier ripples his arms and legs like noodles
column5: and tosses his head so recklessly it threatens to fly off. Chippendale’s head is often wrapped in a ghoulish homemade mask
column6: and his rapid-fire drumming in Lightning Bolt has a brutish quality to match. Neither is all about flash; both use simple kits and have built their idiosyncratic styles from basic
column7: punk-derived roots. But for two decades with their respective groups
column8: Chippendale and Saunier have consistently been a sight to behold.

column1: That’s why the smartest part of their first duo record—besides the idea to have them play together to begin with—is that it’s an audio-visual package. Along with two 19-minute sides of crackling sonics
column2: Brian Chippendale & Greg Saunier includes beautifully-shot video of the entire session
column3: as well as a mini-documentary about the pair with testimonials from the likes of Jon Dwyer
column4: Wayne Coyne
column5: and Kid Millions. The music on its own is compelling
column6: but watching Chippendale and Saunier converse and connect shines a clearer
column7: more hypnotic light on their collective wizardry. Their meeting is cerebral and expressive
column8: but it’s also physical and violent— imagine My Dinner With Andre as a boxing match. As Chippendale says in the mini-doc
column9: ""Playing drums is a workout that has a byproduct of making sound.""

column1: The visceral thrust of Brian Chippendale & Greg Saunier comes across equally in the video and audio-only versions
column2: but with fascinatingly divergent effects. I guessed beforehand that watching the pair play would make the music feel more structured and tangible—since the motion would add cause-and-effect—while the sound alone would seem random. But the opposite proved true. On video
column3: the speed of their playing is dizzying
column4: and the doubled hyper-impulsivity makes everything too dense to fully process
column5: creating an intoxicating waterfall of sight and sound. By contrast
column6: without the visual information to keep track of
column7: listening to the music allows your brain to organize the white-hot playing into discernible sections
column8: some of which approach straight-up rock beats.

column1: Rock naturally informs the pair’s work throughout
column2: and the format
column3: full-on improvisation
column4: gives the session a jazz aura too. But something about their mesh puts this record in its own category
column5: on the edges of both of those immeasurably-wide genres. Perhaps it’s how the always-lurking threat of a beat overlaps with the never-ending consciousness stream. Everytime you sense a 4/4 snap developing
column6: machine-gun kicks and pin-prick slaps wedge inside and bust it apart. Throughout the maelstrom
column7: Chippendale and Saunier maintain their respective percussion personalities—the former’s rapid-fire pointillism and the latter’s rolling rumble—without stepping on each other or canceling out. What could easily become indistinct mush instead is continually precise
column8: each sound hopping around the other like a juggler’s knives.

column1: In fact
column2: if there’s a shortcoming to Brian Chippendale & Greg Saunier
column3: it’s that the two players merge their distinct languages without quite creating a third. That’s to be expected; it’s their first musical meeting
column4: and they have to get to know each other on the fly. In a sense
column5: this makes for a more entertaining record
column6: like the fantasy version of what these two might sound like together. In other words
column7: it doesn’t disappoint. But there’s also a sense that Chippendale and Saunier are inches away from a monstrous two-headed hybrid
column8: one that will not just meet expectations
column9:
but demolish them.

"|20047.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20047-brian-chippendale-greg-saunier/|7.5|Marc Masters

With this week’s shock release of Black Messiah
column2: soul singer and multi-instrumentalist D'Angelo
column3: the man music critic Robert Christgau once earnestly dubbed ""R&B Jesus
column4: returns with his first album of new material in 14 years. It was not
column5: as many have suggested
column6: 14 years of silence. The last D'Angelo album
column7: 2000’s Voodoo
column8: was a near perfect communion of buttery soul
column9: Crisco-fried funk
column10: and hip-hop thump
column11: but the video for its calling card
column12: Untitled (How Does It Feel?)""
column13: a lingering
column14: sensual glance over the singer’s face and chest
column15: turned him into an unwitting sex symbol. Live shows soon descended into catcalling
column16: and D
column17: convinced his music had become an accessory to his looks
column18: slipped slowly out of sight. Dispatches grew scarce and worrisome. There were arrests. There was a car accident. For a while
column19: D'Angelo appeared to follow talented but troubled forbears Marvin Gaye and Sly Stone into the dark.

column1: Even in darkness there was still music. D'Angelo guested on albums by J Dilla
column2: Q-Tip
column3: Snoop Dogg
column4: and more. He taught himself to play guitar. There were perennial promises of a new album. D'Angelo returned to the stage in 2012 peppering sets of old favorites with carefully chosen covers and unreleased new material. Black Messiah isn’t a sneak attack; it’s a slow-simmering gumbo finally boiled over. We tasted its fearless ambivalence to genre boundaries in 2007 when Roots maestro Questlove snuck an early version of the stately Joe Pass homage of ""Really Love"" to Australia’s Triple J Radio
column5: in 2010 when the punk-hop scorcher ""1000 Deaths"" briefly slipped onto YouTube and in 2012 when D'Angelo returned to television to unveil the big band funk smartbomb ""Sugah Daddy"" on the BET Awards. Still
column6: it’s a wonder to hear his mutant groove unblemished by the passage of time and stretched around this gobstopping cosmic slop of country funk
column7: psych and new wave.

column1: Black Messiah is a study in controlled chaos. The nightmarish chorus of ""1000 Deaths"" arrives late and fierce
column2: as though the band unfurled its crunchy
column3: lumbering vamp just long enough to violently snatch it out from under us. ""The Charade""'s Minneapolis sound funk rock follows
column4: every bit as bright as the previous track was menacing until you zero in on the threadbare heart-sickness of D and P-Funk affiliate Kendra Foster’s lyrics. Black Messiah pulls together disparate threads few predecessors have had the smarts or audacity to unite. One song might channel Funkadelic
column5: another
column6: the Revolution
column7: but the shiftless mad doctor experimentation and the mannered messiness at the root of it all is unmistakably the Vanguard. Black Messiah is a dictionary of soul
column8: but D'Angelo is the rare classicist able to filter the attributes of the greats in the canon into a sound distinctly his own. It’s at once familiar and oddly unprecedented
column9: a peculiar trick to pull on an album recorded over the span of a decade.

column1: The timeliness of Black Messiah’s message is doubly astounding. The album was pieced together over painstaking years and originally pegged for launch next year
column2: but D
column3: affected by national unrest around unprosecuted police officer involved shootings in Ferguson
column4: MO and New York City
column5: nudged the release date up to speak to the times. Black Messiah plays out most like Sly Stone’s There’s a Riot Goin’ On in its penetrating sense of disorder. Where Voodoo concerned itself chiefly with the ups and downs of cohabitation
column6: the new music steps outside to see what’s going on
column7: and it ain’t good news. ""1000 Deaths"" folds the old adage about cowards and soldiers into a word about guns
column8: fear and desperation. ""The Charade"" calls bullshit on a knotty history of systemic racism. (""All we wanted was a chance to talk/ ‘Stead we've only got outlined in chalk."") ""Prayer"" looks for strength from on high
column9: opening on a choppy Lord’s Prayer whose signal keeps cutting out.

column1: Alongside this wartime pith even the sunnier songs come across darkly. The bipartite nostalgia romp ""Back to the Future"" looks for solace in memories ostensibly because the present is discouraging. The love songs run a little morbid. The titular pledge of ""Betray My Heart"" doesn’t speak fealty so much as candor
column2: and the album’s barn burner of a closer ""Another Life"" is a song of devotion in the vein of the Stylistics’ ""You Are Everything""—except that the couple never really meets. Black Messiah is about finding something to hang onto in dire times
column3: soldiering through the infuriating insanity of oppression with a support system in tow. ""It’s about people rising up in Ferguson and in Egypt and in Occupy Wall Street and in every place where a community has had enough and decides to make change happen
column4: D'Angelo writes in the liner notes. ""Black Messiah is not one man. It’s a feeling that
column5: collectively
column6: we are all that leader."" He may have taken well over a decade to show face again
column7:
but it turns out D'Angelo is right on time.

column1: If there’s anything The Pinkprint makes clear over its sprawling 22 tracks (six of which appear only on deluxe editions)

column7: everything you got was based off of my contact

column9: but even there she’s consumed with creeping nostalgia for a party that has yet to end. It’s impossible to ignore her frequent mentions of pill-popping. ""I popped a perc and I said thonk youuuu!"" she crows on ""Want Some More""; it’s the most fucked up Minaj has sounded on wax

column3: that performance centered around femininity as a spectacle: the elaborate costumes
column4: the affinity for lurid Barbie pink

column6: the preoccupation made sense. But on The Pinkprint
column7: Minaj addresses a different performance: that of the ""strong woman
column8: the self-sufficient bad bitch role model who works twice as hard as her male peers and looks good doing it (in other words
column9: the performance of the ""only rap bitch on the Forbes list""). This
column10: Minaj declares

column6: on ""Feeling Myself""

column3: even in proper context. ""Pills N Potions"" is cute but hollow

column5: Minaj barks red-blooded bars

It’s the ultimate statement as to whether anyone but Minaj herself understands what’s best for her career. When many thought they’d had her pegged—as a New York battle-rapper

a brand—The Pinkprint presents Minaj in her most unexpected role yet: a human being.

Looking back on the year she's had
column4: it's hard to believe that the phrase ""Charli XCX
column5: mainstream pop force"" was nothing but daydream fodder for the pop cognoscenti little more than a year ago. Forged in the late-'00s crucible of the MySpace music scene and signed to a label when most people are trying to get through high school
column6: Charlotte Aitchison was a critical darling long before she was a chart presence: after leaving a scrappy self-recorded debut in the dust
column7: early singles like ""Stay Away"" and ""Nuclear Seasons"" picked up plaudits but failed to dent the conversation of casual pop fans. It took the surprise explosion of ""I Love It""—a demo she tossed to Swedish party gremlins Icona Pop on a whim
column8: and helped to sing—into an international hit to generate the momentum required for her first full-length
column9: True Romance. An amalgamation of her best singles to date and some sterling new material
column10: the album sated critics again but came and went without leaving any sort of commercial impression.

column1: After peppy advance single ""SuperLove"" landed with a thud at the end of 2013
column2: Charli found herself in a familiar position: beloved by pop Twitterati and devoted fans
column3: but lacking the sort of chart firepower many felt her talent warranted. By the summer of 2014
column4: the script had flipped: with assists from rapping Australian supernova Iggy Azalea and a soundtrack spot on teen drama The Fault in Our Stars
column5: she had credits on the defacto Song of the Summer (the former's ""Fancy"") and her own solo top 10 hit
column6: the swooning ""Boom Clap"". Sucker is her second studio album
column7: and perhaps the years of hard work and compositional refinement it took to reach the top helped to shape the record's uncompromising sensibility; this is an album that seeks to bend the mainstream to its will rather than conform to its reigning trends. And in a bold display of self-confidence and strength of personality
column8: it operates under the premise that Charli is a viable star even though the record will ultimately constitute a referendum on the validity of that assumption.

column1: There's a great deal of volatility to Charli's writing and artistic growth
column2: and it shows in both her evolution leading up to Sucker and the sound of the album itself. Her great early singles were glittering and booming and a little desperate
column3: wrapped up in love in all of its life-or-death glory; on cuts like ""So Far Away""
column4: she sunk into swooning
column5: gaseous dreamscapes. By the end of the period covered by True Romance
column6: she had moved on to brash anthems for cool cheerleaders like ""I Love It"" and ""SuperLove""; disillusioned with the music industry in the time leading up to Sucker
column7: she decamped to Sweden with producer pal Patrik Berger (whose credits are all over the finished product) and put together an unreleased roaring punk record that's already entered into the annals of pop myth. Imagine a world where the boisterous onomatopoeic chant that kicks off ""Boom Clap"" is sped up and made the whole song
column8: and it's an even bigger hit somehow; that's the world of Sucker.

column1: Broadly speaking
column2: it's a collection of colorful power-pop that occasionally veers outside the lines into punk and new wave; there are a few sentimental songs
column3: but they're a lot more compact than the breathy
column4: grand highlights of True Romance. And though Charli keeps the pace brisk and focuses more on speed and attitude than detail
column5: there's a real sense of craft that seeps through cracks in the record's sneering facade. Rampaging highlights like the hilarious ""London Queen"" are still stained with harmony and impressive vocal layering. With its sharp riffs
column6: tight structure
column7: and confident
column8: bratty snarl—tricks cribbed from the Strokes and Weezer
column9: Kesha and Gwen Stefani
column10: and M.I.A.—Sucker distances itself from the work of many other female pop stars that have ruled 2014: the Gothic precociousness of Lorde
column11: the tidy lines and weaponized hooks of Taylor Swift
column12: the focus group LCD pandering of Meghan Trainor. Its closest cousin might be One Direction's Four
column13: a record that finds the hunky urchins steering into classic rock and gleaming Phoenix-like riffs; Sucker is a little harder to pin down
column14: a little less formulaic.

column1: Charli also seeks to differentiate herself from her peers through her attitude; she defines herself through her opposition to the machinery of the pop music industry
column2: and through a sneering independent streak that's strong enough to be distinct but complementary rather than disruptive. Where other pop stars are reliant
column3: even dependent
column4: on the cultivation of relatability
column5: she embraces and lampoons wealth and power and independence
column6: often to humorous effect. On ""London Queen""
column7: she conquers America
column8: drives on the wrong side of the road to feel like JFK
column9: and refuses to return to Britain until she's won enough to fill a wall with plaques. She builds a fortress out of money on the blown out ""Gold Coins"" and relaxes with a cigarette inside. She has a gift for line delivery that grants her put-downs a spiteful glow
column10: and when she opens the raucous ""Breaking Up"" with
column11: ""You had an ugly tattoo
column12: and fucking cheap perfume!"" it's all the characterization the listener needs. Sucker is also a record that's largely detached from romance—any saccharine stuff
column13: like girl group tribute ""Need Ur Luv""
column14: is delivered with tongue firmly in cheek—and Charli is content to revel in hanging with friends and in her individual sexuality
column15: like on salacious pro-masturbation romp ""Body of My Own"".

column1: If you think this sounds like a lot to swallow
column2: you're absolutely right; Sucker is a crowded and surprisingly dense record
column3: given that the majority of its songs are concerned with the various fruits of stardom. It can be an exhausting listen if you're not fully prepared for its willfully destructive energy. The credits are stuffed with a wide breadth of writers and producers plucked from every corner of the contemporary pop world: industry superstars like Benny Blanco and Greg Kurstin
column4: rising producers like Cashmere Cat
column5: indie darlings (Ariel Rechtshaid
column6: Vampire Weekend's Rostam Batmanglij
column7: gonzo doofus Ariel Pink)
column8: and none other than Weezer godhead Rivers Cuomo (on the ""Beverly Hills"" rip ""Hanging Around""). That the album has any sort of coherence and consistency is a credit to Charli's personality and presence
column9: her lust for life and palpable joy. And that may not be enough for some listeners. With its carefully chosen samples (Todd Rundgren!) and swirling
column10: love-drunk arrangements
column11: True Romance oozed craft and measured cool; Sucker opens with a chorus built around the gleeful chant of ""Fuck you! Sucker!""

column1: With that said
column2: there's something undeniably exciting to me about a scenario in which a young fan
column3: fresh out of falling in love with ""Boom Clap"" or ""Fancy""
column4: comes to this record and discovers an uncompromising
column5: ferocious talent
column6: self-assured and empowered and incredibly versatile. Sucker isn't an endpoint for Charli—she's already talking about her next record
column7: inspired by J-pop and ""intensely weird and childlike""—and it's not her finest work
column8:
but it's plenty good enough to rope a cohort of new fans into what's promising to be one hell of a creative ride.

There’s always something of a contrarian streak to Detroit dance music producer Theo Parrish that can also come across as purist
column2: crotchety
column3: fussbudgety. When he first began releasing music in 1996
column4: Parrish and peers like Kenny Dixon Jr.
column5: Marcellus Pittman
column6: Rick Wilhite
column7: Andrés
column8: and more did dance music that was not quite in step with the scene. Instead of futurism and the whirring machinations that informed Detroit’s sleekest export
column9: techno
column10: they preferred house’s slightly slower pulse
column11: their tracks infused with their parents and grandparents’ record collections. Swells of church organ
column12: the coos of R&B
column13: jazz’s swing
column14: funk’s rhythmic gunk—some half-century’s worth of African-American music—teemed just beneath the kick drum.

column1: But as house music tightened and grew sleeker
column2: Parrish's tracks loosened and turned viscous. He began dropping disco edits and when edits began to flood the market soon after
column3: his grew uglier. Deep house all the rage now? Well then
column4: Parrish's most recent mix is comprised entirely out of charged 1970’s free jazz. He’s as renowned for not giving you what you want in a DJ set as he is for delivering both the headiest and dankest dance music of the last 20 years.

column1: He gives you all you can handle with American Intelligence
column2: a title that with each passing news day feels more and more like an oxymoron. It’s his first album since 2007 and the end result is a massive listen
column3: a two-hour collection (or else a slightly trimmed triple LP)
column4: with 10 of its 15 tracks approaching or breaking the 10-minute barrier. Within it
column5: Parrish embraces the paradox of the title: indulgent and defiant
column6: serious and cheeky
column7: political yet intent on getting your dead ass to move. The man is musically generous
column8: even if a copy in the shop might set you back $50.

column1: The album opens with a subliminal bass tone that will set your subwoofer to trembling. He then carefully drips in closed hi-hats
column2: a snare just a millimeter too fast
column3: a ride cymbal that splatters like a circuit in a rain puddle
column4: all of it embellishing a heart-quickening throb. Parrish then takes his sweet fucking time to whisper to his fellow countrymen: ""Where’s your drive? Has it died?"" He then answers himself: ""It keeps me alive.""

column1: Throughout the length of this album
column2: Parrish keeps to the sparest of rhythmic sounds. And as he put it in a recent interview
column3: that was his intent: ""What I try to get to is that part of everybody that is childlike and is simple
column4: it goes to the rhythm
column5: the repetition. The idea of a handclap that keeps happening over and over again is the most-simple thing that can happen and is something everybody can do and relate to."" He’s the Alice Waters of dance music
column6: turning a handful of fresh ingredients into a feast. Often the rhythm tracks are erected out of little more than a live kick drum
column7: tom
column8: snare
column9: hi-hat
column10: dashes of other hand percussion (bells
column11: rattles)
column12: with pads adding a bit more heft. Out of such Spartan percussion
column13: he mesmerizes
column14: to where introducing a new element 5-6 minutes deep suddenly turns revelatory. Some six minutes amongst the echoing bloops and zagging keys of ""Tympanic Warfare""
column15: the drums start to sizzle and what once seemed abstract and not fully sketched out now feels solid.

column1: The length of tracks slows down AI at some points
column2: while some of the keyboard figures seem to echo melodies found elsewhere
column3: which to newcomers might get misread as sameness. As rapturous as the beatless R&B exhalations of vocalist Ideeyah are on ""Ah""
column4: it would have been more effective and sublime at five minutes instead of 10. ""Helmut Lampshade"" turns into a jazz fusion robot run amok. The highway patrol dialogue on ""Welcome Back"" is a throwaway track
column5: but there’s little doubt it’s rooted in the ugliest of truths about American racism
column6: underscoring the political that is always just beneath the surface of Parrish's music and discourse.

column1: The track well worth wading through is the 13 glorious minutes of ""Be In Yo Self"". Built from a shuffling cymbal that slowly gathers momentum
column2: aspects of the track are smooth enough to scan as nu-jazz yet it still feels rooted and raw. Guitarist Duminie DePorres delivers a snaking Phil Upchurch-type guitar line as Ideeyah hums and harmonizes with herself
column3: singing ad nauseam: ""Being yourself shouldn’t have a downside.""

column1: As Parrish explained in the aforementioned interview
column2: the song is ""almost kind of like a spiritual. It's a chant."" Midway through
column3: the shift comes not from a new rhythmic element
column4: but a lyrical one: ""Hey suga
column5: would you dance a little bit closer to me?"" It’s deep
column6: not so much in the house sense
column7: but in an emotional way
column8: an honest request to his betrothed. It’s Parrish at his most disarming
column9: and coming as it does in his broad discography
column10:
it’s a most agreeable sound.

column4: you might have noticed
column5: is on the mind of many musicians. As music consumption continues to shift toward digital methods of distribution
column6: from illegal downloads that pay the artist nothing to authorized streams that pay very little
column7: some makers are wondering just how they’ll continue to make. If the consumer isn’t willing to foot the bill with a sliver of their own income

column1: Though the circumstances have changed in most every respect during the 80 years since the Paramount Records empire crumbled
column2: this core question hasn’t: How do you keep putting music out when you’re no longer pulling money in? The success of Paramount Records
column3: a loss-leader meant to move the music-playing furniture made by the Wisconsin Chair Company as World War I came to a close
column4: was a surprise for the business’ leaders. The shoddily recorded and haphazardly manufactured shellac discs became a rather big boon as the '20s roared. Hired in 1923
column5: J. Mayo Williams
column6: an ambitious talent scout who had headed north from Arkansas
column7: led the pivotal Paramount charge. He assembled and managed a roster of uncontested originals
column8: from Blind Lemon Jefferson and Ma Rainey to Blind Blake and Jelly Roll Morton. But in 1927
column9: Williams left the label following a series of injuries and insults from the company’s white owners and officers. That’s where the first volume of The Rise & Fall of Paramount Records—a massive two-set collaboration between Jack White’s Third Man
column10: John Fahey’s revived Revenant and a fleet of researchers
column11: writers
column12: graphic designers
column13: fabricators
column14: builders
column15: archivists
column16: printers and collectors—closes.

column1: Williams’ departure
column2: though
column3: isn’t the end of Paramount’s rise
column4: even if it might denote the start of the fall. The second volume of The Rise & Fall is instead a catalogue brimming with genius
column5: no matter that the label’s scouts in fields and offices alike didn’t carry the same historical clout as Williams. Charley Patton and Son House
column6: Lottie Kimbrough and Dock Boggs
column7: Geeshie Wiley and Skip James
column8: Thomas Dorsey and Emry Arthur: Those are only some of the names that arrive for this set
column9: which stretches from 1928 until the label’s unceremonious end in the wake of the Great Depression in 1932. That’s when the money ran out for music.

column1: The talent had not stopped shipping into Grafton’s record-pressing plant during that time of widespread financial woe. In fact
column2: the 800 remastered tracks offered in Volume Two document the roots of gospel and swing and the intensification of blues and jazz through the efforts of some of American music’s formative musical minds. You can hear the earliest echoes of bluegrass
column3: which would be born a dozen years after Paramount closed
column4: and antediluvian traces of rock’n’roll
column5: hot on its heels with added electricity.

column1: The funds
column2: however
column3: just weren’t what they used to be. ""Despite many of the great talents he helps bring to Grafton
column4: you can’t sell the records if no one has money to buy them
column5: writes Scott Blackwood of the pale
column6: bespectacled and pivotal Paramount recruiter Art Laibly. ""Likely
column7: out on the road or riding the rails across the South
column8: Art Laibly’s anxieties about the future would sometimes get the best of him. The Crash. The poor getting poorer. A part of him knowing the days of the Race Records business were numbered."" At least they kept it going long enough to firm up the foundation for their rather young country’s recording pedigree.

column1: You can examine that foundation for yourself on Volume Two. You can ponder the existential strangeness of Patton’s still-singular approach to the blues and his divisive belief in both religion and the bottle. (His ""Prayer of Death"" tunes as Elder J.J. Hadley are essential.) You can sway to the woozy
column2: wobbly string-band fare of the Mississippi Sheiks. You can nod and shake to the delirious a cappella spirituals of the Famous Blue Jay Singers of Birmingham
column3: particularly the delirious and pulsing ""Clanka-A-Lanka (Sleep on Mother)"". Skip James’ inescapable ""Hard Time Killin’ Floor Blues"" is here
column4: as are two versions of Dock Boggs’ ""Will Sweethearts Know Each Other"" and Geeshie Wiley’s continually magnetic and tragic ""Last Kind Words Blues"". Had the unlikely and uncanny venture of Paramount never thrived
column5: and had these songs never been captured
column6: it’s easy to imagine the next several decades of music taking very different turns.

column1: Not everything here changed the world
column2: of course
column3: and some of Paramount’s hidden gems arrive through its most obscure oddities. Brother Fullbosom’s ""A Sermon on a Silver Dollar"" is a racially and religiously irreverent faux testimonial to the power of that most almighty ducat. ""Wicked Treatin’ Blues""
column4: a duet for despondent harmonica and vocals that seem delivered from a deathbed
column5: hypnotizes with sadness. George Hamilton’s ""Chimes Blues"" offers a delightful piano jaunt. Ollie Hess’ parlor-ready ""Mammy’s Lullaby"" combines arching
column6: urbane vocals and simply picked guitar—country
column7: meet cosmopolitan. Two of the best and most truly haunting songs in the entire Paramount oeuvre belong to Rube Lacy
column8: a little-known blues moaner who only recorded these two cuts as far as anyone can tell. In its waning days
column9: without Williams in command
column10: Paramount was grasping for anything to sell. Many of these didn’t do that
column11: but thanks be to Paramount for thinking they might—they are wonderful
column12: ponderous relics. The worst that can be said about any of these songs is that they’re simply curious; the best is that they’re landmarks.

column1: The first volume of The Rise & Fall came housed in an impressive chestnut box
column2: lined with green felt and accessorized with metallic emblems. Its six LPs lived in a wooden record book
column3: and the marbled brown vinyl looked as though it had been cut from the cross-section of some grand old oak. An accompanying USB drive—a ""Jobber-Luxe""
column4: Third Man likes to call it—contained the central trove of songs and graphics in a tarnished brass device that seemed pulled from a steampunk’s wildest pipe dream. Both the design and the text were nominated for Grammys in early December
column5: and deservedly so.

column1: You can expect much the same for Volume Two
column2: which steps into the machine age through an aluminum replication of RCA Victor’s beautiful Special Model K portable record player. When the outside latches are unlocked
column3: sets of rivets on either half unscrew to reveal the contents—on one side
column4: a packet of promotional Paramount reproductions and six alabaster white records that sparkle with holograms when lit; on the other
column5: two dense books that detail what’s known about all the musicians involved on these tracks and Blackwood’s romantic history of the second Paramount era. A second USB drive sits lodged in this volume’s navy blue felt. It’s the Paramount eagle
column6: wings up and cast in bright aluminum. The Streamline Moderne approach intends to pull the music from a past of rural antiquity and toward urban modernity. ""The machine was the source of America’s might and standing in the world
column7: Blackwood told Wired in October
column8: ""our capacity as an industrial power that connected the vast plains of our country.""

column1: Still
column2: it’s hard to see these sets as more than museum pieces
column3: or
column4: at best
column5: fetishist collector items that lock vital research
column6: history
column7: and context away in a private vault with actual latches. Taken together
column8: volumes one and two of The Rise & Fall of Paramount Records are mighty resources for understanding how the near-century of music that has followed first moved. But it’s a shame that such indispensable history remains so relatively unobtainable. Issued in editions of 5
column10: these bulky boxes cost $400 each; tellingly
column11: the first volume is still available through Third Man
column12: more than a year after its release.

column1: The price
column2: believe it or not
column3: is worth it. Given the work that went into each package
column4: it’s hard to imagine that White is building his own private railroad with the profits. The treasures in the sets are staggering and sprawling
column5: capable of inducing laughter
column6: heartache
column7: belief
column8: and disbelief. There is bedrock and bedlam alike. But as Blackwood himself writes of a different but not entirely separate era
column9: ""You can’t sell the records if no one has money to buy them."" It’s hard to believe that most people have an extra mortgage payment sitting around for this history lesson
column10: however great it may be.

column1: And that’s a shame
column2: because this music still moves. Not only do many of these songs maintain a vibrancy and a spirit that function even now
column3: but they’re part of a still-incomplete story. Paramount was infamously terrible at record-keeping and accounting
column4: so researchers like archivist Alex van der Tuuk are still finding facts and chasing myths to build a more complete label history. ""Sun to Sun""
column5: a steady-swerving Blind Blake tune recorded in November 1931
column6: hadn’t been heard by modern ears until a copy was found in a steamer trunk in Raleigh
column7: North Carolina
column8: by the collector Marshall Wyatt in 2007. And Willie Brown
column9: who contributes some of the best blues guitar to either set
column10: remains something of a ghost
column11: despite his relationships with the more famous House and Patton. ""No conclusive evidence has been found to prove that this is indeed the real Willie Brown
column12: van der Tuuk writes of Brown’s believed burial site.

column1: Such mysteries sit close to the core of Pitchfork contributor Amanda Petrusich’s 2014 book
column2: Do Not Sell at Any Price. ""There is even a vague fear that rare-record collecting could one day become analogous to fine-art collecting
column3: Petrusich writes early in her book
column4: ""the obligation of wealthy aristocrats whose consumption of art is more a statement of status than a function of love or even understanding."" It’s unfortunate
column5: then
column6: that in an age of infinite digital replication
column7: where media need not be scarce
column8: these archival releases have intentionally realized those fears by turning this music into artifacts for only those who can afford it. The new Jobber-Luxe contains an application that plays all of these tracks in specific orders or at random. If these boxes ever sell out
column9: let’s hope Third Man considers its money made and puts that player online
column10:
so that more listeners can know exactly where they came from.

In October of last year
column2: David Byrne’s Luaka Bop label released Who is William Onyeabor?
column3: a compilation of the obscure Nigerian musician some eight years in the making. A few months on
column4: Sinkane’s Ahmed Gallab led an all-star tribute to Onyeabor. Over the course of concerts in London
column5: New York
column6: and Los Angeles
column7: Gallab assembled the likes of Byrne
column8: Damon Albarn
column9: members of Hot Chip
column10: the Rapture
column11: and LCD Soundsystem
column12: the Beastie Boys’ Money Mark
column13: fellow Nigerian stars the Lijadu Sisters
column14: Dead Prez
column15: jazz star Joshua Redman and '60s free jazz legend Pharoah Sanders
column16: Peaking Lights
column17: and more to cover Onyeabor’s music live. There was also a documentary

column19: and six commissioned original pieces of art by contemporary West African and American artists. Now follows a 9xCD box set (also split into two hefty vinyl boxes) that collects the entirety of William Onyeabor’s recorded output. But even after listening to all nine of these albums and absorbing the contributing essays from Mike Rubin (an expanded version of his New York Times profile) and Nigerian author Chris Abani
column20: as well as recollections of the search for the man from Luaka Bop’s Yale Evelev and Eric Welles
column21: one question still remains: Who is William Onyeabor?

column1: There’s little doubt that Luaka Bop turned over every single stone in their quest. They both talked to Onyeabor on the phone and traveled to his compound in Enugu. (Welles tells of his travels from Lagos to Nigeria’s “coal city
column2: ” where Onyeabor remains a prominent businessman
column3: with a flour mill
column4: gas station
column5: Internet café
column6: and record pressing plant
column7: along with a street named after him and the honorific title of “High Chief.”) And they did ask Onyeabor personal questions while in his presence. But at almost every turn
column8: he evaded specifics. And so very little biography on Onyeabor has been advanced beyond what was written on the back of his debut album
column9: which calls him “a French and American trained professional film maker
column10: ” though the stories go that he also studied film in Russia. And when he returned to his native Nigeria
column11: he had both filmmaking equipment as well as a trove of prohibitively expensive early synthesizers.

column1: His 1977 debut Crashes in Love is subtitled “A tragedy of how an African Princess rejects love that money buys” and is presented to the record buying public as a soundtrack to Onyeabor’s film of the same name
column2: though there seems to be no trace of the film. On the front cover is an advert for Onyeabor’s own Wilfilms
column3: which produces
column4: exhibits
column5: and sells features and documentaries
column6: as well as “Records
column7: Motion Advert
column8: General Entertainment
column9: etc.” and the back features the disclaimer: “You may wish to know that it is neither all nor only the sounds contained in this album that are tracked in film.”

column1: There are no credits other than that of Onyeabor
column2: but there’s a full band behind him
column3: a crisp backbeat of drums and hand percussion
column4: horns
column5: snaking guitar lines and bubbling bass
column6: and female singers who sing “One day you’ll be lying dead” on the mortality funk of “Something You’ll Never Forget”. Onyeabor’s organ sounds less like a synthesizer prototype purchased in an Eastern bloc country and more like something airlifted from an Indiana rollerskate rink and what would be the primary instrument on future albums is relegated to accompaniment instead
column7: the horn line and bass.

column1: On Crashes in Love
column2: Onyeabor is of a piece with his Nigerian contemporaries—the album bears similarity to the likes of other mid-70s bands like BLO
column3: the Funkees
column4: and Ofege. The title track has a lilt to it as if at any moment the melody might veer off into a particularly light-footed take on “Red Red Wine” while “Heaven & Hell” sports the kind of breakbeat that would have led beat heads to seek the album out in the first place. It closes with one of Onyeabor’s stranger songs
column5: “Jungle Gods”
column6: featuring roiling bass and thundering percussion
column7: Onyeabor speaking in echoplexed tongues. It’s also an outlier in that the sense that soon after followed a second version of Crashes in Love
column8: now minus “Jungle Gods”. The alternate version of this album sounds ever so slightly sped up on “Something You Will Never Forget”
column9: and now features a sputtering drum machine atop every other song.

column1: In his essay to the box set
column2: Abani recalls hearing Onyeabor’s “Atomic Bomb” on the way to seminary
column3: where it vies for attention with Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony
column4: Michael Jackson
column5: Fela Kuti
column6: and Bob Marley amid the din of the marketplace. Not even a few months later
column7: Abani and his fellow Nigerian classmates attended an assembly on the nuclear threat and later that night dance to the ecstatic eight minutes of “Atomic Bomb”
column8: which inverts that world-destroying fear into an expression of love.

column1: On Onyeabor’s 1978 album
column2: he ditches his dream of being a filmmaker and emerges as a singular musical artist. Opener “Beautiful Boy” features a relaxed loping beat
column3: the organ now resembling a ray gun from a '50s alien invasion
column4: Onyeabor unveiling a soft croon to a woman
column5: “I’m gonna take you home.” Elsewhere
column6: he furthers his loverman persona
column7: singing “My love
column8: I need you all my life.” Another undeniable groove powers “Better Change Your Mind”
column9: the most politically-engaged Onyeabor song and the catalyst for Luaka Bop’s search for Onyeabor when they included it on Love's A Real Thing: The Funky Fuzzy Sounds Of West Africa.

column1: Tomorrow
column2: his third album in as many years
column3: now featuring Onyeabor in a velvety double-breasted suit
column4: begins to move away from the solid groove of Afrobeat towards something more diaphanous. The drums and bass loosely twine about Onyeabor and his female backup singers
column5: their vocals unhurried
column6: the organ squirreling in
column7: out
column8: above and around the rhythm. “Why Go to War” has what sounds like a Slinky threaded through an electric guitar and then nervously plucked
column9: continuing Onyeabor’s mind being on both the smallest of affairs between man and woman and the mutually assured destruction of the world. The album also features what some 35 years later might be Onyeabor’s greatest pop ""hit
column10: the preening funk of “Fantastic Man” (which you can now hear on ads for It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia). And no wonder—it’s a doozy
column11: Onyeabor peacocking before a group of females even as he steps on a disco duck and has a UFO crash land on his fly threads.

column1: “Body & Soul”
column2: the title track off his next album
column3: has made its rounds on open-minded dancefloors via a few different 12” pressings. It scans as Afrobeat while maintaining a slack beat
column4: suggesting downtempo
column5: reggae
column6: funk and disco
column7: with modular synth bleeps without ever being beholden to any one of them. Instead Onyeabor (dapper in a white tuxedo on the album sleeve) testifies to his love of music
column8: body and soul. But the rest of the album maintains a relaxed grip on Afrobeat
column9: “The Way to Win Your Love” urgent in its pleading if not its meter. While on “Poor Boy
column10: ” Onyeabor's keyboard blurts are hurried and the interplay between horns
column11: drums
column12: and synths are some of the most intricate to date.

column1: Great Lover is the album I’m least familiar with
column2: in that only “Love is Blind” –with its “Ring My Bell”-esque synth swoops– was previously compiled. It continues Onyeabor’s run of swag covers
column3: now posing in a tux and tophat
column4: his wristwatch bling-sized. On the back are photographs of the Wilfilms compound
column5: which seems formidable indeed in rural Africa circa 1981
column6: with a four-story building
column7: 24-track recorder
column8: 32-track mixing console and a photo of Onyeabor wearing that top hat indoors with the caption “We Mean Business” underneath. “Tell Me What You Want” shows Onyeabor absorbing reggae and its lilting rhythms
column9: his keys chirping and pinging like island birds and the album itself sounds cloaked in haze
column10: either from there being missing master tapes or the condition of the copy sourced here. But such sonic haze no doubt will endear it to Ariel Pink
column11: Lewis and DaM-Funk fans
column12: or those who now associate low fidelity with heightened mystery.

column1: Hypertension finds our mystery man now dressed as a mariachi band member
column2: right down to a blood-red sombrero. But musically he seems taken with calypso and soca and other Caribbean rhythms on “The Moon and the Sun” and “Papa Na Mama”. That amalgam of island beats
column3: disco sensibilities
column4: and Onyeabor’s warped synths bring to mind compilations like Tropical Disco Hustle
column5: showing a strange kinship between the Caribbean and Nigeria during the Year of Thriller.

column1: By the next year
column2: a greater urgency underlies Good Name (Onyeabor now sporting a white cowboy hat and gold crucifix chain)
column3: a two-track album with one song apiece taking up an entire side. In much the same way that a continent away Indian pedal steel guitarist Charanjit Singh invented acid house with Synthesizing: Ten Ragas to a Disco Beat in 1983
column4: Onyeabor himself seems to be anticipating the rise of the machines. Squelches and throbs propel “Let’s Fall in Love”
column5: continuing Onyeabor’s foremost inspirations
column6: God and love. On “Good Name”
column7: the guitars sear
column8: the sputtering drum machines skitter fast as rats
column9: and Onyeabor’s keys bear a frayed and serrated tone as he sings—a trace of desperation in his voice—how “no money can buy a good name.”

column1: Anything You Sow
column2: the Onyeabor album that first entranced me
column3: was also his last album before he gave his life (and every subsequent interview answer) over to Christ
column4: turning his back on his musical output. Sampled by Caribou (under his Daphni alias) and no doubt a template for the likes of Four Tet
column5: LCD Soundsystem
column6: Peaking Lights
column7: and James Holden
column8: to name a few
column9: Onyeabor’s influence can most easily be gleaned here on primitive-futuristic tracks like “Everyday” and “This Kind of World”. Over a joyous splutter of a beat on “When the Going is Smooth & Good”
column10: Onyeabor couches a bitter pill. Perhaps a commentary on Onyeabor’s own status at the time of his conversion
column11: the song rails against people who soothe in good times only to evaporate in bad
column12: or worse still
column13: “to help in knocking you down down down.”

column1: In the past decade
column2: the only other Nigerian artist to merit such a career-spanning box set was Fela Kuti
column3: yet in some ways it’s odd to consider William Onyeabor an equal. While Fela was truly a force of nature (the year of Crashes in Love’s release
column4: Fela himself recorded and released six albums)
column5: Onyeabor seems
column6: for lack of a better word
column7: meeker (if more liable to keep his stylish shirt on). Fela's music feels irreducible as steel while Onyeabor's is curiously ductile. An enemy of the state as opposed to a respected businessman. Both were politically-minded
column8: though it’s hard to compare Onyeabor to the vociferously outspoken Kuti.

column1: A God-fearing man making sweet
column2: light-hearted ditties in juxtapose to a demiurge with a compound full of women
column3: yet both men have greatly influenced western music-making in the late 20th century and early 21st century. Fela’s influence spans from Brian Eno to Talking Heads on up to Broadway and his revolutionary music can be felt in an instant
column4: but Onyeabor’s was quiet and every bit as revelatory. Folks tinkering with analog gear and archaic drum machines and how to make such machines express sweet-hearted human sentiment may not have realized Onyeabor’s example until reaching this precise thin layer of sediment buried deep down in reissue culture. Perhaps then Onyeabor’s renaissance will be closer to that of Arthur Russell’s
column5: both of their catalogs continuing to find resonance among those fiddling with gear
column6:
be it in their bedrooms or in their compounds.
