Japanese producer Canooooopy draws from the more mundane moments of daily life. ""The sound of an air conditioner
column2: the rhythm of a pen falling down
column3: a conversation from other people
column4: are just some of the ho-hum influences on his music that he mentions in an interview with Japanese music blog Hi-Hi-Whoopee
column5: capping his answer off with ""a monotonous life."" Canooooopy subscribes to a ""100% sampling"" ethos
column6: and builds every track on his first CD release Disconnected Words Connect the Worlds from noises that seem innocuous enough in their original context—an automated telephone greeting
column7: people chatting
column8: children singing. Yet he’s able to warp them into disjointed little worlds
column9: and Disconnected serves as a solid introduction to one of the wonkier beatmakers to pop up out of Japan over the last couple of years.

column1: A lot of what makes Canooooopy interesting emerged via a recent collaborative project
column2: wherein he teamed up with fellow Japanese trackmakers Lidly and Axion117 to form Ganghouse Fungi. That trio’s work often featured experimental dashes that hinted at what Canooooopy would do on Disconnected
column3: but his partners hailed from a more traditional crate-digging beat scene
column4: one influenced by the sound of American hip-hop and favoring jazz samples. Canooooopy
column5: meanwhile
column6: appears tied to nothing—he loads up on samples and field recordings and melds them together into forms few rappers could contend with
column7: all in Garageband (an approach he shares with Grimes
column8: who along with James Brooks of Default Genders have shared Canooooopy’s music online).

column1: Despite the herky-jerky nature of his collage approach to music
column2: Canooooopy shows an attention to detail on Disconnected that makes his best tracks click just right. ""Viral Address Stalker"" kicks off by nabbing the intro to Marnie Stern’s ""Plato’s Fucked Up Cave"" (""Get me out of this prison
column3: man/ Let me run
column4: run
column5: run
column6: run
column7: run"") and looping her stuttered ""run
column8: building a beat around it before playing with the vocal some more. ""Songs About a Sunken Hope"" bounces between various vocal samples of British-accented words and syllables
column9: Canooooopy timing it just right so no voice rams into the other and everything syncs with the skittery beat. Even brief numbers such as ""Kaleido World Mysty Sisters"" and ""Doppelinedancerstomps"" treat every second and sound with care
column10: not wasting anything during their 90-second runtimes.

column1: Disconnected’s jagged construction also emphasizes an eerie atmosphere
column2: the rush of voices often making for some uneasy moments. Sometimes it’s simply an unexpected sound—""Mono Montaged Oratorio"" is packed with sampled dialogue
column3: but none comes through headphones more clearly than a cutesy voice saying ""baby"" for a jarring second. Usually
column4: though
column5: Canooooopy lets the mishmash of sounds create an unnerving feel that lingers over the entire beat
column6: such as on the bouncy ""Too Long Way Home""
column7: where voices mixed deep in the track constantly sneak into the main rhythm. The album suffers when Canooooopy strips the music down and tries to create something creepy with minimalism
column8: as he’s at his best when sounds jumble together and unsettling moments emerge from the clamor.

column1: Even though Canooooopy has an attentive eye when it comes to individual tracks
column2: Disconnected doesn’t quite click together as an album
column3:
as certain stretches of it can get a little too cluttered. But then an individual track will burst through—such as the burbling ""The Polygonic Spree"" or clattering ""The Phantom of the Gauss""—and remind how he’s able to turn a scattershot collection of samples into something otherworldly. It’s a great introduction to a producer able to alchemize the everyday into the surreal.

J. Cole is a student of hip-hop

column9: “A Tale of 2 Citiez”

column1: J. Cole is a workmanlike MC

column4: and TLC are highlights in his growing body of work

column3: ” “Cole heating up like that leftover lasagna”) are thankfully absent

column6: too. It’s relatable but hardly the kind of story you want to hear more than once. “No Role Modelz” parlays a suspicion about a hookup being a golddigger into a tirade about black women lacking respectable public figures

column8: and “No Role Modelz” is something of a tacit admission.) 2014 Forest Hills Drive often plays at a depth it never delivers.

column1: Still
column2: ceding an entire hour to a rapper who works best in short bursts works better here than anyone could’ve expected. “03’ Adolescence” flips the classic rags-to-riches narrative inside out as Cole starts to reminisce about how hard he had it growing up only to get a chin check from a friend whose future isn’t half as bright. “G.O.M.D.”
column3: “Fire Squad”
column4: and “A Tale of 2 Citiez” all flash Cole’s technical excellence
column5: while “Intro”
column6: “Apparently”
column7: and “St. Tropez” emote through his gruff singing voice. The production here is never less than delightful; Cole’s own beats run coyly referential samples through milky instrumental embellishments. “Wet Dreamz” is an adept “Impeach the President” flip
column8: and “St. Tropez” reimagines Mobb Deep’s “Give Up the Goods (Just Step)” as sedate
column9: orchestral R&B.

column1: 2014 Forest Hills Drive is Cole planting himself in the pantheon of rap greats
column2: a volley to the spike of Kendrick Lamar’s “Control” verse. He gets more than a little ahead of himself
column3: though
column4: claiming to be better than Slick Rick
column5: LL Cool J
column6: Rakim
column7: and Big Daddy Kane on “January 28th”. Kane and Rakim’s flows were tighter
column8: LL’s swagger is inimitable
column9: and Rick’s stories surge with a purpose nothing in J. Cole’s canon can muster. This self-aggrandizing pageantry is a ultimately bad look on a guy who earns his keep speaking to the struggles of the common man
column10: and these songs work best when they’re not busy telling you how good they think they are. 2014 Forest Hills Drive is a decent album selling itself as great. It wraps itself in the garments of a classic
column11:
but you can see that the tailoring is off.

The Iceland-based sound artist Ben Frost released one of 2014's best records
column2: A U R O R A
column3: so here comes the obligatory remix EP
column4: V A R I A N T. It's frontloaded with three takes on ceremonially pounding highlight ""Venter""
column5: followed by versions of the equally forceful ""Nolan"" and the calmer drone piece ""No Sorrowing"". Frost mines a hard
column6: ferrous seam between multiple genres related by intensity and repetition
column7: and these remixes isolate them in individual strands—noise (Dutch E Germ)
column8: ambient (HTRK)
column9: dance (Evian Christ and Kangding Ray)
column10: and industrial (Regis). This results in diluted tracks that either pale in comparison to the brawny originals
column11: seem superficially connected to them
column12: or both. It would be a tall order to expect them to rival Frost's raw power
column13: but these remixes don't unearth much fascinating stuff
column14: and the EP turns out (mostly) competent but wan.

column1: Evian Christ turns ""Venter"" into regal
column2: explosive EDM
column3: coring its melody down to a nervy screw and cladding it in huge basses and time-bomb drum programming. Though it's the most immediate track here
column4: this pro forma banger is neither particularly inspired nor particularly Frost—it really could be any Evian Christ song. A less splashy but more satisfying composition is Raster-Norton artist Kangding Ray's ""No Sorrowing"". On the original
column5: a lone subfrequency drop in acres of long tones suggested walking over crystalline plains and suddenly falling into a pit; Ray retrofits it as rough-textured house music
column6: like Frost as Jon Hopkins. Downwards label proprietor Regis gives ""Nolan"" a solid
column7: somewhat similar treatment
column8: but more gnarled and industrial.

column1: And then there's the Dutch E Germ remix of ""Venter""
column2: which is actually pretty bad. Dominated by shrapnel-like blasts of noise and an annoying squeak like a rusty wheel
column3: it's repetitive and grating without being transfixing. A desultory
column4: imbalanced structure changes without going anywhere in particular. Jagged tone pileups and irritating shrills are just the kind of harshness-for-its-own-sake that Frost eschews in favor of clear
column5: commanding compositions. HTRK's version follows it and comes as a relief. You won't be surprised to hear that the Australian down-tempo duo turns it into chill-out music
column6: reducing its tribal drums to a hollow knock and then blowing thin currents of atmosphere around a lone fillip of bass. It's a little tedious
column7: though it's sensual and hypnotic if you let yourself flow into it.

column1: The most fundamental
column2: buried part of Frost's aesthetic is classical minimalism
column3: a strand that is left undisturbed by these surface-level retrofits. A remix EP that exhumed it could provide actual interest and value
column4: but it doesn't seem like that much thought went into this—it's par for the course that instead of creating a new
column5: coherent collection
column6: you send out stems to some people you like and hope for the best. These kinds of remixes can make for great bonus tracks and promotional freebies—and hey
column7: if someone wants to pay for them as a collection
column8: more power to Frost. But if you need another reminder of the pointlessness of the remix EP as a commercial artifact
column9:
here it is.

column1: Within D.C.

column2: ""Celebration""
column3: and ""Legend"". That self-assurance helps sell him when stomping across evergreen rap topics like the drug trade
column4: gunfire
column5: and money. He commits
column6: quite convincingly
column7: to every word. So when he spits ""Take me out these handcuffs/ I like to eat salmon/ I can’t be in handcuffs"" on ""Handcuffs""
column8: the plea is not of frustration at the law

column10: and would deny him a seafood dinner.

column1: Earlier this year contributor Lawrence Burney explored that possibility that
column2: through street rap
column3: D.C. could finally see broader success in a post-Wale world. Here
column4: Glizzy stuck to that model
column5: choosing to keep working with two of his most reliable producers: trap legend Zaytoven and the undervalued K.E. on the Track. Unlike a number of other major cities
column6: D.C. is not burdened with a specific definition of what a rapper from the city could or should sound like; when rappers of the city range from the '90s throwback of Oddisee to the post-Tumblr rap of Yung Gleesh to the hardened trap of Fat Trel

column1: The cover of Young Jefe evoked the '80s film Scarface
column2: which is not an unfamiliar motif for a young rapper seeking to assert his own gangster machismo. But there is a real harshness to Glizzy’s music on Law 3 that rises above his last tape’s cartoonish bombast. On the early highlight ""Funeral"" Glizzy approaches his death the same way he deals with his mortality: Extravagantly and violently
column3: as he raps ""It's gon' be some superstars at my funeral…You might get your ass robbed at my funeral."" There is no tension here for Glizzy
column4: he accepts the reality that such opulence could come with consequences. It's a fitting sentiment for Glizzy's past year: 2014 was full of opportunity for him
column5:
and Law 3 finds a rapper refusing to take it easy on his way to success.

column5: though

column7: and he moves in lockstep time to guitars
column8: drums and bass
column9: all sharing intentions beyond aural obliteration. Each of these songs has at least one hook you’ll be able to hum

column11: Bloodyminded’s most recent LP
column12: Solotroff yelled lines like
column13: ""mounds of bodies lying unburied"" and ""air so fouled by the pungent stench of millions of dead children."" If you encounter temporary cognitive dissonance while singing along to songs about science and seasons with his Mark Mothersbaugh-meets-They Might Be Giants intonation
column14: just trust that you’re not the only one.

column1: Solotroff has long been a very busy and involved collaborator
column2: but in recent years
column3: his partnership has added unexpected elements to pre-existing projects. He supplied
column4: for instance

column7: the slow-moving and cinematic collective that works between poles of orchestral splendor and doom furor. Aside from founder J.R. Robinson
column8: Solotroff is one of the project’s sole stable and necessary elements. Such integration is key to Ciphers + Axioms. Only Solotroff and Kenny Rasmussen return from Anatomy of Habit’s earlier iteration
column9: but the new members are copacetic by any standard: Will Lindsay
column10: whose brawny riffs lead the aforementioned Indian
column11: commandeers guitar
column12: while indispensable Tortoise and session drummer John McEntire takes the kit. Joan of Arc’s Theo Katsaounis accents the beats with auxiliary percussion. Chicago metal stalwart Sanford Parker engineered the sessions in McEntire’s Soma Electronic Music Studios. This is an enviable cast of contributors.

column1: Together
column2: they are excellent. In particular
column3: the rhythm section of McEntire
column4: Katsaounis
column5: and Rasmussen’s burly and distorted bass works as one of the record’s great assets. During ""Radiate and Recede""
column6: they power ahead like a seasoned but smart doom band. They pull back in the perfect places
column7: allowing Lindsay’s gnarled riffs and Solotroff’s enigmatic words to cut through their rests. After introducing ""Then Window"" with an unstable shock of feedback
column8: Lindsay cycles subtly through a series of strong-arm riffs and phantom countermelodies. Katsaounis and McEntire match him in the background
column9: adding touches of bells and woodblocks to drums that suggest an incoming infantry.

column1: The occasional nature of Anatomy of Habit—in particular
column2: this first-time lineup—cuts both ways. There’s a sense of discovery to Ciphers + Axioms
column3: as the members seem to be negotiating their way through domains of post-rock and doom
column4: math rock and post punk collectively. By record’s end
column5: you want them to keep navigating. During the album
column6: though
column7: the nebulous configuration can produce frustrating results. ""Radiate and Recede"" depends too much on its start-and-stop
column8: quiet-loud-and-louder structure
column9: as the band flips again and again between loaded metal lurch
column10: eerie ambient crawl
column11: and mid-paced art-rock shuffle. A veteran group might get much the same result with an editing overhaul. That symptom also coincides with how Solotroff sounds a touch uncomfortable
column12: or at least not fluid
column13: in his new role as an enunciating frontman. The speak-sing spans of ""Radiate and Recede"" are forced and stiff
column14: as if he were trying to raise his voice without screaming. He is more at ease and more convincing when he’s actually singing

column18:
its squall wired by Lindsay’s alluring guitar line. You’re left with the suggestion of future possibilities for this take on Anatomy of Habit.

Stop me if you’ve heard this one before: dashing bon vivant Tony Stark is mangled in a horrifying accident on the job
column3: is resurrected by a confluence of mad science and divine intervention

column5: the comic book franchise that gave Ghostface Killah
column6: aka Tony Starks
column7: his first album title and likely

It should if you’ve heard anything about 36 Seasons; the main difference is that Adrian Younge is exchanged for Brooklyn revivalists the Revelations and that Tony Starks doesn’t actually die before he rains vengeance upon those who have wronged him.

column1: One can see this continuous and considerable narrowing of Ghostface Killah’s artistic scope as a course correction or an apology to his hardcore fanbase; penance for the shameless bids for commercial relevance on The Big Doe Rehab and Ghostdini: The Wizard of Poetry in Emerald City. The sadder truth is that Ghostface has been in an artistic tailspin for the past seven years and
column2: as with Twelve Reasons to Die
column3: there seems to be a tacit acknowledgement that he can’t pull out unless someone else takes the controls.

column1: Though still credited to Ghostface Killah
column2: 36 Seasons is a truly collaborative work. Comic book artist Matthew Rosenberg returns to provide the storyline and Ghostface doesn’t even appear on nearly a third of the tracks
column3: which are earmarked for character introductions and a chance for the Revelations to show their neo-soul credentials. While nowhere near as fantastical as Twelve Reasons’ supernatural storyline—Ghostface was a hired gun murdered by his employees and his remains were melted into 12 vinyl albums—36 Seasons is far more promising. In short
column4: Tony Starks was keeping Staten Island in check just with his presence
column5: but for reasons that aren’t quite clear
column6: he’s exiled for nine years; that amounts to “36 seasons
column7: ” as Ghostface constantly reminds the listener throughout. He returns home and sees his girl take up with a local drug kingpin (played by Kool G Rap) and his former running buddy (voiced by AZ) joins the boys in blue. He’s determined to clean up the streets
column8: but has to do some dirt first

column2: jaw-dropping detail
column3: and character sketches that resulted in the most vivid storytelling hip-hop has ever witnessed. But that Ghostface disappeared nearly a decade ago. As such
column4: there was no reason to say ""spoiler alert"" for any of the above. For one thing
column5: it will be mentioned in every single review of 36 Seasons
column6: because the entire story is laid out in a four-panel comic included in the CD’s insert. All of it.

column1: And 36 Seasons is more in line with the spirit of Ghostface’s recent output
column2: where he’s more prolific and ""for the love"" than ever and somehow lazier at the same time. His lyrics barely deviate from the plot points laid in a comic book that can be read in 20 seconds
column3: reverting to Twelve Reasons’ childlike literalism and chronology. The first line is
column4: ""Ayo
column5: I’m back after nine years/ That’s 36 seasons/ Shit is changed up for all types of reasons"" and from there on out
column6: potentially graphic scenes are often similarly reduced to
column7: ""this happened and then this happened.""

column1: How has shit changed and what are these reasons? We’re told that the streets are being overrun with petty thieves and drug dealers
column2: but also that Ghostface’s exile was likely the result of a bid in the Tombs. So who are these kids? Are they like the Polo rubgy-stealing turncoat from ""R.A.G.U."" or the incompetent
column3: petty drug dealer from ""Maxine""? No
column4: on ""The Dogs of War"" (not to be confused with the Fishscale highlight ""Dogs of War"")
column5: they’re selling drugs in a way that Ghostface merely finds unacceptable for aesthetic reasons.

column1: When he confronts his estranged lover Bamboo (played by Kandace Springs) on ""Love Don’t Live Here""
column2: we don’t get the shocking invective of ""Wildflower""

He rhymes ""the crib"" with ""the kid"" twice in the same verse. It’s actually painful to hear him attempt to modulate his voice trying to muster some kind of emotion during this thing. Starks retells his betrayal (""Double Cross"")
column5: his lightbulb moment (""Pieces to the Puzzle"")
column6: and his murder plot (""Homicide"") in similarly unembellished terms and once the climactic shootout arrives

column1: Otherwise

column3: Theodore Unit lackey Shawn Wigs offers
column4: ""you know how we do
column5: O.G. style

column1: Nothing here changes the foundations of Cohen's narrative

The Jewish-Buddhist poet from Montreal whose songs are often best known through others' covers reminded crowds on his money-making tours that—despite a perhaps overstated reputation for aloofness (watch him doing standup comedy in 1965's Ladies and Gentlemen... Mr. Leonard Cohen)—he's a gifted and generous interpreter of his own work. His speak-singing style has grown deeper and gruffer

column9: he skips off stage.

In a recent interview with NPR
column2: Chris Rock suggested that the real ""rapper's rappers""—much like the ""comedian's comedians""—are
column3: at some level
column4: dysfunctional—and when it comes to ranking his favorites
column5: he doesn't like to ""reward dysfunction."" Rakim was Rock's example (""He's dysfunctional 'cause he couldn't get into the studio—he had a chance to make a record with Dr. Dre and he quit. Somewhere in his mind
column6: he would love to have 30 hits""). There's a germ of an idea here that feels correct: oftentimes the artists who most shape the medium aren't necessarily meant to be stars. But the notion that an artist who fails to cross over was never meant to be truly successful begs the question
column7: the flipside of a famous artist rationalizing their success after the fact. To read hip-hop's history in this way ignores the massive structural changes that have worked to obscure the genre's creative spine. The rapper's rappers
column8: the genre's true innovators
column9: are as often victims of the market's arbitrary whims as they are their own flaws.

column1: The Jacka came out of one of hip-hop's most creatively vibrant regional scenes. One-fifth of the respected Pittsburgh
column2: Calif. Mob Figaz crew
column3: the group arose in the wake of Mac Dre's post-penal second wind
column4: and were prepared to sign to his Thizz Entertainment label when the rapper was murdered in Kansas City in 2004. The Bay's hyphy movement followed
column5: as national attention focused on the dry
column6: manic production style of producers like Rick Rock
column7: and the culture that surrounded it: the drugs and the dreads
column8: ghostriding the whip and thizz faces. While national attention focused on hyphy's production novelty
column9: street rap fans in a network of Bay-affiliated cities from the Pacific Northwest to Kansas City became obsessed with Jacka's potent skill with the pen—particularly with the release of 2005's classic The Jack Artist. The arc of his career—the moment when every verse he dropped felt like a vital piece of the puzzle—lasted about four or five years. But this year's What Happened to the World is his best record since 2009's Tear Gas
column10: and suggests that whatever his potential for national stardom
column11: the Jacka should be recognized as one of the last decade's strongest writers—both within and outside of hip-hop.

column1: What Happened to the World is a leisurely-paced record
column2: moving at the speed of syrup. (The one exception
column3: the uptempo ""MOB 4 Life""
column4: is perhaps the record's only misfire). The production is of-a-piece and by and large Jacka still has a gift for a good chorus melody
column5: but the heart of the album is in its star's lyrical performance. Jacka is a minimalist as a writer
column6: an artist for whom saying a little implies a lot. Although those looking for club records or pop hits in the real-world sense might look elsewhere
column7: Jacka still has an open
column8: inclusive pop ear—this is accessible music which could easily appeal to a wide audience. Nonetheless
column9: the album will most readily reach those who still value hip-hop as an art form of evocative lyricism. One of Jacka's strengths is a gift for potent and original imagery
column10: as on ""2 Dungeons Deep"": ""Got the Wesson poppin' like meat in the pot fryin'/ Better have respect like the vet when he feed lions."" Even at his most brutal
column11: he sidesteps cliché (""When the trigger squeeze we only leave bones
column12: like a Lynx home
column13: ""This Canon not for pictures but it still will make your center fold"") in the service of triggering powerfully rendered ideas.

column1: For those just discovering the Jacka's work
column2: it helps in some ways to think of him as the West Coast's answer to mixtape legend Max B: born within a year of each other
column3: the two share similar influences (Slick Rick's melodic nonchalance seems an obvious common touchstone)
column4: and their sing-song choruses helped both become regional stars just as the old super-producer system began to break down. Their fundamental approach was both hip-hop and pop
column5: and they reimagined New York's commercial golden era—roughly 1998-2003—for a new time or place. Where Max's style had the kind of implicit politics of music from the have-nots
column6: Jack was more explicitly informed by both his identity as a Muslim and a tradition of the left coast's political radicals
column7: particularly rappers like Ice Cube
column8: Kam
column9: and Paris. At the same time
column10: there can be no question that his identity was first and foremost as a gangster rap artist
column11: with all of its morally compromised implications. But it's what makes his approach so uniquely effective.

column1: The bulk of Jacka's career feels like an attempt to reconcile principle and morality with a lifestyle that has made such stances untenable—on third song ""See It Thru"" (as throughout the record) he brings the contradictions together directly: ""Hard times
column2: trying to be cool
column3: I made the bed I slept.../ Ill whip come through the night
column4: though I'm a piece of shit."" Rather than running from hip-hop's love of the fast life
column5: of drugs
column6: of materialism
column7: he embraces their attraction. Criticisms of hip-hop's glorification of drugs and violence ignore that those things often glorify themselves; they are self-evidently appealing. One could argue Jack tries to have his cake and eat it too
column8: but his fundamental realism one-ups hip-hop's typical righteous/ignorant dichotomy. ""On Methazine""
column9: a record about promethazine addiction
column10: manages to make the drug feel like a panacea for all that aches
column11: physically and spiritually
column12: but ends with these words: ""Tell myself I'll put away the cup when the summer's gone/ Shit ridiculous
column13: finna be Christmas and we still ain't done
column14: spiraling into the sample's numb warmth
column15: before shifting to the chorus: ""Fuck with me
column16: let's talk some more
column17: 'cause I know everything/ But it's hard to notice when I'm leaned on Methazine.""

column1: Through the loose sketches of his sparse verses
column2: the album is more than an attempt to reconcile good and evil within; it also refuses to let the outside world off the hook. In attacking his own moral failings
column3: it gives strength to his assault on a wider system. (""Weed Farmer"" is perhaps the closest a pro-pot record has come to ""Nature of the Threat"" in rap history.) Husalah's final verse to close the record has a dark poetic charge: ""False hope tossed the rope around them tree limbs/ Horrific strange fruit hang from loops in deep Southern winds."" But the album is more than its political content
column4: too: it's a personal statement of vitality from an artist now in his 30s
column5: who may be removed from the travails of his youth but still wrestles with their consequences. ""We hit the club
column6: takin' pictures bitches stalkin the kid/ I had the time of my life

I'll never be young again/ But now I only think money 'cuz I'm finally a man.""

Relapse Records ostensibly allowed the young Portland

column1: When Orca Wolf

column1: Usnea do not err on the side of cautious thrift for Random Cosmic Violence

column4: with blanketing distortion locked in perpetual battle against a rhythm section that rattles the room for attention. Guitarist Justin Cory and bassist Joel Williams volley vocals back and forth
column5: the former’s serpent-tongue screams contrasting the latter’s bottom-feeder
column6: doom-or-death bellow. The approach is
column7: at times

column9: doused in blood  on a night clear
column10: he shouts in a caustic tone—leads you like a magnet toward the crunch of drums and guitars that follow. Near its end
column11: opener ""Lying in Ruin"" winds into a noisy comedown
column12: sheets of mutated tones covering and then crawling beneath a militaristic beat. You might wish it stretched ahead forever. And after moving through a beautifully ominous prelude
column13: closer ""Detritus"" rises into a graceful
column14: glacial procession. The quartet gradually piles on the layers
column15: lacing feedback around the distortion and letting the dual guitars drift through complementary pirouettes. Toward song’s end
column16: Cory and Williams trade quick lines about despair and hell and endings. Topical considerations aside
column17: it’s a triumphant moment

column1: Unfortunately
column2: it’s also the record’s lone vital stretch. Usnea’s small step toward heavy metal’s upper echelon seems to have cost the quartet more than recoupable pressing-plant expenses. As if frightened by Relapse’s legitimacy

column5: a pattern that eventually falls into a flatline. Sure

column8: later

column10: as though Usnea are trying to hide their eccentricities from what is certain to be an expanded audience. This feeling presides through more than half of Random Cosmic Violence

column1: On Usnea

column3: as the young quartet wedged strange ideas into the wide spaces of its long songs. But on Random Cosmic Violence
column4: the expected starts to make you wish that this had been the two-side debut
column5: not the four-side Relapse set that you can hold with two hands. Usnea’s leverage may have expanded

their music has not.

There’s little tactile info to be found on Vancouver collective Mood Hut and its residents. But with member names like Cloudface

column1: It makes sense that Washington D.C.’s Future Times label released a single earlier this year from Tanner Matt (aka Ttam Renat and Hashman Deejay) and now follows it up with the full-length Sandopolis

column3: a sumptuous three-tracker that shows a nexus of chillwave
column4: dusty Detroit vibes and Al B. Sure!’s ""Nite and Day"". Recently fellow Hut member Cloudface dropped an untitled seven-track album on Black Opal

column6: that at its finest moments suggested the pensive melodicism of early Boards of Canada and the open-ended beats of Theo Parrish. Between that release and Sandopolis

it augurs well for the label and their particular homegrown strain of house music in the year ahead.

This past January
column2: Mary J. Blige appeared on a remix of Disclosure’s ""F For You""—an unexpected but instantly natural pairing that at the time seemed merely like a coronation of sorts for the legendary R&B singer. Instead it was a harbinger for both the individuals involved and the scenes they represent. As 2014 played out
column3: the Lawrence brothers would see their breakthrough hit ""Latch"" become a surprise staple on rap and R&B radio stations
column4: while Blige used her turn on ""F For You"" as the launching pad for a complete career digression—if not an overall reinvention.

column1: Her new album The London Sessions features primary collaborations with Disclosure as well as fellow British pop superstars Sam Smith
column2: Naughty Boy and ""Latch"" songwriter Jimmy Napes. That it stands as one of the final major releases of the calendar year is fitting as a summation of R&B in 2014. As the sound of pop mutated into dance music a few years back
column3: R&B lost its footing in the American mainstream
column4: leaving even its established superstars in the lurch. But R&B clawed back some of its relevance this year thanks to danceable
column5: appealing songs that didn’t immolate the genre at the altar of pop radio. Chris Brown’s ""Loyal""
column6: for instance
column7: was a massive hit
column8: but more instructive in the context of Blige’s new album were Kid Ink’s ""Show Me"" and Jeremih’s ""Don’t Tell 'Em""
column9: two hugely popular DJ Mustard-produced songs that showed a younger generation how R&B could fuse with house beats in a way that feels completely natural.

column1: All of this—from Mustard’s wizardry to R&B playlists finding room for ""Latch"" and Smith’s ""Stay With Me""—has helped provide a soft landing spot for Blige
column2: whose career has been floating aimlessly for a few years now. Blige is nothing less than a titan of R&B music
column3: but she had fallen into a trap familiar to many popular musicians two decades into a career: by trying to cling to the zeitgeist she was making music that felt stale. Blige’s albums since 2007’s Growing Pains have been patchy
column4: and she hasn’t had a true hit single since that album’s ""Just Fine"".

column1: No single from The London Sessions has yet changed that latter issue
column2: but as an album it certainly doesn’t feel stale. Instead
column3: it’s a seamless and occasionally thrilling listen that establishes a fact many could have predicted: Blige’s throaty vocals
column4: as passionate and emotional as ever
column5: are an ideal fit for house music. Nonetheless the album doesn’t exactly play out how you might expect.

column1: For instance
column2: it opens with a quartet of ballads
column3: only one of which—a classic Blige self-help anthem called ""Doubt""
column4: co-written with Naughty Boy collaborator Sam Romans—rises to the level of the album’s better
column5: later songs. Despite Blige stoking the album’s narrative with its name and by listing six songwriters on its cover
column6: we are eased into the album slowly
column7: as if we are wading into cold water. It’s like Blige couldn’t bear for her core fanbase to immediately hear a four-on-the-floor beat. The real meat of the album comes after these opening tracks—the album opens with a few wobbly steps
column8: making the sequencing curious at best.

column1: Then there is the matter of the big name collaborators. Disclosure and Sam Smith are the starry names here peeking out from behind the curtains
column2: though they even get their moments in the spotlight in the form of spoken word interludes in which they gush openly about Blige. The thing is that
column3: although these three might have been the inspiration for The London Sessions
column4: their contributions don’t exactly stand out.

column2: a Disclosure production with a Smith co-writing credit that was the first song released off the album
column3: is not only one of the album’s most forgettable tracks
column4: but it’s also so bland that it seems like Disclosure and Smith (along with Napes) were almost afraid to disturb Blige. Their reverence is clear in the clipped interludes—""To me she was this untouchable goddess
column5: Smith says in one of them—but that too often translates to a sort of distance. ""Follow""
column6: the other Disclosure track (though this time without Smith)
column7: is better
column8: but with its simple skipping garage drums and rubbery bassline it still feels like a Disclosure starter kit.

column2: which was produced and co-written along with Blige and Romans by R&B god Rodney ""Darkchild"" Jerkins. The track is a pure '90s house throwback
column3: and it’s the first song on the album that really seems to electrify Blige. ""I’m in heaven
column4: every time you lay your body next to me
column5: she sings early in the track
column6: letting her vocals run just slightly. Blige is channeling dozens of great
column7: and often anonymous
column8: house divas here
column9: and naturally she fits in their lineage perfectly.

column1: That song kicks off a run of tracks that really stabilizes the album. ""Long Hard Look""
column2: which sounds like a take on Sampha’s broken keyboard confessionals

column4: another vintage Blige ballad that features quietly arresting vocals: ""It took a whole damn year to repair my body/ It’s been about five years."" Following that is the second instance in which the young kids get taught old tricks: ""Nobody But You""

""Preaching With Singing"" is three minutes and 33 seconds of preaching and singing. The Elder Oscar Saunders testifies to the mighty love of Jesus
column3: who ""bought me with His own blood
column4: while the congregation interjects passages from hymns like ""Jesus Is Mine"" and ""I Sing Because I’m Happy"". It’s a rambunctious round of music
column5: as though each element—the preaching and the singing—was trying to outpraise the other. Midway through the sermon
column6: a female voice rises up to lead the congregation in a few lines of a different song: ""What a friend we have in Jesus
column7: all our sins and deeds to bear/ What a privilege to carry everything to God in prayer!"" Almost as soon as you have identified the song—""What a Friend We Have in Jesus""
column8: a 19th-century hymn penned by Joseph Scriven as a gift for his mother—the voices pivot fluidly into the next song
column9: leaving you with that singular gospel idea: faith as an unburdening of woes.

column1: Having grown up in a Southern Baptist church in rural West Tennessee
column2: I’ve sung ""What a Friend We Have in Jesus"" more times than I can remember
column3: but I’ve never heard it quite like this. I recall a more staid version from the bright green hymnals in the pews of our sanctuary
column4: a somber sing-along with rough harmonies yet a sense of communal reassurance. It was always set to the same tempo at which every other hymn was paced
column5: but singing together with 200 other congregants instilled a sense of churchly unity; you were part of a larger group bound together in song. Yet
column6: on ""Preaching With Singing"" the melody of ""What a Friend"" is bouncier and more urgent than I could have ever imagined
column7: the sentiment more vivid as that female voice (which remains
column8: sadly
column9: uncredited and most likely lost to history) soars above the congregation. Its spiritedness makes you want to believe in such a higher animating power
column10: which may be gospel’s great musical achievement. Even nonbelievers can listen to this music and understand the bone-deep thrill of faith.

column1: When I Reach That Heavenly Shore: Unearthly Black Gospel
column3: compiled by the notorious 78 collector Christopher King and released by Tompkins Square
column4: collects 42 tracks similar and dissimilar to ""Preaching With Singing"". They come from a variety of sources and locales
column5: but the defining aspect of this compilation may be the era it represents. These songs predate the commercial heyday of gospel in the 1940s
column6: depicting instead a time when radio was broadcasting this music to new audiences and when many of the elements that would define the genre were only just being set in stone. For that reason
column7: When I Reach That Heavenly Shore offers a glimpse of gospel’s early calls and responses
column8: its first hallelujahs and amens. ""This gift of extemporaneous expression is at the heart of the recordings contained in this modest collection
column9: ” King writes in the liners. ""The variety of regional approaches to sacred song in this collection—shape-note hymnody
column10: verse ‘lining
column11: ’ unbridled ecstasy
column12: and plaintive mourning—are all informed by the then recent experience of slavery and by the then current state of Jim Crow.""

column1: Gospel would become the soundtrack to the Civil Rights movement of the 1950s and 1960s
column2: with hymns like ""We Shall Overcome"" and ""This Little Light of Mine"" lending a moral dimension to the cause of equal rights. Especially on such numbers as the Jubilee Gospel Team’s ""Stations Will Be Changed"" and Blind Joe & Emma Taggart’s ""I’ll Be Satisfied""
column3: there is a sense of earthly striving
column4: as though there is little difference between social and spiritual struggles. As Edward W. Clayborn
column5: self-billed as ""The Guitar Evangelist
column6: rips through ""I Shall Not Be Moved""
column7: he hints at the significance the song would later obtain
column8: as the fluidity of his picking signifies an excitement over the heavenly promise that the wrongs of this world will be made right in the next. Listening to these songs in 2014—a year when the violent loss of black lives has gone bafflingly unprosecuted—is a powerful experience: glorious because this music can speak to us across nearly a century
column9: tragic because these fears are still relevant and unresolved after so much time.

column1: As King states in his liner notes
column2: When I Reach That Heavenly Shore displays the breadth of gospel styles in pre-WWII America
column3: from the intense sermonizing of Rev. A. W. Nix to the rural acoustic blues of Mother McCollum. The differences between these styles are often obvious
column4: even if King provides no background on any particular track or performer. There are copious Bible verses to bolster the songs’ spiritual messages
column5: but there is little sense of who these people were
column6: what circumstances shaped their craft
column7: or what their larger contributions to music or ministry might have been. Anything to settle and contextualize their tracks or to humanize these artists would be helpful
column8: even just a broad discussion of trends in gospel during this particular era.

column1: One of the precepts of gospel music
column2: of course
column3: is a certain earthly anonymity: These congregations and ministers sing not to distinguish themselves
column4: but to glorify God. In this case
column5: the ""Unearthly"" in the subtitle makes a bit of sense
column6: even if it reads as weirdly mystifying and potentially erases the accomplishments of these artists. Previous Tompkins Square gospel comps have employed similarly evocative
column7: albeit highly questionable adjectives
column8: like ""raw"" and ""otherworldly."" (Using ""other"" in this context is extremely problematic
column9: as it relegates African American experience even further to the margins of what is considered the norm.) And there is nothing unearthly about Rev. Emmet Dickinson’s ""What the Men Wanted the Women Was Sitting On""
column10: a sermon that balances the sexual trickery of women with the lustful idiocy of men
column11: or Rev. J.M. Gates’ ""Dead Cat on the Line""
column12: which unspools one of the weirdest metaphors imaginable for our lack of communion with God. These are earthly messages
column13: grounded in everyday experience and nearly convinced that man is unworthy of redemption.

column1: That word ""unearthly"" resonates uncomfortably throughout
column2: as excusing the absence of historical materials. It dislocates the artistic accomplishment from the mouths of the artists and assigns it to some vague ether between Heaven and Earth. That may seem largely academic
column3: as it barely affects the immediate enjoyment of the songs collected on When I Reach That Heavenly Shore. But gospel is ultimately a music that thrives on empathy—singers communicating spiritual ecstasy to Christians and non-Christians alike. If these songs can stir a spiritual desire even in the nonbeliever
column4:
then it also ignites a desire to know more about the people recording these incredible professions of faith.

For a genre built on
column2: and named after

column4: grime also holds a certain power in its calmest moments. Before last year

column6: with a self-titled 2010 debut EP and 2012 beat-battle showstopper ""Senior Bass"" standing as early-career trophies for the producer; his ability to bump the heavy shit but shun cold-concrete aggression for bright
column7: alcopop-buzzed hyperactivity was what made him exciting. Even when he went a little overcast
column8: he did so playfully—for proof

column10: bottom-heavy synthesizer whistle. It's as potent with ""Funky Worm"" squiggle-synths as classic g-funk was.

column1: That's why Parallel Memories is surprising. Just a year ago
column2: Mitch was bumping trap-drenched
column3: hip-hop-adjacent bass-war artillery like the Suave EP. But he also made a point of countering last year's agressive
column4: grime-producer soundclash ""war dubs"" free-for-all with his own simmered-down ""Peace Edits"". Now he's breaking out with a full-length record that's more restrained
column5: more skeletal
column6: and often more mournful than anything he's done before
column7: a metamorphosis from somebody who's had fans growing to expect them on the regular. And he so regularly nails that transformative take on grime that it's tempting to assign the things he does here as a new potential signature sound. At the minimum
column8: it gives him a new tool in his kit.

column1: The wide-open hushed silences and swooning interplay between synth hooks and pared-down beats puts Parallel Memories in the neighborhood of something that could be called ""ambient grime"" if that weren't a little too pat. But the slow-burning loops
column2: distance-making reverb
column3: and glassy digital melodies are made to envelop
column4: not built to destroy. The first kick on the album doesn't show up until nearly two and a half minutes into opener ""Afternoon After""
column5: and when it does finally thump its way through warped-Minimoog swells that chirp like the offspring of harps and whistles
column6: it sounds like a bomb being dropped. That's just one bracing use of negative space
column7: and in a track more suited to scene-setting; in the cuts with more of a focus on rhythm—as busy as the plastic clatter of ""Intense Faces"" or as screwed-down as the deep-snow trudge of ""Hot Air""—the sawed-off beats hit harder for the air around them.

column1: But what's remarkable is how many different moods Mitch is able to evoke this way. Take ""Don't Leave"": it's simple—and staggeringly effective—to draw off the power of a sampled hook like he does with Blackstreet's ""Don't Leave Me""
column2: pitting virtuoso R&B vocal intensity alongside delicate
column3: wandering
column4: halting digital melodies that create deep tension with two different strains of slow-motion heartache. But the calm that masks tension also sweetens harshness
column5: like the way the subtly martial snap-thump stutter-step beats of ""Intense Faces"" shed their gloom the moment he brings in its plinky keyboard counterpoint. And even inside those juxtapositions
column6: there are different shades and detours that provoke mood swings through each loop. ""The Night"" is frayed nerves or lucid relaxation depending on the angle

column1: More than any other subgenre

column3: about placing sounds like immaculately arranged furniture in a white room. Gymnosphere
column4: in that regard

column6: the album also came with De La Sierra's 20-page hand-drawn booklet to accompany it. ""Greetings to all fellow members and space colonizers here present in this our local universe
column7: De La Sierra wrote in the liners' opening page
column8: in a decorous Hallmark script. The music within he humbly offered as ""spatial food... for our finer being bodies"" along with his instructions that portions of it be specifically listened to ""at the nexus in the diurnal-nocturnal cycle"" (presumably
column9: he meant ""twilight""). It was
column10: in every way

column1: Now Numero Group has reissued De La Sierra's Gymnosphere in its original length and with De La Sierra's original drawings lovingly intact. It's a remarkable turnabout for an album that was lost in the digital wilderness for decades. Finding information on the Internet about De La Sierra that predates last year is rough
column2: usually turning only a few tremulous queries for this ""orphaned work"" to find a new home. But recently
column3: as labels reissue more material from the period

column6: Iasos

column1: Narrating music without any legible action is a bit if a riddle

column3: recorded live in Grace Cathedral in 1977
column4: is an elusive sound
column5: at once tactile and abstract. On the one hand
column6: it's clearly a piano ringing out into a drafty cathedral
column7: muffled by room tone and tape recording
column8: and occasionally you can feel the stale breeze from the chapel pews on your face. On the other
column9: his glimmering tone feels like a trick of the light

Since the turn of the century
column2: the Smashing Pumpkins have been a promise Billy Corgan just can’t keep. MACHINA/The Machines of God had about 20 minutes of outstanding music

column5: Zeitgeist and Oceania each attempted to signify a workmanlike
column6: “back to basics” approach for a band who never did workmanlike or basic. The whine was there
column7: the riffs too

column9: so Monuments to an Elegy turns out to be his first savvy artistic move in nearly 15 years: a Smashing Pumpkins album that has no precedent whatsoever in his catalog.

column1: For one thing
column2: it is 33 minutes long. We're not talking about a mid-album triptych named after Greek goddesses or a bonus compilation available only if you preordered Monuments on iTunes—like
column3: the whole thing is barely more than a half hour. And it’s split almost equally amongst nine songs of concise
column4: gleaming alt-rock that leaves the album title as the only remnant of Corgan’s excessive tastes. Just a few months ago

column1: As a result
column2: Corgan isn’t chasing dead formats or trying to fit into playlists at radio stations that consider “Today” to be classic rock. He simply does what most de facto “alt-rock” bands do in 2014—he tries to blend in

column4: H&M
column5: or car commercials but wouldn’t be out of place if those did come to pass.

column4: he uses guitar as a tool rather than an instrument of expression as what were once riffs are now power chords

column1: Monuments is the easiest Smashing Pumpkins album

Which is why “Drum and Fife” is the most resonant thing here. As with “Cherub Rock” and “The Everlasting Gaze”

column10:
” he’s only addressing those who have been following his beat the whole time.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21294/homepage_large.2c4f36c5.jpg|A Los Campesinos! Christmas EP|5337.0|Los Campesinos!|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Turnstile'
column2:
'Heart Swells']|2014-12-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:34.867387|"

""I’ll be anything you want of me
column3: Gareth Campesinos! sings with conviction on ""A Doe to a Deer""
column4: then offers
column5: ""an angel teetering atop a tree
column6: vomiting from vertigo!"" It's not a line you expect from a Christmas song—it’s not really a line you’d expect from any song about trying to win over a lover’s heart. But its silly Debbie Downer-tone bares some truth: Christmas is a holiday full of romantic promise
column7: but it also has its sour side. This honesty comes courtesy of Los Campesinos!’s latest
column8: a six-track EP of yuletide goodness (and sadness) that brings together three holiday singles the band has released over the past few years
column9: along with two covers and a new track.

column1: The Christmas songs are chock-full of holiday imagery: deer run rampant
column2: life is lined with tinsel
column3: and baby Jesus makes a few appearances. A band that has always favored texture
column4: Los Campesinos! make these songs brassy and jangling in all the right places—their love affair with the glockenspiel is right at home. And throughout the record
column5: the band conveys the typical holiday mix of Christmas emotions: sentimentalism
column6: desperation
column7: and loneliness. If George Michael is giving his heart to someone special
column8: lead singer and songwriter Gareth is bitterly trying to force his heart back upon whoever initially tossed it.

column1: Sometimes the band tackles these feelings with a welcome smirk. ""A Doe to a Deer""
column2: here in a shinier version than the one they released back in 2012
column3: is a cheeky
column4: dramatic proclamation of love
column5: one that has Gareth shape-shifting into everything from annoying sleet to security footage of a drunk Santa at the mall. Then there’s the equally impassioned ""Kindle a Flame in Her Heart""
column6: with a resilient Gareth greedily swallowing coal and begging to be swaddled in his lovers’ arms.

column1: These holiday songs are neither sad-sack nor hyper-cheerful; they'd find good company next to the Waitresses’ ""Christmas Wrapping"" or even the Kinks’ ""Father Christmas"" in their mix of cynicism and traditional Christmas narrative. The holiday music landscape could stand to lose a few of the retro covers and pile on a little more bleakness and humor. Gareth’s songwriting has always excelled in the dark arts of self-deprecation and crucifying exes
column2: and hearing it in this setting is like sitting next to a sarcastic teenage cousin at the Christmas dinner table—refreshing
column3: albeit unconventional.

column1: But even when Los Campesinos! aren’t getting overtly snarky
column2: the melancholy woven throughout the album makes for beautiful Christmas music in a more familiar sense
column3: from the soulful rendition of Mud’s ""Lonely This Christmas"" to ""The Trains Don’t Run (It’s Christmas Day)"". A folksy cover of the old British carol ""The Holly & the Ivy""
column4: which features Rob Taylor on vocals
column5: sounds out of place on the album
column6: but that's understandable given that it was once released on its own. As a standalone track
column7: it’s gorgeous
column8: but it’s also a testament to how well the Los Campesinos! angst works in this context.

column1: Christmas can sometimes be an incubator for loneliness
column2: magnifying the distance between families
column3: friends
column4:
and partners. This is a holiday that makes people kiss if they’re caught standing under a plant; people really want romance to thrive. A Los Campesinos! Christmas is a record for those who want to spin a seasonal record that's both crushingly isolated and humorously self-aware.

"|20031.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20031-a-los-campesinos-christmas-ep/|7.5|Hazel Cills

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21303/homepage_large.de171f69.jpg|12|4001.0|Supersilent|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rune Grammofon']|2014-12-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:35.437560|"

Supersilent is a band built around a singular vision of improvised music without ego. The group hasn’t been very active lately—the recordings that comprise 12 were all made in 2011—but they were also never a conventional band in the first place
column2: meeting only to perform completely improvised pieces together and never discussing their music before or after playing it. Albums are named numerically in sequence
column3: and the tracks are named the same way. If you follow Norway’s improvised music and avant garde scenes
column4: you likely know the work of Helge Sten
column5: who records on his own as Deathprod and has produced Jenny Hval and Jaga Jazzist
column6: Arve Henriksen
column7: who records as a solo artist and session musician
column8: and Ståle Storløkken
column9: who has played with Terje Rypdal among many others. In Supersilent
column10: though
column11: the three musicians work assiduously to efface their usual identities
column12: collectively creating music that defies easy categorization.

column1: 12
column2: their twelfth album as the title implies
column3: is no exception. It is at times intensely beautiful
column4: playing like a soundtrack to footage of the frozen surface of Europa
column5: but more often exudes a creepy
column6: ashen vibe
column7: as if the mission to Europa had gone just slightly wrong
column8: leaving no way for the survivors to escape an alien world. More aggressively abstract and unsettling than most of their previous work
column9: it nevertheless has a compelling shape
column10: leaving the ice fields of its outer thirds for a place no less strange but more active. Storløkken’s keyboards and Henriksen’s trumpet rise out of the churning textures to become recognizable for fleeting moments
column11: and it becomes clear just how much of that foreboding texture that greets you at the beginning of the LP is trumpet
column12: stretched and smeared to a point where it surrenders its identity and merges with the electronics.

column1: Direct reference points for this music are hard to come by. Pink Floyd’s most consciously out music
column2: Iannis Xenakis’ Metastaseis
column3: Ash Ra Tempel’s Schwingungen
column4: Ligeti’s work with tone clusters
column5: and Tangerine Dream’s Atem all operate in similar sonic territory
column6: but Supersilent arrive there from a completely different direction. Whether they’re focused on a cavernous
column7: gravelly drone or subsuming a nascent melody under a scraping wall of electronics
column8:
the results are spellbinding and make for a unique entry in the band’s already deep discography.

"|20037.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20037-supersilent-12/|7.8|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21306/homepage_large.580e1d52.jpg|Teenage Retirement|32648.0|Chumped|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anchorless']|2014-12-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:36.384213|"

The most successful pop music has a certain magic oomph. It can appear as a well-placed bridge
column2: or a godlike key change (or many)
column3: or an impossible note belted at a song's climax that sends an involuntary chill down your spine. Science says it's hidden in an ornamental note called an appoggiatura
column4: but for these purposes let's just call it auditory umami: that moment in a song that makes your feelings explode
column5: whether you want them to or not. We hear it most often in populist genres
column6: where songwriters compose specifically to hook the largest amount of people possible
column7: and sometimes it's employed in bad faith (see: the Lumineers). But nowhere has it been more effective than in pop punk.

column1: Brooklyn quartet Chumped is hot on the heels of this elusive sound. Their debut LP
column2: Teenage Retirement
column3: is no <i>A Mark
column4: A Mission
column5: A Brand
column6: A Scar (perhaps thankfully so)
column7: but it often finds that melodramatic sweet spot that made emo and pop punk hit so hard in the '90s and '00s. Synthesizing the aesthetic developed over the past few years by DIY pop-punk revivalists like Columbus's All Dogs with the soaring instrumental prowess and energy of the old guard
column8: Teenage Retirement
column9: at its best
column10: sounds like a new evolutionary stage of the genre.

column1: Structurally
column2: Chumped is working with a wide array of influences. There are times when their licks wax Weezeresque
column3: like on ""Hot 97 Summer Jam"" and ""Anywhere But Here""
column4: and the cleverly titled ""Novella Ella Ella Eh"" is essentially ""Don't Speak"" on uppers. On ""Coffee""
column5: bassist Doug McKeever takes the mic for a self-lacerating turn that could easily be mistaken for Swearin's Kyle Gilbride (see: ""Crashing""). And in several instances (""Long Division"") they channel Aye Nako's measured confessional
column6: spinning it upwards into a gloriously bitter bridge—""I hope wherever you end up it makes you happy/ And when you're ready come and find me I'll be waiting""—worthy of the great emo umami (emami?) gourmands
column7: from Matchbook Romance to Jimmy Eat World.

column1: The record does get caught in a few of the traps that separate the remembered from the forgotten in pop punk. Songs like ""Long Division"" and album opener ""December Is the Longest Month"" are handicapped by seemingly arbitrary melodies or half-heartedly structured verses; others sometimes spend half their length getting to their catchiest
column2: tightest musical phrasings. At times
column3: Teenage Retirement can feel like trying to scratch an itch millimeters beyond your grasp
column4: because it's obvious Chumped knows what they're doing
column5: or at least are 90 percent of the way there. Instrumentally
column6: they succeed in spades
column7: hitting angsty guitar-solo sweet spots again and again
column8: the ones that make you shout
column9: ""YES!"" in your car
column10: punching the gas as you're speeding down the highway.

column1: The grown-up punks walk the line between the immature self-obsession that drove white suburban boy bands to their best apoplectic histrionics and the more graceful
column2: articulate adulthood that characterizes the genre's more contemporary potency. Take the empathetic
column3: soaring elegance of ""Old and Tired""
column4: a comforting song about age and loneliness whittling down a loved one's spirits: it's more elegant and meaningful a statement than anything Jesse Lacey ever howled
column5: and it's delivered in just as powerful a package.

column1: When they align themselves with pop punk's present
column2: however
column3: Chumped also lean away from the elements that turned an earlier generation's entitled complaints into pure gold: tight
column4: slick
column5: almost stupidly indulgent pop songwriting
column6: completely littered with auditory umami. Not every DIY outfit in Brooklyn has the ability to write these kinds of songs
column7: but Chumped
column8: when they hammer it down and let it rip
column9: can pull it off. Purists may argue that it's this sickly sweetness that led to the end the genre's first era
column10: but in today's overflowing indie milieu
column11: melody and structure are what mark an album as exceptional. There are real possibilities buried here
column12: just below the surface
column13:
and Chumped might produce greatness if they can dig them up.

"|20040.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20040-teenage-retirement/|7.3|Devon Maloney

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20972/homepage_large.0355dcee.jpg|The Ape of God|30452.0|Old Man Gloom|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore'
column3: assholes
column4: began a Facebook post from the sporadic metal supergroup Old Man Gloom in early November
column5: five days before the release of what was presumed to be their sixth record. ""The Ape Of God is two entirely different albums. If you downloaded some leaked shit
column6: you don’t have either.""

column1: Working in cahoots with their new label
column2: Profound Lore Records
column3: Old Man Gloom had circulated an eight-track
column4: 46-minute promotional download called The Ape of God
column5: portraying it as their second release since ending an eight-year hiatus two years earlier. Reviews appeared
column6: followed
column7: as the band predicted
column8: by back-channel leaks. That’s when Old Man Gloom announced that the version many might have swiped was a carefully edited combination of two albums sharing one name. The bait had been stripped of essential interludes and lengthier pieces. Both records
column9: the band said
column10: would arrive on their proper release date. ""The interweb has sucked all the fun out of releasing records and we wanted people to be fucking surprised by something again
column11: Aaron Turner subsequently told The Quietus. ""At least we tried.""

column1: In one rather isolated online corner
column2: a flood of vitriol
column3: kudos
column4: and schadenfreude began. Some fans praised the ruse’s ingenious simplicity. Others called Old Man Gloom ""douchebags
column5: ""fascist pricks
column6: and ""clowns
column7: or pointed out that bogus promos meant to hoodwink critics and pirates weren’t as novel as the band might have hoped. Reviewers who had already invested time in the album’s early edition <a href=""http://www.decibelmagazine.com/featured/sucker-for-punishment-grand-and-morbid/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">complained
column8: somewhat legitimately
column9: that they’d been cheated of their time while trying to do their jobs—that is
column10: many suffered for the sins of a few. But the duplicitous release should have come as
column11: at worst
column12: only a slight shock; after all
column13: what have Old Man Gloom done for the last 15 years but try to troll would-be fans? From the way they delivered The Ape of God to the fastidious and belligerent mess the dual albums themselves deliver
column14: these 12 tracks are the most perfectly provocative Old Man Gloom have ever been.

column1: When they’ve existed at all
column2: Old Man Gloom have thrived in a state of concrete fluidity. Each of their albums has been its own gyre of heavy elements
column3: tumbling d-beat and doom
column4: harsh noise and hardcore
column5: stoner rock and psychedelic rock into exuberant if sometimes uneven anti-patterns. A mix of audacity and devil-may-care enthusiasm powered their earlier records; during the first three tracks of 2004’s Christmas
column6: for instance
column7: they moved from a near-collage of Neurosis and Pink Floyd to a grindcore outburst to an alien instrumental reverie that suggested a punk rocker’s take on the early tape works of Gordon Mumma. Somehow
column8: it worked. It’s as if the parents of the members—Turner
column9: Converge’s Nate Newton
column10: Cave In’s Caleb Scofield
column11: versatile drummer Santos Mantano—told the kids they could be anything they wanted to be when they grew up
column12: and that the quartet continues to hold that assurance as safe as scripture. Old Man Gloom’s boastful inability to make up their collective mind about what kind of band they are makes them incredibly divisive. They are either adored or reviled. That seems to be the way they prefer it
column13: anyway.

column1: The Ape of God thrills with that indecision
column2: amplifying it through two albums that act as clashing
column3: fraternal twins. The first set is the most streamlined Old Man Gloom effort to date
column4: as the band moves through eight songs in 43 minutes. Hardcore bruiser ""Fist of Fury"" is aggression couched in antiphony
column5: with the band bounding into straightforward pounce only to stop in perfect time for screams barked over beds of near-silence. ""Never Enter"" delivers the kind of jubilant
column6: anthemic agitation that served as Fucked Up’s early calling card
column7: while opener ""Eden’s Gates"" peaks in a fists-up
column8: sludge-metal sing-along that seems to have crept north from the same bayou as Eyehategod or Down. But even the straightest bits here are demented and warped. That pummel of ""Fist of Fury"" arrives over an organ-and-guitar drone that only grows louder. And the two minutes of radical
column9: mean post-punk that form the core of ""The Lash"" follow nearly five minutes of full-band improvisation
column10: where Old Man Gloom seem to be fighting the symptoms of dying equipment. Its din emerges from the end of ""Simia Die""
column11: a wordless anthem that condenses the power and poignancy of post-metal into a tune that takes a third of the time Pelican or Turner’s old Isis would need to reach such heights. They do that by suspending the motion of a burly riff
column12: walloping beat and celestial choir until one definitive
column13: romantic crescendo arrives. It’s perhaps Old Man Gloom’s best-ever rendezvous of impact and economy
column14: a union generally not favored by such indulgent explorers.

column1: That’s the side of Old Man Gloom that arrives unfettered for the second set. The bulk of the disc was omitted from the more concise promotional tease; perhaps not coincidentally
column2: it’s the half that renders The Ape of God essential. Everything that’s ever made Old Man Gloom captivating collides in these four tracks and 47 minutes. ""A Hideous Nightmare Lie Upon the World"" moves from a whirlpool of distortion and disembodied vocals into a tide of turgid doom. Scofield’s bass line is a menace
column3: rebelling against Montano’s drumset like an angry stepchild; Newton and Turner’s guitars twist in and out of feedback-and-effects tangles
column4: flipping between militant riffs and anarchist bedlam. Both ""Predators"" and ""Arrows to Our Hearts"" find Old Man Gloom playing hide-and-seek with the cores of their own songs
column5: dividing the action between blown-out instrumental tangents and delightful detours. All Old Man Gloom albums have functioned in much that same way
column6: but here
column7: they mete the misdirection with new momentum. That is
column8: though some of these songs last 14 minutes
column9: they lag very little between start and finish.

column1: There’s no better example
column2: and no better moment on any Old Man Gloom album
column3: than ""Burden""
column4: which opens set two. At large
column5: it’s a punishing doom march
column6: an unafraid parade toward an ever-widening abyss. But the quartet takes its time getting into formation
column7: tinkering first with punishing feedback
column8: static bursts
column9: and riffs that seem to lampoon what’s coming next. For a work that lasts as long as many major motion pictures
column10: The Ape of God mostly avoids monoliths
column11: a consequence of Old Man Gloom’s varied interests. ""Burden"" is their one concession to the colossal. Extrapolated brilliantly for a quarter-hour
column12: it’s a coup of force and focus.

column1: Old Man Gloom revel in the disorienting. As early as their debut
column2: they spotted unseen through-lines between disparate musical realms and raced along them. That very approach has made them a hard sale
column3: because quantifying
column4: categorizing
column5: or controlling what they hoped to achieve seemed so difficult. But the context for their brand of ruthless patchwork has increased in recent years
column6: as the borders of once-obdurate niches and subgenres have been bled. Old Man Gloom sound a little less outlandish than they once did
column7: then
column8: less like separatists in a stronghold of one than early adopters in a land of intrigue and opportunity. Following the band’s 2012 return with the fine but slight NO
column9: The Ape of God—in all its two-volume
column10: high-volume upheaval—reasserts their eminence in that field. And guess what
column11: assholes? They didn’t need two albums to do it
column12:
but it’s hard to resent such brittle riches.

"|19744.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19744-the-ape-of-god/|8.3|Grayson Haver Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21295/homepage_large.7c529025.jpg|Nerve Net|526.0|Brian Eno|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['All Saints']|2014-12-05 00:00:00|1992|2016-06-11 16:16:38.079072|"

Brian Eno had a very busy decade in the 1990s. He worked on U2's Achtung Baby and Zooropa
column2: James' Laid
column3: David Bowie's Outside
column4: and innumerable other records by musicians from around the world. He scored Neil Gaiman's TV series Neverwhere. He wrote the fascinating diary published as A Year with Swollen Appendices. He published the fourth edition of his brilliant card deck of ""worthwhile dilemmas
column5: Oblique Strategies. And
column6: of course
column7: he recorded his greatest hit
column8: one of the most-played compositions of all time: the Windows 95 startup tone.

column1: Somewhere in there
column2: he also released the four solo albums that have now been reissued in expanded editions
column3: with an extra CD appended to each. Well
column4: four and a half: in 1991
column5: My Squelchy Life
column6: his first song-based solo album since 1978's Before and After Science
column7: made it as far as advance promotional cassettes. Then
column8: as he told Audio magazine a few years later
column9: he found out that the album was being pushed back from September to February
column10: and decided to withdraw it and replace it with a newer recording that was more on ""the cutting edge... my feeling is that things don't come with intrinsic and timeless value. Where you place them in time
column11: the context they fall in
column12: is what charges them.""

column1: The album that replaced My Squelchy Life in the context of 1992 was Nerve Net
column2: which is more obviously a product of its time than any other Eno record. It's roughly half-vocal
column3: half-instrumental
column4: and half-baked. The vocals are generally not Eno's
column5: and mostly spoken; the instrumental tone is cold and brittle (although a couple of Robert Fripp guitar solos briefly light a fire on its surface); the synthesizer tones are the presets of their moment. ""Ali Click"" even interpolates the ""Ashley's Roachclip"" break made famous by Milli Vanilli
column6: as well as some iffy rapping. Also iffy: ""What Actually Happened?""
column7: a Vocoder-distorted discussion of a rape
column8: paired with a forceful beat. The album's home stretch features two consecutive mixes of the not-up-to-much instrumental ""Web""
column9: totaling over 15 tedious minutes.

column1: The bonus disc on the reissue
column2: though
column3: is its real draw: My Squelchy Life
column4: Eno's most enjoyable solo album of the '90s by a wide margin. It's only ""retrospective"" (as he dismissed it) in the sense that it plays to some of the strengths he'd demonstrated earlier in his career
column5: like songwriting and singing. (A couple of its songs were re-edited for Nerve Net
column6: and most of the rest were parceled out on one release or another over the next few years; this is the first time it's all officially appeared in one place.) Its opening tracks
column7: the dissonant stomp ""I Fall Up"" (""I'm sucking the juice from the generator! More volts!!"") and the slow churn ""The Harness""
column8: are the proclamations of the King of the Weirdos come home to rule again
column9: and for every failed experiment like ""Tutti Forgetti"" there's a delightful throwaway like ""Stiff"".

column1: The 10 rhythmless
column2: tuneless pieces that make up The Shutov Assembly
column3: also released in 1992 but recorded between 1985 and 1990
column4: are named after places where Eno had done image-and-sound installations—although presenting them outside those contexts also depleted whatever charge they might have had. Eno later described them as sketches for orchestral works: electronically generated tones that acoustic instruments were meant to somehow replicate. They are whooshy
column5: and evaporate as soon as they're over. The bonus disc is seven more pieces from the same era
column6: in the same amorphous vein
column7: although a few of them have some sort of beat; ""Storm"" even incorporates what sounds like another Fripp guitar solo.

column1: Eno likes to talk about his interest in perfume
column2: and a scent provided the title of the hour-long
column3: single-track 1993 album Neroli (although he'd already released a four-minute edit of the same piece as ""Constant Dreams"" on the 1989 album Textures). At the time
column4: it might have been a riposte to the low-key dance tracks that were being fobbed off as ""ambient"": as the person who'd more or less invented ambient music
column5: Eno knew well that the point of ambience is that it's just barely perceptible. But the softly echoing pings and plinks of ""Neroli"" are instantly overfamiliar; without the famous name on the cover
column6: no one would have given it a second thought. The new reissue pairs it with a previously unreleased hour-long drone piece from 1992
column7: ""New Space Music""
column8: which mostly suggests that Eno had figured out how to hold down keys for a really long time.

column1: 1997's The Drop is a set of mostly brief instrumentals—and one very long one
column2: ""Iced World""—in a style Eno referred to as ""Unwelcome Jazz"" (because
column3: he explained
column4: ""most of the people I played them to don't really like them""). They're semi-abstract or ""generative"" electronic pieces
column5: made with instrumental sounds that already have cultural associations
column6: like piano
column7: early-hip-hop drum machines
column8: and
column9: on ""Dear World
column10: samples of Eno's own voice. It's not uninteresting to hear once. The extra disc here is a set of The Drop's outtakes and alternate versions
column11: originally sold as a limited edition at a Tokyo exhibition of Eno's ""77 Million Paintings"".

column1: Eno subsequently recorded a string of limited-edition soundtracks to installation pieces
column2: but his next solo album to see wide release would be 2005's Another Day on Earth. It included the same version of the lovely
column3:
slowly pulsing ""Under"" that had originally been intended to appear on My Squelchy Life—a song whose ""retrospective"" character had apparently worn off in the intervening 14 years.

Brian Eno had a very busy decade in the 1990s. He worked on U2's Achtung Baby and Zooropa
column2: James' Laid
column3: David Bowie's Outside
column4: and innumerable other records by musicians from around the world. He scored Neil Gaiman's TV series Neverwhere. He wrote the fascinating diary published as A Year with Swollen Appendices. He published the fourth edition of his brilliant card deck of ""worthwhile dilemmas
column5: Oblique Strategies. And
column6: of course
column7: he recorded his greatest hit
column8: one of the most-played compositions of all time: the Windows 95 startup tone.

column1: Somewhere in there
column2: he also released the four solo albums that have now been reissued in expanded editions
column3: with an extra CD appended to each. Well
column4: four and a half: in 1991
column5: My Squelchy Life
column6: his first song-based solo album since 1978's Before and After Science
column7: made it as far as advance promotional cassettes. Then
column8: as he told Audio magazine a few years later
column9: he found out that the album was being pushed back from September to February
column10: and decided to withdraw it and replace it with a newer recording that was more on ""the cutting edge... my feeling is that things don't come with intrinsic and timeless value. Where you place them in time
column11: the context they fall in
column12: is what charges them.""

column1: The album that replaced My Squelchy Life in the context of 1992 was Nerve Net
column2: which is more obviously a product of its time than any other Eno record. It's roughly half-vocal
column3: half-instrumental
column4: and half-baked. The vocals are generally not Eno's
column5: and mostly spoken; the instrumental tone is cold and brittle (although a couple of Robert Fripp guitar solos briefly light a fire on its surface); the synthesizer tones are the presets of their moment. ""Ali Click"" even interpolates the ""Ashley's Roachclip"" break made famous by Milli Vanilli
column6: as well as some iffy rapping. Also iffy: ""What Actually Happened?""
column7: a Vocoder-distorted discussion of a rape
column8: paired with a forceful beat. The album's home stretch features two consecutive mixes of the not-up-to-much instrumental ""Web""
column9: totaling over 15 tedious minutes.

column1: The bonus disc on the reissue
column2: though
column3: is its real draw: My Squelchy Life
column4: Eno's most enjoyable solo album of the '90s by a wide margin. It's only ""retrospective"" (as he dismissed it) in the sense that it plays to some of the strengths he'd demonstrated earlier in his career
column5: like songwriting and singing. (A couple of its songs were re-edited for Nerve Net
