column2:
It's Time to Return|1503.0|Flake Music|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-12-05 00:00:00|1997|2016-06-11 16:16:38.748401|"

There are two Broken Bells albums out there
column3: so hearing James Mercer make dull music isn’t the novelty it used to be. Fortunately
column4: that’s not what we’re promised on <i>When You Land Here
column5: It’s Time to Return. Flake Music’s only full-length LP
column6: originally released in 1997
column7: didn’t hit the same high marks of Mercer’s subsequent work with the Shins
column8: nor did it really sound like it aspired to. But unlike the discofied dross of his collaboration with Danger Mouse
column9: Mercer’s earlier band’s inability to offer the same pleasures as his more famous group offers something charming in return. Namely
column10: the sound of potential unfulfilled—the retroactive promise that the people involved here were headed towards something great.

column1: Flake Music get tantalizingly close on ""Spanway Hits""
column2: the song where you can most cleanly separate the qualities that would become definitive artistic tics in the future—even more than the thing here that’s actually called ""The Shins"". Over 15 years after the fact
column3: it’s hard to hear it as the work of anyone else; beyond Mercer’s piercing tone which distinguished him from more mumbly peers
column4: there’s still the slight gap between his vocals and the wonderful melodies he writes for them. It lends an appealing degree of human error in his exquisite craftsmanship and he decorates these songs like ornate dioramas
column5: both compact and highly detailed.  There’s a directness on ""Spanway Hits"" that Mercer would later forego—it’s a youthful reminiscence of Big Wheels in the driveway and a poster of Simon LeBon in the bedroom
column6: and how little they eventually mean—""Cut these ties and you’ll see how far apart we are."" This also hints at the subtle bitterness that would seep into the Shins’ Chutes Too Narrow in particular
column7: though the poison is more potent here (""You’ve got the words to defend/ every bias you’ve learned while being human""). Is it on par with any of the songs on <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/7113-oh-inverted-world/""><i>Oh
column8: Inverted World? That’s a matter of taste. Would it fit on Oh
column9: Inverted World?

column1: Not at all
column2: as ""Spanway Hits"" is also the song that most clearly demonstrates what separates Flake Music from the Shins
column3: which is the real
column4: weird divide between ""indie rock"" and ""indie pop"" that becomes more apparent as When You Land Here levels out after its initial peak. While the earliest incarnation of the Shins had basically the same lineup as Flake Music
column5: the major shift was Mercer taking full command of the lyrics. It was not long before the Shins were revealed as more or less him. But from the outset
column6: they had a singular aesthetic
column7: more sourced from the bedroom than the garage—Oh
column8: Inverted World was the next to take the baton in the soft parade of Elliott Smith
column9: the Elephant 6 collective
column10: Belle and Sebastian
column11: and other songwriters who weren’t opposed to copping from Simon & Garfunkel. There was not a single edge to it
column12: and while there were guitars
column13: bass and drums
column14: they never once rocked.

column1: Conversely
column2: Flake Music is Mercer’s pimpled and angry record collector from ""Know Your Onion!"" in real time
column3: and When You Land Here functions as a state-of-the-art indie rock mixtape where he’s the curator rather than just an inclusion. Seeing as how Mercer and Beirut’s Zach Condon are the only rock musicians of note to ever come from New Mexico
column4: one doubts there was ever an ""Albuquerque sound."" So inevitably
column5: Flake Music reached out in all directions to establish their neighbors
column6: becoming de facto Californians and residents of the Pacific Northwest.

column1: As with most guitar bands in the late '90s
column2: they’re in the shadow of Pavement and Mercer’s lyrics can often crib from Stephen Malkmus’ coding system for legible thoughts and feelings. Relying more on lyrical guitar leads than percussive strumming
column3: ""Mieke"" (which was later included in Shins live sets) and ""Blast Valve"" owe a huge debt to pre-Perfect From Now On Built to Spill
column4: albeit with a much higher ratio of twee meekness to heroism. It’s for the best
column5: as the most jarring moment occurs when Mercer stomps on the fuzz pedals for the chorus of ""Structo"" and pissily enunciates the words ""high school"". Meanwhile
column6: if Sub Pop had released When You Land Here in 1997
column7: the fractious rhythms of ""Deluca"" might have tipped them as a passable scion of Sunny Day Real Estate.

column1: It’s all delightful in a scattershot way that betrays the fact that Flake Music had been around for five years at that point. But as with every reissue
column2: the intent seems to be as much of a subject for appraisal as the content. When You Land Here isn’t widely considered a lost classic or ahead of its time
column3: or really much beyond a very good album serving as a reminder of what indie rock sounded like in 1997. With all that said
column4: it’s now been reissued twice. The first time can actually remind you of when reissues were a protracted decision that required balancing financial risk and reward. <i>Oh
column5: Inverted World was a rainmaker for Sub Pop after an unsteady few years and while Flake Music may have been dutifully namechecked in reviews
column6: there’s a good shot that new Shins fans hadn’t heard of them and were unlikely to find the original Omnibus release in stores.

column1: While the Shins are celebrating their fifteenth year of existence
column2: none of their albums nor When You Land Here is celebrating a round number anniversary
column3: which is usually the only requirement for reissue. That said
column4: even if you’ve somehow owned this record twice already
column5: the 2014 version ensures you get something out of this. Both the new artwork and the production do the best job possible of removing everything timestamped from 1997. Kennie Takahashi and J.J. Golden’s respective remix and remaster ensure it has some of the gleam and pop of Broken Bells
column6: though they still maintain the vocal filters and grainy guitars whose subsequent absence made the Shins sound so novel. They’re not the only vestiges of a time when Mercer and company erred towards indie’s defense mechanisms. When You Land Here is a short record as is
column7: one that shrinks even more due to a couple of early instrumental scribblings that level off momentum rather than establishing continuity
column8: to say nothing of ""Vantage""
column9: a five-minute guitar workout that should be closing out a record of other shambling
column10: five-minute guitar workouts.

column1: That might not sound like much of an endorsement for the people who may have actually caught those shows Flake Music did with Califone or Modest Mouse back when they were both merely up-and-coming indie rock curiosities. But consider that an 18-year old who’s just discovering the Shins right now was six last time When You Land Here was in stores. And most of those stores have probably closed down by now. Or maybe think of it this way: here we are making our year-end lists with some kind of assumption that we’re creating a time capsule of what mattered and what it foretold for the future. In doing so
column2: take a second to think about the records you came across this year that seemed promising
column3: pretty good or ""not quite there"" and a couple of years from now
column4: there’s a good chance they’ll be revealed as a transition towards greatness. It happens all the damn time and while When You Land Here is a fine reminder of a bygone time in indie rock
column5:
its current status is also a reminder of our inability to predict the future.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21202/homepage_large.0e65a665.jpg|Minoans|29981.0|Giant Squid|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Translation Loss']|2014-12-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:39.343113|"

Giant Squid aren't musicians so much as they are veritable deep-sea divers. Over the course of 10 years
column2: three albums
column3: and three EPs
column4: the Bay Area quintet have engulfed themselves in anemones
column5: swum through Cenotes
column6: and conducted thorough musical studies of aquatic organisms. Considering that Earthly life started as great big bowl of primordial soup
column7: it isn’t difficult to see how a progressive metal band would take up an oceanographic interest. Mastodon's thunderous Leviathan springs to mind: a portrait of the sea as a sublime force
column8: engulfing our experiences in life and death and salt. But whereas Mastodon briefly dipped their toes in the water and proceeded to shift their focus elsewhere
column9: Giant Squid have remained entrenched in the depths with sea creatures as their muses
column10: crafting concept album after palatial concept album. Their latest long-play
column11: Minoans
column12: details the tragic story of a fatal struggle between man and the sea—and the figurative and literal empires lost in the chaos.

column1: Minoans centers around the Bronze Age civilization of the same name
column2: which flourished on the island of Crete beginning around 2700 to 1450 BCE before coming to a sudden
column3: mysterious end (potential culprits identified by historians include a volcanic eruption on nearby Santorini
column4: recurring tsunamis and earthquakes
column5: and internal political turmoil). The Minoans are widely regarded as the inspiration for the legend of Atlantis
column6: and by extension
column7: the original overseers of the archetypal ""lost world""—and since so many questions remain
column8: their narrative leaves plenty of room for interpretation. The aforementioned cataclysms serve as landmarks on the album
column9: as well as apexes of narrative and musical tension. There's the looming ""Thera""
column10: so named for Santorini’s deadly volcano
column11: as well as a playful ode to the ""Sixty Foot Waves"" that lashed the shoreline.

column1: Despite their dedicated study of ancient lore
column2: Giant Squid skew modern in their instrumental preferences
column3: opting for quaking electric guitars and brittle synths over lyre or cithara. Most of the momentum is supplied by Zack Farwell’s restrained drumming
column4: showcased prominently in his work with the similarly forlorn Grayceon. His calculated pauses are subsequently filled in by multilayered vocal harmonies and the leathery whispers of Jackie Perez Gratz’s cello
column5: with the occasional opulent synth part. Such an airy approach allows Giant Squid to freely coast between hymnal ballads (""The Pearl and the Parthenon""
column6: ""Palace of Knossos"") and hard rock (the manic
column7: constantly-morphing ""Sixty Foot Waves"") on a melancholic drift
column8: often within the span of a single song.

column1: For those who desire immediate thrills
column2: such a carefully-dosed approach to tension could scan unsavorily—and indeed
column3: Minoans' sedate pace won't do much to sway listeners with a disdain for post-metal. There are certainly bursts of immediacy: the leaden thump of ""Mycineans""
column4: the proggy trappings of ""Sixty Foot Waves""
column5: and the mesmerizing ""Sir Arthur Evans""
column6: which welds doomy stylings to Dorian frameworks. Still
column7: like their namesake animal
column8: Giant Squid prefers to kill by elegance and discipline
column9: as opposed to throwing a tantrum like Leviathan's Moby Dick. Consider it a show of cathartic self-control
column10: as well as a nod to the cumulative nature of albums past.

column1: Why revisit ancient Cretean history two thousand years after the fact? Consider the words of the American writer and philosopher Will Durant
column2: who responded to the discovery of Minoan civilization in the early 20th century by referring to it as ""the first link in the European chain."" The early trappings of western civilization (and by extension
column3: western music) were in cities on the sea
column4:
making Giant Squid's latest bout of spelunking all the more mysterious—and perhaps even a little bit meta.

"|19951.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19951-minoans/|7.1|Zoe Camp

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21276/homepage_large.ffae07b2.jpg|I'm in Your Mind Fuzz|32633.0|King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Heavenly'
column2: 'Castle Face'
column3:
'Flightless']|2014-12-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:40.770359|"

When a band hits the stage with more than five members
column4: you're looking at something that's bound to be either a spectacle or a complete fiasco. Sure
column5: the history of popular music is full of excellent bands with unwieldily large lineups (Funkadelic
column6: Talking Heads on Stop Making Sense). Sometimes
column7: it's just a mess (various jam
column8: nu-metal
column9: and high school talent show bands). King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard are a seven-person band from Australia who specialize in unpredictable psychedelic music. Their ranks include two drummers
column10: three guitarists
column11: and a harmonica player. To reiterate: They're a septet with a name that sounds like it could've been ripped from ""Masters of the Universe"" who make heady soundscapes punctuated by blues harp.

column1: Ridiculous as this all sounds on paper
column2: King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard aren't wasting anyone's time with throwaway joke music. While they started as a side-project (following in the great Australian tradition where each member plays in other groups) and self-admitted ""joke band""
column3: the Melbourne band have definitely paid their dues over the past four years with critically acclaimed live sets and a prolific string of records. I'm in Your Mind Fuzz is their fifth album to date
column4: and if their discography tells a story
column5: it's one of a band who never fully settle into one sound. Their album Oddments from earlier this year featured flashes of bubblegum pop and Hammond organ-led soul. On their debut album 12 Bar Bruise
column6: they invoked Oblivians-style garage punk. It's never clear from the outset exactly which path they'll explore or what sounds they'll plop into the mix along the way. Horses neighing
column7: xylophones
column8: and instruments of unidentifiable origins have appeared in their songs
column9: and impressively
column10: King Gizzard always manage to wrangle the chaos into well-crafted compositions.

column1: As usual
column2: the band's latest collection
column3: I'm in Your Mind Fuzz
column4: partially recorded at Daptone in Brooklyn
column5: isn't easily categorized. While the blues feels like an inevitable touchstone thanks to Ambrose Kenny-Smith's harmonica (disorienting as it sounds when caked in psychedelic effects)
column6: it's also got the psych pop jaunt of the Millennium. But as varied as King Gizzard are
column7: they've established one surefire safe bet with each record: They implement their ""more is more"" approach for maximum impact. Their songs are dense
column8: intricately crafted
column9: and most importantly
column10: powerful. It's appropriate that Mind Fuzz is out via Castle Face (in North America—Heavenly's got it out in Europe and Flightless once again have them covered in Australia)
column11: as the 17-minute ripper ""Am I in Heaven?"" is arguably the best Thee Oh Sees track to be released in 2014. There are easy comparisons to be drawn between the two bands—Stu Mackenzie lets out a point-perfect John Dwyer ""WOO"" before employing explosive
column12: rapidfire guitar lines. And like their label overlords

column1: The album's overall lyrical concept is mind control. If they've managed to brainwash their listeners
column2: they've done it by making a record that's hard to tune out. Take
column3: for example
column4: I'm in Your Mind Fuzz's absolute peak—the opening 12-minute chunk comprising the four song stretch of ""I'm in Your Mind"" to ""I'm in Your Mind Fuzz"". They churn and choogle relentlessly forward
column5: each rafter-reaching jam bleeding into the next. The rhythm section—bassist Lucas Skinner
column6: drummers Michael Cavanagh and Eric Moore—stay locked in the same groove across all four songs while the guitars
column7: harmonica
column8: and Mackenzie's vocals explore various melodies within that structure—different movements operating in the same theme.

column1: But a steady stream of bangers comes at a price. When you open with a sprint
column2: things eventually have to slow down
column3: and the comedown is right where King Gizzard trip up. Immediately following the all-power introduction are a pair of tracks (""Empty"" and ""Hot Water"") that sound like watered-down versions of what came before them. They make the save later
column4: though
column5: closing the album with some of their best slow jams. (Two of which are titled ""Slow Jam"".) And
column6: right when it seems that they've settled into a restrained groove
column7: they shake it up again: the speed picks up
column8: guitar solos are delivered
column9:
vocals are augmented and distorted. King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard don't do predictability.

Anonymity can be a kind of calling card
column2: and in electronic music

column4: in part
column5: by hiding their identities
column6: at least at first; just think of John Talabot
column7: or Redshape
column8: or Burial. The popularity of that strategy
column9: in recent years
column10: has dovetailed with a design philosophy that emphasizes mystery over clarity. In certain record stores
column11: it sometimes seems that the hand-stamped white labels with little or no identifying information outnumber
column12: by a considerable margin
column13: what I guess you could call ""normal"" records
column14: where you have some semblance of an idea who made the thing. Underground techno
column15: in particular
column16: has developed a conspicuously sub-rosa aura
column17: keen to convey the impression that all those slabs of wax had been recorded in secret
column18: pressed up in some dank basement
column19: and sold out of the back of someone's car.

column1: Once upon a time
column2: though
column3: before it became a shtick
column4: facelessness was just par for the course in techno
column5: a natural byproduct of the way the music was made and consumed—recorded by amateur producers
column6: released by fly-by-night record labels
column7: and spun in darkened rooms to audiences who probably had no idea what was playing at any given moment anyway. Just as importantly
column8: techno's facelessness had ideological aims; it was a reminder that the individual was less important than the collective.

column1: The Dutch-born
column2: Berlin-based DJ Steffi runs a hand-stamped white-label imprint herself
column3: but I'm pretty sure that the title of her new album
column4: Power of Anonymity
column5: is meant to evoke the more romantic aspects of techno facelessness—both the privileging of scenius over genius and the idea that
column6: as long as the music is good
column7: it doesn't matter what the name on the center sticker is; that when a DJ has earned the dancers' trust
column8: Shazam becomes unnecessary
column9: because the moment itself is too precious to sacrifice for a paltry morsel of metadata. (As a resident DJ at Panorama Bar
column10: Steffi understands this concept as well as anyone. The DJ booth there is on the same level as the dancefloor
column11: and so it is entirely possible to spend hours in the crowd without having the faintest idea who might be playing.)

column1: She has made an album equal to that ethos. There are no gimmicks here. These are club tracks
column2: through and through—late-night techno that radiates a deep blue glow beneath its brushed-metal surface. It would be wrong to call them workmanlike—no one will ever mistake these for humdrum DJ tools—but they're not exactly virtuosic
column3: either; they go out of their way to sound like approximations of an ideal type
column4: rather than expressions of individual genius. With the exception of ""Treasure Seeking""
column5: a springy electro-funk jam that takes inspiration from A Number of Names and Vanity 6
column6: they're all instrumentals
column7: and their similarities tend to eclipse their differences. They all share the same minor chords and moody synth wash; their pieces seem largely interchangeable. On ""Selfhood""
column8: a little two-note bassline digs in its heels; on ""Bag of Crystals""
column9: it reappears as a mirror image
column10: toggling up instead of down. The majority of the album's cuts are paced somewhere north of 130 beats per minute. They can be gorgeous
column11: and emotional
column12: and even sentimental
column13: but they're not meant to be calmly considered from a safe remove—they're designed to throw yourself into
column14: with a serenely ecstatic kind of gusto.

column1: The album
column2: her second
column3: is tougher
column4: deeper
column5: more nuanced
column6: and more confident than her 2011 debut
column7: Yours & Mine. Stylistically
column8: it's a fusion of classic Detroit and Berlin techno—the rich tones and pumping chords of the former
column9: the dub-assisted exploration of space of the latter. There are echoes of Robert Hood and Basic Channel
column10: as well as some of the high
column11: lonesome ostinatos of DJ Pierre's ""Wild Pitch"" style; there's also a pronounced electro influence in ""Bang for Your Buck""
column13: and ""Treasure Seeking""
column14: all of which are enlivened by a Drexciyan sense of snap and squelch. But nothing here feels throwback
column15: merely timeless—an overused term that
column16: for once
column17: earns its place. Formally and technologically
column18: any of these tracks might have been made at any point in the past 25 years. Her specialty is in creating streamlined arrangements consisting of multiple tonal parts that all interlock; no single one of them plays the lead
column19: and there are rarely any melodies to speak of. Instead
column20: they tend to move separately but together
column21: in sync
column22: rippling as naturally as the surface of a rain-dappled lake.

column1: Those intricate mechanics betray the album's key irony: it would be hard to imagine anyone but Steffi making this particular collection. Power of Anonymity is a masterclass in the sleight-of-hand that we call techno; there is virtuosity in the music's very attempts to sneak past under the cover of darkness. It may pass unidentified
column2:
but it will not go unnoticed.

column1: The video is at once strange

It's been nearly a half decade since he first started putting out New Age-indebted drone tapes as Run DMT
column2: and in that span Michael Collins has proved himself a pretty capable revivalist. As that project morphed from minimal
column3: no-fi ambient work into a '60s-leaning guitar-pop act before finally settling down as a freaky folk band under the similarly punny moniker Salvia Plath
column4: his M.O. remained the same: delve wholeheartedly into a well-trodden genre from the past and warp it with an eccentric
column5: acid-addled approach to production and composition. Now
column6: he's sparked up another endeavor with longtime friend and occasional collaborator Sasha Desree called Silk Rhodes that applies that same method to the familiar tropes of '70s funk and soul
column7: all the while remaining just offbeat enough to avoid pastiche.

column1: After a brief introductory track—complete with a dazed narrator exclaiming ""this is crazy!""—the record's lead single and obvious standout ""Pains"" slowly clatters in as a thesis statement of sorts for the 10 tracks that follow. Built around a swooning string sample
column2: droning organ lines
column3: and the slow shimmer of a lightly tremoloed guitar line
column4: it's a hazy deconstruction of the slinky R&B tracks that D'Angelo has chunked out over time. All the while
column5: Desree sings spiraling falsetto sweet nothings and offers up a lyrical platitude that seems to sum up their status as tinkerers in established fields: ""all things must change and remain.""

column1: But if Collins is to be believed
column2: none of the similarities to icons from the annals of soul's history (see also the Al Green-isms of ""Realtime"" or the Chicago house send-up ""Personal Use"") were intentional homages. It was instead what came to the duo unconsciously while tripping on the front porch of a house they shared in Baltimore. While that was only the direct circumstance for the creation of the eccentric funk track ""Face 2 Face""
column3: it's a mode of working that seems to explain the record's idiosyncrasies. Even on ""Pains""
column4: which is as close as this record gets to the rearview mirror worship of similarly silky acts like Gayngs and Inc.
column5: Desree's otherworldly vocalizations appear mostly unadorned—the usual orchestral flourishes that you might expect in this sphere give way to downtrodden minimalism. It's a tactic they pick up occasionally throughout the record
column6: and all of its best moments
column7: including the narcotized
column8: drumless ballads ""This Painted World"" and ""Barely New""
column9: demonstrate their dedication to counterintuitive arrangements and fractured songwriting.

column1: With Desree and Collins' predilection toward sparse instrumentals in mind
column2: at a breezy half-hour runtime Silk Rhodes could easily feel like an unnecessarily slight release. But those shorter tracks end up being one of the record's great strengths. Even when they occasionally stumble upon a melody that might start to feel a little too familiar
column3: as on the wordless ""ahh-ahhs"" that fill ""Group 1987""
column4: they're quick to shuffle to the next track
column5: letting the disorienting lurch between songs serve as substitute for groundbreaking experimentalism. On each of his many releases to date
column6: Collins is always trying to reinvent one wheel or another
column7: and even though that's traditionally seen as a fruitless exercise
column8:
what he and Desree have ended up with on Silk Rhodes is an invention worth marveling at in its own right.

column3: Chicago's drill scene endures

Case in point: SD (born Sadiki Thirston) opted for the independent route from the beginning

column4: especially with the lurching melody he rolls around during his verses
column5: like a less marble-mouthed Chief Keef. In many ways
column6: the album sounds like the kind of music that Keef might be making if he was interested in recording a proper follow-up to Finally Rich rather than burrowing deeper into his own insular world.

column1: In other words: anthems abound here. Whether it's the Zaytoven-esque funhouse mirror trap of ""Styles""
column2: on which SD stretches out vowels about as far as vowels can be stretched
column3: or the gargantuan bruiser ""Circles""
column4: where his singsong melodies fold in on themselves
column5: eating their own tails in a game of musical Ouroboros
column6: SD knows how to key in on one particular element in a song and then spend four minutes exploring it from every possible angle. Take ""Clockwork""
column7: for instance
column8: where he borrows inspiration from the tick-tock heave of Sonny Digital and B Wheezy's production without running the track's central conceit (""What time is it? Go get some money"") into the ground.

column1: Even with his penchant for selecting tough-as-nails production
column2: Truly Blessed is rarely a heavy affair. The narrative around drill often claims that those who make it are dead-eyed goons
column3: nihilists who not only perpetuate the violence that plagues their city but actually glorify it. This conveniently avoids admitting that
column4: while a lot of drill is unrelentingly bleak (see: most of Lil Durk's oeuvre)
column5: there's a lot of humor and outright joy to be found in it as well—SD isn't the natural class clown that King Louie is
column6: but he may be drill's most natural lothario. The most infectious moments on Truly Blessed are its giddiest
column7: and a few of them also happen to be honest-to-God—and really good—love songs.

column1: ""I want the best of you
column2: don't worry 'bout tonight"" SD sing-raps on ""Big Things""
column3: which captures the dizzying swirl of being completely and entirely head-over-heels about someone. It's also a shimmering swath of Lite-Brite synths that still possesses a lower-end that could knock pictures off of walls. ""I Do"" might be even better—SD sells the song by committing fully to its starry-eyed ecstasy
column4: and it may very well contain the most sunlight a drill song has ever dared to let in. ""This money saved me"" claims SD at one point on Truly Blessed
column5:
but the 15 songs here make a compelling argument that changing ""money"" to ""music"" wouldn't make his statement one iota less accurate.

The Wu-Tang Clan’s seminal debut album Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers) turned 20 last fall
column2: commemorated in a litany of glowing reminiscences and a lengthy intercontinental festival tour. There was a clean-cut finality to the proceedings
column3: a sense that the group was sending off a movement that had finally run its course. Producer and de facto group leader RZA thought he’d get the guys together for one last job and spent the year trying to will a new Wu-Tang album into existence in time for 36 Chambers’ November anniversary. The date came and went
column4: but no album surfaced (though we did get ""Family Reunion""
column5: a sentimental homecoming over a perhaps-too-chunky slice of the O’Jays’ 1975 hit of the same name). Work was plagued by old complaints about RZA’s lush live band arrangements flying in the face of the claustrophobic kung fu grit of the Clan’s classics. Raekwon publicly challenged RZA’s authority and boycotted the sessions. The new album had a name (A Better Tomorrow
column6: after the emotional Wu-Tang Forever cut) but no fully functioning group to record it.

column1: Tense negotiations and a reconciliation followed
column2: but A Better Tomorrow arrives this week illuminating the early apprehensions. The production here is more of a piece with the muscular soundtrack work of RZA’s 2012 directorial debut The Man With the Iron Fists than anything bearing the Wu-Tang name
column3: barring the heavily orchestrated bits of 2007’s 8 Diagrams that inspired Raekwon’s last mutiny attempt. But A Better Tomorrow’s thick and moody soundscapes run off-puttingly perpendicular to the group’s cerebral storytelling. ""Felt"" practically drowns memorable turns from Ghostface Killah and Method Man in unnecessary drum-n-bass flourishes. Inspectah Deck and Cappadonna come off uncharacteristically plodding over the fluid
column4: proggy groove of ""Mistaken Identity"". Sounds that were once punishing
column5: tumbling out of shoddy recording equipment in a home studio
column6: are distractingly pretty
column7: pumped full of all the crack session playing A Better Tomorrow favors.

column1: Where overbearing arrangements don’t get in the way
column2: a cloying sentimentality does. 4th Disciple delivers one of the album’s better productions with ""Miracle""
column3: but a drippy
column4: beatless chorus and melodramatic coda hack the momentum out from under suspenseful verses. ""Felt"" nicks a chorus from the mawkish '70s weeper ""Feelings""
column5: and the hokey
column6: swinging Dusty Springfield homage of ""Preacher’s Daughter"" is only listenable for Meth and Ghost’s flexible senses of humor. The title track fits the methodical build of Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes’ ""Wake Up Everybody"" under suitably socially conscious verses
column7: but right as you start to hope they’re not just going to play the actual chorus of the original in full
column8: they do
column9: strings ramped noxiously high in the mix. By the time ""Family Reunion"" hits
column10: A Better Tomorrow will have felt more like a karaoke bar’s old school night than a new album by the guys who gave us ""C.R.E.A.M."" and ""Triumph"".

column1: When A Better Tomorrow commits to sounding like an actual Wu-Tang affair it starts to cook. Longtime Wu associate Mathematics brings Meth and GZA to life with a lively soul chop on the album’s lead single ""Keep Watch"" and imbues ""40th Street Black/We Will Fight"" with the spirit of The W’s upbeat but by no means peppy ""Gravel Pit"". ""Pioneer the Frontier"" fashions the energy of ramshackle W deep cut ""Careful (Click
column2: Click)"" into a menace RZA can’t even kill when he signs verse one off with ""Holla at the moon
column3: my goons at Coachella."" ""Necklace"" and ""Ron O’Neal"" follow suit in piling on the soot
column4: and for a moment
column5: this thing is heavy enough to bear the weight of the name on the cover. But all too often
column6: A Better Tomorrow prefers to bask in those idyllic blue skies instead.

column1: Raekwon was right: RZA’s vision no longer suits the rabid
column2: renegade spirit the Wu-Tang Clan represents. He’s helmed a record that’s drunk on its own musicality
column3: one that seems to befuddle the very guys rapping on it. It’s impossible to say how engaged the rest of the members were in recording
column4: whether the wonkier moments here are the result of rappers disinterested in their own beats or production crafted awkwardly around pre-existing verses. But it’s deeply telling that the night the Wu-Tang Clan was set to release its first album in seven years (and possibly
column5: its last one ever)
column6: Raekwon was already pushing something else entirely on Twitter. The union hasn’t worked in a while
column7: and rather than hiding irreparable fissures by posting up a unified front to tickle fan nostalgia
column8: better to let it crystallize unblemished in memory. Keep up appearances for the kids if you like
column9:
but trust and believe that they can tell when something is off.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21243/homepage_large.c57b45b6.jpg|Fourth World Vol. 1: Possible Musics|526.0|Brian Eno|['Global'
column2: 'Jazz'
column4: Vol. 1: Possible Musics has a brainy and academic ring to it
column5: but according to Jon Hassell
column6: the record is at least 50% body music. ""The basic metaphor is that of the north and south of a person is a projection of the north and south of the globe
column7: the composer
column8: improviser
column9: and trumpet player
column10: now 77
column11: explained in an interview earlier this year. ""A mind formatted by language and located in the head
column12: compared with the area of wildness and sensuality below the waist where dance and music and procreation reigns.""

column1: However
column2: the first time through
column3: Possible Musics—which Hassell created in 1980 in collaboration with producer Brian Eno—you might find that ""wildness"" and ""sensuality"" are not the first adjectives that come to mind. It is eerie
column4: dreamlike
column5: and otherworldly music.

column1: Throughout the record
column2: Hassell’s trumpet is processed using a harmonizer effect
column3: producing alien tonalities that seem to slide between the notes of a traditional Western scale. Often
column4: his melody lines sound more like a human voice than a brass instrument. The rhythm tracks—made up of hand percussion and electric bass—are highly repetitive
column5: but also wobbly and destabilized. The result is a sound that melds minimalism
column6: jazz
column7: and ambient sounds
column8: but doesn’t fit comfortably into any of those genres.

column1: Though his name is not invoked as frequently as Eno’s
column2: the last few decades have proven Hassell—who was born in Memphis
column3: Tennessee—to be an influential presence in electronic music and modern composition. Active since the mid-'60s
column4: his background is hard to duplicate. He studied with Karlheinz Stockhausen
column5: played on the first recording of Terry Riley’s ""In C""
column6: and has performed session work for Talking Heads and Peter Gabriel. His solo work has provided the sonic blueprint for a number of contemporary musicians
column7: as well
column8: including Aphex Twin (See Selected Ambient Works Vol. II) and Oneohtrix Point Never (Returnal) to name a few.

column1: Possible Musics was
column2: in a lot of ways
column3: the first full realization of Hassell's Fourth World concept. Many of the sounds—the freaky trumpet tones
column4: the drifting ambient structures—were already in place on his 1977 debut LP
column5: Vernal Equinox
column6: but while that album is as meditative and mesmerizing as anything he has released
column7: it is clearly identifiable as a jazz fusion record.

column1: On Possible Musics
column2: synthesizers and electronic treatments help to nudge things into less recognizable territory. The music is informed by minimalism
column3: but Hassell's take is very different than the works of Philip Glass or Steve Reich that are linked to that style. For those composers
column4: minimalism often involved rigorous structure and clockwork execution
column5: whereas Possible Musics is conceptually dialed in
column6: but loose and improvisational in its execution. Harmonic motion is limited and all attention is centered around the embellishment of a single melodic line. Hassell is playing lead on these songs
column7: but his performances often blur seamlessly into the backing tracks.

column1: Like Eno’s ambient records
column2: Possible Music is all about mood. However
column3: where Music For Airports sought to reflect a highly impersonal environment
column4: Hassell’s work is intentionally exotic. No specific nation or people is being quoted here
column5: though. Hassell's landscape is an invented one—an imagined culture
column6: where high technology and mysticism are blended together. ""John’s experiment was to imagine a 'coffee coloured' world
column7: explains Eno in an essay first published in the Guardian and excerpted for the reissue's liner notes. ""A globalized world constantly integrating and hybridizing
column8: where differences were celebrated and dignified—and realize it into music.""

column1: In this sense
column2: Possible Musics is an exercise in science fiction. Like the William Gibson book Neuromancer
column3: the record offered an imperfect
column4: but prescient glimpse toward the near future.  The subsequent decades have not produced much music like Hassell’s
column5: but the concepts that informed Possible Musics have proven predictive of the way that technology would come to mesh with music-making in other cultures—whether that’s Konono N°1's amplified thumb pianos
column6: Group Doueh’s electric guitars
column7: or any number of global electronic and pop sounds that have been produced using a laptop computer.

column1: And once you acclimate to the weird and warbly tones
column2: there is a certain sensuality to Possible Musics. In Hassell’s desire to crossbreed cultures there’s an implicit act of intercourse going on—a desire for personal renewal and transformation via an ""other""
column3: be it a nation
column4: culture
column5:
or another human being.

Even when he was just emerging in the blog-rap golden era of 2009-10
column3: Big K.R.I.T. felt like a remnant from another time. The Mississippi rapper/producer was as Southern as it’s possible to be
column4: with a deep drawl that could suddenly accelerate like a souped-up caddie. His topics of choice were car culture
column5: faith
column6: and music-making
column7: and he created rousing anthems celebrating those subjects. He played the role of local boy made good at a time when the Internet was thought to be dissolving the idea of what ""local"" meant.

column1: ""I apologize if I’m oh-so-old fashioned"" he raps during ""Third Eye"" from his new album
column2: <i>Cadillactica
column3: and at this point
column4: the remark can be taken in multiple ways. In the context of the song
column5: K.R.I.T. is calling himself old school
column6: but he’s also the kind of self-producing Southern rapper who was put on by his catalogue
column7: as opposed to a single infectious single—no ""Versace"" or ""No Flex Zone"" for him. Instead
column8: blogs vaunted his debut mixtape K.R.I.T. Wuz Here and he remains an album rapper at a time when albums are less important than ever.

column1: Throughout Cadillactica
column2: K.R.I.T. acknowledges that the music he makes is no longer quite as relevant as it was just a couple of years ago. The title track includes a less-than subtle Migos reference
column3: and on ""King of the South""
column4: the rapper specifies that he works for the OG’s rather than the ""blogspot comment box."" The most noteworthy testament to K.R.I.T.’s attitude about developments in hip-hop comes in the furious ""Mt. Olympus""
column5: the best response to Kendrick’s ""Control"" verse that you may not have heard yet
column6: perhaps because it wasn’t recorded over the same beat. The song is almost worth quoting in its entirety
column7: because no track more perfectly sets up the problem for an old-fashioned ""lyrical"" Southern rapper at a time when Southern rap is best known for catchphrases
column8: singles
column9: and forward-thinking production. K.R.I.T.’s anger on the track is stirring and his flow about eight times more impressive than you probably remember. But the fact that his ire is directed at ""swagger-jackers"" who popularized Southern sounds and slang is disconcerting
column10: evidence of an artistic conservatism that may be what’s kept the rapper on a plateau for his last few projects.

column1: Even if Cadillactica may look to some like an artist struggling to stretch
column2: it certainly feels like the quintessence of the sound that K.R.I.T. has been working toward. On tracks like ""Kreation"" and ""Mind Control""
column3: there’s deep maximalist Southern funk reminiscent of Big Boi’s musical backdrop on Speakerboxxx and Sir Lucious Leftfoot. The efficacy of ""My Sub: Part 3"" will depend on how capable the bass in your earphones or stereo is
column4: but it’s a fitting peak for a rapper who has ""thought about the thump from the jump."" (After all
column5: ""hos can’t twerk to the hi-hat
column6: never."") The album is filled with the kind of soul-infused hip/hop that's been missing from the genre. ""Soul Food""
column7: featuring the immortal Raphael Saadiq and ""Saturdays=Celebration"" are resurrections of a neglected art form; the way that they’re executed makes you wonder why more people aren’t making music like this.

column1: K.R.I.T. is such a gifted storyteller that he’s often able to transcend the hackneyed concepts from which his songs are built. Take ""Third Eye""
column2: where his skeezy
column3: new-age come-on somehow morphs into a seductive (and wholly club-inappropriate) vision of creating a family: ""Picket fences
column4: and chilling playing instruments…I saw your face
column5: you were full of Grace
column6: at least that’s what we named her/ My angel had an angel and I was so thankful."" Another song that deals with ""Angels"" (and features the unfortunate hook
column7: ""I think angels get high"") has an amazing moment where K.R.I.T. describes his friend’s fear of an apocalyptic storm in such specific detail that you remember your own fear when encountering something so elemental.

column1: At this point in K.R.I.T.'s career
column2: we have a clear idea of his limitations—and with a runtime nearly reaching an hour
column3: the 17 tracks here can’t help but magnify some of the rapper’s flaws. There are empty songs on Cadillactica; ""Lost Generation""
column4: which features Lupe Fiasco
column5: has the rappers encouraging each other’s pedantic tendencies. K.R.I.T.
column6: too
column7: will often lay back and let his production cover a shallow 16—""Mind Control"" is one of the best sounding songs on the record
column8: but its verses
column9: including features from E-40 and Wiz Khalifa
column10: don’t do much to elevate the track.

column1: And yet
column2: like a basketball star managing to score within a wholly antiquated offense
column3: Cadillactica is the triumph of a style that has all but been discarded. It’s no doubt a conservative record
column4: maybe even a deeply unfashionable one
column5: but much of its strength lies in the fact that it sounds different from everyone else out there. K.R.I.T.’s stubborn resolution to stick to perfecting one particular approach may eventually doom his growth
column6: and it would be nice to see him move in a new direction at some point. But the power of Cadillactica repudiates the need for a change of pace—why trade in an old
column7:
reliable car when it still rides so clean?

It’s been 19 years since At the Gates released Slaughter of the Soul
column3: one of the best
column4: most innovative
column5: and most influential metal albums of the '90s. Maybe it was a little too influential—because now that Slaughter’s ""will-it-ever-come?"" follow-up
column6: At War With Reality
column7: has arrived
column8: it’s got a big cross to bear. The Gothenburg death-metal titans have reconvened at a time when their precise
column9: abrasively melodic sound has been repurposed—and re-repurposed—by about a zillion mediocre melodeath and metalcore outfits. That shouldn’t have any bearing on At War With Reality
column10: but it does: Any seminal band that resurfaces after so long an absence are prone to be called on the carpet not only for their own accomplishments
column11: but for the zeitgeist they’ve unleashed
column12: better or worse. Luckily for At the Gates
column13: they don’t seem to care one way or the other. Though maybe they should have.

column1: Heavy bands making stunning comebacks has become nearly routine over the past few years; look no further than Amebix’s Sonic Mass
column2: Carcass’ Surgical Steel
column3: or Godflesh’s A World Lit Only by Fire. At the Gates have earned a spot on the ladder
column4: but on a lower rung; At War With Reality is crisp
column5: concise
column6: and tastefully technical
column7: but it isn’t tear-your-head-off incredible. The production
column8: for one
column9: is miles better
column10: with a fuller
column11: fleshier attack
column12: and frontman Tomas Lindberg’s feral rasp has been coarsened even more by his tenure with his resurrected d-beat group Disfear. On ""Order from Chaos""
column13: a simmering
column14: tribal rhythm augments his apparent attempt to throw up his own lungs; lead guitarist Anders Björler installs atmospheric melodies and nearly gothic arpeggios. It’s one of the few glimpses of dynamism to the album. Mostly it sticks to a clipped
column15: cold
column16: chunky groove that might as well be a melodeath plug-in.

column1: The lack of highs and lows aside
column2: At War With Reality sticks to a solidly savage middle. ""Eater of Gods"" and ""The Conspiracy of the Blind"" are meaty
column3: marauding
column4: and righteously irate. Too bad they’re also practically interchangeable. At times
column5: they sound more like the Haunted
column6: the long-running outfit that’s been a halfway house of sorts to various members of At the Gates following their 1996 breakup. That’s not always a good thing
column7: as the Haunted ran out of steam and ideas years ago; At War With Reality tracks like ""Heroes and Tombs"" seethe and shred
column8: but they might as well be Haunted tunes with a few more flourishes (and a lot less cartoonishness). At a time when At the Gates should be doing everything it can to set itself apart from the pack
column9: it’s leaned on the most obvious—and most insular—signifiers imaginable.

column1: At War With Reality unquestionably rocks with fury and passion
column2: and that’s its saving grace. What doesn’t work is the album’s concept—in essence
column3: an homage to the elliptical
column4: magic-realist short stories of Jorge Luis Borges. Basically
column5: the concept involves shuffling around various Borges motifs—labyrinths
column6: mirrors
column7: mysterious cities—and making a patchwork of them. It’s a shallow approach to one of literature’s greatest writers
column8: and while Lindberg should get credit for not
column9: say
column10: being yet another metal band singing about H. P. Lovecraft
column11: the opportunity to rise above feels squandered. Not only does Lindberg directly
column12: lazily lift the titles of two Borges stories wholesale—for the songs ""The Circular Ruin"" and ""The Book of Sand""—the music doesn’t in any way connect with or evoke the otherworldliness of the author’s work (aside from the shadowy
column13: sumptuous instrumental ""City of Mirrors""). It’s funny that one of Borges’ primary themes is self-reference—because At War With Reality is
column14: above all else
column15:
an At the Gates album that feels like a pastiche of At the Gates. At least it’s a spirited one.

It’s strange to think that the collaboration between Maryland grindcore band Full of Hell and Japanese noise legend Merzbow had its roots in a t-shirt. In the design
column3: Full of Hell appropriated the album art of Merzbow’s 1996 album Pulse Demon
column4: a pulsing visual that works as a testament to the hypnotic waves of that collection. Depending on your opinion of Full of Hell
column5: you’d either call it a tribute or a ripoff. Either way
column6: rarely do shirts lead to actual collaboration
column7: something that came about here when the band met Balázs Pándi—who’s served as Merzbow’s drummer as of late—while on tour in Europe.

column1: Combining noise and metal is a worthwhile pursuit
column2: with groups like Portland’s Knelt Rote and Toronto’s Column of Heaven synthesizing noise’s freer destruction with metal’s more structured attack. In fact
column3: both genres seems to be reversing roles—many of the more critically acclaimed noise records
column4: like Wolf Eyes’ 2004 breakout Burned Mind and Pharmakon’s Bestial Burden
column5: are praised for incorporating structure
column6: while the more extreme ends of black and death metal are rapidly becoming looser and more feral. (Impetuous Ritual’s Unholy Congregation Of Hypocritical Ambivalence
column7: from earlier in the year
column8: is a prime example.) Merzbow is no stranger to metal
column9: having released several albums with Boris
column10: contributed to two songs on Sunn O)))’s Flight of the Behemoth
column11: and has cited death metal as influence on 1994’s Venereology
column12: released through the since-shuttered Relapse sub-label Release Entertainment. This collaboration
column13: however
column14: is frustrating because it falls short of its goals
column15: in part due to Merzbow’s too-reduced role and that Full of Hell don’t make up for the missing space.

column1: ""Burst Synapse"" begins with a quick rush of powerviolence
column2: an even quicker patch of Merzbow’s static
column3: then continues to be dominated by Full of Hell’s rote playing. ""Gordian Knot"" and ""Humming Miter"" offend more in this matter
column4: where Merzbow feels squandered. He doesn’t get to show any of his strengths. Full of Hell are one of those bands that can get people moshing in clubs
column5: but can’t capture that intensity in the studio
column6: and it’s more than obvious here. Merzbow isn’t quite able to bolster their riffs
column7: unlike in Rock Dream
column8: where he helps make Boris’ riffs grand and ecstatic. For his reputation as the antithesis of music
column9: Merzbow has a strong command of rhythm
column10: and if Full of Hell are gonna use Demon's art to gas up their van
column11: they should have embraced that record’s dynamics
column12: not simply its textures.

column1: Some potential arises toward the album’s conclusion
column2: where Merzbow begins to sync with Full of Hell. The blastbeats of ""Mute"" feel more unhinged thanks to his noise
column3: for once
column4: overcoming the guitar. ""High Fells"" sees Full of Hell dooming out
column5: and in the process
column6: giving Merzbow more room to cast a wide shadow. There’s even saxophone on here
column7: and in closer ""Fawn Heads and Unjoy""
column8: which is not only a nod to Merzbow’s love of free jazz
column9: but also lends unpredictability. Full of Hell restrain themselves even more on ""Ludjet Av Gud""
column10: dominated by booming floor toms and drifting noise undercurrents. (Some editions of the album come with Sister Fawn
column11: a bonus disc of outtakes. They’re long jams of noise and drums
column12: and even if they don’t form a cohesive whole
column13: they’re a much more satisfying listen than the actual record.)

column1: In the end here
column2: Merzbow feels more like a over-hyped
column3: under-trotted guest. It doesn’t even have the muster to serve as a compelling entryway for hardcore kids to get into noise. (As great as Demon and Venereology are
column4: they may be a bit overwhelming for novices; Merzbow’s collaborations with Boris would be smoother introductions.) In an interview with the Quietus last year
column5: Merzbow mentioned a forthcoming
column6: more grindcore-oriented record called Merzgrind. Maybe there
column7:
we’ll find the emancipating fury that's lacking in this Full of Hell collaboration.

Nineties indie rock was the sound of '80s hardcore kids growing up. And for many get-in-the-van vets
column2: it was a transition that necessitated a clean-slate reboot
column3: whether it was Lou Barlow channeling Dinosaur Jr.’s roar into Sebadoh’s trembling whispers

column5: or Davids Yow and Sims harnessing Scratch Acid’s strangulated squeals into the Jesus Lizard’s militaristic might. But for Yo La Tengo co-founders/cohabitants Ira Kaplan and Georgia Hubley
column6: the ascent to the Amerindie frontlines was a more gradual
column7: unceremonious process
column8: one that involved downsizing their band from a quartet to a trio
column9: jumping from label to label
column10: and a chronic inability to hold onto a bassist for more than one album at a time. Where they began as a prototypical college-rock outfit in the Velvets-via-Feelies mould (with an unabashed soft spot for '60s-pop covers)
column11: Yo La Tengo would go on to define '90s indie—and its evermore sophisticated post-millenial permutations—not by refining their sound
column12: but by blowing it wide open. Painful was the moment of detonation.

column1: The importance of Painful to the Yo La Tengo narrative can be gauged as such: This year marks the band’s 30th anniversary
column2: and they’re celebrating it by reissuing their sixth album
column3: released nearly a decade into their career. Painful marked a couple of significant firsts for Yo La Tengo: it was their first album made with eventual long-time producer Roger Moutenot
column4: and their first to be issued through Matador Records
column5: whose post-Pavement popularity (and resultant Atlantic Records parternship) afforded the band their widest distribution yet. And though Painful was actually the second Yo La Tengo album to feature bassist James McNew
column6: it was the first to fully enmesh his sensibilities with Kaplan and Hubley’s
column7: shirking the typical new-guy/third-wheel dynamic for a more polyamorous professional relationship that continues to this day.

column1: As recently as 1992’s May I Sing With Me (McNew’s debut with the band)
column2: Yo La Tengo albums tended to slide back and forth between narcotic noise-pop and hushed folky balladry
column3: producing music that was unerringly charming and consistent if not exactly transcendental. But with the introductory organ hum of the prophetically titled ""Big Day Coming""
column4: Yo La Tengo’s musical universe instantly turned three-dimensional
column5: projecting a vastness their previous records never really approached; by the time they kick into the dizzying tremoloed groove of the following ""From a Motel 6""
column6: you can already hear their hearts beating as one. Remarkably
column7: Painful thoroughly expanded Yo La Tengo’s sound by emphasizing two basic ingredients: a little shaker here
column8: and a lot of Ace Tone there (a development so notable
column9: it even earns its own celebratory rock-out in ""Sudden Organ""). But taken together
column10: they temper the band’s once-scrappy vigor into hypnotic motorik motions and droning reverberations
column11: while casting Hubley’s plainspoken vocals in a dreamy haze
column12: and inspiring Kaplan to drop the bratty insolence of old for a more congenially conversational drawl.

column1: The cardigan-cozy sound of the record effectively established Yo La Tengo as indie rock’s great romantics. Though musical-cum-matrimonial partnerships weren’t exactly a novelty at the time (see: Kim Gordon and Thurston Moore
column2: Neil Hagerty and Jennifer Herrema
column3: Jon Spencer and Cristina Martinez)
column4: Kaplan and Hubley were the rare pair to use their songs to openly address matters of the heart. But while Kaplan and Hubley’s exchanges on Painful can resemble scenes from a marriage
column5: it’s not necessarily their own; rather
column6: a hazy-headed ballad like ""Nowhere Near"" conveys both an intimacy and non-specificity that make it applicable to any long-distance relationship spent waiting for the phone to ring. And the album’s most tender moment—with Kaplan crooning ""baby
column7: I’m in love with you"" like a lonesome doo-wop singer abandoned by his crew on some moonlit corner—comes through a to-die-for cover of UK power-popsters the Only Ones’ ""The Whole of the Law"" (yet another sterling example of Yo La Tengo acting out their record collection). Even Painful’s most blown-out moments are infused with an unspeakable tenderness—Yo La Tengo were no strangers to extended
column8: feedback-screeching jams at this point
column9: but never before had they pulled one off that could actually make you weep (""I Heard You Looking"").

column1: What makes Painful so eminently approachable after all these years is that it manages to sound like a fully realized
column2: band-defining statement yet unpretentiously off-the-cuff at the same time. It’s a feeling reinforced by the overflow of material available on this reissue
column3: appropriately retitled Extra Painful on account of its enlarged 2xCD girth (not to mention an additional album’s worth of download-only odds and ends even more revelatory than the bonus disc proper). More so than any other band in recent memory
column4: Yo La Tengo’s body of work hinges on the notion that no song is ever a completely finished
column5: end-state product; what we hear on any given album is seemingly a function of what mood they were in the day it was recorded
column6: what the weather was like on the day of mixing
column7: or how much studio time was left before the budget was blown. There is no such thing as a permanent record; songs have many lives before they’re officially documented and continue to evolve long thereafter.

column1: It’s a concept that Yo La Tengo had hinted at before with the two oppositional treatments of ""The Evil That Men Do"" on 1989’s President Yo La Tengo and the double
column2: duelling dose of ""Upside-Down"" on the 1992 EP of the same name. Painful continued the conversation with dramatically different versions of Kaplan’s ""Big Day Coming""—the gauzy
column3: weightless opener and the penultimate
column4: fuzzed-out chugger—but Extra Painful ups the ante with three more wildly varying live mutations: a laid-back acoustic take sung by Hubley
column5: a revved-up rendition that’s almost twice as fast as the second Painful one
column6: and a mammoth 19-minute distention that fills in the canyon-like divide between Yo La’s soothing/squalling extremes. Likewise
column7: a percussion- and fuzz-free CBGB performance of ""Double Dare"" foregrounds the pent-up longing that gets washed over by the original’s shoegazey drive
column8: while an Ace Tone-free demo of the same underscores just how important the organ was in achieving it. And it speaks volumes about Painful’s superior quality—and the band’s surging creative energies at the time—that the steely
column9: Stooges-inspired stomper ""Shaker"" could be earmarked for a non-album single
column10: while the spectacular slow-dissolve ballad ""Slow Learner"" would be shelved altogether.

column1: From this point on
column2: Yo La Tengo could no longer be described as mere Velvet Underground wannabes (unless
column3: of course
column4: they were playing them in a movie)
column5: and within just a few years
column6: you’d be hard-pressed to even call them a rock band anymore. But then
column7: such a free-ranging future seemed almost predestined when
column8: after a decade of playing the rock'n'roll classicist
column9: Kaplan opened up Painful by declaring
column10: ""let’s be undecided."" As Yo La Tengo’s post-Painful path would prove
column11:
indecision has never sounded so assured.

"|20017.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20017-yo-la-tengo-extra-painful/|9.6|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21299/homepage_large.229804f7.jpg|Classics|5676.0|She & Him|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2014-12-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:49.938965|"

She & Him might need a time machine. After three albums and a Christmas record
column2: the duo’s pretty
column3: uncomplicated pop songs keep harkening back to decades they were too young to experience first-hand; a bit of 1960s Loretta Lynn country here
column4: a bit of '70s Carpenters’ sunny pop there. So it was hardly surprising when M. Ward and Zooey Deschanel announced that their next release would be Classics
column5: a cover album of 13 of their favorite old-school songs.

column1: So
column2: what makes a classic song? For She & Him
column3: classic songs find their roots in country
column4: soul
column5: and jazz orthodoxy
column6: and they’re culled from the eras in which these genres were arguably the most golden—the '30s
column7: the '50s
column8: the '70s. Clearly
column9: a classic song is a love song. From Ella Fitzgerald and Louis Armstrong’s flirtatious duet ""Would You Like to Take a Walk?"" to Johnny Mathis’ sadly hopeful ""It's Not for Me to Say""
column10: She & Him tuck a wide range of romantic ups and downs into this starry-eyed and glamorous little record.

column1: She & Him aren’t trying to surprise anyone with these covers; there’s no off-the wall instrumental experimentation
column2: no dramatic shift in lyrics. Instead
column3: Classics is charming and sleepy in a '60s samba sort of way
column4: filled with whispering percussion
column5: light electric guitar solos
column6: and string arrangements worthy of the silver screen. ""This Girl’s in Love With You""
column7: a slight twist on Herb Alpert’s ""This Guy’s in Love With You""
column8: is highly reminiscent of the original
column9: with a retro brass and woodwind arrangement. It would make delightful title music if Deschanel ever wants to star in a version of ""New Girl"" set in the mid-'70s.

column1: Even when She & Him push their sonic boundaries a little
column2: the effect is still subtle and sophisticated. On ""Teach Me Tonight""
column3: they manage to move the 1954 classic further into the past
column4: painting the soulful tune with a sped-up '30s flare
column5: layering back-up ""oohs"" and ""aahs"" under Deschanel’s lead vocals into a Boswell Sisters-worthy harmony. They take ""Unchained Melody"" to an absolutely haunting place
column6: featuring just Deschanel and Ward’s guitar
column7: her words echoed by a ghostly ensemble choir.

column1: A cinematic quality reverberates throughout Classics
column2: and songs like ""She""
column3: ""Unchained Melody""
column4: and ""We’ll Meet Again"" were featured in or made for series or films. The songs themselves play like romantic mini-dramas
column5: with pleas for lovers to stay and odes to loneliness. That said
column6: some narratives call for a singer with more force. While Maxine Brown and Aretha Franklin belt the chorus of ""Oh No
column7: Not My Baby"" in a gesture of soulful refusal
column8: Deschanel opts for tender restraint
column9: so that the song’s metaphoric head-shaking suddenly becomes a limply apathetic shrug. And Dusty Springfield’s jangling ""Stay Awhile"" is muted considerably in She & Him’s rendition
column10: as Deschanel’s voice takes a somber turn.

column1: Even though they're working with dated lyricism by 2014’s standards
column2: saccharine lines like ""When you’re strolling through the wherezis
column3: you need a whozis to lean upon"" don’t sound contrived or silly in She & Him's hands. ""Funny
column4: each time I fall in love
column5: Deschanel sings on Bing Crosby’s hit
column6: ""It’s always you."" If Classics proves anything
column7:
it’s that these songs stick around for a reason.
