column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21247/homepage_large.39545df2.jpg|Noctilucence EP|29178.0|Mark McGuire|['Rock'
column3: Mark McGuire has carved out a unique space for himself in the realm of contemporary alternative music through prolificness and sheer force of will. A former member of the influential
column4: similarly release-happy experimental trio Emeralds
column5: his music has retained a distinct and idiosyncratic feel even as his compositions have become increasingly ambitious and dense. It begins with his guitar work
column6: which is always texturally rich and recognizable for its tone even though his playing is widely varied. He can send out layer after layer of simple and easily melodic patterns
column7: making them overlap and flutter like hummingbird wings; he’s unafraid to top all of those intricately constructed layers with a meat-and-potatoes solo that wouldn’t be out of place on a Journey song. This skill has remained the core of his songs from his earliest CD-Rs all the way through to epic multi-instrumental efforts like Along the Way
column8: a full-length released earlier this year.

column1: There’s a consistent emotional aspect to McGuire’s work that’s just as important as his fretplay. He’s an earnest and unabashedly sentimental composer
column2: whether exploring his youth and family (on his first prominent full-length
column3: Living With Yourself) or plumbing philosophical depths and metaphysical questions on Along the Way. There’s a gentle
column4: searching quality to the length and slow expansion of his songs
column5: and to his infrequent vocals. His new EP
column6: Noctilucence
column7: is more of the same: named for a bright
column8: bold
column9: and rare cloud phenomena
column10: it finds McGuire further expanding his sonic palette.

column1: There are moments on Noctilucence where McGuire's steps toward a more complicated strain of composition are palpable. Take a song like ""Entity (Presence)""
column2: one of the shorter tracks on the EP at only six minutes in length: it begins with the sort of chugging
column3: easily layered lines that have formed the base of hundreds of McGuire's songs over the last half-decade. Within a few seconds
column4: it breaks open and reveals a pulsing drum machine and waves of chirping synths; those layers of guitar are still present
column5: but they're buried under dozens of other elements by the time the song is finished. This constant building grants each song on Noctilucence an impressive depth
column6: something that's particularly noticeable on the album's pair of 10-plus minute titans
column7: ""Noctilucence"" and ""Astral Protection""; in the middle of them
column8: I find myself remembering that McGuire once released an EP called Get Lost. In trying to summon the size and scale of constellations and galaxies far beyond our current reach
column9: McGuire invites the listener to surrender their directional impulses and cede control; when he deconstructs these songs and slowly strips them down to their humble beginnings towards their conclusions
column10: it feels like reaching the end of a long journey.

column1: While the sheer size and density of McGuire’s work on Noctilucence is certainly impressive
column2: it should be noted that the EP is just a variation on the sort of quest for truth and peace in the maelstrom he’s been conducting for over a half-decade. His methods may have changed
column3: but the end result of his best work remains the same: the loss of your grip on space and time
column4: the release of control. One of my favourite McGuire songs is ""Dream Team""
column5: originally released in 2008 and collected on the phenomenal 2011 compilation A Young Person's Guide to Mark McGuire. Stretching over 17 minutes
column6: it doesn’t begin to approach the diversity and colour of the material on Noctilucence. It’s a collage of dozens of layers of distorted guitar and some echoing
column7: wordless vocals
column8: one that slowly builds to an impossible crunch before dissipating and drifting away. ""Dream Team"" is simpler
column9: but it’s just as effective. And while it would be reasonable to compare that song and something like ""Noctilucence"" to reach the conclusion that McGuire is reluctant to leave his lane
column10: I choose instead to revel in his singular gift
column11:
one he’s slowly and surely exploring.

"|19988.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19988-mark-mcguire-noctilucence-ep/|7.5|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21252/homepage_large.ebc39f09.jpg|Confidence|28912.0|Trash Kit|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Upset the Rhythm']|2014-12-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:51.052237|"

Confidence
column2: the second LP from London trio Trash Kit
column3: is a pointillist triumph
column4: a million small gestures arranged with jaw-dropping exactitude. For 29-odd minutes
column5: Rachel Aggs (also of Shopping)
column6: Electrelane's Ros Murray
column7: and Halo Halo's Rachel Horwood piece the album together
column8: then yank it apart
column9: contorting and complicating these songs at every opportunity. It's 11 calamity-skirting post-punk tunes that teeter between control and chaos.

column1: It's been four years since Trash Kit's self-titled debut
column2: a rangier record of distortion-dodging guitars
column3: skittish snares
column4: and head-swimming harmonies. At times
column5: the songs on Trash Kit seemed to be angling for space amidst all the snags and snarls Trash Kit threw at them. On the clearer-headed Confidence
column6: however
column7: the ever-hastening rhythms and countless left-turns provide the framework for the topline melodies to glide over; there's less frenzy here
column8: more co-mingling. A typical Trash Kit song—even the ones that barely scrape the two-minute mark—rarely winds up anywhere near where it started; ""Skin""
column9: the best of the bunch
column10: throws out a springy riff
column11: halfway-flips ""Walk Like an Egyptian""
column12: then suddenly doubles in speed
column13: plunging rollercoaster-style through an anxious array of whoops and shouts. The sound of Confidence is crisp and clean
column14: every note in place
column15: displaying little in the way of post-production; with nothing to hide behind
column16: navigating all these bends and pivots becomes paramount
column17: but Trash Kit seem to take every left-turn and abrupt detour on Confidence with ease
column18: never once having to look down at the map.

column1: Confidence is a high-wire act
column2: and maintaining an air of unpredictability in the midst of these tightly-wound songs might be Trash Kit's most impressive feat. Despite the note-perfect presentation
column3: Confidence is loose and limber; hooks seem to emerge from the corners and crevasses of these songs
column4: seemingly forged from the friction caused by all those intersecting parts. Beyond a couple of James Chance-ian honkouts from Murray's ex-Electrelane bandmate Verity Susman
column5: these songs are all built from pretty much the same stuff: Aggs' rippling
column6: highlife-inspired fretwork
column7: Murray's cascading basslines
column8: Horwood's frayed-nerve drums
column9: and swooping
column10: meet-you-in-the-middle vocals from the two Rachels. But listening to Confidence is like watching three people put a puzzle back together 11 different ways: the picture changes every time
column11:
yet the pieces always seem to fit. 

Lyrically
column12: Confidence veers from the wistful to the anxious at the same careening clip as the music; opener ""Beach Babe"" pines for summer
column13: while immediate follower ""Medicine"" begins in ""t-e-r-r-o-r."" ""Teeth"" bows out with ""confidence
column14: all confidence""; seconds later
column15: there's the shakier ""Shyness""
column16: which gets going with ""you're so shy
column17: you should hide."" After a quick pep talk
column18: though
column19: ""Shyness"" takes a turn towards the triumphal
column20: sliding into a major key while Aggs and Horwood gleefully shout down the naysayers. ""Shyness""
column21: like the rest of <i>Confidence
column22: is a testament to casting off the shackles of convention
column23:
to not letting anyone (yourself included) stand in the way of what you want.

"|19995.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19995-trash-kit-confidence/|7.4|Paul Thompson

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21258/homepage_large.6137acad.jpg|You Go Girl|32620.0|Frank & Tony|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Scissor and Thread']|2014-12-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:51.636000|"

Frank & Tony is a collaboration between two Brooklyn-based dance music veterans
column2: Francis Harris and Anthony Collins. If the name brings to mind one of those innumerable East Coast production duos who vacillated between house and R&B in the early '90s
column3: that’s probably not an accident: Harris and Collins have
column4: over the course of several EPs
column5: pursued the contemplative and melancholic deep house sound developed in New York and New Jersey. It’s the type of music that inevitably gets described as ""sumptuous""; a sound that
column6: with its relaxed tempos and smoky hues
column7: has proven itself equally at home on dance floors and in living rooms.

column1: Harris and Collins both have long histories churning out high energy singles for DJs
column2: but it’s Harris whose solo work has recently taken a turn toward outre composition and lush textures. This year’s well-received Minutes of Sleep was an experiment almost completely untethered from the dance floor
column3: an album whose exceptional clarity allowed Harris and listeners to swim amongst its rich detail. It’s easy to see Harris’ hand in You Go Girl
column4: Frank & Tony’s first album
column5: an album that is far more concerned with the sound of house music than its function.

column1: Though the album’s sound is indebted to those deep house classics
column2: it doesn’t share their cultural impact. Those records
column3: crucial in helping carve out spaces for gay and transgender communities
column4: had a socio-political purpose that You Go Girl can’t; instead
column5: the record plays as an exquisite display of deep house’s sound palette
column6: a record on which every sound and gesture is imbued with elegance and purpose.

column1: There’s a moment in the middle of ""Call Me Rain"" that will be familiar to anyone who’s listened to house music before: a heavy
column2: trudging bass drum is reintroduced after a short passage of heavily-effected electric piano. A few bars latter
column3: a tittering hi-hat and then a clap on the second and fourth beat
column4: splashing down like a boot into a puddle. There is no novelty here; every one of these elements is commonplace
column5: including the structure of the track. What feels unique about Frank & Tony
column6: however
column7: is that these elements aren’t aligned like this to aid a DJ in mixing a track
column8: but rather because this is the ideal presentation for better appreciating these sounds: the cavity the kick drum carves out each time it booms
column9: the crisp landing of the clap
column10: the glittering tinsel of the hi-hats.

column1: You Go Girl is an appreciation and a study of sound. The sounds it wants to study happen to be best observed in a 120 bpm deep house track. It’s in this way that Harris and Collins owe a debt to artists like Matthew Herbert and Terre Thaemlitz (especially her work as DJ Sprinkles)
column2: artists with avant-garde roots who have often chosen to contrast their more experimental and sound design impulses with the conventions of house music. (Indeed
column3: the duo collaborated with Thaemlitz for a track on one of three 12''s that accompanies the release of You Go Girl.)

column1: You Go Girl offers a similar richness of detail
column2: its slack tempos gently guiding listeners. They mostly stick to the script: brisk drum
column3: hazy keyboards
column4: a nod-able bassline. Tracks such as ""After Days"" and ""Faded (Dub)"" construct noir-ish atmospheres
column5: imagining a world in which grim detectives nod along on dusky dancefloors. A handful of vocal collaborations—a moody and sour Gry Bagøien on ""Bring the Sun""
column6: a cryptic Jason Poranski on ""Resistance""—offer crucial variety.

column1: You Go Girl is a conservative album in every way
column2: asking very little of listeners: if you choose not to stare at the macro details of a bass drum
column3: You Go Girl will fade pleasantly into the background. It doesn’t have the scope or ambition of Thaemlitz’s monumental Midtown 120 Blues
column4: a clear influence. Its instincts are construction
column5: not destruction. The album at times seems like a coloring book in which someone has exclusively drawn inside the lines
column6: but with extreme precision. There’s value in that: these are pretty pictures with a lot of detail
column7:
and the care and attention with which they were produced shouldn’t be confused for a lack of passion.

"|20000.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20000-frank-tony-you-go-girl/|7.2|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21038/homepage_large.092a07e0.jpg|Didn't It Rain|26175.0|Songs: Ohia|[]|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2014-12-01 00:00:00|2002|2016-06-11 16:16:52.320249|"

“The last Songs: Ohia record is Didn’t It Rain
column2: ” Jason Molina states definitively in a 2006 interview—not published in its entirety until after Molina’s death in 2013—with the blog Underground Bee. That statement answers a question that Molina left wide open with the release of his 2003 album The Magnolia Electric Co.
column3: which also became the name of the band that he primarily recorded under for the remainder of his life. It might all seem like so much semantics
column4: but there’s a profound and telling truth behind Molina’s line drawn in the sand: 2002’s Didn’t It Rain
column5: the eighth studio album by his haunting folk-rock project Songs: Ohia
column6: was intended to be an end.

column1: Molina’s music
column2: especially in the wake of his death
column3: has taken on an air of myth
column4: but it’s the most unassuming kind of myth imaginable. A trailer-park kid with a garage-sale guitar
column5: he spun his upbringing in Ohio and West Virginia into the stuff of hardscrabble eloquence. He began recording solo under the name Songs: Ohia in the 1990s
column6: at the height of the slicker
column7: more traditional alt-country boom. But rather than kick shit
column8: Molina followed a path parallel to Will Oldham’s: cryptic
column9: fractured
column10: and with the faint
column11: deconstructive underpinning of post-rock. Molina
column12: though
column13: struck closer to full-throated confessionals
column14: even as his eerie guitar tunings and oblique angles of vocal engagement—marks of an autodidactic—kept him squarely sequestered as an outlier.

column1: Didn’t It Rain doesn’t veer from the pattern Molina had established by 2002. But it’s a step forward in assurance
column2: while remaining anything but assuring. Recorded live in the studio with a handful of musicians
column3: including Jim Krewson and Jennie Benford from Jim and Jennie and the Pinetops
column4: the album is a slow sketch in black chalk. The title track is one of Molina’s greatest compositions
column5: full of glistening
column6: suspended chords and a refusal to comfortably resolve. Molina’s narrative perspective is just as uneasy: “No matter how dark the storm gets overhead
column7: ” he sings
column8: “They say someone’s watching from the calm at the edge.” Where are we watching from? Who is he supposed to be? The answers aren’t hidden; he doesn’t seem to know. And that slipperiness feeds into the song’s simple
column9: circular swell.

column1: Vocally
column2: Molina reached new heights. Notes dip
column3: quake
column4: and hover. Syllables are either softly stretched or sharply snapped. He harmonizes with Benford in heart-stopping glimpses of intimacy
column5: sounding far more like Alan Sparhawk and Mimi Parker of slow-core contemporaries Low than any kind of corny ’90s Americana act. If anything
column6: there’s a walloping melancholy that matches Gene Clark at his White Light loneliest. “I’m gonna help you all I can
column7: ” Molina ultimately offers on “Didn’t It Rain”
column8: but every quiet pocket of emptiness in the song screams that he’s powerless to keep that promise. The song’s title may be borrowed from a gospel traditional
column9: but it isn’t about salvation. It’s about having a hand
column10: any hand
column11: to hold as the inevitable comes crashing down.

column1: Molina was always imagistic
column2: and the piercing hollowness Didn’t It Rain gives him more room than usual to project his nightmares and daydreams. In particular
column3: the moon and the color blue surface repeatedly—not only in the titles “Steve Albini’s Blues”
column4: “Blue Factory Flame”
column5: “Two Blue Lights”
column6: and “Blue Chicago Moon”
column7: but in the way those motifs are worked into the fabric of Molina’s harsh
column8: hushed revelations. The image of a blue moon is one of pop’s most enduring emblems of loneliness
column9: and Molina milks that archetype for all its worth on “Blue Chicago Moon” and “Blue Factory Flame”. They’re the only two tracks played with a full band
column10: but Molina whittles that fullness into a bony vestige; both are creeping and tentative
column11: with picks skidding off strings as if barely willing to activate them.

column1: Cut from the same ragged flannel as Neil Young and Crazy Horse’s “Danger Bird”—minus the smoldering guitar solos
column2: which Molina wouldn’t begin to incorporate in earnest until Magnolia Electric Co.—“Blue Factory Flame” opens with one of Molina’s most indelible verses
column3: and one that’s become bloodcurdling in the wake of his death: “When I die/ Put my bones in an empty street/ To remind me how it used to be.” But he follows it with a sharp shift to the everyday
column4: a move that mitigates morbid pity with something that almost approaches levity: “Don’t write my name on a stone/ Bring a Coleman lantern and a radio/ The Cleveland game and two fishing poles/ And watch with me from shore.” When
column5: on “Two Blue Lights”
column6: he equates the moon with lights from a late-night bus
column7: all those lunar allusions become ghostly
column8: recursive reflections of each other
column9: a way of amplifying the beauty and dread that Molina never seemed ready to separate.

column1: The moon would also prove to be a looming symbol of austerity and menace on Molina’s next album
column2: Magnolia Electric Co. Here
column3: though
column4: it shines wanly
column5: filtered through a more polluted atmosphere. That’s heard even more clearly on the eight bonus tracks included with the new
column6: deluxe reissue of Didn’t It Rain—six of which represent songs from the album proper
column7: and two of which (“The Gray Tour” and “Spectral Alphabet”) would turn up in different versions on later records. They’re gorgeous
column8: acoustic demo renditions
column9: managing to strip down arrangements that are already skeletal. But they lack the spark of Molina’s in-studio push-and-pull with his handful of collaborators. They do
column10: however
column11: provide an even less guarded portrait of Molina at the time; on the demo version of the self-referential “Cross the Road
column12: Molina”
column13: his pleas to “Set my pulse/ To the Great Lakes pulse” feel almost transcendentally pagan.

column1: Didn’t It Rain would be the slow
column2: sad end of Songs: Ohia
column3: but it isn’t a whimper. It’s where Molina felt the need to contract himself to a pinpoint
column4: gathering all his energy into a lonesome quantum
column5: before unleashing the wholehearted force of Magnolia Electric Co. He couldn’t have known what was to come
column6: including some of his best work and worst times
column7: but it’s obvious this is the sound of Molina standing on the brink of something. He didn’t seem to know quite what yet
column8:
and that stark uncertainty imbues Didn’t It Rain with a sickening yet heroic alchemy: the ability to make smallness and helplessness feel somehow brave.

"|19805.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19805-songs-ohia-didnt-it-rain/|8.8|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21273/homepage_large.3ec22205.jpg|Music Industry 3. Fitness Industry 1. EP|2801.0|Mogwai|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rock Action']|2014-12-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:53.078647|"

Earlier this year
column2: Mogwai released their eighth album and then reissued their second one
column3: and listening to both in tandem
column4: one could reasonably conclude that the Scottish art-rock quintet have either evolved considerably over the past 15 years or not at all. Sure
column5: Mogwai songs are no longer the ticking time-bombs they once were; now as reliant on sci-fi synths as nuclear guitar blasts
column6: their once forbidding 10-minute-plus epics have been pared down to more digestible
column7: pop-friendly forms. But on an album-to-album basis
column8: that change has been so incremental
column9: it can seem like Mogwai have stagnated. While the sneak-attack tactics of old have been replaced with more carefully orchestrated ascents
column10: their music has nonetheless retained the slow-roiling tension and uneasy atmosphere that defined the band’s early efforts.

column1: In lieu of rewriting their formula
column2: Mogwai have instead opted to outsource any radical reinvention to producer friends who don’t so much provide them with remixes as wholesale rethinks. After subjecting their 2011 release
column3: Hardcore Will Never Die But You Will
column4: to a nigh-unrecognizable full-album overhaul
column5: the stop-gap Music Industry 3. Fitness Industry 1. EP presents a more modestly scaled counterpart to this year’s Rave Tapes
column6: complementing remixes of three album tracks with a trio of new songs. Collectively
column7: the EP has a little bit of something for every type of Mogwai fan: those who just want them to stick to the same-ol'-same-ol'
column8: those who want to see them steer their sound into new directions
column9: and those who’d prefer they dismantle it completely.

column1: EPs have traditionally been the format where Mogwai showcased their more pensive material
column2: so it’s a wonderful shock that Music Industry 3. Fitness Industry 1. leads with the purest
column3: catchiest vocal track the band has ever attempted. Picking up on the motorik momentum first introduced on Hardcore’s “Mexican Grand Prix”
column4: the glimmering dream-pop anthem “Teenage Exorcists” feels very much like a conjuring of Mogwai’s own adolescence
column5: applying My Bloody Valentine’s beautiful blur to Stuart Braithwaite’s dancefloor confession. But while it’d be intriguing at this point to hear Mogwai attempt a whole album in this mode
column6: the EP proves there are limits to their student-disco aspirations: the promisingly titled “HMP Shaun Ryder” proves to be a textbook Mogwai move from ominous
column7: vibraphoned lurch to ape-shit guitarmageddon onslaught
column8: meaning we’ll have to wait just a bit longer for the band to embark upon its baggy phase. (And
column9: alas
column10: “History” offers more of the same
column11: albeit in more pastoral
column12: less dramatic fashion.)

column1: But rather than feel tacked-on incongruities
column2: the three Rave Tapes remixes found on the EP’s second half provide a welcome
column3: unpredictably outré counterpoint to the linear songs heard on the first. In the hands of Blanck Mass—a.k.a. Fuck Buttons co-founder Benjamin John Power—the Italo-prog excursion “Remurdered” is reborn as “Re-Remurdered”
column4: which deploys the original’s synth line not as a melodic motif
column5: but as the rhythmic foundation for its convulsive electro-funk. And tellingly
column6: the other two remixes tackle Rave Tapes’ two meditative closing tracks in sequence
column7: as if Mogwai were admitting that the album’s anti-climactic comedown was in need of a do-over. True to his hauntological m.o.
column8: enigmatic producer Pye Corner Audio recasts the oscillating refrain of “No Medicine for Regret” in a ghostly
column9: post-apocalyptic fog
column10: but uses it as the springboard into a light-headed acid-house odyssey
column11: while German composer Nils Frahm reduces the vocoderized ballad “The Lord Is Out of Control” to a gorgeously spare piano melody
column12: before introducing a skyward surge that channels the angelic grace of vintage Sigur Rós. All told
column13:
the final score for Music Industry 3. Fitness 1.: Remixers 3 Mogwai 1. 

"|20016.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20016-mogwai-music-industry-3-business-industry-1-ep/|6.8|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21301/homepage_large.d77184f2.jpg|Void|31527.0|RL Grime|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Wedidit']|2014-12-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:53.687955|"

Dance music has always been fiercely tribalist in nature
column2: but those inclinations seem to be breaking down in the era of EDM—a movement whose very name speaks to its purportedly all-inclusive nature. The Internet has facilitated links between geographically distant scenes and structurally distinct styles
column3: and it has given fans instant access to the whole sweep of dance music's history. And then there's the food-court model of the contemporary festival
column4: in which attendees can sample a range of styles with relative ease—sometimes
column5: without so much as wandering from one stage to the next.

column1: The budding career of a 23-year-old producer named Henry Steinway is exemplary of this shift in dance music's politics. For a time
column2: he was known principally as Clockwork
column3: a maker of brash
column4: energetic electro-house for labels like Steve Aoki's Dim Mak and Diplo's Mad Decent. Clockwork fit the profile of an EDM main-stager: he bootlegged Avicii's ""Levels""
column5: dealt in crowd-stoking mashups (Wolfgang Gartner's ""Nuke"" with the White Stripes' ""Seven Nation Army""
column6: for instance)
column7: and harnessed the usual array of atom-smashing snares
column8: roller-coaster crescendos
column9: and supersonic whoosh.

column1: Around the same time that he first signed to Dim Mak
column2: Steinway began exploring a different sound under the alias RL Grime. Inspired
column3: he has said
column4: by both James Blake and Lex Luger
column5: he set about attempting to connect those worlds with a cat's-cradle of pitched-up vocals
column6: chiming keys
column7: diamond-cutter snares
column8: and clickety-clackety hi-hats. A 2011 mix sketched the outlines of his adopted terrain: Rustie
column9: Untold
column10: and Joy Orbison on the one hand
column11: and Drake
column12: D'Angelo
column13: and Missy Elliott on the other. Recently
column14: RL Grime's profile has risen considerably via his interpretation of ""trap
column15: a gruff
column16: swaggering style informed by Southern hip-hop and Dutch hardstyle.

column1: With VOID
column2: his debut album
column3: he's clearly keen to showcase his versatility. Roughly half of the album forsakes trap in favor of various bass-heavy strains of club music or its home-listening variants. It's refreshing to see him unbound by genre strictures
column4: but it can seem like he's trying too hard to please too many people. The opening ""Always"" features a pitch-shifted Janet Jackson sample over moody minor chords and 2-steppy drum programming that invariably bring to mind Four Tet and Burial; it's followed by the Boys Noize co-production ""Danger""
column5: a taut-electro-techno stormer aimed at Boddika's sullen corner of the dance floor.

column1: Both tracks sound like attempts to shore up his underground bona fides
column2: but neither are exactly best-in-class productions
column3: which is a problem that plagues the album: RL Grime may have range
column4: but he doesn't have a terribly original voice. Too many of these feel like items on an imaginary checklist of requirements for any ""serious"" dance album. Pensive scene-setter? Check. Non-beat-gridded ""cosmic"" interlude? Check. Ecstatic drum'n'bass roller? Come and get it! Then there's ""Reminder""
column5: Steinway's contribution to the burgeoning canon of gauzy R&B
column6: complete with guest vocals from How to Dress Well himself. Tom Krell's falsetto is strained and pitchy
column7: and there are points where it might be confused for an ungenerous parody of Bon Iver. Steinway overcompensates by piling on turgid synths
column8: trap hi-hats
column9: and pitch-shifted echoes of Krell's voice run through oodles of reverb. It's a mess.

column1: Steinway sounds far more at home when he's making trap. Had he stuck to his favored lane
column2: in fact
column3: he could have gotten a potent six-track EP out of VOID. ""Core""
column4: with its Middle Eastern reed melody and jump-up vocal refrain
column5: is a veritable earthquake of a tune; it comes on like a .gif of a landslide demolishing a house
column6: over and over—awe-inspiring violence reduced to a few elegant strokes. ""Scylla""
column7: with its Koyaanisqatsi-inspired arpeggios and drum'n'bass undercurrents
column8: is busier and maybe even heavier
column9: with horn riffs that could go toe to toe with Hudson Mohawke's gnarliest anthems.

column1: Given that Steinway is still
column2: apparently
column3: making music as Clockwork—his last single under the alias
column4: ""Signals""
column5: came out in July
column6: on Dim Mak
column7: and it sounds like more of a sop to the EDM middle ground than ever—it does seem curious that there's such a wide gulf between that project and the music showcased on Void. In an electronic-music scene distinguished by its blurred lines
column8: and on an album allegedly meant to celebrate the same
column9: why does he continue to compartmentalize? Discussing how his sets vary from city to city
column10: he told Resident Advisor
column11: ""In the UK people may expect different things because they've grown up in a different scene and less of the EDM stuff has come through there. I guess I try to tone down the EDM stuff when I'm in Europe."" The comment
column12: like Void itself
column13:
sounds like he's hedging his bets.

"|20035.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20035-rl-grime-void/|5.5|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21116/homepage_large.db37a6c7.jpg|Privacy|30558.0|Raspberry Bulbs|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blackest Ever Black']|2014-12-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:54.379321|"

The success of HBO's True Detective—and the plagiarism charges that dogged the show’s first season—sent thousands of viewers scrambling for books by authors that most of them had never heard of before. Those authors included the contemporary horror writer Thomas Ligotti (the alleged victim of True Detective’s plagiarism) and Robert W. Chambers
column2: whose 1895 book The King in Yellow is referenced often throughout the show. Naturally
column3: H. P. Lovecraft—whom Chambers influenced and
column4: in turn
column5: who influenced Ligotti—also casts a shadow. Like a squirming colony of worms underneath an overturned rock
column6: that niche literary continuum found itself suddenly thrust into the spotlight. Privacy
column7: the third album by Brooklyn blackened-punk outfit Raspberry Bulbs
column8: also draws from that continuum
column9: according to frontman Marco del Rio
column10: who began the project as a solo affair following the demise of his black metal duo Bone Awl. There’s nothing novel in that connection; counting the number of rock bands that have cited Lovecraft alone would take ages. But what Privacy does so well
column11: regardless of the listener’s familiarity with del Rio’s cult inspirations
column12: is transpose the intangible dread of Ligotti
column13: Chambers
column14: and Lovecraft into a salvo of cold
column15: sharp jolts to the psyche.

column1: Raspberry Bulb’s last album
column2: 2013’s  Deformed Worship
column3: was a strong step in this direction
column4: but it also marked the project’s transition into a full band. The no-fi spew of Bone Awl had morphed into a murky howl
column5: and that distance slightly blunted the record’s impact. On Privacy
column6: though
column7: del Rio and company—including Rorschach’s Nicke Forté and Les Savy Fav’s Andrew Reuland
column8: both on guitar (and reunited two decades after their joint band Radio to Saturn)—don’t leave an inch of space in which to flinch. “Lionhead” staggers intrepidly into new dimensions of punk ugliness
column9: set at a tempo too fast to be sluggishly grungy and too slow to comfortably mosh to. Forté and Reuland
column10: old partners at guitar interplay
column11: splinter their riffs into each other
column12: leaving a nasty mess everywhere. The fully-rocking instrumental “Nail Biting” doesn’t justify its lack of vocals
column13: but it’s a nerve-jangling exhibition of lacerated harmonics makes del Rio’s absence a little less glaring. But when “Finger Bones
column14: ” prickly and abject
column15: gives del Rio room to chew out his own tongue while the band marches over the top of him
column16: his pinpoint application of chaos congeals into a sickening
column17: misanthropic logic.

column1: Del Rio has denied any hint of black-metal allegiance when it comes to Raspberry Bulbs
column2: but there’s no mistaking his blood-gurgling
column3: Quorthon-circa-Under the Sign of the Black Mark grunt-screech
column4: particularly on “Behind the Glass” and “Hopelessly Alive"" which embody an awestruck disgust in the face of grotesque eternity. It’s almost religious
column5: if such a thing as Raspberry Bulbs could be considered a creature of faith. There’s a perverse piety at play on “How the Strings Are Pulled""
column6: a Venom-meets-Negative Approach hymn to debasement and moral powerlessness. When the woah-woah-woahs in the chorus come deliriously close to comprising a pop hook
column7: it seems for a second as if Privacy might pierce its own veil and reveal its squishy humanity. But every time the album builds up a lick of sympathetic momentum
column8: it’s cruelly defused by one of the brief
column9: ambient interludes that break up the proper tracks—six numbered asides constructed of treated noise
column10: distorted spoken-word
column11: strangled strings
column12: and eerie keys that help elevate Privacy’s fractured
column13: labyrinthine torment above Deformed Worship’s more straightforward assault

column1: In The King in Yellow
column2: Chambers writes of “the blackness that surrounds me”—a trite phrase to 21st-century readers
column3: but one that carried far more existential weight in the author’s own time. Is Privacy’s “Light Surrounds Me” some kind of response to Chambers? The song itself certainly sounds as if it could be: del Rio slurs its title in spasms of loathing
column4: as if light were twice as horrifying as the alternative. Yet Privacy as a whole is vivid andwide-eyed
column5: with del Rio sounding more swaggeringly confident than ever about his utter lack of confidence. Doubt and fear as cleansing ecstasy: That cognitive dissonance is part of what makes del Rio’s literary antiheroes so cryptically enduring
column6: and it’s what makes Privacy so hideously hypnotic. “Big Grin""
column7: a skeletal
column8: garage-goth dirge that drags its carcass across five unforgiving minutes
column9: feels like del Rio’s ultimate exorcism—only instead of a release
column10: it’s a spiritual implosion. Unlike most bands that seek to probe the notion of a malevolent cosmos
column11: Raspberry Bulbs aren’t trying to cheaply translate cosmic awe into a stomping
column12: grandiose melodrama. Privacy is small
column13: pitiful
column14: tinny
column15: messy
column16: and emaciated
column17: and it dares to demand that mankind doesn’t have the right to feel any differently. When punk stares into the abyss
column18:
this is what stares back.

"|19876.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19876-raspberry-bulbs-privacy/|8.2|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21117/homepage_large.dba744f9.jpg|Movement Building Vol. 1|30958.0|Gabriel Saloman|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Shelter Press']|2014-12-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:55.034218|"

When I interviewed Gabriel Saloman in 2012
column2: he insisted that the work of Yellow Swans—his prolific noise/drone duo with Pete Swanson—was “body music
column3: ” intended to get limbs moving and pulses accelerating. Unfortunately
column4: audiences didn’t always respond that way. “A lot of folks weren’t able to go there with Yellow Swans over the years
column5: ” he lamented. “People didn’t reciprocate with their bodies as much as I always hoped.”

column1: The respective solo careers of Saloman and Swanson (who dissolved Yellow Swans in 2008) are perhaps attempts to rectify that situation. In Swanson’s case
column2: he’s pioneered a visceral brand of techno-noise that has scored him gigs on body-filled dancefloors. For Saloman
column3: body-sound interaction has taken the form of scores created for choreographed dance performances. The Disciplined Body is his third such work in the past three years
column4: following 2012’s Adhere and 2013’s Soldier’s Requiem. All three combine tense
column5: driving soundscapes with threads of kinetic narrative. If you didn’t know they were made to accompany dancers
column6: you might guess it anyway; the music is constantly moving
column7: and often in many directions at once.

column1: On Saloman’s previous two albums
column2: he concocted that motion with diverse sounds and styles
column3: using several instruments and noticeable sonic shifts from piece to piece. Both are thematically coherent
column4: but they cover lots of terrain. The Disciplined Body is more narrowly-focused. It’s a single 35-minute piece stretched across two LP sides
column5: and in some ways it’s a minimalist work. Long tones predominate
column6: and they’re not always dense; in places this is some of the simplest
column7: least-layered sound Saloman has made.

column1: Yet The Disciplined Body continually builds and escalates
column2: always going somewhere. Much of that effect is due to Saloman’s use of percussion
column3: a tool that seems to have particularly caught his fascination since Yellow Swans’ demise. It was especially crucial on Soldier’s Requiem
column4: whose militaristic drumming and march-like beats evoked the aftermath of war. Percussion is more subtle and sparing on The Disciplined Body
column5: but it’s just as integral. When it does weave its way into the narrative—particularly in two rattling
column6: snare-roll-heavy sections on side one—its thrust gives Saloman’s ambience a tangibly physical dimension.

column1: In fact
column2: the percussion is so important that it has an effect even when it’s not there. There’s no discernible beat for the first half of the album’s second side
column3: yet you feel a pulse
column4: a slow wave that rises even when it ebbs. Halfway through
column5: rhythm emerges in a heartbeat-mimicking bass-drum throb. That pushes the surrounding music into determined overdrive
column6: as reflective guitar tones coagulate into miles-deep noise. This compelling climax recalls some of Yellow Swans’ best moments (the majestic “Mass Mirage” comes to mind)
column7: but with the kind of muscle-stretching that’s specific to Saloman’s current vision. It’s like watching a human form being gradually inflated until it becomes a giant.

column1: All this physicality—the way Saloman’s music embodies human motion—is perhaps why his solo work doesn’t feel dry or incomplete. Often scores are too conceptual to sound like fullly-formed music
column2: or their scope seems limited—you sense there’s something else going on
column3: but since you can’t see it
column4: you can’t really hear it either. But nothing’s missing on The Disciplined Body. Everything you need to know is right there in Gabriel Saloman’s rich
column5:
moving music.

"|19877.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19877-gabriel-saloman-movement-building-vol-1/|7.7|Marc Masters

column2:
'Interscope']|2014-11-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:55.586496|"

Eminem's music has been unrelievedly awful now for a full decade. The tenor and quality of that awfulness have varied slightly—2004's Encore was awful in an embarrassed
column3: shrugging
column4: transparent way; Relapse's awfulness lay in its regressive puerility. On Recovery
column5: he discovered a new and commercially successful kind of awful
column6: mixing the ugly viscera of domestic abuse with power-ballad glucose.

column1: The awfulness he settled on for last year's endless Marshall Mathers LP 2 seems to be his new default: He's aggressively
column2: thoroughly
column3: eagerly awful
column4: like a sociopathic A-student who thinks he's figured out exactly what you are looking for. In this case
column5: it's snarling syllables and endless vitriol. He has never been working harder
column6: Eminem has observed in interviews; in the sense that he's released a 78-minute album and another disc of new music all in the last year
column7: he's right. But the wearying
column8: dispiriting
column9: and frankly numbing output of his current career phase isn't ""work."" It's maniacal persistence
column10: of the same sort that leads some douche to text a woman 38 times about the $32k he made in June.

column1: Seconds into the 2xCD label compilation Shady XV
column2: which pairs 12 new songs with a disc of ""greatest hits
column3: Eminem fires up his rappity-rap sputtering chainsaw
column4: and it never ceases for the spiritually exhausting hour that follows. Even at his peak
column5: his rapping was never melodious
column6: but at his nadir
column7: he has all the musicality of a leaf-blower. The production functions simply
column8: like a stopwatch: It's there to tell him when to start and when to stop
column9: and occasionally a juiced-up power-rock chorus interrupts him. Submitting production to an Eminem album must feel
column10: for a producer
column11: something like a novelist feeding their manuscript into a wood chipper. On the one hand
column12: you are guaranteed unprecedented exposure
column13: and on the other
column14: you are all but ensuring that no one will notice a note of your work.

column1: These days
column2: Eminem raps in a near-constant shout
column3: with every line escalating into rage spittle that erases all tension or continuity or emotional impact. In his will to annihilate
column4: he's also abandoned all claims to sense. ""Affable guy next door's laughable/ My next whore's gonna have mechanical arms that'll jack me off with a lotion dispenser/ With a motion sensor/ No emotion
column5: hence I guess a sick prick dies hard/ I got a Magic Johnson
column6: he babbles on ""Shady XV"". He then goes onto say ""I'll slap Linda Ronstadt with a lobster"" and adds something about ""Charles Hamilton slash Manson and Bronson (grr) animal snarls."" There's nothing here to be impressed by.

column1: Or observe this string of logorrhea from ""Right For Me"": ""Roses are violet
column2: mollys are blue
column3: lost in a ball of confusion it's all an illusion/ It's probably the shrooms I'm on
column4: cuz I think I started hallucinating/ Cuz I just thought I heard Jay Electronica and Odd Future's new shit/ And all I could do was just follow the music and end up with Paula Abdul at Lollapalooza filling water balloons with nail polish remover."" Could you even read all that without your eyes glazing over?

column1: Mathers' great talent—his 180-degree ear for how everything can be made to rhyme with everything else
column2: how chains of these rhyming lines can be erected into dizzying towers—has officially devolved into a tic. His verses denature all sense of pronunciation and meter and natural speech rhythm; you could probably read this review as one long Eminem verse.

column1: The glimmers of self-awareness that pop up here and there are the passing thoughts of a superstar
column2: bobbing bottles of insight in an ocean of gibberish. ""A martyr on a private charter/ Whose life could be harder?"" he sneers at himself on ""Shady XV"". On ""Fine Line""
column3: he wonders ""Is it really my soul to keep
column4: or have I sold it cheap?"" Occasionally he buries a confession in plain sight
column5: as on ""Fine Line"": ""Sometimes I just wanna walk into Target and look at shit
column6: browse
column7: I don't even wanna buy nothing
column8: I just wanna fuckin' wanna walk around inside it/ Look how excited I sound when I get to talking about life and everything about it I miss."" There's nothing artful or even interesting about that phrasing
column9: or the way he tortures and twists the vowels so they rhyme (""sometimes"" finds its way mashed up against ""I don't""
column10: which is forced to then rhyme with ""I just""
column11: ""inside it""
column12: ""excited I sound"" and ""I miss""
column13: a mess of nonsensical emphases)
column14: but the feeling is legible
column15: an isolation and a prevailing sense of unworthiness that has always lingered beneath Mathers' hateful snarl.

column1: The greatest-hits disc is a misnomer: It's mostly a grab-bag of Shady throwaways and deep cuts. But there are some good songs here: Obie Trice gets three of them
column2: all good and worth rescuing from the commercially doomed albums they were buried on. There's the Dre-produced ""The Setup""
column3: from Cheers; ""Cry Now [Shady Remix]""; and the Entourage theme song ""Wanna Know""
column4: in which Trice spits over a tumbling garage rock sample. For some reason
column5: several cuts from 50 Cent's Get Rich or Die Tryin'
column6: one of the most ubiquitous rap albums in history
column7: are reproduced. There are a couple of decent
column8: bruising Slaughterhouse songs. But the presence of these songs is mostly a signifier of the Shady Industry
column9: the group of hangers-on that on some level seems to keep Mathers going.

column1: On the saccharine Sia-featuring single ""Guts Over Fear""
column2: Eminem baldly admits to resorting to the sophomore and puerile tactics here—threatening to punch Lana Del Rey in a BET freestyle
column3: or threatening to rape Iggy Azalea on ""Vegas""—because he has no other ideas
column4: and nothing further to say
column5: and is painfully aware of it: ""There's no more emotion for me to pull from/ Just a bunch of playful songs that I make for fun/ So
column6: to the break of dawn
column7: here I go
column8: recycling the same old song
column9: he says. The frankness of the message is remarkable: We're stuck with him
column10:
an aging white man with nothing left to say gripping the biggest bullhorn in hip-hop.

"|20036.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20036-various-artists-shady-xv/|2.0|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21275/homepage_large.99106f9c.jpg|21 Again|2846.0|Mouse on Mars|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Monkeytown']|2014-11-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:16:56.128728|"

A little more than halfway through the second disc of 21 Again
column2: a 2xCD collection of new collaborative tracks and guest-artist birthday greetings celebrating Mouse on Mars' 21 years together
column3: Prefuse 73's Scott Herren can be heard reflecting on how he got into the pathfinding German electronic group and its peers. ""All the like
column4: scholastic
column5: kind of academic '90s things that were happening there
column6: I was really into

column9: like
column10: 'Oh
column11: we're gonna do electronic music
column12: ' like <i>boom
column13: boom—no four-four shit. You guys always did something melodic.""

column1: Herren's remarks may strike a note of familiar nostalgia for longtime Mouse on Mars fans
column2: and for anyone somehow stumbling on this loose
column3: playful
column4: slightly overstuffed record unaware it will be the first real clue as to what all this is about. Since the duo of Jan St. Werner and Andi Toma formed Mouse on Mars in 1993
column5: they've blurred the edges of techno
column6: electro-acoustic music
column7: and pop tunefulness over the course of about a dozen albums
column8: most recently 2012's virtuosically maximalist Parastrophics. They've also long indulged a collaborative streak; just recently
column9: Toma produced Africa Express's star-studded tribute to Terry Riley's ""In C"". On 21 Again
column10: they bring together slightly more than 21 collaborations between Mouse on Mars and other artists
column11: plus several recorded messages such as the one from Herren.

column1: The results
column2: spanning 32 tracks and nearly two hours
column3: are best approached as a huge party full of Mouse on Mars' old friends. It can be overwhelming
column4: with so many distinguished and varied attendees you'd be hard-pressed to remember your conversations the next morning
column5: but there's more than enough squishy-synthed whimsy here to make 21 Again a worthwhile listen
column6: particularly for those veteran fans but also for that hypothetical newcomer
column7: who might replicate Herren's experience of being inspired by Mouse on Mars and their extended musical family. And if the broader culture takes nothing else away from this set

column1: Mouse on Mars have always resisted easy categorization
column2: and that's evident in the sheer eclecticism on display here. One of 21 Again's unique draws is a one-off reunion by fellow German duo Funkstörung
column3: who split in 2008; their lovely

column5: mesmerizing guitar-and-groove workouts in the locked-in style of what once would've been called post-rock (Tortoise track ""Shoe Fly"")
column6: twitchy disco-funk (""Fertilized"" with Cavern of Anti-Matter
column7: a project featuring Stereolab's Tim Gane)
column8: off-kilter synth-pop (""Lost and Found"" with Eric D Clark)
column9: or a contemplative
column10: storytelling reverie (""My Toe Is on Fire

column12: we're gonna do electronic music
column13: <i>boom
column14: boom.""

column6: the cathartic tribal-drum ululations of ""Nkanka"" with the Boredoms'/OOIOO's Yoshimi P-We

column11: berserk track with Tyondai Braxton

column13: 21 Again could also almost serve as a survey course of the past couple of decades in experimental music.

column1: The birthday messages
column2: though
column3: drive home the sense of 21 Again as a low-stakes
column4: insular bit of fun rather than a sweeping artistic statement. The Fall's Mark E. Smith
column5: who joined up with Mouse on Mars in 2007 as Von Südenfed

Non-German speakers will have to settle for being charmed by the laughter during the best wishes from artist Ingrid Wiener and her husband Oswald. A Hawk and a Hacksaw turn their greeting into another chance for musical collaboration

column8: which uses the 19th-century melody that's customary for such occasions
column9: brings a call from the copyright lawyers
column10: well
column11: 21st birthdays often involve audacious decisions. After 21 years
column12:
Mouse on Mars remain joyously unpredictable.

This year
column2: for Halloween
column3: Hound frontman Perry Shall went as AC/DC's Angus Young. I don't mean to say Shall merely ""went as"" Angus Young for Halloween; what I mean is
column4: from the socks-and-shorts to the upturned brim
column5: this dude was Angus Young. I bring this up to underscore Shall's greatest strength as a frontman: he has a real knack for inhabiting the look and feel of a very particular era of rock'n'roll
column6: the post-prog
column7: pre-NWOBHM intermingling of hard-rock and proto-punk. At no point during Hound's Out of Time—a triangulation of ""Highway Star""
column8: the first few Queens of the Stone Age LPs
column9: and a not-unhealthy fixation with one Lemmy Kilmister—do Shall and company attempt to flaunt tradition

column13: bongwater-splattered rock'n'roll
column14: the kind designed to sound particularly righteous coming from a pinstriped AMC Gremlin.

column1: More than anything
column2: Out of Time is unrelenting; just over 27 minutes of low rumbles and snaky leads
column3: pausing only for the delicately fingerpicked ""Colintro""—courtesy of bassist Colin McGinniss
column4: also of None More Black—just past the halfway point. Shall's not a flashy player

column6: as a student of the classics
column7: he's picked up just the right combination of attack and restraint
column8: and Out of Time does lean every bit as well as mean. Taken together

column10: mid-fi tunnelvision—and near-monomaniacal drive are transportive
column11: beamed in directly from the middle of a long
column12: dark night spent blasting down some backwater at 90 MPH
column13: lids heavy
column14: heart pounding.

column1: Leadoff single and snarling highlight ""Little One"" plunges a particularly toothsome Shall riff headlong into a roaring McGinniss bassline. Better still is ""I Can't Take It No More""
column2: an anxious
column3: hard-charging punker that finds an unusually excitable-sounding Shall screaming his way around the chorus. He's not exactly a brazen presence behind the mic; throughout plenty of Out of Time
column4: he coats his voice in a thin layer of fuzz
column5: or deadpans his way through his delivery
column6: allowing certain lines to get stuck in the surrounding sludge. Even at full howl
column7: though
column8: Shall's never in any danger of overpowering these monstrous riffs
column9: and Out of Time sounds best whenever he drops the inhibitions and fully leans into these songs. To that end
column10: the Sabbath-indebted slowdown—""Houdini""
column11: ""Stupid Dreams""—sandwiching the outlying ""Colintro"" is a slight momentum-sapper; they don't plod
column12: exactly
column13: but they don't quite get the blood going like the scrappier stuff surrounding them.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Out of Time isn't much to chew on. While Shall smartly sidesteps the dunderheaded machismo too often associated with capital-R rock revivalism
column3: what he offers in its stead—anxiety
column4: boredom
column5: and self-doubt
column6: more or less—is only a mild improvement. ""If god was real
column7: I think she'd be disgraced
column8: Shall sings on ""Stupid Dreams""; it's maybe the single most intriguing thought to be found on Out of Time
column9: one Shall all but leaves unexplored. Still
column10: this de-emphasis on lyrics is in keeping with tradition; despite what your uncle's trying to tell you with that wrongheaded ""Led Zeppelin vs. Nicki Minaj"" meme he keeps slapping on your Facebook wall
column11: the hard rock canon Hound are harkening back to has a long
column12: storied tradition of dumb
column13: overwrought
column14: or otherwise beside-the-point lyrics. At this point
column15: Hound seemingly aren't all that interested in toppling their influences or killing their idols; instead
column16: they're trying to inhabit them
column17: to pile up enough riffs to tap into that deathless feeling of plowing down the road
column18: windows down

column20: the night ahead of them. That much
column21:
they nail.

Best known for defining the pulse of Fela Kuti’s propulsive Afrobeat sound
column2: the self-taught Tony Allen is a near superhuman combination of metronomic sense of time
column3: light touch
column4: economy
column5: endurance
column6: and musicality. Though it took a long time
column7: his distinctive beat is part of the world’s musical vocabulary now. Since parting ways with Fela
column8: he’s done quite a range of work
column9: including a couple of recent
column10: fairly high-profile collaborations with Damon Albarn that took him pretty far away from the pigeonhole people tend to place him in on the basis of his best-known playing.

column1: Film of Life doesn’t quite break new ground for Allen
column2: but it does offer a pretty solid and succinct demonstration of Afrobeat’s adaptability to changing times. There are no side-long epics in the Fela mold here
column3: but Allen packs quite a bit into each of these four-to-seven-minute-tracks
column4: building up from his own drums grooves with hypnotic guitar and bass patterns
column5: a richly arranged horn section
column6: and an assortment of other sounds that are nearly all overwhelmed by the massive rhythm that dominates everything.

column1: Allen himself handles vocals on the first two tracks
column2: mostly talking in his deep bass register and aided by a female chorus
column3: narrating a personal history and thanking the listener for being there. His voice is appropriately situated well down in the mix; he does his best talking with his hands
column4: and though he shows a little uncharacteristic flash here and there
column5: the really impressive thing about Allen is the way he can take a simple
column6: slow beat like the one on ""Tiger’s Skip"" and make it sing when a lot of drummers would have trouble just staying in time at that tempo. Comparing it to the much faster beat on the storming
column7: spacey funk instrumental ""Ewa"" reveals a lot about what makes his playing so special; no matter what else is going on
column8: Allen has an ability to stay steady and fill time with exactly as much embellishment as necessary.

column1: Albarn’s guest vocal turn on ""Go Back"" provides the album’s highlight and the closest thing to a single that it has to offer. The man could sound sad singing ""The Wheels on the Bus""
column2: and the contrast of his hang-dog delivery and Allen’s spryness makes for a song as good as anything the two have done together in <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/9778-the-good-the-bad-the-queen/"" target=""_blank"">the Good
column3: the Bad
column4:
and the Queen or Rocket Juice & the Moon. Moments like this and Kuku’s totally unexpected Auto-Tuned vocal in the second half of ""Koko Dance"" take Film of Life a few steps past a simple summary of the things Allen excels at and make it something to hear even for people who aren’t Afrobeat obsessives.

As prices for sample permissions have skyrocketed and the musicians whose work is being borrowed have become more litigious
column2: producers are less willing to use sampling in their music. We’re seeing a lot of that in hip-hop
column3: where producers from Kanye to El-P are simply making their own beats to imitate the sounds that they love
column4: and in that way
column5: avoiding the ire of the original creators. The development has also reverberated within the world of formerly sample-happy electronic music
column6: where even big-name producers whose entire process was once screwing around with samples have begun to switch up their style.

column1: That’s certainly the case with Charlie Yin: the producer
column2: working under the name Giraffage
column3: was known most well for sampled beats like the one on last year’s thrilling Alpha Pup single
column4: ""Close 2 Me""
column5: and his remix of the entirety of The-Dream album Love Hate. Yin signed to Fool’s Gold this past June and promptly announced a new EP by releasing a remix of R. Kelly’s ""Ignition (Remix)"". But when the EP
column6: No Reason
column7: arrived last week it was accompanied by an interesting disclosure: the songs on it were written completely sample-free.

column1: That’s what Giraffage says
column2: anyway. Listening to the EP
column3: fans will notice a wealth of the same kind of tricks that Yin hooked them with in the first place. There are still plenty of vocals and sound effects present here: ""Hello"" kicks off the record with a screwed up version of the phrase: ""I just want to hear that we’re ok"" and those words echo throughout the track
column4: set between the sound of iOS notifications
column5: dial tones
column6: static
column7: and the lushest of synthesizers. When he talks about eschewing samples
column8: Yin may just mean that he wrote all the instrumental music before adding borrowed sounds. But even if he recorded the other noises himself
column9: their variety and interpolation contributes to the same sense of dynamism and depth that's always powered his music. Which is to say that
column10: even if everything about his process has changed
column11: not much about his music has.

column1: Which is good news: Giraffage excels at wringing a variety of feelings out of his tracks
column2: using changes in register as an emotional dial. By changing how high or low a voice registers
column3: he’s able to shift the way we understand what we’re hearing
column4: as on ""Tell Me""
column5: in which the title phrase is spun back and forth so that it’s made to sound like a dialogue between lovers. But even more important is what’s happening lower in the mix
column6: where a wall of sound rears up
column7: suffusing the listener in colored sonics so deep that the words become a small part of an enormous sensation.

column1: This kind of sudden eruption is typical of Giraffage; the producer's become a populist favorite as much because of his willingness to use traditional drops as his penchant for candy-colored R&B. ""Be With You""
column2: the last and best song on the record
column3: pulls the beat out several times only to reintroduce it with fringed
column4: lightning-rod synths on top of it. Fans will recognize the instrumental; it’s the same one that was constructed around that R. Kelly remix
column5: though it actually works better as a standalone.

column1: And maybe that’s really what Giraffage means when he talks about his new approach. His work with remixes and samples in general has always reflected a remarkable sense of depth
column2: so much so that
column3: if you were to pull out the original artist’s work
column4: you would still be left with the sense of hearing a complete track. More than ever
column5: the music he’s constructed on No Reason has the ability to stand on its own. But add the vocals and the ticks
column6: the bleeps and the bloops
column7: and you’ve got style in addition to that solidity. Those smaller elements make Yin who he is as a musician
column8: and samples or no samples
column9:
here’s hoping he doesn’t abandon them anytime soon.

Roosevelt
column2: New York is a beautiful social experiment gone awry. As post-war urban renewal squeezed black families into towering inner-city housing developments and whites out into their sprawling suburbs
column3: this hamlet near the south end of western Long Island’s Queens bordering Nassau County served as a template for suburban integration. Blacks and whites cohabited there for years until real estate agents’ racist scare tactics pushed white families to sell at a loss and funneled new black ones into the same homes at inflated prices. The city's methodical transformation would have a profound effect on Nassau local Carlton Ridenhour
column4: better known as Chuck D. On the short trip from home to nearby Adelphi University
column5: where he studied graphic design
column6: Chuck could watch the soft segregated lower-middle-class black community of Roosevelt give way to golf and country clubs for the affluent
column7: predominantly white Garden City
column8: home to Adelphi and a pair of prestigious prep schools. First-hand experience of racialized contempt
column9: along with a rich education from civil rights activist parents
column10: sparked a righteous ire in Chuck that would burn hot and bright in the following years.

column1: Public Enemy formed around Chuck’s gig at Adelphi’s student radio station
column2: gaining momentum as he and his friends’ forays into rap music grew increasingly accomplished. Their squelching
column3: skeletal ""Public Enemy No. 1"" won a fan in Def Jam co-founder Rick Rubin
column4: kicking off a lengthy courtship of Chuck
column5: sidekick Flavor Flav
column6: DJ Terminator X and producers Hank Shocklee and Eric Sadler. Two years later
column7: the group caved and signed with the label. A debut album (1987’s Yo! Bum Rush the Show) and a package tour with Run-D.M.C. and LL Cool J followed. The music was boldly gritty
column8: if a touch late to the party
column9: scooped by advances in landmark singles by Big Daddy Kane and Eric B. & Rakim released the same year. The live show was gripping
column10: Chuck and Flav stalking the stage as ""Minister of Information"" Professor Griff cut in with searing political diatribes and the S1w’s
column11: the group’s security detail
column12: performed silent combat exercises with toy rifles in the background. It was black power theater. It shocked American audiences cold. Concerns about P.E.’s image and intent quickly arose: Were they gangsters? Terrorists? Separatists? Yo! stalled out around 400
column13: 000 units sold
column14: a modest turnout in the wake of the Beastie Boys’ blockbuster Licensed to Ill
column15: and Public Enemy entered into a contentious dance with the media that would precipitate their greatest successes and their darkest hardships.

column1: In retrospect
column2: Yo! Bum Rush the Show was a blueprint. What came after it was the work of a well-rehearsed unit keenly aware of its purpose and capabilities. Released the following summer
column3: Public Enemy’s sophomore album It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back was a brash refinement of the themes of Yo! and a jab at the jaws of detractors
column4: high and low. ""Bring the Noise"" and ""Don’t Believe the Hype"" railed against the press
column5: holding up the lurid sensationalism surrounding the group as a warning against trusting anything you read. ""Caught
column6: Can We Get a Witness?"" is a nightmare where P.E. gets nabbed for sampling. (More on that later.) Nation teemed with a didactic social consciousness too. ""She Watch Channel Zero?!"" strikes out against junk television
column7: while ""Night of the Living Baseheads"" addresses the crack epidemic
column8: and ""Black Steel in the Hour of Chaos"" leads a draft-dodging conscientious objector through a vengeful jailbreak. Chuck’s booming ministerial baritone sparred with Flav’s piercing yawp in a masterful hero-and-sidekick interplay. The message couldn’t entice the masses without the levity; the levity was gimmicky without revolutionary grit giving it weight.

column1: Nation found a way to expound on the explosive soundscapes of the debut without exhausting listeners or cluttering the mix. Chuck
column2: Sadler
column3: and the Shocklee brothers’ production as the Bomb Squad was as thick as its source material was diverse; it was rap
column4: soul
column5: rock
column6: funk and musique concrète all at once. ""Most people were saying that rap music was noise
column7: Hank Shocklee told Rolling Stone in 1989
column8: ""and we decided
column9: ‘If they think it’s noise
column10: let’s show them noise.’"" ""She Watch Channel Zero?!"" pulls its central riff from Slayer’s thrash classic ""Angel of Death"". ""Night of the Living Baseheads"" outfits a stable of trusty James Brown samples with over a dozen assorted soul and rap tidbits and bridges
column11: folding in elements of ESG’s ""UFO"" and David Bowie’s ""Fame"". Snippets of legendary speeches from Jesse Jackson and Malcolm X and stage banter from Public Enemy’s successful European tour formed connective tissue between songs for a unified listening experience that only let up briefly in the middle and finally
column12: at the end. The Bomb Squad built beats like ships in a bottle
column13: delicately stitching tiny pieces of black history into layered blasts of sound. Public Enemy looked and sounded a fright to the uninitiated
column14: but careful attention showed every piece of this black radical machine moving in perfect concert.

column1: Nation of Millions netted Public Enemy the elusive American audience and platinum sales their debut couldn’t
column2: and it changed the face of rap music. The hip-hop landscape of ‘89-’90 was dotted with sample-heavy sons of Nation. Chuck sent early copies of the album out west to Dre and Ice Cube
column3: and N.W.A.’s landmark Straight Outta Compton cropped up like a gangsta rap rejoinder to the Bomb Squad ethos. (Cube would later tap the team for production on his post-N.W.A. solo debut AmeriKKKa’s Most Wanted.) De La Soul’s 3 Feet High and Rising and the Beastie Boys’ Paul’s Boutique added a playful
column4: psychedelic charm to the proceedings. Nation’s message of black self-sufficiency resonated through the proudly Afrocentric art of A Tribe Called Quest
column5: X Clan
column6: Brand Nubian and more. Beyond the '80s
column7: the music of Nation of Millions would continue to find new life in unexpected places: Weezer’s 1996 comeback single ""El Scorcho"" nicked its ""I’m the epitome of public enemy"" barb from ""Don’t Believe the Hype""
column8: and Jay-Z’s 2006 post-retirement salvo ""Show Me What You Got"" is a nod to Nation’s ""Show ‘Em Whatcha Got"". (Without Public Enemy we don’t get Kanye West; in addition to sampling the Long Island legends liberally
column9: Kanye inherited a bit of his fearless politics and kitchen sink beat construction from here.)

column1: Critics warmed to Public Enemy in the wake of It Takes a Nation of Millions but remained suspicious of their political affiliations. ""If Farrakhan’s a prophet my dick’s bigger than Don Howland’s
column2: Village Voice scribe Robert Christgau quipped in a year-end roundup
column3: ""but that doesn’t make Nation of Millions anything less than the bravest and most righteous experimental pop of the decade."" Others would be less warm as Professor Griff’s incendiary ethics began to strike sour notes. He publicly accused white America of bestiality during a press-filled gig at Rikers Island in 1988 and voiced a shocking disdain for Jews and gays in various interviews overseas. In the spring of 1989
column4: Washington Times scribe David Mills sat Griff down and coaxed out a rant charged with cold
column5: ugly hate speech that would quickly torch the group’s reputation on both sides of the Atlantic.

column1: Privately
column2: Chuck struggled with how to respond to the controversy. At first
column3: he stood by Griff
column4: then he announced Griff’s expulsion from the group
column5: then
column6: amid a growing media firestorm
column7: he disbanded Public Enemy entirely. The hiatus was short-lived. Spike Lee’s blistering racial relations passion play Do the Right Thing debuted a week after the firestorm with a new Public Enemy song as its theme. ""Fight the Power"" summarized the mood of both the film and the climate it was released into. It telegraphed the tense discomfort of a New York summer where innocent youth from Central Park to Bensonhurst would pay the ultimate price for being black in the wrong place at the wrong time. By July
column8: the seemingly inactive group had a #1 Billboard rap single
column9: and work was quietly underway on a Nation of Millions follow-up.

column1: Fear of a Black Planet from 1990 made kindling of the previous summer’s anti-Public Enemy sentiment
column2: quoting the group’s biggest critics in interludes and ribbing them in the songs. ""Contract on the World Love Jam"" weaves negative news reports into a scene-setting intro; later ""Incident at 66.6 FM"" sets outraged calls from a Chuck D squareoff with New York political radio host Alan Colmes over sedate keys and drums
column3: playing the grumps for squares without even responding to their charges. A late album Terminator X showcase snarkily titled ""Leave This Off Your Fuckin Charts"" is a tenacious dare. Elsewhere
column4: Fear pulls the camera off P.E. to speak to community issues. ""Anti-Nigger Machine"" and ""Who Stole the Soul?"" levied heavy accusations of censorship while ""911 Is a Joke"" explored black community police mistrust and ""Fear of a Black Planet"" tackled apprehension about interracial dating. Sourcing Public Enemy’s media struggles back to age-old racial strife was a brash
column5: heavy-handed play
column6: but Fear’s genius trick was coating its righteous rage in music that aimed to groove where earlier songs seemed to want to maim.

column1: Fear of a Black Planet finds the Bomb Squad at the height of their powers
column2: assembling deeply intricate grooves out of infinitesimal building blocks. ""Pollywannacracka"" cycles through a breakneck array of sounds inside of its first 10 seconds and modulates between spacious verses and a jam-packed chorus
column3: bubbling into bedlam whenever Chuck stops rapping. ""Fight the Power"" manages to cram over a dozen different samples into five minutes of shockingly smooth funk. What sets these songs apart from the last batch is that their structure was often as varied as their list of ingredients. They didn’t just modulate between similar verses and choruses. These compositions breathed
column4: moved
column5: changed from one refrain to the next
column6: from one second to the next. A new sound showed face on every listen. Fear of a Black Planet deftly stated the case for hip-hop as savvy collage art rather than pastiche. Sure
column7: they borrowed liberally from pre-existing music
column8: but these patchwork symphonies bore scant resemblance to their source material.

column1: It should be noted that none of this can ever happen again. Biz Markie was sued over an unauthorized sample in 1991
column2: and <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Upright_Music
column3: _Ltd._v._Warner_Bros._Records_Inc."" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the judge’s ruling required future producers to seek the original artist’s clearance before incorporating a sample into a new composition. Overnight it became forbiddingly difficult and expensive to incorporate even a handful of samples into a new beat. The nightmare of ""Caught
column4: Can We Get a Witness?"" had become the hard reality. Producers scaled back their creations
column5: often augmenting one choice groove with a bevy of instrumental embellishments. This is how we arrive at the lush live band pomp of West Coast G-funk
column6: the cold synthetics of early 2000s East Coast rap
column7: and the gothic textures of Southern crunk and trap. The early Public Enemy masterpieces remain unique and inimitable now
column8: relics of a world irreparably changed though in a few notable ways
column9: very much the same.

column1: The strife that birthed Nation of Millions and Black Planet is mirrored in some of the upheaval of 2014. The business of hip-hop has changed
column2: as free mixtapes have supplanted retail albums as the chief method of kicking off a rap career. Artistic freedom can evaporate at the drop of a gavel. (see: Lord Finesse’s pursuit of Mac Miller for borrowing a beat on a free release.) Hip-hop has again had its political mettle tested by social injustices too systemic to deny. Returning to It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back and Fear of a Black Planet for these just-released reissues is an encouraging reminder of what a hip-hop album can be to the world
column3:
