"|19997.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19997-public-enemy-it-takes-a-nation-of-millions-to-hold-us-backfear-of-a-black-planet/|10.0|Craig Jenkins

column1:
1|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21255/homepage_large.486c0883.jpg|Fear of a Black Planet|3411.0|Public Enemy|['Rap']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Def Jam']|2014-11-25 00:00:00|1990|2016-06-11 16:16:59.379669|"

Roosevelt
column2: New York is a beautiful social experiment gone awry. As post-war urban renewal squeezed black families into towering inner-city housing developments and whites out into their sprawling suburbs
column3: this hamlet near the south end of western Long Island’s Queens bordering Nassau County served as a template for suburban integration. Blacks and whites cohabited there for years until real estate agents’ racist scare tactics pushed white families to sell at a loss and funneled new black ones into the same homes at inflated prices. The city's methodical transformation would have a profound effect on Nassau local Carlton Ridenhour
column4: better known as Chuck D. On the short trip from home to nearby Adelphi University
column5: where he studied graphic design
column6: Chuck could watch the soft segregated lower-middle-class black community of Roosevelt give way to golf and country clubs for the affluent
column7: predominantly white Garden City
column8: home to Adelphi and a pair of prestigious prep schools. First-hand experience of racialized contempt
column9: along with a rich education from civil rights activist parents
column10: sparked a righteous ire in Chuck that would burn hot and bright in the following years.

column1: Public Enemy formed around Chuck’s gig at Adelphi’s student radio station
column2: gaining momentum as he and his friends’ forays into rap music grew increasingly accomplished. Their squelching
column3: skeletal ""Public Enemy No. 1"" won a fan in Def Jam co-founder Rick Rubin
column4: kicking off a lengthy courtship of Chuck
column5: sidekick Flavor Flav
column6: DJ Terminator X and producers Hank Shocklee and Eric Sadler. Two years later
column7: the group caved and signed with the label. A debut album (1987’s Yo! Bum Rush the Show) and a package tour with Run-D.M.C. and LL Cool J followed. The music was boldly gritty
column8: if a touch late to the party
column9: scooped by advances in landmark singles by Big Daddy Kane and Eric B. & Rakim released the same year. The live show was gripping
column10: Chuck and Flav stalking the stage as ""Minister of Information"" Professor Griff cut in with searing political diatribes and the S1w’s
column11: the group’s security detail
column12: performed silent combat exercises with toy rifles in the background. It was black power theater. It shocked American audiences cold. Concerns about P.E.’s image and intent quickly arose: Were they gangsters? Terrorists? Separatists? Yo! stalled out around 400
column13: 000 units sold
column14: a modest turnout in the wake of the Beastie Boys’ blockbuster Licensed to Ill
column15: and Public Enemy entered into a contentious dance with the media that would precipitate their greatest successes and their darkest hardships.

column1: In retrospect
column2: Yo! Bum Rush the Show was a blueprint. What came after it was the work of a well-rehearsed unit keenly aware of its purpose and capabilities. Released the following summer
column3: Public Enemy’s sophomore album It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back was a brash refinement of the themes of Yo! and a jab at the jaws of detractors
column4: high and low. ""Bring the Noise"" and ""Don’t Believe the Hype"" railed against the press
column5: holding up the lurid sensationalism surrounding the group as a warning against trusting anything you read. ""Caught
column6: Can We Get a Witness?"" is a nightmare where P.E. gets nabbed for sampling. (More on that later.) Nation teemed with a didactic social consciousness too. ""She Watch Channel Zero?!"" strikes out against junk television
column7: while ""Night of the Living Baseheads"" addresses the crack epidemic
column8: and ""Black Steel in the Hour of Chaos"" leads a draft-dodging conscientious objector through a vengeful jailbreak. Chuck’s booming ministerial baritone sparred with Flav’s piercing yawp in a masterful hero-and-sidekick interplay. The message couldn’t entice the masses without the levity; the levity was gimmicky without revolutionary grit giving it weight.

column1: Nation found a way to expound on the explosive soundscapes of the debut without exhausting listeners or cluttering the mix. Chuck
column2: Sadler
column3: and the Shocklee brothers’ production as the Bomb Squad was as thick as its source material was diverse; it was rap
column4: soul
column5: rock
column6: funk and musique concrète all at once. ""Most people were saying that rap music was noise
column7: Hank Shocklee told Rolling Stone in 1989
column8: ""and we decided
column9: ‘If they think it’s noise
column10: let’s show them noise.’"" ""She Watch Channel Zero?!"" pulls its central riff from Slayer’s thrash classic ""Angel of Death"". ""Night of the Living Baseheads"" outfits a stable of trusty James Brown samples with over a dozen assorted soul and rap tidbits and bridges
column11: folding in elements of ESG’s ""UFO"" and David Bowie’s ""Fame"". Snippets of legendary speeches from Jesse Jackson and Malcolm X and stage banter from Public Enemy’s successful European tour formed connective tissue between songs for a unified listening experience that only let up briefly in the middle and finally
column12: at the end. The Bomb Squad built beats like ships in a bottle
column13: delicately stitching tiny pieces of black history into layered blasts of sound. Public Enemy looked and sounded a fright to the uninitiated
column14: but careful attention showed every piece of this black radical machine moving in perfect concert.

column1: Nation of Millions netted Public Enemy the elusive American audience and platinum sales their debut couldn’t
column2: and it changed the face of rap music. The hip-hop landscape of ‘89-’90 was dotted with sample-heavy sons of Nation. Chuck sent early copies of the album out west to Dre and Ice Cube
column3: and N.W.A.’s landmark Straight Outta Compton cropped up like a gangsta rap rejoinder to the Bomb Squad ethos. (Cube would later tap the team for production on his post-N.W.A. solo debut AmeriKKKa’s Most Wanted.) De La Soul’s 3 Feet High and Rising and the Beastie Boys’ Paul’s Boutique added a playful
column4: psychedelic charm to the proceedings. Nation’s message of black self-sufficiency resonated through the proudly Afrocentric art of A Tribe Called Quest
column5: X Clan
column6: Brand Nubian and more. Beyond the '80s
column7: the music of Nation of Millions would continue to find new life in unexpected places: Weezer’s 1996 comeback single ""El Scorcho"" nicked its ""I’m the epitome of public enemy"" barb from ""Don’t Believe the Hype""
column8: and Jay-Z’s 2006 post-retirement salvo ""Show Me What You Got"" is a nod to Nation’s ""Show ‘Em Whatcha Got"". (Without Public Enemy we don’t get Kanye West; in addition to sampling the Long Island legends liberally
column9: Kanye inherited a bit of his fearless politics and kitchen sink beat construction from here.)

column1: Critics warmed to Public Enemy in the wake of It Takes a Nation of Millions but remained suspicious of their political affiliations. ""If Farrakhan’s a prophet my dick’s bigger than Don Howland’s
column2: Village Voice scribe Robert Christgau quipped in a year-end roundup
column3: ""but that doesn’t make Nation of Millions anything less than the bravest and most righteous experimental pop of the decade."" Others would be less warm as Professor Griff’s incendiary ethics began to strike sour notes. He publicly accused white America of bestiality during a press-filled gig at Rikers Island in 1988 and voiced a shocking disdain for Jews and gays in various interviews overseas. In the spring of 1989
column4: Washington Times scribe David Mills sat Griff down and coaxed out a rant charged with cold
column5: ugly hate speech that would quickly torch the group’s reputation on both sides of the Atlantic.

column1: Privately
column2: Chuck struggled with how to respond to the controversy. At first
column3: he stood by Griff
column4: then he announced Griff’s expulsion from the group
column5: then
column6: amid a growing media firestorm
column7: he disbanded Public Enemy entirely. The hiatus was short-lived. Spike Lee’s blistering racial relations passion play Do the Right Thing debuted a week after the firestorm with a new Public Enemy song as its theme. ""Fight the Power"" summarized the mood of both the film and the climate it was released into. It telegraphed the tense discomfort of a New York summer where innocent youth from Central Park to Bensonhurst would pay the ultimate price for being black in the wrong place at the wrong time. By July
column8: the seemingly inactive group had a #1 Billboard rap single
column9: and work was quietly underway on a Nation of Millions follow-up.

column1: Fear of a Black Planet from 1990 made kindling of the previous summer’s anti-Public Enemy sentiment
column2: quoting the group’s biggest critics in interludes and ribbing them in the songs. ""Contract on the World Love Jam"" weaves negative news reports into a scene-setting intro; later ""Incident at 66.6 FM"" sets outraged calls from a Chuck D squareoff with New York political radio host Alan Colmes over sedate keys and drums
column3: playing the grumps for squares without even responding to their charges. A late album Terminator X showcase snarkily titled ""Leave This Off Your Fuckin Charts"" is a tenacious dare. Elsewhere
column4: Fear pulls the camera off P.E. to speak to community issues. ""Anti-Nigger Machine"" and ""Who Stole the Soul?"" levied heavy accusations of censorship while ""911 Is a Joke"" explored black community police mistrust and ""Fear of a Black Planet"" tackled apprehension about interracial dating. Sourcing Public Enemy’s media struggles back to age-old racial strife was a brash
column5: heavy-handed play
column6: but Fear’s genius trick was coating its righteous rage in music that aimed to groove where earlier songs seemed to want to maim.

column1: Fear of a Black Planet finds the Bomb Squad at the height of their powers
column2: assembling deeply intricate grooves out of infinitesimal building blocks. ""Pollywannacracka"" cycles through a breakneck array of sounds inside of its first 10 seconds and modulates between spacious verses and a jam-packed chorus
column3: bubbling into bedlam whenever Chuck stops rapping. ""Fight the Power"" manages to cram over a dozen different samples into five minutes of shockingly smooth funk. What sets these songs apart from the last batch is that their structure was often as varied as their list of ingredients. They didn’t just modulate between similar verses and choruses. These compositions breathed
column4: moved
column5: changed from one refrain to the next
column6: from one second to the next. A new sound showed face on every listen. Fear of a Black Planet deftly stated the case for hip-hop as savvy collage art rather than pastiche. Sure
column7: they borrowed liberally from pre-existing music
column8: but these patchwork symphonies bore scant resemblance to their source material.

column1: It should be noted that none of this can ever happen again. Biz Markie was sued over an unauthorized sample in 1991
column2: and <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Upright_Music
column3: _Ltd._v._Warner_Bros._Records_Inc."" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the judge’s ruling required future producers to seek the original artist’s clearance before incorporating a sample into a new composition. Overnight it became forbiddingly difficult and expensive to incorporate even a handful of samples into a new beat. The nightmare of ""Caught
column4: Can We Get a Witness?"" had become the hard reality. Producers scaled back their creations
column5: often augmenting one choice groove with a bevy of instrumental embellishments. This is how we arrive at the lush live band pomp of West Coast G-funk
column6: the cold synthetics of early 2000s East Coast rap
column7: and the gothic textures of Southern crunk and trap. The early Public Enemy masterpieces remain unique and inimitable now
column8: relics of a world irreparably changed though in a few notable ways
column9: very much the same.

column1: The strife that birthed Nation of Millions and Black Planet is mirrored in some of the upheaval of 2014. The business of hip-hop has changed
column2: as free mixtapes have supplanted retail albums as the chief method of kicking off a rap career. Artistic freedom can evaporate at the drop of a gavel. (see: Lord Finesse’s pursuit of Mac Miller for borrowing a beat on a free release.) Hip-hop has again had its political mettle tested by social injustices too systemic to deny. Returning to It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back and Fear of a Black Planet for these just-released reissues is an encouraging reminder of what a hip-hop album can be to the world
column3:
a peek back at that one time a rap act pissed square into the mouth of adversity and came away unscathed. Hear the drummer get wicked.

Sly and the Family Stone's 1969 fourth album Stand! was a major pop success you could get down to
column2: the peak of the Family Stone's ability to bend minds and hips alike. 1971's There's a Riot Goin' On was a challenging
column3: divisive artistic statement
column4: the first words of which were ""feel so good inside myself
column5: don't want to move."" The general sense is that there's almost nothing in the pop or R&B mainstream that bridged these two sides of Sly Stone for the wider public.

column1: History states that Riot was an unexpected detour into pessimistic introspection to an audience that only knew the sunnier side of a band that looked and sounded like the best possible socially integrated future. And with three mid-late 1969 songs (""Hot Fun in the Summertime"" and ""Thank You (Falettinme Be Mice Elf Agin)"" b/w ""Everbody Is a Star"") as the only new cuts to appear under the Sly and the Family Stone banner for nearly two years
column2: it was easy to wonder exactly how that transition happened—and how it sounded.

column1: Miles Marshall Lewis's absolutely essential 33 1/3 on Riot tells a good part of the story—the disillusioned national mood after the Death of the Sixties
column2: Sly's post-Woodstock ambivalence towards the fame he once craved
column3: and his sonic turn towards introversion and quietude that manifested in muffled vocals and a restrained drum machine in place of Greg Errico's thunderous backbeat. Also hinted at
column4: but by no means marginalized
column5: is the story of Stone Flower
column6: the vanity label Atlantic Records let Sly run as part of his production deal.

column1: The biggest breakthrough from this imprint was Little Sister
column2: the post-R&B girl group comprised of Mary McCreary
column3: Elva Mouton
column4: and Stone's actual younger sister Vaetta ""Vet Stone"" Stewart. They'd already earned some measure of renown as backup singers on some of the Family's biggest hits and found another place in history when their 1970 version of Stand! deep cut ""Somebody's Watching You"" became the first major hit single to use a drum machine—a Maestro Rhythm King. It wouldn't be the last to do so in Sly's hands.

column1: Stone Flower as a label produced four singles in all
column2: one promo-only
column3: all written by Sly and many of them stripped-down revamps of older Family Stone material. But thanks to alternate versions
column4: outtakes
column5: and prototypical versions of songs that would later form the backbone of Riot
column6: I'm Just Like You: Sly's Stone Flower 1969-70 fortuitously doubles as the clearest available sonic roadmap for one of the most radical transformations in pop history. The exhaustive liner notes
column7: written by Alec Palao
column8: lay out every detail from Stone's preferred settings for the MRK-1 to the pitfalls of trying to balance outside production and personal work
column9: benefiting from a decade-plus worth of archived and recent interviews. The talk with Sly is worth the price alone
column10: from his admitted pioneering of the ""all instruments are real"" drum machine defense to his take on the less-is-more approach—or
column11: in his terms
column12: ""more is less""—that informed his early 1970s releases.

column1: The clearest route through this evolution runs through Little Sister's music
column2: five variations on three songs pointing to their unsung role in the Family and Sly's efforts to use them as a conduit for some of his newer ideas. It wasn't
column3: however
column4: an immediate shift. The first
column5: full-band version of ""Somebody's Watching You""
column6: included here
column7: makes that later single version's minimalism even more striking: with clearer voices
column8: bright horns
column9: and a guitar figure that's more prominent than the final track's ghostly presence
column10: it's hard to imagine it escaping the shadow of the Stand! original. Meanwhile
column11: the debut Little Sister single ""You're the One"" doesn't have the historical import of ""Somebody's Watching You""
column12: but it was a bigger hit; with its slippery
column13: heavy-bottomed kick-cymbal pattern
column14: its proto-disco bonafides are unimpeachable while it provides some of the last throes of ""Thank You""-style twanging funk lingering in Sly's system.

column1: That big change came within the year. The final version of ""Somebody's Watching You""
column2: released in November 1970
column3: is mighty illuminating
column4: the original Stand! version's glib ""shady as a lady with a mustache"" silliness revealing a quiet intensity underneath. (The singers' emphatic swings from hushed restraint to full belting on certain lines—""just when you think you've pulled a fast one"" is a particularly sharp jolt—sounds even more surprising than that now-familiar mechanical drum pattern.) The B-side to the original 7""
column5: a more uptempo cut titled ""Stanga""
column6: points even more clearly to the future; the juxtaposed MRK and shadowy wah-wah guitar fit the Riot blueprint almost as starkly as its dark
column7: cynical-realist lyrics do. Imagine hearing ""Everybody Is a Star"" in December '69 and learning less than a year later that the same man would write the line ""Sometime or another
column8: you're gonna be stung/ Sometime or another
column9: you might see a brother hung.""

column1: Another piece of the puzzle is provided by Joe Hicks
column2: an enigmatic singer whose output largely consists of a couple Stone-produced singles
column3: a 1973 LP on Enterprise
column4: and little else. Stone reveals little about the man (""[I knew him] back in Sacramento when he used to be a bully. He got real depressed
column5: got strung out on heroin and died."")
column6: and so does his single ""Life & Death in G & A""—a song originally given to the New York A&M funk-rock band Abaco Dream in 1969 but rumored to have been played by the Family Stone themselves. Handled by Hicks
column7: the two-key arrangement is a far cry instrumentally from the brass-blasting funk of the Abaco Dream original (or the '74 Funkadelic-tinged Chairmen of the Board epic
column8: for that matter)
column9: the see-saw dynamic at its most extreme through the stark downtempo accompaniment and Hicks' almost pained-sounding wail of the refrain ""if it feels good
column10: it's all right."" Like Little Sister's metamorphosis
column11: the change of scene for Joe Hicks is represented by a major jump in Sly's approach; the horn-driven fuzzbomb of 1969's first Stone Flower production
column12: ""I'm Goin' Home"" b/w ""Home Sweet Home""
column13: is a fine feint towards both rock and funk that's the closest the Family Stone ever came to resembling the J.B.'s' beating-heart machinery precision. Another what-could've-been.

column1: There are four tracks on I'm Just Like You credited solely to Sly
column2: demos and prototypes for what would eventually define the singular sound that ran through the lifeblood of Riot. (""Just Like a Baby"" is a little too fast
column3: ""Spirit"" and ""Scared"" are unremarkable sketches
column4: and ""Africa"" is coldly desolate when it's not talking to you.) But it's the band behind this compilation's titular song that proves to be the most compatible purveyor of Sly's developing vision. 6IX were a done-too-soon one-off group built around the talents of New York harmonica player/CBS mail clerk Marvin Braxton
column5: with ""I'm Just Like You"" b/w ""Dynamite"" their sole Stone Flower single. Initially
column6: they were their own thing; early-stage circa-'69 recordings (""Trying to Make You Feel Good""
column7: ""You Can
column8: We Can""
column9: and an early full-band runthrough of ""I'm Just Like You"") relied on the punchy live-band funk provided by the former members of a mixed-race nightclub-circuit group called the Soul Rascals.

column1: By the time their sole single dropped in December 1970
column2: however
column3: the live band that warmed a Madison Square Garden crowd for Sly the previous month manifested on wax as Stone and Braxton alone with singer Charles Higgins. Life highlight ""Dynamite""
column4: originally slated as the headliner
column5: was remolded into a skulking
column6: hiccuping
column7: skeletal B-side. ""I'm Just Like You"" became the A-side
column8: and its first 15 seconds—dusty drum machine clicks prodded by human hands
column9: heavy-shouldered bass murky with humidity
column10: organ notes that dart like wary eyes—could fit somewhere on a spectrum between ""Family Affair"" and ""Brave & Strong"". And then Higgins starts belting lurching cartoons of Sly-esque melody to knockout effect
column11: the empathy of ""Everyday People"" upended into a mirror-staring reckoning: ""Don't'cha know that I can see/ You're takin' steaks away from me/ You forgot
column12: I get hungry too/ I know how you feel
column13: I'm just like you."" Few knew at the time that this kind of spirit would lead to the dominant sound of Riot. But in retrospect
column14:
hearing that development going on made one thing clear: everything was new.

column2: Rock

and Country 1966–1985|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Light in the Attic']|2014-11-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:00.744323|"

The members of the Canadian rock group Sugluk saw their small
column4: remote village electrified in more ways than one. Located in the northernmost tip of Quebec
column5: just outside the Arctic Circle
column6: their town—previously called Sugluk as well—consisted primarily of tents and igloos
column7: with the first few permanent structures and power lines added in the 1960s. Even after that initial modernization
column8: most teenagers traveled down to Kuujjuarapik or even as far south as Quebec City for school. The four musicians returned home with loads of pop records by the Beatles
column9: Hendrix
column10: and others
column11: which they used as textbooks to teach themselves how to play their instruments and write their own songs. Soon they were playing community dance halls around the region
column12: and their reputation grew to the point that the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation recruited them to record two 7"" singles in 1975. That remains the extent of their catalog
column13: although Sugluk continued touring into the 1980s and reunited in 2013.

column1: Of their handful of extant tracks
column2: three are included on Light in the Attic’s new comp Native North America (Vol. 1): Aboriginal Folk
column3: Rock
column4: and Country 1966-1985. Those songs show a band developing an identity even as it stamps popular folk-rock with its own personal flourish. ""Fall Away"" opens with a thundering drum fill and a shaky one-note bass groove
column5: setting the stage for singer George Kakayuk’s bittersweet tale of thwarted romance. The song has the folksy grit of Neil Young
column6: but the rambunctious energy of the Flamin’ Groovies. Guitarist Tayara Papigatuk takes over on ""I Didn't Know""
column7: which sounds so loose and rambling the rhythm section might be the only thing holding it together. Showing their range
column8: ""Ajuinnarasuarsunga"" (which translates from Inuktitut as ""I Tried Hard"") is a folksier number defined by the band’s careful harmonies and a lovely piano rambling in the background. ""Though the band was not 100 percent satisfied with these raw one-take recordings
column9: writes Kevin ""Sipreano"" Howes in the Native North America liner notes
column10: ""they remain one of the earliest examples of original Inuit rock music recorded in Canada and carry an exceptional spiritual weight.""

column1: If Sugluk emerge as one of the stars of Native North America
column2: it’s largely because you can hear a very particular struggle in their songs—not necessarily to be heard by a mainstream audience
column3: but to define themselves through some combination of Native American culture and popular music. That endeavor to some degree informs every song here
column4: as artists from all over Canada calibrate their own equations for personal expression. Some
column5: like the group Sikumiut
column6: sound like they could play shows alongside Young or Joni Mitchell. Others
column7: like Morley Loon and Shingoose
column8: barely nod to pop music at all. But almost everyone on Native North America writes and sings about the impulse to both imitate others and distinguish oneself. Gordon Dick
column9: a member of the Lil’wat Nation and a self-taught guitarist
column10: even gives a name to this music: ""I dreamed I was in a rock group
column11: playing on a Saturday night. Our name wasn’t like the Beatles
column12: but I found an old Indian name: Siwash Rock.""

column1: Native North America might have easily buckled under the weight of good intentions. Howes
column2: a Toronto-based vinyl collector
column3: DJ
column4: and blogger
column5: spent years scouring record stores and flea markets all over Canada to locate these rare records
column6: then tracked down and researched the unsung artists behind them. That process by itself is important
column7: as it provides valuable information on lesser-known chapters in the history of Canadian rock
column8: but that alone doesn’t ensure a 2xCD/3xLP set
column9: much less the first in what appears to be a multi-volume series
column10: will be listenable or engaging as anything other than an artifact. Fortunately
column11: Howes does not conflate the idea of the music—its origins
column12: its politics
column13: or its import—with the music itself. He has curated the tracklist not only to emphasize the diversity of the artists and their ideas
column14: but to reveal the vibrancy and energy of this large and largely undocumented scene.

column1: Native North America likewise shows the extent to which popular music welcomes and nourishes marginalized perspectives; the form is endlessly adaptable and fundamentally democratic—even when democracy itself is not. Most of these artists faced prejudice or hardship of varying severity
column2: which naturally informed their music. ""Police they arrest me
column3: materialists detest me
column4: Willie Dunn sings on ""I Pity the Country"". ""Pollution it chokes me
column5: movies they joke me."" The impression is one of forced isolation
column6: as though society has stripped away every refuge that might comfort the singer—except music
column7: that is. It’s a startling opener to the comp
column8: especially since Dunn’s steadfast voice conveys resignation more than anger. He’s not fighting the system
column9: but pitying the sad men who perpetuate their own unhappiness.

column1: ""I Pity the Country"" is not too different from the politically-motivated folk
column2: rock
column3: and country coming out of the North American mainstream at that time. Many of the artists on Native North America were weaned on early country & western
column4: in particular the lonesome ballads of Hank Williams
column5: but their music has more in common
column6: both sonically and politically
column7: with that of Buffy Sainte-Marie
column8: Bob Dylan
column9: and Johnny Cash (whose 1964 album Bitter Tears looms large over this set
column10: even if it is never mentioned). Tribal drums become a rock'n'roll rhythm section on Lloyd Cheechoo’s ""James Bay"" and ""Tshekuan Mak Tshetutamak"" by Groupe Folklorique Montagnais
column11: a powerful means of announcing the artists’ aboriginal roots. The Chieftones (who billed themselves as ""Canada’s All Indian Band"") kick off ""I Shouldn’t Have Did What I Done"" with a drum pattern practically quoted from some cheesy old Hollywood Western
column12: but it turns out to be more than just a marketing ploy as the band’s energetic garage-rock attack subverts any expectation of stoicism associated with Aboriginal stereotypes.

column1: The idea of pop music as a means of presenting oneself to the world gives Native North America some cohesion despite the range of ethnicities
column2: geographies
column3: and genres represented in its tracklist. The comp celebrates those distinctions even if it can’t quite underscore them
column4: which means the extensive liner notes become a crucial guide for listening. A problem that affects so many compilations becomes especially acute: You not only want to hear more songs by these artists
column5: but also want to hear more songs in their original context. How did Willy Mitchell expand on the folksy urgency of ""Call of the Moose"" for his 1981 album Sweet Grass Music? Does the rest of the Saddle Lake Drifting Cowboys’ material sound as good as the Ventures-meets-Buckaroos ""Modern Rock""? And what about the 1981 comp Goose Wings: The Music of James Bay
column6: which includes tunes by Lawrence Martin
column7: Lloyd Cheechoo
column8: and Brian Davey? Of course
column9:
stoking your curiosity about underrepresented artists only means Native North America is doing its job.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21198/homepage_large.601bfe91.jpg|Seeing Sound|32572.0|Jay Shepheard|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Retrofit']|2014-11-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:01.200123|"

Back when Jay Shepheard’s imprint Retrofit was gearing up to release his scrappy debut LP Home & Garden
column2: Shepheard declared a set of aesthetic ground rules for the album he was hoping to create: no filler
column3: no obvious singles
column4: no slapping guest vocals onto instrumentals to make them sound more album-y. Shepheard may appreciate the need for discriminating tastes and efficient technical know-how more than most—before founding Retrofit
column5: he worked for several years in the vaults of online retailer Juno Records
column6: indexing crate after crate of music as it arrived. His savvy ear was one of the chief pleasures of Home & Garden
column7: which showcased Shepheard’s contemporary visions of piano-driven garage
column8: tech house
column9: and starry-eyed nu-disco in compact four-and-a-half-minute bursts. But it also sounded a little tight-fisted
column10: the work of a skilled producer powering through the uncertainty of being his own label boss.

column1: Shepheard’s new album
column2: Seeing Sound
column3: is the result of a slight relaxation of those aesthetic strictures. It’s a looser set of eight sprawled-out house tracks that wisely taps Shepheard’s skills as a singles producer (something he honed on a series of six 12'' releases for Compost’s Black Label
column4: the most successful of which was the nocturnal fantasy ""Pipes N Sneakers"".) Despite hitting many of the same touchstones
column5: it feels more thematically consistent than his last effort.

column1: Shepheard's typically dry style
column2: which borrows much of its artificial surface character from analog techno
column3: is fully present here—""Mover Friendly"" is an almost parodically twitched-out version of a ghetto house stomp
column4: while ""One Day City""'s classic disco riff comes in harsh
column5: electronic plunks.

column1: Seeing Sound also features some of Shepheard's most creative vocal manipulations
column2: which add an extra-human element to music already soaked in technical manipulation. ""Dance Language"" features a heavily filtered gurgle that's eerily ambiguous
column3: while the irrepressibly fun ""Mover Friendly""
column4: with its fractured stutters and mumbles
column5: is a master class on expressive post-verbal vocal sampling. Shepheard is no traditionalist
column6: despite his use of familiar styles; on Seeing Sound
column7: his interpretations fuse those sounds with the techno-anxiety of recycled culture and Internet-native music
column8:
subtly expanding house music’s sound by situating it firmly in the present.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21250/homepage_large.cdd60c62.jpg|An Evolutionary Music (Original Recordings: 1972 – 1979)|32617.0|Ariel Kalma|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2014-11-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:01.966673|"

Tracing the trajectory of French-born musician Ariel Kalma does not yield a straight path. Which makes sense for an artist prone to world travels and crafting a strain of music that acts as a peregrination through numerous musical forms of the late 20th century: free jazz
column2: progressive rock
column3: drone
column4: tape-loop based minimalism
column5: electroacoustic composition
column6: field recordings
column7: new age meditations
column8: and more. His name crops up as a sideman for the likes of bossa nova guitarist Baden Powell
column9: Belgian pop crooner Salvatore Adamo
column10: and prog rock guitarist Richard Pinhas
column11: while his own recorded works are ludicrously rare
column12: released in small batches that now fetch astronomical sums online. Saying that Ariel Kalma is underappreciated isn’t quite right in that most of his work remains unheard.

column1: As is their wont
column2: RVNG Intl.’s reassessment of Kalma seeks to correct that imbalance
column3: not by just reissuing such rarities as 1975’s Le Temps des Moissons or the strange hybrid of jungle field recordings and body-elevating drones on 1978’s Osmose
column4: but by encouraging the composer himself to unlock old boxes of tapes and reevaluate whatever little treasures were left behind. So while much of Kalma’s released music aims towards the infinite
column5: with compositions taking up the entire side of vinyl records and often surpassing the nine-minute mark
column6: An Evolutionary Music is rather concise: 15 of the 17 tracks are under seven minutes while two of the standouts are also the longest.

column1: Kalma’s bio—as detailed in the liner notes—finds him aligned with similarly-minded musical travelers. At one point
column2: he worked at Paris’s iconic INA-GRM Studio
column3: the birthplace of 20th century electronic music. Busking on the streets of New York City in the 1970s
column4: he encountered another world music fuser in Don Cherry and also came into contact with American minimalist Terry Riley. Those two might be the closest comparisons for Kalma’s own music. In 1971
column5: Kalma—already having picked up flute and saxophone—acquired a reel-to-reel tape machine and holed up in his Montparnasse flat
column6: began making home recordings that explored tape feedback
column7: echo
column8: and his own voice. Some of these earliest recordings
column9: like ""Les Mots de Tous Les Jours (Rêves Etranges)"" and ""Les Etoiles Sont Allumées"" appear here
column10: short and exploratory
column11: interesting primarily for what they indicate lays ahead.

column1: Similarly succinct as these spoken word pieces
column2: ""Enuej Elleiv"" hints at Kalma’s fusion of free jazz
column3: experimental electronics
column4: and the timbre of esoteric instruments from around the world. Kalma plays harmonium and saxophone and takes collaborator Dominique Regef’s hurdy-gurdy and sends it through an extreme amount of phase
column5: giving the song a phantasmal
column6: shifting sound that carries you far afield in under three minutes. His work with primitive drum machines also provides for interesting fragments like ""Chase Me Now"" and ""Voltage Controlled Wave"".

column1: ""In 1974 and 1975 I had some very strong experiences of oneness with the universe."" So Kalma is quoted in Evolutionary Music’s liner notes and his travels took him through India
column2: Afghanistan
column3: Turkey
column4: and Israel
column5: where he picked up strange stringed instruments and mastered the art of circular breathing. That latter technique dilated the range and duration of his horn improvisations. With his never-ending horn drones in motion with his own tape machine
column6: he began to find a peaceful
column7: unmoored sound. Some of these early combinations appear here as ""Almora Sunrise""
column8: while the expansive 10 minutes of ""Ecstasy Musical Mind Yoga"" show him the French equivalent to Riley’s all night flights.

column1: Some pieces seem promising in their mesmerism
column2: but don’t hang around long enough to fully take effect
column3: instead coming across as detours rather than full-fledged trips. Kalma’s own ""Love and Dream"" reminds me of Laraaji (another such cosmic artist recently reassessed) but in a smaller dosage. Only on the 19-minute tapestry ""Yogini Breath""
column4: which Kalma developed for use with a friend’s breath therapy work
column5: does the true scope of his sonic vision come into full view. Powered along by struck bells and the sound of the incoming tide
column6: veil-like layers of sound accrue: a chorale of wordless chants
column7: a ticking drum machine
column8: thrumming bass
column9: and more bells. Kalma weaves them all together into something dense
column10: kaleidoscopic and weightless at once
column11:
a magic carpet ride.

"|19993.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19993-ariel-kalma-an-evolutionary-music-original-recordings-1972-1979/|7.7|Andy Beta

Many recording artists release a self-titled debut album
column3: while some opt to release a self-titled album later in their career
column4: and others even go on to release multiple self-titled albums. But the Velvet Underground are the only band to have released multiple self-titled debuts.

column1: Technically
column2: their first album was 1967’s The Velvet Underground & Nico
column3: a bracing collision of Brill Building pop classicism and avant-garde noise terrorism that
column4: by the time White Light/White Heat was released in 1968
column5: had progressed to all-out warfare. The tension at the heart of these two records has often been attributed to the oppositional approaches of its principal songwriters—professional popsmith Lou Reed and viola-scraping iconoclast John Cale—though this reading has always been reductive. After all
column6: Cale delivered one of White Light/White Heat’s few moments of serenity (""Lady Godiva’s Operation"")
column7: while Reed unleashed the album’s most brutalizing shock 53 seconds into ""I Heard Her Call My Name"". But for Reed
column8: the only logical response to White Light/White Heat’s anti-pop extremism was to ricochet back in the other direction
column9: a move that would force Cale out of the Velvets and present Reed with the opportunity to lead a different kind of band.

column1: The romantic myth about the Velvets—the commercially ignored
column2: ahead-of-their-time proto-punk innovators proudly out of step with the peace'n'lovey-dovey pop of the day—often overlooks a crucial quality about the band: they actually wanted to be popular. And in light of disappointing sales for their first two albums on niche jazz imprint Verve
column3: they traded up to parent company MGM in 1969 with the intention of being a proper rock band that makes records for big labels in Hollywood and stays at the Chateau Marmont.

column1: From the very first second of The Velvet Underground
column2: everything about the group had changed from where they left off with the epochal squall of White Light/White Heat’s ""Sister Ray"". Reed and Sterling Morrison’s amp settings were dialed down from 11 to 1; Maureen ""Moe"" Tucker’s thundering thump was softened into a breezy brushed-snare sway; and Reed’s ding-dong-sucking snarl was replaced by the melancholic whisper of Cale’s successor Doug Yule. It’s like returning from a holiday only to find your rat-infested apartment building had burned down and been replaced with a white-picket-fenced bungalow. And even though the song Yule was crooning
column3: ""Candy Says""
column4: marked Reed’s first explicit character reference to the Warhol Factory scene that birthed his band
column5: it ultimately underscored the Velvets’ increasing remove from its hazy decadence: A devastatingly intimate portrait of then-transitioning Factory regular Candy Darling
column6: ""Candy Says"" is the sobering soundtrack for that inevitable moment when all tomorrow’s parties turn to morning-after
column7: makeup-smeared
column8: self-loathing introspection. (The album cover reinforces the reflective mood: though shot at the Factory
column9: the Velvets look more like they’re hosting a small gathering friends in their living room
column10: their '67-era striped tees and fuck-you wraparound shades replaced by comfortable sweaters and sensible collared shirts.)

column1: If The Velvet Undergrounddialled down the aggression and abrasion of its predecessors
column2: it undercuts the mellow approach with some of the rawest songwriting of Reed’s career
column3: and a plainspoken candor as startling as his past meditations on smack and S&M. His blunt language drives a spike into the album’s gentle jangle to unleash a maelstrom of emotions
column4: where ecstatic moments of spiritual reawakening (""Beginning to See the Light"") are answered by cruel reality checks (""I’m set free/ To find a new illusion"")
column5: where the love of his life becomes someone else's (""Pale Blue Eyes"")
column6: where a Jewish guy feels so fucked up
column7: he starts praying to Jesus. Even the seemingly easy-going choogle of ""What Goes On"" is routinely upset by Reed’s admissions of anxiety (""One minute born/ One minute doomed""). By that token
column8: the simultaneous-poetry experiment ""The Murder Mystery"" feels less like an anomalous WTF throwback to the Velvets’ avant-garde roots than the sound of the album’s slow-stewing inner turmoil coming to a boil.

column1: This interiority complex was crucial to Reed
column2: to the point of him taking the original recordings engineered by MGM house producer Val Valentin and remixing the entire album to bring the already unguarded vocals to the fore. This so-called ""Closet Mix""—featuring an entirely different
column3: more cerebral take on the blues soliloquy ""Some Kinda Love""— initially appeared only on the album’s first U.S. run; it would later resurface on the 1995 career-spanning box set Peel Slowly and See. This 45th-anniversary package not only revives Reed’s Closet Mix alongside a new crystalline mix by Valentin
column4: but also a third mono version that could very well be dubbed the Armoire Mix
column5: thus making the transition out of White Light/White Heat feel a little less abrupt. (For one
column6: the once-blissful fade-out organ drone on ""What Goes On"" now sounds like a ray-gun burrowing into your skull.) Which mix you prefer depends on just how cozy you want to get with the Velvets: would you rather they engage you in a private
column7: face-to-face conversation (Valentin’s mix)
column8: whisper in your ear (Closet Mix)
column9: or take up residency inside your brain (the mono mix)?

column1: But The Velvet Underground’s six-disc deluxe edition has a purpose beyond just encouraging audiophiles to A/B different versions of the same songs. Rather
column2: it’s a complete portrait of a period when the Velvets’ populist ambitions were being matched by their exceedingly prolific output
column3: and the notion of what we now consider to be the archetypal Lou Reed song—be it a tough
column4: streetwise rocker or tender
column5: empathetic ballad—was being more clearly defined. Shortly after The Velvet Underground’s March 1969 release
column6: the band had recorded enough new material at New York’s Record Plant for a fourth album; souring relations with MGM
column7: however
column8: resulted in those sessions being shelved. This material has
column9: of course
column10: surfaced in various iterations over the years (be it on mid-'80s compilations VU and Another View
column11: the Peel Slowly and See box
column12: or in revised form on various Reed solo albums)
column13: and has proven as canonical as the band’s officially released work. But this set is the first to present it as a proper
column14: logically sequenced
column15: stand-alone album
column16: kicking off with the locomotive charge of ""Foggy Notion"" and ending with an instrumental version of ""Ride Into the Sun"" that
column17: here
column18: feels less like an unfinished demo than a strategically placed closing-credits theme.

column1: It’s no coincidence that these songs count as the most upbeat and playful the Velvets produced; as Yule observes in David Fricke’s liner notes
column2: ""There was a type of song that Lou wrote that was not thematically important to him
column3: but was fun to put together
column4: that had a lot of rhythm—a good tune when you needed something to open up an audience."" The last two discs of this set—pulled from two November '69 shows at San Francisco club The Matrix—present a glorious opportunity to experience this engagement process in action. This period of the band’s onstage evolution has been documented on the 1974 double-album 1969: The Velvet Underground Live and the no-fi bootleg comp The Quine Tapes
column5: but never with such cohesion and clarity. (The Matrix—owned by Jefferson Airplane singer Marty Balin—boasted a professional four-track console at its mixing desk.)

column1: While San Francisco’s hippie haven may have seemed like enemy turf for the Velvets
column2: the city was essentially the band’s home away from home for much of '69
column3: The Matrix their Factory West. And the rollicking performances betray their desire to out-jam the jam bands
column4: and expose the rock ‘n’ roll heart beating through even the Velvets’ most transgressive songs. The cornerstone is a ""Sister Ray"" to end all ""Sister Ray""s
column5: though its 37(!)-minute roller coaster journey from a molasses-slow blues to heart-racing rave-up is hitched to a relaxed West Coast groove that ventures far away from the original’s distortion holocaust. And the Velvets take such liberties in stretching out and reshaping their most concise songs (""Waiting for the Man""
column6: ""Lisa Says""
column7: ""There She Goes Again"")
column8: that the faithful rendition of first-album freak-out ""Heroin"" practically sounds formalist in comparison. (That said
column9: even when in crowd-pleasing mode
column10: Reed was already plotting future provocations: Prior to kicking into a distended early version of ""Rock & Roll""
column11: Reed strums a droning warm-up chord
column12: and marvels
column13: ""imagine a hundred guitars doing that at once!"")

column1: Alas
column2: the obvious joy with which the band whip through the Matrix setlist obscures the sad truth about The Velvet Underground: that the Velvets’ concerted ""pop"" album turned out to be the biggest commercial flop of their career up to that point
column3: not even able to scrape the bottom reaches of the Billboard 200
column4: as its two more caustic predecessors barely managed to do. When the band sing in unison
column5: ""How does it feel to be loved?"" at the end of the Matrix take on ""Beginning to See the Light""
column6: Lou ad libs
column7: ""somebody tell me
column8: PLEASE!"" with an amplified sense of desperation that indicates he never thought he’d know the answer. But just as The Velvet Underground’s hushed tones and tempered tempos demanded a greater sense of patience from listeners
column9: its acceptance proved to be a protracted
column10: gradual process that took decades.

column1: The band’s first two albums prefigured punk
column2: goth
column3: and contemporary noise
column4: but The Velvet Underground anticipated the sound of popular indie rock from the late-'80s onward
column5: through the barb-wired chime of Galaxie 500
column6: Pavement
column7: Yo La Tengo
column8: and countless others; the entire Stereolab discography can be heard in the outro of ""What Goes On"" alone
column9: while even the Moe Tucker-sung confection ""After Hours"" (and its '69-session counterpart ""I’m Sticking With You"") single-handedly spawned all things twee.
column10: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Brian Eno famously quipped that everyone who bought The Velvet Underground & Nico
column11: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> started a band
column12: but The Velvet Underground
column13: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">'s stunning simplicity and unflinching honesty presented an even more accessible model of DIY aspiration
column14: free of Warholian conceptualism and Cale’s classically schooled chaos. T
column15: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">he album
column16: serif;""><span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> remains both an open invitation and a dare—to face Reed’s hard truths or
column17: better yet
column18:
to reveal your own.

Listening now to Finally Rich
column2: Chief Keef’s capstone 2012 release and only album with Interscope
column3: it’s striking how easily the hits seemed to come to the then–17-year-old star. Even its unheralded album tracks hit a sweet spot of purposeful insouciance that promised a career in the spotlight. With songs selected and sequenced largely by Young Chop
column4: Finally Rich is a creative success (if only a modest commercial one) because it sells Chief Keef as a hitmaker. In the pre-Internet industry
column5: perhaps that's just what he would be. But today his interests lie elsewhere
column6: and his path since has been a defiant refutation of any direction but his own.

column1: To make a case for Chief Keef’s more recent music is to wander into a catch–22. Though short
column2: defensive explanations (""he’s got good hooks
column3: ""it’s just turn-up music"") are tempting
column4: they undersell his breadth; any lengthy defense is dismissed out of hand for overthinking music unworthy of the attention. But Chief Keef has not only sustained creatively in the waning spotlight of his initial breakthrough
column5: he’s become one of the more original young voices in hip-hop. Over the course of the past two years
column6: his music has been in a state of continual reinvention. His latest tape
column7: Back From the Dead 2
column8: is a bold step in a dark new direction. Largely self-produced
column9: it again redefines his sound
column10: pushes his rapping to the foreground
column11: and makes his older records—including the recent Big Gucci Sosa
column12: much of which was recorded more than a year ago—seem quaint.

column1: Though reminiscent of his earlier rap style
column2: Big Gucci Sosa is a mediocre record
column3: and shows the futility of pining for Chief Keef’s supposed golden era of 2012. Admittedly
column4: his biggest records from this time had an immediacy that trumped everything else out there. But Big Gucci Sosa lacks the songwriting of peaks like ""Love Sosa""
column5: parachuting Keef verses into the one-dimensional pulp-gangster formula that’s been Gucci Mane’s collaborative stock in trade since 2011. Not that Keef is the album’s weak link. On standout ""Darker"" (which has been in circulation for at least a year)
column6: Keef completely washes his mentor.

column1: He stands out again on ""Paper""
column2: the only song on both Big Gucci Sosa and Back From the Dead 2
column3: if only for a callback to Lil Wayne’s infamous ""lasagna"" lyric (this one’s about spaghetti). Thankfully
column4: it’s the only pro forma trap record on the latter tape. Sixteen of BFTD2’s 20 tracks are produced by Chief Keef himself. For his first steps into rapper-producer territory
column5: he shows promise—though it’s tough to imagine most of these beats working outside the context of a Chief Keef album
column6: as they are primed to frame his vocals. He’s cultivated a consistent sound; each beat is of-a-piece
column7: with brooding synthesized string and chorale patches moving in beefy quarter notes to conjure a grim yet electric atmosphere. Where the production on 2013's Almighty So had the pace and bleary color of city lights sliding up a rain-drenched windshield
column8: Back From the Dead 2 prowls through back alleys
column9: preferring gritty textures and coiled energy.

column1: In jazz improvisation
column2: there’s a saying that if you screw up
column3: make sure to do it loud—a confident mistake isn’t really a mistake at all. In keeping with this notion
column4: Keef’s production has an amateurism-as-aesthetic element not unlike late ‘90s Swizz Beatz records. The seams show—cymbals take a full beat to decay
column5: waveforms distort
column6: and though he conveys a range of moods
column7: he doesn’t yet have the facility for much rhythmic variation. But Keef’s commitment to the beats’ functional effect blurs the line between ""mistake"" and mastery—whether through misunderstanding
column8: willful mutation
column9: or both
column10: there’s a savviness and sophistication to the album’s sound. Like many aspects of his musical approach
column11: his conviction makes the unconventional connect.

column1: The main sonic shift from his recent work to this tape is rhythmic. Through loosies released to iTunes and YouTube
column2: Keef’s 2014 output varied from the sudden roller coaster effects of the low-pass filter (""Gucci Gang""
column3: ""Sosa Style"") to the intricate
column4: nimble rhythms of 12hunna’s production (""Hundreds""
column5: ""Make It Count""). On Back From the Dead 2
column6: tracks like ""Whole Crowd"" and ""Wheres Waldo"" seem to float forward
column7: while more groove-driven records like ""Farm""
column8: ""Sets""
column9: and “Wayne” are relentless
column10: creeping ahead on four-beats-per-bar tip-toes. It’s not monochromatic; ""Faneto"" has the feel of a '70s Chinatown sequence
column11: ""The Moral"" sounds like music from Castlevania
column12: and “Blurry” is all searing exultation. But when compared with this summer’s dynamic
column13: uptempo sound
column14: Keef’s beats are deliberate
column15: the grooves often static—creating a stark contrasting canvas for the dynamism of his delivery.

column1: Keef's rapping holds the project together. His earliest records
column2: like ""Everydays Halloween"" and ""John Madden""
column3: hit particularly hard because of a central contradiction: his voice was at once an unbothered flatline and a tool of projection. Keef had Gucci Mane’s nonchalant flow
column4: but his voice popped to the front of the speaker without sacrificing that sense of effortlessness. As he’s evolved
column5: Keef’s detached from that behind-the-beat pocket and shifted to a more aggressive style—one freed from the rhythmic grid other artists treat as a requisite constraint
column6: without being untethered from it altogether
column7: a la certain Lil B releases. This unpredictability lends a chaotic tension to the music.

column1: His lyrics are more effective for their blunt economy—he gets more mileage per syllable (as on the cleverly brutal ""Faneto"": ""Talkin’ out his neck
column2: pistol to his throat/ Blow this motherfucker
column3: he gon’ choke""). He’s unafraid to use space
column4: preferring the compositional effect of short burst phrases
column5: rather than long
column6: familiar cadences. (E–40’s new single ""Choices (Yup)"" is an example of a more traditional rapper working in this style.) Like King Louie
column7: he will lock into a particular pattern for several lines
column8: using extreme slant rhymes (""I just hit a stain
column9: finagle/ I just hit a stain
column10: finito"")
column11: as if trying to demolish the distance between words themselves
column12: or to camouflage his thoughts. He’s made rhyming a word with itself into an art form of its own—he likes to complete the circuit early
column13: or to let words stay static while the meaning shifts (""Nigga don’t slip
column14: you lose it
column15: then you lose it"").

column1: Over the course of his career
column2: critics have suggested Keef was a diminished version of every rapper from Waka to Lil B to Soulja Boy. These comparisons now seem absurd; grappling to describe something truly new
column3: we look to the past
column4: and inevitably fall short. Today
column5: Chief Keef is in rarefied air for street rap—a creative voice with an original
column6: cohesive aesthetic. True
column7: in the media spotlight
column8: interest in him is at low ebb: for a certain hipper music listener
column9: he’s not weird enough
column10: eclipsed by the gender-bending
column11: manic Lil Wayne disciple Young Thug. For hip-hop heads
column12: Keef is too weird—and so we end up with a straightlaced (if energetic) street rapper named Bobby Shmurda. Yet to the grassroots
column13: among a new generation of stars
column14: he sits at street rap’s aesthetic center
column15: not its margins.

column1: The subtext of this music remains deeply bleak; there are numerous shouts to his murdered cousin
column2: and it’s extremely disconcerting how casually Chicago rappers refer to kush blunts by the names of fallen enemies. Yet at its heart
column3: there’s a playfulness
column4: both explicit (""I can cut my dreads and sell them on Ebay"") and artistic—witness the poetic run-on about money midway through ""Wheres Waldo"". He plays his own narrative close to the vest
column5: letting his story loom below his elliptical rhymes like ice cubes in a glass. Nonetheless
column6: moments of clarity burst through suddenly
column7: crackling with significance: ""And I’m still rollin’ dice
column8: no monopoly/ I can’t be controlled
column9: this ain’t no colony."" That line comes from ""Wayne""
column10: which sounds like a hit rap single turned inside-out to reveal its rotten core—Rae Sremmurd’s evil antithesis. Malevolent and psychedelic
column11:
Back From the Dead 2 is Chief Keef’s own ""Down 2 Tha Last Roach"" blown out to album-length proportions.

Listening now to Finally Rich
column2: Chief Keef’s capstone 2012 release and only album with Interscope
column3: it’s striking how easily the hits seemed to come to the then–17-year-old star. Even its unheralded album tracks hit a sweet spot of purposeful insouciance that promised a career in the spotlight. With songs selected and sequenced largely by Young Chop
column4: Finally Rich is a creative success (if only a modest commercial one) because it sells Chief Keef as a hitmaker. In the pre-Internet industry
column5: perhaps that's just what he would be. But today his interests lie elsewhere
column6: and his path since has been a defiant refutation of any direction but his own.

column1: To make a case for Chief Keef’s more recent music is to wander into a catch–22. Though short
column2: defensive explanations (""he’s got good hooks
column3: ""it’s just turn-up music"") are tempting
column4: they undersell his breadth; any lengthy defense is dismissed out of hand for overthinking music unworthy of the attention. But Chief Keef has not only sustained creatively in the waning spotlight of his initial breakthrough
column5: he’s become one of the more original young voices in hip-hop. Over the course of the past two years
column6: his music has been in a state of continual reinvention. His latest tape
column7: Back From the Dead 2
column8: is a bold step in a dark new direction. Largely self-produced
column9: it again redefines his sound
column10: pushes his rapping to the foreground
column11: and makes his older records—including the recent Big Gucci Sosa
column12: much of which was recorded more than a year ago—seem quaint.

column1: Though reminiscent of his earlier rap style
column2: Big Gucci Sosa is a mediocre record
column3: and shows the futility of pining for Chief Keef’s supposed golden era of 2012. Admittedly
column4: his biggest records from this time had an immediacy that trumped everything else out there. But Big Gucci Sosa lacks the songwriting of peaks like ""Love Sosa""
column5: parachuting Keef verses into the one-dimensional pulp-gangster formula that’s been Gucci Mane’s collaborative stock in trade since 2011. Not that Keef is the album’s weak link. On standout ""Darker"" (which has been in circulation for at least a year)
column6: Keef completely washes his mentor.

column1: He stands out again on ""Paper""
column2: the only song on both Big Gucci Sosa and Back From the Dead 2
column3: if only for a callback to Lil Wayne’s infamous ""lasagna"" lyric (this one’s about spaghetti). Thankfully
column4: it’s the only pro forma trap record on the latter tape. Sixteen of BFTD2’s 20 tracks are produced by Chief Keef himself. For his first steps into rapper-producer territory
column5: he shows promise—though it’s tough to imagine most of these beats working outside the context of a Chief Keef album
column6: as they are primed to frame his vocals. He’s cultivated a consistent sound; each beat is of-a-piece
column7: with brooding synthesized string and chorale patches moving in beefy quarter notes to conjure a grim yet electric atmosphere. Where the production on 2013's Almighty So had the pace and bleary color of city lights sliding up a rain-drenched windshield
column8: Back From the Dead 2 prowls through back alleys
column9: preferring gritty textures and coiled energy.

column1: In jazz improvisation
column2: there’s a saying that if you screw up
column3: make sure to do it loud—a confident mistake isn’t really a mistake at all. In keeping with this notion
column4: Keef’s production has an amateurism-as-aesthetic element not unlike late ‘90s Swizz Beatz records. The seams show—cymbals take a full beat to decay
column5: waveforms distort
column6: and though he conveys a range of moods
column7: he doesn’t yet have the facility for much rhythmic variation. But Keef’s commitment to the beats’ functional effect blurs the line between ""mistake"" and mastery—whether through misunderstanding
column8: willful mutation
column9: or both
column10: there’s a savviness and sophistication to the album’s sound. Like many aspects of his musical approach
column11: his conviction makes the unconventional connect.

column1: The main sonic shift from his recent work to this tape is rhythmic. Through loosies released to iTunes and YouTube
column2: Keef’s 2014 output varied from the sudden roller coaster effects of the low-pass filter (""Gucci Gang""
column3: ""Sosa Style"") to the intricate
column4: nimble rhythms of 12hunna’s production (""Hundreds""
column5: ""Make It Count""). On Back From the Dead 2
column6: tracks like ""Whole Crowd"" and ""Wheres Waldo"" seem to float forward
column7: while more groove-driven records like ""Farm""
column8: ""Sets""
column9: and “Wayne” are relentless
column10: creeping ahead on four-beats-per-bar tip-toes. It’s not monochromatic; ""Faneto"" has the feel of a '70s Chinatown sequence
column11: ""The Moral"" sounds like music from Castlevania
column12: and “Blurry” is all searing exultation. But when compared with this summer’s dynamic
column13: uptempo sound
column14: Keef’s beats are deliberate
column15: the grooves often static—creating a stark contrasting canvas for the dynamism of his delivery.

column1: Keef's rapping holds the project together. His earliest records
column2: like ""Everydays Halloween"" and ""John Madden""
column3: hit particularly hard because of a central contradiction: his voice was at once an unbothered flatline and a tool of projection. Keef had Gucci Mane’s nonchalant flow
column4: but his voice popped to the front of the speaker without sacrificing that sense of effortlessness. As he’s evolved
column5: Keef’s detached from that behind-the-beat pocket and shifted to a more aggressive style—one freed from the rhythmic grid other artists treat as a requisite constraint
column6: without being untethered from it altogether
column7: a la certain Lil B releases. This unpredictability lends a chaotic tension to the music.

column1: His lyrics are more effective for their blunt economy—he gets more mileage per syllable (as on the cleverly brutal ""Faneto"": ""Talkin’ out his neck
column2: pistol to his throat/ Blow this motherfucker
column3: he gon’ choke""). He’s unafraid to use space
column4: preferring the compositional effect of short burst phrases
column5: rather than long
column6: familiar cadences. (E–40’s new single ""Choices (Yup)"" is an example of a more traditional rapper working in this style.) Like King Louie
column7: he will lock into a particular pattern for several lines
column8: using extreme slant rhymes (""I just hit a stain
column9: finagle/ I just hit a stain
column10: finito"")
column11: as if trying to demolish the distance between words themselves
column12: or to camouflage his thoughts. He’s made rhyming a word with itself into an art form of its own—he likes to complete the circuit early
column13: or to let words stay static while the meaning shifts (""Nigga don’t slip
column14: you lose it
column15: then you lose it"").

column1: Over the course of his career
column2: critics have suggested Keef was a diminished version of every rapper from Waka to Lil B to Soulja Boy. These comparisons now seem absurd; grappling to describe something truly new
column3: we look to the past
column4: and inevitably fall short. Today
column5: Chief Keef is in rarefied air for street rap—a creative voice with an original
column6: cohesive aesthetic. True
column7: in the media spotlight
column8: interest in him is at low ebb: for a certain hipper music listener
column9: he’s not weird enough
column10: eclipsed by the gender-bending
column11: manic Lil Wayne disciple Young Thug. For hip-hop heads
column12: Keef is too weird—and so we end up with a straightlaced (if energetic) street rapper named Bobby Shmurda. Yet to the grassroots
column13: among a new generation of stars
column14: he sits at street rap’s aesthetic center
column15: not its margins.

column1: The subtext of this music remains deeply bleak; there are numerous shouts to his murdered cousin
column2: and it’s extremely disconcerting how casually Chicago rappers refer to kush blunts by the names of fallen enemies. Yet at its heart
column3: there’s a playfulness
column4: both explicit (""I can cut my dreads and sell them on Ebay"") and artistic—witness the poetic run-on about money midway through ""Wheres Waldo"". He plays his own narrative close to the vest
column5: letting his story loom below his elliptical rhymes like ice cubes in a glass. Nonetheless
column6: moments of clarity burst through suddenly
column7: crackling with significance: ""And I’m still rollin’ dice
column8: no monopoly/ I can’t be controlled
column9: this ain’t no colony."" That line comes from ""Wayne""
column10: which sounds like a hit rap single turned inside-out to reveal its rotten core—Rae Sremmurd’s evil antithesis. Malevolent and psychedelic
column11:
Back From the Dead 2 is Chief Keef’s own ""Down 2 Tha Last Roach"" blown out to album-length proportions.

Travis Stewart is a tireless musician
column4: but his prodigious output is also his Achilles' heel. Pouring himself into the Machinedrum project has served Stewart well over the past five years or so
column5: as he became one of Ninja Tune's best known and beloved artists on the back of 2013's memorable Vapor City LP. But his success has allowed him to inundate excitable fans with music
column6: and Stewart is a poor self-editor. His Vapor City Archives record is the culmination of a year spent stretching an album cycle to its limits with a world tour
column7: multiple EPs
column8: an interactive website
column9: a digital subscription service
column10: and just about every other trick in the marketing book. So there's precious little he can share that we haven't already heard in a variety of forms.

column1: Though he's dabbled in hip-hop
column2: IDM
column3: and house
column4: Machinedrum hasn't really switched up his sound since he discovered Chicago's fertile juke and footwork scene. Room(s) from 2011 was the first LP to fully manifest the style that has come to define Stewart's solo output—whiplash tempos
column5: 808 drums
column6: heavy bass
column7: bright synths
column8: and loads of Burial-like vocal samples. To this formula
column9: Vapor City added acoustic guitar
column10: Amen breaks
column11: and the producer's own voice. Once a mercurial experimentalist
column12: Machinedrum now refines what's already there
column13: an approach certain electronic artists would do well to follow. So it's no surprise Vapor City Archives operates on that wavelength. But where the two previous albums were drawn from different sessions
column14: this 10-song collection is culled from the same material as its namesake. The quality gives Archives a lingering sense of déjà vu; even if the tracks don't sound exactly like their Vapor City counterparts
column15: they sure as hell remind you of them.

column1: To his credit
column2: though
column3: Machinedrum does fit a few updates into the tracklist. ""B Patient""
column4: for example
column5: juggles speaker-toasting bassweight and a cloud of emotive guitar and vocal figures with reinvigorated flair. Then there are the fizzy vocal hooks and dayglo pads of ""More Than Friends""
column6: which make a great case for Stewart taking his breezy jungle/footwork concoction into the dance-pop realm. On the other hand
column7: ""Hard 2 Be""'s choppy synth stabs and tumbling drum patterns are dead ringers for a handful of the hyped-up singles on Sepalcure
column8: the eponymous 2011 album from Machinedrum's and Praveen Sharma's collaborative project. ""Vizion (Centered)"" is the most blatantly recycled of the bunch
column9: a near facsimile of Vapor City's mid-album interlude in both name and mood. Flawlessly produced and unmistakable as it is
column10: Vapor City Archives repurposes sounds and ideas from across Stewart's repertoire
column11: setting up well-versed fans to trainspot similarities over any kind of immersive listening.

column1: If the abundance of music Machinedrum has put his name on in the past year is any indication
column2: he could probably make these kinds of wistful
column3: breaks-addled
column4: post-dubstep/footwork/bass music hybrids while he files his taxes or cooks a nice dinner. Stewart's increased output and dearth of exploration gives Archives an unflattering offhandedness
column5: and it also dilutes the potency of Vapor City
column6:
like putting together an album is just another item to mark off his to-do list.

Faust’s intentions have never been easy to discern. Over their 40-plus years of morphing
column2: discontinuous existence
column3: they’ve been so good at dodging expectations and confounding analysis that even when they’re playing it straight
column4: you wonder if something else is going on. So when the press sheet for j US t (pronounced ""just us"") claims the band is ""inviting the whole world to use [the album] as a base on which to build their own music
column5: it’s hard not to get suspicious. Is this a decoy? Do Jean-Hervé Peron and Zappi Diermaier want you to imagine other music so you won’t focus on theirs? Is it simply a way to say ""if you don’t like it
column6: make your own""?

column1: Perhaps Faust truly are earnest about wanting this album to inspire public collaboration. But the idea does point to something that’s always been intriguing about Faust’s music: it’s often just as much about what they aren’t playing as what they are. Their work is full of implications and innuendos
column2: spaces waiting to be filled in.  j US t doesn’t necessarily have more of that than most Faust albums
column3: but implication does seem to be a main theme here. This is music in which every note suggests many more possibilities.

column1: j US t begins by proclaiming more than intimating
column2: and in this way it bears an uncanny resemblance to the last Faust effort
column3: 2011’s stellar Something Dirty. That record began with three bold
column4: practically rocking tunes
column5: and so does this one. Based around simple riffs and looping beats
column6: these songs are like free-form post-rock
column7: sturdy in their rhythms but opened-ended in their direction. And despite how well-defined the base of each track is
column8: there’s also tantalizing space in each one. Take ""80Hz""
column9: whose simple two-note bass figure flows beautifully with the well-timed accents of Diermaier’s percussion and Peron’s sonic grab bag. At times it dips to near-silence
column10: in other places it crests to frantic peaks
column11: but throughout it maintains a tension that compels attention.

column1: The balance between action and suggestion tips more toward the latter for the rest of j US t
column2: in ways both fascinating and frustrating. Some songs maintain the attraction of anticipation
column3: hinting at where they might go without ever fully abandoning other options. But others feel more flat than ripe
column4: not so much flirting with tense silence as drifting into empty inertia. One in particular
column5: the seven-minute ""Palpitations""
column6: is mostly limp. Its intermittent percussion and electronic squiggles sound more random than impulsive
column7: making it the only instance on the album where I find myself wishing I could already hear other bands filling it in.

column1: It takes a few tracks to recover from that mid-album drop
column2: but Faust manage to rebound on closer ""Ich Sitze Immer Noch""
column3: whose slow
column4: rising lope sounds like a sunny homage to Spiderland-era Slint. Like the bulk of j US t
column5: it offers a lot worth hearing and just as much worth daydreaming about—in other words
column6:
it achieves the band's stated goals. Maybe Peron and Diermaier really did mean what they said.
