""Try to walk a straight line in circles."" It sounds like a prompt from Brian Eno and Peter Schmidt's Oblique Strategies
column2: but really it's the artist Barnt
column3: aka Daniel Ansorge
column4: explaining his creative process in an interview with Amsterdam's Trouw nightclub. ""It's like our love for the blue ribbon in the sky
column5: he continues. ""Do we want to catch it? Or do we want to let it fly away?""

column1: It's not surprising to hear Ansorge speak in riddles and abstractions
column2: because the trappings of his music follow suit. Ansorge is a co-founder of Cologne's Magazine label—or
column3: sorry
column4: not a label
column5: but ""a depot and a serial publication of contemporary contributions."" Magazine's sleeves
column6: which look like they've been pieced together with images clipped from out-of-date textbooks
column7: might pass for pages from Artforum. Likewise
column8: Barnt's titles might as well be culled from scraps of paper found on the sidewalk
column9: or from spambots' emails: cryptic fragments with the sterile whiff of L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poetry (""All the alts I'mm holding are hurting."" (sic)
column10: ""Wiggett: So we know that hexog****""
column11: ""How Do I Know What Solutions X Form?"")
column12: whose very refusal to express anything is itself weirdly expressive.

column1: As arch as all this may seem
column2: Barnt's music is hardly short on emotion
column3: which is just as you'd expect of a techno producer schooled in krautrock and Kompakt. ""Collection""
column4: from his debut EP in 2010
column5: was a haunting house track poised halfway between Superpitcher and John Carpenter. On the same record
column6: ""What Is a Number
column7: That a Man May Know It?"" paired naïve synthesizer melodies with piledriver kicks to surprisingly moving effect. ""Libretto""
column8: compiled on Kompakt's Pop Ambient 2011
column9: conjured absent-minded melancholy out of rubbed wineglass rims. And his singles ""Geffen"" and ""Tunsten""
column10: for the Cómeme label
column11: spun minimal techno into gonzo Casiotone freakouts
column12: all seesawing chromatic sequences and dog-whistle octave play.

column1: That said
column2: Barnt's take on dance music is marked by a strange kind of clinical remove. It's not that his tracks don't work on the dancefloor—they definitely do
column3: often in the most deranged way possible—but there's always a sense of something slightly off about them. If techno is supposed to be the meeting of Kraftwerk and George Clinton in an elevator
column4: then Barnt's music is an encounter between those artists' waxy avatars on the floor of Madame Tussauds. If hyperintelligent extraterrestrials were to recreate the sound of earthling dance music after 30 years of observing us through telescopes
column5: their algorithmic reconstructions might come out sounding something like Barnt's recent 12"" for Will Bankhead and Joy Orbison's Hinge Finger label in which shuddering drum sequences and EBM bass synths hammer away
column6: without pause or variation
column7: as long as the vinyl will let them.

column1: With his debut album
column2: Barnt continues to tease out the contradictory impulses—as stone-faced romantic and lab-coated hedonist—that make his work so compelling. His kit remains the same as always: cheapish-sounding synthesizers
column3: usually no more than one or two per track
column4: and outmoded drum machines with the tempo knob seemingly permanently soldered to the 120 beats-per-minute mark. He's fond of tinny
column5: bit-crushed hi-hats and quavering tremolo leads; save for a little reverb here or there
column6: there are few obvious effects in play. It is a dry
column7: almost deadpan sound.

column1: The repetitive nature of Barnt's music
column2: with its steadily cycling arpeggios and constant pedal tones
column3: has led some listeners to connect it with the ""kosmische"" tradition of German synthesizer music of the '70s and '80s
column4: but one of the great pleasures of Barnt's work is how modest it is
column5: built of cheap plastic and low-grade metal and cracked rubber fittings. As interstellar metaphors go
column6: this isn't the hi-def sci-fi of Skrillex's spaceship; it's more like the paltry 64-kilobyte memory of the Apollo Guidance Computer.

column1: The bulk of the album is devoted to five longish tracks
column2: none shorter than six-and-a-half minutes long
column3: and one that's more than 15
column4: in which cautious melodies and economical counterpoints rise and fall above stolid four-to-the-floor beats. (Three short interludes serve as palate-cleansers; their single-keyboard riffing recalls a kid trying out synths in the music shop—dreamy
column5: wistful little airs that bridge classical schooling and solid-state circuitry.) To enumerate their elements is even more useless than usual when discussing club tracks. The leads tend to be reedy
column6: spindly things
column7: and the drum sounds lumpy and leaden; there are almost no basslines to speak of. Pedal tones and open fifths are par for the course. All the elements go out of their way to be unremarkable; it's the way they come together that really sings.

column2: a strident
column3: two-note pizzicato sequence saws dully away until it's relieved by lowing choral samples. The opening ""Wiggett: So we know that hexog****"" plays hypnotic counterpoints against cricket-legged hi-hats and insistent splash cymbals. ""How Do I Know What Solutions X Form?"" balances Medieval European and Middle Eastern influences over an Italo-disco bassline. ""Cherry Red""
column4: one of the album's best tracks
column5: works as a kind of relay race
column6: as a nervous
column7: 16th-note patter is passed from voice to voice—tuned toms
column8: open hi-hats
column9: monotone bass—for 11 minutes of continuous shuddering that sounds a lot like the echo chamber of contemporary media. The final track
column10: and the one with the most inscrutable title (""All the alts I'mm holding are hurting."")
column11: offers more than 15 minutes of minor-key meandering and desultory drum workout; the last two minutes are just one-handed keyboard noodling
column12: as if the artist were lost in a dream
column13: unable
column14: or unwilling
column15: to decide what to do about that blue ribbon in the sky
column16: and unwittingly become one with it.

column1: For all the album's studiously generic sounds
column2: there's nothing else that sounds quite like this
column3:
and perhaps that's the most important contradiction of all. For all his clinical reserve and careful attention to detail—some of these beats might as well contain footnotes—Barnt has ended up crafting an unusually heartfelt testament to techno's emotive potential.

Andy Stott must thrive in limbo. For much of the last decade
column2: the Manchester producer shifted restlessly between varied electronic niches. He darted from spartan techno to luxuriating dub and so on
column3: releasing singles with the enthusiasm of a keen listener trying to stake his own artistic identity. In 2011
column4: he claimed that place with unapologetic if muted audacity
column5: issuing two immersive EPs within four months. Passed Me By and We Stay Together flooded his self-made world of gray sounds and surface static with beats that
column6: in retrospect
column7: he seemed to have spent years learning and bending to his will. The deep house thuds of ""Cherry Eye""
column8: the footwork splendor of ""North to South""
column9: the slow-motion stutters of ""Execution"": They all cohabitated within Stott’s new twilit mode.

column1: The addition of Alison Skidmore’s clarion vocals and Stott’s evermore-aggressive rhythms only enhanced the ghostly environment of the masterful 2012 LP
column2: Luxury Problems. Mixing field recordings
column3: vocal takes
column4: and an assortment of technical processes
column5: Stott operated both inside an uncanny valley and within its inverse
column6: making the artificial seem natural and the alien seem familiar. After more than a dozen releases
column7: Stott could now call an approach—a liminal state of the human and inhuman
column8: of the driving and the drifting—his own.

column1: On Faith in Strangers
column2: Stott’s first substantive solo release since Luxury Problems
column3: he applies that kilned aesthetic to an expanding set of sounds and ideas. If that 2011–2012 trilogy found Stott codifying his style
column4: Faith in Strangers is his attempt to stretch it by piggybacking that recent system onto his early adventurousness. It’s a bold move
column5: one made with a new vote of public valediction. Luxury Problems
column6: for instance
column7: began with its most instant hook. Her voice wrapped in a lacework of effects
column8: Skidmore seductively repeated ""touch"" until Stott’s shuddering beat fell in behind her. But Faith in Strangers starts with something that belongs more on the landmark sound-art label Touch. ""Time Away"" opens in silence
column9: or at least the room tone of a field recording. A horn slowly intones one note
column10: which decays against a bed of quiet and creepy field recordings. It’s as though Stott’s world breathed in the long-tone pieces of minimalist composer Yoshi Wada and exhaled them through his trademark filter of glitches
column11: pops
column12: and hazes.

column1: Skidmore’s voice arrives for the second track
column2: the stunning ""Violence""
column3: but it’s reversed and filtered
column4: pieces of her syllables simply cut off at the root. ""Clap your hands/ clap your hands
column5: she sings as though to tease an audience about a beat that
column6: nearly nine minutes into the album
column7: has yet to arrive. When at last it does
column8: the pulse is one of the most forceful of Stott’s catalogue
column9: the shuddering bass and snare snaps suggesting that the producer has now welcomed trap into his vocabulary
column10: too. But it’s damaged and distorted in much the same way as all Stott sounds. He pulls new influences into his fold without allowing them to push him outside of his preordained spheres—a nightclub built with pillows and wired with headphones
column11: or a narcotics den affixed with mirror balls and strobe lights.

column1: Faith in Strangers starts soft and light
column2: only to have Stott gradually amplify the energy across its 54 minutes. By the time the record enters its second half
column3: it’s climbed from half-graceful
column4: half-spectral footwork to minimal rhythms rattled by enormous bass and lurid synths. And then
column5: on ""No Surrender""
column6: an organ run that suggests the house music at Timothy Leary’s Daheim Castle introduces a catastrophic beat. The kick pounds and snares pop through a sheet of static
column7: moving as if they’ve ruptured every speaker system upon initial impact. Stott applies that distortion to the splintered IDM of ""How It Was"" and
column8: most tellingly
column9: to the remarkable ""Damage"".

column1: The meat of that aptly named number is an enormous
column2: bass-backed melody
column3: the exact sort of chirping hulk that turned TNGHT into a set of five adrenaline injections. For Stott
column4: though
column5: it’s just another plaything
column6: an element to drag into his mix. He lets the hook blow out until it’s degraded into low fidelity
column7: and he surrounds it on all sides with caustic noise. The harsh cymbal splashes at the start recall a Max Neuhaus experiment with drums
column8: the clipped ending the manic cut-ups of Hrvatski. ""Damage"" is the shortest and most magnetic song on Faith in Strangers
column9: Stott’s real shot at a legitimate single. But he rejects the notion wholesale
column10: as though boasting that the rubric he’s rendered simply won’t allow something so straight.

column1: In the last three years
column2: Stott has not only cemented his approach but also upped his ambition
column3: moving from a producer who made disjointed singles to a musician hoping to craft albums with unspoken narrative action. ""It sounds cliché to say a ‘journey
column4: ’ but it’s got to be a story in some sense
column5: he told Tiny Mix Tapes of this LP. ""It does intensify from start to finish."" At this point
column6: actually pulling that off remains Stott’s main challenge. Despite his increasingly disciplined and unified technique
column7: Faith in Strangers can feel disorganized when taken as a whole. The intended arc from invitation toward aggression occssionally scans more as zigs and zags between a few distinct suites. Still
column8: the separate moments are astounding
column9:
evidence of a musician who has managed to remain inquisitive even as he’s established his signature.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21149/homepage_large.cbc3ee03.jpg|First Demo|1584.0|Fugazi|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dischord']|2014-11-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:06.651459|"

It’s always been kind of hilarious that Ian MacKaye’s first recorded declaration as Fugazi’s frontman was ""I am a patient boy."" In both a literal and figurative sense
column2: MacKaye’s early career was defined by restlessness
column3: whether setting land-speed records for early '80s hardcore in Minor Threat or swiftly shifting gears into the anthemic proto-emo of Embrace. But from the first notes of Joe Lally’s circular bass riff
column4: ""Waiting Room""—the opening song on 1988’s debut self-titled EP—instantly asserted Fugazi as something markedly different than their D.C.-hardcore pedigree suggested: cooler
column5: funkier
column6: and
column7: judging by the rhythmic pause slyly introduced at the 23-second mark
column8: even a little frisky.

column1: Actually
column2: scratch that—as it turns out
column3: MacKaye’s first recorded declaration as Fugazi’s frontman was ""Oh…. whoops."" As heard on this reissue of the band’s first recording session in January '88 (back when Arlington
column4: Virginia’s fabled Inner Ear Studio could still be found in producer Don Zientara’s suburban basement)
column5: the aforementioned pause in ""Waiting Room"" not only trips up the song’s rhythm
column6: but its lead vocalist as well. Still growing accustomed to that structural hiccup
column7: MacKaye starts singing his first lyric before quickly realizing he came in too early
column8: the self-described patient boy ironically thwarted by his own impatience. But the band played on and the tape kept rolling
column9: and
column10: despite the audible flubs and some obviously ad-libbed lyrics
column11: Fugazi would informally distribute cassette copies of the 11-track session at their early shows
column12: because
column13: well
column14: that’s what fledgling groups did with their first recordings before Bandcamp existed. And in lieu of the internet
column15: you had a small but growing tape-trading cult of Fugazi fanatics who wore out their hi-speed-dubbing decks to spread the word.

column1: But despite Fugazi’s seeming eagerness to share these off-the-cuff efforts
column2: a listen to First Demo today reveals the band’s greatest virtue in their early years was indeed their patience. It’s a quality apparent not just in the performances themselves (which see the band tempering hardcore’s incendiary energy through dub’s woozy influence
column3: rap repartee
column4: and Zeppelin-schooled groove)
column5: but in how long it took for most of these songs to officially surface. Only three of the tracks here would be rerecorded for Fugazi’s first two EPs
column6: four would eventually turn up in revised form on 1990’s full-length Repeater or its 3 Songs supplement
column7: while others remained buried until as late as 2002
column8: if not scrapped altogether. But what changed in the interim wasn’t so much the sound or shape of the songs
column9: but the very intra-band dynamic that would go onto define Fugazi’s essence.

column1: At the time of First Demo’s recording
column2: Guy Picciotto was still trying to elbow his way into a band that MacKaye
column3: Lally
column4: and drummer Brendan Canty originally envisioned as a power trio. Yet to assert himself as MacKaye’s feisty
column5: Flavor Flav-esque foil
column6: Picciotto’s second-vocalist duties initially amounted to punctuating MacKaye’s lines with extra emphasis rather than provide a counterpoint. You can immediately sense Picciotto’s tentative position on ""Waiting Room""
column7: where he offers up his now-famous ""come on and get up"" post-chorus retort as a half-muttered afterthought rather than the brash call to arms we know today. And true to its title
column8: Picciotto’s lone lead-vocal on ""Break-In"" feels very much like an intrusion
column9: a shot of pure punk insolence that serves as a check on Fugazi’s rapidly expanding musical scope.

column1: You can see why certain First Demo tracks didn’t make the cut on the band’s early proper releases
column2: considering Picciotto would soon be bringing corkers like ""Give Me the Cure"" and ""Glue Man"" to the table. The embryonic take on ""Furniture"" was presumably shelved due to its rhythmic similarity to ""Waiting Room""
column3: and it practically sounds like a preemptive dub remix of the single version that surfaced in 2001; the compilation-bound rarity ""The Word"" gets even woolier
column4: its garage-blasted charge dissolving into a distended coda likely deemed too ponderous for release even by Fugazi’s loosening standards. Meanwhile
column5: ""In Defense of Humans"" and ""Turn Off Your Guns"" (the one song here never released before in any form) sound like dry runs for the sort of accelerated
column6: in-the-pocket rave-up Fugazi would perfect several years later with Red Medicine’s ""Bed For the Scraping"".

column1: But if Fugazi was only just starting to exploit the call-and-response frisson that would ultimately spawn classics like ""Suggestion"" and ""Margin Walker""
column2: First Demo nonetheless amplifies a quality so often overshadowed by the band’s ideological concerns: Fugazi are fun
column3: and from day one
column4: they’ve wielded an affirming
column5: bounding
column6: adrenalizing noise to which the only logical physical response is hurtling yourself through a basketball hoop. And if songs like ""And the Same""
column7: ""Badmouth""
column8: ""Song #1""
column9: and ""Merchandise"" would appear in superior
column10: tightened-up form on future releases
column11: the slackened but still-potent versions here capture a band of hardcore veterans not so much stepping out of their comfort zone as finally locking into it. For long-time fans
column12: First Demo makes something of a sport out of noting the minor differences between the early and official takes
column13: like the breakdown on ""Merchandise"" where MacKaye repeats a line—""a dollar earned/ a dollar spent""—later nixed
column14: presumably for being a bit too on-the-nose. But rather than diminish First Demo’s worth
column15: such quirks ultimately justify its enduring value—these are rare
column16: illuminating displays of imperfection from a band that
column17: for the subsequent 15 years
column18:
made no false moves.

""Are you smiling? Are you frowning?""
column2: sings Pete Shelley on ""Keep on Believing""
column3: one of the best tracks on Buzzcocks’ otherwise tepid ninth album The Way. It’s a set of questions the band has been asking their listeners—and themselves—for 38 years. Following the departure of lead singer Howard Devoto soon after the release of their 1977 debut EP
column4: Spiral Scratch
column5: guitarists Pete Shelley and Steve Diggle took over as co-frontmen; from there
column6: Buzzcocks perfected pop-punk before it even existed as such
column7: infusing blurred
column8: breakneck punk anthems with doomed romanticism
column9: anti-macho tenderness
column10: and a flair for nerdy screeds about technology and morality. At the heart of those Buzzcocks classics
column11: though
column12: was the nervy balance between happy and sad. Smiling and frowning weren’t an either/or
column13: but layers of a single gloriously conflicted expression. Which only makes The Way feel even flimsier by comparison.

column1: Buzzcocks’ most recent album was 2006’s solid Flat-Pack Philosophy
column2: but those intervening eight years don’t mean much in Buzzcocks-time. Shelley
column3: Diggle
column4: and their shifting rhythm section (now comprising Chris Remington and Danny Farrante) have taken long breaks before
column5: starting with the band’s original dissolution in 1981. If anything
column6: The Way is a chance to flaunt the fruits of their latest rejuvenation. That chance is only barely taken. The album alternates neatly between Shelley- and Diggle-sung tracks
column7: and Shelley’s songs mostly hover in the mediocre range. ""Keep on Believing"" squanders a grabby opening and some vicious velocity by failing to summon a deep enough hook
column8: which Buzzcocks songs live and die by. In fact
column9: the majority of Shelley’s contributions to The Way seem to forget that speed
column10: distortion
column11: and melody don’t mean anything unless they sync up into something that sticks in the ear; ""The Way"" and ""Out of the Blue"" also come on strong then quickly evaporate
column12: while ""It’s Not You"" and ""Virtually Real"" come closest to grasping
column13: if weakly
column14: what Buzzcocks once uncontestedly owned. When ""Virtually Real"" tries to take on the dehumanization of social media
column15: it almost works—the disconnect between true love and false fronts is
column16: after all
column17: Buzzcocks’ wheelhouse—until Shelley’s rant against trolls becomes what it hates.

column1: Diggle has always been more erratic a songwriter than Shelley
column2: and that hasn’t changed on The Way. His voice is gluey and growly when matched against Shelley’s boyish
column3: heartbroken coo
column4: but Diggle’s compositions define both the highest and lowest points of the album. On the overwhelmingly positive side is ""Chasing Rainbows/Modern Times""
column5: which is not only the best song on The Way
column6: but the only song here worthy of being canonized into the group’s stable of classics. After a verse that puts a deft twist on the most basic pop-punk riff of all time
column7: that of the Ramones’ ""Blitzkrieg Bop""
column8: Diggle’s indelible yelp carries the song through with nasal
column9: nonsensical catchiness. ""In the Back"" is almost as good
column10: but Diggle mars it with limp strings of clichés (""Everything’s not what it seems/ And what you give is what you get""); the turgid ""People Are Strange Machines"" doesn’t get any cleverer than its Doors-referencing title. His voice almost disintegrates on ""Third Dimension""
column11: an embarrassing pastiche of 21st-century frat-garage stomp
column12: but it’s miles better than the five plodding
column13: go-nowhere minutes of the self-serious ""Saving Yourself"".

column1: At their best
column2: Buzzcocks can turn punk rock into a paean to bubblegum
column3: bad love poems
column4: and the Beatles. That bipolar exhilaration is evident on The Way
column5: but it doesn’t snag as well as it could. Instead of jittery counterpoint
column6: there’s a lax wobbliness to these songs
column7: and that lack of interplay—both vocally and guitar-wise—is the album’s most glaring omission. Energy isn’t the problem; they just don’t know what to do with it. Every song here wants to be an anthem
column8: and a couple almost hit the mark
column9: but the majority are barely worthy of jingle-hood. The Way is the converse of what Buzzcocks fans might have come to expect from the band at this point in the game: Instead of growing soft and slick while retaining their songwriting prowess
column10:
they’ve stayed fast and raw—but left much of their popcraft somewhere behind.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21170/homepage_large.fae035a5.jpg|Different Every Time|4629.0|Robert Wyatt|['Rock'
column3: Robert Wyatt recently announced that he's stopped working on music. Wyatt had the aspect of an old man even when he was young
column4: but for at least the last four decades he's been maintaining a consistent persona: the white-bearded great-uncle of British art-pop
column5: smoldering with revolutionary indignation about political matters but affable and goofy on every other subject
column6: turning up in his wheelchair when anybody happens to need his marvelous
column7: unmistakably cracked
column8: not-at-all-American-accented tenor on a record. It's a little alarming that he actually is getting older.

column1: Different Every Time
column2: an attempt to survey Wyatt's extraordinary half-century as a steady presence at the far edges of pop
column3: coincides with the release of Marcus O'Dair's biography of him
column4: which shares its title; apparently
column5: Wyatt and O'Dair were part of the group that picked the 2xCD's tracks. It's a very peculiar retrospective—not least because it's named after the first line of ""Sea Song""
column6: one of the most exquisite songs ever written
column7: but doesn't actually include ""Sea Song"" (or anything else from his best album
column8: 1974's Rock Bottom). His hit reworking of the Monkees' ""I'm a Believer"" is absent too.

column1: Instead
column2: its curious track listing is split between a disc of Wyatt-as-frontman and a disc of Wyatt-as-guest. (Even so
column3: one of the most durable songs to have come out under his name—the Falklands-war lament ""Shipbuilding""
column4: written for him by Elvis Costello and Clive Langer—has somehow ended up on the latter.) The first disc begins awkwardly: a 19-minute track by Soft Machine
column5: the prog-rock ensemble with whom he played drums and sang from 1966 to 1971
column6: a couple of briefer pieces by his subsequent I'm-gonna-do-this-my-way band Matching Mole (an Anglicization of ""machine molle
column7: i.e. ""soft machine"")
column8: and a song from the 1974 Live at Drury Lane gig that was his only stage performance as a solo headliner. The rest of it is a collection of terrific material that's less satisfying than most of the solo albums from which it's excerpted. Still
column9: it shows how wide Wyatt's range of moods can be: sadly meditative (""Free Will and Testament"")
column10: sadly blissful (a cover of Chic's ""At Last I Am Free"")
column11: sadly jolly (""Yesterday Man"")
column12: sadly terrifying (""Beware""
column13: sung as a duet with its writer Karen Mantler).

column1: The real attraction of Different Every Time is its second disc
column2: subtitled ""Benign Dictatorships""
column3: which cherrypicks from Wyatt's scores of guest appearances on other people's records. For an artist as idiosyncratic as he is
column4: he's an astoundingly versatile and prolific collaborator: the six-degrees-of-Kevin-Bacon figure who directly links Jimi Hendrix
column5: Hot Chip
column6: Swell Maps
column7: Pink Floyd
column8: and Björk. The track selection here mostly gravitates toward quiet and subtle work
column9: rather than the juicy pop records on which Wyatt has occasionally sung—it's worth seeking out Ultramarine's ""Happy Land"" and Bertrand Burgalat's ""This Summer Night""
column10: neither of which are included here.

column1: But it's sequenced for mood and continuity rather than chronology
column2: and it flows as well as any album Wyatt's made. One section focuses on his longstanding affiliation with jazz composers Michael Mantler and Carla Bley. Another sequence features Wyatt singing a couple of marvelous revolution-for-the-working-class anthems
column3: ""Turn Things Upside Down"" (with the brass band Happy End) and ""Venceremos (We Will Win)"" (a Latin-jazz groove recorded with Working Week and Tracey Thorn). There's even a pretty good song featuring O'Dair's band Grasscut
column4: and a beautiful deep-cut choice for the closer: Wyatt's unaccompanied
column5: ancient-sounding voice
column6: recorded in 1976
column7: singing ""Experiences No. 2""
column8: a John Cage setting of an E.E. Cummings poem. If we're not going to get any more new records from the old man
column9:
this is a more than acceptable consolation prize.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21192/homepage_large.c1516ce9.jpg|Kenny Dennis III|29808.0|Serengeti|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Joyful Noise']|2014-11-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:08.688009|"

David Cohn's earned a reputation as a storyteller who can dredge up some pinpoint details and harrowing emotions in his more serious releases as Serengeti. And since Kenny Dennis first bellowed his way into the world
column2: an alter ego that first seemed like a delivery means for some oddball Chicagoland Joe-sixpack comedy has become the sort of deeply familiar character that reveals new facets each time out. Increasingly less of a pure comedy character as time goes on
column3: the raspy
column4: mustachioed Cool Uncle of indie rap has also turned out to be a put-upon underdog
column5: a proud yet self-conscious working artist who's determined to shake off failure at all costs with a strident determination. In hindsight
column6: his defense of Cubs scapegoat Steve Bartman feels like a strong solidarity with a guy who has to live with the weight of a ""What Could've Been?"" scenario that was actually out of his control.

column1: Kenny Dennis III is technically a few Roman numerals behind the actual size of the Dennis discography (word to Tha Grimm Teachaz). But it does make for a strong thematic trilogy with 2012 character-study Kenny Dennis EP and last year's pathos-injected Kenny Dennis LP. Odd Nosdam returns to provide more off-kilter
column2: goofy yet stirring production
column3: and there's another suite of skits featuring Anders Holm from ""Workaholics"" playing Kenny's on-again/off-again estranged friend Ders. But this time
column4: there's a stronger throughline to the concept: most of the feel to Kenny Dennis III hinges on what happens when Ders decides to move back to Chicago from L.A. and tries getting a hip-hop group going with Kenny. It all goes to hell pretty quickly over the course of two separate skit medleys
column5: as Kenny's big idea to record '90s throwback freestyle house crossover as ""Perfecto"" brings out the worst in Kenny's ego and puts another wedge between himself and Ders. As off-the-wall nonsense goes
column6: it's actually pretty affecting
column7: a mixture of caricatured absurdity and real-folks groundedness worthy of Prince Paul.

column1: But the frustration and the anger are also a little more palpable than on LP and EP
column2: with Ders' POV of Kenny's jerk-ass behavior on tour offset by Kenny's own diatribe-flow stories. He still liberally sprinkles in references to sports fandom
column3: '80s muscle cars
column4: and basic-cable action movies
column5: but now it feels more like those points of interest double as security blankets. ""No Beginner"" plants his feet firmly on the ground in opposition to calculated trendy weirdness -- ""I'm not tryin to kill turtles or dye my hair strange colors/ I'm just tryin' to do rap songs and be down with my brothers""—but a daily diet of ""hot dog for lunch/ hot dog for dinner/ don't eat breakfast/ I am no beginner"" isn't exactly the glamorous life. He gets into chest-puffing brawls in ""Shidoshi"" over people mad about how he's ""makin' it look good
column6: attempting to pull Dim Mak death punches on fools. (The video for this track
column7: meanwhile
column8: involves a failed intervention.) On ""Buddy Guy""
column9: the Chess Records legend's name becomes a taunting way of addressing a hopped-up adversary who might just be himself. And ""Tanya T"" is the flashpoint where things implode
column10: as Kenny helps bail out his little brother—a victim of domestic violence—and puts a (garage) roof over his head
column11: only to see him become a police informant. When the track ends with Kenny screaming ""and this the thanks I get?!"" over and over
column12: any impressions of Kenny Dennis III as ""comedy rap"" dissipate pretty quickly
column13: and it's hard not to feel for a guy once easily thought of as a funny voice and funnier mustache.

column1: Serengeti inhabits the Kenny Dennis world so thoroughly that the affectations and tics have become a style to actually contend with
column2: raspy muttering and roaring bellows concealing vivid free-association worldbuilding and playing with the joys of repetition. The characteristic Odd Nosdam production toes that line between awkward
column3: whimsical discomfort and melancholy
column4: muddy stoner soul
column5: a Madlib/Black Moth Super Rainbow midpoint that flips from amusing to unnerving without you even noticing. And in the end
column6: all the blue-collar detritus and supposed punchlines give a stark portrait of a man who invokes his '90s glory days like a shield against their loss
column7: making a clear point of the coping-mechanism properties of his nostalgia without either reveling in it or mocking it. ""Sometimes I watch The Negotiator and think about life's long times
column8: he admits in the midst of the downcast
column9: reflective closer ""Tickled Pink""
column10:
a search for perspective and meaning in a life that might not have turned out the way he wanted it to.

Ty Segall's 2011 singles compilation collected material he recorded and released between 2007 and 2010—25 loose ends from his ""scrappy upstart"" beginnings. His songs weren't especially complex
column2: but they hit their marks and made an impact. His crazed performances were undeniable. Sure
column3: the recording quality was pretty crummy
column4: but you could say the same of the Oblivians' and Reatards' early records (and Segall's demos stand up alongside Soul Food and Teenage Hate). It was easy to root for him on those early outings—the fresh-faced punk screamer unleashing his inner demon and making songs promising enough to make you wonder where he'd go next.

column1: His trajectory from there—following Melted in 2010—isn't as easily summarized. After signing to Drag City
column2: he generally moved in a singer/songwriter direction
column3: but still kept releasing one-off rippers on labels like Castle Face
column4: Goner
column5: and Permanent. And now
column6: his prodigious output is what he's best known for: Segall has released a lot of music
column7: heaps of stuff
column8: to the point where it's hard to keep track of it all
column9: and he's refused to conform to a single style or aesthetic. Sometimes
column10: he'll sing in a detached croon (""Fine"") and trigger full-on folk nostalgia with his acoustic rambles (""Gold on the Shore""
column11: ""The West""). Elsewhere
column12: he transforms into Mr. Hyde for blasts of vicious
column13: blistering rock'n'roll (Slaughterhouse). So when presented with a compilation of singles from his past four years
column14: the first question is which version of Segall will get top billing: the lizard-brained Kiss/Black Sabbath apostle or the sentimental balladeer.

column1: Thankfully
column2: $INGLE$ 2's 12 songs avoid pigeonholing. Segall brings the fuzz and fury
column3: but the aggression is cut with tracks like ""Falling Hair"" and ""Children of Paul""
column4: the plaintive Goodbye Bread era B-sides. If his previous singles compilation showed an artist asserting his garage punk dominance
column5: this is the teenaged wrecker all grown up and ready to prove that he's capable of much more.

column1: For a collection of odds and ends
column2: $INGLE$ 2 works remarkably well as an album. To my ear
column3: it's sequenced better than Twins or Manipulator
column4: which makes some sense: the tracks are presented in chronological order
column5: which makes for a natural narrative
column6: each of his short-lived modes transitioning into his next. It also helps that there's no filler to speak of—any A-sides already found on Drag City albums have been omitted in favor of B-sides and rarities. The only track that previously appeared on an album is ""Hand Glams""
column7: but the single version is another beast entirely
column8: and
column9: with the addition of vocal harmonies and a psychedelic warble
column10: a far more interesting one at that.

column1: It's almost hard to believe that Segall's scraps are this strong—take ""For Those Who Weep""
column2: a Twins era B-side that ranks as one of the best songs he's written. It was a sign of things to come from Sleeper—warm acoustic material that sounds classic
column3: the sort of thing you could have seen the Byrds covering. On the other end of the spectrum
column4: Segall delivers ""Fucked Up Motherfucker""
column5: which
column6: with its vicious churn and Steve Mackay-style sax
column7: deserves a place in the spotlight instead of getting lost in the shuffle as one-twelfth of Castle Face's Group Flex II book. Segall even breaks the trend of covers that feel like hollow throwaways. (The low point of Slaughterhouse was the Segall Band's version of ""Diddy Wah Diddy"".) His ramped up version of the Velvet Underground and Nico's ""Femme Fatale"" excels in this comp's context
column8: as does his stomping rendition of the Groundhogs' ""Cherry Red"". The album ends on a high note with ""Pettin the Dog""
column9: a predictably vicious GG Allin cover (made G-rated for WFMU
column10: with a more radio-friendly title).

column1: Segall's most recent album
column2: Manipulator
column3: was at times a frustrating listen. It was quite good on a song for song basis
column4: but it often felt safe
column5: and Segall's mix of thrilling and somber was muddied. All of which explains why this compilation is so welcome. In addition to rounding up odds and ends
column6:
it's an important LP in its own right. Don't be fooled by how tacky the two dollar signs look in that album title: $INGLE$ 2 is the best Ty Segall album that got released in 2014.

'Legacy']|2014-11-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:10.253280|"

 To pick a few selected works from an artist's career is to construct an argument about that artist. Every curator knows that
column3: and David Bowie is nothing if not a curator. The first great Bowie best-of was 1976's Changesonebowie LP
column4: whose argument was that he was a mamapapa comin' for you
column5: a rocker too strong and too glittery to be pinned down. (The 1981 Changestwobowie LP and the 1990 Changesbowie CD
column6: stabbed in its gut by the dreadful remix ""Fame '90""
column7: tried to extend that premise.) Bowie's initial attempt at a full-career assessment was the 1989 Sound + Vision box set
column8: revised and updated in 2003. In both forms
column9: it's a bunch of hits and album tracks and rarities clumped together
column10: an impressive show of range whose failure is that it assumes
column11: rather than argues
column12: that he's a rock god and that therefore anything he does is interesting.

column1: Twenty-five years later
column2: coinciding with an actual touring museum exhibition of the apparatus around his music
column3: Bowie has assembled a new retrospective. Nothing Has Changed—a very sly title
column4: as a riposte to Changesonebowie and ""Changes""
column5: especially since it's also a lyric lifted from his 2002 song ""Sunday""—comes in three different versions
column6: each with a cover image of Bowie regarding himself in a mirror. That's a sharp gesture too: he's never been shy about his fascination with his own mercurial self
column7: shedding his skin again and again and then carefully preserving it to wriggle into again later. (This is not the first time he's done the ""multiple versions of a greatest-hits set"" trick
column8: either: 2002's Best of Bowie had twenty different track lineups
column9: depending on which country you bought it in.)

column1: The weakest of the three versions of Nothing Has Changed is the chronologically sequenced 2xCD version. It's basically just a slight revision of Best of Bowie
column2: compressed to throw in five later songs including the newly recorded oddity ""Sue (or In a Season of Crime)"". The first disc starts with his commercial breakthrough ""Space Oddity"" and ends with its sequel/repudiation ""Ashes to Ashes""
column3: which is a nice bit of symmetry. Mostly
column4: what we get is Bowie as he's understood by oldies radio
column5: although we're seven tracks in before he really starts to toughen up (with ""Ziggy Stardust"").

column1: But the second half of the 2xCD version covers three times as many years as the first
column2: and suggests that Bowie was a temporarily interesting trend-follower whose fade-out has been slowed by his being repeatedly propped up and dragged into modernity by big-name collaborators: Queen
column3: Pat Metheny
column4: Pet Shop Boys
column5: Trent Reznor
column6: James Murphy. This Bowie's sense of tune eventually abandons him and never returns. After the look back in sorrow of ""Absolute Beginners""
column7: halfway through the second disc
column8: he's coasting on his rep; it's just one decent comeback attempt after another
column9: with ""Sue"" at the end as a sort of I-give-up-but-here's-something-new-anyway gesture. That's a reasonable case to make; it also misses most of what's magical about this particular artist.

column1: The 2xLP version of Nothing Has Changed makes a simpler and happier argument

On the front cover of their 2013 debut
column3: Silence Yourself
column4: UK quartet Savages seized our attention with a printed manifesto about seizing our attention: ""The world used to be silent
column5: now it has too many voices
column6: it began
column7: ""and the noise is a constant distraction."" Their remedy for distraction was disruption—that is
column8: to make a spine-jolting
column9: whiplashing
column10: smartphone-shattering noise that couldn’t be ignored
column11: coupled with uniformly stern appearances and a striking lead singer
column12: Jehnny Beth
column13: who can seem like she’s peering into your soul and draining you of your secrets even when she’s glancing in another direction. Savages assert an ironically severe
column14: almost militaristic aesthetic for a band who says its primary objective is to promote ""emancipation"" from cultural conformity and institutionalized oppression. But you can’t accuse them of not heeding their own advice: mere weeks after Silence Yourself hit record-store shelves
column15: Savages were already eager to upset the expectations of anyone who had them pegged as that month’s post-punk pin-ups.

column1: Words to the Blind is the name of a 37-minute
column2: Dada-inspired concert staged at the Red Gallery in London
column3: UK on May 29
column4: 2013 in collaboration with locally based Japanese psych-punk outfit Bo Ningen. Or
column5: rather
column6: in confrontation: As Beth explained to me in an interview last year
column7: ""At Cabaret Voltaire [in Zurich]
column8: they would do simultaneous poetry—poems in different languages recited at the same time. We started from that idea and did this sonic poem with two bands playing a piece together simultaneously
column9: [like] a battle."" To emphasize that aspect
column10: the two bands were arranged symmetrically in a U-formation
column11: so that their respective players were facing off against one another. But while the notion of two groups engaging in lawless sonic warfare—and listeners’ attention being divided between two oppositional entities—may run counter to Savages’ core philosophy of drowning out extraneous noise and sharpening our mental focus
column12: this live document of the event ultimately serves the same ideal (albeit through a more meticulous
column13: protracted
column14: and sometimes punishing process).

column1: The phrase ""words to the blind"" first appeared as a lyric in Silence Yourself’s caustic opener ""Shut Up""
column2: and thus serves as a sort of hyperlink from Savages’ ideologically driven art-punk attack into the sensory
column3: improvised mode of communication at play in this piece. Likewise
column4: the performance requires Bo Ningen to melt down their intricately constructed
column5: hyperactive contorto-rock—the technicolor yin to Savages’ grayscale yang—into more mercurial form. True to the project’s original Dadaist-poetry inspiration
column6: Words to the Blind begins with Beth and Bo Ningen’s Taigen Kawabe ominously whispering random phrases in French and Japanese
column7: respectively
column8: as if reciting an ancient spell to awaken their sleeping-beast instrumentalists. Over the course of the next 10 minutes
column9: the recording stirs to life in a slowly mounting atmospheric swirl of eerie guitar squeals
column10: rain-on-tin drum patter
column11: random bass blurts
column12: and frosty-breathed coos
column13: before the two groups find a common ground on a stalking rhythm that eventually yields to a series of seismic
column14: Boredoms-worthy psych-metal eruptions at the halfway point.

column1: But while those sudden volcanic outbursts provide ample payoff for Words to the Blind’s distended build-up
column2: and serve as the piece’s structural peak
column3: its true climax is revealed in the ashen aftermath. As Beth assumes lead vocals in English
column4: the final third unsurprisingly constitutes the most distinctly Savages-like passage
column5: with a corrosive groove gutted from the same sludgy turf as Silence Yourself’s ""Strife"". But in this context
column6: Beth’s familiar references to fraught eroticism (""you are jealous
column7: ""I betray you
column8: ""We are friends
column9: we are enemies
column10: speaking our love songs in different languages"") speak as much to the tension that inevitably exists between two bands engaging in a musical experiment of this magnitude. In Words to the Blind’s deceptively peaceful dying moments
column11: Beth repeats the phrase ""The skin divides the broken hearts/ The love divides the lovers/ The beautiful song of the night/ Is a song of war""—before the two bands unleash one final round of cacophonous crossfire
column12: like a gangland shootout from which no one walks away alive. For Savages and Bo Ningen
column13:
harmony is ultimately found in anarchy.

For each song on Nots’ debut album
column2: there’s a word or phrase that makes itself prominent
column3: forcefully. Most of these are ripped from the song’s titles: ""insect eyes
column4: ""decadence
column5: ""reactor
column6: ""strange rage
column7: ""static
column8: ""psychic talk show."" They’re used as bludgeons
column9: shouted by multiple voices
column10: often lobbed with disdain or disgust. Obviously
column11: there’s a lot of punk rock utility in catchy
column12: abrasive
column13: oft-repeated two-word hooks—when several people shout ""black mold"" in unison
column14: you pay attention. With these kinds of choruses
column15: they come out of the gate with undeniable power
column16: but Nots aren’t merely offering a surface-level veneer of ""creepy"" or ""strange."" Natalie Hoffmann
column17: Charlotte Watson
column18: Madison Farmer
column19: and Alexandra Eastburn are
column20: at times
column21: incredibly bleak. They’re letting you know that they’ve lived through some shit.

column1: Here are some of their points of reference: a person stumbling in the dark while consumed by rage
column2: joyless posturing
column3: blank smiles
column4: blood on the lawn
column5: decay—the names
column6: faces
column7: stories
column8: details
column9: and circumstances behind their songs are unclear
column10: veiled behind minimal poetry and symbolism. That's why every song encourages a few deep listens with the lyrics sheet in hand—there are so many subtle turns in their words
column11: and when you look closely at their stark phrasings
column12: it's clear they communicate quite a bit.

column1: Regardless of where it's coming from
column2: We Are Nots is fueled by its deep well of anger and frustration. Listen to how they yell; they're sick of being complacent
column3: of watching people walk around with an unwarranted smug ease. Nots don't have time for that
column4: and their brand of ""weird punk
column5: as Hoffmann summarized it during a Memphis morning TV segment
column6: lends an ominous attack which reflects that tone. Every member of the band plays a role in adding heft and urgency to complement the lyrics. There's Farmer's persistently ominous bass
column7: Hoffmann's swirling and echoing hellscape guitars
column8: Watson's unrelenting bash
column9: and perhaps the most imperative weapon in Nots' arsenal
column10: Eastburn's ever-present synthesizer. So often
column11: synths in punk music are an afterthought with a definitively tertiary spot behind the guitars. Here
column12: it plays a prominent role in forming each track's overall tone.

column1: Eastburn's presence also gives the band more freedom to go long. The Memphis band’s debut 7” arrived late last year—four muffled
column2: lo-fi tracks that were vicious and raucous. Under their initial lineup (Hoffmann
column3: Watson
column4: and Laurel Ferdon)
column5: they delivered great songs. Still
column6: they felt definitively like 7” songs—succinct
column7: loud
column8: and powerful
column9: but too primitive and punchy to carry an entire album. Like so many other bands in the garage punk sphere just putting out their first single
column10: it was unclear whether or not they could transition naturally into an ""album band."" They did
column11: though—We Are Nots succeeds because Nots have evolved. With Watson moving behind the drums
column12: they’ve got a stronger backbone. Eastburn’s synthesizers expand the band's scope
column13: making their songs feel more fully realized and giving the band more freedom to go long. On “Reactor”
column14: for example
column15: Hoffmann takes her time with a few well-placed guitar stabs; she wouldn’t be able to do that without the band’s newfound synth sprawl.

column1: The biggest obstacle they face with their first long-player is that We Are Nots is clearly set in its ways. The synthesizers
column2: the gang vocals
column3: their approach to choruses—it's all reasonably similar across these 27 minutes. Even Hoffmann’s vocal style
column4: thrillingly furious in its from-the-gut delivery
column5: doesn’t vary too much. But the structures
column6: stories
column7: and overall tones differ enough from song to song that this never feels like a monotone slog. They've created a surefooted
column8: aesthetic defining opening statement.

column1: ""Don’t act like you and I would get along
column2: sings Hoffmann on the 48-second track ""Get Along"" shortly before she’s joined by several voices feverishly yawping ""LA LA LA LA LA LA LA"" over and over again. Hoffmann might be alone in pointing the finger accusingly during the verse
column3: but she's quickly backed by her bandmates. They're a united front
column4: belligerent and dizzying in their approach. It's aggressive
column5:
and it sounds like fun.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21241/homepage_large.eaf4f4cd.jpg|Aliens in the Outfield EP|31392.0|Diarrhea Planet|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Infinity Cat']|2014-11-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:12.272071|"

Two songs into Aliens in the Outfield—the latest EP from Nashville ruffians Diarrhea Planet—and Brent Toler is feeling himself: ""Why are you chumming with the high class
column2: he asks a young woman of his acquaintance
column3: when ""you could be getting with a badass?"" One song over
column4: drummer Casey Weissbuch's locked himself in the bathroom
column5: where he's enjoying a few minutes to himself in full view of the mirror. On name alone
column6: it's hard to say just how seriously a person should be taking a band like Diarrhea Planet; and even harder
column7: when they're spitting comically awful game
column8: touting the well-documented virtues of self-love
column9: or trying to cram four guitar solos into two-and-a-half minutes. Still
column10: listening to Aliens in the Outfield
column11: you get the distinct impression that
column12: if nobody else is going to take Diarrhea Planet seriously
column13: they may just have to take up the task themselves. Fear not
column14: DP loyal: the five-song Aliens contains no shortage of boot-and-rally solos
column15: nor opportunities for downing freshly keyed beers. But once you cut through the tangled fretwork and all those gang choruses
column16: there's a quiet ambition at work here
column17: which finds Diarrhea Planet stretching out song lengths and dipping into a darker mood or two.

column1: Recorded with Justin Francis (Anti-Flag
column2: Kenny Rogers)
column3: Aliens is Diarrhea Planet's first release since 2013's sophomore LP I'm Rich Beyond Your Wildest Dreams. Francis helps DP maintain a bit more control over the inevitable chaos that arises when you've got four guitars
column4: three singers
column5: and—in Weissbuch—a drummer with roughly seven arms. Not that Aliens is an especially polished recording; tempos still fly forward
column6: and vocals still take a note or two to find their pitch. But
column7: with a little more separation between all those moving parts
column8: DP's frequently squashed studio sound is getting closer to approaching the sweat-spattered energy of their can't-miss live shows.

column1: Chorus-dodging opener ""Heat Wave"" is a blur
column2: barreling through a couple Jordan Smith verses
column3: a bridge-to-nowhere from the sweet-voiced Emmett Miller
column4: and at least one barnburning solo. ""Heat Wave"" feels a bit grafted together by spare parts
column5: getting by purely on forward motion; Smith's slippery verse melody and Miller's starry-eyed interlude are no match for the solo jammed between them
column6: and the general apathy at the heart of the lyrics (""I don't give a shit/ And I know that you don't care"") don't exactly help the song linger long past the fadeout. Highlight ""Platinum Girls"" sets Toler's ""Two Princes"" routine up with a lively little melody or three; atop a melody this blithely catchy
column7: a line like the eternally eager Toler's ""though I could never be your nice guy/ I'd proudly be your 20-times-a-night guy"" manages
column8: in its fumbling sort of way
column9: to endear.

column1: ""Bamboo Curtain"" doesn't limit its self-examination to matters of the flesh; Weissbuch's stolen moment finds him ""washing away all [his] crazy shit that [he] can't deal with"" alongside wads of used Kleenex. While the song's slantwards melody and flickers of neon guitar recall Weezer's Pinkerton-era lonerism
column2: live staple ""Spooners"" goes for Japandroids-style communal catharsis: ""it's all about the drugs
column3: money
column4: power
column5: and getting off
column6: Smith yells
column7: adding ""and getting fucked up when you can't get your point across."" Between the extended intro
column8: the false ending
column9: and the wordless chorus
column10: the restless ""Spooners"" seems too busy getting from one place to another to actually settle into the business of being a song for more than a few seconds at a time. So it goes with closer ""Peg Daddy""
column11: which rides a lengthy post-rock buildup into a yearning chorus; the anticipation's nice
column12: but the song it eventually settles on is your standard-issue existential drama
column13: hinging awkwardly on a slapdash metaphor full of crashing waves and mental prisons.

column1: The uptick in ambition all these take-offs and landings inject into DP's music is certainly admirable
column2: but the execution's not always so dazzling; every one of these songs would do well to push the chorus further forward
column3: not to delay the inevitable by throwing another twinkling guitar on the pile. And between the rough-around-the-edges presentation and the ripcord song structures
column4: there's a certain unfixed quality to these five tracks; you get the feeling
column5: listening to Aliens in the Outfield
column6: that these tunes—spirited
column7: albeit spotty—still haven't quite come to full fruition
column8: that they'll be at their best on some Tuesday night in Omaha
column9: not here as presented on record. And
column10: for whatever it's worth
column11: the more serious notes they've attempted to fold into these songs simply can't match the easy charms of an old chestnut like ""Ghost With a Boner"". But the real issue with Aliens in the Outfield isn't so much unrealized ambitions or misguided stabs at something like maturity. As with every other DP record before it
column12: it's this: it'll do in a pinch
column13: but up against that beastly live show
column14:
the play-at-home version's just no match for the real thing.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21206/homepage_large.a6954982.jpg|Alpha Mike Foxtrot: Rare Tracks 1994–2014|4596.0|Wilco|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nonesuch']|2014-11-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:12.732192|"

Near the start of Alpha Mike Foxtrot
column2: a 77-track collection of rarities
column3: alternate takes
column4: and live tracks from across Wilco’s 20-year career
column5: Jeff Tweedy can be heard worrying about whether he has a place in the long line of great singer/songwriters that came before him. ""You already know the story
column6: the chords are just the same
column7: he sings
column8: accompanied by strums and warbling cassette ambience. ""You already know I love you
column9: now I sound like what's-his-name.""

column1: When he recorded the demo of ""Someone Else’s Song""
column2: Tweedy was entering a scary new phase of his musical—and personal—life after the dissolution of alt-country heroes Uncle Tupelo
column3: in which he mostly played second fiddle to fellow frontman Jay Farrar. And in 1995
column4: the same year the demo was originally released
column5: the then-28-year-old became a new husband and father
column6: with little name recognition and no discernible life skills other than writing and singing songs. But even on that imperfect artifact
column7: a lot of what would later define Tweedy as an artist was apparent: the casualness
column8: the anxiety
column9: the almost-uncomfortable sincerity. Meanwhile
column10: the randomness of the recorded-over cassette’s pops and hisses could be heard as an accidental precursor to the unplanned abstractions that would later elevate Wilco to the realm of America’s most innovative rock bands. So just as the early take on ""Someone Else’s Song"" catches a vulnerable songwriter at an especially vulnerable moment
column11: its overall message is resolute
column12: with Tweedy spinning his referential concerns into confidence: ""You can't stop me
column13: I want you to know/ I know it sounds like someone else's song
column14: from a long time ago.""

column1: Both Alpha Mike Foxtrot and the 38-song What’s Your 20? best-of compilation offer compelling timelines of Wilco’s unlikely evolution from somewhat-generic roots rockers
column2: to quasi-pop studio mad men
column3: to soothsaying rock’n’roll deconstructionists
column4: to spasmodic guitar adventurers
column5: to epiphanic jammers
column6: to a comfortable
column7: if less exciting
column8: combination of all those previous guises. What’s Your 20? is for the neophytes—it’s a very reasonable place to start for future generations facing down Wilco’s full catalog on Spotify. Alpha is for the die-hards
column9: the ones who may have a yellowing ticket stub from the band’s fall 2001 tour in a drawer somewhere
column10: who know all the words without thinking
column11: who want to live through this band once again
column12: but in a skewed
column13: newish way.

column1: Every track isn’t some kind of lost classic
column2: and not just because every track has already been released in some form
column3: whether as a B-side
column4: on a soundtrack
column5: or via the band’s website. Even Tweedy himself acknowledges some of the lesser moments here with off-the-cuff
column6: generally-on-point track-by-track liner notes: He describes a scattershot remix of Summerteeth’s ""A Shot in the Arm"" by David Kahne (aka the guy who rejected Yankee Hotel Foxtrot and dropped Wilco from Reprise Records) as ""a dated mess [that] doesn’t have anything to do with the feeling that I had about the song
column7: and confesses that the horny
column8: cringe-worthy ""Old Maid"" is drummer ""Glenn Kotche’s least favorite song in the entire Wilco oeuvre."" Running nearly five hours
column9: Alpha plays like a clearinghouse more than a finely-edited set but
column10: largely thanks to its bevy of well-chosen live tracks
column11: its sidelong view of Wilco is worth a peek.

column1: Though Tweedy first gained attention as an acolyte of classic country and folk
column2: it’s his penchant for upending convention that has proven to be most enduring. This restlessness was there from the beginning; though Uncle Tupelo were known for their reverence to songwriting tradition
column3: they also weren’t afraid to bust out a blitzing punk version of ""Knockin’ on Heaven’s Door""—or a country take on the Stooges' ""I Wanna Be Your Dog"". Alpha highlights this rip-‘em-up aesthetic early on with two versions of the small-town ode ""Passenger Side""
column4: from Wilco’s 1995 debut
column5: A.M.; the first jangles and twangs tastefully while the second turns the song into a pop-punk screecher in the Replacements mold.

column1: This contrarian strategy—taking a quiet song and exploding it live
column2: or vice versa—offered a way for Wilco to make their early songs
column3: along with the band itself
column4: more slippery and less susceptible to pigeonholing. Another great example of this from Alpha is an aching guitar-and-piano take on A.M.’s ""Box of Letters""
column5: which reveals the hurt underneath the kiss-off’s biting album version while reminding us of the warmth of Tweedy’s determined shrug of a voice. Eventually
column6: the band figured out how to combine its multiple musical personalities within one song as Tweedy delved further into himself to tease-out a fresh kind of indirect writing based on improvisation and subconscious connection.

column1: ""For a long time
column2: I thought if I wrote a song that anybody could sing
column3: I'd succeeded
column4: he told The Chicago Reader in 2004. “Then I started losing interest in that and started feeling like I wanted to write stuff that only makes sense if I sing it."" A watershed example of this approach is Summerteeth’s ""Via Chicago""
column5: which morphs from a downtrodden ballad to a tumbling feedback squall while Tweedy nonchalantly dreams of murder. It's not a Bob Dylan song
column6: or a Neil Young song
column7: or a Tom Petty song. It is a Jeff Tweedy song
column8: a Wilco song. The track is rightly included in What’s Your 20?
column9: though the early demo of it featured on Alpha is just a static
column10: stepping-stone take that Tweedy himself calls ""sad and miserable.""

column1: A huge factor going into Wilco’s ever-changing sound throughout their first decade was the band’s ever-changing lineup. For instance
column2: the change from Summerteeth’s maximalism to the focused austerity of Yankee Hotel Foxtrot can in part be attributed to the band recruiting known experimenter Jim O’Rourke to mix Foxtrot at the same time as they were losing touch with multi-instrumentalist
column3: producer
column4: and overdub impresario Jay Bennett. Later on
column5: Bennett’s ouster would lead Tweedy to flex his lead-guitar muscle on the brilliant A Ghost Is Born. And it’s this middle period filled with personnel switches and personal tumult—Summerteeth
column6: Foxtrot
column7: and Ghost—that still stands as their greatest work.

column1: Considering Foxtrot’s lofty status within the history of Wilco—along with its sign-of-the-times label drama
column2: it’s still their best-selling album by a wide margin—it is somewhat underrepresented on Alpha. The box set boasts a few relatively well-known outtakes
column3: but in light of Foxtrot’s painstaking gestation
column4: which had the band trying songs out in many different styles to see what stuck
column5: it would have been interesting to hear a few previously unreleased attempts at those beloved tracks.

column1: The material culled from Wilco’s ambitious and fruitful time making and playing Ghost is more substantial
column2: peaking with three consecutive 2004 live tracks featuring their fleshed-out six-man incarnation
column3: which remains intact to this day: 10-minute motorik blast ""Spiders (Kidsmoke)""
column4: eerie deal-with-the-devil update ""Hell Is Chrome""
column5: and the monolithic and bipolar ""At Least That’s What You Said"" all spotlight Tweedy’s stunning distorted guitar work—oddly one of the band’s most underutilized assets—which combines the majesty of Television’s Marquee Moon with the spontaneity of free jazz great Albert Ayler. The sheer emotional audacity of these solos cannot be overstated; 21st-century rock guitar does not get better than this. After figuring out how to get the most out of abstracting his lyrics and arrangements on Foxtrot
column6: Tweedy did himself one better by eliminating language altogether on large swaths of Ghost
column7: replacing it with six-string bursts that said just as much
column8: if not more.

column1: Whereas material from the first five Wilco albums make up the lion’s share of Alpha
column2: the band’s last three records are only represented by about a dozen tracks
column3: which seems about right. Because while those albums
column4: especially 2007’s earthy Sky Blue Sky
column5: contain great individual songs
column6: they don’t coalesce the way Wilco’s best albums do. Perhaps the stability of their lineup has made it harder for them to make exciting left turns
column7: or maybe Tweedy grew tired of constantly pushing himself and his audience to uncomfortable places. Even the singer himself recently admitted that their last record
column8: 2011’s The Whole Love
column9: ""was taken for granted a little bit
column10: not necessarily by critics
column11: maybe by ourselves."" After 20 years of Wilco
column12:
Tweedy is seemingly no longer vexed by the prospect of overcoming someone else’s song—though surpassing his own is only getting tougher.
