column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21240/homepage_large.df549301.jpg|Avonmore|1479.0|Bryan Ferry|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['BMG']|2014-11-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:13.877291|"

Throughout his post-Roxy Music solo career
column3: Bryan Ferry has rarely stood still. Aside from an ill-advised collection of Dylan covers in 2007
column4: his recorded output generally represents a series of assured steps forward. His last record
column5: 2013’s The Jazz Age
column6: allowed Ferry to play around with big band takes on his expansive back catalog
column7: a project that could have potentially been dismal (and unnecessary)
column8: but instead came off as both fun and surprisingly inspired. Now
column9: nearly a year later
column10: Ferry releases Avonmore—his 15th solo album and his first collection of new songs in nearly four years.

column1: On Avonmore
column2: Ferry enlists the help of an all-star cast of players and producers—Todd Terje
column3: Nile Rodgers
column4: Johnny Marr
column5: Flea
column6: Ronnie Spector
column7: Mark Knopfler
column8: and Maceo Parker. With the exception of Rodgers (whose graceful guitar work pops up all over the record) and Terje
column9: most of the special guests are all but invisible on Avonmore
column10: their presence muted by Ferry’s unmistakable voice and the lush production. As Ferry has become known increasingly for his impeccable covers
column11: it’s refreshing that Avonmore is comprised almost exclusively of original material
column12: most of which hearkens back to his most classic sounds.

column1: Some of the tracks could have drifted off of one of Ferry’s mid-'80s solo records. ""Loop de Li"" and ""Midnight Train"" come complete with tastefully employed chimes and a smattering of low key horns. Both are dark and romantic with the kind of breathless quality that only Ferry can offer. Going even further
column2: ""A Special Kind of Guy"" is so intensely Ferry-ish that it borders on parody
column3: as he croons ""When you’re with me every problem seems to disappear/ Fields of roses burst into flower and everyone a tear."" Almost no one else could get away with this
column4: but Ferry manages to sell it perfectly almost every time.

column1: Avonmore flounders when the music
column2: which routinely flirts with a kind of adult contemporary smoothness
column3: leans over into blandness. Co-written by Johnny Marr
column4: ""Soldier of Fortune"" would be forgettable were it not for Ferry’s tremulous voice
column5: which manages to make a line like ""Girl stop rockin
column6: you’re driving me insane"" sound more compelling than it actually is. ""Driving Me Wild"" and ""Lost""
column7: while not terrible
column8: lack the surging mystique of the record’s better songs
column9: while ""One Night Stand"" mines '80s tropes in the worst possible way—honking sax
column10: a chorus of sassed up backup singers
column11: and an un-funky Ferry going on about tiger skin rugs. It nearly negates all the amorous glamour that makes the rest of the record such a delicious swoon.

column1: The two covers on Avonmore provide some of the weirdest surprises. Stephen Sondheim’s ""Send in the Clowns"" could have been rendered as a bit of grandly devastating melodrama
column2: but instead gets mostly buried under a load of damp electronica. While it’s admirable that Ferry might give the venerable bit of camp a modern spin
column3: the end result is something limp and mostly drama-free. He has more success with his cover of Robert Palmer’s ""Johnny and Mary""—a collaboration with Norwegian producer Todd Terje that first appeared on Terje’s excellent It’s Album Time earlier this year. It’s one of the album’s most gorgeous moments
column4: a melancholic ode to romantic ennui that actually allows Ferry to sound his age.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Avonmore is a fine addition to Bryan Ferry’s oeuvre
column3: if not necessarily a terribly challenging one. At this point
column4: Ferry’s well-documented good taste is both an asset and possibly a curse. While this new record is slick and often quite lovely—recalling '80’s masterworks like Boys and Girls or Bête Noire—one can’t help but wish that Ferry might go spend a little more time in the studio with someone like Terje. His voice remains one of the most singular and finely-honed sounds in popular music
column5:
it would just be nice to hear it dropped into new settings more often.

"|19981.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19981-avonmore/|6.7|T. Cole Rachel

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21248/homepage_large.4df0a71b.jpg|Heartless|32615.0|Jesse Ruins|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Desire'
column2:
'M/A/G/N/I/P/H']|2014-11-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:14.583878|"

Artists have been trying to say something smart about the rise of social media and its place in the world for a while now
column3: but the results are often clunky. Some have reminisced about the good old inconvenient days (Arcade Fire’s ""We Used to Wait"") while others have refused to see any potential benefits from people talking to one another on Twitter (David Eggers). This year
column4: EMA entered the conversation with The Future’s Void
column5: but her otherwise solid music was marred by awkward lyrical references to the ""interwebs"" and ""selfies."" Just this month
column6: Parquet Courts (or Parkay Quarts) released a song called ""Content Nausea"" whose message boils down to ""the Internet is not good."" It’s a topic worth exploring
column7: but one that comes with a lot of pitfalls.

column1: Looking at the track titles on Tokyo duo Jesse Ruins’ latest album
column2: Heartless
column3: it appears they’re devoting their second full-length to confronting the social-media-saturated world of 2014. Songs include ""She Is in Instagram""
column4: ""Forgot Your Account""
column5: and ""URL Sinking"" among others
column6: but Heartless avoids trying to make a statement in favor of capturing what a digitally soaked life is like. It’s a jarring listen
column7: as the pair of Nobuyuki Sakuma and Naho Imajima move from lush synth-pop to aggressive dance sounds
column8: puncturing songs with sudden vocal touches. Heartless is a work shaped by the mad pace of the Internet.

column1: The project wasn't originally concerned with the real world. Sakuma created Jesse Ruins in 2011 to make woozy music blurring the line between dream-pop and dance; though they remained on the edges of the Japanese scene
column2: tracks like ""Dream Analysis"" caught the attention of Western music blogs and New York label Captured Tracks
column3: who released an EP compiling their earliest songs. After releasing their debut last year on Lefse Records
column4: though
column5: they went in a slightly different direction. Sakuma told Japanese site Public Rhythm earlier this month that his group’s earlier material explored fantasies
column6: while Heartless would be more conscious of the world around them.

column1: This shift doesn’t erase all the sonic tricks Nobuyuki and Imajima have developed
column2: though. As escapist as songs like ""Dream Analysis"" could get
column3: there was also always a shadowy element lurking underneath the shine. They use one specific technique from that song—overlapping Imajima’s voice with a lower-pitched
column4: throaty vocal—on early Heartless number ""L for App""
column5: a rumbling number that achieves further unease by repeating a second-long sound of a person moaning. Jesse Ruins’ get a lot out of voices emerging from the ether
column6: highlighted on the skeletal ""Empty TL""
column7: wherein barely audible murmurs float in like lonely echoes.

column1: Heartless keep you on your toes
column2: switching between meditative and aggressive. The latter take heavy cues from Sakuma’s early interest in dance
column3: and in cases like ""Eat a Holy Monitor""
column4: the music is squelchy acid house turned suffocating. A late run of floor-oriented cuts end up being the album’s weak point
column5: though
column6: as Jesse Ruins let unremarkable grooves such as ""Eat a Heartless Monitor"" and ""Click Raw"" go on too long. Heartless works best when moving frequently between styles and speed
column7: sometimes on the same song
column8: such as the fast-paced-but-melancholic ""ILAifS"" or the skittering ""404nf"".

column1: Even though it doesn’t aim for any grand statements
column2: Heartless’ shifty nature manages to reflect a balanced view of what an online-oriented world is like. There are moments of claustrophobia and of loneliness (""Forgot Your Account"" might be the saddest song to make you think of a ""forgot your password?"" link)
column3: and lots of hints of something more menacing lurking in the distance. Yet Jesse Ruins can also get dreamy
column4: as on late optimistic slow burns ""Truth of D"" and ""URL Sinking"". If Sakuma and Imajima set out to not take a hardline stance but rather reflect web-intertwined life
column5: Heartless succeeds thanks to its multiple sonic directions
column6:
which often spill over onto one another. It makes for a multi-dimensional listen that rarely trips over itself.

"|19989.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19989-jesse-ruins-heartless/|7.0|Patrick St. Michel

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21169/homepage_large.b7ec41bd.jpg|Nansemond|30957.0|Nathan Bowles|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Paradise of Bachelors']|2014-11-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:15.332269|"

Beneath the simple
column2: familiar melodies of traditional Appalachian music lies an elemental undercurrent. It’s easy—and fun—to stomp your feet to old-timey tunes
column3: but when their circling figures are repeated at length
column4: the catchy gradually becomes the hypnotic. Many musicians have recognized this potential and mined it brilliantly—think of John Fahey matching country-blues fingerpicking to Indian ragas
column5: or the twangy held-tones of Henry Flynt’s ""avant-garde hillbilly"" style.

column1: Early in their now 21-year career
column2: Virginia band Pelt similarly gravitated toward the mesmerizing possibilities of Applachian-influenced drone. In 2006
column3: they added banjo player Nathan Bowles
column4: presumably because he shared that sensibility. That common approach subsequently shone through on his 2012 solo debut A Bottle
column5: A Buckeye
column6: and it’s even brighter on his follow-up
column7: Nansemond. Its seven tracks aren’t all extended loops; a few are more succint songs with vocals
column8: and there’s sonic variety everywhere. But the core of the album is a fascination with entrancing repetition.

column1: In the best instances
column2: Bowles sounds like he could play forever without boring himself or anyone listening. He attacks his strings boldly and sharply
column3: yet he continually adds small variations and minute adjustments
column4: viewing each iteration of a chord or phrase from a slightly different angle. This subtly-evolving consistency creates an intriguing blend of comfort and tension. You can settle your ears into Bowles’ grooves
column5: or you can lean to the edge of your seat wondering what little shift will come next. Often
column6: you can do both at the same time.

column1: Bowles places his longest explorations at the beginning and end of Nansemond
column2: and they serve as the album’s high points. ""Sleepy Lake Bike Club"" opens with a low
column3: echoing tone and some deliberate chords
column4: before launching into six minutes of energetic plucks and strums. Even though he hews to a form
column5: Bowles intuitively feels his way around those melodic paces rather than dryly executing them. At the other end of Nansemond
column6: ""Golden Floaters/Hog Jank"" is patient and halting in a way that puts you in the passenger seat next to Bowles
column7: while the spry chords of ""Sleepy Lake Tire Swing"" escalate into a passage played so fast it feels maniacally possessed.

column1: In between
column2: Bowles offers a gruffly crooned ditty
column3: a fiddle-heavy hoedown
column4: and a folk piece that morphs into a rock journey with searing electric guitar from Charalambides’ Tom Carter. All of those strands are united by Bowles’ dedication to repetition
column5: as well as his knack for making everything intensely percussive even when no drums are present. (Bowles was a drummer before he joined the more-traditional-sounding Pelt side project Black Twig Pickers
column6: who convinced him to take up banjo.)

column1: Bowles titled Nansemond after a near-extinct Indian tribe; he grew up next to a river in Virginia that adopted their name. The word represents lots of complex history
column2: and one could surely make parallels between that textured legacy and the many nuances in Bowles’ music. But it’s also fitting to just think of this record as a musical river—a flowing body of work that’s dependably solid and rippling with variation. For Bowles
column3:
the rich potential of simple traditions is as crucial as the water that fills a stream.

"|19919.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19919-nathan-bowles-nansemond/|7.2|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21238/homepage_large.6e709704.jpg|A Hound at the Hem|19363.0|Slim Twig|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['DFA']|2014-11-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:15.876193|"

Slim Twig is a young man from Toronto named Max Turnbull and
column2: among other things
column3: his work makes the case that Bobby Pickett’s ""Monster Mash"" might well be a cultural high-water mark. He's by no means a novelty act
column4: however; Turnbull takes underground art seriously and literally
column5: releasing spooky
column6: risen-from-the-grave albums like A Hound at the Hem that feature multi-layered
column7: sophisticated pop songs mired in misdirection and haunted-house trickery.

column1: When he was the toast of Toronto a few years ago
column2: Slim Twig was an intriguing cultural cross between John Waters
column3: Vincent Price
column4: and Gene Pitney—high-minded
column5: campy
column6: and playful enough to draw us into his surreal world of rockabilly blues and horror. A precocious theatre kid at the time (his parents are filmmakers Ross Turnbull and Jennifer Hazel; he himself played Ellen Page’s love interest in The Tracey Fragments)
column7: he took as much care of his visual persona—a nattily dressed
column8: pompadour-sporting crypt-keeper—as he did his music. However divisive
column9: he was Canada’s great grey hope for an unlikely moment
column10: shielding us from the restless
column11: driving spirt within.

column1: His work has drawn comparisons to wily shape-shifters like David Bowie
column2: Suicide
column3: Nick Cave/The Birthday Party
column4: and David Lynch
column5: all of whom have certainly drawn power from the same hair-raising darkness that feeds Slim Twig. He recorded A Hound at the Hem in 2010 but shelved it in favor of a more palatable album called Sof’ Sike. Apparently Hound’s edgy
column6: mind-altering textures were a bit much for anyone accustomed to the comparably direct
column7: accessible releases he'd dispatched up to this point. For all of his slick grit
column8: nothing seemed to spook him and his business associates as much as the enigmatic A Hound at the Hem
column9: which
column10: after a small self-released run in 2012
column11: is finally reaching a wider audience via DFA.

column1: The record starts so beautifully with ""Heavy Splendour""'s soothing string arrangement by Owen Pallett and executed by St. Kitt’s string quartet. But the progression deliberately goes awry. Turnbull’s penchant for dramatically off-kilter musical flourishes and gestures means that an infectious pop progression is often perverted and unsettled; some kind of howling
column2: dissatisfied specter possesses each song’s eerie  soundscape.

column1: A Hound at the Hem has been framed as a call-back to Serge Gainsbourg and Jean-Claude Vannier's 1971 masterpiece Histoire de Melody Nelson
column2: which is a loose but orchestral concept record inspired by Vladmir Nabokov’s Lolita. Turnbull’s adaptation of his source material is distorted and murky
column3: barely articulating notions of ill-advised romance before reflecting them in a funhouse mirror. He adopts different voices
column4: calling and responding with himself
column5: as he utters mostly indecipherable lyrics. Rather than firm intent
column6: he primarily conveys foreboding attitude and an outsider’s cold-as-ice swagger. On ""Clerical Collar""
column7: he sounds like Jim Morrison fronting a production of The Rocky Horror Picture Show
column8: strains of ""L.A. Woman"" seeping through with a creepy choir of low and high voices emerging during every chorus.

column1: A Hound at the Hem is a twilight zone of madness and provocation. As the album unfolds
column2: Slim Twig rarely ever sounds like the same guy
column3: each song (hell
column4: each verse) presenting multiple personalities and tones of expression. Its hard-psych is ugly
column5: alluring carnival music that warps and melts before us just as we begin to trust it. Through it all though
column6:
there’s an undercurrent of humor and fun; Turnbull’s active imagination stretches out for miles and he comes across as a twisted visionary on his most accomplished album yet.

"|19979.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19979-slim-twig-a-hound-at-the-hem/|7.7|Vish Khanna

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21187/homepage_large.b02cb19b.jpg|Pom Pom|3447.0|Ariel Pink|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2014-11-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:16.414320|"

Before Paris Hilton and Kim Kardashian assumed fame as a feudal right
column2: Angelyne cruised Los Angeles in her flamingo pink Corvette. License plate: ANGELNN. If her teased platinum wig or volleyball breasts led you to mistake her for a pornographic Dolly Parton
column3: her true identity could be confirmed by the ubiquitous advertisements for herself that she purchased on billboards and bus shelters. Even though practically no one could tell you what she did or had done
column4: she became an '80s Southern California fixture as iconic and purely ornamental as the palm trees—the sunshine daydream to Elvira’s ghoulish noir.  The tragedy is that she peaked before Bravo. Without a reality show to channel the day-to-day eccentricities of Angelyne and her candy-dyed Maltese
column5: the O.G. avatar of ""famous for being famous"" had to settle for a bit part in Earth Girls Are Easy
column6: a brief gubernatorial run
column7: and a self-released album on her Pink Kitten imprint.

column1: In a city where Mr. Incredible brawls with Batgirl while Chewbacca and Freddy Krueger vainly break it up
column2: Angelyne naturally still finds work in the meet-n-greet racket. Her most recent appearance was yesterday at Origami Records in Echo Park
column3: as part of Ariel Pink’s ""Tantalising [sic] Tinsel-Town Take Over."" Should you have missed the mass email
column4: the promotional docket for Ariel Pink’s latest schlock-opus Pom Pom included ""Delicious Donuts and Delectable Ditties""; ""Pretty in Pink. Permanently"" (where ""L.A.’s top manicure artists"" did nails in only pink); and the ""Luxuriously 'L.A.' Limo Listening Luau"". The latter offered a ""ride in style"" to ""enjoy L.A.'s finest sites"" in a ""pink stretch job."" RSVP did not guarantee entrance.

column1: It’s usually over-simplistic to extrapolate from a marketing scheme
column2: but in Ariel Pink as with Angelyne
column3: the medium is the message. The campy flair
column4: smirking irony
column5: and deliberately ""retrolicious"" alliteration matches the scarecrow-genius of his new album
column6: Pom Pom. By wheeling out the inflatable mummy of Angelyne
column7: the former Ariel Rosenberg wryly casts himself as her timeless prom date in the Hollywood Babylon of conniving prophets
column8: sexualized excess
column9: and sterling self-mythologizers.

column1: A decade ago
column2: Pink crept out of his rented room in an ashram off Crenshaw with reels of spindly
column3: self-destructing love songs. Issued on Animal Collective’s Paw Tracks imprint
column4: The Doldrums (and later Worn Copy) inspired chillwave and a lo-fi revival
column5: as well as altering the perception of L.A. as an indie-rock backwater. Pink was the sunshine and noir dialect rolled into one
column6: writing gorgeous heat-warped AM pop made to soundtrack driving off of a cliff on Mulholland or save an animal from drowning in a shimmering David Hockney swimming pool.

column1: The intervening years have seen him transform from wraith to wolf. The romantic cult hero fantasies have given way to headlines that he’s the ""most hated man in indie rock."" The analog necessity of his early work has been replaced by studio sheen
column2: alienating those inclined towards the cassette hiss and rawness of his first wave. Pink’s compared social media vilification to the Rwandan genocide
column3: dated porn stars
column4: called Grimes ""stupid and retarded"" and scored a werewolf film—inevitably empathizing with the antagonist.

column1: If you hate Ariel Pink
column2: nothing in this review can possibly alter your opinion. You’ll scour the record for misogyny
column3: say it’s too long
column4: and roll your eyes at the helium disco-grooves about getting white freckles at the tanning salon and the amphetamine jingles for Jell-O. You think he’s funny or you don’t. If you do
column5: the best engagement is one of suspended disbelief. After all
column6: the CalArts alumnus remains the stylistic next-of-kin to Frank Zappa: satirical
column7: divisive
column8: and more interested in terraforming genres than neatly deconstructing them.

column1: But for all the arch humor and affectation
column2: Pink writes some of most wistful and peculiarly moving songs in contemporary music. ""Put Your Number in My Phone"" feels like David Crosby covering 2Pac’s ""What’z Ya Phone #"". Despite the '60s Sunset Strip jangle
column3: the terrain shifts to the Eastside
column4: a Silver Lake taco truck where Pink sweetly begs for the chance to get to know a girl better
column5: before promptly blowing her off—which we hear in uncomfortably Drake-ian Voicemail detail. It’s the paradox at the heart of the collection and what ultimately makes it so compelling. Beyond catchy melodies
column6: there’s a constant agitation between Pink’s moonlit dreams and everyday pessimism. He wants to be the romantic lover of fiction
column7: but turns out to be just another undependable disappointment—but at least he admits it.

column1: There’s ""Sexual Athletics""
column2: where the sleazoid of the first half makes preposterous pull-your-dick-out boasts about being the ""Sex King on a velvet swing/ Waiting for my Alice in Wonderland."" The coda descends into lo-fi clatter and a tender
column3: Four Seasons-falsetto about his life-long desire for a girlfriend. The ironic shell is always there
column4: lest you get too close to treating the songs like journal entries
column5: but the emotions remain conflicted and unconcealed.

column1: If 2012’s Mature Themes found him recovering from a break-up by concocting Kinski Assassin Who Shagged Me daydreams during hungover wanderings to the Highland Park Wienerschnitzel
column2: Pom Pom is Pink on the prowl—with its attendant sexploits and screwups. Sometimes
column3: the tales are in villainous character. ""Four Shadows"" recasts Station to Station-era David Bowie as a comically morbid goth. ""Black Ballerina"" chronicles the night that ""One-Eyed Willie"" took ""Shotgun Billy"" to L.A.’s finest strip club for his first (short-lived) exotic dance experience. ""Lipstick"" concerns a predatory pick-up artist flashing his teeth and threatening to suck a girl into his darkness. There are new wave synthesizers
column4: demands to be showered in blood
column5: and Pink’s best ""Hey Little Girl"" baritone. It might be the finest Cure song since ""Friday I’m in Love"".

column1: Other times
column2: there’s no need for subterfuge. The album’s finale
column3: ""Dayzed Inn Daydreams""
column4: refurbishes an old track from Odditties Sodomies Vol. 1 with unnatural poignancy. The goofy voices and bipolar shifts are jettisoned for a straightforward psych-pop song in the vein of Love’s Forever Changes. It’s difficult not to read as a veiled statement of purpose: an anachronism to when his greatest fear was dying young and anonymous
column5: a musical John Kennedy Toole
column6: with hundreds of unheard songs his only hope for posthumous recognition.

column1: The rest of the songs comprise crooked detours through Pink’s hometown. Fellow passengers include: Kim Fowley
column2: the immemorial L.A. gadfly who played ""hypophone"" on <i>Freak Out!
column3: co-wrote with Warren Zevon
column4: and managed the Runaways; Don Bolles
column5: the drummer from the Germs; novelist Alex Kazemi (""Not Enough Violence"")
column6: and producer/writer Justin Raisen (Charli XCX
column7: Sky Ferreira).

column1: But the zigzags and bizarre pit stops are clearly at Pink’s behest. Opening track ""Plastic Raincoats in the Pig Parade"" finds him hallucinating cocaine banks
column2: Tokyo nights
column3: and Arkansas moons over what sounds like psychedelic Ringling Bros. polka. ""Dinosaur Carebears"" riffs on Syrian wedding music
column4: shifts to a Tweedledum and Tweedledee melody
column5: and then finds Pink role-calling random L.A. neighborhoods: Tarzana
column6: Reseda
column7: the City of Industry
column8: Beverly Hiiiiiiilllls. Finally
column9: the groove switches to a cosmic space dub.

column1: This is no haven for conventional logic or normative restraint. ""Negativ Ed"" is pure Zappa homage
column2: a gym class anthem for delinquent rebels in an '80s B-movie. It’s ridiculous and superfluous
column3: but also endearingly whimsical. The same goes for ""Nude Beach a Go-Go""
column4: a time warp to the Malibu surf rock of the Frankie Avalon and Annette Funicello era. But unlike the beach blanket bingo wholesomeness of the censored past
column5: Pink reimagines it as the nude mating ritual it probably was.

column1: One of Pink’s strongest gifts is making the absurd seem real and the real seem absurd. If this album has a closest predecessor in his catalog
column2: it might be Worn Copy
column3: with its weary refrain that ""life in L.A. is so lonely."" His coping strategy remains a rich fantasy life
column4: of which he’s occasionally the star and sometimes the sardonic observer. You can see it on ""Picture Me Gone""
column5: a haunting meditation about how digital technology will erase all physical evidence of our pasts. Set in the near future
column6: the narrator’s age keeps changing. Even at his most sincere
column7: there is something protean and shifty. Or as Pink seemingly indicts himself on ""One Summer Night"": ""Fantasies and fallacies/ All fairy tales and lies/ Time is running out yeah/ Better write these lines."" Or maybe you prefer ""Exile on Frog Street""
column8: in which Pink does his best karaoke of Jim Morrison circa ""Celebration of the Lizard"". The song concerns an ""enchanted frog... waiting for his Princess Charming to come and kiss him on his frog lips."" When the kiss finally comes
column9: the toad turns into Ariel Pink. You hear the fairy tale magic twinkle of a Disney soundtrack. Then you hear a frog’s ribbit.

column1: You can interpret this as another surreal metaphor in his search for enchanted love or chalk it up to a teenaged fixation with the Doors. Maybe a little of both. He can be the frog prince
column2: Shotgun Billy
column3: or ride shotgun in a pink corvette. He can be a rock'n'roller named Ariel from Beverly Hills
column4: complete with his own billboards. And in a place where delusion
column5: self-reinvention
column6: and wish fulfillment have long been the principal cash crop
column7:
who are we to tell him otherwise?

"|19936.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19936-ariel-pink-pom-pom/|8.8|Jeff Weiss

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/21151/homepage_large.c7ee91a3.jpg|The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 OST|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Republic'
column2:
'Mercury']|2014-11-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:16.897930|"

There are few safe choices on Mockingjay
column3: one of the most thrilling soundtracks for a blockbuster film series in recent memory. Much of the record is outfitted with an electronic throb that wouldn’t sound out of place in the clubs of District 1 (the Rich Kids of Instagram in the Hunger Games universe). And
column4: yet
column5: many tracks soar beyond the reasonable expectation of a film soundtrack that would’ve been snapped up by thousands of teenagers even if it were just 81 minutes of off-pitch Mockingjay whistles.

column1: Lorde
column2: who’s gone from complete unknown to holding the reins of one of the world’s biggest movie franchises in just 18 months
column3: has assembled a stable of rising stars like Tinashe
column4: hyper-relevant indie-friendly sensations like Charli XCX and Chvrches
column5: Raury
column6: and more. Tracks like Chvrches' kinetic call-to-arms ""Dead Air"" and Raury's meditative ""Lost Souls"" would have been standouts on their respective debuts. They’re standouts here. There are the emotional highs and stripped-down ballads you might expect to color moods of a specific scene
column7: but the whole record crackles with electricity: Those ballads are just as striking as the more pounding cuts like the opener ""Meltdown"" (Stromae ft. Lorde
column8: Pusha T
column9: Q-Tip and Haim) and Ariana Grande's sky-scraping collaboration with Major Lazer
column10: ""All My Love"".

column1: Charli XCX connects with Simon Le Bon for the lovely piano ballad ""Kingdom""
column2: an effortlessly composed song co-written with Vampire Weekend's Rostam Batmanglij after the two got drunk at a Miley Cyrus concert. Lorde's cover of Bright Eyes' ""Ladder Song"" is straightforward
column3: but sweet. Bat for Lashes' contribution
column4: a cover of Son Lux's ""Plan the Escape""
column5: is a twinkling snowglobe of a song that will almost certainly score a tense moment of Katniss introspection as she mulls over the two hollow clods after her heart (team #SingleKatniss).

column1: After the rustic rock-leaning OST of the first movie
column2: which featured contributions from Arcade Fire
column3: the Decemberists
column4: and Neko Case
column5: the series leans toward electronic pop. Following in the veins of Catching Fire’s OST
column6: Mockingjay moves with the action of a series that began in a hermetically sealed environment before transitioning to a city where every battle has larger implications. Across the board
column7: the songs sound like threads of hope escaping gloomier pasts
column8: echoing the arc of the film's generational heroine. It's no coincidence that
column9: of the 14 songs featured on Mockingjay
column10: 11 feature female vocalists in the foreground. Sure
column11: the lyrical sentiments are often delivered as platitudes—""We’re just a mess of broken people but we love the game!
column12: and so forth—but that's part of the deal when you're working with some populist YA lit poking around well-established archetypes. It’s a big
column13: broad tent for everyone to get lost in.

column1: Though lots of distinctive voices are represented on the soundtrack
column2: one person stands out. ""Katniss would be a huge Lorde fan
column3: series star Jennifer Lawrence voiced during the promotional rollout
column4: directly making the connection that the strong
column5: independent Katniss character is an effective muse to the world's most famous teenager. While Lorde's vocals are all over Mockingjay—from the swirling centerpiece ""Yellow Flicker Beat"" (and its Yeezus-tinted Kanye West rework) to supplementary vocals on ""Meltdown"" and a hook to the Miguel/Chemical Brothers collaboration ""This Is Not a Game""—her presence elevates the project; you can feel the other stars on the soundtrack bringing their A-game out of respect for the project's core vision and passion. Though not everything works on its own (the flat electropop of XO's ""Animal"" is one dud) Mockingjay adds up to a fun pastiche of modern sounds. In conclusion
column6:
three fingers out of five.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21264/homepage_large.81b83617.jpg|Flesh and Machine|2577.0|Daniel Lanois|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anti-']|2014-11-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:17.477233|"

A blast of frantic noise
column2: ""The End"" is not the closer but the second song on Daniel Lanois’ new album
column3: Flesh & Machine. Scribbles of distressed electric guitar and waves of distortion grate against scratchily arrhythmic drums
column4: creating a sustained explosion of sound uninterrupted by lyrics or melody. It’s all static and tension
column5: with no release until it fades into the more percussive ""Sioux Lookout"". Listening to ""The End""
column6: it’s almost impossible not to be reminded of Lanois’ motorcycle crash four years ago
column7: when he lost control of his bike in Los Angeles and ended up in the hospital with multiple broken bones. The song conveys the same sense of slowed time that most of us experience during an accident
column8: a hyperawareness that allows you to take in every small detail. Such associations emphasize the song’s queasy friction: guitar strings against drum heads
column9: bone against asphalt
column10: flesh against machine.

column1: A deft guitarist who gravitates toward the liquid sound of the pedal steel
column2: Lanois plays the studio like it’s just one more instrument
column3: which would be a cliché if he didn’t take the studio on the road with him and produce each show like it’s a new record. More than 30 years after getting his first credits—one of which was a Raffi album
column4: no less—he has become one of the most recognizable names in the control room
column5: collaborating closely with Brian Eno and twiddling knobs for Neil Young’s Le Noise
column6: Bob Dylan’s Time Out of Mind
column7: Emmylou Harris’ Wrecking Ball
column8: Willie Nelson’s Teatro
column9: and nearly half of U2’s catalog (although not their most recent catastrophe). But Lanois is less well known as a solo artist
column10: partly because one album per decade isn’t exactly prolific and partly because he has never settled on one particular sound or approach. Instead
column11: he toggles between singer-songwriter fare (like 2003’s Shine) and blurry
column12: concept-driven soundscapes (2005’s Belladonna).

column1: Fortunately
column2: Flesh & Machine is purely instrumental
column3: with no lyrics to structure it too rigidly and no concept to hem Lanois. There’s an intriguing sense of entropy to these songs; rather than pristine
column4: everything sounds weathered and worn. Like a robot detaching its limbs
column5: ""Tamboura Jah"" actively disassembles itself as you listen
column6: cut-and-pasting its constituent parts into new patterns. The mere act of holding together
column7: though
column8: gives the song its self-propulsion
column9: as the cymbals and guitars reverberate against each other in unexpected ways. Of course Flesh & Machine is going to sound great
column10: with each instrument calibrated either to pull you into Lanois’ sonic world or to shake you up once you get there.

column1: Lanois creates some lovely sounds and moods on Flesh & Machine
column2: but what really sets it apart from his other work is how he sets them against each other. The disembodied vocals on opener ""Rocco"" are pitched high to sound inhuman
column3: lulling you a bit before the jarring conflagration of ""The End"". The album starts strong but picks up considerably on the second side
column4: pitting the ethereal piano of ""Iceland"" with the raking-light nostalgia of ""My First Love""
column5: which sounds like it’s stuck halfway between an old Floyd Cramer instrumental and the new Twin Peaks reboot. With its descending piano theme and bossa nova underpinning
column6: it’s exactly the kind of song that would be on the jukebox at the Double R.

column1: Flesh & Machine reaches its climax on ""Aquatic""
column2: with its lurid pedal steel gliding like a shark around a reef. Lanois amplifies and exaggerates that lead instrument
column3: not only lending it a supreme fluidity but also distorting its tone
column4: like a microphone held too close to the mouth or an eye pressed right up to the TV screen. Yet
column5: the effect is somehow delicate rather than noisy. It might seem like faint praise to call Flesh & Machine Lanois’ best and most realized solo album
column6: but it’s also one of the best ambient records of 2014—an endlessly inventive collection of songs built on odd
column7: often lurid sounds and textures
column8:
somehow rough and gentle at the same time.

"|20007.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20007-daniel-lanois-flesh-and-machine/|7.7|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21266/homepage_large.bff8f0a2.jpg|Ypres|4245.0|Tindersticks|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['City Slang']|2014-11-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:17.946540|"

Ypres is an album that suspends sound in a state of perpetual motion
column2: never finding a natural start or end point. It was designed that way—in the notes accompanying its release
column3: Tindersticks point out how it’s intended to loop all day without ever finding a place of rest. The record is unique in the band’s canon
column4: although it sometimes brushes close to their soundtrack work for French director Claire Denis. Ypres is a commissioned piece
column5: from the In Flanders Fields World War One museum in Ypres
column6: Belgium
column7: composed to accompany visitors as they make their way through the institution. The mood is suitably somber and inward facing
column8: with moments of beauty and light scattered throughout. It’s largely the work of two members of Tindersticks
column9: Stuart A. Staples and Dan McKinna
column10: with help from longterm collaborator Lucy Wilkins
column11: who presided over the dense orchestral recordings that give the album its sizeable weight.

column1: Tindersticks possess the enviable ability to work in big and small spaces
column2: combining barely-there minimalist compositions with full-blown orchestral works. Ypres slots into the former category
column3: with silence acting as a key constituent in its makeup. The muted tone creates an air of reverence
column4: of silent contemplation. ""Gueules cassées""—a title that translates as ""broken faces
column5: in reference to injury ravaged combat veterans—contains barely any instrumentation at all
column6: other than a solitary wind instrument faintly circling in time. It’s easy to imagine such work providing a perfectly unobtrusive accompaniment to a museum visit
column7: but it works as a standalone piece as well
column8: largely due to the depth and refinement sunk into it. On the fullest track here
column9: ""Sunset Glow""
column10: the lack of complexity allows for notes to stretch out expansively
column11: with the string section interlocking in a way that’s positively hypnotic.

column1: Learning of the history of Ypres
column2: which was virtually destroyed during the Great War
column3: with rebuilding only recently finished
column4: provides clues as to the mindset at work when these pieces were composed. But
column5: shorn of its context
column6: it becomes the type of material that’s easy to impinge other thoughts and feelings on. Notes seem to stretch on for days in the 20-minute-long ""The Third Battle of Ypres""
column7: opening up a framework to cloak an existential crisis in
column8: if you feel so inclined. It’s a powerful
column9: masterfully repetitive piece
column10: containing great sways and sighs of purposefully deadened sound. Sometimes ""Battle"" even feels like it's heading somewhere
column11: gaining form and structure
column12: only for Staples and his cohorts to pull back from the brink
column13: retreating into the haltingly rotating figures that make up the rest of the album. It’s an interesting moment
column14: resembling the more familiar front of this band taking over for a minute or two
column15: before they check where they are and sink back into the solemnity.

column1: A touchstone for Ypres is the soundtrack work Popol Vuh produced for Werner Herzog’s films
column2: not least because of the way these tracks simply appear then vanish without development. But there’s also a similarity in the way the pallid atmosphere is entwined with moments of grace and beauty. On ""Whispering Guns
column3: Parts 1
column4: 2 and 3""
column5: a death-ship bell clangs throughout
column6: scattered drums resemble artillery fire
column7: and strings tenderly see-saw over the top—all combining to create an atmosphere somewhere between unease and elegance. The tools for getting there may be different
column8: but that’s a familiar place to be for this band. One key difference
column9: though
column10: is in Tindersticks’ fondness for taking small moments and blowing them up big. Here
column11: they turn that method inside out
column12: starting with a huge
column13: globe changing event and working something humble around it
column14:
making it feel like they’re respectfully cowering in its shadow.

"|20009.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20009-tindersticks-ypres/|6.8|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21028/homepage_large.e00d325c.jpg|Soft|30712.0|Dan Bodan|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['DFA']|2014-11-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:18.546056|"

Dan Bodan’s music is driven by the conflict between his gorgeous
column2: traditionally pleasant voice—a voice he likes to use to bring himself uncomfortably close to his audience—and the production he sings over
column3: modern electronic tapestries that can veer from sentimental to corrosive at a moment’s notice. A Berlin resident who grew up in the Canadian heartland and was forged as an artist in the crucible of the Montreal music scene
column4: Bodan has a set of pipes more suited to adult contemporary radio than a spot on venerable NYC label DFA; with his rich
column5: resonant tone and particular phrasing
column6: he's a little reminiscent of Marc Anthony. But given the sphere in which Bodan is working
column7: more apt comparisons are the work Tom Krell's doing as How to Dress Well
column8: or perhaps the unvarnished and raw indie-pop of Sean Nicholas Savage. Like these artists
column9: Bodan is unafraid to enter sentimental terrain in the pursuit of something radiant and real
column10: and he does so again and again on his debut full-length
column11: Soft.

column1: There’s an impressive diversity to the sound of the album. Covers of jazz standards butt up against drum and bass tracks. Bodan will summon the chintzy spirit of Destroyer’s Your Blues with a track like dewy opener ""A Soft Opening""
column2: only to pivot into amorphous
column3: cracked soul on highlight ""Anonymous"". All of these detours are linked by that powerful voice
column4: which he pushes to the edge of its capability in several different ways throughout the record. On ""Soft as Rain""
column5: he tests its range and agility over warm
column6: rounded synth tones; one song later
column7: on ""For Heaven’s Sake (Let’s Fall in Love) <3""
column8: he takes a song famously rendered by Billie Holiday and performs it with a palpable
column9: unnerving desperation. In his hands
column10: love is a life raft
column11: a dangerous narcotic
column12: a portrait of a partner fractured and faded; by the end of the song
column13: he’s pushing himself in and out of tune and dancing around the beat
column14: as if he’s on the edge of our world. It’s an entrancing
column15: indelible performance
column16: the best of what Bodan has to offer.

column1: Bodan’s approach to vocals—the way he searches out boundaries and then pushes at them—is mirrored in his lyrics
column2: an important part of his cultivation of intimacy on Soft. The album is awash in sensuality
column3: from fraught love stories in miniature like ""Romeo"" and ""Rusty"" to the set of songs revolving around the titular concept of ""softness."" Bodan is fond of imagery that takes physical acts and tempers them
column4: granting them a sort of gentleness—a good example can be found on ""Soft as Rain""
column5: where close contact is reduced to ""You fall on me/ Soft as rain""—and numbers
column6: whether it's seven wasted years (""Soft as Rain""
column7: again) or $50 worth of cheap cologne (""Anonymous""). This dual focus works to give Soft both personality and specificity; it makes the album feel like a true document of Bodan's life and love in recent years. All that said
column8: when the ways Bodan tries to eliminate distance come together—the voice
column9: the lyrics
column10: the rawness of the emotion on display—the final product can induce claustrophobia. The effect is undeniably powerful
column11: but there's a fine line between powerful and overwhelming
column12:
and his work should grow more potent as he manages to find a balance between the two.

"|19992.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19992-dan-bodan-soft/|6.2|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/21270/homepage_large.261e8685.jpg|Seeds|4313.0|TV on the Radio|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Harvest']|2014-11-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:19.121216|"

The cheap Williamsburg loft that Tunde Adebimpe and Dave Sitek rented with day-job paychecks while making their first 4-track recordings is now an expensive condo with a wine shop built into it. TV on the Radio
column2: the band that formed there with help from friends in other nearby noisy bands—the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Liars—make music that sounds a lot more expensive more than a decade later
column3: but have otherwise moved more toward accessibility than away from it. That’s how music works differently from the market for the real estate where it’s made: while Brooklyn’s been gentrified into the walled-off backdrop for Lena Dunham’s mumblecore Marlo Thomas performance
column4: infinitely more people will have access to TV on the Radio’s fifth album Seeds than the band’s 2004 Touch & Go debut
column5: exactly because more money has been invested into it. Thankfully
column6: for longtime fans and new listeners alike
column7: though the music might sound pricier than ever
column8: the basic architecture hasn’t really changed at all.

column1: Opening song ""Quartz"" demonstrates that from a production standpoint
column2: the group hasn’t lost its unique ability to conjure a surreal
column3: soulful dread. Everything starts in medias res
column4: as if we’ve been dropped into the middle of a séance in the desert. The handclaps
column5: moaning vocals
column6: and what sounds like a South Asian percussion instrument (it’s actually a loop of Sitek dropping a drumstick onto piano strings) sound like a glossier version of ""Satellite"" and ""Staring at the Sun"" from 2003’s Young Liars EP
column7: Sitek and Adebimpe still merging lessons drawn from the European-derived NYC avant-garde and centuries of African-American church music. When Adebimpe’s powerhouse vocal comes in
column8: it’s instantly familiar
column9: both as a reminder of the absolute best that the shrunken state of post-millennial rock can produce and the fact that that voice—that voice—can still turn even the most interpersonal utterances into sentiments of galactic force.

column1: Even though it’s meant to signify moving on from a romantic relationship
column2: when Adebimpe keeps rolling out the phrase ""but I should really give it up sometime"" it’s hard not to remember that the past several years for TV on the Radio—as they came down from the impossible peak of Return to Cookie Mountain—have been marked by different forms of loss. Most crucially
column3: longtime bassist Gerard Smith passed away from cancer days after Nine Types of Light was released—a huge blow for a tight-knit band. The group also broke from its label Interscope
column4: which pushed Mountain in front of the largest possible audience (this is its first album on legendary '70s prog-rock haven Harvest). Light also marked the point where TV on the Radio more or less stopped incorporating explicit politics in their lyrics—observational and ironic message tracks like ""Caffeinated Consciousness"" and ""No Future Shock"" (""do the ‘no future’"") felt like an extended ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ after the gospel-powered hopefulness of 2008’s ""Golden Age""
column5: which for more than a few of us was the unofficial theme song of the sadly brief window of hope and change following Obama’s inauguration.

column1: So while TV on the Radio peaked from 2006 to 2008
column2: the last two albums feel less like an artistic decline and more like a shift in focus and a lowering of stakes. The lead single from Seeds
column3: accompanied by a video of Paul Reubens doing a Speed Racer knockoff
column4: was ""Happy Idiot""
column5: another song superficially about getting over a relationship that can easily double as an strategy for negotiating an existence over which one’s lost all control. Like much of Seeds as well as its predecessor
column6: ""Idiot"" embraces rhythms derived from the electronic end of the dance music spectrum
column7: and does so as easily as they incorporated John Zorn skronk and Prince synth funk in the past. Like their best songs
column8: ""Idiot"" works because it balances simple catchiness with urgency and anxiety
column9: like their post-punk forebears taught them: the piston-pumping rhythm section is counterposed against Adebimpe’s tenor
column10: which floats in a dazed murmur for the vocals and upshifts to nervous falsetto for the chorus. This is a Sitek production
column11: of course
column12: and underneath the lustrous exterior he layers a subtle
column13: high-pitched synth drone (a cousin to the menacing washes of distorted guitar that distinguished the band’s early music)
column14: which gives the song a sense of creeping dread nearly at an unconscious level.

column1: After Cookie Mountain
column2: as with the followups to so many great records on which a restless band seeks to conquer new territory
column3: Sitek started cleaning up the band’s sound
column4: doing away with its trademark siren-like clamor after falling for the pristine production of ""Eyes Without a Face"" (listen to that song again and then come back to Light and Seeds. You’ll hear them differently). What’s quietly happened since then is that TV on the Radio have shed the Best Band in the World expectations and simply become a really good anthemic rock band. Check the segue from the neon sizzle of the Gary Numan/Depeche Mode burner ""Careful You"" into the open-hearted jangle boogie of ""Could You""
column5: which achieves the ultra-rare feat of writing a '90s Sugar chorus as good as the ones Bob Mould came up with
column6: or the perfectly-executed Ramones bop that introduces late-album track ""Lazerray"". It sounds simple
column7: but shockingly few bands at TV on the Radio's level are able to do it without sounding corny. So while they've long segued from fin-de-siecle Brooklyn to edge-of-the-continent Silver Lake
column8: losing more than they’ve gained along the way
column9:
TV on the Radio are still capable of conquering big stages and broad sonic territory with the kind of precision and power for which their increasingly desperate older contemporaries need to rely on expensive stunts.

"|20013.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20013-tv-on-the-radio-seeds/|7.2|Eric Harvey

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/21269/homepage_large.77adb65f.jpg|Black Metal|30837.0|Dean Blunt|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2014-11-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:19.722347|"

Though he's said that he doesn't set out to make ""difficult"" music
column2: Dean Blunt certainly hasn't made much easy over the course of his career. Both as one-half of the shadowy duo Hype Williams and under his own name
column3: the London-based art-pop provocateur has spent the better part of the last half decade turning out dense keyboard drones
column4: giving intentionally obtuse and combative interviews
column5: and putting on bizarre performance art live shows. But with his latest full-length
column6: it seems he's finally decided to open up
column7: to highlight a love for pop music that's always been somewhere underneath the found sound samples and sub-bass firebombs.

column1: The material Blunt has released since he cut ties with Hype Williams collaborator Inga Copeland has hewed closer toward pop song structures. And it's clear even from the opening strains of album opener ""Lush""—a straightforward sample of Big Star's sunny-eyed strummer ""For You""—that Black Metal is a whole lot more welcoming than past records have been. Blunt pairs Big Star's orchestral sweep with a slowly plodding rhythm section
column2: his own deadpan vocals
column3: and some lazily picked electric guitar parts that wouldn't sound out of place on a Kurt Vile record. ""Molly & Aquafina""'s narcotized Americana and ""100""
column4: which employs a sample of the Pastels' ""Over Your Shoulder""
column5: similarly value clarity and directness
column6: two qualities absent from much of his preceding work.

column1: Even as he jumps from those indie pop touchstones to the genre exercises on the record's second side—the imploded dub of ""Punk""
column2: ""Hush"" and ""Grade""'s dizzy rap deconstructions
column3: the pair of occasionally frigid ambient tracks that make up a 20-minute block at the record's middle—Blunt is able to keep their knotty worlds relatively accessible. Pinned together by a series of keyboard drones
column4: ""Forever"" and ""X"" both employ distant vocalizations from recurring collaborator Joanne Robertson as an easy point of entry amidst their occasionally abstract spheres. These are light moments
column5: airy passages function mostly to separate the lilting first half of the record from the bleak second. But where Blunt would have once used lengthy drone passages to project alienation
column6: here they function as a seam between the two otherwise disjointed album segments.

column1: All of Blunt's work to date—if you're willing to consider his bizarre public character as part of that work—has been wrapped up in questions of identity. He's constantly concealing personal details and controlling the discourse about him to an apparently paranoid degree
column2: and his sonic persona
column3: shaped by distinctly gnarled postmodern experimentation
column4: is as hard to pin down as his image. So what does it mean that for those questions now that he's appearing on the covers of glossy magazines and making pop songs? He's at once a folk pop troubadour and a downcast dub vocalist—a staid ambient composer and a gruff grime MC. He's everything all at once
column5: or maybe he's not much of anything at all. As with everything he does
column6: Black Metal offers few definitive answers
column7:
but this time around the hazy images he's projecting have come into sharper focus.

"|20012.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20012-dean-blunt-black-metal/|7.3|Colin Joyce

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/21253/homepage_large.a5a2b5f7.jpg|BLUE|28647.0|iamamiwhoami|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['To whom it may concern.']|2014-11-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:17:20.273497|"

On her first two albums as iamamiwhoami
column3: Jonna Lee explored surreal universes populated by blinking trees
column4: psychic mannequins
column5: and tall
column6: faceless monsters furred from head to toe. Her audiovisual works bounty and kin each house a subtle narrative that's more concerned with the movement of figures through space than concrete dramas in the traditional sense. bounty followed Lee through a series of textural transformations as she clawed through the world around her apparently in search of someone tall
column7: bearded
column8: and naked who's stranded in the Scandinavian countryside. kin saw her pass through different environments by enormous sentient shag rugs. Neither album resolved itself cleanly
column9: but both fostered rich tension in music and visuals alike. Her best songs feel like they'd come for your body parts the second you divert your attention from them; thick and mysterious
column10: they resist the usual half-life of boredom that affects songs designed for short-term radio play. Like the Knife
column11: iamamiwhoami threads ghosts through what you thought you knew about the pop song.

column1: Or she did. Compared to kin and bounty's viscerally unnerving shorts
column2: BLUE's visuals play out like screensavers. Lee dances in beautiful scenery. Lee fits messages into bottles and casts them out to sea
column3: attempting to communicate with figures in black morphsuits who don't carry nearly the visual weight of her bizarrely disfigured companions from the first two records. The images are lovely but tedious
column4: and the music follows suit.

column1: BLUE's audio component flows on synths that gleam like the ice Lee fondles in its videos
column2: glassy and pale. ""Hunting for Pearls"" ripples with arpeggios that make it sound more uptempo than it actually is
column3: while the bristling bass on ""Tap Your Glass"" sounds like it could have been scraped off Shaking the Habitual's cutting room floor. At points the album echoes Madonna's Ray of Light
column4: but Lee doesn't quite have the gravitas to pull off these round
column5: easy melodies. She's a songwriter that thrives on danger; BLUE encloses her in a space where she's far too safe.

column1: ""Thin"" is the closest iamamiwhoami gets to its old mischief
column2: setting Lee's voice close in the ear over faraway percussion. It's riddled with the same neon arpeggios that take up space everywhere else on the record
column3: but it at least leaves some shadows for Lee to get lost in. It shifts its course halfway through
column4: moving seamlessly from slow stalker to towering ballad. But it's a rare moment of intrigue on an album that's generous in its beauty while leaving little to wonder about
column5:
a sky that never rains.

"|19996.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19996-iamamiwhoami-blue/|6.1|Sasha Geffen
